title: Reckonings; Blessed Are the Weak
description: Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill recently gave an interview in which he dismissed claims that the dollar was overvalued, arguing that concerns about our trade deficit are based on ''trivial and wrong notions.'' He also thinks that concepts like gross domestic product are obsolete. I took his remarks as an indication that the dollar's inevitable decline will probably come sooner rather than later. And while that will be embarrassing for Mr. O'Neill, it will be a good thing for our economy.

title: From the Ocean To Your Salad Bowl
description: YOU could consider a seaweed salad to be an ocean-based mesclun -- simply a combination of greens with a distinctive sesame-flavored dressing. While it is a standard dish at Japanese and Korean restaurants, few people make it at home. And that's a shame.

title: Two Camps At W.T.O. Said to Be A Bit Closer
description: Eager to avoid repeating its humiliating failure in Seattle in 1999, the World Trade Organization moved today to rescue foundering negotiations on a new global round of trade talks by offering concessions to developing-country members.

title: At Least 60 Die as Landslides Ravage an Indonesian Island
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 1  Huge floods and landslides poured down mountainsides early this morning on a remote Indonesian island, sweeping away entire villages and causing at least 60 deaths, local officials said.

title: To Help Make It Through the Day, Schedule Minivacations as Needed
description: EVERY hour or two -- more often, I admit, when the writing is not going particularly well -- I pause and take a vacation of sorts. My current favorite ''destination'' is Minesweeper, the computer game. After a few minutes I return to the real world, refreshed and ready to work, at least for a little while.

title: Argentina's Bid to Save Itself
description: Argentina took an important symbolic step on Monday in its struggle to avoid financial collapse. The country's Senate passed a law committing itself to a balanced budget, paving the way for wage cuts for public employees and tax increases. Whether the provinces will follow the federal government's orders of fiscal prudence remains to be seen. But in the meantime, leaders of the world's economic powers should help Argentina by speeding up aid and expressing confidence in its latest efforts.

title: Management: Vigilance In the Face Of Layoff Rage; Employer Miscues Can Breed Retaliation
description: Juval Aviv, a private investigator in New York, had lunch in April with a man he suspected of sabotaging one of his client's computer systems, causing up to $20 million in damage and indefinitely delaying a long-planned public stock offering.

title: Bush Prods Congress to Agree on Acceptable Education Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1  President Bush used an address before the National Urban League today to prod Congress to change the way America educates its children.

title: Avoiding Florida's Mantle
description: Last year, when Florida's sloppy vote-counting became an international scandal, New York election officials must have realized how easily they could have been in the same humiliating position. After all, it took them seven weeks to resolve a single close State Senate race in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLICKMAN, EMILY
description: GLICKMAN-Emily. Age 70, of Cranbury, N.J. passed away Monday, July 30, 2001 at her home. Born in Manhattan, N.Y., she resided in Cranbury since 1983. Mrs. Glickman was an active facilitator with the Child Assault Prevention Program, Middlesex County Chapter. She visited schools and presented programs for the past 15 years. She is survived by her husband Sheldon Glickman of Cranbury, two sons and one daughterin-law Leo Glickman of Brooklyn, N.Y. and Valiant C. and Kathleen M. Glickman of Manhattan, N.Y. and one brother P. W. Valle of Bronx, N.Y. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, August 2nd at 2PM at A. S. Cole Funeral Home 22 North Main St., Cranbury, N.J. Interment will follow in Princeton Memorial Park, Robbinsville, N.J. Relatives and friends may call Wednesday, August 1 from 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Funeral Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEHR, FRANZ G.
description: KEHR-Franz G. Formerly of Forest Hills, New York, on July 31, 2001, beloved husband of Michal, devoted father of Gabriela, Lewy, and Dorit Bollinger, dear brother of the late Edith Werner, loving grandfather of Nicole, Daniela, Eric, and Zoe. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ on Thursday 11:30 A.M.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cingular To Enter Utah Markets
description: Cingular Wireless, the second-largest United States mobile phone company, agreed to buy airwaves in Utah from Leap Wireless International for $140 million to enter two new markets. Cingular, a venture of BellSouth and SBC Communications, will buy 15 megahertz of spectrum, or capacity, in Salt Lake City and in Provo, Utah, the Atlanta-based company said. Leap will retain 15 megahertz of spectrum in each market to continue providing its flat-rate, unlimited local wireless service.

title: A Plan to Ease Principals' Work
description: Assistant principals from School Districts 2 and 19 will study budgeting, data systems and other management topics in a pilot program that will train them as chief operating officers to free principals to focus on academic issues. The 12-month program, which starts next month and will be run by the City University of New York, will involve faculty members from Baruch College's School of Public Affairs and the Schools of Education at Brooklyn and Hunter Colleges. It is financed in part by a $50,000 grant from the Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund. EDITH EVERETT, the former vice chairwoman of the CUNY board of trustees, helped develop the pilot and is assembling an advisory group to evaluate it and expand it to include all New York City school leadership. NICHOLAS MICHELLI, CUNY's dean for teacher education, will direct the project. Karen W. Arenson

title: An Actor and Actress, All Rolled Into One
description: About 10 minutes into the somewhat eccentric performance of ''Pirates of Penzance,'' which is playing through the summer aboard the four-masted barque Peking at the South Street Seaport, the shrill nursemaid Ruth, with red hair and frumpy nightgown, darts on stage and begins tormenting the lead character, Frederic, who is played by Colin Hanlon.

title: Austerity Plan In Argentina Provokes Wide Protests
description: Tens of thousands of unemployed workers, public employees and students blocked scores of major highways and city streets across Argentina today to protest new government spending cuts aimed at averting a default on the foreign debt.

title: A Mideast Partnership Can Still Work
description: Last week we and 50 of our colleagues Palestinian and Israeli political and cultural leaders -- signed a declaration that was published simultaneously in Israeli and Palestinian newspapers. Our declaration did not attempt to solve every aspect of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Rather, at this most tragic and difficult of times in the Middle East, it attempted to state unequivocally those principles on which we believe a solution can be based.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFALOWICZ, BARBARA
description: RAFALOWICZ - Barbara. Our deepest sympathy to Dr. Adam Rafalowicz and his son Peter on the passing of their wife and mother, Barbara. The Maliniak Family

title: Nascar Wants Stewart to Shut Up and Drive
description: A soda-pop machine hunkers in front of the Olympia Dairy and Bakery in Columbus, Ind. Across the front of the machine is a large photo of Tony Stewart, who has become a famous stock car driver for driving hard into the corners and for refusing to veer from controversy.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a movie listing in the Television section on Sunday for the 2000 TV film ''The Railway Children,'' shown that day on Channels 13 and 49, carried an erroneous description. The film is based on E. Nesbit's tale of three children who adopt a tiny trunk railway. (The reference to a suicidal British aristocrat applied to the 1997 film ''Sweet Revenge,'' which was not scheduled.)

title: Corrections
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday misidentified the river in Arles, France. It is the Rhne, not the Rhine.

title: The Real Reality In Reality TV
description: Expectations for summer television were raised to unrealistic heights in the last two years, first by ''Who Wants To Be a Millionaire'' on ABC, then by ''Survivor'' on CBS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, B SMITH, MD.
description: HOPKINS-B Smith, MD. The Dept of Surgery of The Saint Luke'sRoosevelt Hospital Center mourns the passing of B Smith Hopkins, M.D., on July 29, 2001. Dr. Hopkins graduated from Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons in 1975 and completed his general surgery training at Saint Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in 1980. After Fellowship Training in surgical metabolism, he joined the surgical faculty in 1981. He will be remembered as an exacting and caring surgeon, a role model and mentor to the Surgical House Staff, and a highly respected and revered colleague of both the surgical and medical faculty. He was a genuine friend to patients, fellow physicians, hospital staff, and adminstration. His wit, wisdom and good humor will be missed by the entire hospital family. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Alice, and sons, Daniel and Benjamin. George J. Todd, M.D., Chairman Richard A. Marks, M.D., Vice Chairman

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Dell Introduces $699 Server
description: Extending its effort to expand beyond the desktop personal computer market, Dell Computer introduced a new low-priced server intended for use by small businesses or corporate departments. The single-processor PowerEdge 500SC begins at $699. Dell, based in Round Rock, Tex., has seen its server and data storage business account for an increasing portion of revenue as PC sales have declined. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Liberties; One More For the Road
description: Well, I guess Honor and Dignity can take you only so far.

title: G.O.P. Delays Effort to Give Bush Latitude On Free Trade
description: Short of votes to push through President Bush's top trade priority, Republican leaders of the House said today that they would delay until fall the effort to give the president broad authority to negotiate new trade agreements.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Prudential Voting Ends
description: In a small conference room at a hotel in Newark yesterday, 22 of the 11 million policyholders of Prudential Financial, one of the country's largest life insurers, voted on whether the company should reorganize and go public. Voting had been going on through the mail, over the phone and on the Internet for almost three months. And while only a few turned out at the only polling place on the only day when votes could be cast in person, Prudential executives suggested that they were not worried about getting the required minimum of a million votes -- two-thirds of them in favor -- for authorization of the reorganization. Mary Flowers, a spokeswoman for Prudential, said Prudential would not say how many people had voted until an official tally was completed in several days. The approval of New Jersey's banking and insurance commissioner would also be required for the reorganization. If the reorganization takes place, as Prudential executives hope, the policy holders will share $20 billion in accumulated profits. Yet even with that windfall, the reorganization has been controversial. Joseph B. Treaster (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Proposals For I.R.A.
description: The British and Irish governments make public today their non-negotiable final package of proposals aimed at persuading the Irish Republican Army to begin disarming and prevent the collapse of the power-sharing Northern Ireland Assembly set up by the 1998 peace agreement. Protestant politicians say they will not continue to serve alongside Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., without the action on weapons. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Rex T. Barber, Pilot Who Downed Yamamoto, Dies at 84
description: Rex T. Barber, a World War II fighter pilot who was a central figure in the storied 1943 mission that resulted in the death of Adm. Isoroku Yamamoto, the architect of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died on Thursday at his home in Terrebonne, Ore. He was 84.

title: An American Treat Inspired by Sweden
description: A POPULAR Swedish treat might be the ultimate Mallomar, and it is now made in America.

title: G.E. Said to Be Planning Appeal of Honeywell Decision
description: General Electric is planning to appeal the European Commission's decision to block its acquisition of Honeywell International, executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Will the Economy Ever Party Like It's 1999? Don't Count on It.
description: Two debates going on right now are how much more the economy will slow and what the state of growth and corporate earnings will be when the economy recovers.

title: Retooling an Offense Begins With Lawton
description: Internally and publicly, the Mets for months believed the answer to their offensive problems was in their clubhouse. If their players played as they were capable, the Mets reasoned, the team would hit again.

title: Gas Giant In Russia Told to Guard Its Assets
description: The directors of Gazprom, the Russian gas giant, ordered the company's managers today to keep a closer watch on Gazprom's property and to curtail the privileged relationship that Itera, a Florida-based gas trading company, has enjoyed with Gazprom.

title: Problems With E-ZPass on Turnpike Increase
description: The litany of problems that has plagued New Jersey's E-ZPass system grew longer today, with the acknowledgment by state transportation officials that thousands of motorists paid higher tolls than they should have and that a plan to collect millions of dollars in fines from toll cheats is not yet up and running.

title: Details Emerge On a Budget Meant to Hurt
description: New details of the stripped-down budget that leaders in the State Legislature intend to pass later this week began to emerge today, and it was not a pretty picture for most state agencies and nonprofit organizations dependent on state help.

title: An Unenlightened Energy Bill
description: In a rational world, the members of the House of Representatives would disappear on their August vacation this Friday without touching the energy bill that lies before them, then start all over again in September. The bill is a mishmash of four smaller measures written by four separate committees. It runs to 511 pages, which few members have actually digested. It contains some useful suggestions to improve electricity transmission and streamline the distribution of natural gas. It also has modest subsidies for alternative fuels like wind and solar power and modest tax credits for energy-efficient cars and homes. On the whole, however, it is a dismal compendium of tired ideas favoring the coal, oil and gas industries.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Thursday with an article about the elusiveness of peace in the Middle East misstated the number of people killed by a suicide bomber at a Tel Aviv discothèque and misstated the date. The bombing occurred on June 1, not 2, and killed 21, not 18.

title: Health Costs, Under a Microscope
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Austria: Payment In Nazi Case
description: Austria made the first payment of $36 million to former Nazi slaves and forced laborers who worked in the country during World War II. Remittances were made to about 1,200 individuals in some 20 countries, as well as to 9,205 people represented by organizations in Poland, the Czech Republic and Ukraine. The payment came after Judge Shirley Wohl Kram of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York dismissed two lawsuits against Austria last week. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Riots After Election
description: About 100 supporters of a defeated candidate for chief of an isolated Indian reserve in northeastern Quebec went on a rampage after election results were announced, wrecking the tribal council building, damaging a local school, setting cars on fire and stealing liquor from the reserve's convenience store. Thirty officers from the Quebec provincial police and nearby towns had to be called in. Tensions have risen on the Uashat-Maliotenam reserve since two rival Indian bands started accusing each other of mismanaging tribal finances. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Hitchcock Moves In As Keisler Moves On
description: Randy Keisler paced around the Yankees' clubhouse yesterday afternoon, strongly suspecting that he was about to lose his slot in the rotation because of the acquisition of Sterling Hitchcock. But no club official had told him anything directly, and Keisler wandered around sadly, seeming to wait for someone to pull him aside.

title: Francisco da Costa Gomes, 87, General Who Led Portugal
description: Francisco da Costa Gomes, a high-ranking Portuguese military officer whose opposition to his country's fight against liberation movements in its African colonies eventually led to his appointment as president, died yesterday at the military hospital in Lisbon. He was 87.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIELHOLZ, ALLEN
description: SPIELHOLZ-Allen. Of Bronx, NY, on July 31, 2001. Devoted father of Linda Alania Flaster and Wendy Shear. Dear brother of Henry Spielholz. Loving grandfather of Michael, Janel, Greg and Alex. Services ''Wien & Wien'' 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ, Friday 1PM.

title: Red Sox Pick Up Urbina, And the Expos' $1 Million
description: On a deadline day that was dominated, not unexpectedly, by the pursuit of pitchers, the Montreal Expos traded a pitcher and made club history yesterday. In trading Ugueth Urbina, their closer, to the Boston Red Sox for two young pitchers, the Expos also sent along $1 million to defray the remainder of Urbina's salary. Imagine that, the cash-poor Expos giving rather than receiving. And to a far wealthier club no less.

title: Bill Clinton in Harlem
description: To the Editor:

title: Embattled Community Center Loses Fight Against Eviction
description: The Charas/El Bohio Community Center lost its fight to remain in its home of 22 years yesterday, as word came that two appeals courts had refused pleas to stay its eviction. The orders ended a protracted legal struggle that had become emblematic of the boiling tensions over the gentrification of the Lower East Side.

title: Prime Minister Offers to Resign, Sending a Shock Wave Through New Delhi
description: Seemingly exasperated by sniping within his governing alliance, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee suddenly offered to resign today, a move that jolted much of the political establishment to ponder life in a post-Vajpayee India.

title: Architecture Dean's Chair Goes to Museum
description: When he was growing up in New York, GEORGE RANALLI, dean of the school of architecture at City College, often visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Now one of his chairs -- Valentine Chair No. 2 -- is in the Met's permanent collection and in its current show, ''A Century of Design, Part IV: 1975-2000.'' He designed the chair, which looks like a three-dimensional geometric jigsaw puzzle, for the breakfast room of a Westchester house. The room was never built, but the Formica Company fabricated a prototype of the chair and displayed it. When it was shown at a small gallery in New York, three museums bid on it. The choice of the Met was not hard, Mr. Ranalli said: ''For me, the Met was a big deal.'' Karen W. Arenson

title: National Briefing | West: California: Stock Ownership Questioned
description: Gov. Gray Davis's press secretary bought stock in the same energy company as five state consultants who were dismissed last week for possible conflicts of interest. But the press secretary, Steve Maviglio, says he will not resign, as the governor's Republican rival, Secretary of State Bill Jones, has urged. Mr. Maviglio bought 300 shares of stock in the Calpine Corporation, a San Jose power generator, in June. Calpine has received about $13 billion in state contracts to supply electricity. The five consultants were fired because they owned Calpine shares while also helping the state buy electricity from the company. Todd S. Purdum (NYT)

title: Koizumi Sees Election Victory as Mandate
description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi, the most popular leader since World War II and the clear victor in elections last weekend, has taken the victories scored by his Liberal Democratic Party as a mandate to pursue reforms aimed at restoring Japan's economic and social vitality.

title: Verizon Posts a Loss and Cuts 2001 Forecasts
description: Verizon Communications lowered its profit forecast for the year yesterday, citing falling demand for business phone services, and it posted a second-quarter loss as the value of some investments dropped.

title: No Room for Hate
description: To the Editor:

title: Homo Sapiens, Uneasy in the Pristine Sea
description: To the Editor:

title: Two New Deans at Yeshiva University
description: Yeshiva University recently named two undergraduate alumni as deans. DR. CHARLES J. SNOW, an expert in accounting and finance and a former vice president and worldwide director of training for Morgan Stanley, is the new dean of its Sy Syms School of Business. Dr. Snow, who earned his master's and doctoral degrees from the Stern Graduate School of Business at New York University, has been on the Sy Syms faculty since 1993 and won the students' professor of the year award five times.

title: Consumers Splurge but Confidence Wanes
description: American consumers increased their spending in June, especially on expensive items like cars and refrigerators, but their confidence about the economy over the next few months has recently deteriorated, raising questions about whether such spending can continue at its current pace.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lord Archer's Move Blocked
description: Jeffrey Archer, 61, the millionaire novelist and member of the House of Lords beginning a four-year sentence for perjury, has been denied an expected assignment to a low-security prison because of a new investigation of his affairs. Scotland Yard said last week that it was looking into missing millions of dollars from a charity rock concert for Iraqi Kurds that was run by Lord Archer in 1991 and was supposed to have raised $80 million.

title: F.T.C. Is Acting In 3 Tenors' Case
description: In ''Mitridate, Re di Ponto,'' one of Mozart's early operas, the king of Pontus realizes that his two sons are plotting against him and sings an aria vowing to seek revenge, or at least justice.

title: Developers Bid on Three School Board Buildings
description: Ten developers have submitted bids to buy the three buildings that make up the Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn — 110 and 131 Livingston Street and 65 Court Street — and several others have expressed interest in leasing to the board a smaller building to serve as a new headquarters. The Economic Development Office, which is reviewing the bids, declined to discuss details or to say who submitted the offers; officials told bidders that they hoped to award contracts by the end of the year.   Edward Wyatt Architecture Dean's Chair Goes to Museum

title: John Irving Takes Command of an Unlikely Ink: That of the Tattoo Parlor
description: John Irving has two tattoos: a maple leaf on his left shoulder (in honor of his wife, who is Canadian) and a symbol on his right forearm signifying the starting circle of a wrestling match (because he is a wrestler). Wearing a brightly colored Hawaiian-style short-sleeve shirt, revealing the maple leaf as a kind of badge of identification, he spent a recent Sunday afternoon at the Fourth Annual Tattoo Convention (at the Roseland Ballroom on West 52nd Street in Manhattan). The visit there was all in the name of research.

title: Gays Seeking Asylum Find Familiar Prejudices in U. S.
description: By the time he came to the United States in 1999, Gerson Platero, 29, had had his fill of life as a gay man in Latin America. He had been attacked by the police in El Salvador because he is gay, he said, and shot at after moving to Guatemala. He fled to the United States, to attend an AIDS conference, and applied for asylum based on his sexual orientation.

title: Championing Education Without Commercials
description: The Center for Commercial-Free Public Education, based in California, has honored one of its new heroes with a place on the student advisory board. TRISTAN KADING, a high school sophomore in Stonington, Conn., objected to a mandatory school assembly on job-interview skills in May that was sponsored by McDonald's. Tristan offered to participate in a mock interview, but when he got on stage, he announced that he did not want to work at McDonald's, saying that the company had falsely denied using beef flavoring in its French fries -- an affront to vegetarians like himself and to Hindus. (McDonald's says that it never said its fries were vegetarian.) The school made Tristan apologize publicly to McDonald's. Andrew Hagelshaw, director of the California center, said: ''If this were a school assembly or a classroom, his behavior would be out of line. But when you have a questionable activity to begin with, why is the punishment the same?'' Kate Zernike

title: Small Town Reels From Boy's M.R.I. Death
description: It was a beautiful summer day today, the kind of day that Michael Colombini would have savored. He might have gone swimming. Gamboled in nearby Sunset Park. Made new friends to add to his ever-growing circle.

title: Learning to Teach: Two Students, Two Different Styles
description: For five weeks this summer, 340 college graduates have been going through a rite of passage in the Bronx: learning what it means to be a teacher.

title: Lucent Seeks $1 Billion Through Securities Sale
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it was seeking to raise $1 billion through a private sale of securities in a deal that could provide a cushion for the company's creditors.

title: Some Energy Executives Urge U.S. Shift on Global Warming
description: With President Bush continuing to oppose international or domestic restrictions on gases linked to global warming, among the losers are energy companies that favor government action and have already spent millions on voluntary efforts to cut emissions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption last Thursday with an article about the elusiveness of peace in the Middle East misstated the number of people killed by a suicide bomber at a Tel Aviv discothque and misstated the date. The bombing occurred on June 1, not 2, and killed 21, not 18.

title: Bush Latin America Nominations Reopen Wounds
description: At a recent party held by the Costa Rican ambassador, a group of Reagan administration veterans chuckled over the fierce opposition their names have stirred since President Bush selected them for senior positions responsible for Latin America and human rights.

title: Police Wound Man In Brooklyn Gunfight
description: Police officers traded gunfire with a man in Brooklyn yesterday, wounding him after what witnesses said was a fight between rival gangs.

title: There Are Some New Faces, but It's the Same Old Mets
description: Bobby Valentine flew here with the Mets on Monday night, and after dinner with some players, the trade rumors danced through the conversation. There were some new ones, said Valentine, Mets manager, and he estimated that every player but Mike Piazza had been mentioned in at least one potential deal.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: Ghana: Profit For Gold Miner
description: The gold mining concern Ashanti Goldfields Company said third-quarter earnings would not match second-quarter profit, which more than doubled as lower-cost production at its Geita mine in Tanzania helped replace lost production in Ghana. Net income for the quarter ended June 30 climbed to $14.1 million, or 12 cents a share, from $6.4 million, or 6 cents, a year earlier.

title: Chief Abruptly Quits Business Magazine Group
description: In a move that underscores the fragility of a critical sector of the magazine industry, David Carey, the president and chief executive of the business magazine division at Gruner & Jahr, resigned yesterday after just six months and will return to his previous job as publisher of The New Yorker.

title: INSIDE
description: Seeking Women's Votes

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY TO ACQUIRE XTRA
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the investment vehicle of Warren E. Buffett, agreed to buy the Xtra Corporation, a container leasing company, for about $590 million, the companies said yesterday. Berkshire agreed to pay $55 a share and to assume another $710 million in Xtra's debt. Berkshire's investment comes as shipping companies that lease Xtra's equipment struggle in a slowing economy. Xtra said yesterday that profit in its most recent quarter fell 57 percent because of lower freight demand and increased costs. Julian H. Robertson Jr., the billionaire who leads Tiger Management and is Xtra's biggest shareholder, agreed to the transaction. Xtra will remain at its headquarters in Westport, Conn., and operate as a wholly owned subsidiary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELNIKOFF, MEYER
description: MELNIKOFF-Meyer. On July 30, 2001 of Verona, formerly of Millburn, NJ. Beloved husband of Elaine (Yospin). Devoted father of Susan Sibley, Dr. Barbara, and Peter Melnikoff. Loving brother of Roslyn Thaler. Adored grandfather of Brent and Taft. Funeral service at Temple Sholom of West Essex, 760 Pompton Ave., Cedar Grove, NJ on Thursday, August 2 at 10AM. Services by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Union, New Jersey.

title: The Low Cost of Lowering Auto Emissions
description: Requiring sport utility vehicles and other light trucks to go farther on a gallon of gas is the most effective step America could take both to limit dependence on foreign oil and to slow global warming, yet for years Congress has not taken it. The report issued yesterday by the National Academy of Sciences, asserting that this improvement is not only environmentally critical but technically feasible, gives solid support to those of us in Congress who have long wanted to set the same fuel efficiency standards for S.U.V.'s and light trucks that we now set for cars.

title: A Son's Score for His Father's Choreography
description: DanceGalaxy opened its weeklong season at the Joyce Theater on Monday night with a buzz that had nothing to do with dance. For once, it was the music that everyone was talking about. Nilas Martins, a principal with the New York City Ballet, had created his first score for a professional ballet company. The choreography was the work of his father, Peter, who heads the City Ballet. It was a publicist's dream.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Patricia Breen and Dan Willey were named senior vice presidents and creative directors at the Troy, Mich., office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of the Bcom3 Group. Ms. Breen and Mr. Willey had been vice presidents for creative at Pentamark Worldwide, Troy, part of the Omnicom Group.

title: PHELPS DODGE IS EXPECTING THIRD CONSECUTIVE LOSS
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, a leading copper producer, said it expected a loss in the third quarter because of weakening demand. The company, based in Phoenix, will lose $1.10 to $1.20 a share, before any one-time gains or losses, its chairman, J. Steven Whisler, said. It would be the third consecutive quarterly loss for Phelps Dodge. ''We have just not seen the recovery we expected,'' Mr. Whisler said. ''The severe slowdown in the U.S. economy is starting to impact Latin America and Europe, particularly in Germany.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, RUTH S.
description: KAHN-Ruth S. November 23, 1913July 30, 2001. Died peacefully at her home Monday surrounded by family and friends after a valiant struggle with cancer at age 87. She is survived by her daughter Geraldine Karetsky, grandchildren Jeffrey, Robin, Stephen and Anne Kahn and Andrew and Robert Karetsky and Jennifer Andres and their spouses; Anneke, Kirby, Suzanne, Scott, Pamela and Brett. She also leaves nine great-grandchildren; Beckett, William, Harry, Zora, Phineas, David Henry, Jakob, Charlotte, and Samuel, and her sister Pearl Kaufman. She is pre-deceased by her husband Herman, beloved sons, Seth and Sidney and her son-in-law David Karetsky. A strong, intelligent beautiful woman, she was an avid bridge player, artist, designer, dutiful wife, family woman and loving mother. God Bless You, Ruthie Kahn. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Guild for the Blind, 15 West 65 Street, NY, NY 10023.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Sports of The Times; A-Rod, Mets Are Going Nowhere
description: ALEX RODRIGUEZ waltzed into Midtown with the Texas Rangers early yesterday, about a dozen hours before the trading deadline. This was the first time Rodriguez had been to our lovable city this season, the city where he could have and should have been playing baseball for the Mets. Instead, selfishness, miscommunication and hastiness destroyed this potential marriage. Too bad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, ROBERT, DR.
description: MARGOLIS-Robert, Dr. Died July 31. Healer, mentor and role model. His wisdom and compassion were a constant source of inspiration and benevolence to his family, patients and friends. He will be deeply missed. Beloved husband to Grace, devoted father to Stefan, Karen and Randi, grandfather of Yori, Elyse and Lance.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Initial Offering Ends First Day Higher
description: HPL Technologies Inc. made its trading debut with a 21.4 percent climb. Shares of HPL, a maker of testing software for the semiconductor industry, closed at $13.35, up $2.35 from the $11 offering price for the six million shares sold. HPL Technologies, based in San Jose, Calif., produces software that helps semiconductor makers enhance the efficiency of integrated circuits. The company has operated as Heuristic Physics Laboratories Inc. since 1989.

title: Martha Stewart to Run Spot on Space Organizers
description: Martha Stewart Everyday will start to run a television commercial today inviting consumers to join Ms. Stewart's "space program."

title: Much-Maligned B-1 Bomber Proves Hard to Kill
description: For most of its relatively short and often bumbling life, the B-1 has been the strategic bomber even the Pentagon has loved to hate.

title: Deutsche Telekom Says 2nd-Quarter Results Slumped
description: Deutsche Telekom said today that it earned just enough cash to cover expenses in the second quarter, as the cost of acquisitions and new wireless licenses ate into profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURKEL, MINDA
description: TURKEL-Minda. Passed away on Sunday, July 29, 2001. She had been a psychiatric social worker at Jacobi Hospital and had a private practice as well. She was a graduate of NYU and continued to be active in alumni affairs. She leaves behind a large group of family and friends who were devoted to her. She will be greatly missed by all of us. Funeral to be held at Ferncliff Cemetery in Hartsdale, NY on August 2 at 11:30AM.

title: G.O.P. Tries to Counter Lack of Support Among Women
description: Republicans inside and outside the White House are focusing anew on the party's disadvantage among women in the electorate, a problem that has persisted -- and by some recent measures worsened -- through the beginning of the Bush administration.

title: Flutie Happy to Be the Chargers' Little Big Man
description: When quarterback Doug Flutie dropped back to pass at a recent training camp practice of the San Diego Chargers, his 5-foot-10 frame disappeared amid the towering linemen as if he were a sapling in a forest of oaks. But when the ball was fired out of the pocket, crisp and bullet-like, it was clear his arm was as strong as any quarterback's in football despite his short stature.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Spending Questioned
description: Senator Jeff Sessions, Republican of Alabama, is asking why the Office of Management and the Budget has approved $5.5 million for property for a new F.B.I. office in downtown Birmingham when a lot four blocks away is available for $800,000. The more expensive land is south of Interstates 59/20 near the Jefferson County complex; the other property is near the Birmingham-Jefferson Civic Center. Armand DeKeyser, an aide to Mr. Sessions, said the budget office had put a hold on the project pending discussions with the F.B.I. ''We don't see any difference in the more expensive site,'' Mr. DeKeyser said. Dana Beyerle (NYT)

title: Rural Towns Turn to Prisons To Reignite Their Economies
description: For a town of 4,114 in western Oklahoma, Sayre has an impressive landfill. The scales to weigh the bales of crushed scrap are new. A machine for shredding trees is new. So, too, is the 60-unit apartment complex going up on the side of the road leading to the dump, the asphalt that covers that road, and the sprawling Flying J Truck Plaza nearby.

title: Refreshing Brew: Tall and Cool, Floral and Fruity
description: This season, the Wild Lily Tea Room, 511 West 22nd Street, has added a few new flavors to its list of popular iced teas. Among them are Tahitian, a black tea flavored with rock sugar and tropical fruits including passion fruit; jasmine, delicately touched with lemon and sugar; and a floral chrysanthemum. A tall glass is $4 to $5, available sweetened or unsweetened. And for those who prefer to stir up their own refreshment, Wild Lily also sells its iced-tea blends for home brewing. Canisters of whole-leaf Tahitian or Emerald, a quick-dissolving green-tea powder, are $12; its unsweetened jasmine is $18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, LAUREL H.
description: ADAMS-Laurel H. July 30, 2001. Beloved wife of Francis. Loving sister of James Haring. Adored aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. She was a devoted nurse who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Friday, August 3rd, 10-12 noon with service following at noon.

title: Mountain Bikers Try to Hold Their Own on the Trails
description: More than one great divide looms over the trails for mountain biking, hiking, horseback riding and backcountry skiing in the vast, beautiful vertical landscape surrounding this popular resort town.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Needle Suit Can Proceed
description: A lawsuit by a drug addict charging that the police arrested him for possession of a syringe despite his participation in a legal needle exchange program can proceed as a class action, a federal judge ruled yesterday. The plaintiff, identified only as James Roe, sought to expand the suit to include other addicts, charging that the New York Police Department's policy of sweeping drug areas, including some where needle exchanges are situated, makes it likely that participants will be arrested. Judge Robert W. Sweet of United States District Court agreed that revealing Mr. Roe's identity would be dangerous for him. In granting class status, Judge Sweet applied a First Amendment principle that ''a threat of police action that chills the exercise of protected speech may confer standing to sue.'' A spokeswoman for the corporation counsel's office would not comment.

title: Soul of Simplicity in an American Bistro
description: JANE is a restaurant with the soul of a cafe. Shiny aluminum tables and chairs on the sidewalk outside strike a cheery note, and there's an air of cool, loungy relaxation to the big bar and even bigger banquettes inside. There's a lot of beige, although ''wheat'' would probably be the catalog color. Either way, the wood floors and the studiedly neutral dcor massage the nerves, and the menu couldn't be more friendly if it were printed with Have a Nice Day at the bottom.

title: Navistar to Increase Its Truck Production
description: The Navistar International Corporation will increase production of heavy-duty trucks at an Ontario plant by about 40 percent starting in September and call back 189 workers because of fewer unsold vehicles at dealers.

title: From Snapping Shutter To Snapping the Reins
description: After looking at the Hambletonian through the lens of his camera for 20 about years, Stefan Melander of Sweden hopes to be the focus of attention in the Meadowlands winner's circle in Saturday's 76th edition of the race.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kurile Islands: South Korean Fishermen
description: A flotilla of 26 South Korean fishing boats began trolling off the southern Kurile Islands, seized by Soviet troops in the closing days of World War II and claimed ever since by Japan. The boats had Russian inspectors on board, but Japan has told South Korea that the islands are Japanese and foreign vessels need Japanese, not Russian, permission to fish around them. The Japanese were not expected to stop the South Koreans this time, but they have threatened to ban South Korean boats from their waters. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Readers' Conversation With Marcus Arnold and Jonathan Lebed
description: The NYTimes.com's Readers' Opinions area hosted Marcus Arnold, a 15 year-old who posed as an attorney on askme.com, and Jonathan Lebed, who manipulated stocks on the Web, in a special panel discussion. Mr. Arnold and Mr. Lebed were profiled in two articles by Michael Lewis- 'Faking It' and 'Jonathan Lebed's Extracurricular Activities' .

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's absence from a gathering to welcome former President Bill Clinton to Harlem quoted a word incorrectly in a comment from the mayor. Speaking to reporters, Mr. Giuliani said, ''I don't think it is really a big deal, but you'll probably make it a big deal anyway.'' He did not say Mr. Clinton would make a big deal of the event.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Security Products Makers To Merge
description: RSA Security said it would acquire the privately held Securant Technologies, a San Francisco-based maker of authorization software for managing access to computer networks. RSA, which is based in Bedford, Mass., will pay $136.5 million in cash for the company, in a deal expected to close in August. RSA said it expected the acquisition to add $3 million to $4 million in revenue in the third quarter and $35 million to $40 million in fiscal 2002. Securant's ClearTrust authorization software is used by electronic commerce companies to manage users' access to certain features and areas online. The addition of Securant's technology helps RSA round out its security product line, which already includes authentication, digital certificate and encryption technologies.

title: Find Your Inner Wastrel
description: I want to be honest about this, but I also want to be modest, and that's difficult. Well, here goes. I, the same guy who is scared to death of needles and loud noises and rap music, am a hero of the recession, or rather, of the ''economic slowdown.''

title: New West Coast College, Born of the Far East
description: ALISO VIEJO, Calif., July 20  On a lavender-covered hilltop halfway between Los Angeles and San Diego, in the midst of miles of look-alike red-roofed tract houses, an architectural and educational marvel reaches skyward above the Pacific, waiting to spring to life next month as the first new private liberal arts college to be built in California in 25 years.

title: Use of Shelters By Families Sets Record in City
description: The number of homeless families lodging nightly in New York City's shelter system has risen higher than ever and the trend is accelerating, city officials said yesterday. With a critical shortage of low-cost housing, and applications for shelter running 30 percent higher than last year, officials say they expect new records to be set this winter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MERGENTIME, LEE JR.
description: MERGENTIME-Lee Jr., 85. Of Manalapan, NJ on July 31 in Freehold Twp. He was predeceased by his wife, Rose Berlin Mergentime, and a son, Charles M. Surviving is a son and daughter-in-law, Lee and Fran Mergentime of East Brunswick; a brother, Max of Bloomfield, MI; and two grandsons, Brian and Larry. A funeral service will be held today at 11:30 AM at the Freeman ManalapanMarlboro Funeral Home, Manalapan. Interment will follow at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge. Donations to Deborah Hospital, Pine Brook Ch., L. Shargel, 236-G Medford, CT, Manalapan, N.J. 07726.

title: Our Towns; A Boy Named Soup?
description: JASON BLACK blames it all on a fortune cookie.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MILTON
description: GOLDSTEIN-Milton, 86. Beloved husband of Ethel for 57 wonderful years. Devoted father of Howard and Richard and father-in-law of Judy and Candy. Dedicated and loving grandfather of Lee (and his wife, Gretchen), Jonathan, Lauren, Daniel, Robert and Amanda. Cherished uncle, brother-in-law and friend. We will miss his kindness, caring and compassion but we will never forget the values and principles he bestowed upon us. His spirit, intelligence and tenacity will be an inspiration to us all. Rest in peace.

title: A Creamy Confection's Inner 'Ooh La La'
description: IN addition to being able to tie a scarf at least 10 different ways and to walk with grace in stilt-high heels along treacherous cobblestone streets, my Parisian friends can whip up a ptisserie-perfect fruit tart on a moment's notice or sauce a chocolate mousse with a pouring custard so smooth it could make you weep.

title: 2 ARE YOUNG BOYS
description: Eight Palestinians, including two small boys, were killed today when Israeli Army helicopters fired missiles into the offices here of the militant Islamic group Hamas, igniting fury on the street and demands for swift revenge.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Arms Trader Sentenced
description: An arms dealer who pleaded guilty to wire fraud was sentenced to time served, 10 months in jail, by a federal judge in Los Angeles after cooperating in another investigation. The dealer, Sarkis Soghanalian, 71, a Lebanese citizen, admitted depositing a stolen $250,000 check into his Paris bank account. Although assistant United States attorney Terri A. Law did not reveal details of the cooperation, Mr. Soghanalian had been freed to travel from Los Angeles to Amman, Jordan, after being held 10 months without bail following arrest in 1999. During that time, he reportedly obtained documents involving the sale of 50,000 AK-47 assault rifles to Vladimiro Montesinos, the former Peruvian intelligence chief.

title: Use of Shelters by Families Sets Record in New York
description: The number of homeless families lodging nightly in New York City's shelter system has risen higher than ever and the trend is accelerating, city officials said yesterday. With a critical shortage of low-cost housing, and applications for shelter running 30 percent higher than last year, officials say they expect new records to be set this winter.

title: Food for Thought? In Many Cases, No
description: WHAT is the most efficient way to raise low-income pupils' achievement? Is it ending social promotion, increasing accountability or adding more testing?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gardens Coalition To March
description: Members of the More Gardens coalition say they will hold a ''festive musical march'' on City Hall today to present 25,000 signatures in support of a referendum on whether to designate community gardens as open space. The coalition needs 5,000 more signatures for a referendum, but wants to call attention to stalled legislation proposed by City Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher that would achieve the same end, said Aresh Javadi, a coalition spokesman. Of the 700 community gardens, Mr. Javadi said 400 are in danger of development.

title: Lilly Is Good, But Rangers Are a Bit Better
description: Ted Lilly's locker is next to the blue front door of the Yankees' clubhouse, and the rookie pitcher sees all who come and go. Randy Keisler, the fellow rookie with whom Lilly spent most of his time, stuffed an equipment bag yesterday and walked out, demoted to Class AAA Columbus to make room for Sterling Hitchcock.

title: USX BOARD APPROVES PLAN TO SPLIT INTO 2 BUSINESSES
description: The USX Corporation's board approved a restructuring plan that will divide its U.S. Steel and Marathon Oil businesses into two separate companies. The plan is subject to shareholder approval and a tax ruling from the government, USX said. The spinoff is expected to occur at the end of the year, the company said. In April, USX said it planned to split by year's end into two companies, one an oil explorer and the other a steel maker, to increase investors' returns and make it easier to use stock for acquisitions. U.S. Steel, the nation's largest steel maker, and Marathon have had their own tracking stocks since 1991.

title: Developers Bid on Three School Board Buildings
description: Ten developers have submitted bids to buy the three buildings that make up the Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn -- 110 and 131 Livingston Street and 65 Court Street -- and several others have expressed interest in leasing to the board a smaller building to serve as a new headquarters. The Economic Development Office, which is reviewing the bids, declined to discuss details or to say who submitted the offers; officials told bidders that they hoped to award contracts by the end of the year. Edward Wyatt

title: Save Children's Express
description: To the Editor:

title: What They Were Thinking
description: 'The last thing people think of when they see a pedicab is freedom, but it is a kind of freedom, believe it or not. You can make your own schedule, pretty much. And you get to meet the people -- good people, bad people, you've got it all. I always introduce myself. People develop the skill of telling their life story in a few minutes -- they talk fast, talk rich -- and you find out things. I have a few of my life stories that I tell, too. It's theater on wheels. It's based on a true story. Me and my passengers, we are a mobile institution.'' interview by Catherine Saint Louis

title: Priceline.com Posts a Profit On Sharp Increase in Sales
description: Priceline.com, the name-your-own-price Internet travel service that six months ago was reeling from unhappy customers, has reached a milestone that few other Internet companies have passed: it made a profit according to generally accepted accounting principles.

title: Martha Stewart Spot On Space Organizers
description: Martha Stewart Everyday will start to run a television commercial today inviting consumers to join Ms. Stewart's ''space program.''

title: War Crimes Court Takes It Easy On a Cooperative Bosnian Serb
description: A former Bosnian Serb police chief who was arrested after being kidnapped by bounty hunters and turned over to NATO troops was handed one of the lightest sentences yet by the United Nations war crimes tribunal today, in part because he had pleaded guilty to most charges and pledged to cooperate with the court.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: B.A.T. Profit Is Up
description: British American Tobacco said second-quarter profit increased 7.9 percent, to 287 million ($409 million) or 13.4 pence a share, compared with 266 million ($379 million), or 12.4 pence a share, last year. The figures exclude the cost of integrating Rothmans International, which B.A.T. bought in 1999. B.A.T., which makes Lucky Strike and Pall Mall cigarettes, said results benefited from higher prices in the United States and rising sales in Europe and Asia.

title: A Master Chef With a New Role
description: HIS luxuriant white hair has thinned a bit, and his step has slowed. But at 71, Roger Verg, the chef and owner of Le Moulin de Mougins near Cannes, still has his matinee idol charm.

title: Study Says 20% of Girls Reported Abuse by a Date
description: Their faces are far younger than those that appear in public service advertisements about domestic violence. They are too young to drink legally and, in many cases, too young to vote.

title: A Melon You Can't Judge by Its Peel
description: The Sprite melon is a newcomer worth meeting. It may not be an instant attention-grabber in the produce bin, but it proves that the goodness of a melon is more than skin deep. The size of a grapefruit, with a pale ivory skin sometimes traced with rough brown, it has a crisp whitish flesh and a lovely tropical aroma, almost like a litchi. The flavor suggests a mildly musky honeydew crossed with Asian pear.

title: WHITMAN TO ISSUE ORDER TO DREDGE HUDSON FOR PCB'S
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, Christie Whitman, has agreed to go ahead with a plan issued in the closing days of the Clinton administration requiring the General Electric Company to spend more than half a billion dollars to dredge PCB pollution from the Hudson River, according to officials at the agency.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLLHAUS, PHILIP EDWARD, JR.
description: ROLLHAUS-Philip Edward, Jr. Passed away peacefully at home in Palm Beach, FL on Saturday, July 28th, after a courageous battle with cancer. Mr. Rollhaus, 66, was the founder and chairman of Quixote Corporation, headquartered in Chicago, whose highway safety products have saved over 40,000 lives and countless serious injuries. Mr. Rollhaus is survived by his loving wife, Barbara, two wonderful children, Natalie (Matthew) Burton of Los Angeles, CA, and Philip E. ''Ned'' Rollhaus III (Catherine) of San Francisco, CA, his loving sister Barbara (Warren) Quimby of Albany, NY, adored granddaughter, Sydney Grace Burton, and several cousins, nieces & nephews. Burial services will be private. A memorial service will take place at The Fourth Presbyterian Church, Michigan Avenue at Delaware Pl in Chicago, IL, on Tuesday, August 7th at 4:00 in the afternoon. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Shelter Island Friends Meeting, Box 520, Shelter Island, New York 11964.

title: Market Place; S.E.C. Leader Cites Conflicts Of Analysts At Large Firms
description: Laura S. Unger, the acting chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress yesterday that the agency had found that conflicts of interest run deep and wide among analysts at almost all the nation's largest brokerage firms. And, in an interview after her testimony, she said that some of the analysts' actions might become the subject of enforcement cases brought by the S.E.C.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sony And Yahoo In Promotional Deal
description: Sony has agreed to promote its movies and sonystyle.com electronics store on Yahoo, the big Internet portal, as part of a multiyear deal. It will also create a Sony version of the My Yahoo start page that will be offered to people who buy its Vaio personal computers. This arrangement is a temporary move while Sony develops its own portal that will tie together its various offerings, including online games, music and video downloads and photo sharing. Yahoo will consult on the new portal, as well. ''We are trying to contact directly with our customers beyond the point of purchase,'' said Robert Wiesenthal, executive vice president of Sony Broadband Entertainment. He declined to specify the financial terms but noted that the value of the promotion and consulting Yahoo provides Sony are offset by the value of customers provided by Sony to Yahoo.

title: A Meeting of the Shortstops
description: Alex Rodriguez and Derek Jeter spent weeks in spring training publicly discussing their friendship after Rodriguez made vaguely derogatory comments about Jeter in the off-season.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the arts pages on Monday about Woody Allen's orchestral and movie tour misstated the opening date of his latest film, ''The Curse of the Jade Scorpion.'' It is Aug. 17, not Aug. 10.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STONE, FLORENCE RUTH
description: STONE-Florence Ruth. On July 30, 2001, at age 78. Survived by her children Philip, Roberta and Andrea. Adoring grandmother of Alex. Loving sister of Linda Dietz, Paul Stone and Mark Stone. Service today, 1:30 PM, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARTALSKY, DEBORAH
description: TARTALSKY-Deborah. Of Brandon VT and formerly of Jersey City NJ died Monday, July 30 at the age of 100 after a long and fruitful life. Her late husband, Samuel, was a Jersey City attorney. She is survived by daughter Lea (Ruth) Sneider of NYC and son Jeremiah Tarr of Rutland VT, and by nine grandchildren and fifteen great grandchildren. Service at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, 685 Fairview Avenue, Fairview NJ at 2:30PM, Wednesday August 1. Donations in Debby's memory to Hadassah, 50 West 58 Street, NYC 10019, attn: Suzi Somosi.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Internet Gambling Case
description: A United States appeals court panel yesterday upheld the conviction of a bookmaker who was sentenced to 21 months in prison as part of what the authorities called the first federal prosecution of Internet sports gambling. The case involved a Internet sports betting business run by the man, Jay Cohen, from Antigua, in the Caribbean. According to the opinion, customers opened accounts with the venture, World Sports Exchange; wired money to the accounts; then used the Internet or phone to authorize the company to place bets. Federal prosecutors had charged that the enterprise violated a federal law that banned the use of interstate wires for betting. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Peel a Merlot, Find a Coy Carmenre
description: WHEN you think about it, the contemporary wine industry embodies a fascinating paradox. It is a never-ending search for something new in a business that is based on and reveres tradition.

title: Liberty Seeks Run Before the Playoffs
description: The Liberty kept going back in time last week. Its loss at Portland sent the team back to 1999, the last time it had dropped three in a row. Its loss at Utah on Wednesday sent it back to 1998, the last time the team had lost four in a row. It ended the four-game losing streak Saturday with a 64-61 victory at Houston and returned home with a 1-2 mark on the trip.

title: Negotiators on Patients' Rights Focus on Ability to Sue for Harmful Decisions on Care
description: With House Republican leaders eager to schedule a vote this week on a patients' bill of rights, Congress and the White House haggled today over the biggest unresolved question: the right of consumers to sue health insurance companies and employers for treatment decisions that cause harm to patients.

title: Senate Rejects G.O.P. Effort To Limit Emergency Farm Aid
description: Risking a presidential veto, the Senate today rejected a Republican proposal to limit emergency farm aid to $5.5 billion, pushing ahead with a Democratic measure worth $2 billion more.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar slipped against the yen but gained against the euro. In New York, the dollar settled at 125.05 yen, down from 125.11 yen on Monday. The euro traded at 87.45 cents, down from 87.49 cents.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BROWNSTEIN, NOAH J.
description: BROWNSTEIN-Noah J. 5/21/52-8/ 1/92. Nine long lonely years since you opened our door, hugged, kissed, and made us laugh. You were our world, now our hearts are broken and the pain grows deeper. Every minute of every day you are with us. Hugs, kisses, Mom and Da

title: National Briefing | Washington: Scouts Found
description: Four teenagers from Tanzania who had been missing from a Boy Scout gathering in Virginia since Sunday were turned over to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The boys, ages 14 to 17, presented themselves to the Washington police on Monday evening, said an I.N.S. spokesman, William Strassberger. He said he could not comment on whether they had requested asylum. The boys left the Scout gathering on Sunday afternoon, slept on the side of a road that night and then hitchhiked to Washington on Monday, Mr. Strassberger said.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Con Edison's Income Rises
description: Consolidated Edison Inc. said its second-quarter net income rose 13 percent because it sold 24 percent more natural gas in the period. Net income was $100.6 million, or 48 cents a share, a rise from $88.7 million, or 42 cents, a year earlier, said Hyman Schoenblum, Con Ed's vice president for corporate planning. The company had been expected to earn 41 cents a share. Revenue rose 3.4 percent to $2.11 billion from $2.04 billion. There were no gains or charges in the most-recent quarter. Con Ed supplies electricity to more than three million customers in New York City, neighboring Westchester County, and in parts of New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The average price of electricity traded in New York City rose 6.7 percent last quarter to $66.42 a megawatt-hour from a year earlier, according to Bloomberg Energy Service statistics.

title: HOUSE BACKS BAN ON HUMAN CLONING FOR ANY OBJECTIVE
description: After an impassioned debate that pitted the promise of cures for disease against the horror of making babies that are genetic replicas of adults, the House of Representatives voted by a wide margin today to ban cloning, not only for reproduction but also for medical research.

title: Double Duty for Bean Counters
description: Those who get as much of a jolt from money as they do from caffeine can find both at the new ING Direct cafe at 45 East 49th Street. Instead of bank tellers behind bulletproof glass, there are baristas behind the counter in the company's bright orange cafe. The same person can show customers how to open a bank account or apply for a loan online while dispensing one of the best cups of coffee around. The coffee comes from Peet's, the popular Bay Area roaster known for its dark, full-bodied beans. It's $1.50 for a cup of coffee; espresso-based drinks range from $1.75 to $3.50. Open an account and the coffee is on the house. ING Direct, the North American affiliate of a Dutch bank, also has Internet-linked bank-cafes in Europe, Australia and Canada. The branch here sells Peet's beans at $9.95 to $12.95 a pound, and it's the only place you'll find them in New York City.

title: At the Whitney, Cake Imitates Art
description: Anyone who has ever seen the film ''Big Night,'' that marathon of Italian cooking, and promptly headed to the kitchen will understand what Sarabeth Levine had in mind after seeing the Wayne Thiebaud retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Court Suspends Judge
description: A judge was suspended for three months without pay yesterday by the State Supreme Court after the court found that she had lied to the police about a hostile encounter with a sheriff's officer she had dated. The judge, Rosemarie R. Williams of State Superior Court in Mercer County, and Officer Alfred Wesley Bridges had broken off their relationship when in April 2000 he took another woman to a restaurant in Ewing where Judge Williams was having dinner, prompting a heated argument, the court said. She followed Officer Bridges and the woman to a bar in Trenton, where the hostilities resumed, the court said. But, the court said, after he asked the proprietor to call the police, the judge called the police to report that he had followed her. In her actions, the court ruled, Judge Williams ''demonstrated a lack of respect for the law that as a judge she has sworn to uphold.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMF BOWLING INC., Richmond, Va., filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, just weeks after its subsidiary, AMF Bowling Worldwide, did the same.

title: Trivia Question
description: Here are the question and answer from last week's Baseball Report. Subscribe to The Baseball Report and get a new question each week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, VICTORIA (NEE DEVOE)
description: TAYLOR-Victoria (nee Devoe). Died July 30 in her home in Rumson, at age 76. Beloved wife of the late Francis. Devoted mother of Gregory, Roderick, Harold and Victoria. Memorial service will be held August 3 at 10am at St. George's-By-The River in Rumson.

title: Six Shows Are Added For 'Seagull'
description: The Joseph Papp Public Theater/New York Shakespeare Festival has extended its run of Chekhov's ''Seagull'' at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park for one week, until Aug. 26. The star-studded production started previews on July 24, is to open formally on Aug. 12 and was to have closed Aug. 19. The six added performances, Tuesday through Sunday at 8 p.m., will make 11,400 more tickets available.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR DROPS. Sugar fell on increased shipments from the new crop in Brazil, the world's biggest exporter. In New York, raw sugar for October delivery fell 0.42 cent, to 7.93 cents a pound.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: Sexy and Zany? Nah, He Just Prints the Stuff
description: IF only Hugh Hefner could keep his hands away from those Playboy bunnies, he might come off a bit more like Jeff Brauer, the strait-laced strategist behind On Your Own Publications, publisher of ''Sexy New York City,'' an annual guidebook to Big Apple erotica; Zany's, a reference tool for apartment seekers; and the brand-new ''Queer New York,'' a compendium Mr. Brauer predicts will become ''a bible for the gay community.''

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day yesterday, about a campaign for OP, a vodka that blends fruit and spices, misidentified the distributor of Absolut vodka. It is Future Brands -- a partnership of Jim Beam Brands Worldwide and V&S Vin and Sprit of Sweden -- not Seagram Americas.

title: Bullish Merrill Call on Chip Sector Fuels Rise in Technology Shares
description: Technology stocks rose today, led by a rally in semiconductor issues after Merrill Lynch upgraded its ratings on some companies in the sector, saying that the worst may be over for chip makers.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Struggling Consultants Join Forces
description: IXL Enterprises and Scient, Internet consulting firms that have eliminated hundreds of jobs as their stock prices plummeted, will merge and move their headquarters to New York. The companies will operate under Scient's name. IXL shareholders will get 0.25 share of the new company's stock for each IXL share and Scient's holders will get 0.31 share for each Scient share. IXL is based in Atlanta and Scient in San Francisco. Scient cut 675 jobs, or half of its staff, in April. IXL followed in May with a cut of 300 employees, or 23 percent.

title: For the Fires of Summer, a Soothing Sea of Noodles
description: I HAVE two common-sense strategies for hot-weather eating. One is to seek out the foods of regions where it is hot, like the Middle East, Greece, Southeast Asia or India. These cuisines have evolved over centuries of dealing with often unbearable heat. My other tack, simply enough, is to eat foods that are served cool.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Bobby Flay Fish Stews

title: Air Force One Has Flown, but Clinton's Still Celebrity in Chief
description: He used to stop traffic. Now he sits in it.

title: Hevesi Faults Vallone for Saying He'd Cut Police or Schools Before Parks
description: Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that one of his rivals for the Democratic mayoral nomination, City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, was making an ''error of the first order'' by ruling out future budget cuts for the Parks Department but not for the Police Department or the Board of Education.

title: A Novelist Takes Command of an Unlikely Ink: That of the Tattoo Parlor
description: John Irving has two tattoos: a maple leaf on his left shoulder (in honor of his wife, who is Canadian) and a symbol on his right forearm signifying the starting circle of a wrestling match (because he is a wrestler). Wearing a brightly colored Hawaiian-style short-sleeve shirt, revealing the maple leaf as a kind of badge of identification, he spent a recent Sunday afternoon at the Fourth Annual Tattoo Convention (at the Roseland Ballroom on West 52nd Street in Manhattan). The visit there was all in the name of research.

title: I Frown on Distractions
description: I never thought about the impact that winning the Super Bowl would have on my private life until I was on the train to New York for the weekend. My wife turned to me and asked, ''Are we going to be O.K.?''

title: Bush Endorses Panel's Call to Overhaul Election System
description: Without explicitly acknowledging that anything went awry in Florida's presidential election last year, President Bush today accepted and endorsed some of the general principles in a blue-ribbon panel's report on overhauling the nation's election system.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Bomber's Brother Leads Cause

title: Cool Mitts, Washable And Pliable
description: AS any home cook knows, the one characteristic that cloth potholders have in common is the grunginess they acquire after just a few days on the job. And if you wash a cloth mitt or pad with the laundry, its good looks often go down the drain with the suds.

title: Report Finds Abuse Of High School Girls
description: A new report suggests that one in five adolescent girls becomes the victims of physical or sexual violence, or both, on dates. Such violence, the researchers found, is frequently associated with such problems as drug abuse.

title: People
description: * Vincent Tulley, creative director at CMG Communications, New York, has left, the agency said, ''to pursue other endeavors.'' Mr. Tulley's duties overseeing the creative department will be handled on an interim basis by Dave Berger, who had been a freelancer.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Farrakhan Ban Lifted
description: A High Court judge overturned a 15-year-old ban on Louis Farrakhan's entering Britain, rejecting government arguments that his presence could stir up racial division and cause public disorder. Lawyers for Mr. Farrakhan, 67, the Chicago-based head of the Nation of Islam, have argued that he now regrets past anti-Semitic remarks and wants to give Britons a message on ''self-reliance, dignity and discipline.'' Justice Michael Turner said the ban would remain in effect until October when he would explain his judgment in full. The government is expected to appeal.

title: Keeping a Treasure Close to Home
description: HOSE it down first.''

title: Spurned New Hires Have Their Say
description: Wendy Withers had rented out her Los Angeles apartment, sold her furniture and her Nissan Xterra and said goodbye to her colleagues at TBWA/Chiat/Day. After three years as a full-time art buyer for the advertising agency, she said she had landed a long-term freelance job with a large Madison Avenue advertising agency, and she could hardly wait to begin.

title: Updated Shakespeare, at the Opera and in the Outback
description: Australia seems to be going through a Shakespeare thing these days.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about a new study of Internet use and social isolation referred incorrectly to the precedents for research in the field. Even before the Internet and American Life Project of the Pew Research Center reported last year that Internet use increased social interaction, other studies had reached similar conclusions. Earlier research included a nationwide survey first conducted in 1995 by James Katz of Rutgers University and Philip Aspden of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: RESTATEMENT BY PRE-PAID LEGAL REDUCES EARNINGS
description: Pre-Paid Legal Services Inc. restated financial statements for the last two years, wiping out more than half its profit, after the Securities and Exchange Commission said the provider of legal insurance improperly recorded some commissions paid as assets. The S.E.C. said in May that Pre-Paid incorrectly classified advance payments to salesmen as an asset, instead of as an expense, as required by accepted accounting principles. Pre-Paid appealed the ruling. It was the third time since 1986 that the S.E.C. demanded the company restate earnings. The restatement reduced 2000 earnings to 81 cents from the $1.92 it had reported at the end of April. Earnings for 1999 were cut to 57 cents from $1.67.

title: Norwegian Coastal Voyages
description: Any cruise that skirts the coast of Norway isn't complete without shore excursions, and Norwegian Coastal Voyage has reduced the cost of these excursions by 25 percent from rates in its brochure. The company operates 11 ships that sail daily Bergen and Kirkenes along the 1,250-mile west coast of Norway, with seven-day trips northbound, six-day soutbound trips and 12-day round trips. Shore excursions can be bought as a package ($180 per person for four excursions on a one-way trip, $281 for seven on a round trip) or as individual tours, ranging in price from $20 to $95. Information: (800) 323-7436 or www.coastalvoyage.com .

title: Lincoln Center Gets Jazz Director
description: After a seven-month search, Jazz at Lincoln Center announced yesterday the appointment of Bruce MacCombie, dean of the School for the Arts at Boston University, as its new executive director.

title: Quick Sellers
description: Brooklyn Cyclones baseball caps are the nation's second-best seller, topping every major league team except the Seattle Mariners.
