description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Pushes to Refocus Racism Conference
description: State Department officials said today that they have been engaged in a strenuous and complicated diplomatic effort to persuade other nations to omit two contentious issues from the agenda of a coming United Nations conference on racism -- whether Zionism is racism and whether nations should pay reparations for slavery.

title: Madagascar Dinosaur Discoverers Help Finance a Village School
description: When David W. Krause, a paleontologist in the anatomy department at the medical school of the State University at Stony Brook, goes to Madagascar, it is usually to hunt for dinosaur bones and other fossils.

title: At the Whitney, Cake Imitates Art
description: Anyone who has ever seen the film "Big Night," that marathon of Italian cooking, and promptly headed to the kitchen will understand what Sarabeth Levine had in mind after seeing the Wayne Thiebaud retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: The Mideast Maze: Steps and Missteps
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; The industry is abuzz with speculation, but few hard answers, as to when the downturn will end.
description: ROUND and round went the toy train on a platform the size of a kitchen table. A man at the Amtrak display booth intently watched the little five-car model Acela Express buzz across the track, as if it were moving in something other than a circle.

title: Giants' Canadians Are 'Cultural' Ambassadors
description: The veteran players in a football training camp usually command the rookies to stand on a table and sing their college songs at team dinners. But last week, the rookie quarterback Jesse Palmer was instructed to sing ''O Canada.'' The rendition was greeted with boos.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Register.com Revenue Increases
description: Register.com Inc., a Manhattan domain registration and Internet services company that is one of the few profitable publicly traded Internet companies in Silicon Alley, reported yesterday that its net income increased significantly in the second quarter. The company reported net income of $2.1 million on revenues of $29.9 million, compared with a net loss of $922,100 on revenues of $20.2 million in the second quarter of last year. But by June 30, the company's cash and cash equivalents had declined 82 percent over the past year to $26 million, compared with $148 million at the same date last year. Register.com said that much of that money went to short-term investments and available for-sale securities, which increased to $100 million from $26.9 million. The company's deferred revenue also declined, to $57 million by June 30 compared with $63 million at that date last year. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: News Consortium
description: A consortium that includes the broadcasters British Sky Broadcasting and CBS along with Bloomberg News said it had bid on a four-year contract to supply news to ITV, Britain's largest commercial television network. If the group succeeds, it would unseat ITN, which has provided news to the network since its creation nearly half a century ago. ITN, which has submitted a bid to renew the contract, is owned by Carlton Communications and Granada, the main ITV shareholders. The current contract, which runs through 2002, is valued at 46 million ($65 million). ITV is expected to make a decision by the end of the year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Scholar's Future Uncertain
description: The Hong Kong university that employs Li Shaomin, the Chinese-born American scholar convicted of spying by Beijing, said it had not decided whether to allow him to resume his post. Mr. Li, who was deported to the United States after his trial, returned to Hong Kong on Monday. The president of City University, Chang Hsin-kang, said he would discuss Mr. Li's case with his board before deciding.

title: A Park Emerging From a Nightmare; A New Spirit Rises Near Columbia
description: Morningside Park in Upper Manhattan was long a battleground between Harlem residents and the students and faculty at Columbia University. In 1968, after the university started construction on a new gym in the park, protests on campus resulted in the arrests of 700 students and a lasting suspicion of Columbia in the neighborhood.

title: A Town of Tents and Civil Disobedience
description: The groups that have taken sides over the Navy firing range on Vieques have more than their ideologies to mark their turf. In a twist on the idea of a political camp, they have set up a Hooverville with flags, tents, sleeping bags, field kitchens and outhouses.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Police Seek Shooting Suspect
description: The authorities said yesterday that they were seeking a suspect in the shooting death of a bystander struck by a stray bullet during a fight Sunday evening. The suspect, Juan Nunez, 23, is being sought in connection with the death of Jose Niola, 31, of Queens. The police said Mr. Niola was walking near 111th Street and Roosevelt Avenue in Corona shortly after 6 p.m. when he passed Mr. Nunez arguing with another man, who drew a knife. Mr. Nunez drew a gun and fired, striking Mr. Niola in the head, the police said. Mr. Niola died Monday. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Foot-and-Mouth Disease Lingers
description: In early June Prime Minister Tony Blair summed up the struggle in Britain against foot-and-mouth disease, which by then had caused the destruction of some 2.5 million animals and the postponement of the general election. ''The battle is not over yet,'' he said, and then added, ''We are getting the disease under control.'' Mr. Blair has been right on both counts. The number of new cases reported has steadily dropped since late April, though at a nearly crippling cost to farmers in the north and west and to the national treasury. By early June the air of crisis hanging over Britain, caused in part by the closing of much of the rural countryside, had subsided enough to allow elections to proceed and a hint of optimism to creep into Mr. Blair's voice.

title: Consumer Spending Declines As Japanese Try to Save More
description: Personal spending showed a steep decline in June as Japanese consumers set aside a larger share of their income in anticipation of tougher economic times.

title: Miscellany
description: * Grey Global Group, New York, sold a majority stake of the Paris office of Grey Interactive to Inferentia, Milan. Terms were not disclosed. The Grey Interactive Paris office, in which Grey Global will continue to hold a minority stake, will be renamed FullSIX.

description: Avoiding Freezer Burn

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRONER, HARRY
description: GRONER-Harry. On July 31, 2001. Beloved husband of Miriam, and the late Pauline. Loving father of Edward and Warren Groner, and Phillip Pressel. Dear brother of Anna Mirel, and the late Joseph. Adoring grandfather of Jeff, Steve, Cindy, Peter, Deborah, Allan, David, and Linda. Great grandfather of Greg, Brian, Laura, Josh, Jacob, Peter Joseph, Paul, Sabrina, Robbie, Adam, Austin, and Julia. Services Thursday 11:30 A.M. at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Race For Governor
description: Paul Vallas, who resigned in June as the superintendent of Chicago public schools, announced he would seek the Democratic nomination for governor. Mr. Vallas, 48, joined what is likely to be a crowded field in the March 2000 primary. Democrats see an opportunity to win the Republican-held office, particularly in light of a federal inquiry into a driver's license bribery scandal that occurred while Gov. George Ryan was secretary of state. Mr. Ryan has not said whether he will seek a second term. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Bookmaker Loses Federal Appeal in Internet Sports Betting Case
description: AUnited States appeals court panel in Manhattan yesterday upheld the conviction of a bookmaker who was sentenced to 21 months in prison as part of what the authorities called the first federal prosecution of Internet sports gambling.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MICHAELS, BEATRICE (NEE LIFLAND)
description: MICHAELS-Beatrice (nee Lifland) on Tuesday, July 31st, of Clifton, NJ. Beloved wife of Benjamin Michaels of Clifton, NJ, devoted mother of Judith Taddei of Paterson, NJ and Susan Cohen of Menlo Park, CA, dear sister of Helen Stern of Las Vegas, NV, loving grandmother of three grandchildren. Services at Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Rd., Clifton, NJ, Thursday at 10:30 AM. Interment at the King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ.

title: National Briefing
description: NEW ENGLAND MASSACHUSETTS: BILINGUAL EDUCATION CHALLENGE Ron Unz, the software millionaire who led successful efforts to end bilingual education in Arizona and California, announced that he planned financial support for a Massachusetts ballot initiative to replace bilingual classes. The classes now serve nearly 50,000 students with English immersion programs. Mr. Unz and his allies must collect more than 57,000 signatures to get the initiative onto the November 2002 ballot.    Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It's a 20-year-old system. It's not stealthy. It's designed for the cold war. It has been headed towards expensive obsolescence.''

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Investigation Of Videotape
description: The United Nations has completed an investigation into the handling of a contentious videotape that may relate to the kidnapping last year of three Israeli soldiers by the Hezbollah, said Fred Eckhard, a United Nations spokesman. Officials at the organization say they were initially unaware of the videotape, made by United Nations forces in southern Lebanon and said to show vehicles used in the abduction. ''We'll announce the next steps as soon as the secretary general has had time to consider the report,'' Mr. Eckhard said. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

title: Religion and Restraint
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times yesterday with an article about research on a proposed nuclear waste repository at Yucca Mountain in Nevada misstated the purpose of the test shown. It studied the effects of heat on rock, not those of atomic waste on metals.

title: Bush's Nominee to Lead F.B.I. Seems Headed for Confirmation
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee completed two days of largely uncontentious hearings today on the nomination of Robert S. Mueller III to head the F.B.I. He appeared likely to be confirmed as the bureau's director.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Gunman Sentenced
description: Robert W. Pickett, the former Internal Revenue Service worker who fired a gun outside the White House on Feb. 7, was sentenced to three years in prison and three years of supervised release. Judge Henry H. Kennedy of Federal District Court accepted a plea agreement from Mr. Pickett, 48, on charges of carrying a pistol without a license and assaulting a federal officer. He recommended that Mr. Pickett, an Evansville, Ind., man with a history of mental illness, serve the sentence at a Bureau of Prisons hospital in Rochester, Minn. The police said Mr. Pickett fired two shots outside the White House and pointed a gun at a Secret Service officer. Another officer then shot Mr. Pickett in the knee.

title: Bloomberg Portrays Himself As a Leader for Hard Times
description: Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that New York City was descending into rough economic times and predicted that the city's budget would be battered by declining tax revenues and rising costs for labor contracts and welfare over the next four years. Mr. Bloomberg, a Republican mayoral candidate, said his business background made him particularly qualified to lead the city through any slowdown.

title: ENGELHARD WILL ELIMINATE JOBS AND TAKE A CHARGE
description: The Engelhard Corporation, a maker of catalysts that reduce emissions from vehicles and industrial processes, said it would cut 200 jobs as part of a plan to increase its petroleum-refining catalyst business. Most of the jobs will be eliminated in Georgia, Engelhard said. The company, which is based in Iselin, N.J., said it took a related second-quarter charge of $7.1 million. Engelhard will consolidate its kaolin operations in Georgia that make products for the paper industry and its petroleum-refining catalyst plant in Savannah, Ga.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Losses And Layoffs
description: Evaporating demand for computers, cellular phones and other electronic products saddled Matsushita Electric Industrial with a group net loss of 19.4 billion yen ($155 million) for the quarter ended June 30, its first quarterly loss in 30 years, the company reported yesterday. Matsushita's revenue fell to 1.67 trillion yen ($12.7 billion), 6 percent less than in the 2000 quarter. Another Japanese electronics maker, NEC, said yesterday that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs, more than half of them in Japan, by next March, and that it would close and consolidate plants to cut costs. The plan is NEC's second announced reorganization in three months. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Priceline Reverses Fortunes And Posts Quarterly Profit

title: House Republicans Gather Support for Alaska Drilling
description: Hoping to push through President Bush's energy plan, Republican leaders said today that they were increasingly confident that the House would vote to allow oil drilling in a swath of protected wilderness in Alaska.

description: Frederick Moss, the chairman of the Cincinnati Stock Exchange, died on Friday in New York, where he lived. He was 72.

description: In a city as complicated and unforgiving as New York, almost any worthy endeavor requires men and women of great imagination.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Group Says Web Sites On Insurance Have Pitfalls
description: Many Web sites that sell life insurance do not show the lowest-priced coverage, and some have misleading information, according to a survey by a consumer group to be published today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOYCE W.
description: GREENE-Joyce W. Died at home in NYC, July 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Arthur B., mother of Jonathan M., and mother-in-law of Denise. She was one of the greatest ladies ever; she was respected for her wit and generosity. She was a friend and caretaker of all animals. Joyce was born in England, 1933. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Wednesday, August 1st, 7-9 PM, with funeral services Thursday, August 2nd, 5:30 PM. Interment in England. Memorial services will be scheduled at a future date. In lieu of flowers, gifts may given in the name of Joyce W. Greene to the Bide-A-Wee Home Association, 410 East 38th Street, New York, NY 10016; 212-532-4455.

description: To the Editor:

title: Temirtau Journal; Steel Company Buys a Mill, Gets a Kazakh Town
description: When a foreign steel company bought a giant aging steel mill here on the windswept steppes of central Kazakhstan, its executives had no idea they would also become de facto proprietors of a company town.

title: A Club Where Flamboyance Is Queen; The Barracuda Welcomes the Outr, From Tammy Faye to Tonya
description: The man who prefers to be called Cashetta is pacing the stage in a sparkly black frock and a waterfall of a wig, waiting for a first glimpse of the latest sweetheart of Barracuda Lounge.

title: Ellis and Abraham Plan To Stack Up the Sacks
description: They were like toppled bookends, two offensive linemen thrown to their backs during the first day of Jets training camp, one in the morning practice, one in the afternoon, the beginning and end of a very good day for defensive tackle Shaun Ellis.

title: More Trouble For Maker Of Software
description: The AremisSoft Corporation said yesterday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission and that Lycourgos K. Kyprianou, its chairman, had resigned.

title: As Golfers Struggled, ABC Struggled, Too
description: It seemed like a good idea, but ended up evoking miniature golf.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Union Sues On Reimbursements
description: A health care union that staged strikes at 39 nursing homes this year is suing the state for reimbursing private nursing homes for strike-related costs at private nursing homes. The New England Health Care Employees Union, District 1199, says that an estimated $26 million in reimbursements violated state rules. Dean Pagani, a spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland, said the payments were legal and necessary for the safety and welfare of nursing home residents.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: U.S. Toehold For Japan Satellite Company
description: The PanAmSat Corporation, the largest operator of commercial satellites, and the JSAT Corporation of Japan are set to announce a $100 million joint venture today that will provide voice, data and Internet services in the United States. The venture, to be called Horizons, will allow JSAT to offer satellite services for the first time in the United States. The venture expects to use a satellite to be launched in late 2002 to provide leased transmission capacity beginning in 2003. PanAmSat, based in Wilton, Conn., is controlled by the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Bush Announces Agreement on Patients' Rights Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- President Bush and a key fellow Republican said this afternoon that they had reached an agreement on a patients' bill of rights that they were sure would be acceptable to a majority of lawmakers.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Lebanon Peacekeeping Plan
description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously to begin reducing the peacekeeping force along the Israeli border in southern Lebanon, and will consider ways to replace the 23-year-old operation with a military observer force at the end of the newly approved, six-month mandate. The resolution supports a plan that will reduce the peacekeeping force, now involving about 4,500 troops, by 20 percent in the next few months. Despite pressure from the United Nations, Lebanon has been slow to deploy its own forces in the south since Israel withdrew in May, and the area is now controlled by Hezbollah guerrillas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, DORIS
description: BROWN-Doris age 72, of Wyckoff, NJ, on July 31, 2001. Survived by her children Karen Midyet of Golden, CO, Arlene Brown of Wyckoff, and Richard of Saddle River, NJ. Sister of Stanley Katz. Adored grandchildren Marisa and Justin Midyet, Marc and Jason Graziano & Sarah & David Brown. Services are today, 11:30AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, 150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: The Global Lawyer : U.S.-Style Concorde Payouts Break New Ground
description: PARIS  The multimillion-dollar settlements paid to the families of the victims of the Air France Concorde crash outside Paris represent a level of compensation unknown in Europe until now and give new impetus to the spread of American-style legal damages around the world, lawyers and legal analysts say.

title: Mayor's Arrest Hits Waterbury Harder Than Past Corruption
description: The people in this struggling blue-collar town in the hills of western Connecticut had come to accept it all: the empty city coffers, the boarded-up buildings, the magazine ratings as one of the worst places to live in America.

title: U.S. Team Selects Chelios as Captain
description: Chris Chelios, who apologized for his team's destructive behavior at the 1998 Nagano Olympics, will return to the Olympics in February as captain of the United States squad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHLOW, ROBERT W.
description: MARSHLOW-Robert W. Of Pelham, NY. World War II veteran, retired attorney, former Mayor of the Village of Pelham. Beloved father of Melinda, Robin and Melanie; brother of Carole; grandfather of Maura, Walt, Gerard, Claire and Heather. Memorial donations may be made to Community Service Assoc., 115 Sharpe Blvd. So., Mt. Vernon, NY 10550.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: The Hague: American Advises Milosevic
description: Ramsey Clark, a former United States attorney general, spent several hours with the former Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, in a United Nations cellblock where Mr. Milosevic has been held since June 29. Mr. Clark, who plans a third visit today, has ''only given legal advice'' to Mr. Milosevic and has not been hired as counsel, said Jim Landale, the spokesman for the tribunal that charged Mr. Milosevic with war crimes. Mr. Clark, 73, who served under President Johnson in the late 1960's, has since taken up causes that often put him at odds with American policy. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Commercial Real Estate; For Brooklyn, a High Courthouse
description: For about a decade, the state and city of New York looked for a site in downtown Brooklyn for the new Kings County Family Court, the New York State Supreme Court and related city agencies. They finally found it at 330 Jay Street, across the street from MetroTech Center, the 10-block complex of commercial, educational and high-technology offices.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Campaign Bill Maneuver
description: Advocates of overhauling the campaign finance law gathered the signatures of at least 190 House members in the first 24 hours of a petition drive to force the issue back onto the House floor for a vote. Such petitions are considered a challenge to the majority party and rarely succeed. By evening, 13 Republicans had crossed party lines to sign it. The petition needs 218 signatures to succeed. Alison Mitchell (NYT)

title: Making Plans for the New Economic Reality in Store for New York
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Michael R. Bloomberg, the media entrepreneur and a Republican candidate for mayor. The interview was conducted yesterday by editors and reporters of The New York Times, and it is the fourth in a planned series of interviews with each of the major candidates.

title: Fresh Flavors at a Flick of the Wrist
description: THERE is nothing quite like a freshly ground spice. Crushing or grinding releases oils, fragrance and flavor, all of which quickly dissipate once the spice sits for a while. Airtight packaging preserves the quality of ground spices, which is why those little jars release such a wonderful aroma when first opened. Sniff those jars a few months later and the excitement is gone. So is much of the flavor.

title: Mixed Data on Economy Give Dow an Early Rally
description: Stocks rose yesterday as investors took heart from economic data showing unexpected strength in consumer spending. But the rally faded somewhat in the afternoon, and some analysts questioned how sustainable yesterday's gains would be.

title: ABC to Take Over WEVD, Bastion of Liberal New York Radio
description: The group that owns WEVD, the venerable New York radio station that was founded to promote fiercely liberal programming, has signed an agreement to turn over control of the station to ABC, which plans to turn it into an outlet for ESPN Radio, executives close to the companies said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, DONALD H.
description: RIVKIN-Donald H., 77, on July 29. Loving father of David, Judith and Daniel, and their spouses, Marilyn, George Davison and Jennifer Conlin; beloved grandfather of Jessica, Katie, Sam, Alice, Harriet, Florence and Charles; brother of Mary Jane Pollack; and devoted husband of the late Lois Borwick Herman. A remarkable gentleman who led by example in pursuing high civic, artistic and personal ideals. We will honor him always. Memorial service on Monday, August 6, at 11:30 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom or the Franklin & Eleanor Roosevelt Institute in Hyde Park, NY.

title: Earnings Increase 34% for Equity Office
description: Equity Office Properties Trust's second-quarter earnings rose 34 percent as the company, the largest owner of office property in the nation, was helped by higher occupancy and profit margins.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Tire Maker's Profit Slips
description: Europe's biggest tire maker, Michelin, warned that operating income this year would be 6.2 percent to 6.8 percent of revenue, down from an initial forecast of 7.7 percent to 8.3 percent, because of the slowdown in the United States, a weak global market for truck tires and the high cost of rubber, which is priced in dollars. Michelin said first-half operating income dropped 9 percent, to 491 million euros ($430 million) from 540 million euros last year, on a 4.5 percent increase in revenue, to 7.7 billion ($6.7 billion) from 7.4 billion euros. Michel Rollier, Michelin's chief financial officer, said the company could not rule out that those difficulties would not spill into 2002. One bright spot appeared to be the sale of 4 million tires to Ford to help replace 13 million Firestone tires Ford considers potentially hazardous. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Shooting Victim Dies
description: Charmene Pickering, a 27-year-old woman shot by a New York State trooper during a drug raid in Brooklyn on Thursday, died Sunday morning at Kings County Hospital Center, a spokeswoman for the medical examiner's office said yesterday. She said the death was not reported to her office until yesterday as doctors considered transferring Ms. Pickering's organs. A spokeswoman for the state police said that the shooting was apparently accidental but that the trooper, Senior Investigator Samuel Mercado, whose gun was fired, had been placed on administrative duty pending an investigation by the Brooklyn district attorney's office. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Unemployment Rises
description: In the latest sign that Europe is succumbing to a global slowdown, unemployment in France, the second-biggest economy in Europe after Germany's, rose in June to 8.8 percent. It had hovered at 8.7 percent for the previous four months. This was the first rise in French unemployment since August 1998, as companies, which were encouraged to hire in recent years by an expanding economy, lay off workers in response to falling demand for goods and services, notably abroad. The higher unemployment rate, coupled with reports of declining factory prices in France, Italy and the Netherlands, is expected to put pressure on the European Central Bank to cut interest rates.

title: No Prosecution in Dutch Case
description: The former chairwoman of World Online International, Nina Brink, will not be taken to court over her role in the initial offering last year of the company, an Internet service provider, the Dutch prosecutor said.

title: Accounts
description: * AT&T Wireless, Redmond, Wash., to White Horse, Portland, Ore., to create online advertising, and Avenue A, Seattle, to handle online media planning and buying. Billings were estimated at more than $5 million. White Horse and Avenue A take over duties that were handled by Digitas, Boston, which continues to handle assignments like World Wide Web site design.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Harris Travel Reviewed
description: The Republican-controlled Legislature has created a committee to review all expenses of Secretary of State Katherine Harris in promoting international trade over the last three years. Ms. Harris, the state's chief elections officer, also directs an international affairs office, which this year has a budget of $3.4 million. She has made several trips abroad. Ms. Harris said she welcomed the review, which will also recommend whether to retain the international affairs office when the secretary of state becomes an appointed position in 2003. Gary Fineout (NYT)

title: Rex T. Barber, Pilot Who Downed Yamamoto, Dies at 84
description: Rex T. Barber, a World War II fighter pilot who was a central figure in the storied 1943 mission that resulted in the death of Adm. Isoroku Yamamoto, the architect of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died on Thursday at his home in Terrebonne, Ore. He was 84.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Independent film producers are turning to new kinds of outdoor promotions to fill theaters.
description: ADVERTISING may be in a slump these days as people who buy time and space grow more conservative in a sluggish economy, but not everyone is playing it safe. In some industries, people are using advertising in ways they never did before.

title: PBS Channels In New York Plan Merger
description: WNET, Channel 13, the nation's largest public television station, is expected to merge operations with WLIW, Channel 21, the Long Island-based public television station that is the country's fourth-largest, after a vote by the WLIW board yesterday.

title: Ballot Wars Have Started; Casualties Are Expected
description: Sandra Vassos is off the ballot, Peter Vallone Jr. is on. Winston B. Rouse is off, and, for the moment at least, Yudelka Tapia is on. Carolyn Younger, on the other hand, will have to come back again today to find out whether she will be a candidate for City Council come September.

title: Paul Giamatti Is a Character Actor for Our Age
description: People recognize Paul Giamatti in public sometimes, but they're not always sure why. ''It's a weird thing,'' says the actor, whose roles have stretched from Andrei Prozorov, the spineless brother in Chekhov's ''Three Sisters,'' to Pig Vomit in Howard Stern's ''Private Parts'' to a nefarious orangutan who trades human slaves in Tim Burton's new ''Planet of the Apes.'' ''A lot of the time people don't quite know where they know me from. They're not necessarily thinking that I'm a movie actor.''

title: 11th-Hour Agreement Spares Scofflaw Diplomats From Tow Truck
description: New York City gave some of its scofflaw diplomats a reprieve yesterday.

title: Tom Colicchio
description: MY minestrone looks like summer. And it tastes like summer. But the way I make it also reflects my philosophy of cooking.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Bilingual Education Challenge
description: Ron Unz, the software millionaire who led successful efforts to end bilingual education in Arizona and California, announced that he planned financial support for a Massachusetts ballot initiative to replace bilingual classes. The classes now serve nearly 50,000 students with English immersion programs. Mr. Unz and his allies must collect more than 57,000 signatures to get the initiative onto the November 2002 ballot. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Defense Panel Sees ABM Violations As Arising Soon
description: A Pentagon agency has determined that aspects of the administration's plans to test missile defenses next year would probably clash with the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972.

title: Laughs With the English Lessons
description: Like most New York City summer school students, 25 students in the English as a Second Language program at Bushwick High School will have to take a test when classes end. But their final assignments, tomorrow, will also include watching the job-switching episode of ''I Love Lucy,'' in which Ricky and Fred turn househusbands and Lucy and Ethel work in a chocolate factory. The Hispanic students have attended a new summer school program at the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, since early July. Instruction was all in English, and included viewing and discussing American film classics. The purpose is twofold: to immerse students in the language, and to introduce them to cultural institutions. Kate Zernike

title: The Comforts of Home on the Road
Seeking Refuge, in Words and Pictures
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Ethiopia's Holy Places Carved Out of Rock
BP Prevails In Struggle For Company In Russia
description: BP has prevailed in a long-running corporate battle over Sidanko, a Russian oil company in which it had invested nearly half a billion dollars, as two Russian financial groups have settled their differences, people close to the negotiations say.

title: Telepathy in Motion For Sax and Piano
description: One of the thrills of seeing Greg Osby's bands in the last five years has been his unbroken sets, a natural device for a bunch of improvisers and one that far too few jazz groups practice. In these startling performances, the natural ebb and flow of his music intensifies, then suddenly a line from a new tune is signaled and the band plays within two pieces at once.

title: Gore Set to Re-Enter Politics
description: Former Vice President Al Gore is easing back into American politics, starting by training Democratic operatives for this fall's elections in New Jersey, Virginia, and New York and then launching a political action committee to help Congressional candidates in the 2002 elections.

title: G.M. Hires Lutz to Head Product Development
description: DETROIT, Aug. 2 -- The General Motors Corporation, often criticized for cars lacking flair, said today that it had hired Robert A. Lutz, the former president of the Chrysler Corporation, to head its product development.

title: Technology Rallies as Semiconductor Shares Get a Lift
description: Technology stocks rose yesterday, led by a rally in semiconductor issues after Merrill Lynch upgraded its ratings on some companies in the sector, saying that the worst may be over for chip makers.

title: Talk Is Cheap. But Is It Disposable?
description: MOST consumers don't think twice about using a disposable pen and throwing it away when it has expired. Soon people may be able to take that carefree approach toward mobile phones.

title: AremisSoft Backer Says He Lacks Information
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis financier, retreated from his previously vigorous support of the AremisSoft Corporation yesterday after the troubled company said on Tuesday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Former Players Recall Few Heat Incidents
description: Emerson Boozer, one of the Jets' running backs when they won Super Bowl III, remembers that when he was playing football in high school he collapsed from the heat and almost died. He remembers that when he was watching a golf tournament four years ago, he walked 18 holes in the morning heat, felt dizzy during lunch and ended up in a hospital getting fluids intravenously.

title: Decision on Dredging Doesn't Stop Debate
description: The E.P.A.'s decision to proceed with the cleanup plan for the Hudson River appears to have settled the biggest question about the river -- whether to dredge it to remove the PCB chemicals on its bottom. But there are inevitable skirmishes ahead, legal experts said.

title: An Old River Town Debates Modern Change
description: To contact a colleague, employees here at the hub of government in Greene County rely on couriers, since there is no e-mail and not enough telephone lines. To type reports, social workers in field offices drive nine miles to the nearest computer, then wait to use a pair of fax machines shared by 70 people. To make matters worse, they share their work space with skunks, raccoons and cockroaches who call the outdated government buildings home.

title: Heat Kills a Pro Football Player; N.F.L. Orders a Training Review
description: Korey Stringer, an offensive tackle for the Minnesota Vikings, died early yesterday, a day after collapsing from heatstroke at the Vikings' training camp in Mankato, Minn. His death sparked discussion and review of training camp procedures in extreme heat throughout the National Football League.

title: AT HOME WITH/George Wein; Art, Life and All That Jazz
description: IF you go deep enough into the East Side apartment of George and Joyce Wein -- through a long corridor hung with luminous African-American artwork and into the farthest, smallest bathroom -- you'll come upon a black-and-white photograph of Mr. Wein with Bill Cosby and a group of jazz musicians. Mr. Wein is in the center of the picture, and everyone is poised in a mixture of bonhomie and anticipation.

title: Judge Bars Statements Made in A.A.
description: A federal judge has ruled that conversations between members of Alcoholics Anonymous have the same sort of privilege as contacts between clerics and parishioners, and has overturned the conviction of a man who killed two people in Larchmont, N.Y., 13 years ago.

title: Times Names Deputy Editor For Editorials
description: Philip Taubman, assistant editorial page editor of The New York Times, has been appointed deputy editor, effective in March. He will succeed Philip M. Boffey, who plans to retire.

title: Ferguson's Injury Disrupts Jets' Plans
description: When nose tackle Jason Ferguson signed a four-year, $12 million contract in March, he was putting a tumultuous season behind him. He had lost his starting job and, on the day players cleaned out their lockers, said that he did not want to return to the Jets because of his fractured relationship with Coach Al Groh.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Prime Minister To Stay
description: The country's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, withdrew his threat to resign after members of his ruling coalition rallied behind him and issued a statement of ''unqualified faith and trust'' in his leadership. Support for Mr. Vajpayee was renewed after he expressed exasperation with political sniping from his allies. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Leaping From Childbirth to Ballet Stage
description: As Margaret Tracey floated across the Lincoln Center stage on Sunday afternoon, every line of a perfectly fit ballerina's body where every line ought to be, it was impossible to believe that little more than six months ago she was, as grandmother used to say, great with child.

title: At Val-Kill, A Legacy That Lives In Empathy; Teaching Leadership As It Was Practiced By Eleanor Roosevelt
description: In rustic Val-Kill cottage, the historic retreat of the First Lady of the World, it isn't enough merely to keep alive the principles of Eleanor Roosevelt. Here, the basic plan is to create new Eleanor Roosevelts.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Daschle Is 'Uncomfortable' With Cloning
description: The Democratic leader of the Senate today declared himself ''very uncomfortable'' with human cloning even for research purposes as he struggled to turn the debate over science and politics back to embryonic stem cell research, which he and many other Democrats support.

title: Verdict Is Due Today in Major Trial on War Crimes in Bosnia
description: Mark Harmon, an American prosecutor, ended his final plea in a quiet voice that contrasted oddly with the scale of killing that he had just described, the reported massacre of 7,000 Muslims by Bosnian Serbs who overran Srebrenica in eastern Bosnia in July 1995.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Makers To Merge
description: Vishay Intertechnology said it had agreed to acquire its smaller rival, General Semiconductor, in a stock deal valued at $519 million, three months after General Semiconductor rejected a lower bid. Vishay, which makes electronic components and computer chips and had sales of $2.5 billion last year, said the acquisition, which includes the assumption of $229.4 million in debt, would expand its line of automobile chips and add to its earnings within a year. Investors will receive 0.563 Vishay share, whose value slipped 88 cents yesterday, to $23.17, for each of their General Semiconductor shares, which gained $1.56, to $12.82. Richard N. Grubb, Vishay's chief financial officer, said the company would set aside about $50 million for restructuring charges to close plants and lay off employees after the acquisition. Vishay also reported second-quarter earnings, excluding special charges, of $39 million, or 28 cents a share, a 70 percent decline from the comparable period last year. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: A Black Film Festival Aims For a More Universal Image; Showcase for New Movies That Avoid Stereotyped Heroes
description: When she was trying to get a distributor for ''All About You,'' her gentle romantic comedy about two black people who have given up on love but find each other despite themselves, Christine Swanson, a 30-year-old filmmaker, was told that it was ''not edgy enough,'' she said.

title: Deal Is Reached On a Bill to Set Patients' Rights
description: President Bush and Representative Charlie Norwood, the leader of a six-year campaign to enact a patients' bill of rights, said tonight that they had agreed on compromise legislation, clearing the way for House passage of the measure this week.

title: Senate Committee United in Seeking Bush Action on Emissions
description: A Senate committee unanimously approved a nonbinding resolution today that called on the Bush administration to develop a plan to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases and to take part in international negotiations on global warming.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Debate Over G-8 Meeting
description: Interior Minister Claudio Scajola of Italy survived a vote of confidence in the conservative-dominated Senate, while accusations continued over violence by the police during the recent G-8 meeting in Genoa. On Tuesday, the lower house of Parliament approved an independent investigation into events in Genoa when the police shot and killed one protester and were accused of brutality in a late-night raid on the headquarters of the Genoa Social Forum, a group that organized anti-globalization protests. The Interior Ministry and the police are also conducting internal investigations. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALON, BENJAMIN
description: FALON-Benjamin. Beloved husband of Frances for 55 years. Devoted father to Paul and Carol and Janet and Cary. Adored uncle to Ellen, Sandy, Barbara, Jerry, Sara, Jeff, Dana, Michael, Etta, Anna Claire and Jacob. Loving brotherin-law to Anne Kahan and Claire Roth. Services Friday, 12:45 PM at ''Parkside Chapels'', Queens Blvd and 66th Ave, Forest Hills.

title: The Vote to Ban Human Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrest In Grand Jury Leak
description: Federico Giovanelli, whom the F.B.I. has identified as a captain in the Genovese crime family, was arrested yesterday on charges that he leaked information about the pending indictment of 40 crime figures in another Mafia clan. An indictment by a federal grand jury in Manhattan charged Mr. Giovanelli, 69, with conspiracy to obstruct justice and obstruction of justice for what prosecutors said was a leak in 1999 to a Decavalcante mob figure who was to be indicted. The authorities say that Mr. Giovanelli got the information from a court stenographer who worked for a company under contract to the United States attorney's office. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPKINS, B. SMITH
description: HOPKINS-B. Smith. The Physicians and Staff of the Division of Infectious Diseases and the Department of Pediatrics, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons wish to express our heartfelt sorrow and condolences to our esteemed colleague Alice Prince and her family on the passing of her husband, B. Smith Hopkins. John M. Driscoll Jr., M.D. Chairman, Dept. of Pediatrics Anne Gershon, M.D. Director, Infectious Diseases

title: Amnesia on the Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Enhanced Version of MP3 Is a Case of Less Being More
description: MP3 fans may soon be able to double their pleasure, thanks to an enhanced version of the venerable MP3 audio compression format.

title: Nebraska Is Said to Use Death Penalty Unequally
description: A new study of capital punishment suggests that it is applied unequally in rural and urban areas and that defendants whose victims are affluent are more likely to get the death penalty.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From visiting Maui with children to sailing near Patagonia, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: S.E.C. Accuses 3 Accountants in Fraud Suit
description: Three current and former PricewaterhouseCoopers accountants helped the Allegheny Health, Education and Research Foundation inflate fiscal 1997 earnings and hide the fraud, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: UNION PACIFIC CORP., Dallas, the largest U.S. railroad, won a contract with General Motors Corp., Detroit, the automaker, to transport all 2.5 million G.M. vehicles moved by rail in the Western U.S. Union Pacific said the multiyear deal could increase the company's annual sales by about $60 million.

title: Under One Roof, a Time-Honored Meeting
description: Antiquity, a new store in TriBeCa, sells Chinese and American antiques. ''The simplicity of the American furniture compliments the ornate carvings and details of the Chinese pieces,'' said Kaye Martell, one of the shop's three owners. Ms. Martell's brother Graeme Mann, who owns John Piper House Antiques in Stratham, N.H., supplies the American furniture, most of which dates from 1810 to 1910. Debbie Mao, another owner, who is from Beijing, finds furniture and accessories there and in the surrounding Shanxi Province. The Asian pieces can be very old, like the 16th-century Ming Dynasty roll-top desk, right; $2,500. The American slant-top desk (center right) was made in the 1840's and is from Newburyport, Mass.; $2,800. Antiquity is at 46 White Street (Church Street); (212) 925-4444 or www.antiquitytribeca.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: CBS hopes new slot for 'Big Brother 2' soothes sponsors.
description: CONCERNED that the content of its summer reality series ''Big Brother 2'' has become too sexually oriented to play in the early hour of 8 p.m., when more children are watching television, CBS announced yesterday that it would push the starting time of the show back to 9 p.m.

title: Sharing Vacation Photos With a Click of the Mouse
description: With summer vacations and their inherent photo opportunities in full swing, America Online and the Eastman Kodak Company presented a revamped version of the online You've Got Pictures service this week.

title: Argentina Fights to Save Mural by Mexican Painter
description: An important piece of Latin America's artistic history lies anonymously in five metal containers exposed to moisture, rust and temperature changes in a storage lot a few miles outside this city.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I have read about two new viruses going around the Internet. How can I tell if my computer is infected and how do I get rid of these viruses?

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Court To Hear Skakel Appeal
description: The State Supreme Court will hear the appeal of Michael C. Skakel, who has challenged the transfer of the murder case against him from juvenile court to adult court. Mr. Skakel, 40, is charged with the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley, 15, a Greenwich neighbor. Mr. Skakel, who was 15 at the time, was initially arraigned in juvenile court, but a judge ordered last year that the case be transferred to adult court.

title: Senate Approves Limits on Mexican Truckers
description: The Senate approved a $60 billion transportation bill today that President Bush has threatened to veto because it would block his plan to allow Mexican trucks to have widespread access to American roads beginning next year.

title: FRAUD SETTLEMENT BY 3 FORMER OFFICIALS OF MAX INTERNET
description: Three former officials of Max Internet Communications of Dallas agreed yesterday to pay penalties totaling $100,000 as they settled civil fraud charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agency said Max overstated its revenue during the last six months of 1999, causing the share price to rise as high as $28.25 in February 2000. The price later plunged after the company admitted that the reported sales were false, and it was delisted from Nasdaq. Lawrence Biggs, Max's former chief executive, and Donald McLellan, the former president, agreed to pay $40,000 penalties, while Leslie D. Crone, the former chief financial officer, agreed to pay $20,000. Floyd Norris (NYT)

title: Hudson Debate Goes On Despite E.P.A. Decision
description: A retired fisherman, Henry Nichols, is so looking forward to having the river back that when the expected dredging begins in the near future to clean the bottom, he said, the workmen ''can dump the stuff right here in my field if they like.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about gay asylum seekers referred incorrectly to the circumstances that led a Lebanese woman, identified as N., to seek asylum. She said she feared that someone in Beirut, where homosexuality is a crime, would report her to the police. Her family did not threaten to report her.

title: Carter Agrees to Contract; Olajuwon to Join Raptors
description: The speculation began when Vince Carter threw down his first poster-quality dunk in a Toronto Raptors uniform, increased when he was labeled the next Michael Jordan and became deafening when Tracy McGrady split up the N.B.A.'s next great perimeter duo by leaving the Raptors to play for Orlando last summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLLHAUS, PHILIP EDWARD, JR.
description: ROLLHAUS-Philip Edward, Jr. Passed away peacefully at home in Palm Beach, FL on Saturday, July 28th, after a courageous battle with cancer. Mr. Rollhaus, 66, was the founder and chairman of Quixote Corporation, headquartered in Chicago, whose highway safety products have saved over 40,000 lives and countless serious injuries. Mr. Rollhaus is survived by his loving wife, Barbara, two wonderful children, Natalie (Matthew) Burton of Los Angeles, CA, and Philip E. ''Ned'' Rollhaus III (Catherine) of San Francisco, CA, his loving sister Barbara (Warren) Quimby of Albany, NY, adored granddaughter, Sydney Grace Burton, and several cousins, nieces & nephews. Burial services will be private. A memorial service will take place at The Fourth Presbyterian Church, Michigan Avenue at Delaware Pl in Chicago, IL, on Tuesday, August 7th at 4:00 in the afternoon. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Shelter Island Friends Meeting, Box 520, Shelter Island, New York 11964.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Real Estate Web Site
description: New York Times Digital, the Internet division of The New York Times Company, and several residential real estate firms in Manhattan announced yesterday that they had begun a partnership on the real estate Web page of nytimes.com, the Internet division's flagship Web site. Brokerage firms that have signed up to list properties on the site, www.nytimes .com/realestate, include the Corcoran Group, Brown Harris Stevens, Douglas Elliman and Stribling & Associates. The brokerage firms were recently involved in an unsuccessful attempt to create the first multiple listings service in Manhattan, but they left a coalition of other firms in that effort to join the nytimes.com project. Manhattan is one of the few areas in the nation without such a listings service, which allows brokers to share information about properties and gives consumers a wide view of the market. The nytimes.com project has been designed and managed by Gabriels.net, which was once part of the effort to create the listings service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESSEX, MARIE L.
description: ESSEX-Marie L. Parsons School of Design of New School University mourns the passing of Marie L. Essex, mentor to the stars of fashion design. Marie L. Essex died Friday July 27, 2001 after a fiveyear battle with pancreatic cancer. Ms. Essex was a member of the Parsons family for over 40 years, as a student, fashion illustrator, faculty member and Department Chair of Fashion Design, colleague and friend. She inspired a generation of leading fashion designers including Donna Karan, Isaac Mizrahi, Louis Dell Olio, Albert Capraro, Narciso Rodriguez, Peter Speliopoulos, Martin Cooper, Cynthia Steffe, Charlotte Neuville, and Michael Vollbracht. She received New School University's Teaching Excellence Award and the coveted Parsons Award. Ms. Essex is survived by husband Jack T. Essex, son Harry, sister Vivian Ascenzi and several nieces, nephews, and cousins. Memorial contributions may be made to Mercy Corps International, PO Box 2669, Portland Oregon, 97208-9652 or Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Pinochle, Anyone?

title: Ferrer Accents Message With Appeals to Different Audiences
description: Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and candidate for the Democratic nomination for mayor, is running two new television commercials -- one in English, one in Spanish. The English ad is scheduled to begin appearing today on English-language stations. The Spanish ad, which began yesterday, is being broadcast locally on Telemundo and Univision.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, BERTA M., M.D.
description: RUBINSTEIN-Berta M., M.D. The Department of Radiology of Montefiore Medical Center and Albert Einstein College of Medicine mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague on July 29, 2001 at the age of 95. Scholar, teacher and clinician, Dr. Rubinstein was beloved by colleagues and students in the United States and Israel. Seymour Sprayregen, M.D. Chief of Radiology, Montefiore Medical Center, Moses Division

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COVIELLO, JOSEPH F.
description: COVIELLO-Joseph F. Of Tiburon, California, July 30, 2001, beloved husband of Carolyn, loving father of Danielle and Christopher, dear son of Joseph and Rose Coviello, and brother of Thomas, a native of New Jersey, age 52 years. Memorial Mass Friday August 3, 2001 at 11:00 AM at St. Hilary's Church, Tiburon, CA. Interment in Valley Memorial Park, Novato, CA. Memorial gifts to Coviello Children's Fund, Account #

title: Miscellany
description: HealthVizion, Parsippany, N.J., a unit of Torre Lazur McCann Healthcare Worldwide, is opening an office in Los Angeles. David Dunn, president at HealthVizion, will oversee both East and West Coast operations. Torre Lazur McCann is a unit of the McCann-Erickson World Group, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: World Business Briefs
description: EUROPE

title: Economic Scene; The mainstream can't or won't recognize some basic facts about world poverty.
description: THERE has been little headway made in the fight against world poverty in the last decade. Yet when Group of 8 leaders met in Genoa, Italy, two weeks ago, they chastised protesters with warnings that they would only obstruct progress for the poor.

title: Appeals Court Denies Request to Reconsider Microsoft Ruling
description: Afederal appeals court today denied a request from the Microsoft Corporation to reconsider a part of its decision upholding a lower-court antitrust ruling that the software company illegally blended its Windows operating system and its Internet Explorer web browser.

title: Accounts
description: National Oilheat Research Alliance, Arlington, Va., a coalition of 8,000 distributors of oil heat, to the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, which is part of the Publicis Groupe, as its first agency of record. Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: Bush Promotes Education, And in a Calculated Forum
description: President Bush pressured Congress today to settle differences in House and Senate education bills and send legislation to him as quickly as possible, saying the state of many urban schools was a ''great and continuing scandal'' that cried out for rapid action.

title: VIACOM IS COMBINING 2 OUTDOOR ADVERTISING DIVISIONS
description: The media conglomerate Viacom said yesterday that it had formed a new unit, the Viacom Outdoor Group, by combining two advertising divisions of its Infinity Broadcasting Corporation. The move, joining Infinity Outdoor and Infinity TDI, will meet increasing client demand for ''one-stop shopping'' in outdoor advertising, Viacom said. Viacom Outdoor is the largest outdoor advertising group in North America, with more than 100,000 billboards, Viacom said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPORN, MURIEL K.
description: SPORN-Muriel K. On August 1, 2001, beautiful in her 73rd year. Beloved mother of Robert and Carolyn, wife of Arthur, aunt of Michael and Sarah, sister-in-law of Deborah, and beloved by her friends. As a psychotherapist she was instrumental in helping many of her patients, even in her brief career, to put their lives on a happier, saner, and sounder footing. Services on Friday, at 10 AM, at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Domestic Auto Sales Fell 6% in July
description: Auto sales in the United States fell 6 percent in July as the slowing economy and the continued struggles of domestic automakers dampened sales.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANLEY, MARJORIE
description: HANLEY-Marjorie. Of Scarsdale for 52 years, died in Jupiter, Fla., July 29. Survivors include Richard, Patrick, Philip, Lawrence, & Claire Hanley-Eckert, M.D. Husband, William J., predeceased her on February 16, 1998. Donations to Church of the Little Flower of Browning, Mt 59417

title: Landslides And Floods Take a Toll In Indonesia
description: After days of torrential rains, floods and landslides poured down mountainsides early this morning on Nias, an Indonesian island 60 miles off the coast of Sumatra, sweeping away entire villages and causing at least 60 deaths, local officials said.

title: Veritas Shares Fall 32%
description: Shares of Veritas DGC Inc. fell 32 percent today, one day after the oilfield-services company said its fiscal fourth-quarter profit would be about 83 percent less than analysts' estimates. The stock fell $7.40, to $15.50 a share. Veritas uses sound waves to map geologic formations and then sells the data to oil exploration companies that are looking for the best places to drill. The company, which is based in Houston, said delays in signing contracts for its data libraries resulted in lower-than-expected sales for the quarter. Profit in the period ended Tuesday was about 5 cents a share, Veritas said. The company was expected to earn 30 cents a share, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
