description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Note; Making Books
description: The Making Books column will resume in September.

title: Police Museum Bids for Status And Funding In Elite Group
description: Barely two years into its existence, the New York City Police Museum has already overcome considerable controversy. It has slashed a staff that once included 22 uniformed officers, weathered criticism that its exhibits omit the more scandalous side of the Police Department's history, and reorganized itself after an executive director was found to be leasing expensive cars.

title: Hitchcock Wins, but Rivera Adds the Sheen
description: Sterling Hitchcock must have wondered about how easy things have gone for the Yankees this season. By the third inning last night, the home team had hit five home runs and had built a seven-run lead over the Texas Rangers at Yankee Stadium.

title: The Vote to Ban Human Cloning
description: To the Editor:

title: Harlem's Visible Man
description: The long-awaited second coming of William Jefferson Clinton happened on a day of splendid weather and general thanksgiving in Harlem. Current and former elected officials lauded him as the last legitimate occupant of the White House, and the Republican secretary of state of New York proclaimed the day ''William Jefferson Clinton Day'' in the name of the governor. Family matters detained the senatorial Clinton. Rare good judgment kept Mayor Rudolph Giuliani away. Harlem's adroit perennial congressman, Charles Rangel, praised the economic impact of the former administration's empowerment zone in language akin to that lavished on the Marshall Plan. The New Black Panthers and a few others sounded discordant notes about exploitative gentrification and the loss of community identity, but they were drowned out by thousands of others in the plaza fronting the state office building bearing the name of the original ''king of the cats,'' Adam Clayton Powell. Bill Clinton, famously described by Toni Morrison as the first black president, had come home.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: TWO NEWSPAPERS SOLD

title: Technology Briefing | Software: I.B.M. Pact Lifts Peregrine Shares
description: I.B.M. said it would sell software from Peregrine Systems Inc. as part of its effort to expand its infrastructure management operation. The software helps companies cut costs by more closely monitoring the use of equipment like computers, fleets and phone systems. Under the agreement, which lifted Peregrine shares 5.9 percent, to $28.96, I.B.M.'s information technology services unit will train several hundred consultants to sell Peregrine's software and to provide systems integration services. The pact makes I.B.M. the largest reseller for Peregrine, a 20-year-old software company based in San Diego. In another component of the deal, Peregrine has selected I.B.M. to be host of its expanding electronic commerce operation, an online exchange called Get2Connect that processes more than a million transactions a day. Financial terms of the deal were not available. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Omsk Journal; In Which We Learn How to Hide a Head of State
description: Kim Jong Il, the leader of North Korea, wound up a two-day visit to this dusty Siberian metropolis today, enlivening a historic state visit to Russia with an eclectic and energetic sampling of musical theater, tank manufacture, pig farming and library science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINMAN, WILLIAM
description: HINMAN-William, 56, Buddhist, Philanthropist, Businessman. William Hinman, prominent member of the Buddhist community and longtime business leader in Chicago passed away early on Friday July 27 of natural causes. Mr. Hinman was born in February 1945 in Evanston, Illinois and grew up in Lake Bluff, Illinois. During his years at Lake Forest High School he was an all-state athlete in baseball and football and he quarterbacked a football team that was undefeated during his four year high school career. He graduated second in his class, summa cum laude, National Honor Society and was a National Merit Scholar. At the age of 15, he became a union musician and played bass professionally in a jazz band for his remaining high school years. He graduated from Cornell University in 1968 with a major in Philosophy. He was a member of the Zeta Beta Tau fraternity. Beginning at the age of 26, he pursued a career as an executive recruiter in Chicago for twenty years with great success. His clients included many Fortune 100 companies. He was an avid sailor and sailed many Chicago-Mac races; he also skied and ran many marathons. In 1992, he created SSC, an Information Technology consulting company that married his recruiting and consulting skills. For seven years he built this company as a vision and reflection of his Buddhist practice planting the seeds of Buddhist principles into the business model of corporate America. In 1998, he sold the company in order to devote full time to his philanthropic endeavors. He was an active Buddhist practitioner and leader for over 10 years. He worked tirelessly to preserve the precious Tibetan Buddhist teachings and texts. He traveled all over the world amassing an extensive collection of religious art, cultural material and literature that he made available to the American Buddhist community. He supported the construction and restoration of major monasteries in the United States, India and Tibet. Throughout his life he inspired people to aim for their highest dreams and to achieve them. His own crowning achievement was to play a major role in the conception and creation of a full Nyingma Buddhist retreat center and university in upstate New York with the help and guidance of his longtime teachers, two Tibetan Masters. The temple was consecrated three days before his death; he was honored for the fulfillment of his dream at this ceremony. His great joy and gusto for life, loving nature, generosity, creative mind and ability to listen to people will be missed by his many friends and family. Those who heard his infectious laugh will never forget it. He was a larger than life character who touched many people deeply and with whom many people identified as their best friend. There will be a celebration of his life in the Grand Ballroom at the Marriott Resort in Lincolnshire, Illinois on Wednesday, August 8 at 6 P.M. There will also be a memorial service at the Buddhist temple in September. For details please contact Barrie Hinman at 847-382-8420. He is survived by his parents, Glidden and Virginia, brother Robert, sister Barrie, nieces Lael (Jim) Stanczak and Jessa (Jeff) Heydt, great nephews Caelen Heydt and Teaguen Stanczak, and great nieces Ainsley Stanczak, Alicia Heydt, Keeley Stanczak and Genevieve Heydt. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Vajrakilaya Foundation, 119 North Grant Street, Barrington, IL 60010.

title: Flirting With a Memory
description: To the Editor:

title: Reebok Signs Deal With N.B.A.
description: Reebok International Ltd., the exclusive maker of apparel for all National Football League teams starting in 2002, signed a similar 10-year contract yesterday with the National Basketball Association.

title: Britain and Ireland Present 'Final' Ulster Rescue Plan
description: Britain and Ireland proposed last-ditch measures today aimed at obtaining a start to disarmament by the Irish Republican Army and thereby preventing a breakdown of the power-sharing Northern Ireland Assembly later this month.

title: Players Shake Their Heads in Recognition, and Then Pray
description: A group of nearly two dozen Giants linemen knelt in a circle after practice this morning. Together, for about a minute, they bowed their heads and prayed for Korey Stringer, the Minnesota Viking tackle who died early today of heatstroke.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Loan Swap Agreement
description: Argentina reached agreement with banks to exchange $1.32 billion of maturing government bills for longer-term debt, easing concern the country will default as soon as this month. Citigroup Inc., the Bank of America Corporation, the BankBoston Corporation, J. P. Morgan Chase & Company and 10 other banks agreed to swap their Treasury bills for two securities coming due in one and three years. The agreement came nine days before $708 million of bills mature. The government is in a ''very comfortable'' position to cover its debt, said the finance secretary, Daniel Marx. He said the ministry would sell $400 million of five-year notes in the next week.

title: Senate Republicans Put Hold on Farm Bill
description: At least $5.5 billion in emergency aid for farmers was put in jeopardy today when Republicans in the Senate filibustered a farm bill because they said it provided too much money to farmers.

title: ROYAL BANK OF CANADA IS BUYING TUCKER ANTHONY SUTRO
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said yesterday that it agreed to buy the Tucker Anthony Sutro Corporation for $625 million in cash, its second purchase this year of a United States brokerage firm. Royal Bank, which is based in Toronto and is Canada's largest bank, will pay $24 for each share of Tucker Anthony, which is based in Boston and controlled by the buyout firm the Thomas H. Lee Company and its employees. That is 5 cents more than Tucker Anthony's closing price Tuesday of $23.95. The purchase follows Royal Bank's acquisition in January of the Dain Rauscher Corporation, a Minneapolis-based brokerage firm that will be combined with Tucker Anthony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLER, SILVIA A.
description: MULLER-Silvia A. Widow of Dr. Erwin T. Muller, died on Wednesday morning July 25, 2001. She is survived by her nephew William Proops of Edmonds, WA, by her grandniece and nephews, her step-grandchildren, adopted family and a host of others who loved her dearly. A true lady, she was always curious about the world and delighted in young people. Though a retired teacher, she never stopped learning and teaching by example. She took charge of her life, was considerate of all those around her, and leaves those of us who knew and loved her deeply saddened at her passing. She was the best this world has to offer.

title: Bench Proves the Tonic for Whitmore
description: Liberty forward Tamika Whitmore, mired in a shooting slump, was not in the starting lineup again last night. Coach Richie Adubato said he wanted Whitmore to come off the bench to face ''lower-tiered players'' in the hope of restoring her confidence.

title: To Cut, Fold and Consider
description: Small-Scale Buildings

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Monitoring The Taliban
description: The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution calling for monitoring teams to be placed on Afghanistan's borders to make sure that international sanctions against the Taliban rulers are being enforced. In response, the Taliban's foreign ministry has warned that the use of monitors would be considered as aggression and those posted would be treated ''like enemies on the front line.''

title: Bias Led to Attack on Mexicans, Prosecutor Says as Trial Opens
description: The two men charged with beating two Mexican day laborers last fall were inspired by hatred for Mexicans, a Suffolk County prosecutor said today during the opening arguments at one man's trial.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The bottom line and the goal is, we want to change the law. And the last time I looked, that's pretty difficult to do without the presidential signature.''

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Long-Lost Dahlias

title: Mexico's Fox Pledges to Bar U.S. Trucks
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 2 -- President Vicente Fox vowed today to bar American trucks from Mexico until Mexican truckers are allowed on American highways, raising the volume in a war of words between the two governments.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: Border Attacks
description: Attackers opened fire on a police post near Kyrgyzstan's border with Uzbekistan in what the authorities believed was the third assault by Islamic rebels on this former Soviet republic. The incident follows two assaults on Kyrgyz border posts last week, and Western officials in the region are now predicting that fighting may step up in coming weeks. The authorities said last week that 12 rebels from the Islamic Movement of Uzbekistan were killed in a clash with Uzbek government soldiers last month.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: 10 Villages Inundated
description: The village of Lumbini, which is believed to be Buddha's birthplace, has been endangered by floodwaters in southwestern Nepal. Monsoon rains have inundated 10 villages near the historic site with waist-high water, though Lumbini itself has yet to be submerged. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Connecting Visor Users To Sprint Network
description: The Handspring Visor, the Swiss Army knife of personal organizers thanks to its plug-in modules, will soon be able to operate as a wireless phone on the Sprint PCS network.

title: Matching The Battery To the Task
description: IF the F.B.I. ever singled me out for surveillance, its final report wouldn't hold much interest. ''Wife, two kids, dog. Watches 'Survivor.' Aversion to mayo.'' Only one line at the end of the document might seem a little peculiar. ''Buys AA batteries by the gross.''

title: Turning the Tables on a Groundbreaking Biographer
description: BOSWELL'S PRESUMPTUOUS TASK

title: Wesley Posvar, 75, U. of Pittsburgh Chancellor
description: Wesley W. Posvar, former chancellor of the University of Pittsburgh, who led the university as it went from near bankruptcy to academic prestige, died on July 27. He was 75 and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: 'Life Is Wonderful' for the Man With a Self-Contained Artificial Heart
description: A month ago, the patient could barely eat or lift his head. He needed a wheelchair because walking a step or two made him so breathless, and a statistical formula used to estimate the life expectancy of people with heart failure gave him a 91 percent probability of being dead by now.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Kennedy Nephew Declines To Run
description: William Kennedy Smith, a nephew of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, said he would not run for Congress. Dr. Smith, who was found not guilty of rape in a highly publicized 1991 trial in Florida, is director of the Center for International Rehabilitation in Chicago, which helps victims of land mines. Dr. Smith, 40, said he would not seek the seat being vacated by Representative Rod R. Blagojevich, Democrat of Illinois.

title: A Singapore Bank Apology Blames Goldman, Sachs
description: Singaporeans awoke today to a startling act of public contrition in their morning newspapers.

title: Nearly 400 Srebrenica Bodies Found in Bosnia Grave
description: SARAJEVO -- Forensic experts unearthed in July the remains of 203 Bosnian Muslims believed killed by Serb forces from a mass grave in which U.N. war crimes investigators last year found 191 bodies, a Bosnian official said on Thursday.

title: Sports of The Times; Culture of Extremes and Extreme Heat Collide
description: There is a grammar school athletic field a couple of miles from my house, that I pass on the way out of town. Soon, youth football teams will be huddling up there, in helmets and pads, gearing up for the fall. I get thirsty just driving past them on oppressive August days, and have occasionally found myself mumbling, ''Poor kids.''

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Death In Grubman Family
description: Yvette Grubman, the mother of the publicist Elizabeth S. Grubman, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. She had undergone surgery for ovarian cancer on July 7, three days after Ms. Grubman's spat with a bouncer ended with a sport utility vehicle bolting backward into a crowd outside a Southampton dance club, injuring 16 people. Mrs. Grubman, who managed singers and bands before and after her marriage to the entertainment lawyer Allen Grubman, was 58. She had had multiple sclerosis since the 1970's, friends said. James Barron (NYT)

title: Black Couple Beaten in Bed; Attack Is Called a Hate Crime
description: Two white men invaded the apartment of a black couple in Pemberton Township, N.J., and beat them with a baseball bat as they lay in bed early Tuesday morning, the police said yesterday. The Burlington County prosecutor said the attack would be the second assault to be treated as a hate crime in that South Jersey county in two and a half years.

title: Dragging Out the Beast In the Rock 'n' Roll Beat
description: Joshua Todd has a mouth big enough to be sold as real estate, and he's been made more Jagger-esque by a short haircut that highlights his bone structure. He used that mug to great effect as he led his Los Angeles-based band, Buckcherry, through a stomping set Monday at Irving Plaza. Taking nearly every song from a caustic growl to a scream, Mr. Todd didn't bother with tricks. He just kept feeding the rock 'n' roll beast the band dragged out.

title: The Comforts Of Home, On the Road
description: PEOPLE often say they live in their cars. The 2001 Ford Excursion measures more than 18 feet, longer than many living rooms. So why not furnish cars like houses?

title: Miklos Vasarhelyi, 83, Hungarian Rebel
description: Miklos Vasarhelyi, press secretary to the reformist prime minister, Imre Nagy, during Hungary's unsuccessful anti-Soviet uprising in 1956 and one of the few survivors among Nagy's close associates, died on Tuesday, a Hungarian government radio broadcast said. He was 83.

title: Painting Pyongyang Into a Corner
description: In seeking to justify its controversial missile defense program, the Bush administration often warns that North Korea is developing long-range missiles capable of reaching the United States. But is the administration really worried about North Korean missiles? Or are some of the president's more hawkish advisers exaggerating North Korean missile capabilities and sabotaging a dtente that could undermine the rationale for missile defense?

title: One Less Thorn, Perhaps, in Peace Negotiations in Macedonia
description: The peace talks in Macedonia took a tentative, but significant, step forward today when political leaders announced agreement on perhaps the thorniest issue dividing them and this tense nation.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Exports Decline
description: The exports needed to power the Korean economy dropped by a record 20 percent in July from July 2000 while imports fell 18.7 percent. Blaming the decline in semiconductor prices for nearly 70 percent of the drop in foreign sales, the commerce ministry said exports totaled $11.57 billion, the lowest since August 1999, when the country was recovering from an economic crisis. With $11.1 billion in imports, the overall trade surplus in July was $470 million, down from $784 million in June.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Debate Over G-8 Meeting
description: Interior Minister Claudio Scajola of Italy survived a vote of confidence in the conservative-dominated Senate, while accusations continued over violence by the police during the recent G-8 meeting in Genoa. On Tuesday, the lower house of Parliament approved an independent investigation into events in Genoa when the police shot and killed one protester and were accused of brutality in a late-night raid on the headquarters of the Genoa Social Forum, a group that organized anti-globalization protests. The Interior Ministry and the police are also conducting internal investigations. Marina Harssome (NYT)

title: Blacks Hit by Housing Costs Leave San Francisco Behind
description: At 21 years old, Shanika Long is giving up on San Francisco, the city she was born and reared in and would rather still call home.

title: Ex-Teacher Denies Charges She Had Sex With Students
description: A former special education teacher accused of having sexual relations with three teenage boys from her school acknowledged today that she had invited them to her home and e-mailed an off-color joke to one of them, but said that nothing else happened.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a new analysis of data collected on Mars 25 years ago misstated the affiliation of Dr. Joseph Miller, who made it. He is an associate professor at the University of Southern California, not the University of California.

title: Senate Committee Rejects Bush Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Senate Commerce Committee today rejected President Bush's choice to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, dealing Mr. Bush a sharp political setback even as he was savoring two Capitol Hill triumphs from Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, AGNES K.
description: SAUNDERS-Agnes K., a naturalist and educator known to her family and friends as Tib, died peacefully of heart failure on July 30, 2001, at her home in Lynbrook, NY. She was 94. At her death, she was with her son, Paul Saunders, and her daughter, Marcia Dolan. She is also survived by another son, Dr. John Saunders, and she was predeceased by her husband, John, and her daughter, Nancy Saunders Raymond. She leaves 13 grandchildren: Susan Raymond Stala, Christopher Raymond, John Raymond, Dr. Paul Saunders, Michael Saunders, David Dolan, Matthew Dolan, Stephen Dolan, Mary Kate Dolan, John Dolan, Dr. John Kenneth Saunders, Thomas Saunders and Kate Saunders. She is also survived by a great-granddaughter, Olivia Stala, and by her brother, Hugh Kelly, and her sister, Claire Gilbert. She had 36 nieces and nephews. Tib Saunders (nee Kelly) was born in Utica, NY, in 1907. She graduated from Cornell University in 1929 and received a Master's degree from Cornell in 1930. Upon graduation, she worked as an associate in the Education Department of the American Museum of Natural History, where, among other things, she edited the films brought back from the Gobi Desert in 1930 by Roy Chapman Andrews. At the Museum, she met her husband, John, who later became chairman of the Education Department. She left the Museum in 1939 and moved to Lynbrook in 1942 to raise a family. She taught in the Lynbrook public school system and was elected to the Lynbrook Board of Education. She later became head of the Lynbrook office of the Nassau County Cooperative Extension, where she worked until her retirement in 1981. She was devoted to her alma mater, Cornell. For many years until her death, she served as Corresponding Secretary for the Class of 1929. She was also devoted to her church, St. Raymond's, where she served as Prefect of the Sodality. Throughout her life, Tib studied, wrote, taught and lectured extensively about natural history. She was widely recognized as an expert in the flora and fauna of Long Island and her advice was actively sought on a wide variety of environmental and ecological topics. As evidence of her lifelong devotion to science and to Cornell University, she has donated her body to the Cornell Medical School. There will be no wake. A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Raymond's Church, Atlantic Avenue, East Rockaway, NY, on Saturday, August 4, at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to the Development Office, Cornell University, 55 Brown Road, Ithaca, NY 14850-1247, Attention of Rebekah Coleman.

title: As Whitman Deliberated Plan, the Pressures Mounted
description: The pressure faced by Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, on whether to proceed with the dredging of the Hudson River was enormous.

title: Young and Old Are at Greatest Risk
description: Heat-related illnesses typically strike two groups: young athletes overexerting themselves in hot, humid weather and elderly people living in houses without air-conditioners. The initial symptoms can include profuse sweating, headaches, cramping, dizziness and vomiting.

title: Developer Looks Beyond the Buildings of Harlem
description: GREGORY PASCAL is climbing the steps to the roof terrace of a Harlem apartment building that he has renovated handsomely. It has a Spanish-style courtyard with cobblestones, tall cast iron gates, blooming flowers and trees.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Religious Display In Court Building
description: Chief Justice Roy Moore unveiled in the rotunda of the judicial building in Montgomery a granite display of historical quotations that was topped by carved tablets of the Ten Commandments. The display fulfills a campaign pledge the judge made last year to acknowledge in a public place God's influence on the law; he had displayed the Ten Commandments in his courtroom when he was a state circuit judge.

title: Phone Firms Seek More Time on 911 Locator
description: SEVERAL major mobile phone companies have said they may not meet an Oct. 1 government deadline requiring them to be able to pinpoint the location of subscribers making emergency 911 calls on specially equipped phones.

title: Online Maps That Offer Journeys to the Past
description: IT'S never too late to navigate with Prince Henry, raft down the Colorado with John Wesley Powell, chart the Pacific with Capt. James Cook or observe Longstreet's troops through a Union gunsight on Cemetery Ridge. All you need is a good map and a little imagination.

title: A Bold Gambler Ups the Ante Despite Long Odds
description: Theodore J. Forstmann is a gambler. For months, Mr. Forstmann, a New York financier, has been holding a losing hand on a $1 billion bet he made on McLeodUSA, a telephone company whose stock has tumbled 88 percent in the last six months.

title: Deloitte Parts With S.E.C. Over Audit Of Company
description: Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, took the unusual step yesterday of stating publicly that it believes the Securities and Exchange Commission was wrong when it forced a company to restate its financial results. The firm said it would not certify the revised books because it does not believe they are correct.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From road noise to used car repairs, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Florida Gives Computers in November Election to News Groups for Inspection
description: Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, today turned over four computer hard drives used to draft correspondence during the presidential race for an inspection by news organizations to determine if any records were destroyed during the election stalemate in Florida last November.

title: The 'House of Tomorrow,' Now a Retro Trophy
description: KATHRYN WELCH and her fianc, Joe Williams, were driving around Brentwood, Mo., last year looking for a place to rent, when an all-metal house caught their attention. The distinctive siding, made of two-foot-square panels, suggested a find. Maybe it was a Lustron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONTOW, SHIRLEY
description: JONTOW-Shirley. Of Bradenton, FL. Formerly of Dumont, N.J. Beloved wife of the late Lawrence. Devoted mother of Brian, Kenneth and Carol Masio. Cherished grandmother of Joshua and Erin. Loving sister of Annette Silver and Howard Resnick. Services will be held at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park Street, Hackensack, N.J. on Friday, August 3, 2001 at 10:30AM.

title: America's New Take on the World
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERGER, ROSE (''RONNIE'')
description: BERGER-Rose (''Ronnie''). 80, of Flushing, NY, and Sunrise, FL. Beloved mother of Tammy Newman, and Max and Dale Berger. Cherished grandmother of Meredith, Brian, and Erin, Mara, and Mason, and step-grandmother of Nick and Kenny. Loving aunt of Florence Weyer. Eternal wife of the late Izzy Berger, and devoted friend of Jack Pinsker. Services Friday, August 3rd at noon at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Re "Learning to Speak Their Minds" (July 19): I was astounded to read of the reaction teachers had to dyslexic students' using voice-activated software. Because dyslexia is an invisible disability, many people do not understand the challenges that dyslexics face daily.

title: Israel Defends Missile Attack That Killed 8
description: Rejecting protests from the United States and other countries that it had gone too far, Israel today firmly defended its missile strike on Tuesday that killed eight West Bank Palestinians and said it would carry out more such assaults if it felt that Israeli lives were at risk.

title: Contentious Details Await E.P.A. Cleanup Plan for Hudson
description: The decision by the Environmental Protection Agency's administrator, Christie Whitman, to proceed with an ambitious, expensive and complicated pollution cleanup plan for the Hudson River appears to have settled the most important overarching question about the river -- whether to dredge it to remove the PCB's on its bottom.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Intelligence Agent Fired
description: The National Intelligence Service has fired one of its chief operatives on North Korea for passing on information to a foreign contact. The agency said the man, identified only by his last name of Ahn, had been in charge of planning strategy related to the North and often handled top-secret information. It was not clear if he sold classified material or simply gave information to the North during meetings. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Market Place; Drug Maker Is Set to Ship Generic Prozac
description: In a warehouse in Virginia, tens of thousands of boxes filled with generic fluoxetine, the antidepressant long sold under the brand name Prozac, sit ready to be shipped.

title: Building Beauty On the Boundaries
description: DAN SNOW figures that this is the third time the stones in his chalky hands have been used to build a wall. He set down his chisel and pointed to a meadow next to his job site here on a farm in the Connecticut River Valley.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deloitte & Touche Disputes S.E.C. Audit Restatement

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about legal challenges to primary election ballots misspelled the surname of a lawyer handling them for the Queens Democratic Party. He is Frank A. Bolz III, not Bowles.

title: In the Mideast, a Run-Down House of Mirrors
description: To the Editor:

title: Footlights
description: Flights of Fancy

title: Giants' Garnes Sprains His Right Ankle
description: Giants safety Sam Garnes sprained his right ankle today during the team's first full-contact scrimmage of training camp. Garnes could not put any weight on the foot, and was driven from the practice field on a cart.

title: Crepe Hangers Of Teen Pop
description: The release this week of 'N Sync's third album, ''Celebrity'' (Jive), has been accompanied by a story popular with people in the entertainment business. And the story is this: With the Backstreet Boys in a slump, the less-than-blockbuster performance of 'N Sync's single ''Pop'' and disappointing sales from acts like Mandy Moore and LFO, teen pop is over, they say. But sometimes predictions get mixed up with desires.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: W. Joseph Brookman was named to the new post of chief marketing officer at Improv Technologies, New York. He had been chief executive at Brookman, Piscataway, N.J., a software consultancy.

title: Feeling Restless At Macy's Parade
description: I HAD frequently shopped at both Bloomingdale's and Macy's. So why wouldn't I shop at their online versions?

title: Air Canada Sets Pay Cuts And Another 4,000 Layoffs
description: Air Canada said today that it would lay off 4,000 workers and cut management pay in an austerity plan to counter slack demand and stiff fare competition.

title: Appeals Court Denies Request to Reconsider Microsoft Ruling
description: Afederal appeals court today denied a request from the Microsoft Corporation to reconsider a part of its decision upholding a lower-court antitrust ruling that the software company illegally blended its Windows operating system and its Internet Explorer web browser.

title: Political Radio Station Gives Way to ESPN
description: The group that owns WEVD, the venerable New York radio station that was founded to promote programming with a leftward bent, has agreed to turn over control of the station to ABC, which plans to turn it into an outlet for ESPN Radio, executives close to the companies said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANAHAN, ANITA
description: SHANAHAN-Anita, 79. Of St. Petersburg, FL, formerly of Flushing, NY, died July 27th, 2001. Born in Bronx, NY, she was an insurance adjuster for Home Life in Manhattan. Survivors include a sister, Patricia Shanahan, a companion, Eloise Cooke, 4 nieces and nephews and six grand-nieces and nephews. Memorial service Friday, 10 AM, at St. Bede's Episcopal Church, St. Petersburg. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to St. Bede's Episcopal Church, 2500-16th St. North, St. Petersburg, FL 33704. Anderson - McQueen Funeral Homes, 1-800-365-7211.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Some Brennan Charges Dropped
description: The New Jersey Division of Criminal Justice said yesterday that it was dropping state charges against the bankrupt financier Robert E. Brennan in light of his nine-year prison sentence on related federal charges last week. State investigators arrested Mr. Brennan at his home in Colts Neck a year ago for failing to disclose $4.5 million in assets after filing for bankruptcy protection. The state charges may be reinstated if Mr. Brennan's federal conviction is overturned, and the state will continue to seek $100 million in claims against him, said Emily J. Hornaday, a division spokeswoman.

title: Pricewaterhouse Consulting Is Planning Further Layoffs
description: The consulting arm of PricewaterhouseCoopers warned employees of another round of layoffs yesterday, primarily in its United States offices, affecting as many as 800 people, or 5 percent of its consultants and support staff.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Argentina: British Leader Visits
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair met for a few hours with President Fernando de la Ra near Iguazu Falls and became the first British leader to visit Argentina since the Falkland War between the two countries in 1982. Officials said their conversation centered on economic issues and not on the sovereignty of the Falkland Islands, which both countries claim. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: An Outdoor Fan to Rustle Up A Breeze, or Send Bugs Flying
description: Ed Schwing used to escape the heat and what he called ''mosquitoes big as hummingbirds'' on his porch in New Orleans by sitting under a vintage outdoor ceiling fan. When he moved to Wisconsin and found the heat and bugs equally inhospitable, he came up with a portable, weatherproof outdoor fan. Last year, he sold the idea to the Hunter Fan Company, which introduced the Nomad (right) this summer. With a base that weighs 136 pounds, it is a stretch to call the Nomad ''portable.'' But when tested, it discouraged bugs and stirred up a pleasant breeze. Be warned: The $950 fan arrives in three boxes, and you'll need patience, four hands and a qualified electrician to assemble it. At www.frontgate.com (search for No. 3374). Also from Frontgate, the Blizzard misting fan for cooling down large outdoor areas ($2,495). TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: PaineWebber's Longtime Chief Steps Aside
description: With remarkably little fanfare, Donald B. Marron, 67, stepped down yesterday as chairman of UBS PaineWebber, the brokerage firm he sold to the Swiss bank UBS last year.

title: Children Cruise Free
description: The 900-passenger Regal Empress, a Regal Cruises ship, will allow children 16 or younger sharing a cabin with two adults to sail for free on Halloween, Thanksgiving, Christmas and Easter cruises. Parents are responsible for each child's port charges and service fees, which can run from $84.75 to $139.75 a child, and air fares for everyone are extra. The five-night Halloween cruise leaves Fort Lauderdale Oct. 29 for the Bahamas; adult fares, with all port fees, are $519 to $949 a person. On Dec. 23, a seven-day Christmas cruise leaves Port Manatee, Fla., for Mexico; adult fares are $619 to $1,209. The Easter cruise, for three nights departing Port Manatee March 29, 2002, stops at Key West. Fares: $369 to $659 per adult. Information: (800) 270-7245 or www.regalcruises.com .

title: Arnold Will Handle Antismoking Effort
description: The Massachusetts Tobacco Control Program in Boston said yesterday that it had retained Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising ( news/quote ), to handle its anti- smoking advertising account. Spending was estimated at $10 million to $20 million for a one-year contract, which has four one-year renewal options. Arnold has handled the account since 1993.

title: House Passage of Patients' Rights Bill Likely
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The House today was expected to pass a patients' bill of rights embodying a last-minute compromise with President Bush. The vote will follow a long, tumultuous debate in which Democrats denounce the legislation as a sham, providing less protection to patients than to health insurance companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank's Profit Is Up
description: First-half profit at Standard Chartered P.L.C. rose 11 percent as the bank increased profit from its credit cards and from new units in India. A slowdown in Asia may hurt second-half earnings, the company said. Net income rose to $404 million, or 40 cents a share, from $363 million, or 36 cents, a year earlier. Slumping Asian economies forced the bank to earmark a greater-than-expected $269 million for possible loan defaults. The chief executive, Rana Talwar, bought credit card assets in Hong Kong and businesses in South Asia and the Middle East to diversify away from mortgage lending in Hong Kong and eastern Asia.

title: Proposing the Use of Computer Mapping to Improve School Accountability
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Mark Green, the public advocate and a Democratic candidate for mayor. description: Phillips Petroleum and its partners will shelve plans to build a $500 million pipeline from gas fields under the Timor Sea to Darwin, Australia, because a tangle of legal and tax issues are unresolved, executives said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHECHTER, STANLEY J.
description: SCHECHTER-Stanley J., of Willingboro, NJ, died Wednesday, August 1st. He was 77. Mr. Schechter was born in Rockville Centre, NY. He was a veteran of World War II, serving in Europe in the Third Army. After receiving degrees in Chemical Engineering from Columbia University in 1950, he joined Rohm & Haas in Philadelphia from where he retired in 1992. During his career he became a world recognized expert on industrial safety, on which he continued to consult in recent years. Mr. Schechter received a Resolution of Appreciation from the Town Council of Willingboro in January of this year for his community service over 26 years as member or chair of the Library Board, the Environmental Commission and the Planning Board. He is survived by his wife, Eleanor, with whom he celebrated 50 wonderful years of marriage in April. He is also survived by their two children, Dianne of Manhattan, NY and David of Chestnut Hill, MA, his daughter-in-law Gail, son-in-law Ray, and his three grandchildren, Rebecca, Jordan and Jacob. He also is survived by his sister, Jeanne Goldfarb and her husband Marty, of Uniondale. NY. Services will be held at 11:15AM at the Riverside Memorial Chapel in NY located at 76th and Amsterdam on Friday, August 3rd.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MP3.Com Loss Narrows, Along With Sales
description: MP3.com, an Internet music site, reported a second-quarter net loss of $11.6 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a loss of $177.1 million, or $2.71, a year earlier. The company preferred to focus on a pro forma loss for the quarter of $1.6 million, or 2 cents a share. The pro forma figure, which excludes some legal costs and costs related to MP3.com's pending acquisition by Vivendi Universal, is an improvement from the first quarter, when the company lost 3 cents a share, and from the comparable quarter of 2000, when the company lost 8 cents a share. But while earnings improved for the San Diego-based company, revenue in the latest quarter fell to $17.5 million from $21.8 million in the first quarter and $20.2 million a year earlier. MP3.com agreed in May to be acquired by Vivendi for $5 a share, or $372 million. MP3.com shares rose 2 cents, to $4.96. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Metro Matters; Take a Stroll In the Park, On a Budget
description: ''PARKIES'' -- people who care more about parks than just about anything -- held a mayoral forum on Tuesday evening where five of the six major candidates turned up and agreed on one of the easiest things to agree on in a campaign for City Hall. They admitted -- surprise -- to loving parks.

title: Mrs. Whitman Stays the Course
description: Environmentalists who have regularly been disappointed by the performance and policies of the Bush administration got something big to cheer about on Tuesday. It came in the form of a difficult and admirable decision by Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, to proceed with a plan issued in the closing days of the Clinton administration requiring General Electric to spend nearly half a billion dollars to dredge PCB's from the Hudson River.

title: Elizabeth Yates, 95, Author Of Noted Children's Books
description: Elizabeth Yates, a writer whose books, many of them for children, were more than enough to fill a library shelf, died on Sunday at a hospice in Concord, N.H. A resident of Peterborough, N.H., she was 95.

title: Lucent Raises $1.75 Billion in Convertible Stock Offering
description: Lucent Technologies raised $1.75 billion in a securities offering yesterday, providing it with a sizable injection of cash after months of seeking to dispel concerns about its liquidity.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Strip-Club Trial May End In Plea Deal
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers spent the day negotiating possible plea agreements that could bring an end to the Gold Club trial, a case concerning charges of prostitution and mob connections at an Atlanta strip club. Testimony in the trial, now in its 14th week, was postponed.

title: Experts on Mexican Trucking Say Safety Issue Is Misleading
description: About 1,500 miles from this border city, on Capitol Hill in Washington, the prevailing wisdom is that unsafe, badly maintained Mexican trucks are about to invade the United States unless Congress maintains a ban that has kept Mexican truckers from traveling more than a few miles inside the border.

title: The Power of Roundup; A Weed Killer Is a Block For Monsanto To Build On
description: Monsanto jumped headfirst into the future five years ago, when it spun off its old-line chemicals business and rechristened itself a ''life sciences'' company that used biotechnology to develop genetically altered crops.

title: Simple If Much Decorated Chairs From a Distinguished Designer
description: ''A chair is only finished when someone sits in it,'' the Danish designer Hans J. Wegner once said. These days, Mr. Wegner, who turns 87 this year, has plenty of bodies cozying up to his furniture. Wegner pieces have been available in this country for 50 years, first through Georg Jensen and later through George Tanier and his DSI network. DSI, (914) 271-3736, continues to carry the Wegner Wish chair, Shell chair and Ox chair. Now, 20 Wegner designs will be widely available through an arrangement involving Brayton International, a Steelcase company; PP Mobler, a Danish manufacturer; and Marianne Sorensen, Mr. Wegner's daughter. His Round chair, proclaimed the world's most beautiful in 1949 by Interiors magazine and later renamed the Chair, is offered by Brayton for $3,965 in ash with a caned seat, along with the 1986 Circle chair, right, $7,555. Store locations: (800) 627-6770. Here's another idea: at ABC Carpet & Home, 888 Broadway (19th Street), Modernlink has vintage versions of the Chair starting at $2,800.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUDKO, LILLIAN (NEE WOLFE)
description: GRUDKO-Lillian (nee Wolfe) on July 31, surrounded by beloved family. Her sweetness, keen mind and passion for the arts touched all who knew her. You will be with us always in our hearts. Donations to New York League for Hard of Hearing. Services Thursday, Parkside Memorial Chapel, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY, 11:30am

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHR, HILDA
description: BEHR-Hilda. Born July 9, 1902 in Limersheim, Germany; died July 29, 2001 at Anchin Pavilion, Sarasota, FL. Beloved aunt, grandaunt and great-aunt. She was industrious throughout life and was very devoted to family. She was a lifetime member of the Great Neck chapter of Hadassah, where she was a regular volunteer. She fled Nazi Germany in 1939 and lived in Great Neck until 1999. She will be sorely missed by her nieces and nephews and all those whose lives she touched.

description: Brain surgery is better than prolonged drug therapy for treating the most common form of epilepsy, according to the first study that directly compared the two treatments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOOTMAN, PHYLLIS M., PH.D.
description: GOOTMAN-Phyllis M., Ph.D. The Faculty of the School of Graduate Studies, SUNY Downstate Medical Center at Brooklyn, mourn the sudden passing of their eminent Professor of Physiology and Pharmacology. Dr. Phyllis Gootman served the research and teaching mission of the Graduate School with distinction for more than 25 years. The excellence of her research on postnatal development of neural regulation of heart and lung function earned her worldwide recognition and regular support from the National Institutes of Health. The scientific community will sorely miss her substantial contributions to this field. Throughout Dr. Phyllis Gootman's tenure, she tirelessly devoted herself to mentoring young scientists. We extend our sincere sympathy to her husband Dr. Norman Gootman, her children Dr. Craig Gootman and Dr. Sharon Gootman Rosen, her mother Mrs. Ida Adler, and her brother Dr. Saul Adler Susan Schwartz-Giblin, Ph.D, Dean of the School of Graduate Studies

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ACKERMAN, MARTIN S.
description: ACKERMAN-Martin S. August 2, 1993. You are in our hearts forever. Diane and Kell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, EDYTHE
description: WASSERMAN-Edythe. August 1. Beloved wife of the late Milton Wasserman. Loving mother of Joan Dodge. Cherished grandmother of Andrew Aronson and great grandmother of Noah and Jesse. Devoted sister of Gerald Rogers. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service private.

title: Facing Huge Crowd on Ballots, Election Board Seeks $18 Million
description: The City Board of Elections is seeking an extra $18 million to help cope with the September elections, in which a huge number of candidates will go before the voters.

title: Agency Hired to Catch E-ZPass Scofflaws
description: In an effort to collect millions of dollars in overdue fines, the New Jersey Turnpike Authority has belatedly hired a collection agency to begin dunning motorists who drive through E-ZPass lanes without paying the tolls.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about budget proposals by New York legislators misstated the amounts of three cuts planned for conservation efforts in the Hudson Valley. The Hudson River Park Trust would lose $72,000, not $72 million; the Greenway Heritage Conservancy $82,000, not $82 million; and the Greenway Communities Council $376,000, not $376 million.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: New Zealand: Qantas Bid Backed
description: Qantas Airways, which is vying with Singapore Airlines over ownership of a stake in Air New Zealand, has received encouragement from the Australian government. Air New Zealand owns Ansett, Qantas's major domestic rival, and needs capital to update its fleet. Qantas's proposal involves buying into Air New Zealand and transferring Ansett to Singapore Airlines. For its part, Singapore Airlines wants to keep Air New Zealand intact but double its stake to 49 percent. The proposal by Qantas ''should be very strongly explored because long term, it will offer a better competitive balance,'' Australia's transport minister, John Anderson, said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, JOYCE W.
description: GREENE-Joyce W. Died at home in NYC, July 27, 2001. Beloved wife of Arthur B., mother of Jonathan M., and mother-in-law of Denise. She was one of the greatest ladies ever; she was respected for her wit and generosity. She was a friend and caretaker of all animals. Joyce was born in England, 1933. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Wednesday, August 1st, 7-9 PM, with funeral services Thursday, August 2nd, 5:30 PM. Interment in England. Memorial services will be scheduled at a future date. In lieu of flowers, gifts may given in the name of Joyce W. Greene to the Bide-A-Wee Home Association, 410 East 38th Street, New York, NY 10016; 212-532-4455.

title: Robot Competitors Meet on a Soccer Field of Dreams
description: AN eight-day international soccer tournament that begins this week features all the trappings of your typical game: goals, blocked shots, even penalty cards. But you won't see any headers, and the matches certainly won't end with the winners ripping off their jerseys. After all, the players are robots, the field is a Ping-Pong table and the soccer ball is actually a golf ball.

title: Four People, Including a Child, Are Rescued From High Waves
description: Three fishermen and a 10-year-old boy were rescued from heavy seas by the police and Coast Guard crew members yesterday after their 23-foot motorboat capsized a mile and a half north of Sandy Hook, N.J., the authorities said.

title: Green Stakes Out Positions Starkly Contrasting Giuliani's
description: Mark Green said yesterday that if he were elected mayor, his administration would be profoundly different from the current one running New York City, even within the Police Department, where he would like to shift some of the overtime budget used for crime fighting to social programs for the police and for crime prevention.

title: Bad Deal on Patients' Rights
description: Representative Charlie Norwood, the Georgia Republican who has long championed a meaningful patients' bill of rights, apparently sold out his own cause yesterday. Meeting alone with President Bush, Mr. Norwood made a secretive deal on the eve of today's scheduled House vote that left his allies befuddled and angry.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Maryland: Helicopter Crashes At Airport
description: One person was killed and a second critically injured when a helicopter crashed at Baltimore/ Washington International Airport. There was no fire and no airliners were involved in the accident, officials said. The Bell Jet Ranger III helicopter was being used to take photos of an airport expansion project. Francis X. Clines (NYT)

title: Hatchette Can't Focus After Loss of a Friend
description: Matthew Hatchette was told about Korey Stringer's death 15 minutes before he took the field today, the hottest day of Jets training camp. Hatchette was Stringer's teammate for four years with the Minnesota Vikings, before Hatchette signed as a free agent with the Jets this off-season; he said Stringer had been one of his closer friends on the Vikings, because their hometowns were only 30 miles apart in Ohio.

title: Martin Stern Jr., 84, Architect, Dies; Redefined Vegas Skyline
description: Martin Stern Jr., an architect who pioneered the eye-popping Googie-style coffee-shop architecture of Los Angeles and then brought his exuberant vision to the skyline of the Las Vegas strip, died on Saturday at a Los Angeles hospital. He was 84.

title: Old-Fashioned Cotton Rugs To Cover All and Carry All, Too
description: Elizabeth Eakins Cotton, a company in South Norwalk, Conn., has a bright new take on the old-fashioned cotton rug: custom-sizing up to room size. The rugs come in plaids, stripes and jacquards. Color combinations range from very subtle to bold and bright. The cost is $20 a square foot; cotton binding in a choice of 40 colors is an extra $10 a running foot. Delivery takes six to eight weeks. This summer, Eakins is also offering a modern carpetbag in seven colors for $125. Showrooms are at 21 East 65th Street, (212) 628-1950, and 5 Taft Street, South Norwalk, (203) 831-9347. (Connecticut shoppers should call for an appointment.)

title: Editorial Observer; The Rise and Violent Fall of Patrice Lumumba
description: There is a scene in the director Raul Peck's chilling biographical film ''Lumumba'' in which the title character, the doomed Congolese Prime Minister Patrice Lumumba, played by Eriq Ebouaney, confers alone with his army chief of staff, the soon-to-be military strongman Joseph-Dsir Mobutu. It is September 1960. Their fledgling independent nation is disintegrating into chaos. ''I am at your side,'' coos the suavely malign Mobutu, played by Alex Descas. Lumumba replies: ''You are no longer beside me. You're behind my back.'' Mobutu returns soon thereafter to place Lumumba under house arrest.

title: For the Dorm, Bed Linens Of a Less Expensive Stripe
description: If you think your child's college tuition is pricey, wait until you start buying the extra-long, fitted twin-size sheets he or she will need for the dorm. But even now, at peak dorm-furnishing time, there are bargains at discount stores and Web site clearance pages, like that of www.bedbathandbeyond .com. If you shop carefully, discounts are deep. However, merchandise changes daily and quantities may be limited. Among the other Web sites that offer clearance items are www.garnethill.com, where the other day extra-long twin flannel sheets in assorted colors were $18, down from $30, and www.thecompanystore.com. Then there's TJ Maxx, where some bed linens are on sale. For instance, extra-long, twin-size cotton jersey sheet sets are $14.99; (800) 926-6299 or www.tjmaxx.com for store locations. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Bioethicists Find Themselves the Ones Being Scrutinized
description: Scientists at the Jones Institute for Reproductive Medicine knew they were treading on uncertain moral ground when they proposed mixing eggs and sperm to create human embryos for experiments. So, they say, they consulted three separate panels of ethics experts for advice.

title: Paddling Into the Past to Revel in Craftsmanship
description: Before there was aluminum, fiberglass or plastic, there was wood, animal skin and bark. The canoes originally made by native people in North America have spread throughout the world. They are celebrated at the Wooden Canoe Heritage Association site, www.wcha.org.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBMAN, YVETTE
description: GRUBMAN - Yvette. Devoted mother of Elizabeth and Jennifer. Beloved daughter of Harold and Helen. Cherished niece of Rose. She was the kindest and most loyal friend. We will never forget her thoughtfulness, selflessness and compassion. She taught us what it meant to fight and she will always be an inspiration to us.

title: Gebrselassie Is Back After Surgery
description: ''Would you mind if I showed you?'' Haile Gebrselassie said, sliding back in his chair and placing his bare right foot on a table for the benefit of a large assemblage of reporters.

title: In America; Texas Travesty
description: The state of Texas is planning to execute Napoleon Beazley on Aug. 15 for a murder he committed when he was 17 years old.

title: BUSH'S ENERGY BILL IS PASSED IN HOUSE IN A G.O.P. TRIUMPH
description: In a major legislative victory for Republicans and the White House, the House voted Wednesday night to allow drilling in an Alaskan refuge shortly before it passed a sweeping energy plan that would encourage energy production, promote conservation and modestly raise fuel efficiency standards.

title: Swelling Shelters
description: For weeks, city officials, advocates for the homeless and landlords have been holding meetings in a conference room at a Manhattan courthouse, trying to overcome some of the longstanding bureaucratic obstacles that stand between the homeless families crowding the city's shelter system and apartments they can afford.

title: Last Place, but All Is Not Lost
description: Joe Parker began the best day of his racing life the same way he has nearly every morning for the past 30 years: in the dark, mucking out a stall.

title: I.B.M. Making A Commitment To Next Phase Of the Internet
description: I.B.M. is announcing today a new initiative to support and exploit a technology known as grid computing, which the company and much of the computer research community say is the next evolutionary step in the development of the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DECECIO, THOMAS CARMYN, M.D.
description: DeCECIO-Thomas Carmyn, M.D., F.A.C.C.P., D.I.M., on Wednesday, August 1, 2001. A resident and physician in Cliffside Park, NJ for more than 60 years, Dr. DeCecio maintained a private practice until 1988 and also served at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, NJ for over 45 years as, among other things, Chief of Medicine, Chief of Staff, lecturer in the Nursing School, and vice president of the Board of Trustees. Dr. DeCecio was a member for 18 consecutive years and chaired two committees of the State Board of Medical Examiners, served as a trustee of the Medical Society of New Jersey, and was past president of the Bergen County Medical Society. In his retirement, he established and worked in Holy Name's corporate annual exam program until a severe stroke forced him into full retirement at age 83. Dr. DeCecio's parents came from Capua, Italy to Brooklyn, NY, where Thomas was born on July 4, 1910. Precocious and multi-talented, Thomas graduated early from Boys High School and from the City College of New York, played violin in the Brooklyn Boys Philharmonic, and earned spending money by providing musical accompaniment for silent movies. Dr. DeCecio earned his M.D. from the Long Island College of Medicine (now SUNY Downstate Medical Center) in 1933 and, after completing his residency at Pollak Hospital for Chest Disease in Jersey City, became the first Italian American on the medical staff of Holy Name Hospital. Survivors include his wife, Dorothy Anechino DeCecio; his daughter, Dorothy (Rori) Kanter and her husband Dr. David Kanter of Teaneck and Lenox, MA; a sister, Vivian Bua of Baldwin, NY; four Kanter grandchildren: Mark Thomas and his wife Heather Hutchison, Daniel and his wife Marianne Gargour, Sara, and Beth and her husband Peter Miller; and two Kanter great-grandchildren, Dante DeCecio and Gabriella Renee. Funeral from McCorry Brothers Funeral Home, 780 Anderson Avenue, Cliffside Park, on Saturday, August 4, at 10:00 AM. Funeral Mass to be celebrated at St. Anastasia's R.C. Church, Teaneck, at 11:00 AM. Interment to follow at George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Visiting hours are on Thursday, from 7-9 P.M., and on Friday, from 2-4 & 7-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to: Thomas Carmyn DeCecio, MD Endowment Alumni AssociationCollege of Medicine, SUNY Downstate Medical Center, 450 Clarkson Ave, Box 1204, Brooklyn, NY 11203.

title: A Surprising Early Deal In a Cosmopolitan Contest
description: The Spingold Knockout Teams, which ended in Toronto on Sunday, had the flavor of a world team championship. Seven of the 16 top-seeded teams included European stars, and an all-European team reached the semifinal after starting as the 32nd seed.

title: In the Airport Fast Lane, With Your Eyes as a Passport
description: JET lag may be an inevitable part of international travel, but another unpleasant aspect -- waiting in line at passport control -- will soon be bypassed by some people flying into London. Instead, they will gain entry to Britain by directing their eyes toward a camera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVKIN, DONALD H.
description: RIVKIN-Donald H., 77, on July 29. Loving father of David, Judith and Daniel, and their spouses, Marilyn, George Davison and Jennifer Conlin; beloved grandfather of Jessica, Katie, Sam, Alice, Harriet, Florence and Charles; brother of Mary Jane Pollack; and devoted husband of the late Lois Borwick Herman. A remarkable gentleman who led by example in pursuing high civic, artistic and personal ideals. We will honor him always. Memorial service on Monday, August 6, at 11:30 AM, at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to Congregation Rodeph Sholom or the Franklin & Eleanor Roosevelt Institute in Hyde Park, NY.

title: Shortchanging Dyslexics
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing To Cut Jobs As Loss Widens
description: The Bermuda-based telecommunications company Global Crossing had a wider second-quarter loss on higher expenses and said it would cut 2,000 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force. The loss widened to $629.6 million, or 78 cents a share after the payment of preferred dividends, from $365.4 million, or 62 cents, a year earlier. Sales, adjusted for acquisitions, rose 19 percent, to $1.07 billion from $898.2 million a year earlier. The company said it would eliminate more than 2,000 jobs and combine offices and other real estate to reduce expenses $160 million to $170 million a year. It will have 11,400 employees after the cuts, it said.

title: Profits Decline at Alltel
description: The Alltel Corporation, a telephone company that sells wireless, local and long-distance services, said second-quarter profit fell to $218.5 million, partly because of a rise in costs for adding mobile-phone customers.

title: Arnold Will Handle Antismoking Effort
description: The Massachusetts Tobacco Control Program in Boston said yesterday that it had retained Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, to handle its anti-smoking advertising account. Spending was estimated at $10 million to $20 million for a one-year contract, which has four one-year renewal options. Arnold has handled the account since 1993.

title: Gun Arrests Increase in City As Shootings Fall, Police Say
description: Gun arrests by city police officers, long seen as a linchpin of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's crime reduction efforts, are on the rise again after a period of sharp decline following the shooting of Amadou Diallo, police statistics show.

title: ABBOTT ASKS FOR FORMAL APPROVAL OF THYROID DRUG
description: Abbott Laboratories said yesterday that it had asked the Food and Drug Administration for formal approval of its Synthroid thyroid drug, one of the most widely prescribed medicines, after more than 40 years of sales. New rules have required Abbott to go through the agency's usual steps for making sure a new drug is safe and effective, even though Synthroid has been sold since 1955, before the advent of that requirement. Abbott must now race to get the approval. The agency said last month that Abbott must cut distribution of the drug over the next two years unless it can win the agency's backing.

title: America's New Take on the World
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Queen Mother In Hospital
description: Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother was hospitalized in London with anemia and given a blood transfusion after she complained of feeling fatigued in recent days while attending outdoor events with the temperature rising to 90 degrees. Aides say she hopes to return to her home near Buckingham Palace on Saturday for the celebration of her 101st birthday. It is a day on the royal calendar that prompts ''God Bless You Ma'am'' tabloid headlines and brings thousands of visitors into the street outside her Clarence House residence singing ''Happy Birthday.''

title: Metro Business Briefing | Two Newspapers Sold
description: The Journal Register Company in Trenton announced yesterday that it had acquired two nondaily newspapers in New York, increasing to 197 the number of nondaily publications it owns. The company has bought Roe Jan Independent Publishing, a privately held company in Hillsdale, N.Y., that includes The Independent, a newspaper with a circulation of 9,600 that is published every two weeks and covers Columbia and Rensselaer Counties, and The Paper, a free arts and entertainment newspaper that is published 17 times a year in Columbia and Dutchess Counties; Berkshire County, Mass.; and Litchfield County, Conn. The Journal Register, which did not disclose the purchase price, also publishes 22 daily newspapers and operates 132 Web sites.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In January Rape
description: The police said yesterday that they had matched DNA evidence to a Queens man and had arrested him in the midday sexual attack on an 18-year-old woman in Jackson Heights on Jan. 15. The suspect, identified as Moussa Blade, 19, of East Elmhurst, placed a jacket over the victim's head, dragged her through a backyard to the side of an unidentified property and assaulted her, the police said. Mr. Blade was charged with rape and sodomy. The police said his DNA was available in a database because of a previous arrest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKEY, PETER
description: STARKEY-Peter. The Mayor and Board of Trustees of the Village of Saltaire are deeply saddened by the sudden death on July 30 of Peter Starkey, lifelong village resident and a village prosecutor. We extend our sincerest sympathies to Peter's wife Renee and their children, and to his parents and their family. Martin M. Berger, Mayor

title: National Briefing | Washington: Government Helps Finance DNA Tests
description: Attorney General John Ashcroft said the Justice Department would spend $30 million to help states cut a backlog of thousands of DNA samples awaiting analysis at forensic laboratories. Mr. Ashcroft said the grants would pay for the testing of a half-million samples. David Johnston (NYT)

title: Ethiopia's Rock of Ages, Balm of the Faithful
description: Awakened to the chill of a wintry dawn in this mist-covered town hidden in the mountains of northern Ethiopia, peasants and priests groped through dark stone-pitted dirt roads on their way to prayer. After climbing to the town's highest hills, they descended into pits carved out of rock, inside which rose stately 800-year-old churches that were hewn, it is said, by a king laboring during the day and by angels toiling at night.

title: Police Arrest Man in Killings And Carjackings in 3 States
description: A 41-year-old man from this Boston suburb who had earlier boasted of killing people was arraigned in Vermont today after confessing to three killings and a series of carjackings over the past week in Massachusetts, New Hampshire and Vermont, according to court documents.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the jazz record producer and dealer Milton Gabler on July 25 misattributed the reference book ''Hot Discography.'' It was published in France by Charles Delaunay and was reprinted by the Commodore Music Shop, which Mr. Gabler owned; he did not compile it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURA, MARILYN
description: BURA-Marilyn. Co-owner of the SoHo Lock & Key. Beloved wife of the late Solomon. Devoted mother of Lorri and Robert. Loving grandmother of five. For information, call Bernheim Apter Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, Maplewood, N.J. 973-763-3505

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Travel Acquisition
description: The European Commission has asked the Cendant Corporation to resubmit its notification of the proposed acquisition of the electronic travel reservation firm Galileo International Inc., because its first notification omitted information about the car rental market in Europe, a commission spokesman said. Competitors fear Cendant will be able to use information about them gathered on Galileo, which makes reservations in 200 hotel chains and 40 car rental agencies around the world. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Cigna Falls Short of Estimates; Oxford to Cut Growth Forecast
description: Managed care health insurance companies are feeling the effects of rising medical costs and the economic slowdown -- and they are not good.

title: House Panel Forbids Closing Of Firing Range on Vieques
description: The House Armed Services Committee today approved a measure that would prohibit the Navy from closing its firing range on the island of Vieques until it found a replacement that was as good or better, a move that Democrats said could keep the Puerto Rican training site open for many years.

title: In the Mideast, a Run-Down House of Mirrors
description: To the Editor:

title: Vallone Asks Superintendents To Help Cut Board's Costs
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone said yesterday that Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy had ignored an agreement with the Council to cut administrative spending at the Board of Education. As a result, he is personally asking school district superintendents their ideas for cost savings at the board and budget priorities for the coming year.

title: Mozart Festival Opens With Trusty Favorites (Mostly)
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival opened its 35th season on Tuesday night at Avery Fisher Hall with precisely the kind of standard-fare program that has garnered the festival planners considerable criticism for their lack of artistic vision. The closest to an unusual item on this concert by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra was the first work, Mozart's Symphony No. 20, composed when he was 16. Then came Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante with two celebrity soloists: the violinist Itzhak Perlman and the violist Pinchas Zukerman. The concert ended with Beethoven's ''Pastorale'' Symphony.

title: Wall Street Lunch Crowd Gets Taste of New League
description: On the eve of its first All-Star Game, Major League Lacrosse was doing its best to impress the Wall Street types. M.L.L., a new league of six teams that began play in June, has not hidden the fact that its audience and perhaps its future depends upon power brokers in the financial district.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Television section on Sunday, with the highlights for this Saturday, about ''Russell Watson: The Voice,'' a Channel 13 music special, misstated the air time and the taping location. The program will be seen at 9 p.m., not 8, and was taped in Atlantic City, not in Leeds, England.

title: Way Cleared for PepsiCo to Acquire Quaker
description: The Federal Trade Commission voted yesterday to drop its investigation into PepsiCo's proposed acquisition of Quaker Oats, clearing the way for the $13.4 billion deal to go forward despite recommendations by the agency's staff to oppose it.

title: City Seeks to Prevent Swindling of Immigrants Over Visa Lottery
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs said yesterday that it would seek to steer immigrants from unscrupulous businesses that claim to help them in a lottery for visas.

title: Write-Downs Hurt Deutsche Bank Profit
description: One of Europe's largest financial institutions, Deutsche Bank, said today that the need to set aside higher reserves against possible loan defaults and a write-down of some slumping investments helped to cut 35 percent off its earnings for the first six months of 2001.

title: New West Coast College, Born of the Far East
description: ALISO VIEJO, Calif., July 20  On a lavender-covered hilltop halfway between Los Angeles and San Diego, in the midst of miles of look-alike red-roofed tract houses, an architectural and educational marvel reaches skyward above the Pacific, waiting to spring to life next month as the first new private liberal arts college to be built in California in 25 years.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2 Giants Join Wireless Group's Board
description: Representatives of Microsoft and Intel have joined the board of the Wireless Ethernet Compatibility Alliance, a trade group promoting the Wi-Fi platform for small wireless networks. The Wi-Fi format, also known as 802.11b, has had enormous growth in recent months as airports and campuses have established local wireless networks. Last week, the alliance announced that 22 new companies had joined the organization, bringing the roster to 103. Although both Microsoft and Intel are conspicuous supporters of the competing Bluetooth wireless standard, they have simultaneously backed Wi-Fi. Bluetooth has suffered a number of setbacks recently. In April, Microsoft said it would use Wi-Fi technology, not Bluetooth, in its new Windows XP operating system. And Psion, which had been planning a Bluetooth-enabled hand-held computer, dropped those plans last month. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: In Lawsuit, Agents Accuse Allstate of Age Bias
description: A little more than a year after the Allstate Insurance Company dismissed almost 6,500 career agents and offered them new jobs as independent contractors, a group of agents is suing the company, contending that they were illegally stripped of their employee benefits and pushed out because of their age.

title: The Glory And Tragedy Of a P.O.W. Scorned
description: War heroes and books would seem to make for a straightforward and happy combination, though there are exceptions. There is, for example, the case of Floyd James Thompson, who retired from the Army with the rank of colonel in 1982 and is a hero by any reasonable definition of the term.

description: NEW YORK

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Casino Ban For Gamblers
description: Problem gamblers can voluntarily bar themselves from casinos under a program approved yesterday by the New Jersey Casino Control Commission. Beginning in September, gamblers may add their names to a confidential list at the commission's offices in Atlantic City or Trenton, effectively preventing themselves from gambling legally in New Jersey for one year, five years or life. Violators' winnings will be subject to forfeiture. Edward Looney, executive director of the Compulsive Gambling Council of New Jersey, praised the program, but said of one registration site, ''Compulsive gamblers don't want to go into the den of iniquity.''

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Picks Thurmond's Son As Prosecutor
description: President Bush selected the 28-year-old son of Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina to be the top federal prosecutor in the state. The elder Mr. Thurmond had urged the White House to pick Strom Thurmond Jr., left, an assistant state prosecutor, for the job as United States attorney. David Johnston (NYT)

title: Factory Index: A Year of Decline
description: The slump in manufacturing extended its run in July to a year, but might be moving toward a rebound in coming months, a major purchasing survey suggested today.

title: Trading Sweat for Shares
description: IN an industrial corner of East Williamsburg, in Brooklyn, a two-story brick building reverberated with cool jazz and sweat equity.

title: Chen Has Good Start, Offense a Record Finish
description: It was one hot inning, and the Mets are far beyond the point of looking for signs of a turnaround. It is not happening this season, and four punchless months, countless statistics and trades of veterans are the proof. This is not the Mets' year.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: Splash May Have Caused Explosion
description: Investigators believe a splash of water that suddenly touched a boiler plate may have caused the explosion of a vintage steam tractor that killed four people on Sunday at the Medina County Fair. Steam-engine experts said the 1918 machine might have been overheated when a dousing of its boiler plate caused a dangerous expansion of steam that exploded the metal boiler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALONEY, JAMES D.
description: MALONEY-James D. After a short, but courageous battle against cancer, 72 year old James Maloney of Juno Beach, FL, passed away on July 30, 2001. Born to Irish immigrant parents on February 28, 1929 in Cincinnati, OH, Mr. Maloney carved out a full and meaningful life along with an illustrious career in the soft drink industry that spanned more than four decades. He began that career in 1954 when he joined the Pepsi Cola Bottling Co. as an assistant driver. Mr. Maloney steadily rose through the ranks of Pepsi Cola in Cincinnati, Philadelphia, Los Angeles, and finally New York, where he was named Vice President of National Sales. In 1986, Mr. Maloney joined the Coca Cola Bottling Co. of Ohio as President, Chief Executive Officer. After a short stint in Akron, he moved to the Big Apple where he was named President and Chief Operating Officer of The Coca Cola Bottling Co. of New York, Inc. Mr. Maloney retired in 1996 as Chairman and CEO of the company. He resided in Juno Beach with his wife of fifty years, Jean Ann Maloney. He is also survived by his children, James T. & Rita Maloney of Acworth, GA, Kathleen Tebbe & her partner of nine years, Jim Quigley of Birmingham, MI., and Kevin Maloney of Jupiter, FL. He will be sorely missed by his six grandchildren, Allison, Shannon, Jennifer, Ryan, Thomas and Daniel along with their mother, Terry Maloney. He is also survived by his loving brother, Thomas J. Maloney of Cincinnati, OH. An avid golfer, Mr. Maloney was a member of Ballen Isle Country Club. He was also a Communicant of St. Patrick's Catholic Church, Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Visitation will be 9AM-11AM Saturday, August 4, at Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, 250 Center St, Jupiter, FL. Mass of the Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11:30 AM Saturday at St. Patrick's Catholic Church, 13591 Prosperity Farms Rd, Palm Beach Gardens with Rev. Bernard Dooley as celebrant. Family requests donations in Mr. Maloney's memory to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Ave, West Palm Beach, FL. 33407.

title: Parallels in Problems Found at 2 Banks, 10 Years Apart
description: A decade ago, federal and state regulators in New York cracked down on an overleveraged bank that was making risky loans to real estate developers and engaging in what they called ''hazardous lending and lax collection policies.''

title: Debate on Expanding O'Hare Airport Moves to House Panel
description: Taking a blunt approach to air travel delays, a House subcommittee took up a bill today to forbid states to block airport expansion and, specifically, would allow Chicago to rebuild O'Hare International Airport and add a runway without state permission.
