title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about gay asylum seekers referred incorrectly to the circumstances that led a Lebanese woman, identified as N., to seek asylum. She said she feared that someone in Beirut, where homosexuality is a crime, would report her to the police. Her family did not threaten to report her.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Another Round . . . Of Water?
description: Germans are losing their taste for beer, and turning into a nation of mineral-water drinkers, the Federal Statistics Office said. Beer sales were down by 4.3 percent to 1.4 billion gallons in the first half of this year, continuing a six-year decline in German beer consumption. But mineral-water consumption has climbed markedly from a per-capita annual consumption of 3.3 gallons in 1970 to 26.2 gallons in 2000. Experts attribute the decline to a public that is more health-conscious, as well as to high unemployment and an overall sluggish economy. Victor Homola

title: An Up-to-the-Minute Sign for a Company in the Business of News
description: Motorola two-way pagers (the new sign on the east side of Broadway, between 42nd Street and 43rd Street) meet the new Reuters sign (coming, perhaps in November, on the west side of Broadway, between 42nd Street and 43rd Street). If architecture in Times Square in the 21st century consists of ''My Sign's Better Than Your Sign,'' the Reuters headquarters building, left, is about to demand its 15 minutes of attention.

title: Band of Nevada Ranchers Clashes With Government on Cattle Grazing Fees
description: Ben Colvin's family ranching roots in Nevada date back to before the Civil War. Jack Vogt started ranching in California just after World War II with a single cow and wound up with a large herd in south-central Nevada.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Spinoff Income
description: The home-improvement retailer Kingfisher said it expected to earn 1.1 billion, or $1.57 billion, from the spinoff of its Woolworth's stores, the sale of Superdrug and a sale and leaseback of 180 stores. Kingfisher is shedding businesses to focus on home-improvement and consumer electronics. Last month, the company sold the Superdrug chain to Kruidvat Beheer of the Netherlands for 310 million ($442 million). Shareholders are expected to vote on the spinoff of Woolworth's on Aug. 24. If approved, the shares are scheduled to begin trading on Aug. 28. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Official Plans Senate Run
description: Secretary of State Elaine Marshall said she would seek the Democratic nomination for United States Senate in 2002, for the seat held by Senator Jesse Helms, a Republican. Mr. Helms, 79, is to announce in September whether he will seek a sixth term. Ms. Marshall, 55, a lawyer and former state senator, in 1996 became the first woman elected to statewide executive office in North Carolina. Eric Miller Reeves, a 37-year-old state senator from Raleigh, has also said he will seek the Democratic nomination.

title: Gateway Heads for Campus With a New Notebook
description: With the school year soon to start, computer makers have begun rolling out machines intended to wind up in knapsacks.

title: Lawton Enjoying Role Around Top of Lineup
description: When Matt Lawton told Mets Manager Bobby Valentine that he did not see himself as a classic leadoff hitter, he did not mean that he does not enjoy the role.

title: The Latest in Leisure Wear For Hand-Held Organizers
description: You see them at the beach and playground: people who cannot bear to leave their Palm 505 or Visor Prism at home. They are the ones hunched over their hand-held organizers as if to shield them from harm. Now a lightweight sleeve made from clear plastic, woven string and two strips of Velcro can protect the treasured devices from blowing sand and spilled water.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERCOVICI, LOLA
description: BERCOVICI-Lola on July 31, 2001, at age 79. She was a New York City public school teacher for 26 years, an artist and active in the Council Senior Center in Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late Alfred, loving mother of Jon and his wife Linda, dear sister of Charlotte Frank and Louis Kizner. Adoring grandmother of Elizabeth and Amanda. Visiting hours on Thursday 7-9PM. service Friday 9:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

She was a devoted nurse who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Friday, August 3rd, 10-12 noon with service following at noon.

title: World Briefing | The World: Population Forecast
description: The human population is likely to stop growing by 2100 as sharp drops in birthrates in some countries make up for continued growth in others, a new scientific analysis has found. The research, described in Nature, adds credence to predictions that explosive growth seen in recent decades will not persist much beyond the middle of this century. The analysis finds that the most likely world population at the turn of the next century will be about 8.4 billion people, while the latest long-term assessment by the United Nations has 9.4 billion as the middle of its range.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Money-Laundering Scheme
description: Millions of dollars in drug money was laundered in the garment district, said Mary Jo White, the United States attorney in Manhattan, who unsealed indictments yesterday against 11 people. Gigolo Enterprises and Designers Concepts, both on West 38th Street, were fronts for a gang made up mostly of Lebanese immigrants who had lived in Colombia, Ms. White said. She said the group received millions of dollars in cash stuffed in suitcases and bags, then sent the money to associates in Colombia through a network of companies and bank accounts in New York, Florida and Hong Kong. No one answered the phone at the two businesses.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Space Plans
description: A new $100 million space program for Nigeria will be used to identify mining areas and develop the country's information technologies, said President Olusegun Obasanjo, according to the state-owned Daily Times. He talked about the plans on Tuesday during the inauguration of the Honorary Presidential Advisory Council on Science and Technology.

description: A new study raises serious concerns about the way the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission assigns priorities to worker claims and questions whether the agency can ever fulfill its mission of handling employment discrimination complaints without more money.

title: Tweaking Technology to Stay Ahead of the Film Pirates
description: WHAT is the first thing you notice when you slip a videocassette or DVD into its player? Before the main feature and even before the ubiquitous trailers and ads comes a copyright warning from the F.B.I. that threatens, among other things, civil and criminal penalties for unauthorized reproduction.

title: A Scientist's Art: Computer Fiction
description: VERNOR VINGE, a computer scientist at San Diego State University, was one of the first not only to understand the power of computer networks but also to paint elaborate scenarios about their effects on society. He has long argued that machine intelligence will someday soon outstrip human intelligence.

title: U.S. Scholar Might Be Freed Friday From Russian Prison
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- Russian judicial authorities indicated today that an American Fulbright scholar imprisoned on marijuana-related charges since February would probably be freed from a prison on the Ukrainian border as early as Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article on Tuesday about four productions at the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., misstated the circumstances under which the original production team for Handel's ''Agrippina'' was replaced two months ago after a disagreement with Paul Kellogg, the company's artistic director. The team withdrew; it was not fired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUARD, SARAH (''SALLY'')
description: GUARD-Sarah (''Sally''). Sally died peacefully July 28 at St. Vincent's Hospital with her husband, David Burger, at her side. Their daughters, Emma and Cameron, were at home nearby with Sally's mother, Gretchen, and her aunt, Sarah Ballard. Born January 26, 1963, near Sydney, Australia, Sally was the daughter of Gretchen, a painter currently of Santa Fe, NM, and the late David Guard, a founding member of The Kingston Trio. Along with her sister, Catherine, and brother, Tom, Sally grew up in Whale Beach, Australia, and in Palo Alto and Portola Valley, CA. She went to Woodside High School and spent spent summers at the Bar 717 Ranch in Trinity County, CA. In 1980, Sally headed to Middlebury College, where she would play varsity soccer, major in English, study French and Italian, and play saxophone in the Ripton Blues Band. After graduating in 1984, she became a reporter at Sports Illustrated in Manhattan, covering golf and the Winter Olympics, as well as soccer, the sport she loved most. She met David, now an economist and senior analyst at Moody's, in a guitar class at The New School in 1993, and they were married 2 years later. Sally was a senior editor when she left Sports Illustrated in 1995, shortly before Emma was born, then an editor at Bishop Books until Cameron arrived in 1998. After that, she devoted her time to her girls and to David, with whom she found enormous joy and fulfillment. She will be remembered for her wit, her artful turn of phrase, her letters, her love of music, language and arts, her honesty, generosity, and for her commitment to family and friends. She was a unique and loving soul, and will be deeply missed. A memorial service will be held at The Orensanz Foundation for the Arts, 172 Norfolk St, NYC on Saturday, August 11, at 1PM. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Ave So., 21 Fl, NY, NY 10016. Please include Sally's name and that acknowledgement should be made to David Burger, 50 Walker St, Apt 4B, NY, NY 10013.

Reason to Believe: Garciaparra Is Back
description: Nomar Garciaparra had taken 20 minutes of intense fielding practice, darting to his left or right, flipping throws to second and pumping throws across to first base, before stopping and then standing motionless at shortstop on Wednesday. Now he was waiting for one of the Red Sox to arbitrarily slap a few more grounders toward him.

title: Mistakes Cited in Downing of Plane in Peru
description: A disastrous series of mistakes, marked by language problems, poor communications and shortcuts in following established procedures, led to the shooting down in April of a small plane carrying a missionary family in Peru by a Peruvian fighter involved in a joint United States-Peruvian antidrug operation, an inquiry by the two countries concluded in a report released today.

title: Shades of the Kirov but Not Cecil B. DeMille
description: The Universal Ballet from South Korea, which made its New York debut in 1998 at City Center, returned to the New York State Theater on Wednesday night with ''La Bayadre'' for a brief run through Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: BARR LABORATORIES SHIPS ITS GENERIC PROZAC
description: Barr Laboratories began shipping its cheaper generic version of Prozac yesterday, winning regulatory approval after a prolonged patent fight with Eli Lilly & Company. Barr said it won the right to sell a 20-milligram generic version of Prozac, more than five years after first challenging a Lilly patent. Consumers should be able to buy the generic drug in a few days, Barr said. Lilly's patent expired Feb. 2, but the company received six months of additional protection by taking advantage of an extension the Food and Drug Administration grants for testing drugs for use in children. That right expired yesterday. Lilly has said it believes its patents are still valid and plans to appeal to the Supreme Court. Prozac had sales last year of $2.6 billion.

description: Zabriskie Gallery

title: COURT RULES AGAINST BOEING ON $419 MILLION TAX REFUND
description: A federal appeals court ruled against Boeing yesterday, overturning a $419 million tax refund for 1979 through 1987 and saying the company misallocated research and development costs attributable to export sales. The court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, ruled in favor of the Internal Revenue Service, which had appealed a trial court's ruling in favor of the company. The court said it agreed with the I.R.S. that Boeing's method of allocating research and development costs violated a requirement for the allocation of total costs. The I.R.S. argued that Boeing improperly allocated those costs to two sales units that qualified for favorable tax treatment, when it should have spread the costs among all sales units. Boeing had paid the required amount to the I.R.S. and requested a refund. It sued in 1996 after the I.R.S. did not grant its request.

title: Investors See Some Missteps By SunTrust
description: With shareholders due to determine the winner today in the battle for control of the Wachovia Corporation, analysts and major investors are predicting that First Union will prevail over the rival bidder, SunTrust Banks.

title: G.M.-Daewoo Talks Said to Be Stalled
description: Negotiations between General Motors and the creditors of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor of South Korea are at a standstill and are in danger of failure, according to people close to the talks.

title: Warily Awaiting The Numbers
description: Michael Cristofer is holed up in his Los Angeles hotel suite, nursing a cold and preparing for a day of interviews for the opening on Friday of his latest movie, ''Original Sin'' (review, this page). As soon as he can, though, he intends to get out of town and await the opening weekend grosses from a place where no one knows about or cares about the box-office numbers. ''It's getting harder and harder to find such a place,'' he said.

description: Bernadette Banhidi is opening Tunity, New York, a marketing and image consulting company, as chief executive. Ms. Banhidi had been marketing vice president at Claessens International, London.

Thompson, a retired army colonel, and ''Glory Denied,'' a new book about his ordeal as a prisoner of war in Vietnam, misstated the location of Fort Bragg, where his family lived at one point during his imprisonment. It is in North Carolina, not Georgia.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trizechahn's Profit Falls
description: The TrizecHahn Corporation, a Canadian real estate company headed by the financier Peter Munk, said second-quarter earnings fell 7.3 percent, reflecting the loss of revenue from more than $2.3 billion of property sales. The company, whose properties include the Sears Tower in Chicago and 1 New York Plaza, posted funds from operations -- a measure of cash flow -- of $84.7 million, or 56 cents a share, down from 91.4 million, or 58 cents, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $273.8 million from $308 million. The company, based in Toronto, has brought in new managers and sold Canadian office and European retail properties to pay debt and focus on properties in the United States.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hevesi And Louima To Campaign
description: City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi plans to campaign for mayor on Sunday with his most recent high-profile supporter, Abner Louima, the living symbol of police brutality in New York. Aides to Mr. Hevesi, who is white, hope that Mr. Louima's surprise endorsement will help the comptroller's candidacy among black voters. The two men are expected to campaign together in Brooklyn, Harlem and the Bronx. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: La Guardia Flight Lottery Continues
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will announce today that it is giving itself another year to figure out how to limit the number of planes flying to La Guardia Airport, officials said, and will continue using a lottery system for new flights it adopted in December. The agency started the lottery after the airport could not efficiently handle the new flights that airlines added in the summer and fall of 2000 because Congress lifted longstanding restrictions on access to the airport. Delays at La Guardia used to account for 25 percent of the nation's total, but the lottery reduced that to 10 percent.

title: Metro Business Briefing | A Landmark Reopens
description: An office building at 48 Wall Street, previously the headquarters of the Bank of New York, has been reopened after a renovation, and 65 percent of it is occupied, officials with Swig Burris Equities LLC have announced. Swig Burris, a New York real estate development, investment and management company, bought the 34-story, 324,000-square-foot tower in 1998 in association with Kirkpatrick MacDonald and Bryce MacDonald of MacDonald & Cie, an investment company in Manhattan. On the northeast corner of Wall and William Streets, the building retains its original 1929 detail in addition to numerous high-tech upgrades, officials said. When renovation began about three years ago, the intention was to convert the office space into rental units, but that decision changed because of a growing need for commercial space. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SENATORE, CARRIE
description: SENATORE-Carrie. On July 31, 2001, cherished sister of Peggy, Marie, and Jack. Loving sister-inlaw of Henry Palumbo. Beloved aunt of Michael, Joseph, John, Linda, and Nancy. Also survived by six great nieces and nephews. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 A.M. at Saint Jean Baptiste Church, 76th Street and Lexington Avenue, NYC. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations preferred to Calvary Hospital and The American Cancer Society, in her memory. For further information contact Krtil-Yorkville Funeral Service at: 212-744-3084.

title: Astros Put Another Loss In Riggan's Notebook
description: Jerrod Riggan has kept a diary since the first week of March, recording his experiences and putting his spiritual beliefs in writing. Riggan, a rookie right-hander for the Mets, will one day reflect on his entries from this week in Houston, where he lost two extra-inning games for the first decisions of his big league career. The pages will describe the first lessons in losing of a young player's major league life.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FURST, EDNA
description: FURST-Edna. Beloved wife of the late Hyman. Loving mother of Rayna and Robert Alperstein and Michael and Barbara Furst. Dear sister of Lawrence Silver & Cecily Gutter. Devoted grandmother of Joann, Leslie & Matthew. Ecstatic great-grandmother of Rachael Ann. Service private.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Slide In Chip Sales Continues
description: Semiconductor sales extended their steep decline into June, tumbling 9 percent from May and 31 percent year over year, a trade group said. Worldwide revenue of chip makers fell to $11.60 billion, compared with $12.71 billion the previous month and $16.74 billion in June 2000, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association, based in San Jose, Calif. The Americas were the hardest hit, with a year-over-year decline of 45 percent. George Scalise, the association's president, predicted that chip makers would continue to work off accumulated inventory for three more months before quarterly growth resumes in the last quarter of 2001. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor sector index gained $20.08, or 3.2 percent, to $656.62. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Profit Forecast By Sharp
description: The electronics maker Sharp Corporation will miss its first-half operating profit forecast by about 8 percent after chip and liquid-crystal display prices fell more than expected. Operating profit at the company, the leading maker of liquid crystal displays in Japan, will be about 50 billion yen ($401 million) in the six months ending Sept. 30, the chief financial officer, Hiroshi Saji, said. The forecast relieved concern that the company might post a loss, and its shares rose 4 percent, to 1,477 yen ($11.87).

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Safir's Security Is Cut
description: The security detail for Howard Safir, left, who resigned as police commissioner last August, has been reduced to four detectives from seven. The change, reported yesterday by The Daily News and later confirmed by a police official, was ordered by the current police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik. In the past, Mr. Kerik has said that the security provided for Mr. Safir was justified by police intelligence reports. But Mr. Kerik and other police officials have declined to be specific about any dangers to Mr. Safir, who works in New York as a consultant to a corporate investigations firm in Atlanta. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Miner's Profit Rises
description: The mining company, the Rio Tinto Group, said first-half profit rose 24 percent after $4 billion in acquisitions helped offset an economic slowdown. ''This is an extraordinarily severe downturn compared with others we have seen,'' the chairman of Rio Tinto, Robert Wilson, said. ''At this stage, we don't see where the motor for recovery is going to come from. There's nothing that would encourage us in the U.S., Europe or Japan.'' The comment came after Rio reported that net income rose to $841 million, or 61.2 cents a share, in the six months ended June 30, from $677 million, or 49.4 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Making Fun With Feet and Tongue
description: ''Imagine a business where people give you money and you give them back absolutely nothing,'' says a smooth-talking Hong Kong gangster (John Lone) toward the end of Brett Ratner's ''Rush Hour 2.'' He's not talking about the movie industry but trying to explain the complicated international counterfeiting scheme that provides this ramshackle sequel with the semblance of a plot. Fans of the first ''Rush Hour,'' which earned nearly $250 million worldwide, will not fork over their cash entirely in vain. Though it lacks some of the high-spirited spark of the original -- it often feels like the fifth or sixth rather than the second in a franchise series -- the action and humor are enough to make an hour and a half pass quickly and pleasantly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOREN, ALBERT J. (NUNU)

Beloved brother-in-law of Jim Heatherly. Survived by seven nephews, two nieces, 3 great-nephews & 4 great-nieces. Memorial service will be held on Sunday, August 12, 1 P.M., at St. James Lutheran Church, 2776 Gerritsen Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11229.

title: Residential Real Estate; 356 Units Under New City Bond Plan
description: A 356-apartment rental complex at Seventh Avenue and 26th Street, part of a spurt of residential building in Chelsea, is the first to be financed under a city-sponsored taxable bond program that offers developers quicker, if somewhat more expensive, access to financing.

description: The Walt Disney Company announced quarterly financial results yesterday that modestly exceeded analysts' expectations.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: WASHINGTON GROUP FILES LAWSUIT AGAINST RAYTHEON
description: Washington Group International said yesterday that it had sued the Raytheon Company over more than $1.5 billion in fees and payments in the purchase of Raytheon's construction unit. Officials of Washington Group, of Boise, Idaho, are seeking to recover $822 million and avoid repaying $700 million in indemnity payments to Raytheon, a spokesman said. The lawsuit was filed as part of a bankruptcy filing by Washington Group. The company filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors in May after accusing Raytheon of hiding cost overruns in its engineering and construction unit, which Washington Group agreed to acquire last year for $503 million in cash and assumed debt. Officials with Raytheon were not immediately available for comment.

title: Lillian Kiesler, 91, Artist and Art Patron
description: Lillian Kiesler, an artist, art patron and the widow of the sculptor and avant-garde architect Frederick Kiesler, died on July 25 in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRUBMAN, YVETTE
description: GRUBMAN-Yvette. Our beautiful, spirited friend; our most brilliant example of fortitude and strength. May the best be yet to be-wear your tank tops in paradise and rain your blessings down on Harold, Elizabeth, Jennifer and your grieving friends. Gail, Starr, Richard and Evan

title: VYSIS SHARES JUMP ON NEWS OF APPROVAL FOR CANCER TEST
description: Vysis Inc. said yesterday that it had won Food and Drug Administration approval to sell its UroVysion test for bladder cancer, setting off an 11 percent gain in its stock price. Vysis shares, which have more than tripled this year, rose $2.65, to $26.65. UroVysion is the first test to be approved by the F.D.A. for monitoring the recurrence of bladder cancer by detecting genetic changes in bladder cells, the company said. Vysis, based in Downers Grove, Ill., estimates a market potential of 1.5 million tests a year.

title: Defiant Legislators Proceed on Budget Spurned by Pataki
description: The State Legislature passed a stripped-down budget early this morning, four months overdue, defying Gov. George E. Pataki only hours after he declared that the spending plan was unconstitutional and would cause many government programs to run out of money.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: With Thom, Jonathan Eismann gets to find out if you can go home again. Mr. Eismann, a New Yorker who earned his stripes at Batons, Fandango and China Grill in Manhattan, headed for Miami in the mid-1990's, took his Pacific Rim cooking with him and opened the highly acclaimed Pacific Time in South Beach. Now he's back, in a small renovated hotel on Thompson Street, where Asian flavors color the menu -- Thom means soup in Thai -- but American ingredients define it.

title: Hate Motives Are Argued In Beating Of Mexicans
description: Prosecutors had a bit of a victory and a bit of a defeat today, as they tried to establish that a man accused of the beating of two immigrant day laborers was motivated by a hatred for Mexicans.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Profit Falls
description: France's third-largest bank, Socit Gnrale, became the latest to report a lower profit because of the slowing economy and lagging securities markets, announcing that second-quarter net income dropped almost 15 percent, to 641 million euros ($566 million) or 1.60 euros a share, from 752 million euros or 1.89 euros a share, a year ago. Investors bid up Socit Gnrale shares more than 4 percent, apparently reflecting the strength of consumer banking, the mainstay of the bank, where operating income fell 8.5 percent, in contrast to a 25 percent drop in corporate and investment banking. Daniel Bouton, the chairman, pledged measures to control costs, including the elimination of about 170 jobs in investment banking. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Shinjo's Preparation Pays Off in the 10th
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 2 — If there is a reason Tsuyoshi Shinjo has played well all season, it is his ability to adjust to pitchers and conditions. Sometimes, he has made those adjustments from one day to the next. On Wednesday, one adjustment helped win a game for the Mets.

title: Gephardt Launches an Attack on Bush's Foreign Policy
description: Drawing clear battle lines with the White House on foreign policy, Representative Richard A. Gephardt accused the Bush administration today of an obsession with missile defense and of pursuing a unilateralist approach to world affairs that risks antagonizing Russia and undermining relations with Europe.

title: The Dangers of Voting Outside the Booth
description: Major reports on election reform have come out in the past few weeks from scholars at the California Institute of Technology and M.I.T., a commission led by former Presidents Gerald Ford and Jimmy Carter, and the Constitution Project of Georgetown University's Public Policy Institute. Most reaction in the press has focused on the groups' varying proposals that seem related to last fall's Florida election, like eliminating punch-card voting machines; letting everyone who comes to the polls on Election Day vote, even though a lack of registration might disqualify ballots later; extending voting hours; and perhaps moving Election Day to a holiday or a weekend. Virtually unmentioned is something all three reports have in common: a concern about the explosion in voting that doesn't involve going to the polls on Election Day.

title: Senate Votes Down Money for Gun Buyback
description: The Senate defeated an effort to restore financing to a federal gun buyback program, which President Bush had said he wanted to eliminate.

title: Corky Lee -- 'Not on the Menu: From Asian Pacific Islander Roots to American Reality'
description: Museum of Chinese in the Americas

title: Interpublic Buys DeVries Agency
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that it had acquired DeVries Public Relations in New York, which specializes in public relations for marketing companies. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Satellite TV Service Adds Internet
description: DirecTV, which is owned by the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors , said yesterday that it would offer two-way, satellite-based broadband Internet service throughout the United States. The service, to be called Direcway, will be available through independent satellite dealers and retail outlets later this year for $59.99 to $69.99 a month. Last week, the company announced that it had reached 10 million subscribers. Larry Chapman, an executive vice president at DirecTV, said the company expected strong sales because of its well-established retail presence. Direcway is being offered in addition to the DirecTV D.S.L. service, which the company began marketing to consumers this spring. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hearing For Health Bill
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, who is running for mayor, has scheduled an Aug. 21 hearing for a bill that would provide a 10-foot buffer around women within 50 feet of clinics where abortions are performed. A draft of the Access to Reproductive Health Services bill would prohibit ''passing a leaflet or handbill to, displaying a sign to, or engaging in oral protest, education or counseling with'' clinic workers or female visitors.

title: Coming Back To 'Shane'
description: HE came into his screening room walking that Woody Allen walk, slightly hunched, a little distracted, his vigorous fingers carving the air as he spoke. ''I hope you don't mind,'' he said, ''but I have prepared a statement.''

title: Couple Are Stabbed to Death in Their Bronx Apartment
description: When the police responded to a 911 call at Apartment 7B of the Daniel Webster Houses in the Bronx early yesterday, they found an unlocked door and an elderly couple with multiple stab wounds. The woman, Katie McNatt, 62, was dead. The man, her longtime companion, Willie Anderson, 72, soon died at a hospital.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Coming Soon: 'Dot-Name' Addresses
description: The group that oversees the Internet's address system, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, signed a contract yesterday with the London-based Global Name Registry Ltd. to distribute addresses with the .name extension. Addresses ending in .name are reserved for use by individuals, who will be able to register addresses in the format ''firstname.lastname .name.'' Global Name Registry also plans to market an e-mail forwarding service, so holders of such addresses can receive e-mail there (in the format firstname@lastname.name). Companies approved by Icann to register Internet addresses, known as registrars, will begin accepting .name registrations in September. The addresses are expected to become functional later this year. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: The Nets Expect To Sign MacCulloch
description: The Nets have waited patiently for the past 15 days for Todd MacCulloch to become their starting center. By midnight tonight, they believe they will have him for the next six years.

title: P. Diddy and The Bad Boy Family's 'The Saga Continues'
description: P. DIDDY AND THE BAD BOY FAMILY: "The Saga Continues . . ." (Bad Boy/Arista). What if Sean (Puffy) Combs looked like Suge Knight? What if, instead of prancing around the Hamptons in a pink Oxford shirt, dating celebrities, cozying up to Regis and rapping gangsta lite in an effete mumble, he was a huge, intimidating ex- bodyguard who flaunted gang affiliations and a beyond-the-law hard- core-rap empire? Chances are that Mr. Combs wouldn't be flaunting the survival skills and not-guilty verdicts that he does on his third album. That he calls himself P. Diddy these days is just one more example of his slipperiness. Who is he? Is he good or evil? Gentle or brutal?

title: It's a Bad Day For Mussina And the Yanks
description: Manager Joe Torre said he was fearful Wednesday night when third baseman Scott Brosius left Yankee Stadium with what was hoped to be only a bruised hand. Tests yesterday morning revealed that Brosius broke a bone in the hand when he was hit by a pitch. It will sideline him for as long as a month and leave Torre rotating players to shore up the Yankees' infield.

title: Rochester, Still a Cradle Of Invention
description: ''Race a boat! Help a good cause!'' shouted a man in yellow boots, waving a pair of footlong toy boats, as we walked down the cobblestone street toward Brown's Race in Rochester, a relic of America's early industrial years that once powered mills grinding wheat into flour for New York City bakeries. For a $5 donation to Big Brothers/Big Sisters, you could watch your toy boat, captained by a rubber amphibian, bob a few dozen feet down the sloping rectangular box that for nearly two centuries has drawn water from the Genesee River at High Falls, the spectacular 90-foot cascade in the heart of downtown Rochester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROLLHAUS, PHILIP EDWARD, JR.
description: ROLLHAUS-Philip Edward, Jr. Passed away peacefully at home in Palm Beach, FL on Saturday, July 28th, after a courageous battle with cancer. Mr. Rollhaus, 66, was the founder and chairman of Quixote Corporation, headquartered in Chicago, whose highway safety products have saved over 40,000 lives and countless serious injuries. Mr. Rollhaus is survived by his loving wife, Barbara, two wonderful children, Natalie (Matthew) Burton of Los Angeles, CA, and Philip E. ''Ned'' Rollhaus III (Catherine) of San Francisco, CA, his loving sister Barbara (Warren) Quimby of Albany, NY, adored granddaughter, Sydney Grace Burton, and several cousins, nieces & nephews. Burial services will be private. A memorial service will take place at The Fourth Presbyterian Church, Michigan Avenue at Delaware Pl in Chicago, IL, on Tuesday, August 7th at 4:00 in the afternoon. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Shelter Island Friends Meeting, Box 520, Shelter Island, New York 11964.

title: TESORO CUTS PROFIT OUTLOOK, SAYING MARGINS ARE LOWER
description: Tesoro Petroleum, which has oil refineries in Alaska, Hawaii and Washington State, said yesterday that it would fall short of analysts' estimates for third-quarter earnings because profit margins had fallen. Tesoro, based in San Antonio, expects to earn 10 to 25 cents a share; analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected 34 cents. Tesoro said second-quarter profit more than doubled, helped by high refining margins in April and May. After a payment of preferred dividends, net income rose to $29.5 million, or 70 cents a share, from $14.6 million, or 35 cents.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Record Prison Population
description: The state prison population, which more than doubled in the 1990's, has reached a new high, officials said. As of yesterday, there were 17,758 prisoners, said Brian A. Garnett, a spokesman for the State Department of Corrections. He attributed the rise to legislation in the last 10 years establishing mandatory sentencing guidelines and requiring that prisoners actually serve a minimum percentage of their sentences. He said the state was expanding facilities to ease crowding problems.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Campaign Warns Of Antibiotics Overuse
description: The National Institutes of Health said it had begun a $2 million advertising campaign, starting in Colorado, to persuade people not to overuse antibiotics. Researchers estimate that half of the roughly 110 million antibiotic prescriptions written in the United States every year are unnecessary. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: The Impressionists at Work, With All Deliberate Speed
description: You know a few things about a painting just by looking: its size, its colors and textures, its arrangement of forms and what, if anything, it depicts. You may also have some idea of how long it took to paint. Clearly, Jan Van Eyck's miracle of Northern Renaissance realism ''The Arnolfini Wedding'' cannot have been made very quickly. A rough little plywood painting by the contemporary artist Richard Tuttle may appear to have taken no more than an hour or so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILSON, VIVIAN DEBORAH
description: WILSON-Vivian Deborah. A retired law professor, died suddenly and unexpectedly at her home in Mill Valley, CA. on June 13, 2001. Known as ''Debi'' to many of her friends, she taught law at Hastings College of Law from 1975 until her retirement in 1993. She was born in New York City on September 5, 1922, was a graduate of Hunter College and a member of Phi Beta Kappa. She earned a Master's degree in Journalism from Columbia University. After graduating from Hastings College of the Law in 1969, she served as a Public Defender until accepting a teaching position at Hastings in 1975 as a Law Professor. She also served as Dean of Students. She was a published author, writing numerous magazine articles and ''Watch Out for the Weather,'' a book about the effects of weather on human behavior. Recently, she had been a peer counselor. She is survived by her sister, Suzanne Barnett of New York, her children Andrew Wilson and Claudia Wilson and four grandchildren who reside in California. She was 78.

Here's it's Hector Elizondo, head of security for the tiny, nonexistent country of Genovia who is told he resembles the private detective who's a sex machine for all the chicks.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Powell Videotape
description: The Chinese government denied that Chinese television violated a promise to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell when it edited out sections of a taped interview. In the interview, broadcast on Sunday by China Central Television, Mr. Powell said the United States wants good relations with China, but his other statements about human rights and Taiwan were omitted. American officials said they had been promised that all of the interview would be shown. Erik Eckholm (NYT)

title: An Artist Exploring An Enlisted Man's Look
description: DAY 1: A couple of thousand years before the arrival of the two-star hotels and waterfront bars, this tiny port on Corsica's northwest coast (population 3,500) was a Roman settlement. Then Goths and Vandals destroyed it. The Genoese rebuilt it in the 13th century as a military garrison, calling it Semper Fidelis until it switched allegiance to France. When the British admiral, Nelson, was shot in the eye off Calvi, the French started calling it Semper Fidelis too, and now a stone citadel overlooking the town bears the inscription ''Civitas Calvi Semper Fidelis.''

title: As They Lived and Breathed
description: In their long efforts to breathe life into dinosaurs, so famously extinct in all but human fancy, scientists may have been wrong about the position of the nostrils through which these huge reptiles breathed, smelled, regulated body temperature and generally nosed around the Mesozoic landscape.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officials Seek Ferry Resumption
description: Six days after the last of several ferry operators discontinued service from Bay Ridge, borough officials called for a resumption of service yesterday and the construction of a landing barge they said would encourage ridership. Representatives of the borough president, Howard Golden, and others gathered at Pier 69 and insisted that service to Manhattan would ease subway and highway congestion, as well as help revitalize the area. But David Strafford, a spokesman for SeaStreak America, which dropped the route on Friday, said that although the ferry is faster, commuters would always choose cheaper subways and buses. Rebecca O'Brien (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Censure Fails
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee's ruling coalition government defeated a motion in the lower house of Parliament to censure the government over a scandal involving India's largest mutual fund, the state-run Unit Trust of India. The government was plunged into crisis on Tuesday when the prime minister threatened to quit after a lawmaker in the ruling coalition linked the crisis at the mutual fund to Mr. Vajpayee's senior aides. P.J. Anthony (NYT)

title: A Difference A Day Made
description: Just when Congressional Republicans had seemed in dangerous disarray, President Bush in a gratifying 24 hours won House passage of his comprehensive energy plan and eked out a victory on a patients' bill of rights.

title: Pennington Has to React, Not Think
description: Chad Pennington was on his way to dinner Wednesday night when he was intercepted. Jets Coach Herman Edwards caught up with Pennington and, smooth as the backpedals Edwards still runs on a treadmill, tried to soothe the busy mind of his quarterback of the future.

title: Coming to Terms on Differing Bills
description: After the monthlong Congressional recess in August, House and Senate leaders will pick lawmakers to meet in conference to work out differences between the two versions of the patients' bill of rights legislation.

title: Women on Television
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Ann Cohen -- Writer, 39
description: Deborah Ann Cohen, a New York marketing executive and writer whose battle with breast cancer inspired her to assist other victims of the disease, died Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 39 and lived on the Upper West Side and in Rowayton, Conn.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: TRIBUNAL IN HAGUE FINDS BOSNIA SERB GUILTY OF GENOCIDE
description: A former Bosnian Serb general was found guilty of genocide today for his role in the systematic execution of more than 7,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys near the Bosnian town of Srebrenica in July 1995.

title: Gore's Political Return to Include Eastern Stops
description: Former Vice President Al Gore is easing back into American politics, starting by training Democratic operatives for elections this fall in New Jersey, New York and Virginia and then founding a political action committee to help Congressional candidates in the 2002 elections.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAFIRSTEIN, ELIOT J. (E.J.)
description: SAFIRSTEIN-Eliot J. (E.J.) of Los Angeles, formerly of Hartsdale, NY. Beloved husband to Liz Safirstein Leshin, loving son of Jack & Sue Safirstein, devoted brother to Julie Massey, and caring uncle of her twin sons Scott and David. Funeral Sunday 12 PM, Woodlands Community Temple, 50 Worthington Rd, White Plains, NY. Memorials to E.J. Safirstein Fund at Vassar College or the Pediatric Dept at Memorial Sloan Cancer Center appreciated.

title: Top Defendants in Strip-Club Trial Strike Deal
description: After two years of investigation, millions of tax dollars spent and 14 weeks of testimony that touched on the sex lives of several professional athletes, the Gold Club trial sputtered out today when the federal government and the principal defendants reached plea agreements.

title: Tempers Seem to Be Growing Shorter in Many Jury Rooms
description: On the fourth day of yelling and pacing in the small, drab deliberation room, the jurors in a routine trial of a man charged with selling a $10 bag of heroin sent yet another note to the judge. Because of one holdout juror who was impervious to reason, the note stated, ''tension is high, nerves are frayed and all minds are not sound.''

title: 'Up on the Roof' -- 'The Culture of New York City Rooftops'
description: New-York Historical Society

title: Bank of England Unexpectedly Cuts Benchmark Rate
description: The Bank of England unexpectedly trimmed its benchmark interest rate one-quarter point today, to 5 percent, responding to worsening economic tidings from the United States and Europe.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a plan presented by the British and Irish governments to rescue the home rule government in Ulster misstated the surname of the Irish prime minister. He is Bertie Ahern, not Hearn.

title: The 46-Year Pursuit of a Restless Soul
description: Sometimes it's better to be misunderstood. That's certainly the case with James Dean, whose brief three-picture career and death at 24 transformed him into a Hollywood icon. Seen in the confines of those movies -- ''East of Eden,'' ''Rebel Without a Cause,'' and ''Giant'' -- he remains forever young, and forever alienated, yearning and vulnerable.

title: Senate Approves Pared Farm Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 — The Senate's Democratic leaders bowed today to a White House veto threat and approved a farm-aid bill that contained $2 billion less than Democrats wanted, handing President Bush another major legislative victory this week and offering a preview of the far more divisive budget battles expected this fall.

title: Morgan Stanley and Analyst Sued Over Advice
description: Two lawsuits filed yesterday in federal district court accused Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and one of its analysts, Mary Meeker, of defrauding investors in the Internet auctioneer eBay Inc. and the online retailer Amazon.com.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MONTERO, JOSEPH R.
description: MONTERO-Joseph R. On August 2, 2001 of Lynbrook, N.Y. Beloved son of the late Joseph and Mildred Montero. Loving husband of Claudia (nee Watkins). Dear brother of Richard. Father of Yorkie Terriers Spanky and Loulu. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre, N.Y. Saturday and Sunday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 11 AM at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment St. Raymond's Cemetery, Bronx.

title: Israelis and Arabs: Can Talks Resume?
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis and Arabs: Can Talks Resume?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thailand's High Court Acquits Prime Minister of Graft
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 3  Thailand's highest court acquitted Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra today of financial irregularities, preserving his political career in a ruling that was seen as a test of Thailand's evolution toward the rule of law.

title: OLAJUWON DEAL COMPLETED
description: Houston and Toronto completed a sign-and-trade agreement last night that sends Hakeem Olajuwon to Canada for first- and second-round draft picks in 2002.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Ruling Halts Tree-Cutting
description: The state does not have the authority to cut citrus trees within 1,900 feet of those infected with citrus canker in Broward County, an administrative law judge has ruled. The state had planned to resume cutting nearly 200,000 citrus trees in Broward and Miami-Dade Counties on Monday. Last November, a circuit court judge ordered the chopping halted after Broward County residents complained of property damage. But the state's Fourth District Court of Appeal overturned the moratorium in June.

title: Becoming Immersed in Japan's Wired Pop Culture
description: ''Buzz Club: News From Japan'' at P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center is a tasty buffet of a show, a lunch of bite-size snacks, a combination obento and candy box. Taken singly, the choices may leave you a little hungry, but together they make a stimulating meal.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Profit At Food Concern
description: Profit at the San Miguel Corporation, a food and drink company, rose 10 percent, to 3.8 billion pesos in the first six months from 3.4 billion pesos a year earlier, the company said. Revenue rose 35 percent to 57.3 billion pesos, reflecting its acquisitions. San Miguel acquired Coca-Cola Bottlers Philippine Inc. and Pure Foods, a meat processor, in the second quarter.

title: Energy Package Split Ranks of Democrats
description: The Republican package in the House won easy passage this week by splitting two of the Democrats' core constituencies: environmental groups and organized labor. In their votes on the energy plan, many Democrats opposed big increases in automobile fuel efficiency. And three dozen broke ranks to support drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge on the ground that it would create thousands of jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, LEE
description: PARKER-Lee. Beloved father of Mark & David, husband of Emily and brother of Stuart, Gary, Craig and Sue. Memorial service 11AM Friday, August 3rd, Central Synagogue, Beir Chapel,123 East 55th Street. Visiting 10-11AM.

title: Just Try Kicking Sand In Camby's Face Now
description: Knicks Coach Jeff Van Gundy could not resist the temptation. He usually stays away from his players to give them space during the off-season, but the things he had been hearing about Marcus Camby compelled him to break his rule.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Signing On to Shays-Meehan
description: Barring a highly unlikely change of heart by the House Republican leadership, there is only one way that supporters of the Shays-Meehan campaign finance reform bill can guarantee a vote on the measure. They must collect 218 signatures on a discharge petition that will force Dennis Hastert, the House speaker, to bring the bill to the floor. As the House prepared last night for its August recess, the reformers had reason to be delighted with the results so far. In only four days they have collected a remarkable 205 signatures, including those of 15 brave Republicans who have chosen principle over party loyalty. This is a clear indication that the appetite for reform remains strong, despite the best efforts of the leadership to suppress it. Nevertheless, a great deal of missionary work still lies ahead, and the reformers must use the next few weeks to enlist wavering members to their cause.

title: Giuliani's Panel on Decency Focuses on Finances Instead
description: Four months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed a panel to set decency standards for city cultural institutions, the effort is beginning to show some movement.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit Up For Drug Maker
description: A leading European drug maker, Aventis S.A., posted a 31 percent increase in second-quarter earnings, helped by demand for the blood-thinner Lovenox and merger-related cost savings. Profit from its continuing operations in drugs, animal health and vaccines rose to 391 million euros ($345 million), or 50 cents a share, from 298 million, or 38 cents, a year earlier. The chief financial officer, Patrick Langlois, raised the forecast for growth in 2001 earnings a share to 35 percent from 30 percent.

title: Giants' Barber Out With Broken Hand
description: A little more than 30 minutes into today's Giants practice, Tiki Barber carried the football on a routine play up the middle. But somewhere in the scrum of what was intended to be a light contact drill, a helmet struck Barber's left hand, breaking a small bone on the outside of the hand.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Shh! It's a Birthday

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EATON VANCE, Boston, a mutual fund manager, has agreed to buy 70 percent of the closely held Atlanta Capital Management, Atlanta, for $75 million.

title: As Justice Returns, Brosius Goes on D.L.
description: The Yankees placed Scott Brosius on the 15-day disabled list before their game against the Texas Rangers after an exam yesterday morning revealed that Brosius had a hairline fracture of the fourth metacarpal in his left, glove hand. Brosius was struck by a pitch from Rangers reliever Kevin Foster in Wednesday's game, played third base for one more inning and left for a pinch-hitter when he could not grip the bat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZEVON, RHEA
description: ZEVON-Rhea. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Mother of Susan Zevon and Barbara Berlin. Grandmother of Eric and Geoffrey Berlin. Greatgrandmother of Olivia and Abraham. Private graveside service. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Smith College Scholarship Fund or Morris View Nursing Home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKEY, PETER BLAIR
description: STARKEY-Peter Blair, 38. Beloved husband of Renee Reso, loving father of Katherine and Patrick. Devoted son of John Richard and Elizabeth, brother of Maura Balaban, David and Carolyn. Grandson of Agnes R. Died in boating accident July 30. Celebratory gathering Sunday, August 5 5:30PM in Manhattan. Location to be announced. Funeral Mass at Holy Trinity R.C. Church, 213 West 82St, Monday, 10:30AM. Burial, St. Patrick's Cemetery, Bay Shore, LI.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil gained on expectations for strong fuel demand from motorists during the summer travel season. In New York, crude oil for September delivery rose 94 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $27.71 a barrel.

title: Man Charged In 3 Killings Above Deli
description: The former fugitive linked by his own statement and a palm print to the triple homicide above the Carnegie Deli in Midtown was charged yesterday with three counts of second-degree murder, charges that make him ineligible for the death penalty.

title: Revlon Posts 11th Loss in a Row
description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics maker controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, posted its 11th consecutive quarterly loss yesterday and cut its sales forecast for this year because of falling currencies in Europe and Asia.

title: Democrats Counter Administration on Immigrants
description: House and Senate Democrats proposed today to overhaul American immigration policy, raising the stakes in a political struggle with President Bush for the hearts, minds and votes of the nation's newest citizens and their influential advocates.

title: Test Shows Students' Gains In Math Falter by Grade 12
description: Results of a math test given periodically to students across the country show that fourth graders and eighth graders made modest, steady gains while the scores of 12th graders declined slightly.

title: A Call for Broadband
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an exodus of black residents from San Francisco gave an incorrect surname in some copies for the former San Francisco 49ers owner whose legal troubles stalled development plans in a black neighborhood. He is Eddie DeBartolo Jr., not Bartolo. A map with the article referred incorrectly in some copies to a neighborhood where a jazz district has been proposed. It is the Fillmore, not Filmore.

title: Clinton Lays Out Future for Library, and Himself
description: In a pep talk to a receptive hometown crowd, former President Bill Clinton said today that he would use his presidential library and policy center here to advance themes that were central to his presidency.

title: Horse Parlors Will Get Ritzy Under a City Plan to Sell Them
description: New York City's Off-Track Betting parlors would be transformed into inviting neighborhood entertainment and gambling centers under a plan unveiled yesterday by a partnership selected by the Giuliani administration to buy the 75 once-money-losing OTB sites.

title: Stop and Shop Selects 6 Semifinalists
description: The Stop and Shop Supermarket Company in Quincy, Mass., which operates supermarkets in the Northeast, said yesterday that it had narrowed a review for its broadcast account to six semifinalists. Spending was estimated at $7 million to $10 million.

title: The Crucial Votes in the House on the Energy Bill
description: Following are the roll-call votes in the House on Wednesday and early yesterday passing an energy bill, defeating significant increases in motor vehicle fuel economy standards and rejecting an attempt to ban drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. The vote on the full bill was 240 to 189, with 36 Democrats, 203 Republicans and 1 independent voting for the bill and 172 Democrats, 16 Republicans and 1 independent voting against it. The vote on fuel standards was 269 to 160, with 123 Democrats, 36 Republicans and 1 independent supporting high standards and 86 Democrats, 182 Republicans and 1 independent opposing them. The vote on drilling in the refuge was 223 to 206, as 171 Democrats, 34 Republicans and 1 independent supported the ban, while 36 Democrats, 186 Republicans and 1 independent opposed it. There is one vacancy in the House.

title: Heatstroke Deaths in Football
description: The heatstroke death of Korey Stringer, a 335-pound All-Pro offensive tackle for the Minnesota Vikings, after a strenuous practice in the 90-degree heat of Mankato, Minn., has triggered a round of soul-searching in the National Football League, as well it should. His death, like that of Eraste Autin, a fledgling running back at the University of Florida, a week earlier could have been prevented if the players and coaching staffs had acted more aggressively to prevent overheating.

title: Minus G.O.P., Senate Panel Passes Voting Bill
description: Senate Republicans boycotted the year's first vote on an election overhaul today, laying bare the intense partisan divisions that threaten to kill any change in the nation's electoral system.

title: AOL Time Warner Reverses Itself on Cable Shift After Pressure by NBC
description: After deciding to move the financial news network CNBC to a less desirable, higher-numbered cable channel in New York City, AOL Time Warner reversed itself yesterday afternoon under pressure from NBC.

title: Subtlety Plays the Wallflower At an Orgy of Verbal Slapstick
description: Almost 40 years ago, a pudgy parodist took a lyric from a well-known patriotic song, dropped a silent W, changed a G to a D and put an O where an A was.

title: Liability Insurers Pushing Companies to Share Risks
description: Americans have had to get used to making bigger co-payments when they go to the doctor, as a result of changes in health insurers' policies. Now, a wave of shareholder lawsuits is prompting liability insurers to impose larger co-payments on corporate clients, too.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: State Bars Gay Group From Program
description: A request by the Sioux Empire Gay and Lesbian Coalition to participate in the state's adopt-a-highway program has been denied. Officials of the State Transportation Department told the coalition it was considered an advocacy group and thus did not qualify for the program. The case, which the coalition said it would fight in court if necessary, appears similar to one in which the Ku Klux Klan sought to adopt a highway in Missouri. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, which includes South Dakota, ruled last year that excluding the Klan from the program violated the group's First Amendment rights. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Trying to Atone for a Sin Despite a Memory Void
description: Abel Ferrara's ''Blackout,'' a film featuring sex, drugs and Claudia Schiffer, caused a stampede when it was shown at the 1997 Cannes Film Festival. That it is only now receiving a New York theatrical premiere says a lot about what the film promises, and what the film delivers. (It will be shown at the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village for the next two weeks, as the climax of a series of Mr. Ferrara's films.)

title: Daze Re-Signs With Blackhawks
description: The Chicago Blackhawks re-signed left wing Eric Daze, a restricted free agent. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.

title: New Video Releases
description: The Mexican

title: Critic's Notebook; With His Head Scenically in the Clouds, Church Became a Star
description: In 19th-century American landscape painting, nature is never caught on the fly, never just happens, organically. Every detail, from the twist of a tree to the tone of the sky, is calculated, premeditated, infused with meaning.

title: Poul Anderson, Science Fiction Novelist, Dies at 74
description: Poul Anderson, who combined his education as a physicist with his passion for Nordic mythology to become a prolific and sometimes poetic author of science fiction, died on Tuesday at his home in Orinda, Calif. He was 74.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''In July 1995, General Krstic, you agreed to evil. This is why the Trial Chamber convicts you today and sentences you to 46 years in prison.''

title: A Jewish Treasure Stays in Israel
description: ''It's like finding the Declaration of Independence in the attic,'' said Rabbi Jerry Schwarzbard, the librarian for special collections at the Jewish Theological Seminary in Manhattan. He was explaining the excitement elicited by a manuscript that came up for auction in April at Sotheby's in Tel Aviv. The rare illuminated manuscript known as the First Nuremberg Haggadah was written and illustrated in about 1449 in Germany by a scribe artist known as Joel ben Simeon.

title: Programming The Housewives
description: Looking for video acquistions for Anchor Bay Entertainment, Jay Douglas usually obtains rights to old movies from studios that don't want them anymore. Anchor Bay, based in Troy, Mich., has a reputation for reviving dozens of neglected properties. One recent example is Richard Rush's acclaimed ''Stunt Man'' (1980), dropped by Fox.

title: Series: In Art's Footsteps
description: The paintings of the Hudson River School are portraits of the Northeast, captured at a time when 19th-century America was re-examining its ideas about nature. The landscapes helped spur tourism and environmentalism.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Queen Mother Back Home
description: Queen Elizabeth the Queen Mother will celebrate her 101st birthday in her Clarence House residence on Saturday after having spent a night in a London hospital receiving an emergency blood transfusion to combat anemia. Early arrivals among the thousands of people expected to greet her stood in the rain with ''welcome home'' placards.

title: Agency Layoffs and a Closing
description: Two agencies have announced lay- offs, while another is closing.

title: G.M. Hires Developer of Some Chrysler Hits
description: General Motors, often criticized for making cars that lack flair, said today that it had hired Robert A. Lutz, the former president of Chrysler, as vice chairman for product development. The company hopes Mr. Lutz, known for championing distinctive vehicles like the Jeep Grand Cherokee, Dodge Viper and the PT Cruiser, will add some personality to G.M.'s cars and trucks.

title: 2 Candidates For Comptroller Had Warnings Of Overruns
description: While most campaigns for city offices have yet to seize on an issue, the race for comptroller has zeroed in on a big one: Who should have alerted the citizenry to $1.9 billion in projected cost overruns that have wrecked the Board of Education's budget for school construction.

title: Of Oft-Ribbed New Jersey, Poll Finds a Neutral Opinion
description: Folks who live in New Jersey are used to being the butt of jokes: that they all hang out at the Bada Bing! strip club, that the state is one big toxic waste dump and that they are more likely to know their highway exits than their addresses.

title: Core's Split on Energy Is Costly to Democrats
description: President Bush won a lopsided victory on energy this week because the Republican package in the House split two of the Democrats' core constituencies: environmental groups and organized labor.

title: Russia Frees U.S. Scholar Jailed on Minor Drug Charge
description: MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- John E. Tobin Jr. walked out of a southwest Russian prison a free man this afternoon, paroled hours earlier by a local court from a minor marijuana conviction that briefly threatened to blossom into an international espionage drama.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: DISCRIMINATION CLAIMED

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Housekeeper Charged With Theft
description: A housekeeper has been charged with stealing $430,000 from a 93-year-old woman she worked for, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. The housekeeper, Joan S. Miller, 56, of Forest Hills, who was arrested on Wednesday on grand larceny and forgery charges, also tried to gain power of attorney over an incapacitated former police officer to take possession of an apartment and sell it to pay off gambling debts, Mr. Brown said. He said Ms. Miller, also known as Susan Wong, would face up to 15 years in prison if convicted on all charges. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bristol: Man Is Accused Of Voyeurism
description: A man accused of videotaping women's feet as they tried on shoes at a department store is scheduled to appear in State Superior Court on Monday. The man, Brian Sorel, 25, of Bristol, was arrested on Saturday and charged with voyeurism and disorderly conduct, after security guards said they caught him videotaping feet in the women's shoe department at a Kohl's store in Plainville.

title: Armstrong Makes the Rounds on a Victory Tour
description: At 4 a.m. yesterday, a fire alarm sounded at the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown Manhattan. Lance Armstrong turned to his wife, Kristin, and said in resignation, ''Now Luke is going to wake up and won't fall asleep again.''

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: HEINZ ACQUIRES MAKER OF MEXICAN CONVENIENCE FOODS
description: H. J. Heinz said yesterday that it had bought Delimex, a maker of frozen tamales, quesadillas and other Mexican convenience foods, from Fenway Partners, the private investment firm. Terms were not disclosed. Delimex, based in San Diego, has sales of more than $150 million a year, Heinz said. The acquisition expands the number of items Heinz offers that people can heat and serve. Delimex frozen Mexican food products are sold in stores like Wal-Mart Stores, Albertson's and Safeway.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a plan presented by the British and Irish governments to rescue the home rule government in Ulster misstated the surname of the Irish prime minister. He is Bertie Ahern, not Hearn.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Afghan Refugees
description: The government and the United Nations refugee agency have signed an agreement that sets up a screening process for Afghans who have fled to Pakistan to escape war and drought. In the past year, 180,000 people have crossed the porous border, many of them only to end up in wretched camps without adequate food and water. Aid was hampered by a long dispute about how to separate economic refugees from political ones. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Jury Begins Deliberations
description: A jury began deliberations yesterday in the trial of a former special-education teacher accused of having sexual relations with three male students. The teacher, Marci Stein, 29, was forced to resign from Hendrick Hudson High School in Montrose in March 2000 and was later charged in a 15-count indictment that includes charges of statutory rape, sodomy and sexual abuse. In testimony Wednesday, Mrs. Stein denied the charges. Her lawyer, George E. Fufidio Jr., has argued in Westchester County Court that the boys spread false rumors about her that got out of hand. If convicted of the rape or sodomy charges, which are felonies, she faces up to four years in prison on each count. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Barclays Profit Slips
description: First-half profit at Barclays P.L.C. fell 1 percent as the company, Britain's third-largest bank, incurred costs associated with buying Woolwich P.L.C. and set more money aside for possible loan defaults. Net income fell to 1.31 billion ($1.88 billion), or 78.6 pence a share, from 1.32 billion, or 88.9 pence a share, in the first half of 2000. The Woolwich acquisition doubled the Barclays share of Britain's mortgage market.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Conservationists Sue
description: Conservationists have sued the Fish and Wildlife Service to try to hasten a decision on whether the California spotted owl and the Pacific fisher, a relative of the otter, should be listed as endangered species. A decrease in old-growth Sierra Nevada forests has hurt the owl and fisher, according to a lawsuit filed on Tuesday by the Center for Biological Diversity, the Sierra Nevada Forest Protection Campaign, the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Center for Sierra Nevada Conservation. The groups said the Forest Service missed a deadline for listing the species as endangered. Evelyn Nieves (NYT)

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

description: They liked New York.

description: To the Editor:

title: Etching the Notes of a New European Identity
description: VIENNA  First in a series of articles about the Jan. 1 introduction of euro banknotes and coins.

title: AFTER LOSS, ANC RENTAL CONSIDERS SALE OF COMPANY
description: The ANC Rental Corporation, parent of the Alamo and National car rental companies, said yesterday that it might sell all or part of the company. Reporting a second-quarter loss and lowering its earnings outlook for the third quarter, ANC said that it had hired Lehman Brothers to help evaluate options and that ''a significant investment by a third party'' would be considered. The loss of $23.6 million, or 52 cents a share, was in contrast to net income of $15.5 million, or 34 cents, a year earlier. Revenue fell 6.4 percent, to $850.6 million from $909.2 million, as businesses and individuals scaled back travel spending. ANC shares fell 24 cents, to $3.36.

title: A Hike to History, With Nature as a Guide; Class Is in Session on a Cliff in the Catskills
description: On an early fall evening in 1992, Steve Kluge and a group of high school science students from Bedford, N.Y., were hiking toward a sandstone escarpment called the Pine Orchard high above the Hudson River, and Mr. Kluge was preparing them for what they would find: the past.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Domestic Violence Fund Created
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco yesterday signed into law a bill creating a fund for victims of domestic violence, and providing an initial $100,000 for the program. The law allows judges to impose civil fines from $50 to $500 on those convicted of domestic violence. In a statement, he said the fund ''puts the burden of the cost of domestic violence where it belongs.'' Officials estimate that the fines will produce $356,000 a year for housing, legal services and other victims' needs. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Koizumi, in Showdown, Forces Foreign Minister to Back Down
description: A showdown between Foreign Minister Makiko Tanaka and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi over personnel changes in the Foreign Ministry ended today with Ms. Tanaka's backing down and agreeing to replace several top diplomats.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on July 20 about summer exhibitions in Connecticut misspelled the surname of a collector of Russian art who provided the works exhibited in ''Forbidden Art of Postwar Russia,'' which closed on July 29 at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich. He is Yuri Traisman, not Praisman.

title: Tepid Stock Debut For Soybean Shipper
description: Bunge Ltd., the largest soybean exporter in the world, raised $282 million in an initial public offering, at the low end of its expectations. Its shares closed unchanged after dropping as much as 5 percent.

title: Italo Scanga, 69, an Artist Inspired by Found Objects
description: Italo Scanga, a sculptor and painter who fashioned much of his work from found objects in a style that blended Cubist and folk influences, died on July 27 at his studio in Pacific Beach, Calif. He was 69.

title: Film in Review; 'Under the Sun'
description: Directed by Colin Nutley

title: A New Irish Peace Bid
description: The British and Irish governments have presented Northern Ireland's political parties with a fair and extensive package of reforms that offers an opportunity to revive the now-stalled peace accords. An important response is likely to come today, at a meeting of the executive committee of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army. The I.R.A. has balked at disarmament, insisting that it will give up its weapons only in a ''context'' of concessions that include British troop withdrawals and police reform. The proposals go a long way toward meeting that demand. A positive response from Sinn Fein would pressure the I.R.A. to move ahead with disarmament.

description: Red Grooms

description: NEW YORK

title: Coming to Terms on Differing Bills
description: After the monthlong Congressional recess in August, House and Senate leaders will pick lawmakers to meet in conference to work out differences between the two versions of the patients' bill of rights legislation.
