description: EUROPE

title: Democrats Reject Bush's Choice To Head Product Safety Panel
description: The Senate Commerce Committee voted today along party lines to reject President Bush's choice to head the Consumer Product Safety Commission, handing him his first nomination loss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAUNDERS, AGNES K.
description: SAUNDERS-Agnes K., a naturalist and educator known to her family and friends as Tib, died peacefully of heart failure on July 30, 2001, at her home in Lynbrook, NY. She was 94. At her death, she was with her son, Paul Saunders, and her daughter, Marcia Dolan. She is also survived by another son, Dr. John Saunders, and she was predeceased by her husband, John, and her daughter, Nancy Saunders Raymond. She leaves 13 grandchildren: Susan Raymond Stala, Christopher Raymond, John Raymond, Dr. Paul Saunders, Michael Saunders, David Dolan, Matthew Dolan, Stephen Dolan, Mary Kate Dolan, John Dolan, Dr. John Kenneth Saunders, Thomas Saunders and Kate Saunders. She is also survived by a great-granddaughter, Olivia Stala, and by her brother, Hugh Kelly, and her sister, Claire Gilbert. She had 36 nieces and nephews. Tib Saunders (nee Kelly) was born in Utica, NY, in 1907. She graduated from Cornell University in 1929 and received a Master's degree from Cornell in 1930. Upon graduation, she worked as an associate in the Education Department of the American Museum of Natural History, where, among other things, she edited the films brought back from the Gobi Desert in 1930 by Roy Chapman Andrews. At the Museum, she met her husband, John, who later became chairman of the Education Department. She left the Museum in 1939 and moved to Lynbrook in 1942 to raise a family. She taught in the Lynbrook public school system and was elected to the Lynbrook Board of Education. She later became head of the Lynbrook office of the Nassau County Cooperative Extension, where she worked until her retirement in 1981. She was devoted to her alma mater, Cornell. For many years until her death, she served as Corresponding Secretary for the Class of 1929. She was also devoted to her church, St. Raymond's, where she served as Prefect of the Sodality. Throughout her life, Tib studied, wrote, taught and lectured extensively about natural history. She was widely recognized as an expert in the flora and fauna of Long Island and her advice was actively sought on a wide variety of environmental and ecological topics. As evidence of her lifelong devotion to science and to Cornell University, she has donated her body to the Cornell Medical School. There will be no wake. A memorial mass will be celebrated at St. Raymond's Church, Atlantic Avenue, East Rockaway, NY, on Saturday, August 4, at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to the Development Office, Cornell University, 55 Brown Road, Ithaca, NY 14850-1247, Attention of Rebekah Coleman.

title: New Challenger for Greene at World Championships
description: Maurice Greene wants to be remembered as the greatest sprinter in track history.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Marijuana Fields
description: Alan Rock, Canada's federal health minister, toured the country's first legal marijuana farm, inside an old Manitoba copper mine. Under a new law that took effect, this week, Canadians suffering from life-threatening or chronic illnesses are allowed to use marijuana for medical purposes, even though some doctors doubt its usefulness as a pain reliever. The government has given Prairie Plant Systems of Saskatoon a $3.8 million contract to grow marijuana for patients who cannot grow it themselves.

title: University Allows U.S. Scholar to Continue Teaching
description: HONG KONG, Aug. 3 — A Chinese-born American scholar who was convicted as a spy on the mainland, ordered deported to the United States and then returned to Hong Kong, was told today that he could keep his position at City University here, where he is a marketing professor.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Lexus And the Shamrock
description: So I'm checking out of my hotel Wednesday morning, the Dromoland Castle, a real stone castle in western Ireland. The checkout desk is framed by two mannequins in suits of armor once worn by castle guards. I ask for my bill. The desk clerk sheepishly says in a thick Irish brogue that he can't give it to me now because the hotel's entire computer system crashed at 3 a.m., probably a victim of the ''Code Red'' global computer virus. I think to myself: I'm in a castle in the Irish countryside, the Irish desk clerk is surrounded by two knights in shining armor, and he's telling me in his lovely accent that a computer worm ate my bill.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Murdoch Buys Portal
description: The News Corporation, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, said yesterday that it had taken control of a leading Internet portal in India, Indya.com, acquiring ''nearly all'' of the majority stake of Microland Group, adding to its 37 percent stake. Terms were not disclosed. Though only a small number of Indians have Internet access, the eight million who do tend to be young, affluent city dwellers who also watch satellite television, a market dominated in India by News Corporation's Star Network. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Bush Looks Back and Revels Slightly at String of Successes
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Bush treated himself to a Rose Garden celebration today, exulting in a series of victories on Capitol Hill, promising more initiatives after the August break and warning Congressional Democrats not to try to thwart him.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Discrimination Claimed
description: Federal regulators filed a discrimination lawsuit yesterday on behalf of three female construction workers who claimed that they were sexually harassed and forced to pick up after their male colleagues while working at a job site in Brooklyn. The three women complained last year to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission that they were subjected to a hostile work environment while working for Tratoros Construction Inc., a general contractor hired by the New York Housing Authority to renovate the Williamsburg Houses in northern Brooklyn. After investigating their claims, the commission filed a sexual discrimination suit on their behalf in United States District Court in Brooklyn. In its formal complaint, the commission said, ''Offensive and unwelcome comments were made regarding women's menstruation and sexual activity.'' The complaint accuses one of the company's male supervisors of telling his male colleagues to leave the women alone ''because they had cramps'' and ordered the women to ''change their Pampers.'' The supervisor also asked the women if they had recently had sex and publicly accused two of them of having an affair, according to the complaint. The three women say they were forced to clean bathrooms and kitchens and wash windows while the men did demolition and paint jobs. Chris Curis, a spokesman for Tratoros, said the company denied all of the allegations and he could not discuss continuing litigation. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Corrections

title: State Finance Turns Personal
description: For four months, the 211 members of the Legislature have not been paid because there has been no state budget. The question tonight was: would they get their paychecks if they passed a pared-to-the-bone budget?

title: Aching Heart Of Darkness
description: In one of the scenes that have been added to Francis Ford Coppola's ''Apocalypse Now,'' Captain Willard (Martin Sheen) smokes opium with a French widow (Aurore Clment) who lives in the crumbling imperial grandeur of her family's remote jungle rubber plantation. As Willard falls into a glassy-eyed stupor, and she slowly disrobes, the woman talks about her husband, a lost soldier in France's doomed colonial adventure, and about the essential dualism of human nature. ''There are two of you,'' she says, ''one that loves and one that kills.''

title: Rapping at the Senate's Door
description: Last week's hearings before the Senate Committee on Governmental Affairs underscored a major problem for the government as it attempts to balance First Amendment rights with its desire to impose ratings on recorded music. Simply stated, the Senate has created a barrier that prevents its members from understanding the issues that are important to certain groups of artists. That barrier is lack of access. In particular, the Senate demonstrated that it just isn't interested in hearing from young African-American artists who create hip-hop music. The senators would much rather talk about these performers than with them.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Central American Drought
description: The United Nations World Food Program will provide food to 405,000 people who have lost half to all of their crops during a severe drought afflicting Central America. An estimated 1.4 million are affected by the five-year-old drought, and as many as 775,000 face crucial food shortages. To feed the most vulnerable, at least 16,500 metric tons of food -- worth about $7.5 million -- will be required in the next three months. Daniel B. Schneider (NYT)

description: President Vicente Fox vowed today to bar American trucks from Mexico until Mexican truckers were allowed on American highways, raising the volume in a war of words between the two governments.

title: JUDGE DENIES CLASS ACTION IN BIAS SUITS AGAINST LOCKHEED
description: A federal judge refused yesterday to grant class-action status to two race-discrimination lawsuits against Lockheed Martin by 10 black workers at its aeronautics division. The workers, current and former employees at Lockheed's military aircraft factory in Marietta, Ga., contend they were harassed, denied promotions, paid less than white co-workers in similar jobs, and subjected to retaliation when they complained. Judge J. Owen Forrester of United States District Court in Atlanta ruled that the suits could not extend to other Lockheed facilities because employment practices were ''highly localized.''

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Massachusetts: Public Money For Candidates
description: Massachusetts and Arizona have passed ''clean elections'' laws allowing candidates to receive public money for their campaigns in place of most fund-raising from donors. As of this week, the two states will start to see how the new systems work: Would-be candidates will start to gather the thousands of small contributions they need to qualify for public money. In Arizona, for example, a candidate for governor must gather 4,000 contributions of $5 each to qualify for as much as $1 million in public money. Carey Goldberg (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Teradyne and Genrad To Merge
description: The semiconductor testing equipment maker Teradyne said it had agreed to buy GenRad, a manufacturer of electronic test equipment and software, in a $260 million deal. Under the terms of the deal, each GenRad share will be converted into 0.1733 Teradyne share. The deal also includes the assumption of about $85 million in GenRad debt, though that may be reduced by the anticipated sale of a GenRad unit. Robert M. Dutkowsky, chief executive of GenRad, will manage the combined Teradyne-GenRad circuit-board test and inspection division. GenRad stock rose $1.99, or 50 percent, to $5.99. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Rebels Released
description: The government released 10 more jailed Maoist rebels, adding to the 15 who were freed last week. The move is described as a goodwill gesture by the new prime minister, Sher Bahadur Deuba, in anticipation of negotiations with the insurgents. Both the Maoists and the government claim to be holding hundreds of prisoners. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Movie Ban Lifted
description: The Supreme Court ended the ban on the award-winning film ''Death on a Full Moon Day'' and ordered the government to pay the director, Prasanna Vithanage, a $6,000 penalty. Screenings were prohibited after censors said the movie would hurt the morale of troops fighting in the nation's ethnic civil war. In the film, a father demands to see the remains of his son, a soldier killed in battle. Despite efforts by the military to stop him, he opens the coffin and finds only a log inside. description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has promised to slaughter the sacred cows, going after the special interests that have long supported his ruling Liberal Democratic Party and in turn won privileges, protection and subsidies that have bloated the national budget and stalled the economy.

Vallone, the City Council speaker and mayoral candidate, laid out more than two dozen education proposals yesterday that would cost more than $1.5 billion a year, including reducing class size, hiring an additional guidance counselor for every middle and high school and expanding training for teachers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISER, ALAN NOEL
description: WEISER-Alan Noel, 69, died peacefully at home after a brave five-year battle with cancer. A dynamic person and talented performer, he delighted Long Island audiences with over 30 years of community theater appearances. A successful businessman and past President of the Furniture Manufacturers Association of America, Alan also served on the Board of Directors of the Oceanside Theater Guild, the Oceanside Jewish Center, B'nai Brith, and was a founder of the Long Island Symphony. With Ruth, his beloved wife of 45 years, they experienced the world together as they traveled five continents. Alan was a devoted son of the late Harry and Rose Weiser, and brother of Eleanor (deceased). He was a special father to David and his partner Tim, Debra, and Diane and her husband Dave. Services Sunday, 1PM, at Gutterman's, 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island. To all who knew and loved him, ''He dreamed last night he got on the boat to Heaven.''

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Exodus Of Brokers
description: The brokerage units of Citigroup Inc. and Merrill Lynch joined an exodus of investment banks leaving the stock market, where average daily volume fell by almost half this year. Citigroup's brokerage unit, which employs three, will close at the end of August, and Merrill Lynch will sell its brokerage firm, the nation's biggest, accounting for about 7 percent of trade, to local managers. The Nomura Securities Company and at least seven others already quit the market, whose leading index of 33 stocks is worth $13.1 billion, less than 3 percent of the value of Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Bail Is Rejected
description: A special Bombay court yesterday rejected the bail application of P. S. Subramanyam, the former chairman of the country's largest mutual fund, Unit Trust of India. He was accused of conspiring and cheating the mutual fund of 328 million rupees, or $7 million. Mr. Subramanyam and two senior officials of the fund, M. M. Kapur and S. K. Basu, were ordered held in custody until Tuesday. India's top federal detective police, the CBI, which is investigating the Unit Trust scandal, accused the three of being involved in a blatantly fraudulent investment in a software company called Cyberspace Infosys. The did so, the agency says, against expert advice, causing huge losses. Falling values caused by financial mismanagement and too much investment in volatile markets led Unit Trust of India to suspend redemption of units in its flagship US-64 plan on July 2. Mr. Subramanyam later resigned. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Immigration Proposal
description: Interior Minister Otto Schily presented the outlines of a new immigration law to Germany's Parliament, promising a ''flexible'' response to the country's need for highly qualified workers while tightening regulations to deport illegal immigrants. title: CHAIRMAN OF STATE STREET GLOBAL ADVISORS RESIGNS
description: The State Street Corporation said yesterday that Nicholas Lopardo, 54, who ran its State Street Global Advisors, has retired after 14 years. Timothy B. Harbert, 50, was named the unit's chairman and chief executive. Mr. Harbert, the unit's president, has worked with Mr. Lopardo for the last 14 years, State Street said. Mr. Lopardo turned State Street Global, based in Boston, into one of the world's biggest asset managers, with $727 billion under management. He joined the unit in 1987 when it had just $18 billion. Mr. Lopardo said in a statement he was ''eager to devote more time'' to his family and ''other outside interests.'' The Boston Globe had previously reported that Mr. Lopardo had an argument with David Spina, State Street's chief executive, over the cost to the firm of flying the former Boston Bruins hockey star Ray Bourque to Boston after his Stanley Cup victory.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMEY, JOSEPH F.
description: RAMEY-Joseph F. Age 76, of Palm City, Florida, died August 1st, at Hospice of Martin & St. Lucie County in Stuart. He served with the U.S. Army Air Force during W.W. II. Mr. Ramey was a group Vice President of 3M Corporation prior to retirement. He was a member of Harbour Ridge Yacht and Country Club in Palm City and Royal County Down Golf Club in Newcastle County Down, Ireland. Mr. Ramey's accomplished career with 3M included many national and international assignments. Among his most notable accomplishments was the leadership role he played in the development and marketing of the highly succesful Post-it Notes product. Survivors include his wife of 54 years, Dulcie J. Ramey of Palm City, FL, his son John Mulvey Ramey and his wife Maureen of Westport, CT, his daughter Deborah R. Mahood and her husband Thomas R. of Palm City, Fl, and two grandchildren. A private Funeral Mass will be held at Saint Martin dePorres Catholic Church in Jensen Beach, FL, with inurnment to follow at Forest Hills Memorial Park in Palm City. Condolences and acknowledgements may be made to the Ramey family in care of Forest Hills Funeral Home, 2001 SW Murphy Road, Palm City, FL 34990. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of Martin and St. Lucie County, 2030 SE Ocean Blvd., Stuart, FL. 34996.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Korea: Profit Jumps At Telecom
description: South Korea's largest cellular phone company, SK Telecom, said that its profit for the second quarter almost doubled as the company spent less to sign up new subscribers. Profits fell from the first quarter as SK Telecom invested in wireless Internet services. Net income rose 92 percent, to 232 billion won ($181 million) from 121 billion won ($94 million) a year earlier. Profit was down from 400 billion won ($310 million) in the first three months because of spending on network improvements and the advertising of online services. The company is facing the challenge of squeezing more sales out of a market that has 6 mobile phones for every 10 people.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Inflation Concerns
description: Jean-Claude Trichet, a council member of the European Central Bank, said yesterday that the bank remained concerned about inflation in the dozen countries that use the euro, suggesting that the E.C.B. is in no hurry to lower borrowing costs. ''We believe our current monetary stance remains appropriate for now,'' Mr. Trichet told the French radio station RTL. ''Inflation is ebbing, but it remains a concern.'' The comments were the first by a bank policy maker since the bank left interest rates unchanged on Thursday. On the same day, the Bank of England unexpectedly trimmed its rate for a fourth time this year, citing slackening world growth. Lowering interest rates now would go ''against the logic of growth in current circumstances,'' said Mr. Trichet, who is also governor of the Bank of France. ''By preserving price stability, we are working for growth.''

title: ELECTRONIC DATA TO BUY REMAINDER OF UNIGRAPHICS
description: Electronic Data Systems, the second-biggest United States computer services company, said yesterday that it would buy the remainder of Unigraphics Solutions, a software maker, for $172.3 million in cash. Electronic Data, based in Plano, Tex., owns 86 percent of Unigraphics. Under the agreement, Electronic Data will purchase 5.3 million shares at $32.50 each, the companies said in a statement. Electronic Data had acquired Unigraphics, based in Cypress, Calif., from McDonnell Douglas in 1991 and spun it off in 1998, an E.D.S. spokesman, Ish Haley, said. In May, E.D.S. said it would buy Structural Dynamics Research for $950 million in cash. Structural Dynamics is based in Milford, Ohio.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bombing Suspect
description: Scotland Yard said it was looking for a man with a Northern Ireland accent who purchased the used Saab at a local dealership used in the car bombing early Friday of a West London neighborhood. The blast injured 11 people, none seriously, and was the seventh in London in the past 18 months attributed to the Real I.R.A., a dissident Irish group opposed to efforts to forge a political solution in Ulster. Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, condemned the attack, saying ''I want to call upon those who are involved in these actions to stop.'' title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Land Prices Fall
description: Property values in Japan decreased last year for the ninth consecutive year, according to a government survey. On average, land was worth 6.2 percent less in 2000 than in 1999, a slightly slower decline than the prior year's 7 percent. The collapse of a speculative bubble in real estate in the late 1980's has been a principal factor in the country's economic troubles since then. But by world standards, Japanese property is still extremely expensive: land in one part of Tokyo's fashionable Ginza district was worth $9,500 a square foot, up slightly last year, the survey said. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: From Cloning to Cures
description: In a backlash against the onrush of biomedical research into areas that raise moral and ethical issues, the House of Representatives passed a bill this week that would ban all human cloning and subject anyone who violates the ban to criminal penalties and huge civil judgments. Unfortunately, in their zeal to legislate morality and cover their flanks from the religious right, the legislators may put a crimp in research that has promising medical benefits. Once the nature of the work is understood, most citizens would accept the very limited form of cloning involved as a useful scientific tool.

Funeral service wil be held at 3:30PM on Sunday, August 5th at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. description: BURKE-Estelle (nee Levy) of Williamstown, MA. Died August 2. She was the widow of Frederick N. Burke. Born in NYC April 8, 1915. Daughter of the late Louis and Agusta Levy. Attended schools Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Lincoln High School. She received an honorary degree from Morgan State College for her volunteer work in public service and politics. She was politically active and was a member of Freedom Riders in the Cause for Desegregation of Blacks. She worked tirelessly for the freedom and equality of all peoples. She was a member of the Democratic Party in New Rochelle and was the local Chairperson for the John F. Kennedy/Adlai Stevenson and Robert Kennedy Presidential Campaign as well as coordinating the Democrats for Lindsay campaign in NYC. She was a member of Americans for Democratic Action and was an activist in the fight against Joseph McCarthy. She moved to Williamstown in 2000. Survivors, daughter, Leslie Rich, Williamstown, MA; grandson, Edward Rich, Williamstown; brother and sister-in-law, Morton and Lorraine Levy, Great Neck, L.I. Memorial service will take place at a later date. Burial is private. Donations to: Massachusetts Commission for the Blind, The Milne Library, Williamstown or to Visions, NYC. For information arrangements were made through Flynn & Dagnoli Funeral Home, North Adams, MA.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Spike In Power Prices
description: The first week of a program introducing electricity deregulation in Texas began with a temporary spike in prices. On Monday, at least two generating companies did not meet a deadline for submitting their bids for the reserve market. As a result, officials said, demand outstripped supply, pushing the average price of $10 to $45 per megawatt-hour to a capped high of $1,000 per megawatt-hour. By Tuesday prices fell back to normal, and officials said the spike should not affect consumer prices. The entire Texas market is to be deregulated on Jan. 1.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Income Rises At Petrobras
description: Petrleo Brasileiro, Brazil's state-controlled oil company, said second-quarter net income surged 42 percent as oil prices rose and revenue increased 26 percent. Petrobras, as the company is known, said consolidated profit was 3.14 billion reais ($1.25 billion), or about 2.89 reais a share, up from 2.21 billion reais ($890 million), or 2.04 reais a share, a year earlier. The results have not been audited, the company said, and more detailed results will be released on Aug. 14. ''The results were solid,'' said Carlos de Leon, an analyst with Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown in New York. ''They're in line with expectations.'' Rising crude oil prices and higher output helped increase earnings. Since Petrobras sells its oil in dollar-linked prices, a weakening of the real helped bolster earnings in reais. Petrobras said it cut refining costs about 6 percent during the first half of the year, compared with the period a year earlier. The average cost of producing a barrel of crude from reserves also fell.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Possible Joint Bid For Pipeline
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Russia's OAO Gazprom are considering joining forces to bid for a $14 billion project to build a natural gas pipeline across China. Shell and Gazprom are two of the four companies that have been selected to bid for the project; the other two are Exxon Mobil and BP. By combining their efforts, they hope to present a stronger bid than the other companies. The pipeline, to be managed by the PetroChina Company, will carry gas 4,000 kilometers, from China's northwestern Xinjiang province to the eastern metropolis of Shanghai. The project is a centerpiece of China's plan to develop the country's poorer western provinces. China also wants to use more natural gas and reduce its dependence on coal and oil, which are more polluting. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: A Slow Train Across Siberia
description: When you ride the Trans-Siberian Railroad from this Pacific seaport to Moscow, you spend a week traveling 5,778 miles with strangers -- and keep in mind that once you have lugged your suitcases to the station, none of you will have a real chance to bathe. You share a compartment with three other passengers, sleeping on a mattress rolled out on a padded bench. Irritable conductors sometimes keep one toilet locked for their own use, creating lines at the other. Those who can't afford the dining car often end up surviving on fly-specked drumsticks or cabbage pies sold by vendors at stops along the way.

title: A Clown Harboring an Inner Artist
description: EARLIER this summer, Zero Mostel was on the walls of the Gallery-by-the-Sea in Port Clyde, Me., with an exhibition of 50 paintings and drawings. Even before he was an actor, Zero was a dedicated artist, and, for him, the two professions were related. Through the art, one can begin to see the prismatic diversity of the man, who with bold strokes expressed his theatricality on canvas and paper. In the gallery were abstracts, nudes, abstract nudes and, most impressively, self-portraits. Each self-portrait was different, as if the subject were playing a series of roles in life.

title: Ronda's Caves

title: The Zen of the Bus
description: THE subway is New York itself: brash, loud, defiant, overcrowded and unpredictable. The bus, by contrast, is rarely seen as anything other than a lumbering, lurching, coughing cousin of its fleeter subterranean rival. In the myth and lore of New York the subway has the legs of an Irish Riverdancer, while the bus is no more athletic than an elderly man with back pain.

title: Mob Life Draped in Angst (Sounds Familiar, Right?)
description: JUST after he made television safe for pastels with ''Miami Vice,'' and long before his Oscar nomination for ''The Insider,'' Michael Mann created one of the best television series you've probably never seen: ''Crime Story.'' The noirish period drama, in several ways a precursor of ''The Sopranos,'' starred Dennis Farina, a Chicago policeman-turned-actor, as Lt. Michael Torello, a Chicago cop who chased his demons -- and the mob -- all the way to Las Vegas. Viewers can now catch up with the series on A & E, which is rerunning it on Monday nights at 9.

title: New Kids on the Block
description: Jessie Della Femina, who is all of 15 years old, is an up-and-coming name in the fashion world. She has successfully completed two trunk shows, yet she still goes to school and works at a day camp. Being a 15-year-old high-school student myself, I don't understand how she does it. Last month, I was asked to interview her from a ''teenager's perspective.'' Jessie is a soon-to-be-sophomore at Spence and was one of the lucky ones chosen from among the many aspiring designers at the Henri Bendel ''open see'' day. (Anna Sui and Todd Oldham had been selected many years before.) Bendel's then gave Jessie a spot where she could sell her designs. Her clothes, which are very, very cool, are the most colorful and delicate pieces you could imagine. I wanted everything. I was very impressed at the success she has made already, but she is really just beginning.

The jungle swamps encroached on and squared the glen, deep green to black. Loud birds and alligators groaning in their mating season roamed in songs from bayou to bayou. Some fish walked on land in this season.

title: Editorial Notebook; Waiting for Summer to Catch Fire
description: The Bighorns are dry right now, and so is the Wind River Range. A wildland fire burns just west of Wheatland, Wyo., another near Dubois, and still another on the eastern flank of Yellowstone. At the moment, there are fires in Arizona, South Dakota, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, Washington and California, some on rangeland and some in heavy timber. Severe drought has overtaken most of southern Idaho, the northeast quadrant of Nevada and much of the northwest. In conditions like these, every thunderhead is a potential arsonist and every camper a potential incendiary. Summer is a matter of waiting for fire lines to be drawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMOWITZ, JOAN ELAINE (GERSCH)
description: ABRAMOWITZ - Joan Elaine (Gersch), of East Brunswick, NJ, died peacefully in her home Wednesday surrounded by loved ones after a courageous battle with cancer. She was 67. A strong, intelligent woman with an indomitable spirit, she provided the glue to her immediate and extended families. Mrs. Abramowitz was active in community service, including five years on the East Brunswick planning board, and serving as its Chairperson in the late 1970s. A nature conservationist, she served as President of the East Brunswick Garden Club. In 1978, Mrs. Abramowitz and her husband were honored on behalf of the State of Israel for their many years of service. In 1979, Joan began a 19-year career in college counseling, helping hundreds of local student find their college match. Joan is survived by her husband, Victor, her brother Will Gersch, her children Beth, Jeff, Richard and Amy, and seven grandchildren. She was dearly loved and respected by all. Services have been held. Donations may be made to the Joan Abramowitz Memorial Fund, c/o the East Brunswick Jewish Center.

title: July 29-Aug. 4; Vieques Votes a Halt
description: Maneuvers -- both military and civilian -- began anew in Vieques. Two-thirds of the Puerto Rican island's residents voted for the Navy to immediately leave the eastern area it has been using as a firing range. The symbolic vote came after a campaign that portrayed the Navy's 61-year presence as an environmental danger and a violation of residents' civil rights. But President Bush held firm to his declaration that the military would leave in May 2003, and bombing practice resumed, as did the arrests of protesters. David Gonzalez

Powered by small motors activated after a rider starts pedaling, ebikes run on rechargeable batteries, travel 15 to 20 miles on one charge and cruise at speeds up to 25 miles an hour, which adds oomph when scaling Central Park's hills. The manufacturers include Mercedes, whose new Hybrid Bike costs $2,499 at www.PowerAssist.com; Th!nk, a Ford division; and LaFree, based in Seattle. Ebikes by Th!nk and LaFree sell for $995 at Freewheels, on East Houston Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANCKER, JAMES W.
description: BANCKER-James W., 81. Of Atlanta died Friday, August 3, 2001. Born in Oak Park, IL and raised in Summit, NJ, Jim graduated from Andover University in 1938 and Yale University in 1942 with a BA in English Literature. He went on to Rutgers University where he received his MBA in Business Administration. He attended N.Y.U. Jim was a veteran of W.W. II and the Korean Conflict where he served his country proudly in the United States Army. He was a P.O.W. for two years being held in Germany and Poland before escaping. Jim retired as Director of Operations for Western Electric Company. He was preceded in death by his brother, Robert Bancker who lost his life in the Korean Conflict, and his sister, Louise Buckman. Jim is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Peggy Bancker; daughters, Carol Bancker of British Columbia, Canada, Adrienne Bancker of Marietta; and 1 granddaughter, Jennifer Bancker of British Columbia, Canada. A Funeral Service will be held Sunday, August 5th, at two o'clock at Patterson's Arlington Chapel. Interment Services to follow at Arlington Memorial Park. Those who prefer may make a Memorial Contribution in Jim's name to Our Lady of Perpetual Help Cancer Home, 760 Pollard Blvd. SW, Atlanta, GA 30315. H.M. With the stock near $44, Palm was well below its March 2000 peak of $165, reached on its first day of trading. He put a 12-month price target of $80 on the shares, reflecting his belief that they would trade at 19 times his 2001 sales estimate for the company.

A flag-pattern chiffon shirt rippled in the breeze. Jeans brought a sophisticated printed strapless top down to earth. All-white clothes befitted the summer day. The event, an annual discount designer shopping spree called Super Saturday, included a carnival, food tables and a concert by Patti LaBelle. Held in the fields of the Nova's Ark Project in Water Mill, N.Y., it was attended by 1,500 and raised $830,000 for ovarian cancer research. Give a prize to the kids with faces painted to match their dresses.

title: Air Ballet

When we have a hankering for a midnight snack, we shuffle horizontally into the kitchen. When we realize we've run out of shampoo, we trek horizontally to the drugstore. Vertical motion is far less efficient. If you jump a few inches off the ground, you have to return to where you started. Going up always requires coming down.

title: A Graphic Life
description: Bob's diner on Polk Street is just two blocks up from where tourists catch the cable car for a joy ride to downtown San Francisco and just beyond where the hustlers and junkies stroll. Plastic grapes festoon the walls above cracked gray vinyl booths. The chow is strictly short order. In the center of the restaurant, her tweed coat slipping onto the speckled linoleum, a 40-year-old woman sketches in a notebook. When she looks up, time bends. Phoebe Gloeckner has expectant hazel eyes and brown hair shot through with red highlights. She wears round antique spectacles over a small Band-Aid where her 2-year-old accidentally jammed them into the bridge of her nose. She may be an established medical illustrator and mother of two married to a chemistry professor, but she also, quite startlingly, has the face of her 15-year-old alter ego, Minnie, the subject of Gloeckner's semiautobiographical cartoons. Minnie, who was booted from some of the finest Bay Area private schools. Minnie, who was sexually involved with her mother's boyfriend. Minnie, whose best friend dosed her with Quaaludes then traded Minnie's body for more drugs. In fact, if you set the Way Back machine to a quarter-century ago, you could find the teenage Phoebe sitting in this very spot, scribbling in her diary, bearing witness to her life. Bob's was her refuge; safely above the street scene's DMZ, she wasn't likely to run into anyone here who would question what she was writing or why.

title: Extravagant (Except in Quality)
description: CLEOPATRA.'' More than two years in the making. A cast of thousands. Starring Elizabeth Taylor, Rex Harrison and Richard Burton. ''Not a terrible film by any means,'' said Martin Landau, who played the Roman officer Rufio in the movie, directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. It was pretty bad, though, despite its front-rank talent. When it opened in the summer of 1963, the film was as notorious for its extravagant production costs as for the tumultuous affair between Burton and Ms. Taylor that had begun on the set. On screen, the machinations in Roman and Egyptian high places had their moments, but artistically ''Cleopatra'' was swallowed by its gilded pavilions. For all the gigantism, one critic called it a mouse.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-5-01: How To Get A Deal On A Car; Late Summer Harvest
description: 1. Time your attack. Conventional wisdom holds that August is the best time to buy a new car. Sometimes that assumption works to the advantage of the seller. ''The most money I ever made as a salesman was in August, when people thought they were getting the best deal of the year,'' says Ed Wallace, host of an automotive radio talk show in Dallas. The very best bargains can be found in September and October, when dealers are trying to clear the lots for the next year's models. ''Our managers would tell us not to let anyone walk in late October,'' says Joe Girard, the Guinness world-record holder for most cars sold retail. But for buyers looking for the widest selection and the latest model, August can indeed be a good time to shop -- especially this year, when cash rebates and other incentives are averaging $2,619 a vehicle, according to Art Spinella, president of CNW Marketing Research. That's 38 percent more than a year ago.

title: Shades for the Beach

So cosmetic manufacturers are offering a less fussy and gooey alternative: chapstick-like lip tints, with a waxy consistency and pared down packaging. Stila Sport's Bare Color line consists of six sheer shades, spiked with sunscreen ($12 each at Saks Fifth Avenue). Delux Beauty carries four equally streamlined Tintstiks, which provide sun-parched lips with moisturizers and colors so sheer you don't even need a mirror to apply them ($12 at all Sephora stores). Tarte's 24/7 lip sheers come in attractive pink matte-aluminum cylinders: a color for every day of the week ($12 each at Henri Bendel).

title: MEGAN'S LAW DETAILS
description: Essex, Passaic and Camden Counties lead the state in the number of registered sex offenders with 2,317 of the total 7,605 registered under the state's sexual predators act, known as Megan's Law, from the time it was passed in November 1994 through last February, according to a report released last week by the Administrative Office of the Courts. The law requires released sexual offenders to register with the police and allows notification of neighbors, schools and community groups. Of those registered, 98 percent are male; 49 percent are white, 34 percent black and 11 percent Hispanic.

description: JUDY DAVIS had worked for a surgical instruments maker in Cincinnati for three years -- as a contract worker, not an employee -- and when she was laid off five months ago, she burst into tears. But she was not surprised.

title: A Family And Tribe Regain A Piece Of History
description: ON that Friday in May, Helen Rush Robinson, an elder of the Nuu-chah-nulth people, packed the black and red cape she had emblazoned with images of her family story -- a moon, a canoe and a thunderbird -- and joined relatives and other members of the tribe for the trip by car and ferry to Vancouver.

title: Drilling Summer Students In the A B C's of the A.B.T.
description: HISTORICALLY, American Ballet Theater doesn't train dancers; it hires them. For 31 years, however, it had a famous school, the Ballet Theater School. Founded by the company directors Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith and defined by its legendary teachers, especially Valentina Pereyaslavec and the New York City Ballet ballerina Patricia Wilde, the school was a hot spot. Ballet Theater stars and the likes of Fonteyn, Nureyev and Allegra Kent took its professional classes.

Recently, Giselle Bundchen was spotted buying one of Fiorucci's $200 Twin Sets, a belt and handbag with star-shaped studs and leather and rhinestone trim (in a handy twist, the belt can double as a shoulder strap). Institut, on Spring Street, offers a more structured handbag by Tenax ($120) with studded leather sides and handles.

Architects like the elder statesman Ricardo Legorreta, the art-world favorites Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron and the up-and-coming Michael Maltzan have all been tapped, by forward-thinking clients with ample budgets, to create avant-garde villas among the grapevines.

A luncheon was conducted Friday in a huge white tent to honor the drivers who have won the Brickyard 400, and seated on a high dais, from left to right, wearing the golf shirts of their corporate sponsors, were Jeff Gordon, Ricky Rudd and Dale Jarrett.

description: ONE million dollars doesn't go far in Palm Beach's high-end residential hyper market. In some new properties, it may just cover hardware costs, said Jeffrey W. Smith, an architect leading the current mega-mansion revival in this oceanfront resort.

Add to that list Carlisle, Pa., a town with fewer than 20,000 people and a modest economy driven by state government jobs and the defense industry.

title: The Growing Pains of Managed Care
description: Over the past two decades managed care plans have grown so rapidly that they now cover roughly two-thirds of all Americans. But the factors that made managed care successful at first in controlling costs have begun to turn against it. With fewer options for building profits, managed care plans may have to get tougher in denying care to their members. That is why it is critical to get a strong patients' rights bill.

title: Yegorova Wins Ruling; Godina Wins Gold
description: The first full day of competition in the world track and field championships was the day John Godina of the United States won his third and most cherished world title in the shot-put. It was the day the world's fastest man, Maurice Greene, sent a message to his fellow American sprinters instead of receiving one. But as it turned out, and as it too often turns out in modern sports, the day belonged to the continuing struggle to test for performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Suffolk Readies Plan To Meet Bioterrorism
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, a Suffolk County police sergeant began comparison-shopping for makeshift morgues. As unlikely as it may seem, Long Island officials are taking the threat of biological terrorism seriously. With cold-war sobriety they have been meeting regularly to develop a plan for handling a bacterial or viral disaster.

title: Fin of Another Sicle
description: WE are all citizens of two centuries now, so I find myself turning to artists who experienced the same thing 100 years ago -- a generation of writers who were middle-aged when they crossed that boundary, but flung or slyly tossed their visionary bolts across the divide.

description: AT age 19 and on the cusp of stardom, Anne Hathaway has that just-so mix of self-confidence and self-effacement that embellishes her girl-next-door good looks.

description: FROMM-Leo. July 24, 2001. The Rotary Club Of New York mourns their President Emeritus. He was a true humanitarian.

title: July 29-Aug. 4; Dark Side of Dating
description: They are not even old enough to be called battered women. But 1 in 5 adolescent girls endures physical or sexual violence at the hands of a dating partner, according to a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association. The abused girls, the study found, were more likely to report serious problems like drug abuse, unhealthy weight control practices, risky sexual behavior, pregnancy and suicide attempts. Erica Goode

title: A Distant Corner of Europe
description: A FEW minutes after the border guard on the train to Ljubljana handed back our passports, we spotted a long-legged, bluff-gray heron standing calmly in the shallows of the Savinja River in Slovenia. A few minutes after that, we caught our first glimpse of a ruined mountaintop castle, perched on an escarpment above the town of Celje. The prospects of unspoiled nature and the evocative remains of Central Europe's tangled history were what had drawn my wife, Zsofia, and me to this tiny, tidy Alpine republic, and it was already clear we would not be disappointed.

title: RIGHT TO SUE H.M.O.'S
description: Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week signed legislation that would allow patients to sue their health care providers for injury caused by denial or delay of medical care. The Health Care Accountability Act enables patients who have been seriously injured to directly sue health management companies and provides an independent review program for patients with less serious injuries. Shirley K. Turner, one of the bill's sponsors said that the prospect of a lawsuit will pressure H.M.O.'s ''to provide fast, proper care in the first place.'' The bill will go into effect in late September. Anne Ruderman

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Here Come the Alpha Pups
description: Early this year, market researchers headed into playgrounds, skate parks and video arcades throughout Chicago looking for what they called alpha pups. They went up to boys between the ages of 8 and 13 with a question: ''Who's the coolest kid you know?'' When they got a name, they would look for that kid and put the question to him. The goal was to ascend the hierarchy of coolness, asking the question again and again until someone finally answered ''Me.'' By the end of April, they had found alpha pups in most of the schools in Chicago and made them an offer that sounded too good to be true. Hasbro would pay them $30 to learn a new video game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAPLAN, ALAN H., ESQ.
description: KAPLAN-Alan H., Esq. Of Chevy Chase, M.D., who, we hope, attained in his 71 years his youthful wish to ''be happy''. He was a supportive and vital member of our family circle on many levels, a loyal friend and our much-loved and loving brother. Naomi and Martin Karp Ruth and Jay Green

title: 'You're Right, Dear.' 'If You Say So, Dear.'
description: THE comic actors and writers Rene Taylor and Joe Bologna, who have collaborated together onstage and off since the 1960's, have brought their latest show, ''If You Ever Leave Me . . . I'm Going With You!,'' to Broadway, where it opens tomorrow night under their direction at the Cort Theater. It's a delayed encore of sorts, after their 1968 Broadway show, ''Lovers and Other Strangers,'' which was subsequently made into a movie. What happened to them -- and their arguments -- in the ensuing years is one of the subjects of their current play. What inspired them to write is another, described in this conversation, which they have also written.

title: Private Sector; New Journey of a Travel Pioneer
description: FOR Richard N. Barton, the success of Expedia Inc., the online travel agency he created five years ago in Redmond, Wash., is not unlike the satisfaction of painting a house.

title: Lawton Got His Start From Puckett
description: Kirby Puckett has given Matt Lawton many things over the years. Puckett, who will enter the National Baseball Hall of Fame on Sunday, gave Lawton his glove, his wisdom, a nickname and a spot in the majors.

title: DataBank; Interest-Rate Outlook Fuels Half-Hearted Buying
description: With only a handful of stragglers in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index reporting quarterly earnings last week, investors focused on the possibility of lower interest rates as a reason to buy stocks. But that was not enough to sustain much of a rally.

title: Corrections
description: A pop/jazz listing on Page 33 of Arts & Leisure today misstates the day of a concert by Laura Cantrell at the Bowery Ballroom. It is Aug. 18, not next Saturday.

title: Cooler Than Leather
description: For men, recycled denim shoes and sandals can provide sporty alternatives to classic leather. Tootsie Plohound carries loafers ($280) and oxfords ($285), both by Miu Miu, while D&G, by Dolce & Gabbana, offers a more ventilated option: patchwork slides, ornamented with a minirendition of a stitched back pocket ($295 at Gerry's Chelsea). And Jimmy Choo stitches up a more streamlined version, with deckle-edged denim slides ($210 at Jimmy Choo).

title: Personal Watercraft Riders Seek Understanding
description: Mayor William Kelly of Asharoken certainly didn't mince words when he characterized Jet Skiers as an ''emotion-laden group of people who want instant gratification'' [''For Jet Skiers, a Little Less V-r-r-o-o-o-o-m!'' July 22]. What about other thrill-seekers -- boaters, pilots, hang gliders, drinkers, attendees of violent movies and amusement parks (the list goes on and on)? Are they bad people, too?

title: Champions Bracket the Field
description: The unexpected happened in the Dortmunder Sparkassen International Tournament: the two World Champions, the Russian, Vladimir Kramnik of Braingames, and the Indian, Viswanathan Anand of FIDE, were the favorites, but they had opposite results. Kramnik, playing exciting chess, shared first place with the Bulgarian grandmaster Veselin Topalov, both tallying 6 1/2-3 1/2, while Anand came in last with 3-7.

title: Wanted: Rebel to Fill the Shoes of a Giant
description: JAMES FRANCO, 23, isn't the first actor to play James Dean, but he may be the quietest. Seated in an ornate alcove off the lobby of the St. Regis Hotel in New York, sipping mineral water, all dressed up for a screening of his TNT film ''James Dean'' and the celebrity dinner afterward, he was polite but terse, still using the Dean body language that he gets very close to perfect in the film.

title: Corrections
description: The Boating Report article in the sports pages last Sunday misstated the nationality of Lisa McDonald, the skipper of the all-female team entered in this fall's around-the world Volvo Ocean Race. She is American, not British.

title: The Surprising Expense For the AirTrain
description: Re the article about the AirTrain terminal under construction at Jamaica [''Jamaica Station Project: Making Train-Changing More Pleasant (by 2005),'' July 15]: The cost of this terminal is stated to be $326 million. A reference to it in an earlier issue of The Times (Sept. 17, 2000) gives its cost as $300 million. On top of this, the cost of the alterations at the Long Island Rail Road station for the improved track access is given as an additional $249 million. The total for this station work comes out at more than half a billion dollars.

title: Faking It
description: The article does not report on the reliability of Marcus's advice or on whether people have been hurt by that advice. Lewis ought to have asked Marcus if he ever received complaints or if he knew what had happened to those he advised. To set aside the issue of whether Marcus hurt people or helped them is to set aside the whole point of the story, which is whether someone untrained in law can actually provide reliable legal advice or is a serious menace on a keyboard.

title: Why Don't Men and Women Play Golf Together?
description: Both genders spoke out this week about why they do or don't play golf with the opposite sex. The most commonly mentioned factors including the desire for same-sex camaraderie as well as a desire not to need to impress someone of the opposite sex while playing a game that exposes flaws as mercilessly as golf.

title: July 29-Aug. 4; A Congressional Flurry
description: Racing toward the summer break, the House and Senate approved parts of President Bush's legislative program, but left final action on disputed points until September. The House passed a patients' bill of rights that restricts lawsuits more than the Senate's version; Mr. Bush has promised a veto. The House also passed energy legislation that would open an Arctic preserve to drilling, but would not raise fuel-efficiency standards for S.U.V.'s; Senate Democrats threatened a filibuster. And the Senate accepted the House version of a $5.5 billion farm aid bill; Democrats had wanted to add $2 billion. ''We're headed for a year of strong, meaningful legislative achievements,'' Mr. Bush said, before leaving for a month's vacation. John H. Cushman Jr.

title: In Genoa's Noise, a Trumpet for Capitalism
description: THE latest protest-riddled meeting of the world's industrialized powers is over, but not before inspiring more unease about the whole idea of these high-level schmoozefests. A single demonstrator in Genoa, Italy, was killed -- in the act of hurling a fire extinguisher at a police van -- and many influential people suddenly began to fret very loudly in public.

title: A Tenacious Disease Finds New Victims in British Herds
description: Three months ago, running for re-election and anxious to improve public confidence in his government's agricultural policy, Prime Minister Tony Blair boldly declared that the country's foot-and-mouth crisis had turned the corner and was ''in the home straight.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-5-01: Gestures; To the Point
description: When the New York Yankees visited the Oval Office this spring to be honored for winning the World Series, George W. Bush, true to form, engaged in some good-natured banter with the Yankees' principal owner, George Steinbrenner. According to press reports, while the players laughed, Steinbrenner and Bush pointed fingers at each other.

title: Marie-Sophie Calderara, Leonard Auchincloss
description: Marie-Sophie Calderara, the daughter of Marie-Odile and Mario Calderara of Angoulme, France, was married yesterday to Leonard Milburn Auchincloss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Stirling Auchincloss IV of Woodbury, Conn. The Rev. Robert L. Ficks III performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, Conn.

description: TODAY, a test:

title: The World: Reigning, and Reining In; A Not-Quite-So-Deep Pocketbook
description: IN a show of solidarity with the suffering British taxpayer, Queen Elizabeth has been doing a bit of belt tightening.

title: Robin Countee, Myles Pistorius
description: Robin Denise Countee, the daughter of Jane A. Countee and Dr. Roger W. Countee of Watchung, N.J., was married on Friday to Myles Christopher Pistorius, a son of Cassandra A. Pistorius and Frederick E. Pistorius of Marlton, N.J. The Rev. Francis X. Pistorius, an uncle of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark.

title: Hold Fire
description: A friend of mine is a classic hidropoiesist: he perspires when the thermometer hits 33 (Fahrenheit!) and is consequently less and less comfortable as the spring and the summer months rage on. He can't wear a suit or even a sport jacket without his body weeping. His sartorial preferences from May to October, were he allowed to exercise them, would be wife-beaters and those little blue underwear bikinis favored by the Brits. So, of course, August is particularly nasty for him. He doesn't enjoy eating, since everything he puts in his mouth also makes him yearn to remove clothing. So for him and his fellow sufferers, here are a few suggestions not only for dining in August but also for surviving what may be their cruelest month -- particularly here in what is frequently the Baked, Steamed and Braised Apple.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-5-01: The ethicist; No Need for Speed
description: A neighboring town enforces its speed limits by having police cars lie in wait for speeders. Many drivers flash their headlights to alert others to slow down and avoid a ticket. This results in the same type of driving the police are trying to enforce. So, is it O.K.? E.B., Massachusetts

title: Summer Reading
description: To the Editor: About ''Don't Take Boswell to the Beach'' (July 8), by Jennifer Moses: What reader would take just one book on vacation (especially ''How We Die'')? I can't get by without at least three a week -- not that I read all of them, but I get very nervous if a book that fits my present humor is not nearby.

title: CRIME
description: Students of the more morbid branches of forensic science will find themselves in hog heaven when they open FATAL VOYAGE (Scribner, $25), Kathy Reichs's most graphic foray to date into the macabre business of processing human remains in the event of unnatural death. Temperance Brennan, a scrupulously professional forensic anthropologist who has really earned her bones, so to speak, in this series, is routed to the scene of a commercial airline crash in the Great Smoky Mountains of North Carolina to help out with victim identification and mortuary services -- which, given the extent of the carnage, largely entails fighting off bears and other forest predators for the body parts strewn all over the scenery. After walking us through the grisly procedural work at the site and talking us through official theories on the cause of the crash, Tempe pulls up a foot that doesn't match a body -- and targets herself for danger.

title: POSTINGS: 138 Apartments at First Avenue and 23rd Street; 20-Story Rental to Glisten in '02
description: An abundance of glass -- floor-to-ceiling windows surrounded by frosted translucent panels -- is to fill the spaces between rough-hewn, buff concrete columns at the Post Luminaria, a new 20-story rental to be completed next summer at the corner of First Avenue at 23rd Street.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I just love it here. The only thing I don't care for is the summer. I hate the heat.''

title: Add Five in Guilford (And a Dog) to Census
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX; How Am I Doing?
description: IT must be later than I think. I just had my first glimpse of ''back to school'' sale items in a newspaper. Can it be that time already? Not quite, but it is drawing near to the moment when every store is vying for the opportunity to sell you a year's worth of paper and pens.

title: Al, Again
description: Al Gore is coming back. We should have expected him. Bill Clinton came back last week, at a giddy welcoming party from the neighbors of his new Harlem office. The former president was looking so charismatic that it seemed it would be only a matter of time before Mr. Gore would pop up, too, so we could make unfavorable comparisons of his people skills.

title: STATEN ISLAND
description: The Amalgamated Transit Union, Local 726, is suing the city for picking Atlantic Coach Expressways, a private, nonunion company, to run two express commuter bus lines from the South Shore to Manhattan. Larry Hanley, union president, said the city should have sought City Council approval before awarding the contract to Atlantic. The lines are to begin this month. JIM O'GRADY

title: Record Label in Pleasantville Celebrates 5th Anniversary
description: When Irwin Katz retired as a professional musician (he played trumpet in the Cleveland Symphony Orchestra) at age 28, he took a job as a record executive. When he retired as a record executive, having worked at the classical divisions of RCA and later Sony/CBS, he decided to start a record label of his own.

title: Sports of The Times; This Player Is Busy During Halftime, Too
description: THE San Diego Spirit players were clumping off the field for the brief intermission. Captain Julie Foudy spotted Walter Fawcett standing outside the locker room holding 7-week-old Madilyn Rae Fawcett.

title: U.S. Gets Too Few U.N. Jobs, Report Says
description: Even though the United States and Japan are the largest contributors to the United Nations system, the two countries have fewer of their citizens on staff, particularly in European-based agencies, than other countries do, according to Congressional investigators in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REHBOCK, ALIX
description: REHBOCK-Alix. Passed on June 6 in Atlanta, Georgia. Raised in Great Neck. He worked for Revlon, Amirati & Puris, and Ogilvy & Mather as a Commercial Artist and Art Studio Manager. Alix worked for Fine Print and Thinkhouse Creative in Atlanta. Survivors include his sister Alana Rehbock & mother Anita Dantzic Rehbock. Memorial service on August 19 at 11, William Breman Jewish Home, 3150 Howell Mill Road, Atlanta 30327-2199. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The William Breman Jewish Home.

title: July 29-Aug. 4; Russia Releases Student
description: John E. Tobin Jr., the Fulbright scholar from Connecticut, was freed from a Russian prison camp after his captors told a local court that he had been a model inmate, good at woodworking, sports and churchgoing. No one mentioned the case's bizarre course: Russian accusations that he was not only a drug user but an American spy-in-training (he once served in an Army reserve intelligence unit) -- and his own allegation that Russian agents manufactured the drug charge after he refused to become their informant. Mr. Tobin was silent after his release from a prison sentence that once totaled 37 months. But the warden gave him souvenirs and promised to e-mail. Michael Wines

title: Faking It
description: As a divorce with two sons who has survived a four-year custody war, I would guess that Marcus Arnold probably has done no more harm in offering common-sense advice than my first divorce lawyer or my ex-husband's first two lawyers did (Michael Lewis, July 15). To me, the most bizarre aspect of the story was his parents' apparent ignorance of what he does online and with whom he comes into contact.

title: Open-Space Bond Plan Divides Southampton
description: The Southampton town supervisor, Vincent J. Cannuscio, has proposed a $60 million bond sale for protecting farms and open space, the largest preservation initiative ever for any of Long Island's 13 towns. But environmental groups, which have long accused Mr. Cannuscio of not doing enough to carry out existing town preservation plans, are skeptical.

title: A Musical Capital Looks to America
description: IN the lobby of the Gasteig, the cultural complex here that houses the Philharmonie, an elderly woman making her way through the crowd at the intermission of a concert by the Munich Philharmonic imperiously demanded my arm and assistance in negotiating a flight of stairs. ''Well,'' I said, to make polite conversation as she concentrated on the descent, ''how do you like the concert?''

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: These Workaday Walls Are Made of Marble

title: CNN Aims at Young Viewers As It Revamps News Format

Worried about a sharp falloff in business, Mr. Claflin moved to cut thousands of jobs. He was among the first prominent technology executive to say publicly that things were looking bad. No matter how they feel about the matter, most musicians -- Israelis and outsiders, Jews and non-Jews -- have complied. No one wants to offend a nation in which the Holocaust is the defining event of almost every family's history.

But the norms of the legal profession should not be disregarded because allegedly gifted people decide to become experts. The need for standards of professionalism still exists. title: Gertrude Stein Meets Veruschka
description: Perhaps the greatest tribute to Horst, the photographer who made celebrities out of models and models out of celebrities, is that several of his portraits are as familiar as their subjects. HORST PORTRAITS: 60 Years of Style (Abrams, $55) includes an astonishing photograph of Joan Crawford, depicting her face engulfed by an oversize black hat -- which is, in turn, dwarfed by her imposing personality. Here, too, is an image of a contemplative Gertrude Stein, peering while her large white poodle, Basket, directs the viewers toward her. Horst Paul Albert Bohrmann was born in Germany in 1906; his first name alone would come to signify the elegant style with which he glamorized his famous sitters. Beginning in 1931, Horst's career as a photographer spanned six decades, during which he worked predominantly for Vogue. While fashion magazines initially relied on royalty, society women and movie stars as models, Horst helped establish the use of professionals, from Helen Bennett and Lud to Suzy Parker and Veruschka. In an introductory essay, Terence Pepper, curator of photographs at the National Portrait Gallery in London, writes that Horst's mastery of light and shadow followed his relationship with George Hoyningen-Huene, the chief photographer of Paris Vogue. Horst evolved his own, more baroque technique with elaborate sets that sometimes required days to construct. Robin Muir's extensive notes on the 133 plates include short biographies of their subjects and anecdotes regarding the shoots. For instance, rather than obey Marlene Dietrich's instruction to duplicate the lighting methods of her Svengali-like film director, Josef von Sternberg, Horst said that he ''moved the light down slightly below her face . . . and all the wrinkles disappeared.'' If his skills could improve the looks of a Dietrich, his appreciative glance demonstrated time and again that beauty is, indeed, in the eye of the beholder. David Kaufman

title: QUICK BITE/East Hanover; Boy Bites Bagel
description: I had pushed my luck. For five and a half years, I'd carried around a scrap of paper with directions to a Route 10 barbecue joint and the soft ice cream stand next door. By the time I finally made the trek, both places had vanished. Life was passing me by like an S.U.V. in the E-ZPass lane. But hope, and hunger, spring eternal, and it wasn't long before the giant violet banner of Jersey Boy Bagels caught my eye. The inside was big, clean and bright, with vast amounts of food behind a long glass counter. I squinted at the overwhelming menu board: eggels (egg on a bagel), omelettes, 15 different types of fresh-baked bagels, muffins, cookies, brownies, crumb cake, salads, soups and knishes. Many of the 25 sandwiches have Jersey-inspired names, from the Trenton Sunrise (chicken salad, bacon, lettuce and tomatoes on wheat) to the Meatless Manasquan (grilled vegetables, roasted peppers and melted mozzarella on a hero). I decided to go south of the border, past Delaware even, and ordered the Tex-Mex, featuring grilled chicken, melted cheddar and salsa on a kaiser roll. All sandwiches are $3.50 to $4.95. Fear not, this Jersey boy also ate a bagel. It was crisp outside, chewy inside, and still hot. For catering, one choice is Jumbo Party Bagels ($49.95, serving up to 18), also with Jersey names. Still, I'd think twice about ordering something called the Tasty Meadowlands. Jack Silbert

title: Enlightenment's Greatest Hits
description: When the first sentence in a book about Zen refers to Gene Kelly, you know you're not in for one hand clapping. Rather, it's both hands clapping for joy in ''The Zen Commandments'' (Jeremy P. Tarcher, paperback, $14.95), by Dean Sluyter, an English teacher in the Pingry School's Martinsville campus. The commandments are in fact ''suggestions,'' the author says, to help develop ''a life of inner freedom.'' A ''Singin' in the Rain'' attitude -- joyfully jumping in puddles -- is what seekers should (though should isn't a useful attitude) be after. The book includes quotations from Zen masters and other sages, but there are also Willie Nelson, Miles Davis and Bob Dylan and . . . Homer Simpson. Mr. Sluyter, who lives in Plainfield, teaches a popular Pingry course called ''Literature of Enlightenment.'' Mr. Sluyter, who also gives talks on meditation, is hoping to teach it in the state's prisons.

title: Private Sector; When Love and Work Clash in the Valley
description: It has not been an easy year for Bruce Claflin, the chief executive of 3Com, the Silicon Valley networking equipment company that has been hit especially hard by the economic slowdown. But Mr. Claflin, 49, said during a visit to New York last week that the most difficult period for him was in January, just after he was appointed to the job. Worried about a sharp falloff in business, Mr. Claflin moved to cut thousands of jobs. He was among the first prominent technology executive to say publicly that things were looking bad. But what really gnawed at Mr. Claflin, he said, was that his wife preferred to believe the less gloomy outlook offered at the time by John Chambers, the chief executive of 3Com's rival, Cisco Systems. ''My wife said she loved me, but that John Chambers knew a lot more than I did,'' he recalled. ''Then it was personal.''

title: E-ZPASS WOES
description: New Jersey's problem-plagued E-ZPass system is unlikely to be able to pay for itself through fines from violators as was planned when it was installed, according to financial records revealed last week. For a two-year period ending in June, violators paid fines totalling $6 million while another nearly $20 million is owed and considered collectable. That is far short of the $101 million officials originally had predicted would be collected in 2001. Revised budget estimates show the system falling $65 million in debt by 2008 rather than having a surplus at that time. Any shortfall will be paid by the road authorities that operate the Garden State Parkway, New Jersey Turnpike and Atlantic City Expressway. Edward Gross, director of the New Jersey Turnpike Authority which oversees the system, said the 2 percent of drivers violating tolls is what was expected and revenues will increase as the system for collecting fines becomes fully operational. Karen DeMasters

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE

He abandons his car and goes stalking across Los Angeles, terrorizing gang members and convenience store owners along the way as he tries to get to his daughter's birthday party. Robert Duvall turns in a nice, low-key performance as the police offier who pursues him. Mr. Douglas's tirade about the service and food at a burger joint is priceless - Thursday at 10:30 p.m. and Friday at 3:30 a.m. on TNT.

title: The Irresistible Lure of Pursuing a Bank Feeder

Or it probably did, as I couldn't really see it. Nor could my fishing buddy, Glyn Vincent. We were bathed in eerie clouds of cold fog, unable to see much farther than 30 feet ahead, or barely across the river in which we stood, holding flyrods.

title: Lost Worlds Interred in a Neglected Newark Cemetery
description: Woodland Cemetery is on the west side of Newark in one of the city's poorer neighborhoods. Left nearly abandoned for years, it became the site for prostitution and drug deals and the home for bands of wild dogs. Unlike the thousands of abandoned cemeteries across the state, Woodland gained attention when it was suspected an unknown number of graves of children, who died during the flu epidemics in the early part of the 20th century, had been covered over by more recent graves of adults who died in the 1960s and 1970s. Partly in response to the rumor of lost children's graves and partly because of complaints from neighbors about the deteriorating condition of the cemetery, the state Cemetery Board ordered the graveyard cleaned up and is in the midst of researching exactly who is buried in the plots. Mark Herr, director of the state Division of Consumer Affairs, which oversees the Cemetery Board, talked recently at Woodland cemetery.

title: Allies in America's National Interest
description: Perhaps no president in recent memory has invoked the phrase ''in the American interest'' so often and so early as George W. Bush. Mr. Bush's rhetoric represents a reaction, fierce among conservatives, to what they view as the fuzzy-minded, multinational foreign policy of Bill Clinton. They loathed Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's ''assertive multilateralism.'' They detested Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott's globalist vision. (''Within the next hundred years,'' Mr. Talbott once wrote, ''nationhood as we know it will be obsolete; all states will recognize a single, global authority.'') Even Democrats seemed to squirm when Al Gore offered condolences to the families of 15 American soldiers who died in Iraq ''in the service of the United Nations.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LA SALA, BRUCE
description: La SALA-Bruce. On Wednesday August 1, 2001 after a long illness. For more than 40 years an attorney in Englewood, NJ, he was known for his pro bono and community service. He was pro bono attorney for the Social Service Federation for 35 years and for the Flat Rock Brook Nature Association. He was a board member of the Englewood Economic Development Corporation, Englewood Hospital, The Experiment In International Living (now World Learning); counsel for the Center For Food Action in Englewood. He served as attorney for the Englewood Planning Board, The Tenafly New Jersey Board of Adjustment and the school boards in Englewood Cliff and Tenafly. For four decades he was a member of the Rotary Club of Englewood. He was a trustee of his alma mata the Englewood School for Boys and its successor Dwight - Englewood School for more than 16 years. After graduating from Harvard, he served as a Marine platoon leader in the Korean War. He received the Purple Heart, the Bronze Star, and the Chung Mu Medal of the Republic of Korea. He continued as an officer of the Marine Corp Reserve until 1978 when he retired with a rank of Kernal. He obtained his law degree from the New York University School of Law. In addition to his wife of 48 years, Margaret, he is survived by his son Steven, his daughter Ann, a daughterin-law Sharon, two grandsons Nathan and Micah, and his sister Victoria La Sala. A contribution to any of the community institutions which he served will be appreciated.
