title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, ANNA
description: GOLDMAN-Anna. Passed away peacefully surrounded by family on August 3. Beloved mother and mother-in-law of Grace and Ted Fuchs, grandmother of Diane Fuchs, Merrill Lee Fuchs and Rebecca Fuchs-Stengel, great-grandmother of Jesse and Raffe FuchsSimon and Scott and Eric FuchsStengel, and wife of the late Harry Goldman. Nanny will be forever in the hearts of her family and friends. There will be a funeral ceremony at the Cemetery Chapel, followed by interment, on Monday, August 6, 2 PM, at the Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview, NJ.

title: SATELLITE TV RIVAL IN BID FOR HUGHES
description: EchoStar, the nation's second-largest satellite television company, made a $30.4 billion unsolicited bid yesterday for its larger rival, Hughes Electronics, the owner of DirecTV. The offer is an effort to pre-empt the sale of Hughes to Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which has been negotiating to buy the company for months.

title: Port Officials Are Accused Of Filing Strip Club Expenses
description: The New Jersey attorney general's office is investigating allegations that two directors of the South Jersey Port Corporation spent hundreds of dollars in taxpayer money at strip clubs in Veracruz, Mexico, last October while attending a port industry convention, and that the port agency's finance director tried to hide the expenses.

title: A Study's Verdict: Jury Awards Are Not Out of Control
description: Critics of the civil justice system have argued for years that reform is needed because of runaway punitive damage verdicts by juries.

title: Shrewd Pit Stop Strategy Puts Gordon in Command
description: Jeff Gordon won another race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway this afternoon, and a delighted crowd toasted him at the finish line by holding up beer cans, waving souvenir checkered flags and using flash cameras that made a brilliant burst of light on his windshield.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISSMAN, DR. KENNETH
description: WEISSMAN-Dr. Kenneth. On the 2nd anniversary of your passing, at the impossibly young age of 54, from a horrific octopi brain tumor, 3 years after we finally found each other, the other day, this: Looking from outside through the bedroom window you saw me. We were floating. Smiling, you said, ''I'm thinking of coming back.'' How much could you love me to do that? We drifted together for a while, deeply immersed in the joyof our own world, and I was positively inconsolable upon waking that morning. Deeply in love, your wife, Audrey Shachnow.

title: Jack Maple, 48, a Designer of City Crime Control Strategies
description: Jack Maple, who helped script the Giuliani administration's crime control strategy, died of colon cancer on Saturday at his Manhattan apartment. He was 48.

title: How Rush to Manhood Scars Young Africans
description: Thabo Nyangiwe was not supposed to end up here, stretched out on an infirmary bed, with a pain that has scarred more than his body.

title: Thanksgiving in Ireland
description: Thanksgiving brings up thoughts of home, but for those who do want to get away, a touch of domesticity can still be found in a country cottage or town house in Ireland. And for $799 a person, based on double occupancy, Country Cottages can provide a week in a one-bedroom cottage in Ireland, a rental car and round-trip flights between New York or Boston and Dublin (through London). The departure date is Nov. 16. The rental car comes with unlimited mileage, insurance and taxes; extra nights in Dublin are $79 a person, with breakfast and tax. Country Cottages is based in Boca Raton, Fla. Information: (800) 674-8883 or www.villacentral.com .

title: Lilly Protects Jeter but Yanks Fall to Anaheim
description: From the crowd at Yankee Stadium down to Derek Jeter, it appeared as though Ted Lilly was trying to protect his teammates. If so, Lilly's first pitch of the sixth inning yesterday served its purpose, hitting the helmet of the Angels' Scott Spiezio in apparent retaliation for Jeter having been hit by a pitch an inning earlier.

title: A Health Danger From a Needle Becomes a Scourge Behind Bars
description: Prison officials say that nearly 10,000 inmates in New York and thousands more across the country are infected with hepatitis C, an insidious liver infection that is difficult to treat, has no definite cure and, over many years, kills 5 percent of those who contract it.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: For Barak, It's Time to Isolate Arafat the 'Thug'
description: At his desk, Ehud Barak could hear the staccato bursts of automatic fire coming today from up the block. A career soldier, Mr. Barak recognized the sounds right away. He learned soon enough that outside Israel's Defense Ministry, where he presided not so long ago, a Palestinian was shooting at Israelis on the street, wounding 10 people before being gunned down.

title: Rusch Matches Schilling, but Mets Lose Endgame
description: Rick White watched the Atlanta Braves game on a clubhouse television at Bank One Ballpark this morning. From his seat in the Mets' bullpen this afternoon, he kept an eye on the out-of-town scoreboard. White knows precisely how many games out of first place the Mets are, and he has seen how helpless they are to get any kind of offense. But he believes they can still contend.

title: Clinton Is Said To Be Close To Book Deal
description: Bill Clinton is close to a deal to sell the rights to publish a memoir for an advance that will probably exceed his wife's near-record payment, people close to Mr. Clinton said last week.

title: Multi-Tasking With an Omnivorous Musician
description: Bilal aims high. He packed huge aspirations into a short set at Pier 17 at South Street Seaport on Thursday, part of the early evening concert series sponsored by Sam Goody.

title: Malaise in Blue
description: To the Editor:

title: Bert Grant, 73, a Beer Maker Who Developed Microbreweries
description: Bert Grant, a veteran brew master who in 1982 opened the granddaddy of all the good, bad and so-so brew pubs slaking thirsts across the country today, died on July 31 at a hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia, where he had recently made his home. He was 73 and a longtime resident of Yakima, Wash.

title: MediaTalk; Publisher Auditions an Online Farm Team
description: In a twist on the scramble to sell electronic books, the publishing division of AOL Time Warner is using digital publishing as a kind of farm team for its traditional print business.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about leadership training programs for girls at Eleanor Roosevelt's cottage, Val-Kill, misidentified an English king she entertained there in 1939. He was George VI, not Edward VIII. The article also misidentified the classical orator who, like a girl in the program, overcame a speech problem. He was Demosthenes, not Cicero.

title: Temples Honor The Golden Age Of Railroading; New Jersey Works to Save Historic Train Stations
description: In the two decades since it took over the financially ailing commuter lines in the state, New Jersey Transit may have failed to awaken warm feelings among most of its riders, but preservationists and railroad buffs fairly gush about the way the agency has preserved its history -- the stations and rail lines that have stitched the state together over the last 150 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUINNESS, EDWARD
description: McGUINNESS-Edward. Peacefully on August 4, 2001. Beloved husband of Soledad and the late Dorothy. Loving father of Patrick, Susan, Doreen, Edward and the late Thomas. Dear stepfather of Ralph. Cherished grandfather of 10. Edward, a proud veteran of WWII, was a Sergeant in the U.S. Marine Corps. Among his many decorations, he received the Purple Heart for injuries sustained on the battlefield. He worked as a Representative of the NY Typographical Union #

description: These equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Pull in Congress Tied to Grants For Research
description: Members of Congress steered a record $1.7 billion to colleges and universities in their home districts in the past year to study topics like ornamental fish and the pungency of onions without going through the usual peer review involved in awarding federal research grants, The Chronicle of Higher Education says.

title: Bare-Bones Budgeting
description: In its 17 straight years of failing to pass a budget on time, the State Legislature has shown remarkable creativity in finding new methods of avoidance. Last week, in a burst of ingenuity, it approved something called a ''bare-bones budget.'' It's a creation that lies somewhere between a real budget and an emergency appropriation, a package with just enough money to keep the state idling along at minimal speed until mid-September, when everybody may be in the mood to try again.

title: Fewer Children Are Hospitalized for Asthma Since 1997 City Effort
description: Hospitalization rates for children having asthma attacks have fallen by more than a third since the city began its first major effort to combat a citywide asthma epidemic in 1997, officials say.

title: The Courage to Rise Above Mammyness
description: Perhaps few Oscars have come so loaded with meaning -- positive and negative -- as the one Hattie McDaniel won for her portrayal of Scarlett O'Hara's mammy in ''Gone With the Wind.''

title: Despite Split on Bush, Governors Find Common Ground
description: The nation's governors gathered here this weekend for their 93rd annual meeting, with an agenda with items as diverse as ''smart growth,'' commerce on the Internet, energy shortages, agriculture biotechnology and health care for the poor and elderly.

title: A Halfhearted Push for Reform
description: George W. Bush, who has never really acknowledged that anything went wrong in the presidential election in Florida, did finally accept the idea last week that the American system of voting needs some reform. He broadly embraced the report of a bipartisan commission on how to overhaul the nation's patchwork electoral system.

title: New Economy; In another telecommunications dispute, this time in Brazil, the new owners for Telecom Italia may need to settle a fight.
description: ON one point, almost everyone agrees: it can't get any worse.

title: In Pursuit of Reality and Life in the Internet Age
description: Michael Lewis has something important to tell us about the effect of the Internet on our lives. Figuring out what that something is may be a frustrating exercise for those tuning in ''Next: The Future Just Happened,'' his four-hour special on A&E tonight and tomorrow, although this uneven program does offer occasional rewards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHERMAN, JAY SUSAN
description: SHERMAN-Jay Susan. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Newton, MA, and NYC, on August 4. Beloved wife of Philip Abrams. Devoted sister of John F. Sherman III. Services at the Sherman Family Mausoleum of Temple Israel of Boston Cemetery on August 7, at 12 noon. Jay Susan Sherman received a Masters of Art and Masters of Philosophy from Columbia University. She was retired editor for Harry N. Abrams, Inc. of New York, where she was picture editor for numerous books, including John Pile's ''Interior Design'' and the illustrated version of Daniel Boorstin's ''The Discovers.'' To send a condolence note: brezniakrodman@aol.com. For further information Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors 800554-2199.

title: Where the 2 Schumanns Found Common Ground
description: Schumann the symphonist and Schumann the writer of songs rarely had a chance to meet. The one poured out surging lyrical lines on a large scale. The other took snapshots of intimate emotions and empowered them with tuneful imagination and original uses of harmony. ''Das Paradies und die Peri'' at Friday's Mostly Mozart evening in Avery Fisher Hall offered a rare merger. It appeared in 1843, his 34th's year, and was produced out of the same obsessive, marathonlike energies that had allowed Schumann in his earlier years to create two or three immortal songs in a single morning.

title: The Nuclear August of 1945
description: I was one of the first American soldiers to visit Hiroshima after its destruction by the atomic bomb 56 years ago today. Until recently, it was not something I talked about. Still now, at 77, it's hard not to cry when I picture walking into that city more than half a century ago. But it's important to remember. There are few of us around who do.

title: A Cool Gunman Wounds 10 Outside Israeli Defense Office
description: In one of the more brazen strikes at Israel's heart, a Palestinian man stepped out of a car today and sprayed automatic rifle fire outside the Israeli Defense Ministry here, wounding 10 people, most of them soldiers on their lunch break.

title: Free Trade and Mexican Trucking
description: The Bush administration is rightly concerned about the nation's failure to comply with a provision of the North American Free Trade Agreement granting trucks from Mexico and the United States the right to deliver goods in each other's markets. Highway safety concerns and organized labor's protectionist pressure led the Clinton administration to delay granting Mexican trucks access beyond a 20-mile-deep border area. A Nafta arbitration panel ruled in February that the United States was in violation of its treaty obligations. Yet Congress is still seeking, ill-advisedly, to obstruct President Bush's plans to open the border by next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CANTOR, BETTY L.
description: CANTOR-Betty L. Died August 4, 2001. Survived by her sister Sophia Sherman, sister-in-law Selma Cantor, nieces and nephews and her very special friends.

title: An Autism Specialist, But She's in Real Estate
description: For years, Susan VanGilder Berman was absorbed by her autistic son's educational needs. She moved with him from Manhattan to Massachusetts to enroll him in a private program there, then back to New York, where he attended two public schools in Westchester County.

title: Paying to Stay In San Francisco
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservative Gay Columnist Is Under Fire
description: Norah Vincent is a little nonplused at the rage she provokes. After all, she is hardly the only young columnist with a shopping cart of views that could stock any good Republican larder. Like her take on abortion (''Ours is a country in which you are ill-advised to be a fetus''). Or on multicultural college curricula (''those nebulous, oh-so-advanced 'ways of knowing' are likely to keep you driving a cab or flipping burgers for the rest of your life''). Or AIDS (gay advocates ''don't like to admit'' that ''gay men must bear the responsibility for the spread of AIDS.'')

title: New President At D'Arcy Agency
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, part of the Bcom3 Group, has named a well-known executive to its worldwide creative post, while also restructuring its management. The changes are effective Aug. 13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VASAVADA, SADGUNA CHANDULAL
description: VASAVADA-Sadguna Chandulal. Passed away on August 1, 2001. Beloved mother of Kamendu (Chicago), Purnendu (River Falls, WI), Dr. Balendu (Scotch Plains, NJ), Harshendu (Saugus, CA), and Mayura (Toms River, NJ) and grandmother of Dr. Reena, Neel, Hemal, Jasmine, Natasha, Zubin and Nisu. She was a lively, caring and devoted wife, sister, mother, and grandmother, who will be forever remembered fondly by her family and friends.

title: Impressionists in Cyberspace, Digital but Diverse
description: ''Above all, trust your first impression,'' the actor portraying the painter Camille Pissarro tells Kirk Douglas's Vincent van Gogh between his bites of the French scenery in the 1956 biopic ''Lust for Life.'' As the re-enactment of a moment in art history, the episode is dubious. But it is undeniable that those wacky Impressionists had their own way of translating their perceptions of the physical world onto canvas.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Arts & Ideas on Saturday in a grouping of three famous Americans and their views on the role of human rights in foreign policy was published in error. The picture, at the right, showed Alexander Hamilton, not John Quincy Adams, who was quoted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELCER, STANLEY
description: MELCER-Stanley. Age 73, of Boca Raton, FL, on August 5. Donations in his memory may be made to the Hillel Day School, 21011 95th Ave South, Boca Raton, FL 33428; and to the Yeshiva High School, 7902 Montoya Circle, Boca Raton, FL 33433.

title: Steven L. Ross -- Association Chairman, 58
description: Steven L. Ross, a lawyer who was chairman of the Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Association, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Minn. He was 58.

title: A Caustic Look In the Mirror From Boomers
description: Joe Queenan is 50 years old and sorely ashamed of it.

title: A Higher Bid Is Reported For British Telecom Network
description: A consortium led by a major German bank has offered to buy the fixed-line network of British Telecommunications for 18 billion, or about $25.7 billion, people close to the discussions said today.

title: A New Hand Guides Opera In Santa Fe
description: There's a new director at the Santa Fe Opera, and he's doing new things. He's reaching out to the community, offering half-price tickets to New Mexico residents who have never been to the opera before (with 7,000 taking him up on it). He's presenting operas outside the regular festival summer season, in November (which sell out). He has added Spanish titles for two operas. He's talking about more new works: the American premiere of Kaija Saariaho's ''Amour de Loin'' next season; the world premiere of ''Madame Mao'' by Bright Sheng in 2003. He's talking about more big-name singers.

title: Compressed Data; Hand-Held Monitor Compiles Heart Data
description: In these demanding digital times, what is more constant than 24/7/365? How about 72 beats a minute.

title: Giants' Defense Aiming to Oust Ravens' as League's Best
description: It is not the hot story of training camp, not as universal as Ron Dayne's losing weight, not as consequential as Tiki Barber's broken hand and not as winsome as staid Coach Jim Fassel's morphing into a designer model.

title: Point Given Illustrates His Class In Haskell
description: This is how talented Point Given is: he did not want to load in the gate for today's Haskell Invitational, spotted four horses a half-dozen lengths for half a mile, then hung in the stretch. Still, when he crossed the finish line at Monmouth Park, he had left little doubt he was better than any other horse in the nation, if not the world.

description: MONDAY: None

title: Smithsonian Must Exhibit Ingenuity in the Face of Overlapping Gifts
description: The Smithsonian Institution has discovered that it is indeed possible to have an embarrassment of riches.

title: Corrections

They were issued by a local development corporation formed by New York City for the purpose and will be secured by the city's rental payments. They were not general obligation bonds, which are secured by the city's faith and credit.

title: Metro Matters; O Politics, Have You No Decency?
description: LEONARD GARMENT is a troubleshooter from way back. Trained in combat by the Nixon White House, he survived Watergate and has instigated, negotiated and litigated more Washington wars than most people realize were ever fought.

description: LONDON, Aug. 6 - The Irish Republican Army has agreed to a method of destroying its arsenal of weapons that is provable and permanent, the commission responsible for the disarming of paramilitary forces in Northern Ireland said today.

title: In America; Tainted Justice
description: Texas has always had a brutally peculiar take on what constitutes justice. A veteran Dallas defense lawyer, reminiscing last year, said, ''At one point, with a black-on-black murder, you could get it dismissed if the defendant would pay funeral expenses.''

title: Venus Williams Calls All the Shots Against Seles
description: Venus Williams looked shaky at the start of today's Acura Classic final. Four double-faults in the first game contributed to giving her opponent, Monica Seles, three break points. One more miscue on Williams's serve and Seles would seize an immediate advantage, along with an important boost of confidence against an adversary she had been unable to conquer in five previous meetings.

title: A Small City Lines Up to Say Goodbye
description: Inside the Warren G. Harding High School gymnasium today was a scoreboard that hung unlit, an American flag taped above a small clock, black and yellow bleachers that were rolled back against the wall, painted acknowledgments of the school's athletic success from 1966 through 2001 and a carpet that formed a huge, square walkway from one side of the building to the other.

title: Food and Wine Tips From Readers
description: From which herbs to grow indoors to finding a favorite recipe for butterscotch fudge, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: United Business Buys Roper Starch
description: NOP World in London and New York, part of United Business Media, agreed to acquire Roper Starch Worldwide in Harrison, N.Y., a marketing research and consulting agency, for $88 million in cash.

title: Sports of The Times; Honor Hits Home For Hall Inductees
description: THE white-haired 64-year-old man, looking more like a neighborhood bartender, perhaps, than the onetime wonderful second baseman of the Pittsburgh Pirates who could execute his end of a double play the way Nureyev could dance a pas de deux, paused in his speech. Bill Mazeroski, a promlike carnation in the lapel of his blue suit, stood on the shaded podium at one end of Clark Sports Center, looking out at some 20,000 people on this warm, sun-splashed afternoon.

title: I.R.A. Agrees to Arms Pact in Move Hailed as Historic
description: LONDON, Aug. 6 — In a move hailed as historic, the Irish Republican Army has agreed to an acceptable method of destroying its arsenal of weapons, the commission responsible for the disarming of paramilitary forces in Northern Ireland said today.

title: Bush Is Ahead Of Clinton Pace On Nominees
description: After half a year in office, President Bush has 52 nominees for executive branch positions awaiting Senate confirmation and 211 positions in his administration yet to be named, according to a running count by the Brookings Institution.

title: Culture Notes: Begin the Beguine
description: The annual summer preview season of Eliot Feld's Ballet Tech troupe begins tonight and runs through Aug. 18 at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea. Seven works by Mr. Feld are being presented in repertory, including a new one, "Pacific Dances," for 11 women, set to Hawaiian slack-key guitar music. Buffy Miller will perform the solo "Kore," created for her in 1988 and set to a Steve Reich score. Other company revivals include "Theater," to Richard Strauss's Burlesque for Piano and Orchestra, and "Jukebox," to vintage rock tunes by Jerry Leiber and Mike Stoller as sung by the Coasters. Reservations: (212) 242-0800.

title: Mexico's Former Ruling Party Notches Up a Rare Victory
description: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 6 - The dinosaurs are not dead yet, not in the state of Tabasco, where the old ruling party, known throughout Mexico by that reptilian epithet, broke a long losing streak and claimed victory in the election for governor today.

Mr. Ambrogi's wonderful musicianship as a longtime member of the trumbone section, coupled with his positive outlook which made us all richer by his presence, will surely be missed. The Goldman Band family extends our sincerest condolences to his family.

title: Lord Longford, Champion of Eccentric Causes, Dies at 95
description: Lord Longford, a Labor peer famed for championing social outcasts and unpopular causes, and lampooned as everything from an endearing eccentric to a bumbling loon, died Friday in a London hospital. He was 95.

title: Arts Abroad; Brazilian Renaissance For an American Poet
description: The American poet Elizabeth Bishop arrived in Brazil in 1951 intending to visit for just a few weeks but ended up staying nearly 20 years. Though many of her finest poems were written in or are about Brazil, she has, strangely, remained largely unknown and even shunned here.

title: With a Fourth Death, a Family's Last Hope Is Lost
description: The smallest bit of comfort for the family of Maria Alta Gracia Pea lay swaddled in a pale blue blanket in a Brooklyn hospital in the very early hours yesterday. With little else to cling to, relatives sat by the incubator holding Ms. Pea's tiny grandson, and prayed that he would make it through the day.

title: Police Officer Is Arraigned In Fatal Crash
description: A New York City police officer was arraigned on charges of manslaughter and drunken driving yesterday after, the police say, his van plowed into a family crossing a Brooklyn street Saturday night, killing a pregnant woman, her 4-year-old son, her sister and, after an emergency Caesarean delivery, her baby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, LEE
description: PARKER-Lee. Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson mourns the passing of former tax partner Lee Parker, who joined our law firm as an associate in 1974 and retired from the partnership in 1999. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his family at this time of loss.

title: Determined Red Sox Still Need Martnez
description: A television station in New England did a feature story last week on a young man who was cycling around the country to raise money for cancer research. He had been away from home for 10 months, riding his bike all day and sleeping in a tent at night. He was away from his family and friends, away from most creature comforts and, please do not forget, away from his Red Sox.

title: Presevo Journal; In Wedding Season, Expatriate Albanians Return
description: ''Where are you, my wife?'' Armend Idrizi, 25, asked and then hooked his hand around the elbow of his new bride, Feime, 22. She looked lovely. He was admirably composed. Three Gypsies, complaining that it was well past beer time, even if this was a Muslim wedding, played horns and a goatskin drum.

description: Former Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel has evolved from being the ''partner for peace'' of Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, to becoming one of his sternest Israeli critics.

title: Freeh Was Spared Censure For Handling of Ruby Ridge
description: An internal Justice Department inquiry recommended that Louis J. Freeh, the former F.B.I. director, and three other bureau officials be censured for managerial failures during follow-up investigations of the deadly standoff at Ruby Ridge in Idaho in 1992, but Justice Department officials rejected any disciplinary action, government lawyers said today.

title: Surprise Starter Helps Angels Beat Yanks
description: The last pitch appeared to be well outside the strike zone and after a momentary pause, home plate umpire Justin Klemm raised his hands to signal a third strike, a call that had the practical effect of detonating the repressed frustration of Jorge Posada. The Yankees' hitter screamed at Klemm, trailing the umpire as Klemm moved to exit the Yankee Stadium field, shot-putting his bat and barking a final four-letter gratuity.

title: Review by Boeing Is Down to 6 Firms

title: Operating Profit Is Off at British Air
description: British Airways, Europe's leading airline, which is seeking an alliance with American Airlines, said today that its operating profit fell 48 percent in the quarter ended June 30. The company blamed an array of factors -- from Britain's continuing foot-and-mouth disease crisis to higher fuel costs -- and said its situation would probably remain bleak until next summer.

In her own movies, she said, she had always celebrated the positive. When asked for an example, she replied, ''Dams.''

description: One of the most popular television shows in Britain today features a nine-inch-tall puppet in a hard hat and overalls. He, and his show, are named Bob the Builder. Millions of British children are tuning in to the 10-minute adventures of this friendly construction worker and his team of fun-loving machines who work together to complete projects and help one another in times of crisis.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Company Is Introduced
description: A team of former executives from Netscape Communications and America Online unveiled Kontiki, an Internet start-up whose technology accelerates and manages downloaded files. Kontiki, which has 50 employees and is based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had raised $18 million in its first financing round. Investors include Benchmark Capital and the Barksdale Group, a venture capital firm led by James L. Barksdale, Netscape's former president and chief executive. One piece of Kontiki's technology is free software that collects and schedules the delivery of digital music, videos, software and games. Mike Homer, Kontiki's chairman and chief executive, said the technology would be available in beta version publicly next month and in final version by the end of the year. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Shenzhen Journal; Golf Obsesses a Boom Town's Elite
description: It was near midnight, and giant floodlights cast a spectral glow on the 18th hole of the Ernie Els savannah golf course here. The air was still and hot, with a hint of smoke from the nearby factories.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on July 24 about Pope John Paul II's comments during the visit of President Bush, in opposition to research on embryonic stem cells, misstated Mr. Bush's stance on the issue during his presidential campaign. At that time, he said he opposed federal financing for such research; he did not promise to allow federal financing for it.

title: U.S. Reports Progress in Fighting Bias; Rights Groups Are Critical
description: The United States has made significant strides in reducing discrimination against minorities, Bush administration officials contend in the first report by the United States to the United Nations body that monitors discrimination worldwide.

title: Second Laborer Tells Court Of Being Lured and Beaten
description: A day laborer beaten along with his housemate last year testified today that he sensed something was wrong as soon as two men who had offered them work pulled their car into an isolated industrial site off the Long Island Expressway. ''I said to my housemate, 'Why are they taking us here, if we are going to work in gardening, or landscape?' '' said Magdaleno Estrada Escamilla as he testified in Suffolk County Court in the trial of Christopher Slavin, one of two men charged in the attack.

title: Israeli Court Allows Return Of Man Indicted in Fraud

Manny Hellen, president of the union local, said the proposed contract also provided job security and improved medical and dental benefits. The old contract expired Jan. 18, 2000. title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Ex-Masseur Sentenced
description: Two weeks after Abdurrahman Wahid was voted out of the presidency, his former masseur, Alip Agung Suwondo, was sentenced to three and a half years in prison for defrauding the state food distribution agency of $4 million by invoking Mr. Wahid's name. title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Scholar Not Bitter
description: John E. Tobin Jr., the Fulbright scholar paroled on Friday from a Russian prison where he had been held on marijuana charges, still loves Russia and is not bitter about his six months in prison even though he maintains that he was wrongly convicted, his father said at a news conference in Moscow. In a curious sense, ''he's had a marvelous experience,'' Mr. Tobin said, adding that ''he's gotten to see Russia from the inside.'' The Tobins plan to return to their home in Ridgefield, Conn., this week. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Compaq Improves Market Share
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation doubled its share of the hand-held computer market last quarter, to 16 percent from 7.8 percent, according to Gartner Inc., a research firm in Stamford, Conn. Overall worldwide sales of hand-held computers declined 21 percent. Palm Inc., the largest maker of hand-held computers, or personal digital assistants, dropped to 32 percent from 50 percent of the market during the quarter. Palm and one of its top rivals, Handspring Inc., reported losses. Handspring fell to third in sales, behind Compaq, from second; the company's market share fell to 10.7 percent from about 16 percent.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Ban On Some Executions
description: Gov. Michael F. Easley, a Democrat, signed into law a bill making North Carolina the 18th state to ban execution of the mentally retarded. The new law, which will take effect on Oct. 1, lets defendants seek a pretrial hearing on whether they are retarded. Anyone who recorded an I.Q. of 70 or less before age 18 and had ''significant limitations in adaptive functioning'' would be considered retarded. If the judge ruled against the defendant, defense lawyers could raise the issue in the sentencing phase, and a finding of retardation would require a unanimous jury.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLSEN, PAUL T.
description: OLSEN-Paul T. 68, of New York died peacefully at home on August 5, 2001 after a long illness, surrounded by friends and family. He is survived by his life partner of 26 years, Dr. Deborah Rinzler of New York, and his two children, Marissa Olsen of New York and Matthew Olsen of Demarest, New Jersey. Dr. Olsen, a Clinical Psychologist and writer, was in private practice from 1967 until his death. In addition, Dr. Olsen served as Chief Psychologist of the Vanderbilt Clinic at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital (1973), was Director of Psychology Training at Roosevelt Hospital (1973-1977), was Director of Intern Training and Publications at the National Institute for the Psychotherapies (1970-1990), served as the editor of the journal ''Comprehensive Psychotherapy'' and several other professional publications, and was the Supervisor and teacher of hundreds of postgraduate students. Dr. Olsen was the author of three novels: The Virgin of San Gil, Country of Old Men, and Shadow of Me; three non-fiction books: The Future of Being Human, Soul Force, and Sons and Mothers; numerous short stories; many professional papers and essays; and was an editor, with Dr. Rinzler, of the book Heal or Die: Psychotherapists Confront Nuclear Annihilation. Services will be held at 11:45 a.m. on Wednesday, August 8, at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'', 180 West 76th Street.

title: Law Firms Are Slow in Promoting Minority Lawyers to Partnerships

Field punts with one hand. The drill is intended to teach returners the correct body positioning to receive the ball, but in the process -- with footballs bouncing off chests, careering off thighs, landing at players' feet -- it revealed how utterly fickle the nature of punt returning is.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Stimulus Plan
description: The South Korean finance minister, Jin Nyum, has promised a huge government spending program in an effort to increase South Korean economic output, which is slowing this year during a global economic downturn. Mr. Jin said the government would add $7.8 billion to its total expenditures in a pump-priming effort designed to provide industry contracts and create jobs. The pledge came in response to forecasts that the gross domestic product will increase at less than half the rate of 9 percent recorded last year. The government has been concerned by declining exports, primarily responsible for a 2.7 percent drop in industrial output in June from June last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Fire Officials To Reprogram Digital Radios

description: The Supreme Court rejected a request from Argentina to extradite Gen. Augusto Pinochet to answer questions about his possible involvement in the assassination of an exiled Chilean army general in 1974. The extradition was requested by an Argentine judge investigating the assassination of Gen. Carlos Prats and his wife, Sofa, who were killed when a bomb blew up their car in a Buenos Aires suburb in 1974. The killings were suspected of having been carried out under orders by intelligence aides to the former dictator. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

Posada, the Yankees' hitter, screamed at Klemm, trailing him as Klemm moved to exit the Yankee Stadium field, shot-putting his bat and barking a final four-letter gratuity.

The Mitsubishi Corporation, Mitsui & Company and Warburg Pincus plan to help TradeCard manage business development and customer services, the company said. TradeCard provides a patented, secure transaction system intended to reduce some of the inefficiencies and uncertainties of traditional cross-border business deals by preparing purchase orders and trade contracts over the Internet.

title: DUPONT SETTLES ANTITRUST SUITS ABOUT BLOOD THINNER
description: DuPont has agreed to pay $44.5 million to settle consumer lawsuits accusing its drug unit of seeking to monopolize the market for its blood thinner, Coumadin. A federal judge in Delaware gave preliminary approval to the settlement of five antitrust lawsuits over DuPont's campaign to block approval of a generic version of the drug, DuPont officials said yesterday. Plaintiffs in Delaware, New York and Florida contend DuPont artificially inflated the drug's price through anticompetitive behavior. The company did not admit wrongdoing. The settlement comes as DuPont prepares to sell its drug unit to the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company for $7.8 billion.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: New Version Of Rogue Program Strikes
description: Yet another version of the rogue computer program known as Code Red has begun infecting Web servers around the world. This third version of the program, technically known as a ''worm'' because it travels from computer to computer, is far nastier than earlier versions: it installs a ''trojan horse'' program on any infected machine that makes every file on the target computer's ''C'' and ''D'' hard drives easily readable on the Internet. The worm affects only computers that are running the operating systems Windows 2000 or Windows NT along with Microsoft's IIS Web server software. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: After Fatal Drunken-Driving Accident, Anger and a Cry for Justice

title: Article 2001080793562093710 -- No Title
description: The third year of excavations at Bahariya Oasis has produced more remains from the Roman period in Egypt 2,000 years ago, as well as from burials of a governor's family about 500 years earlier.

title: Time of Growing Pains for Information Age
description: These would seem to be heady times to be a computer scientist. This is the information age, in which, we are told, biology is defined by a three-billion-letter instruction manual called the genome and human thoughts are analogous to digital bits flowing through a computer. And, we are warned, human intellect will soon be dwarfed by superintelligent machines.

title: The I.R.A.'s Disarmament Plan
description: The Irish Republican Army has given a powerful lift to peace in Northern Ireland by committing itself to what appears to be a credible disarmament plan. If the I.R.A. moves quickly to begin the destruction of its weapons, there is a good chance that the historic reconciliation of Protestants and Catholics in the troubled territory that began four years ago can gain strength in the weeks ahead.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HEALTH CARE REIT, Toledo, Ohio, which invests in nursing homes and assisted-living facilities, said it plans to sell $150 million of notes to repay bank borrowings and fund future investments.

description: HART-Lawrence. Loving husband of Freda Green Hart. Devoted father of Peter and father-inlaw of Kathy Hart. Stepfather of Meryl and Steven Zalkin. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, August 8 at 4:30PM.

title: The Myth of a Perfect Defense
description: Throughout the long public relations battle over a national missile defense shield, each side has scrambled to cite episodes from military history to back its position.

description: Last October, Robert Stahl had his arthritic hip replaced with an artificial one, a ball-and-socket joint made of titanium.

title: The Downside of Hearing Whoopi at the Mall
description: In the early 1980's, a friend's wife paid a voice impersonator to tape the greeting for her husband's answering machine as a gift. ''Well, John's just not home at the moment,'' the tape began, in a voice eerily like former President Ronald Reagan's. ''But if you'll leave your name and number, Nancy or I will have him get back to you as soon as possible.'' Last week AT&T announced a breakthrough in synthesized speech software that will put many voice impersonators out of business.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Poet Is Released
description: A Chinese poet sentenced to jail for using literature to subvert the state has been released after serving three and a half years in jail in southern Guizhou Province, according to the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy. The poet, Ma Zhe, born Xue Deyun, was previously imprisoned for three years for taking part in student demonstrations in 1986. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FULLER, HENRY M.

It was not a signal of intent to seek the death penalty; rather, they said, they always file the highest possible charge.

Information: www.fairmont.com .

title: MOTION FILED IN SALE OF RAYTHEON CONSTRUCTION UNIT
description: The Washington Group International Inc. asked a federal bankruptcy judge in Nevada yesterday to throw out a $503 million agreement to buy the Raytheon Company's construction unit because of hidden cost overruns. The move comes less than a week after the Washington Group sued in bankruptcy court in Reno, Nev., to recover $822 million and avoid $700 million in indemnity payments to the military contractor in connection with the purchase. Washington Group sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in May and hopes to emerge from its reorganization in October after shedding more than $300 million in debt and the Raytheon unit. Raytheon, which has denied wrongdoing, had expected Washington Group's move, company officials said.

title: Workers' Productivity Made Gains, Report Says
description: The productivity of American workers grew at a strong rate in the second quarter as the effect of job cuts sharply reduced the number of hours worked, the government reported today.

title: For 5,300-Year-Old Iceman, Extra Autopsy Tells the Tale
description: For nearly a decade doctors and archaeologists have puzzled over the death of the Iceman, a 5,300-year-old corpse found melting out of a glacier high in the Italian Alps. Forensic doctors who examined the desiccated corpse found no external injuries, and the first radiologists found nothing in X-rays and CAT scans that could explain why he died.

description: It would be buried at least three feet underground, an invisible, silent artery carrying the lifeblood, natural gas, for an anticipated new crop of power plants to meet New York's growing electricity needs.

description: History ought to be revised in a way that reinstates the contributions of peoples overlooked by victors, and American history is no exception. The irony is that Dutch colonialists find themselves on the list of such aggrieved outcasts clamoring for scholarly affirmative action.

title: ARAB FURY RISING AT ENEMY WITHIN
description: Munzer Hafnawi had the despairing look of a man who sensed that his remaining days on this earth might be few. He blinked hard and often. He muttered to himself. Even when he spoke in a full voice, he could barely be heard yards away. Several times, he asked for a glass of water.

description: The dino saurs are not dead yet at least not in the state of Tabasco, where the old governing party broke a long losing streak and claimed victory today in the gubernatorial election.

title: Breast-Feeding Found to Vary by Race
description: Black women are half as likely as white women to breast-feed their babies, a difference that may contribute to higher infant mortality among blacks, researchers reported yesterday. Writing in the journal Pediatrics, researchers from Brigham Young University said federal health surveys showed that while 65 percent of white women reported having breast-fed, only 30 percent of blacks did.

title: GOVERNMENT INVESTIGATES SEAT BELTS ON FORD S.U.V.'S
description: Ford Motor's Explorer sport utility vehicle, already involved in a tire-safety inquiry, is being investigated to see whether a third rear-seat safety belt is needed following reports of 10 deaths in accidents, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said. The agency is investigating the two-door Explorer Sport and Mercury Mountaineer S.U.V.'s, an agency spokesman, Rae Tyson, said yesterday. Sometimes a third person will sit in the rear seat, which Ford says is designed for two people. The agency has reports of 11 crashes involving the 10 deaths and 20 injuries, he said. ''There's a seat belt for every seating position,'' said Sara Tatchio, a spokeswoman for Ford, adding that Ford provided information sought by the traffic agency in mid-July.

title: A City Struggles to Provide Health Care Pledged by U.S.
description: For the last year, an ambitious campaign by this border city focused on a critical if not particularly glamorous goal: enrolling poor children for federal health benefits. Television and radio advertisements urged parents to apply, while volunteers handed out applications at schools and shopping malls. There was even a telethon.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Bjorn Lomborg; From an Unlikely Quarter, Eco-Optimism
description: The news from environmental organizations is almost always bleak. The climate is out of whack. Insidious chemicals taint food and drink. Tropical forests are disappearing. Species are perishing en masse. Industrial poisons pollute air, earth and water. Ecosystems are being stressed to the breaking point by the greedy, wasteful consumption of the Western lifestyle and its would-be imitators.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Subway Lawsuit
description: London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, and his transport commissioner, Robert R. Kiley, dropped legal action against the government's $18.5 billion partial privatization plan for the city's beleaguered subway because, they said, appeals would be ''unlikely to succeed.'' They said they would continue to oppose the plan to split maintenance and operation of the London Underground between public and private sectors that Mr. Kiley, an American rapid transit expert, has called ''fatally flawed.'' Warren Hoge (NYT)

description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday in connection with the shooting of a livery-cab driver on Thursday afternoon, the police said.

description: For travelers to countries where malaria is a concern, federal health officials warn that antimalarial drugs are not all alike, and it is essential that the right one be prescribed.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Bolivia: President Formally Steps Down
description: President Hugo Banzer, who is stricken with cancer, formally resigned today on a national holiday to prepare a handover of power to Vice President Jorge Quiroga. The 75-year-old former military dictator was a strong ally of the United States and made erradication of coca the cornerstone of his government in the last four years. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Tobacco Smuggling Suit
description: The European Commission filed anew a civil law suit in the United States against Philip Morris and R. J. Reynolds Tobacco, seeking damages for what it calls their involvement with organized crime in smuggling cigarettes into Europe. The original suit, which was filed last November, was dismissed in July by a court in Brooklyn, arguing that the commission, the executive arm of the 15-member European Union, had had no damages. To meet the court's objections, lawyers for the commission resubmitted the suit on behalf of the commission and 10 member states. European governments argue that they lose billions of dollars annually in customs and tax revenues because of illegal sales of American cigarettes that they believe involve American manufacturers. The companies deny the charge. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Ozawa Leads 'Salome' In Tanglewood Farewell
description: Seiji Ozawa has made opera a part of the Tanglewood schedule since the early 1980's, and although there were reservations in the early years about the efficacy of presenting semi-staged opera in the festival's large, open concert shed, Mr. Ozawa's operatic adventures have become highlights. Even so, the level of anticipation attending the Saturday evening performance of Strauss's ''Salome'' was unusually high.

title: 4 FORMER OFFICIALS OF WASTE MANAGEMENT LOSE BENEFITS
description: The nation's leading trash hauler, Waste Management Inc., said yesterday that it would revoke $23.1 million in severance pay and stock options for four former executives to settle shareholder suits contending the company was mismanaged. The settlement, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, also will resolve claims filed in Federal District Court in Texas, company officials said. Shareholders had asserted that the officials, including John E. Drury, a former chief executive, misled investors about the company's financial health after USA Waste Services Inc. bought it in 1998 and kept the company's name. A Delaware court hearing on the settlement is scheduled for Sept. 20.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Gun Safety Lock Measures
description: Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler of Queens said yesterday he would seek an increase in the penalties for failure to use safety locks on their firearms, and to require that law enforcement officials be required to use safety locks in certain circumstances. A trigger-lock law was passed in 1998, but the Giuliani administration opposed applying it to law enforcement officials. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Run-Happy Baseball Is Rewriting Its Unwritten Rules
description: Maybe, in light of the astounding development in Cleveland, Davey Lopes would like to reconsider his old-school (read that old-fashioned) thinking.

title: Holy Bull Is One of Six to Enter the Hall
description: The great Holy Bull, the 3-year-old champion and Horse of the Year in 1994, headed a class of three horses, two trainers and a jockey that was inducted into thoroughbred racing's Hall of Fame here today.

title: Timetable Unclear for Decency Panel's Report
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his Cultural Affairs Advisory Commission, which he appointed last spring to set standards for museums that receive city money, would issue a report of recommendations, although he declined to give an exact timetable. ''We can expect a report still in the process of being developed,'' he said at a news conference devoted to new initiatives on health care.

title: Mr. Bush in Repose
description: Now that George W. Bush has settled in for the month at his Texas ranch, Americans can look forward to the resumption of that vacation tradition in which the president disappears from public view while aides hold briefings on how hard he is working behind the scenes. Gone is the Clinton era of a 24-7 chief executive who sometimes postponed committing to a vacation destination until the last minute.

title: Roy D. Chapin Jr., 85; Ran American Motors
description: Roy D. Chapin Jr., a former chairman and chief executive of the American Motors Corporation who oversaw the company's purchase of the Jeep Corporation in 1970, died on Sunday of heart failure at his summer home in Nantucket, Mass., his son, William R. Chapin, said. He was 85.

title: Pizza Hut Unites Its Media Buying
description: Pizza Hut in Dallas, part of Tricon Global Restaurants, said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with the Media Edge in New York, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, by naming the agency to handle its United States media planning, with spending estimated at $150 million. Media Edge also handles national broadcast buying for Pizza Hut.

title: Splish-Splash, Gorillas Are Taking a Bath and Sending a Message
description: That teenage showoff doing cannonballs off the high dive at the local pool has a counterpart in the wild: male gorillas, who have been seen jumping into and otherwise splashing about a swamp in West Africa.

title: More Vets Eligible For Hall In Baseball
description: In a dramatic departure from past voting practices, the board of directors of baseball's Hall of Fame paved the way yesterday for more players to be elected while saying it acted in the interest of maintaining its high standards for election.

title: Microsoft Appeals Antitrust Verdict to Supreme Court
description: The Microsoft Corporation asked the United States Supreme Court today to hear an argument to throw out all of the findings against the company that were reached by a lower court and left standing by an appeals court.

title: At Stringer's Funeral, Tributes Mingle With Tears and Poetry
description: The funeral service for Korey Stringer was held here today, filled with laughter and song, with tears and tributes, and with recollections of the gentle child who grew to be a gentle giant, of a hometown hero who kept his roots alive.

title: Punk, Served More Often Sweet Than Raw
description: Cruising, that time-honored American pastime, took over the Vans Warped Tour's annual visit to Randalls Island on Saturday, as thousands of young people wandered around looking for the center of a strikingly diffuse day.

description: It is the height of summer, and the mosquito is out and about, determined to spoil everyone's good time.

description: FRIEDMAN-Helen D. Died August 6, 2001 at the age of 95. Predeceased by her beloved husband, Monroe. She is survived by several distant relatives. Interment will be private in accordance with her wishes.

title: Plans to Sell Music on the Internet Raise Antitrust Concerns
description: The efforts of five major record companies to join forces and sell music over the Internet have received increasing attention from regulators and legislators who want to make sure the companies do not engage in anticompetitive behavior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEIN, FLORENCE
description: STEIN-Florence. The Wall Street Synagogue is saddened by the loss of the mother of Ronald J. Stein, its devoted officer and patron, and extends sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Meyer Hager

title: A Once Invincible Jones Gives Up Her Crown
description: After not losing a 100-meter race in nearly four years, Marion Jones lost twice in less than two hours tonight at the world track and field championships.

title: Eliot Feld Sets Sights On Hawaiian Digression
description: Eliot Feld paused for a quick lunch late one recent weekday between rehearsals, a piece of cheese in one hand, a telephone in the other. Mr. Feld was preparing for his Ballet Tech company's two-week season at the Joyce Theater, which opened last night. But he soldiered on about his latest dance, growing increasingly animated as he talked.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Health Booklet
description: The city's Department of Aging has published an 18-page booklet for elderly New Yorkers to record their health information. The booklet, which could help paramedics and others responding to emergencies, would list emergency contacts, medical conditions, allergies and recent vaccinations. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Researchers Debate Human Cloning
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 — A fertility doctor, a chemist and a scientist-entrepreneur vowed today to press ahead with separate efforts to create the first cloned human being, despite warnings from leading experts that the experiments would inevitably lead to babies that are deformed, or die soon after birth.

title: Catholic Church to Support Clergy Reporting Child Sexual Abuse
description: BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 7 — The Catholic church here announced today that it will support a bill in the Massachusetts legislature that would add priests and other clergy to the list of people who must report suspected child sexual abuse to the authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROTTA, MICHELE, M.D.
description: TROTTA-Michele, M.D. Of Juno Beach, FL, formerly of Baldwin, on August 3, 2001. Retired physician and anesthesiologist. Beloved husband of Theresa A. (nee Findley). Loving father of Anna Trotta Githens (John) of Westfield, NJ, and Joseph Trotta of Lynbrook. Dear brother of Bartholomeo Trotta. Cherished grandfather of John (J.P.), Brian and Andrew. Reposing at Fullerton Funeral Home, 769 Merrick Rd., Baldwin. Mass of Christian Burial at Church of St. Christopher, Thursday, 9:45 AM. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday, 7-9 PM, and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations in his name to the American Cancer Society or the Maurawood Residence, PO Box 8246, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, would be appreciated.

title: Rahman Signs for a Championship Rematch With Lewis
description: Hasim Rahman has signed an agreement to fight a heavyweight rematch with Lennox Lewis, most likely in November, a businessman familiar with the negotiations said yesterday.

title: What New Urban Wear Trend Will Step Off the G Train?
description: A trend that is hatched in the world of Bjorks and Anna Wintours has exhausted itself, we assume, once it finds life among those who usually shop at Ann Taylor. Inversely, one could argue that a trend that is incubated on the G train is played out when it is embraced, say, on the ferry to Fishers Island, a summer community in Long Island Sound where the ratio of Groton alumni to indigenous oysters is probably somewhere around five to one.

title: Foreign Affairs; Civil Peace Requires Civil War
description: Why did the peace processes in Northern Ireland and the Middle East grind to a halt at the same time? The short answer is that both negotiations had reached the moment of truth -- the moment where you could not solve the civil war between the parties without a civil war within the parties.

title: South Koreans Challenge Northerner on U.S. Troops
description: South Korea today rebuffed a statement by the North Korean leader during his weekend visit to Moscow that seemed to alter his stance toward the presence of American troops in the Korean Peninsula.

title: DUTCH PUBLISHER VNU IS SELLING EDUCATIONAL UNIT
description: The Dutch publisher VNU said yesterday that it has agreed to sell its educational publishing unit to the 3i Group of Britain and the unit's management for about 195 million euros ($172 million). The sale includes the two operating units of the publishing unit -- L.C.G. Malmberg in the Netherlands and Uitgeverij Van In in Belgium, which had combined revenue of 76 million euros last year. VNU has been selling units to pay for its $2.3 billion purchase of the ACNielsen Corporation, which would make it a leading provider of market research to advertisers and retailers.

description: LISKIN-Elliot. August 7th Always loved and remembered. Children, Grandchildren & Joyce

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSTEIN, HERMAN
description: EDELSTEIN-Herman. In Montreal, on Wednesday, August 1, 2001 after a prolonged illness. Beloved husband of the late Esther, cherished father of Dr. Martin of Great Neck and Leonard of Montreal. Devoted father-in-law of Judy and Debbie and grandfather to Jeremy, Joshua, Justin, Jonathan and Andrea. His warmth, charm and love of life will be missed by all who knew him.

title: That Heavenly Match Made on 'The Merv Griffin Show'
description: Do you by any chance make a habit of crashing wedding receptions, anniversary banquets and family reunions? Do you get your kicks from watching strangers in festive formal wear as they show home movies, make toasts of mutual admiration and swap anecdotes about quirky relatives that somehow all sound the same?

title: F.C.C. to Take Wireless Licensing Case to Supreme Court
description: The Bush administration said today that it would appeal to the Supreme Court to try to overturn the recent ruling that the government had illegally confiscated wireless spectrum licenses from NextWave Telecom while the company was under bankruptcy court protection.

title: Chinese B Shares Plunge As Quickly as They Soared
description: Chinese B shares, stocks denominated in foreign currency whose world-beating rally briefly captured headlines earlier this year, are in the midst of a retreat nearly as swift as their celebrated ascent. As with the rise, actions by the government are behind the fall.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Human Cloning
description: The Order of Italian Doctors said that it had started disciplinary procedures against Dr. Severino Antinori, who is expected to announce during a meeting today at the National Academy of Sciences in Washington that he intends to produce cloned humans for infertile couples later this year. He will use a method similar to the one that produced the cloned sheep Dolly. Italy has not banned cloning, but the doctors' group says that such experiments would violate its code of ethics. Marina Harss (NYT)

title: When Implants Fail, Patients Suffer Twice
description: Up to 10 percent of Americans are walking around with some sort of medical implant: artificial knees and hips, replacement lenses in the eyes, pacemakers to regulate heartbeat. But implants fail and are recalled, with serious effects on thousands of patients, and no one keeps complete track of who has what.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Karen Barnett was named senior vice president and group director at Ogilvy Public Relations Worldwide, New York, part of the WPP Group, responsible for leading the marketing practice. She succeeds John Quick, who left. Ms. Barnett had been senior vice president and consumer group director at the New York office of the MWW Group, part of the Golin/Harris International unit of the Partnership, a division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Dabhol Ruling
description: The Supreme Court of India ruled in favor of Dabhol Power, the Indian unit of the Enron Corporation, in a dispute with a western Indian state utility over $64 million in overdue utility bills. The high court ordered a lower court, the Mumbai High Court, to rule on whether a regional energy regulator in the western state of Maharashtra or an international court in London should have jurisdiction. The state utility of Maharashtra, the sole customer of Dabhol's power plant, wants the case heard by the Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission, while Dabhol wants the case heard by the international court in London, as called for in its original power agreement with Maharashtra. The lower court had earlier refused to accept jurisdiction in the dispute. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Google Names New Chief
description: The privately held Internet search engine company Google Inc. announced yesterday that Eric E. Schmidt, its chairman, had been named chief executive, succeeding Larry Page, the company co-founder. Mr. Schmidt, who was appointed chairman of Google's board in March, was previously chairman and chief executive officer of Novell Inc. He will remain chairman of the board of Novell. Mr. Page was named president for products at Google.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY UNIT IN BRITISH ENERGY DEAL
description: The MidAmerican Energy Holdings Company, which is owned by Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc., announced yesterday that a subsidiary has agreed to buy the northern England power-distribution network of Innogy Holdings P.L.C. in an asset swap valued at 1 billion ($1.4 billion). MidAmerican will acquire Innogy's distribution in Yorkshire. In exchange, MidAmerican will sell a supply unit of its British subsidiary, Northern Electric, to Innogy. The agreement is aimed at enabling MidAmerican to improve profitability by combining the networks and creating a distribution company serving more than 3.6 million customers, MidAmerican's president, Gregory E. Abel, said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURPHY, NANCY (PEARSALL)
description: MURPHY-Nancy (Pearsall), 53, died August 4, 2001, peacefully at her home in Croton-on-Hudson after a courageous battle with inflammatory breast cancer. She was born December 21, 1947 in Portland, Oregon to Douglas (deceased) and Inga Pearsall. Besides her mother, she is survived by her husband Michael, her sons Jonathan and Phillip, and brothers Michael and Charles Pearsall. Nancy was an inspiration to all who knew her as wife, mother, friend, quilter, and cancer survivor. She loved and was a highly talented quilter and a member of the Croton Pointers and the Northern Star Quilters Guild. After being diagnosed with breast cancer, Nancy joined and became a valued member of the Support Connection of Yorktown Heights, New York, where she shared her counsel and love of quilting with other breast cancer survivors. With the assistance of some close friends, she created ''Nancy's Quilt'', a fund-raising project to raise awareness of the disease and financial support for cancer research. At the time of her death, plans for a second quilt in this series were underway and are proceeding. The deep grief shared by her family and friends on her untimely death is tempered by their unforgettable memories of her courage, compassion, and humor in the face of great adversity. Friends may visit Tuesday (August 7) 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Edward F. Carter Funeral Home, 41 Grand Street, Croton-on-Hudson, New York. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at 10:00 on Wednesday morning (August 8) at St. Augustine's Church, Eagle Park, Ossining, New York. Donations in Nancy's memory may be made to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY, or the Support Connection, 360 Underhill Ave., Yorktown Heights.

title: Russian in Digital Copyright Case Is Released on Bail
description: Dmitri Sklyarov, a Russian programmer whose arrest in Las Vegas has incited international protests against an American digital copyright law, was released on $50,000 bail yesterday, after three weeks in custody.

title: A Spinoff at Bristol-Myers
description: Zimmer Holdings Inc., a maker of knee and hip implants, will start trading on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday after being spun off by the drug maker Bristol-Myers Squibb. Bristol-Myers plans to focus on its pharmaceuticals business. Shareholders will receive one Zimmer share for each 10 Bristol-Myers shares they own. Zimmer, which had $1.04 billion in 2000 sales, makes joint replacements and devices used to stabilize bones. It forecasts sales growth of 8 percent to 11 percent this year and in 2002.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Warning On Painkiller
description: State Attorney General Richard Blumenthal recently sent a letter to executives of a pharmaceutical company, Purdue Pharma, urging it to restrict the marketing and distribution of OxyContin, a powerful prescription painkiller that officials say is being widely misused by teenagers, officials said yesterday. Mr. Blumenthal called the abuse ''serious, almost epidemic'' in Connecticut, where 26 residents died in 2000 after taking the drug's active ingredient, oxycodone. Purdue officials objected to the ''harsh tone of his letter,'' but said they planned to speak to Mr. Blumenthal next week. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

Mr. Mytil, who is in custody after being accused of shooting four people on a Greyhound bus from Boston, was held without bail. None of the victims had life-threatening wounds. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLAUSS, PAMELA HEAVEY
description: CLAUSS-Pamela Heavey died peacefully at home on August 5, 2001 after a courageous battle with cancer. Mrs. Clauss, who lived in Manhattan, was the loving and devoted wife of Dr. Roy H. Clauss and the beloved and devoted stepmother of his three children Roy Stuart and his wife Kathryn, Eliot Reid and his companion Jamie Szoke, Jane B. Jackson and her husband David. She was a loving and devoted grandmother to Bryan North-Clauss, Melissa Malone, Lindsay, Ashley and Duncan Clauss, Floyd Jones, Pamela Jackson and Nathaniel Jackson, and sister of Jill Evans and her husband Alan Evans, and Philippa Lazarus and her husband Leslie Lazarus, A.O., of Sydney, Australia. Mrs. Clauss was born in Longueville, Sydney, Australia, to Alison Maud Bennett and John Aloysius Heavey, a New Zealand Navy veteran decorated for bravery in the ANZAC landing at Gallipoli in 1915. She was educated at St. Aidans and graduated from Sacred Heart College in Kensington, Sydney. Mrs. Clauss entered nursing training at St. Vincent's Hospital, Sydney in 1942. Following a grand tour of Europe and nursing in England in 1956, she returned to Australia and was appointed nursing sister in charge of St. Vincent's newly established cardio-thoracic surgical unit under the direction of Dr. Harry Windsor. In 1959 Mrs. Clauss went to the Mayo Clinic as part of an exchange-training program, and in 1965 she joined the openheart surgery team of Dr. Roy Clauss and Dr. George Reed in New York City. Her pioneering of cardio-surgical by-pass techniques at the Mayo Clinic, New York University Medical Center and the New York Medical College educated a host of nurse perfusionists. Mrs. Clauss was a remarkable woman who devoted her life to helping others through her dedication to the Inner City Scholarship Fund and work at the Yorkville Comman Pantry. She pursued her interests in historic preservation through her work at Community Board Eight and the Seventy Fourth Street Association, and had a tremendous love of the arts and music, frequenting the Metropolitan Opera and the Philharmonic as a patron. Mrs. Clauss was a devout Catholic who gave to the Church and who received great strength from her faith. She will be remembered by her family and friends for her warmth, enthusiasm and kindness. Services will be held on Tuesday, August 7th at 10am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street in Manhattan. Burial will be at the Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, New York. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Inner City Scholarship Fund, 1011 First Avenue, New York, NY 10022-4134.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Profit
description: After a $20 billion acquisition spree the last two years to move away from dependence on emerging markets, HSBC, the biggest British bank, beat some analysts' forecasts with a 4 percent rise in first-half net profit to $3.67 billion. The figure included a one-time gain of $667 million from disposals. Analysts said profits rose because of growing European business, particularly from the acquisition of Crdit de Commercial de France, and lower-than-expected provisions against bad debts. title: US AIRWAYS REJECTS UNSOLICITED TAKEOVER OFFER
description: The US Airways Group, whose plan to combine with the UAL Corporation was quashed by regulators last month, said yesterday that a $1.8 billion takeover bid from the Global Airlines Corporation is not worth considering. US Airways said that neither Global nor Emil Bernard, who leads it, had established credentials to support the bid or had met with US Airways executives. Global Airlines, which is closely held and is based in New York, has made other failed bids for airlines and does not operate any aircraft. Under the offer, which was made this weekend, Global would pay $10 a share, or as much as $750 million, in cash and $17 a share in nonvoting Global stock. Global would also assume $8 billion in debt.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Industrial Slowdown
description: Reflecting an acute energy crisis that has forced businesses to scale back on power consumption, Brazil's industrial production fell 1.4 percent in June from June a year earlier and 1.1 percent from the previous month. Production in the metals sector was hardest hit, falling 7 percent in June, the first month of a rationing program that forced a 20 percent reduction in power use. Even with industrial growth slowing, production for the first six months grew 4.9 percent, compared with the first six months of 2000. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Truckers Get Cool Air Without Fouling the Air Around Them

With 90-degree heat outside, the trucks' drivers were coolly air-conditioned in their cabins. Yet none of their engines were running. Not an ounce of diesel fuel was being expended, not a single noxious fume emitted. Instead, the air was being funneled into the trucks through bright yellow tubing.

description: Tropicana Field is supposed to be the place where ailing teams get healthy again, where strong teams look stronger and where even mediocre teams prevail most of the time. The formula is simple: teams pound the young and bumbling Tampa Day Devil Rays, feeling like someone suddenly gave them shots of B-12, and return to the hotel smiling.

title: Italy Holding a New Jersey Woman, 21, Snared in the Genoa Fracas
description: Susanna Thomas called home this morning from the Italian jail where she has been held since her arrest outside Genoa on July 22, hours after the end of the summit meeting of the major industrialized nations and the street disorder that swirled around it.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Subway Announcements
description: Subway conductors' announcements of transfer points and coming stations (''the next stop is 34th Street'') improved in clarity and audibility to 69 percent this year from 47 percent in 1999, according to a new survey by the Straphangers Campaign, a rider advocacy group. The No. 3 line did best, with basic announcements audible 81 percent of the time; the No. 2 line did worst, with 54 percent. But surveyors found that 80 percent of announcements for train delays and reroutings were useless: of those, 16 percent were inaudible, 27 percent not made at all and 57 percent incomprehensible (''the train is being held by supervision''). The survey was done between February and June by 51 volunteers on 20 subway lines.

title: Bush's Loss on Links Can't Dampen His Day
description: President Bush's 18-car motorcade snaked silently into town at dawn today, passing cows, goats and rolled golden hay to reach a country club fairway where his team came in second in a two-team round. But he was bubbling over nonetheless with joie de vivre, mainly because he liked being outside.

title: A More Assertive Khatami Is Sworn In as President of Iran
description: TEHRAN, Aug. 8 - A more assertive President Mohammad Khatami, delivering his inaugural address for his second term today, vowed to enact reforms clearly demanded by Iranian voters and warned his formidable opponents that failure would reflect badly on the very idea of Islamic government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAPLE, JOHN EDWARD (JACK)
