title: Cooper Union Architecture Has Dean
description: The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art has selected an architectural historian and theorist rather than a practitioner as dean of its Irwin S. Chanin School of Architecture. ANTHONY VIDLER, a professor of art history and architecture at the University of California, Los Angeles, and chairman of the art history department, replaces John Q. Hejduk, an architect known for his designs, who led the school from 1975 until his death last year. Before moving to U.C.L.A. in 1993, Professor Vidler taught at Princeton University for more than 25 years. He was also dean of the College of Art, Architecture and Planning at Cornell University in 1997 and 1998. Educated at Cambridge University in England, Professor Vidler earned a Bachelor of Arts degree, with honors, in architecture and fine arts and a diploma in architecture. In 1995 he was elected a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANNER, WINIFRED MCGRATH
description: ANNER-Winifred McGrath, 90 years old, died peacefully at home on August 7, 2001. Mrs. Anner was born in the Bronx to William and Catherine McGrath. She married John L. Anner, Jr. in October 1932, and he died December 26, 1937. She is survived by her daughters Kathryn and husband Marvin Goldsmith, Mary Alice and her husband John Heaney, her son John L. Anner III and his wife Rosemarie, and her daughter Winifred and her husband William Gunsalus. She is the much beloved grandmother and inspiration to her fifteen grandchildren and their husbands and wives. Her grandson Peter Heaney died in 1985. She is also survived by twenty-three great-grandchildren. She was a school secretary with the NYC Board of Education for over thirty years. Winifred was a good sport; an avid NY Knicks fan; and loved reading the NY Times, clipping articles of interest for her large family. John Anner, her very beloved husband quoted the following when he asked her hand in marriage: ''A perfect woman, nobly planned, to warn, to comfort and command, and yet a spirit still and bright, With something of an angel light.'' Winifred embodied all these qualities as she raised her children, and had a warm, wonderful relationship with her grandchildren and great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends and family at Farenga Bros Inc. 920 Allerton Ave, Bronx, NY Wednesday and Thursday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Rosary Church.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Extradited Man Is Jailed
description: A federal judge in Manhattan ordered a New Square, N.Y., man held yesterday after he was extradited from Israel on charges that he participated in a scheme that defrauded the government of millions of dollars. The suspect, Chaim Berger, 75, pleaded not guilty. He had been sought by the authorities since his 1997 indictment in the case, in which four other men were convicted. Earlier this year, President Bill Clinton reduced the sentences of the men. Benjamin Weiser (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NENNO, STEPHEN K.
description: NENNO-Stephen K. ABC Television Network Vice President of Program Operations, died Monday, July 30, at New York Presbyterian Hospital after a battle with cancer. Mr. Nenno, 59, had been with ABC since 1968 and was initially responsible for such programs as General Hospital and This Is Tom Jones. He began his broadcasting career in 1963 at KNX Radio, the CBS-owned radio station in Los Angeles, then moved to KNXT (now KCBS-TV), the CBS television station. In 1965 he became Operations Manager of KHJ-TV (now KCAL-TV) the RKO General station in Los Angeles. Among his responsibilities there were program formatting, FCC license renewal and on-air operations. Mr. Nenno served on the Board of Governors of both the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, New York Chapter, and the International Radio and Television Society, where he created a summer fellowship program. He was also a member of the Broadcast Pioneers; a lifetime member of Alpha Epsilon Rho, the National Broadcasting Society; and was a professional representative on the governing council of Seton Hall University's Campus Radio Station, WSOU. Mr. Nenno was a graduate of the University of Southern California with a BA degree in Telecommunications. In lieu of flowers, please direct donations to the Stephen K. Nenno Fund at the University of Southern California, School of Cinema-Television, Lucas Building, Room 209, Los Angeles, California 90089-2211.

title: Where Soccer Fans Leap and Grilled Sirloin Sizzles
description: I know a lot of cautious eaters. They try to go easy on the meat, they look dimly on fat, they stay away from salt. If, by inclination or necessity, you strive to avoid such indulgences, by all means do not visit Churrascaria Girassol, a tiny Brazilian restaurant hidden away in a storefront in Astoria, Queens. But if you are excited by the idea of juicy, salt-edged steaks, rich sauces mellowed with palm oil and the prospect of unlimited meat courses, then Girassol can be a little bit of paradise.

title: After Protest, British Halt Screening of Travelers in Prague
description: British immigration officers screening travelers at Prague's international airport will be withdrawn on Thursday, Czech and British officials said today, after politicians and human rights groups accused them of racial bias by deliberately preventing Czech Gypsies from traveling to Britain.

description: The question of whether the MetroStars would be serious about their first appearance in an international club tournament, even though it will come in the middle of the Major League Soccer season, was answered today with a 60-minute practice in oppressive heat at their training facility at Kean University.

description: NEWARK, Aug. 7  A two-alarm fire on a day of record- breaking heat sent 17 people, including six firefighters, to the hospital today, and caused many more firefighters to seek treatment at the scene.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARETZKY, HARRY
description: KARETZKY-Harry. Former First Deputy Director of the Office of Municipal Labor Relations of New York City, passed away August 5, 2001. Predeceased by his wife Lillian. He is survived by his children Elisabeth Karetzky and Stephen Karetzky and his grandchildren Benjamin F. Klein and Nikolai A. Klein. Devoted public servant, good husband, excellent father, loving grandfather, he will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Services were held at Sinai Chapels.

title: THOMSON TO BUY NEWSEDGE TO IMPROVE ONLINE SERVICES
description: The Thomson Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the NewsEdge Corporation for about $43 million to bolster its online news and information services. Thomson will pay $2.30 a share for NewsEdge, a 92 percent premium to NewsEdge's closing share price of $1.20 on Monday, a Thomson spokesman, Jason Stewart, said. Thomson, which has been mainly a publisher of magazines and newspapers, is focusing on selling research and information on the Internet. NewsEdge, based in Burlington, Mass., provides editorial content and other services to about 1,500 companies. Thomson is based in Toronto. The transaction is expected to close this year.

title: Szabo Wins the 1,500, and the 5,000 Awaits (Maybe)
description: The questions posed to Gabriela Szabo were all about whether she would run on Thursday in the first round of the women's 5,000, but there was no question that she ran and ran beautifully tonight.

title: Finicky Feasters
description: Given a choice, the female mosquitoes of almost every species prefer the blood of cows and pigs to humans. When it comes to humans, mosquitoes prefer adults to children, women to men and pregnant women most. They find ovulating women more attractive than those menstruating.

description: ''How do you defend yourself against a well-armed, well-trained and numerous guerrilla force? With an equally well-armed, well-trained and numerous organization.''

description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil gained on expectations that demand for gasoline will keep refineries busy processing oil. In New York, crude oil for September delivery rose 20 cents, or 0.7 percent, to $27.94 a barrel.

title: Reckonings; Nothing For Something
description: Recently I gave the ''bipartisan'' commission on Social Security reform -- many of its members and staff are actually associated with the ultra-conservative Cato Institute -- a very hard time over its interim report. Was I unfair? No. It's even worse than I thought.

description: The action in the 500-mile Leg 4 of the EDS Atlantic Challenge from Norfolk, Va., to Boston was described as brisk but uneventful by race headquarters yesterday, with the Open 60's Ecover and Kingfisher jockeying for the lead some 300 miles from the finish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALPERT, RUTH
description: HALPERT-Ruth. Of Glen Oaks, NY at age 73, suddenly on August 6, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Bernard Halpert; devoted mother of Richard Halpert of Stonybrook, NY and Julie Lewis of Chicago, IL; cherished grandmother of Lucas and Jessie Halpert and Inga Lewis; loving sister of Jules and Fred Frohmann. Ruth was currently working for Good Housekeeping Magazine and known to all as ''Mother to the World.'' Family will be receiving friends Thursday from 12-1 PM at Hughes Funeral Home of Kings Park, 69 Indian Head Road with a service to follow visitation at 1 PM by Rabbi Sternstein. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to the Pediatric Aids Foundation would be appreciated.

description: WEISSBERG-Josef H., M.D. On August 6, 2001. The American Academy of Psychoanalysis mourns the loss of a Past-President and recipient of our Presidential Award. He was a dedicated professional who served the Academy, the Consortium of Psychoanalysis, and the larger community in uncountable ways. At the same time profoundly pragmatic and a visionary, a scholar, a therapeutic innovator, a steadfast leader, and above all a wise counselor, he will be greatly missed. To his wife Carol Wheeler, his three children and his grandchildren, our deepest sympathies. Matthew A. Tolchin, M.D. President Cesar A. Alfonso, M.D. Secretary

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Pakistani Criticized
description: In a speech before Parliament, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee blamed Pakistan's military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, for the disappointing outcome of the Agra summit meeting last month, saying the general had a poor grasp of history and little understanding of diplomatic protocol. He said that to Pakistanis the disputed Himalayan territory may ''just be a piece of land,'' but to Indians ''it is a part of our hearts.'' Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Giants and Patriots Share Quality Time
description: The Giants and the New England Patriots practiced jointly today, but not in full pads as planned, a welcome concession for players working beneath a cloudless sky as temperatures reached the mid-90's. The teams even paused for a five-minute break at the midpoint of practice, an uncustomary respite that had players restlessly lingering at midfield, waiting for a whistle to resume their workout. Today's combined practice even ended a few minutes earlier than scheduled, though the Giants filled that time by doing 100 push-ups in the sun as the Patriots, on an adjacent field, watched.

title: Power-Sharing Plans in Doubt as Ulster Peace Talks Falter
description: LONDON, Aug. 8 — With hope of a breakthrough in stalemated peace negotiations fading, Britain faced the growing likelihood tonight of having to put the power-sharing Northern Ireland government on hold by this weekend in order to preserve its future existence beyond then.

title: Volunteers Wanted for Serve-a-Thon
description: Their challenge is to recruit 10,000 volunteers, enough to spread 3,300 gallons of paint on the walls of more than 100 New York City schools, plant 20,000 flowers and bulbs in schoolyards, create hundreds of murals and hopscotch boards and repair several dozen wrought iron fences and gates. To prepare for its 10th annual serve-a-thon, the volunteer organization New York Cares is looking for people eager to spend their Saturday on Oct. 13 helping to spruce up some of the most neglected public schools across the five boroughs.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Greetings For Norton
description: As the first interior secretary to give a keynote speech to the Colorado Oil and Gas Association, Gale A. Norton received a rousing welcome in Denver. Ms. Norton's remarks were devoted to building support for President Bush's energy plan. She said ''safeguards for the land and developing energy resources for the future'' were no longer mutually exclusive. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

description: He may have written as long and as famously on Japan as any other living writer, but Donald Richie returns over and over again to a few favorite stories whenever he meets someone curious about his life in this country.

title: Audrey Cohen Elects Chairman
description: JOHN S. RODGERS, the former chairman of Salant Corporation, a men's wear company, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Audrey Cohen College, succeeding BERNADETTE SMITH. Mr. Salant, who graduated from Harvard College and Harvard Law School, has been a member of the college's board since 1984; he was also its vice chairman. The college offers classes in Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island, Queens and New Rochelle. Karen W. Arenson

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Guilty Plea In Miami
description: A former Miami finance director pleaded guilty in a bribery scheme that also led to the downfall of a city commissioner, county commissioner and city manager. The director, Manohar Surana, pleaded guilty on Monday to one count of conspiracy in exchange for a one-year prison sentence and dismissal of related charges against his son, Pamit Surana. Mr. Surana became an informer in the wide-ranging corruption cases after he was caught on tape in the mid-1990's soliciting millions of dollars in bribes from the Unisys Corporation, a city vendor.

Barsky, has told the city's agency leaders that they may not commit to any new spending or contracts that would rely on any state money without the direct approval of the Office of Management and Budget, citing the austerity budget passed last week by the State Legislature.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Ranks Of DoubleClick To Shift
description: DoubleClick, one of the largest online advertising companies and the most prominent Internet companies in Silicon Alley in Manhattan, announced yesterday that its chief financial officer, Stephen Collins, will step down on Friday. Mr. Collins, 35, will be succeeded by Bruce Dalziel, who had been serving as the vice president for finance and operations for Doubleclick. Mr. Dalziel will become the acting chief financial officer. The company said Mr. Collins would stay at DoubleClick through the beginning of 2002 to work on strategic initiatives like acquisitions. The company said last month that it anticipates reporting losses each quarter for the rest of the year. Company officials said that Mr. Collins requested the new role and that his stepping down had nothing to do with recent financial difficulties. DoubleClick's losses widened in the second-quarter as revenue fell 20 percent because of a decline in spending on Internet advertising.

title: Mortgage Prepayments Off
description: Prepayments on Fannie Mae mortgage bonds fell for a second month in July as mortgage rates stayed above lows set earlier this year and fewer homeowners refinanced. The prepayment rates on loans backing the largest outstanding issues fell as much as 6 percent following 14 percent declines the previous month, Fannie Mae said yesterday. The 30-year mortgage rate averaged 7.12 percent in July, more than 20 basis points above the low set in March. A basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent. The pace of prepayments is still about four times as fast as last year, when mortgage rates rose to above 8.5 percent.

title: Chickpeas, Dressed Up To Show Off
description: CHICKPEAS have characteristics other legumes don't share. When cooked until tender, they don't turn to mush, and their cooking broth is delicious. The cooked chickpeas are sauted over high heat until browned and slightly crisp, and the pan is deglazed with chickpea cooking liquid.

description: Less than a week after a plea agreement in the Gold Club trial in Atlanta, the City Council voted to try to acquire the property for a park. As part of the agreement, which concerned charges of prostitution and mob connections, Steven E. Kaplan, the club's owner, pleaded guilty to racketeering, agreed to a prison term of three to five years, and turned over the club to the federal government, which will auction it. Atlanta's mass transit agency has also expressed interest in the land. Lino R. Rodriguez JR. (NYT)

title: Baubles of Pita, Pastries and Flatbreads
description: At lunchtime in Midtown, fans of Middle Eastern food are lining up at Bread From Beirut, a new cafeteria-style spot at 24 West 45th Street. Crunchy falafel ($6.50 as a platter, $4.50 in a sandwich) is made with ground fava beans and chickpeas. Kebabs are rolled in pita and toasted on the grill ($6.50), and potato salad is showered with fresh cilantro ($4). But the real draw is what comes from the whimsically decorated wood- and gas-fired oven: more than a dozen kinds of flatbreads and pastries. They come with cheeses, topped with crushed wheat, dried goat cheese and sesame seeds ($5.50), or seasoned with za'atar, the Middle Eastern spice combination. Some are hearty enough to make a meal. Others are irresistible snacks. The owner, Samer Halimeh, a diamond dealer who grew up in Beirut, said he was not happy with the Middle Eastern fare sold in the area. So he opened his own place, with cooks trained in Lebanon turning out breads, salads, grilled meats and other specialties. Delivery in the neighborhood is available from (212) 764-1588.
