Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: BP Predicts It Will Meet Output Target For the Year
description: Easing concerns that a global economic slump would crimp demand for its oil and gas, BP said today that it planned to meet production targets set earlier this year.

title: Billboard Quarterback
description: Considering that only a small fraction of the sportswriters and other voters who select the winner of the Heisman Trophy live or work in Manhattan, it seems odd that the University of Oregon is spending $250,000 this summer to promote its quarterback on a large billboard outside Madison Square Garden. Perhaps the school is hoping that riders of the Long Island Rail Road and New Jersey Transit who stream out of Penn Station every workday will be so impressed they will petition their hometown newspapers to vote for Joey Harrington, the Oregon star.

title: Slaw Without Cabbage: Is Nothing Sacred?
description: WHEN you talk about cole slaw, it's a good idea to drop the cole part and just call it slaw, because so many ingredients have become players in the bowl.

title: National Briefing | West: Alaska: Diesel Fuel Leaks
description: A fishing vessel that sank in Prince William Sound on Saturday is leaking 35,000 gallons of diesel fuel. Cleanup crews reached the scene the same day, but the effort was tapering off after about 11,000 gallons were collected. A 10-square-mile sheen remained but was expected to evaporate. The fuel reached land in at least three places. One oiled bird was captured for treatment. The spill was the largest in the sound since the Exxon Valdez leaked 11 million gallons of crude oil in 1989. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Larry Adler, Political Exile Who Brought the Harmonica to Concert Stage, Dies at 87
description: Larry Adler, a harmonica player of enormous sensitivity whose advocacy and artistry helped elevate the instrument to concert status, died yesterday at a London hospital. He was 87 and had lived in Britain since the early 1950's, when he was blacklisted for his political views and his career in America effectively ended.

title: Bcom3 Agencies Merge and Plan Layoffs
description: The Bcom3 Group in Chicago said yesterday that it is merging two agencies that specialize in digital communications and advertising, Giant Step in Chicago and Novo in San Francisco.

title: Russia Enacts Legislation To Thwart Money Laundering
description: Russia, under pressure from Western industrial democracies, adopted a new law today meant to combat money laundering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WERMUTH, RABBI JOSEPH
description: WERMUTH-Rabbi Joseph. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of its distinguished and much respected former Ritual Director for more than 25 years. We will fondly remember his wisdom, wit, gentle personality and total dedication to his synagogue, family and community. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Andrew Mendes, President Elza Weinman, Sisterhood

title: Metro Business Briefing | Manhattan Media Buys 4 Papers
description: Manhattan Media, a publisher of weekly newspapers in New York City, announced on Monday that it was acquiring four weekly newspapers -- Our Town, The West Side Spirit, The Westsider and The Chelsea Clinton News -- from News Communications Inc. Tom Allon, the publisher and editor in chief of Manhattan Media, said that the company planned to announce initiatives to broaden the appeal of the publications. The purchase of the four weekly newspapers was a leveraged buyout, using money borrowed from ISIS Venture Partners, a private equity firm that was organized earlier this year. Our Town is the largest community weekly newspaper on Manhattan's East Side; The West Side Spirit covers the Upper West Side; The Westsider is a paid community newspaper that covers the area between 59th and 125th Streets on the West Side; The Chelsea Clinton News, whose publication predates the former first daughter's birth by more than three decades, is the oldest community weekly newspaper in Manhattan and has served readers in Chelsea and Clinton for 62 years. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EINZIGER, ERNA
description: EINZIGER-Erna. On August 7, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Hans. Loving mother of Ronald and mother-in-law of Roberta. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer & Hillary. Dear aunt of Sylvia Netzer. Services Wednesday 1PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Medical Center, 1st Avenue at 16th Street, New York, New York 10003.

title: G.M. Announces Plans for Fuel Cells
description: General Motors said today that it planned to develop and market fuel cells to heat and power homes and businesses by the middle of the decade to further a technology it expects to supplant the internal combustion engine. But G.M., like other automakers, does not plan to introduce fuel cell vehicles to the public until at least the end of the decade.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Archbishop Has Knee Surgery
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop Daniel A. Cronin had double knee-replacement surgery on Monday, but will continue to oversee the Hartford diocese during his recovery at St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center, church officials said. The archbishop, 73, is expected to be hospitalized for several days, then enter a rehabilitation center for a week, said Msgr. Thomas Ginty, his secretary. Mr. Cronin is expected to return to ceremonial duties October 1.

title: Gazing at the Cosmos: Are We Alone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ranchers in Colombia Bankroll Own Militia
description: A few years ago, Sergio Ochoa all but abandoned his ranch. Leftist guerrillas were extorting money from landowners and torching the homes of those who did not pay. Some cattlemen, including Mr. Ochoa's brother, were kidnapped. Others were killed.

title: Penn Has Talent, But Keep It Quiet
description: Al Bagnoli, the University of Pennsylvania football coach, knows his Quakers will be tough to beat in the Ivy League this season. He just hopes his team does not.

title: Council Candidates Rebuffed on Public Funds
description: Nearly three-quarters of the City Council candidates who registered to participate in the campaign finance program did not receive any public matching funds this week.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Clash Over Holocaust Study
description: The Vatican issued a statement faulting Jewish scholars for the disbanding of a Jewish-Christian group that had been investigating Vatican actions in the Holocaust. Members of the panel have said they could not proceed because the Vatican had refused to release all the necessary documents, a contention that the Vatican denied. The historians had been appointed to sort out conflicting accounts of whether Pope Pius XII did everything he could -- or next to nothing -- to help save the lives of Jews. The statement today was written by the Rev. Peter Gumpel, a German Jesuit who is working to support the beatification of Pope Pius XII. Melinda Henneberger (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Profit Rises
description: First-half profit at the Royal Bank of Scotland rose 42 percent after last year's takeover of NatWest, which reduced costs and increased revenue. The increase fell short of analysts' expectations, but the bank's shares gained as much as 1.7 percent. The bank said earnings rose to 1.1 billion ($1.6 billion) in the first half compared with 779 million in the first half of 2000. Fred Goodwin, the chief executive, said the bank, based in Edinburgh, planned to acquire a small European bank. Last month, it agreed to buy the retail business of Mellon Financial in the United States. It also owns the Citizens Financial Group, the No. 2 New England banking company. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HART, LAWRENCE
description: HART-Lawrence. Loving husband of Freda Green Hart. Devoted father of Peter and father-inlaw of Kathy Hart. Stepfather of Meryl and Steven Zalkin. Adoring grandfather of Chelsea, Daniel, Ian, Mallory and Dana. We mourn our loss and celebrate his life. Interment private. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, Wednesday, August 8 at 4:30PM.

title: New Guards to Lessen Liability
description: Jessica Hartman is a silent victim of sexual harassment in the workplace.

title: 'Seagull's' Wings Help Span a 30-Year Career
description: A LITTLE less than dapper and dashing after three stifling hours onstage, Larry Pine, that venerable non-celeb, was exiting the Delacorte Theater after performing in ''The Seagull,'' the freebie blockbuster in Central Park, when, hallelujah, a fan materialized from the supplicants cajoling autographs from his famous co-stars.

title: INSIDE
description: Ulster Protestant Digs In

title: Body Said to Fall From Airplane
description: Witnesses on Long Island told Nassau County authorities that a body recovered in northern Long Beach last night fell from an airplane en route to John F. Kennedy International Airport in Queens, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Ballot Bid Fails
description: A state judge yesterday rejected a rival candidate's bid to remove Charles J. Hynes, left, the Brooklyn district attorney, from the primary ballot. The judge, Melvin S. Barasch, ruled that an election rule requiring candidates to live in the borough in which they serve had not been violated. Justice Barasch turned down the bid by Mr. Hynes's challenger in the election, Sandra E. Roper, to remove Mr. Hynes because he owns a summer home in Breezy Point, Queens.

title: Outcry Grows Over Police Use of Force in Genoa
description: More than two weeks ago, Susan Hager received a telephone call in Portland, Ore., about her daughter, a student who had stopped off in Genoa to join protesters at the Group of 8 summit meeting on her way to a junior year abroad program in Siena.

title: Revamping, Broadband Provider Offers Swap
description: The Covad Communications Group offered yesterday to swap bonds with a face value of $1.4 billion for a combination of cash and equity as the company, an unprofitable provider of high-speed Internet service, prepares to seek bankruptcy protection.

title: Clear Channel Reports Loss for Quarter
description: Clear Channel Communications, the largest owner of radio stations after acquiring AMFM Inc. a year ago, reported a second-quarter loss because expenses increased.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COUGHLAN, JAMES
description: COUGHLAN-James, 92. Of Somers, NY. Retired Battalion Chief FDNY. Beloved husband of Kathleen (Buckley) Coughlan. Loving father of Kathleen Powell of Danbury, CT. Devoted grandfather of Diana and Kathleen. Brother of Marion Walsh and Gilbert Coughlan and the late Annie Foster, Archie and Douglas Coughlan. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, New York, Thursday 2-4 and 7-9 PM with service at the funeral home on Friday morning at 10 A.M. Interment following at Woodlawn Cemetery, the Bronx.

title: Wife Hunting Sure Is a Sick And Frightful Business
description: The Japanese psychological horror film ''Audition'' has been responsible for throngs of shaken filmgoers staggering out of theaters for the last year or so; it's ''Fatal Attraction'' with a sense of morality instead of a need to pander -- specifically, the movie's theme is the objectification of women in Japanese society and the mirror-image horror of retribution it could create.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOPPMANN, DORIS
description: HOPPMANN-Doris. With heartfelt sorrow and deepest sympathy for the Hoppmann family on the passing of Doris Hoppmann, beloved wife of Frederic & loving mother of Kristin, Randi and Rick. Our hearts go out to you Kristin. All our love, Maria and Kenneth

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Vote Postponed
description: President Chandrika Kumaratunga has postponed a referendum on a new Constitution until Oct. 18. The ballot measure, which had been scheduled for Aug. 21, had been criticized by opponents and legal experts as vaguely worded and unlawful. The president made no mention of restoring Parliament, which she suspended last month. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FTEHA, MARION FAIBIS
description: FTEHA-Marion Faibis. On August 7, 2001. Beloved wife of Joseph Fteha. Services Friday, 11:30 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Mike Haggerty was named to the new post of senior vice president and managing director at Media Planning, New York, part of Havas Advertising. He had been media director at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, New York, part of Euro RSCG Worldwide, also a unit of Havas.

title: An Unexpected Opinion
description: It may have looked like a case of art imitating talk show, but in truth it was an amazingly timed insight by a talk show host into her favorite television series.

title: Cuban Exile Group Split as Hard-Liners Resign From Board
description: After more than 40 years of standing solidly against Fidel Castro, the leading organization for Cuban exiles, the Cuban American National Foundation, was sundered today as nearly two dozen board members resigned. They contended that the group had forgotten its purpose and softened its line on Cuban issues.

title: In Switch, Transit Ridership Outpaces Cars, Study Finds
description: No one who has ridden recently on a packed New York subway or bus needs to be told: public transit ridership has exploded over the last few years.

title: Text: Ashcroft's Press Conference on the Child Pornography Case
description: Following is the complete text of a news conference today in Washington by Attorney General John Ashcroft on an Internet-based child pornography ring, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Buy At Home
description: President Kim Dae Jung says South Koreans should buy more of their own products. He called on Koreans to strengthen the economy ''by creating purchasing power'' instead of counting so heavily on exports. The government said it would spend $23 billion in the third quarter on public works to compensate for falling electronics exports. That is a $500 million increase over the amount previously pledged for the quarter. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Rules Adopted For Reporting Company-Paid Drug Studies
description: Editors of 11 leading medical journals from around the world say they have agreed to a new policy for reporting research sponsored by drug companies.

title: No Bail for Waterbury Mayor, Judge Rules in Closed Hearing
description: A federal judge refused today to grant bail to Mayor Philip A. Giordano of Waterbury, ordering him detained in prison until he is tried on charges of luring a child for sex.

title: Mr. Arafat's Role
description: Many Israelis are understandably frustrated with Yasir Arafat. After spurning a politically courageous Israeli peace offer last summer, the Palestinian leader has broken his pledge of nonviolence and for the past 10 months has repeatedly endorsed an armed Palestinian uprising. Wary of trusting him again as a ''peace partner,'' some prominent Israelis, including former Prime Minister Ehud Barak, are calling on the world to turn ''a cold shoulder'' to Mr. Arafat and wait for a different Palestinian leader. That is a luxury Israel cannot afford.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Judge Demands 'Key Logging' Explanation
description: A federal judge in Newark ordered the Justice Department to reveal technical information about the ''key logger'' system used to procure a computer password used by Nicodemo S. Scarfo Jr., who faces charges of illegal gambling and loan sharking. Federal District Judge Nicholas H. Politan said much of the evidence the government had provided so far -- a transcript of keystrokes -- was ''gobbledygook.'' The judge said the fuller information was necessary to determine whether the government had violated Mr. Scarfo's constitutional rights by installing the key logger without a wiretap order, which would be necessary if online communications were recorded. The judge wrote that the government's memo was due by Aug. 31; the government may also file a memo by Aug. 17 explaining its concerns about whether revealing the information will render the technology useless for future investigations. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: The Bioethicist and the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: EchoStar Makes Headway In Its Effort to Buy Hughes
description: EchoStar Communications won a partial victory yesterday in its effort to buy Hughes Electronics, the satellite television company that operates DirecTV, when the board of Hughes's parent, General Motors, did not reject the idea outright.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUINN, JOSEPH T.
description: QUINN-Joseph T. August 7, 2001. Beloved husband of Mary, father of Rory, Owen, and Maryellen; grandfather of Dan, Kevin and Alexandra. Reposing at O'Connor's Funeral Home, 91st St. and Beach Channel Dr., Rockaway Beach, NY, Wednesday and Thurs. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Francis de Sales Church, Rockaway Beach, 9:45AM Friday.

title: A Whopper of an Auction to Pay Off Prince's Creditors in Brunei
description: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei  In what is perhaps the final insult for a royal family plagued by financial scandal, liquidators here are preparing for a six-day auction of chandeliers, hot tubs, gold-plated light fixtures and thousands of crockery sets  all ordered but never used by a now disgraced prince and his business partners.

title: Management: New Guards To Lessen Liability; Software Trains Workers to Avoid Improper Behavior
description: Jessica Hartman is a silent victim of sexual harassment in the workplace.

title: Astrophotography
description: Astrophotography is a special adaptation of ordinary photography. Some interesting photographs of stars can be made even with inexpensive equipment. A fixed 35-millimeter camera is mounted on a sturdy tripod. The camera shutter is opened to the widest aperture or f-stop. Focus the lens at infinity. A fast film with a rating above 400 should be used to record the greatest number of stars.

title: Bill Clinton, Author
description: To the Editor:

title: New Ulster Setback: Protestant Chief Rejects I.R.A. Offer
description: Northern Ireland's leading Protestant politician rejected as inadequate today a disarmament proposal from the Irish Republican Army that the British and Irish governments had championed as a breakthrough in the stalemated Northern Ireland peace struggle.

title: Now in the Best Bottles: Plastic
description: HAS your Lafite been recorked lately? You should look into it. Every four or five years, Chteau Lafite-Rothschild in Bordeaux sends a team of specialists into the world to change the corks in older bottles of its wine. Why? Because wine corks, even the best of them, are maddeningly unreliable.

title: Baubles of Pita, Pastries and Flatbreads
description: At lunchtime in Midtown, fans of Middle Eastern food are lining up at Bread From Beirut, a new cafeteria-style spot at 24 West 45th Street. Crunchy falafel ($6.50 as a platter, $4.50 in a sandwich) is made with ground fava beans and chickpeas. Kebabs are rolled in pita and toasted on the grill ($6.50), and potato salad is showered with fresh cilantro ($4). But the real draw is what comes from the whimsically decorated wood- and gas-fired oven: more than a dozen kinds of flatbreads and pastries. They come with cheeses, topped with crushed wheat, dried goat cheese and sesame seeds ($5.50), or seasoned with za'atar, the Middle Eastern spice combination. Some are hearty enough to make a meal. Others are irresistible snacks. The owner, Samer Halimeh, a diamond dealer who grew up in Beirut, said he was not happy with the Middle Eastern fare sold in the area. So he opened his own place, with cooks trained in Lebanon turning out breads, salads, grilled meats and other specialties. Delivery in the neighborhood is available from (212) 764-1588.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Empty Freight Containers Rising Too High for Newark
description: Shipping containers are piled six high like a wall between the increasingly prosperous Ironbound neighborhood in Newark and the Passaic River. Along the New Jersey Turnpike, they rise even higher, like rectangular mountains of red, gray and green.

title: Make Mine Fish Oil  la Mode
description: FISH oil in ice cream. Flaxseed in cheese.

title: Unexpected Reds of Provence
description: EVEN in the summer, a steady diet of cool, crisp whites and the occasional ros can make a person desperate for a hearty red. Not a light-bodied Beaujolais that's been chilled but a robust wine with weight, if not gravity. This can be tricky if all around you people are mopping their brows and reaching for the ice.

title: Schundler Alters Concealed-Weapons Stand
description: A day after being assailed by gun-control advocates, Bret D. Schundler said today that he did not favor allowing New Jersey residents to carry concealed weapons and that he would not seek to change the state's gun regulations.

title: Cisco Earnings Drop Sharply But Match Expectations
description: Cisco Systems reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings today in line with analyst expectations, but the company, a bellwether for investors, suggested a global malaise in technology spending could continue at least through the end of the calendar year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Police Charges Dropped
description: Two weeks after two Newark police officers were acquitted on charges of beating and allowing others to beat a man accused of molesting a child, a judge here has agreed to drop lesser charges against four other officers named in the 1999 incident in a precinct cell block. In the request to Judge Michael A. Petrolle, the Essex County prosecutor moved to drop the charges because of the contradictory testimony of the victim, Emmanuel Aldea, 25. Officers Marisol Gonzalez-Cardona, Silas Smith, Chris Gialanella and Anthony Venancio were cleared. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Profit At Airline
description: As major airlines report slumping business, Ryanair, Europe's biggest low-cost carrier, said it bucked the trend with a 28 percent profit increase in the quarter ended June 30. But the Dublin-based airline, modeled on Southwest Airlines of the United States, said its outlook for the future was cautious. Major European airlines have announced lower profits or curbed expansion plans. Ryanair said after-tax profit rose to 23.2 million euros ($20.4 million) after it expanded its European network with 13 new routes. Its shares retreated. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teacher Evaluations
description: The number of New York City teachers receiving unsatisfactory ratings from their principals rose more than 18 percent to 944 this year, up from 798 last year, according to preliminary figures by the Board of Education yesterday. All but 109 of 1,200 principals have filed annual evaluations of the city's 80,000 teachers. The United Federation of Teachers said that principals were not evaluating classroom performance but were responding to Chancellor Harold O. Levy's call to be tougher on teachers. Anthony P. Coles, a deputy mayor, said that with so many poorly performing students, ''it's hard to be believe that only 1 percent of the teachers are doing an unsatisfactory job.''

title: Hints of Retiring in 2 Senators' Fund-Raising
description: Sluggish fund-raising by two Republican senators, Fred Thompson of Tennessee and Jesse A. Helms of North Carolina, has renewed doubts about whether they will run for re-election in 2002, while an all-out effort by an appointed Democratic freshman, Jean Carnahan of Missouri, has made it clear that she is ready to run.

title: Yale Names a Vice President
description: ROBERT L. CULVER, the new vice president for finance and administration at Yale University, has a background more varied than most. He has worked in business and in education, at universities and public schools, and as a university trustee and school board member. He worked for the Cambridge, Mass., school system in the early 1970's, and moved into higher education in 1990, as senior vice president and treasurer of Northeastern University.

title: GENZYME TO BUY COMPANY TO HELP IT DEVELOP DRUGS
description: The Genzyme Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Novazyme Pharmaceuticals for $137.5 million in stock to broaden its pipeline of treatments for rare genetic diseases. Novazyme shareholders will also be eligible to receive two additional payments totaling $87.5 million in stock if the company wins United States marketing approval for the first two products using Novazyme's drug development technologies. Genzyme will gain Novazyme's NZ-1001 drug candidate for Pompe's disease, a rare metabolic disorder, which it plans to develop along with its own experimental treatment. The acquisition also gives Genzyme new methods for making proteins for enzyme-replacement therapies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUCKENS, IRVING
description: RUCKENS-Irving. The Juilliard community mourns the death of Irving Ruckens, a dedicated and accomplished administrator of the School from 1968 to 1988. After his retirement he and his wife Sylvia provided generous support for many programs at the School. We all extend our deepest sympathy to his wife and family. Joseph W. Polisi, President The Juilliard School

title: Iran Parliament Clears Way for Khatami's 2nd Inauguration
description: The latest tussle between reformers and conservatives for the upper hand in Iran's stormy politics ended today with a surly Parliament confirming two new members of its oversight panel, paving the way for President Mohammad Khatami's inauguration on Wednesday.

title: Amid Questions, Northwestern Honors a 'Hero'
description: The breath of summer stood still outside this somber chapel. A hearse sat nearby as they came on a humid afternoon, the old and the young, the black and the white, carrying roses for a Northwestern University Wildcat.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Bodies Found In Trash
description: Workers at a waste management center in the Bronx found two bodies in the trash yesterday, the police said. The first, the badly decomposed remains of a man, was found around 11:20 a.m. Late last night, workers found a second body, this one wrapped, not far from where the first body was found. Neither body was identified and the police would provide no other details. The office of the medical examiner is investigating the causes of death, the police said.

title: Food Takes a Spin In Political Prints
description: The subtext for Sally Minker's print ''Sour Grapes,'' right, is political. A swipe at biotechnology, it is displayed at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, along with Gloria Garfinkel's ''Lunch With Dolly,'' which implies a similar distaste for cloning. The works are part of an exhibition called ''Digital Printmaking Now'' (through Sept. 2). While the exhibition was not restricted to food-related themes, perhaps the curators were feeling hungry. Look for ''Limited Edition Cookies'' by Adriane Herman, decorated with inkjet-printed images. She has turned the technique usually used for printing photographs on birthday and graduation cakes into art.

title: City Will Increase Poll Workers' Pay
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to announce today that the city will increase wages for poll workers for the upcoming elections, a mayoral aide said yesterday.

title: Houston Mother Pleads Not Guilty to Drowning Her Children
description: HOUSTON, Aug. 8 -- Harris County District Attorney Chuck Rosenthal today said he would seek the death penalty against Andrea Pia Yates, the mother accused of drowning her five young children in a bathtub. The announcement came hours after Mrs. Yates pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity to the two counts of capital murder against her.

title: Hernndez Moving In Right Direction
description: The bald-headed man in the black pants and the yellow shirt was already in the visiting clubhouse at Tropicana Field when it was opened to reporters today. He traipsed from the coaches' dressing room to the trainer's room and back, leaving a trail of hugs and handshakes. For the first time in a long time, Orlando Hernndez looked happy.

title: The Bioethicist and the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Bayer Pulls Cholesterol Drug After Side Effects Linked to 31 Deaths
description: FRANKFURT, Aug. 8 Bayer A.G., the German pharmaceutical and chemical conglomerate, withdrew its highly profitable new cholesterol-lowering drug from the market today as a result of side effects implicated in 31 deaths in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: A caption in Weekend on Friday for a picture by The Associated Press with the Pop and Jazz Guide misidentified a member of the band Living Colour, which performed in Central Park on Sunday. He was Corey Glover, not Vernon Reid.

title: Management
description: Jessica Hartman is a silent victim of sexual harassment in the workplace.

title: Nasdaq Selects Marketing Agency
description: The Nasdaq stock market has named McKinney & Silver in Raleigh, N.C., part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising, to handle its creative and media accounts. Spending was estimated at $30 million.

title: CNN Plans to Open Ground-Level Studios in Manhattan
description: Hoping to capture some of the street-theater energy that other major television networks get from their studios in Midtown Manhattan, CNN plans to open two studios on the ground level of the Time-Life Building on the Avenue of the Americas, officials involved in the plans said today.

title: Market Place; Conseco's Performance Isn't the Stuff of Sonnets
description: A great summer romance is on the rocks, a year after it began.

title: NEWPOWER SHARES PLUNGE AFTER REVENUE ESTIMATE IS CUT
description: Shares of NewPower Holdings fell 31 percent yesterday after the venture, formed by the Enron Corporation to compete with traditional gas and electric utilities, said that revenue this year would be lower than projected. Shares of NewPower fell $2.27 to $5.08 on the New York Stock Exchange, where it posted the largest percentage decrease. Revenue in 2001 will be $420 million to $440 million, down from the $530 million to $540 million forecast, the chief executive, Eugene Lockhart, said. The company expects to have a million customers by the end of the year, less than the 1.2 million projected. The revenue projection was lowered partly because of delays in Texas's plan to open its electricity market to competition. Milder-than-expected weather and a higher power-grid fee in the market that includes Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland also hurt business, Mr. Lockhart said on a conference call with analysts and investors. The company is based in Purchase, N.Y.

title: P.& G. Reports Net Loss After Cost of Revamping
description: Fourteen months ago, A. G. Lafley replaced a chief executive who had sought a radical transformation of Procter & Gamble.

title: Study Puts Census Errors At $4 Billion
description: In the protracted battle over whether census numbers should be adjusted to take into account the millions of people nationwide who are missed, a census monitoring group released a study yesterday saying the 2000 census undercount could deprive New York City of some $850 million in federal aid over the next 10 years.

title: A Comic Sees Humor In Years Of Disability
description: Kathy Buckley covers familiar ground in her comedy act, making jokes about the telephone company, relationships and her mother. Like many comedians, she thrives on the alienation and bitterness she feels toward people who haven't understood her. But because this comic has a severe hearing impairment, the familiar becomes exotic, and her ability to extract humor from pain takes on extra meaning.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Power Struggle
description: The White House and the National Governors' Association, at odds over whether states are doing enough to increase power supplies, are setting up a task force to study the issue. Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham warned the governors on Monday that if states did not move faster to increase the flow of electricity by approving construction of more transmission lines the administration might ask Congress for authority to approve such projects. The governors, meeting in Providence, R.I., countered that they were already moving expeditiously and would view any federal intervention as a blatant encroachment on states' rights. B. Drummond Ayres Jr. (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Israeli Killed
description: An Israeli diamond trader living in Jordan was shot to death in Amman, and a previously unknown group called the Nobles of Jordan, claimed responsibility, though it was unclear if that claim was valid. Jordanian officials said the Israeli, Yitzhak Snir, 51, seemed to have been killed in a financial dispute, but Israeli officials leaned toward a theory that Mr. Snir was killed because of his nationality. Mr. Snir was the first Israeli killed in Jordan, where Palestinians form a solid majority, since the Israeli-Palestinian conflict began last September. Clyde Haberman (NYT)

title: Roger Clinton Pleads Guilty to Reckless Driving
description: Roger Clinton, half brother of former President Bill Clinton, who was charged with driving under the influence and disturbing the peace after an arrest on Feb. 17 in Hermosa Beach, Calif., pleaded guilty today to a reduced charge of reckless driving.

title: A Period String Ensemble Turns to Vivaldi & Company
description: Europa Galante, a dozen early-music string players from Italy, won friends from a heatstricken but air-conditioned audience at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon. Fabio Biondi, the group's conductor and principal violinist, is a familiar figure in New York's often abortive period-instrument scene. Here he was making his first appearance at the Mostly Mozart series, as was his ensemble.

title: Lawyers May Reveal Secrets Of Clients, Bar Group Rules
description: Backers of an initiative to overhaul legal ethics rules, allowing lawyers more leeway to disclose client confidences to prevent fraud, injury or death, won a partial victory at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association in Chicago this week.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay Buys Home-Sales Site
description: The Internet auction company eBay said it had acquired HomesDirect, a company that specializes in auctions of foreclosed properties. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. HomesDirect has sold approximately 58,000 homes this year at prices ranging from $50,000 to $100,000. The company earns money by providing the auction platform to government agencies like the Veterans Administration. Ebay started a real estate division in August 2000 that auctions property and time shares. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Group Clears Medical Center
description: The deaths of 16 patients in the Texas Medical Center in Houston during a tropical storm in early June were caused by the critical nature of their illnesses and not the severe flooding that inundated the medical complex, an accreditation group has found. The storm caused $2 billion in damage to the medical center. A team from the Joint Commission on the Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations found that the deaths were not unexpected.

title: Popping Up in Greenmarkets: Tiny Apricots Bursting With Flavor
description: Suddenly, there are apricots in the Greenmarket. These are special: small red-tinted beauties from local orchards. They pack plenty of sweet flavor with a nice tart edge. They have a rich, almost buttery texture and are delicious as is but can also be poached whole in white wine or they can be pitted, halved and baked on a pastry round with a bit of butter and sugar. Walk right past the jumbo apricots at the supermarket and go to the nearest Greenmarket, where petite varieties are selling for under $3 a pound. For information on Greenmarket times, locations and purveyors: (212) 477-3220. The apricot season, if not the supply, is expected to last until late August.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DECLINES. The euro dropped after Germany's unemployment rate rose and industrial production fell, fueling concern that European growth is slowing. In New York, the euro settled at 87.74 cents, down from 88.23 cents.

title: Born to Cook: The Foie Gras Generation
description: WHY did the French chef use one egg in a cake?

title: Caramels and Butter With a Taste of Breton Salt
description: On seaside terraces in Brittany, shellfish are eaten with bread and salted butter. Just ask Maguy Le Coze, an owner of Le Bernardin, who is from Port Navalo in Brittany. Now, New Yorkers who want to indulge as the Bretons do can spread their bread (preferably, brown) with Le Gall Beurre de Baratte au Sel de Gurande, a butter from Brittany that is churned with fleur de sel from the region. It is a deeper yellow than the salted butter in American supermarkets, and it blossoms on the palate with a more intense saltiness. You can actually taste the salt crystals in the butter. It is also excellent for pie crust because of its flavor and low moisture content. Next week, Citarella stores will have it, in an almost-9-ounce package for $4.29. Another Breton product made with salt comes in a surprise package. The box, 7 ounces, looks as if it should hold cheese, but it is candy, smooth little wrapped Caramels au Beurre Sal made by La Maison d'Armoine; $7.99 at Fairway.

title: With Cost Cuts, MetLife Says Net Rose 12%
description: MetLife, the No. 1 life insurer in the country, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 12 percent as it trimmed expenses.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MOSS, CHARLES B.
description: MOSS-Charles B. Happy, Happy Birthday. Your life is celebrated everyday. Love, Nanc

title: The Bioethicist and the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Duong Van Minh, 85, Saigon Plotter, Dies
description: Duong Van Minh, the Vietnamese general who led the coup in 1963 that overthrew Ngo Dinh Diem as president of South Vietnam and later became the republic's last president for a few days before North Vietnamese troops stormed his palace in Saigon, died on Monday in Pasadena, Calif. He was 85.

title: New Disclosure Rule Adopted by Lawyers
description: Backers of an initiative to overhaul legal ethics rules, allowing lawyers more leeway to disclose client confidences to prevent fraud, injury or death, gained a partial victory at the annual meeting of the American Bar Association this week.

title: Contrite Gastineau Pays Visit To the Jets
description: Just two weeks after serving 11 months at Rikers Island for violating the terms of probation stemming from an assault on his wife, the former Jet Mark Gastineau made a rare visit to practice this afternoon.

title: In American Cooking, Chicago's the Kitchen
description: AMERICA has never really had a cuisine. We went straight to ''new American'' without ever having determined how all the regional styles from New England to New Mexico came together to form a national philosophy of food. And what we wound up with was a smorgasbord.

title: Playing Music That Was Old When Mozart Was Young
description: Lincoln Center's expansion of the early music component of Mostly Mozart in recent years is generally a good thing, and one can't argue with the impulse that led the festival's programmers to include the Tallis Scholars on this year's schedule. Still, Alice Tully Hall is not the ideal place for this extraordinary English ensemble or the music it sings. The group's repertory was composed to be heard in the resonant acoustics of a church, and the ensemble itself thrives in that atmosphere.

title: The Palpable Resolve of a Mother's Love
description: Darby (Josh Lucas) is brazen, magnetic and ruthless -- in other words, a trick, hot and seductive, the wrong man to fall in love with. In the new film noir ''The Deep End,'' when he comes to an early end, you think the movie will never recover. With his roving eyes and vulture smile, Darby is all sybarite -- a man of immediate pleasure with a blond brush of a mustache that belongs on one of the Village People; it's immaculate and you can sense his pride of ownership. But the filmmakers Scott McGehee and David Siegel have found an equally proud match for him in a mama bear named Margaret (Tilda Swinton), who becomes enmeshed in a murder involving Darby and his latest target: Margaret's 17-year-old child, Beau (Jonathan Tucker). Margaret has to handle things on her own, because her husband, a naval officer, is away.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Militants Blamed For Killings Of 9
description: Nine people were killed and 30 were wounded today when gunmen opened fire at the railway station in the city of Jammu, the police said. The authorities blamed militants opposed to India's rule over the state of Jammu and Kashmir for the attack. The incident comes within days of a massacre of 15 Hindus in the Doda district of Jammu. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Hatchette Itching to Be Go-To Guy
description: When Matthew Hatchette was toiling with the Minnesota Vikings, able to count his touchdown catches on one hand, he thought about the number of balls he might catch if he were the starter, if Cris Carter and Randy Moss were not playing in front of him, if he were ever to have the offensive spotlight shining on him, rather than leaving him in a considerable shadow.

title: Manhattan Hotel Discounts
description: Eight Manhattan hotels have weekend rates starting at $178 a night for one-bedroom suites through Sept. 9. The participating hotels, members of the Manhattan East Suite Hotels group, are the Beekman Tower, at 49th and First Avenue; Dumont Plaza, 34th between Third and Lexington; Eastgate Tower, 39th between Second and Third; Lyden Gardens, 64th between Second and Third; Plaza Fifty, 50th between Third and Lexington; Shelburne Murray Hill, Lexington at 37th; Southgate Tower, Seventh Avenue at 31st Street; and Surrey Hotel, 76th between Fifth and Madison. Smaller studio suites, for couples, start at $158. Rates are subject to availability and blackout dates apply. Information: (800) 637-8483 or www.mesuite.com .

title: Shuttle Will Ferry New Crew to Space Station
description: The space shuttle Discovery is poised to take a new crew to live on the International Space Station, a trip that will mark a hiatus in what has been a hectic series of construction missions.

title: CHANCELLOR SEEKS TO SHIFT CONTROL IN SCHOOL-BUILDING
description: Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that estimates of the shortfall in the construction budget have ballooned by almost 50 percent to $2.8 billion and that building and repairing the city's schools should be taken out of the hands of the Board of Education.

title: Gender Error Held Up an Arrest in Laptop Thefts
description: For over a year, the police had been trying to identify a suspect who kept cropping up in surveillance footage while stealing laptop computers in Midtown office buildings. But they cracked the case only this week when they realized that the man they were after was actually a woman.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ad Bureau Issues Guidelines
description: The Interactive Advertising Bureau in New York said it had issued voluntary size guidelines for rich media advertising, online ads that contain audio, animation and video. In February, the bureau released standards for sizes and shapes of online ads. Allison Fass (NYT)

title: I'm a Concierge for Travelers
description: I've been a travel agent for 25 years. When I started, it was common for customers to come to the office. Some would dress up. They would make a day of it. These days, people barely have four seconds to spend on booking their trips.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Banker's Death
description: The death of Gasto Eduardo de Bueno Vidigal, the 82-year old chairman and majority shareholder of Banco Mercantil de So Paulo, caused shares in the bank to jump sharply on speculation that it would quickly be sold. Under pressure from minority shareholders who disagreed with his conservative investment style, Mr. Vidigal had started searching for buyers for the bank, Brazil's 22nd largest in terms of assets, but was not eager to sell the family-controlled business. Last month, Mr. Vidigal held talks with Citigroup, which has expressed interest in expanding its branch network. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Standing Up for Umpires
description: When umpires are in the news, it's not a good thing. They're in the news now because of inconsistencies in how strikes are being called. But that's not the real issue.

title: Sluggish Germany Begins to Drag Down Rest of Europe
description: Germany, Europe's biggest economy, provided more evidence today that its growth has come to a stop and that it is dragging down the rest of the Continent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BORENKIND, ARLINE MINCOW (NEE WINOKUR)
description: BORENKIND-Arline Mincow (nee Winokur), 66, of Danbury, CT, on August 6, 2001. Wife of the late Samuel H. Borenkind. Beloved mother of Lawrence J. Mincow of Danbury and Robin B. Mincow of NYC. Sister of Robert Winokur. Funeral Services Wednesday at 11:00 am at the Jowdy-Kane Funeral Home, 9-11 Granville Avenue, Danbury, CT.

title: Tom Colicchio
description: KAREN DeMASCO, my pastry chef at Craft, knows how much I like lemon. Karen worked with me at Gramercy Tavern, and when we were devising the dessert menu for the new restaurant, she immediately came up with a steamed lemon pudding. She made some samples, and I ate two of them on the spot.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Ericsson Wins Verizon Order
description: The Swedish phone equipment maker Ericsson will supply Verizon Wireless, the biggest United States mobile phone operator, with wireless handsets that allow high-speed access to the Web, e-mail and other services. The two companies are testing new handsets that use code-division multiple access, or C.D.M.A., technology to increase the transmission capacity of digital networks. Ericsson says its C.D.M.A. handsets transmit information at up to 144 kilobits a second. Most current cell phones run wireless Web applications at around 11 kilobits a second. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Tours, Tips and Tomatoes, Online
description: A new Web site, www.foodevents.com, is a grab bag of useful information for foodies, for travelers who want dining tips and for those interested in food festivals, wine tastings and similar events. It is updated monthly and is organized by Slow Food, an international food education organization. This month, it offers a tour of New York's Chinatown, information about farmers' markets across the country, reviews of restaurants in Paris and Barcelona and a note about a tomato dinner sponsored by the American Institute of Wine and Food at Herban Kitchen, 290 Hudson Street (Spring Street), on Aug. 21 at 6:30 p.m. Tomato lovers can find out more on the institute's Web page at www.aiwf-ny.com or by calling (212) 447-0456.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenager Indicted Again
description: A teenager who was indicted last week with Robert Iler, a 16-year-old actor on the television drama ''The Sopranos,'' was indicted in a separate case yesterday on two counts of first-degree robbery. In the earlier case, the teenager, Michael Cournede, 19, was charged with robbing a teenager on the Upper East Side. Yesterday, he was charged with robbing money, a jacket and a disc player from a teenager on April 19 on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive promenade near 78th Street.

title: 99degrees Heat Was the New York State of Mind
description: Unless you actually do live in a cave, chances are you noticed how hot it was yesterday. In fact, by 8 a.m. in Central Park it was already past 80 degrees. By noon it was past 90. At 2 p.m., according to the National Weather Service, the city reached the day's high of 99 degrees. In hot parlance, that means torrid, blazing, sultry, boiling, roasting, scorching, steamy, red-hot, white-hot, hot as holy -- well, you get it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINARD, EVERETT LAWRENCE, III.
description: MINARD-Everett Lawrence, III. 51, of Brooklyn, NY and London. Laury died August 2 while climbing Mount Rainier in his home State of Washington. Survived by wife Elizabeth Bailey Minard and daughters Sara and Julia, of Brooklyn; parents Nancy and Everett Lawrence Minard, II of Seattle; brother Frank of Seattle; brother Michael of Prague, and grandmother Margueritte Minard of Wenatchee, Washington. He was the founding editor of Forbes Global Magazine, the international edition of Forbes. He joined Forbes Global in September 1997, after serving as managing editor of Forbes for eight years. Laury had a 27-year career at Forbes, starting as a reporter/researcher in 1974. Memorial service at Trinity Church in Manhattan, 89 Broadway (at Wall Street), on Friday, August 10, at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Riders for Health II, an organization that uses motor cycles to transport doctors and medicines to remote villages in Africa; address: c/o Brown & Sturm, 260 East Jefferson Street, Rockville, MD 20850.

title: Data Permanently Erased From Florida Computers
description: An independent examination of four computers used by Katherine Harris, the Florida secretary of state, and her aides during last fall's presidential recount has found evidence that the machines were used more extensively than either Ms. Harris or her spokesman had acknowledged.

title: Liberties; A Very Personal History
description: Bill Clinton is an indefatigable competitor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOUETA, AMY
description: GOUETA-Amy. On August 7, 2001. Beloved wife of Nessim. Loving daughter of Esther Halifi. Devoted mother of David and Danielle Leone. Dear mother-in-law of Scott Leone. Loving sister of Maurice Halifi, Denise Smouha and Andree Rabinowitz. Services Wednesday, 11:15 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Soldier From North Seeks Return
description: A North Korean soldier returned to Panmunjom after having been carried from North to South Korea by a swift current in a flooded stream. The soldier, Cpl. Ri Sung Hun, 29, who was found on Saturday clad only in his shorts, said he wanted to go back to North Korea. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: O to Have Been Born in Appalachia!
description: The hoary advice to authors, ''Write what you know,'' doesn't apply to Gillian Welch, the songwriter who performed on Thursday night at Town Hall. As one of countless city folks who fell in love with older rural music, Ms. Welch writes with terse empathy about events and situations far from her own experience: moonshining, hard luck, mountain flowers and murder.

title: Op-Art; An Ice Cube's Chance in August
What They Were Thinking
description: John Patrick M. and Alyssa K., Long Island, N.Y., June 17, 2001

title: Arafat and the Power of Persuasion
description: As one who has just returned from the front lines of the intifada, I find the current argument about what happened at Camp David to be surreal. Violence is worsening, Hamas's strength is growing and the Palestinian Authority's institutions are beginning to crumble. Unless we quickly intervene to reverse the rapid deterioration, the next terrorist attack could push both sides toward open warfare and threaten American interests in regional stability as well.

title: Howard Elting, 93; Relayed News of Holocaust
description: Howard Elting, a United States diplomat who in 1942, as vice counsel in the Geneva consulate, was one of the first American officials to pass on to the State Department information on the Nazi plan to eliminate the Jews of Europe, died on July 1 at his home in San Rafael, Calif. He was 93.

title: Recipe: Strata With Spinach and Peppers
description: Adapted from Lula

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, HILDA
description: REICH-Hilda. On August 5. Beloved wife of the late Lester. Loving mother of Elizabeth and Harry Wachen, Maria and the late Benjamin Fishman. Dear sister of Shirley Apfelbaum and Hillel Horwitz, the late Max Horwitz and Sylvia Heyman. Adored grandmother of David, Mark, Kimberly and Hallie and great-grandmother of Rebecca and Allison.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGALL, ARTHUR A.
description: SEGALL-Arthur A. Our deepest sympathies from many friends of Naomi Segall, former daughter-inlaw for twenty-five years, and confidante of Nat and Arthur A. Segall, longtime name partner, Loeb & Loeb, who passed away August 2, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, JAMES V.
description: GOULD-James V., 87. Of Irvington, NY, formerly of Dobbs Ferry on August 7, 2001. Mr. Gould owned and managed the Gould Agency, insurance underwriters, in New York City. Survived by his wife Margaret. Father and father in law of Florence Low, Laura and Mark Hoffman, Margaret Elizabeth and Randy Paul, Norman Carl Mingo, Brian James & Tracy Mingo, Richard Theodore and Mary Mingo. Brother of George Gould and his wife Janet and survived by 11 grandchildren. Mass of the Resurrection Friday at 10 AM, Immaculate Conception Church, Irvington, NY. Visiting Thursday 24 and 7-9PM Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Avenue (exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. Memorials to Immaculate Conception Church appreciated.

title: Recipe: Grouper With Lobster, Potato Salad and Avocado Cream
description: Adapted from Mod

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, JACK AND SELMA
description: RUDOLPH-Jack and Selma. Beloved parents of Susan Rudolph, Pamela and Mark Elias; devoted siblings of Ruth Weissman and Morris Rudolph; loving grandparents of Rachel, Emily and Zack Elias. Services Thursday, 11:30AM, at ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions in their memory can be made to the Alzheimer's Association or the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Chair of Product Safety Panel to Resign
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8  The head of the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today that she will resign later this year, a move that will likely re-ignite the battle over who should replace her.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday about an announcement by Paul Vallas, former Chicago public schools superintendent, that he would seek the Democratic nomination for governor of Illinois misstated the year of the March primary. It is 2002 -- not, of course, 2000.

title: Brazil Inoculating Its Economy With an Injection of Austerity
description: In a decision that promises continued austerity in an election year, the government said today that it planned to cut spending by about $2.5 billion over the next 18 months to qualify for a $15 billion line of credit from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISROCK, S. LESLIE
description: MISROCK-S. Leslie. On August 7, 2001, of Chappaqua, NY, and New York City. Husband of Barbara G. Father of Kathryn and Victoria Misrock. Father-in-law of Adam Goldstein. Grandfather of Benjamin Goldstein. Interment private. Memorial Service, September 12, 2001, at 11 AM, Fordham School of Law, McNally Amphitheater, 140 West 62nd St., New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to: The S. Leslie Misrock Cancer Research Memorial Fund at The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Ave, Box 164, New York, NY 10021.

title: Our Towns; Connecticut Calls It Nouveau Jersey
description: NEW JERSEY!'' the man at the garden supply center said in a tone he might use if you had a geranium growing out of your head. ''Who even thinks of New Jersey?''

title: Money Shouts
description: Some of the Democratic candidates for mayor of New York City seem to be using up most of their ingenuity in finding ways to skirt the city's campaign finance regulations. This low-decibel race can get very noisy indeed when the subject is money and how to spend it.

title: Clifton Brown's Scorecard
description: Every two weeks, Clifton Brown ranks the 10 best men and women in professional golf. These rankings are from August 8.

title: A Swing Toward Mayoral Control
description: Asurvey of 53 New Yorkers conducted by Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs found that those polled consider public education to be the city's most challenging policy issue, and many of them support mayoral control of the school system, an idea that has been gaining momentum in recent months.

title: How Do You Get to Carnegie Hall?
description: With his tan fedora set atop a headful of dark curls and a wine-colored velvet corduroy blazer worn over a T-shirt, Justin Kantor resembles a roving troubador with a cello. ''I just love music,'' he said, shrugging. ''I want to play whatever comes my way.'' A year away from completing a bachelor's degree at the Manhattan School of Music, he can perhaps afford to be dreamy. But one afternoon in May, after a four-hour practice session, Mr. Kantor looked in on the job-networking fair in the school cafeteria.

title: SALTON BUYING WESTCLOX, BIG BEN AND SPARTUS BRANDS
description: Salton, the maker of George Foreman grills and Timex clocks, said yesterday that it was buying the Westclox, Big Ben and Spartus brands from the bankrupt General Time Corporation for $9.8 million to become the largest maker of clocks in the country. Salton also agreed to buy inventory in the United States, Europe and Canada. No other financial terms were disclosed. General Time, which is based in Norcross, Ga., had sales of $109 million in its last fiscal year. Salton is based in the Chicago suburb of Mount Prospect, Ill.

title: Fusion Cuisine From Just-Married Chefs
description: IN the nearly seven years that it has been open, Verbena has carved out a niche that only seems to get nichier as time goes on. Early on, it stood out, if a restaurant this quiet and intimate can be said to stand out, as a lone outpost of elegant cuisine in a neighborhood of takeout shops and taverns. With the emergence of Park Avenue South as a restaurant strip geared to younger diners in search of cool bars and hot chefs, Verbena seems almost Garboesque in its languid disengagement from the sizzling scene swirling around it.

title: Current Releases
description: ALPHA LIST-->

title: Lucrative YankeeNets Deal Nears Completion
description: The deal to sell 40 percent of the Yankees' sports cable television network is expected to be concluded next week, three people involved in the transactions said yesterday.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Militants Rampage
description: At least 10 white people were injured when government-backed militants went on a rampage in Chinhoyi. The attacks followed a clash between white farmers and black farm invaders in which 2 blacks were injured and about 20 whites were arrested. In an incident that appeared to be unrelated to the farm invasions, a 76-year-old white farmer was killed by assailants at his home. Violence has widened as plans expand to redistribute white-owned farms to blacks. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Hevesi Backs Down on Campaign-Funds Fight
description: Alan G. Hevesi backed down from his confrontation with the Campaign Finance Board yesterday, dispatching aides to negotiate with the board and pulling back from a lawsuit the mayoral candidate's political consultant had prepared to file to try to force the board to give the campaign millions of dollars in matching funds.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Vatican City: Pope Meets Married Bishop
description: Pope John Paul II met today with an archbishop who faces excommunication over his recent marriage. The Vatican characterized the meeting as the start of a dialogue ''that it is hoped can lead to positive developments.'' But a spokesman for Archbishop Emmanuel Milingo said he had urged the pope to allow priests to marry. The bishop, 71, was married on May 27 by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon, who chose the bride. As archbishop of Lusaka, Zambia, he resigned in 1983 under pressure over his exorcisms and healings, then worked in the Vatican until last year. Melinda Henneberger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURTIS, THEODORE A. III.
description: BURTIS-Theodore A. III. Of Brooklyn, NY, on August 1, 2001, after a long illness. A gifted and public spirited architect, and founding partner of Buttrick, White & Burtis. Beloved husband of Judy and loving father of Theo. In addition to his wife and son, Mr. Burtis is survived by his father, Theodore A. Burtis, II, and two sisters, Barbara Shipps and Pamela Bartholomew. A memorial service will be held on August 15, 2001 at 11:15 AM in the Fordham University Church at the Rose Hill campus in the Bronx. Additional information, Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, New York, (516) 671-0807.

title: Seat-Belt Use Rises in South In a Campaign To Get Tough
description: A brief campaign in May to enforce seat-belt laws in eight Southern states, supplemented by television and radio advertisements, pushed use up by nine percentage points, government figures show. Now safety advocates say they will press the government to adopt the strategy nationwide.

title: Technology Briefing | Media: Ukraine Trade Status Suspended
description: The federal government has suspended the special duty-free status for products from Ukraine because of the country's persistent failure to curb unauthorized production of optical media products like CD-ROM's and DVD's, trade officials said.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Managers Released
description: P. S. Subramanyam, the former chairman of Unit Trust of India, the country's largest mutual fund company, and two senior aides were released on bail by a court in Bombay. The executives were arrested on July 21 on conspiracy and fraud charges in connection with a spreading financial and political scandal surrounding the fund company. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, STUART CARLETON
description: DAVIDSON-Stuart Carleton. On August 1, 2001, of Washington, DC, while traveling in Norway. Beloved husband of Sally Foulis Davidson; father of Ellen Lindsay Davidson Shea, Olga (Holly) Merck Davidson Boszormenyi - Nagy, Stuart Patterson Davidson and Alexander Johnston Davidson; brother of Mary Howard Davidson Swift, Julia Shaw Davidson Cheshire, Frances Patterson Davidson Bortz. Also survived by seven grandchildren. Memorial services will be held St. John's Episcopal Church, 3240 O St., NW, Washington, DC on Thursday, August 9, 3pm. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to American Rivers, 1025 Vermont Ave, NW, Suite 720, Washington, DC 20005. Joseph Gawler's Sons, Washington, DC.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Legislators Push For Action On Domains
description: Senior members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee are calling for an expedited process to add more extensions, known as top-level domains, to the Internet's address system. The legislators, including Representative Billy Tauzin, above, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the committee, sent a letter to the the commerce secretary, Donald L. Evans, calling for the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, which the Commerce Department oversees, to expeditiously consider additional top-level domains like .travel or .kids. The nonprofit corporation, known as Icann, oversees the Internet's address system and is currently in the process of introducing seven new top-level domains, including .biz and .info. Critics have charged that the rollout of new domains is too slow; Icann says its timetable is designed to protect the stability of the system. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, BRIAN K.
description: MORRIS-Brian K. At age 52 in the prime of his career with Unilever, died tragically from an accident at his home in Manhattan on his return from vacation in France. Beloved husband of Diane and adored by his daughter, Beth. Dear brother to Dawn and Leigh. A British citizen, the funeral service will be held at St. James Church, Biddenham, Bedford on August 21st at 2PM.

title: 2 Admit Robbing Deliveryman But Blame Another for Killing
description: Two of the five Queens teenagers accused in the beating death of a deliveryman in a plot to steal two bags of Chinese food pleaded guilty yesterday to robbery and will not face murder charges. Like a third teenager who has pleaded guilty to robbery, they blamed the youngest of the five, who was 14 at the time, for the killing.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Budget Veto Override
description: As tax opponents protested outside, the state House and Senate voted to override Gov. Don Sundquist's July 26 veto of a $19.6 billion budget that was balanced with money from the tobacco settlement rather than with tax increases. The House voted 66 to 33 and the Senate voted 19 to 12 to override the veto. During the House vote, hundreds staged a noisy anti-tax protest, though it was less boisterous than one on July 12, when hundreds of protesters stormed the Capitol as the Legislature approved the budget. Lino R. Rodriguez JR. (NYT)

title: Footlights
description: All This Jazz

title: A Susan B. Anthony Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Chen, a Newcomer, Impresses the Mets and the Brewers
description: This season's trading deadline provided unofficial finality of sorts to the Mets' desperate attempts to contend for a playoff spot. After spending the previous four seasons plugging holes for their playoff runs, the Mets shed veteran players this time, mostly for younger, less expensive alternatives.

title: DISCOUNT AUTO AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY ADVANCE AUTO
description: Discount Auto Parts has agreed to be acquired by the closely held Advance Auto Parts, creating a company that will operate 2,420 auto parts stores in 38 states. Shareholders of Discount, which is based in Lakeland, Fla., will receive $7.50, plus 0.2577 share of the combined company, the companies said yesterday in a statement. Advance, based in Roanoke, Va., said it would file with the Securities and Exchange Commission to issue shares and become a publicly traded company. Advance valued the new company at $15 to $17 a share. The companies generated more than $3 billion in revenue the last year.

title: Budget Crisis, Still Burning, Has Already Left Casualties
description: A plan to open pre-kindergarten classes in thousands of schools this year is dead. Housing construction for homeless people will sputter. The same could happen to day care programs for tens of thousands of poor children.

title: The Bioethicist and the Mirror
description: To the Editor:

title: Indy racing is using an infomercial in its effort to lure TV viewers off the couch and to the track.
description: ALMOST every television viewer is familiar with infomercials, those late night and daytime commercials that usually last a half-hour and promote products like exercise equipment, diet plans or get-rich-quick ideas.

title: The Presidential Pen
description: In the preface to his memoirs, Harry Truman lamented the fact that so few presidents had told their own stories in their own words. ''It would have been helpful,'' he wrote, ''for us to know more of what was in their minds and what impelled them to do what they did.'' Helpful is an interesting word in this context, but it applies perfectly to the memoir that Bill Clinton will now begin writing to the tune of $10 million of Alfred A. Knopf's money. It would be helpful for us to know more of what was in Mr. Clinton's mind and what impelled him to do what he did, whether the subject is welfare reform, Mideast negotiations, Monica Lewinsky or Marc Rich. Knopf has bet that Mr. Clinton, in the inherent garrulousness of his soul, will tell us, or that he will at least come close enough to allow the publisher to break even.

description: An unidentified seller put 44 million shares of Deutsche Telekom up for sale yesterday at 23.60 euros each, according to Deutsche Bank, which is managing the offer. Analysts speculated that the seller obtained the shares in payment for a stake in the American wireless company VoiceStream, which Deutsche Telekom acquired this year, mainly for stock, and that more such sales could be expected. description: The broiling heat yesterday pushed electricity use to record levels in New York, New England and several other Eastern Seaboard states, but power companies reported few failures as they braced for more high temperatures this week that could give their systems the toughest test in years.

description: Despite warnings from leading experts that the experiments in human cloning would inevitably lead to babies that are deformed, or die soon after birth, a fertility doctor, a chemist and a scientist-entrepreneur nevertheless vowed today to press ahead with separate efforts to create the first cloned human being.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Cutbacks
description: One of Japan's four leading banking groups, Sumitomo Mitsui, said it would eliminate 600 more jobs and close 80 additional branches to cut costs as the economy deteriorates. The cuts are in addition to plans it announced in December to reduce its work force by 4,300 and shut 100 branches. description: Even in a sharp economic slowdown, the new economy seems to be surviving. It just may not be as big a deal as many of its most optimistic proponents had predicted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMAS, CARL WAYNE
description: THOMAS-Carl Wayne. With deep sorrow the Kings County District Attorney and his staff mourn the untimely passing of Carl Wayne Thomas. His unyielding energy and zest for life will be missed by all those who came in contact with him. While an Assistant District Attorney (1993 to 1995), Carl brought a heart-searching vigilance to his legal work. He knew that the law can only strive for justice and fairness and advocated that prosecutors should ''mend the social fabric of our country with a thread of justice.'' Friends and former colleagues of Carl W. Thomas send their heartfelt condolences to his wife, Mrs. Elizabeth Thomas, their children and his family. His friendship, his talent as a skilled attorney and his presence in our lives will be truly missed. May he rest in peace.

description: Occasionally Michael Vick has to snap himself out of his daydream. There are instances where his body is in Georgia but his mind is in California.

description: ROSENBERG-Stanley L., at age 83, peacefully at home on August 3, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Lee Cohen Rosenberg. He is sadly missed by his loving and devoted daughter Maddi-Jane Sobel and his son-in-law David and grandchildren Elana Stern and Rebecca Sobel, his loving and admiring son Jonathan and his daughter-in-law Irit and grandchildren Erik and Jodie, his loving and devoted son Neal and his son Daniel and grandchildren Katherine and Paul. But the scientist, Ann Juston of the Suffolk County Crime Laboratory, said blood DNA in a car that prosecutors say the assailants drove to the building matched the DNA of the second suspect, Ryan D. Wagner. Ms. Juston said in Suffolk County Court that blood found on a digging tool prosecutors say was used in the attack matched one victim's DNA, while another stain found at the scene matched the other victim's DNA. Only 42,000 non-farm jobs were lost, compared to a monthly average of 72,000 in the second quarter of the year. The 49,000 drop in factory jobs was also a slowdown from the second quarter pace. The manufacturing index of the National Association of Purchasing Management fell in July, but has not dropped back to its recent low.

The company has also agreed that three officers would contribute $10 million in stock. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

To filmmakers, Latin America is often dismissed and lumped together as a single sensibility, which is like saying that Luis Buuel and Hector Babenco both made the same kinds of movies. The program for the festival, which starts tomorrow and runs through Sept. 5, points up the radical differences in tone from one picture to the next.

Though a founding member of the 33-year-old Art Ensemble of Chicago, one of the first jazz groups to really understand how showbiz belongs in avant-gardism, he was the one who didn't wear tribal face paint, the one whose music apart from the band grew increasingly empirical and conceptual.

She rented all of the classics -- ''Deep Throat,'' ''Behind the Green Door,'' ''The Devil in Miss Jones'' -- searching for that one overlooked masterpiece worthy of dramatic reconsideration.

title: MUTUAL INSURER CUTS 1,370 JOBS, MOST IN TEXAS
description: United Services Automobile Association, a mutual insurance and financial services company, plans to cut 1,370 jobs, or almost 6 percent of its work force. The cuts are the result of a company review, which was prompted by a drop in sales at life insurance, investment management and financial services businesses, the company said. About 85 percent of the layoffs will be at the headquarters in San Antonio. Life insurers have seen a drop in earnings as declines in the stock market have pared profits at their retirement savings, investment management, financial services and banking businesses.

description: Hoping perhaps to jump-start contract negotiations with the union representing pro football's referees, Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, says he might use replacement referees if an agreement on a new contract is not reached soon.

description: An important but troubled prosecution witness who testified that he heard Michael C. Skakel confess to the 1975 murder of Martha Moxley died on Tuesday in Rochester, apparently from a dose of bad heroin, police officials said.

description: BEIDAIHE, China, Aug. 8 - Jiang Zemin has not yet met George W. Bush, but in their single telephone conversation last month, Mr. Jiang says, ``from his voice I could feel that he was a president I could do business with.''

title: Aetna Posts Wider Losses, Citing High Costs in Managed Care Unit
description: Aetna, the nation's biggest health insurer, said yesterday that its losses deepened in the second quarter as medical costs jumped 17 to 18 percent in its core managed care business. The company said the losses would continue into next year before it could again generate profits by raising premiums and tightening cost controls.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Prosecutor Charged With D.W.I.
description: A veteran Queens prosecutor was charged with driving while intoxicated after an accident on Tuesday, the police said. The police said the prosecutor, John Devlin, 58, an assistant Queens district attorney since 1982, was driving his minivan about 11 a.m. when he crossed the center line at Rockaway Point Boulevard and Beach 216th Street in Queens and hit another vehicle, injuring the driver. Mr. Devlin, who was treated at Peninsula Hospital Center and was released yesterday, has been suspended without pay, said Betsy Herzog, a spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. Ms. Herzog said that to avoid favoritism, the office had asked for a special prosecutor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VON JAGLINSKY, ANITA A.
description: VON JAGLINSKY-Anita A., age 78, of St. James on August 6, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Bogislav, loving mother of Suzanne Toufayan, Sandra Brown, Barbara Wasek and Peter Von Jaglinsky, cherished grandmother of thirteen and great-grandmother of five. Anita was educated at the Lexington Avenue School for the Deaf and later recruited by IBM where she worked as a keypunch operator as a young woman. She was an avid lip reader who never let her handicap interfere with her accomplishments. A lover of books, history and life, her selflessness was her greatest attribute, for she always put her family before herself. She touched the hearts of all who knew her and will be greatly missed by us all. Reposing at The Branch Funeral Home, 190 East Main St., Smithtown, NY. Visiting 2-4 & 7-9:30 Wed. & Thurs. Funeral Mass Friday, 9:45AM St. Patrick's RC Church. Cremation to follow at Washington Memorial Park.

title: Maureen Reagan, 60, Activist and President's Daughter
description: Maureen Reagan, the outspoken daughter of former President Ronald Reagan who was often at odds with her father's policies, died yesterday at her home in Sacramento. She was 60, and had suffered a recurrence of melanoma, a skin cancer with which she was first diagnosed in 1996 and that, after some years in remission, recurred last fall.

title: Richter Briefly Thought Of Hanging Up Pads

description: The province of Ontario is taking a tougher stance on welfare than has ever been tried before in Canada. It plans to make passing a literacy test mandatory for receiving public assistance and it will screen recipients for drug or alcohol problems, cutting off benefits to those who refuse treatment.

description: The Clorox Company said today that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit fell 35 percent as its products lost sales to cheaper store brands. Clorox also dropped a $175 million purchase in Brazil.

Two up-and-coming jeans brands -- one established in the United States, the other from Turkey -- are seeking to capitalize on that notion in different ways with the introduction this week of their first television ads.

Hevesi, a less-than-dynamic and not particularly well-known candidate for City Hall: Hank Morris.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer To Testify
description: A retired police sergeant who came forward last month to challenge the testimony of the chief government witness against Charles Schwarz, left, an officer convicted twice in the Abner Louima case, is to tell his story in public for the first time during a federal court hearing scheduled for Wednesday. The retired sergeant, Patrick Walsh, is expected to say that the witness, Detective Eric Turetzky, had said he was unsure if Mr. Schwarz or another officer walked Mr. Louima to a precinct bathroom on the night of the assault. The Liberty may have relinquished the Eastern Conference title to the Cleveland Rockers and it may not exactly look like a team ready for a possible playoff showdown against the Miami Sol, which beat New York twice this season, but no team should expect the Liberty to lose without a fight.

title: Economic Scene; It was not so long ago that married women had no property rights.

With her ascension, women now make up 1 percent, for a total of five, of the Fortune 500 chief executives. That may not seem like much but only a generation ago, when Ms. Mulcahy was starting her career at Xerox, women were almost completely absent from even the middle ranks of corporate managers.
