title: Optimism and Obstacles Await Scarlet Knights
description: The Rutgers players streamed through the tunnel onto the field and posed for pictures while clad in new uniforms, their pants still a glowing white.

title: Group Honors Actors and TV Shows
description: The third annual Family Television Awards were presented last week by a coalition of advertisers interested in stimulating the production of prime-time television shows intended to appeal to broader multigenerational audiences.

title: Shares Fall After Worrisome Report From Federal Reserve
description: Stocks fell sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve said the economy stayed sluggish in June and July as the recent slide in manufacturing began to infect other sectors.

title: Diet and Exercise Are Found To Cut Diabetes by Over Half
description: Offering hope that a rapid rise in diabetes in the United States can be reversed, a large clinical study has found that even modest lifestyle changes -- eating less fat, exercising two and a half hours a week and losing a moderate amount of weight -- cut the incidence of the disease by more than half among those most at risk.

title: Bomb Attack in Jerusalem Kills at Least 14
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 9 - A Palestinian suicide bomber took the Middle East conflict to the core of downtown Jerusalem today when he blew himself up in a crowded, family-oriented Israeli restaurant, killing at least 14 people, among them 6 children, and wounding about 130 others.

title: ULSTER ASSEMBLY FACES SHUTDOWN
description: Hopes of a breakthrough in the stalemated Northern Ireland peace negotiations faded today, and Britain faced the likelihood of shutting down the power-sharing Northern Ireland government this weekend to preserve it beyond then.

title: Bush Approves Limited Stem Cell Test Funding
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 9  Addressing the nation for the first time since his inauguration, President Bush said tonight that he would allow federal taxpayer money to be used for research into stem cells from human embryos, but he said the research would be limited to cells that have already been extracted and that the government would not support the destruction of new embryos.

title: Hicks Muse Partner Quits Rather Than Move to Dallas
description: A partner in Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, Michael J. Levitt, who led more than $500 million in losing telecommunications investments, has resigned, the firm said in a letter to its clients.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a rift in the Cuban American National Foundation misstated the number of years since its founding. While many of its leaders have opposed Fidel Castro for 40 years, the group itself was formed 20 years ago.

title: Agency Agrees to Hearing On Pipeline Complaints
description: Responding to concerns raised by politicians, environmentalists and residents, the federal commission reviewing the longest proposed interstate pipeline in the country said today that it would soon conduct a hearing to consider the complaints.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Appeal For Death-Row Inmate
description: Lawyers for Ernest P. McCarver, a death-row inmate, said they would continue to ask the Supreme Court to hear his case to decide the question of whether executing a mentally retarded person is unconstitutional. Mr. McCarver's I.Q. is 67, his lawyers say, and on Saturday, Gov. Michael F. Easley of North Carolina signed a bill banning the execution of the mentally retarded, those with I.Q.'s less than 70. On Monday, North Carolina asked the Supreme Court to dismiss the appeal. They plan to challenge the assertion that Mr. McCarver is mentally retarded. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: TALKING POLITICS: Bushwick and Williamsburg; In a Poor Hispanic District, Housing Is Voters' Priority
description: In just under a decade, Rafael and Milagros Hernndez have found in New York City many of the everyday comforts that eluded them back home in the Dominican Republic: clean water, reliable electricity, steady jobs and, in the last few years, safer streets for their children.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Woman Accused In Demolition
description: A woman was charged yesterday with filing forged papers that led to the demolition of a Staten Island cottage where Dorothy Day, left, the advocate for the poor, once lived. The woman, Flory Henao, 38, worked at the time of the demolition for John DiScala, the developer who owned the site. She was accused by Staten Island prosecutors of filing a forged demolition permit with the City Department of Buildings that led to the destruction in February of Ms. Day's cottage at Spanish Camp. Mr. DiScala was not charged. The Landmarks Preservation Commission was about to grant the cottage protected status. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Polo Ralph Lauren Net Up
description: Polo Ralph Lauren said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter profit rose 30 percent as it cut costs and sold more women's clothing. Profit rose to $31.1 million, or 32 cents a share, from $24 million, or 25 cents, a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter rose 6.3 percent, to $517.8 million from $487.3 million. Sales of the Black Label women's line rose 60 percent in the quarter, the company said. Polo Ralph Lauren, which is based in New York, has been sending direct mail booklets, setting up shops inside department stores and increasing advertising spending as it expands sales of luxury clothes and accessories. Its shares rose $1.95, or 8.4 percent, to $25.10. Luxury items make up about 50 percent of the products at the company's own full-priced stores, a 25 percent increase from a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMPSON, ELIZABETH
description: SAMPSON-Elizabeth. Died suddenly at home, June 21, 2001, at age 57. A graduate of Barnard College, Columbia University. A memorial service at St. Paul the Apostle Church, 415 West 59th Street, on Saturday, August 11, at 11:30 AM. Donations in her memory to the library of your choice-or buy a book and pass it on.

title: Before the Big Bang; The Space Age Game That Set the Stage
description: UNLIKE the first television set or the first computer, the first coin-operated video arcade game, Computer Space, looks like something that should be in a museum. An art museum, that is.

title: A Man, a Plan, a Manuscript
Achieving a High-Tech Look With Trusty Ceramic Tile
description: Ceramic tiles with a faintly cracked metallic finish look high tech yet handmade. They come from Paris Ceramics, whose designers chose bronze and pewter finishes as a way to do something radical with an old-fashioned product. The five-inch-square tiles could hold their own in a stainless steel kitchen or in more subdued surroundings (in a checkerboard pattern on a plain or matte-finish wall or used as a backsplash). $15.30 a tile from Paris Ceramics, 150 East 58th Street (Lexington Avenue), seventh floor, or (888) 845-3487. DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: Illinois Governor, Unpopular in Polls, Won't Run Again
description: Gov. George Ryan said today that he would not seek the Republican nomination for governor next year, ending months of speculation about his candidacy, which remained a mystery up until the final minutes before his announcement.

title: Study Offers Hope On Type 2 Diabetes
description: With the rate of Type 2, or adult, diabetes soaring, a large clinical study has found that even modest lifestyle changes -- eating less fat, exercising two and half hours a week and losing a moderate amount of weight -- cut the incidence of the disease by more than half among those most at risk. Sixteen million Americans have Type 2 diabetes, the most common form of the illness.

title: A Caddy That Gives Tips Instead of Accepting Them
description: A new mini-computer is bringing technology to the kind of hacker who wears plaid pants and yells ''Fore!''

title: I.R.A. Agrees to Dump Arsenal, but Deadlock Remains
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 9 — For the first time in Northern Ireland's current stalemate, the Irish Republican Army offered publicly today to put its arsenal of explosives, rifles and mortars "completely and verifiably beyond use".

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Monday about the wireless terminals that are being installed in New York livery cabs cited some new features erroneously. While the terminals will process credit cards, they will not be equipped with 911 buttons or global positioning devices.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, ANNE
description: FEINBERG-Anne. On August 7, 2001 at age 98. Beloved wife of the late William Feinberg. Loving sister of the late Jack, Louis and Rose. Cherished aunt and sister-inlaw. Services Sunday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

description: NORTHWEST

title: U.S. SAYS IT BROKE RING THAT PEDDLED CHILD PORNOGRAPHY
description: Federal authorities today announced the results of a two-year investigation into a child pornography ring that produced the arrests of 100 people and dismantled what they described as a global Internet-based sales operation.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Forecast Cut
description: The Bank of England, which lowered interest rates unexpectedly last week, cut its forecast for British economic growth, saying expansion would slow this year to 2 percent instead of the 2.5 percent estimated three months ago. It also said inflation would dip to around 2 percent early next year before rising to, but not exceeding, 2.5 percent, the bank's target. Economists said the forecasts gave the bank leeway for a further cut in the benchmark interest rate, currently at 5 percent after four cuts this year. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: A Bed Fit for a Queen (And Her Hairy Dog)
description: MY husband begged me not to describe the troubling tableau formed by our tattered, bleached-out, mismatched bed linens. He argued that the world did not need to know that the mattress pad's torn elastic edging droops like a bra strap from a housedress. Or that on top of all this sleeps the brown dog. Who sheds.

title: Mexican Truck Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Life After Karaoke; Presidents as Pitchmen, and Posthumous Play-by-Play
description: THE breakthrough in synthesized-speech software announced by AT&T Labs marks the end of an era. Time was when you dictated ''Good morning'' to voice recognition software, it wrote ''Marshplingfork.'' But times have changed. The simulator of the future has arrived. The future just hasn't arrived yet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, ABRAHAM
description: GOLDSTEIN-Abraham. Loving husband of the late Ceil. Devoted father of Gerald and the late Michael Goldstein. Adoring grandfather of Mark, Deborah, Darren and Jonathan, cherished father-inlaw of Jane and Ellen. Beloved neighbor and friend. Services Thursday at noon at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Stampede to Cloning
description: With all the hoopla over advances in genetics and reproductive technologies in recent months, it was only a matter of time until some headline-seeking scientist would try to create a human baby through controversial cloning procedures. Even so, the assertions this week by three separate scientists that they would soon try to clone a human embryo and implant it in a woman are appalling.

description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Leader to Challenge Bush Today on Missile Defense
description: Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, plans to continue his challenge to President Bush on missile defense by accusing the president of taking a ''single-minded approach'' to national security, according to an advance text of a speech Mr. Daschle is to deliver on Thursday.

title: In Jiang's Words: 'I Hope the Western World Can Understand China Better'
description: Following are excerpts of an interview with Jiang Zemin, the president and Communist Party leader of China, conducted by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., the publisher of The New York Times; Joseph Lelyveld, the executive editor of the newspaper; Howell Raines, Mr. Lelyveld's designated successor when he retires in September; Thomas L. Friedman, foreign affairs columnist of The Times; Erik Eckholm, Beijing bureau chief of The Times; and correspondents Elisabeth Rosenthal, based in Beijing, Craig S. Smith, based in Shanghai, and Mark Landler, based in Hong Kong. The interview was conducted in the resort town of Beidaihe, China, on Wednesday. President Jiang spoke in Chinese and his remarks were translated by a translator provided by the Chinese government.

title: How Is Libel Different in Cyberspace?
description: There's an old legal adage that "talebearers are as bad as talemakers."

title: Inquiry Into Reports of F.B.I. Retaliation
description: The inspector general of the Justice Department is investigating whether senior F.B.I. officials retaliated against agents who criticized the bureau's handling of the 1992 standoff at Ruby Ridge, Idaho, officials said tonight.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Token Booth Lawsuit
description: A coalition of more than 100 community groups, unions and advocacy organizations plans to file a lawsuit today in State Supreme Court in Manhattan asking that New York City Transit be stopped from closing token booths at 53 stations across the city until public hearings can be held. Transit officials want to close the booths and reassign their clerks to save money. But the Transport Workers Union, Local 100, which represents the city's 3,500 token booth clerks, say booth closings would mean fewer eyes and ears to deter crime and help riders. Randy Kennedy (NYT)

title: Student Freed From Russian Jail Is Back in the U.S.A.
description: John E. Tobin Jr., the American Fulbright scholar who was accused of being a spy and jailed in Russia for six months on charges of marijuana possession, returned to the United States yesterday accompanied by his father, John E. Tobin Sr., and Representative James H. Maloney of Connecticut, who had lobbied tirelessly for his release.

title: La Vida Loca? In a Plaza in Madrid
description: It was 10:30 p.m. on a recent Friday and the Plaza de San Ildefonso was packed with a young party crowd.

title: Recreating a Japanese Art With a Few Deft Clicks
description: The Japanese art of black ink painting requires infinite patience; one wrong brush stroke can ruin hours of painstaking work. A Japanese researcher is trying to make things a little easier for practitioners of the art -- known as sumi -- by simulating it on a computer.

title: A Chip That Mimics a Retina but Strains for Light
description: LAST week in Illinois, three patients with severe retinal disease had an unusual operation: tiny silicon chips were implanted in their eyes.

title: A Longer Shortcut to School; More Lessons for Teachers Arriving From Other Careers
description: They skimmed the education theories of John Dewey and Jean Piaget, dabbled in lesson planning and sketched out ideas for setting up their classrooms. They soaked up buzzwords like ''constructivist'' and ''metacognition.'' And between lectures on child development and learning styles, the soon-to-be-teachers crammed their notebooks with handy tips: Play relaxing music after lunch, when the students are usually wound up. Stockpile pencils, but give them out sparingly. Practice a menacing gaze in front of your bathroom mirror. Don't crack a smile until October.

title: My Favorite Explorer Shortcuts
description: In last weeks column, I shared a few fundamental Microsoft Word tricks that Id been surprised to find a lot of people didnt know, such as Control-clicking anywhere inside a sentence (just once, not twice) to neatly highlight it without having to drag. (On the Mac, substitute the Command key.)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Microsoft's decision to appeal its antitrust case to the Supreme Court misstated the timing of conversations held by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of Federal District Court with reporters. They began in September 1999, after the trial and before Judge Jackson issued his findings of fact and conclusions of law; they did not start at the outset of the case.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper dropped after a report showed weakening demand in China, the second-largest user of the metal. In New York, copper for September delivery fell 0.75 cent, or 1.1 percent, to 66.15 cents a pound.

title: Sports of The Times; Footsteps For a Rookie To Follow
description: HERMAN EDWARDS hadn't gone long into his news media briefing yesterday morning when someone asked about the progress of LaMont Jordan, the hard-running rookie from Maryland.

title: Consumer Product Safety Chief Sets Deadline to Resign
description: Ann Brown, chairwoman of the Consumer Product Safety Commission, said today that she would resign from the panel, which protects buyers from faulty products, no later than Nov. 1, reigniting the battle over who should replace her.

title: Q&A / Jacques Rogge : Olympics Chief Aims to Cure Sport's 'Diseases'
description: EDMONTON, Alberta  As Jacques Rogge talks, he draws on a small piece of paper: tiny geometrical designs, one by one, for this aficionado of cubist painting and geometrical art. A narrow rectangle here; a chunky triangle there, with occasional pauses when the conversation flows to an Olympic issue that is more complex than most.

title: The Endless Summer of an Indoor Bower
description: NOW that toile de Jouy appears on everything from eyeglass cases to club chairs, why not be different and move on to botanicals, patterns that are guaranteed to keep summer going. Ikea is offering a blossom-strewn duvet and pillow sham set. But finely drawn flowers don't appear only on fabric. They have sprouted on wallpapers, carpets and inside picture frames.

title: Santa Fe Savings
description: Gasoline prices have come down in the last several weeks, but that's no reason not to take advantage of an offer from the Fort Marcy Hotel Suites in Santa Fe. Any guest visiting through Sept. 30, whether they are driving or not, will have $40 deducted from their bill at checkout (based on 20 gallons of gasoline at $2 a gallon) at checkout. A two-night minimum stay is required, between Sunday and Thursday. The hotel has one-, two- and three-bedroom suites, four blocks from Santa Fe's historic Plaza. Information: (800) 745-9910 or www.fortmarcy.com .

title: SCHERING WINS APPROVAL FOR HEPATITIS TREATMENT
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation, the maker of the top hepatitis C treatment, has won approval for a more effective treatment that combines an extended-release form of the drug with an older medicine from ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc. Schering-Plough's Peg-Intron becomes more potent against hepatitis when ICN's Rebetol is added. There is no cure for hepatitis C, which can cause fatal liver damage. The approval of the treatment, in which an injection of Peg-Intron and a Rebetol capsule can be given together, means Schering-Plough will be able to promote it to doctors in a market that analysts estimate may be worth $2 billion a year.

title: Taking a Global Spin
description: ''Look in any lawyer's office,'' said Anatoli Lapushner, ''and you will probably see a globe. The more successful the lawyer, the bigger the globe.'' Antique-globe dealers like George Glazer and Christie's auction house go to Mr. Lapushner for restorations. After training in the former Soviet Union as an artist, Mr. Lapushner spent 15 years in this country doing upholstery and antique furniture refinishing before he happened on his first globe. Ten years ago, a collector needed a wooden globe stand repaired, and Mr. Lapushner repainted, cleaned and revarnished the globe as well. An additional business was born. The price is variable, from $100 to $2,500, depending on the type of repair. Anatoli's Restoration is at 555 Eighth Avenue (38th Street), (212) 629-0071.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUCKER, SYLVIA J.
description: ZUCKER-Sylvia J. August 7, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harry. Loving mother of Theodore and Elliot. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Deborah, Kevin and Hartlee. Devoted sister of Frances Strauss and the late Irene Rogen. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Friday, August 10, 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: S. Leslie Misrock -- Lawyer, 73
description: S. Leslie Misrock, a New York patent lawyer who was an authority on biotechnology patent law, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 73 and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: Boot Camps Proponent Becomes Focus of Critics
description: Distraught over her 17-year-old son's rebellious attitude and drug use, Rebecca Humble, a single mother from San Diego, began looking for an outdoor therapy program for him. Finding a magazine advertisement for the Pacific Coast Academy, she called and reached the marketing consultant, ''Stephen Michaels.''

title: Data's Validity Is Faulted In Net Registration System
description: The introduction of Internet addresses ending with the new ''.info'' extension has come under attack for an advance registration period that critics say allowed some individuals fraudulently to register the new addresses.

title: R. R. DONNELLEY MERGES 4 UNITS AND NAMES A PRESIDENT
description: R. R. Donnelley & Sons, which had an 89 percent drop in second-quarter profit as demand for printing magazines and catalogs declined, has consolidated four publishing businesses and named Ronald Daly as unit president. The company, based in Chicago, combined its telecommunications, commercial print, book and magazine publishing services, the company said. Mr. Daly, president of the telecommunications unit since 1995, will head the new business, R. R. Donnelley Print Solutions, the company said. The unit will have about 20,000 employees, or two-thirds of the company's work force.

title: 2 Mayoral Candidates Focus on Health Care and Another Worries About the Economy
description: Mark Green and Peter F. Vallone turned their attention to health care issues yesterday, with speeches that outlined their plans to enroll more New Yorkers, particularly children, in health care programs. In a speech to health-care-policy experts at the Robert F. Wagner School of Public Service, Mr. Green addressed four areas -- the uninsured, children's health, medical research and the troubled public hospital system.

title: Decency, Money And New York Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Paterno Is Looking Ahead
description: Joe Paterno seemed jaunty, as he often does. His quips came quickly, along with smiles and animated body language. This is a veteran coach who quotes Winston Churchill to explain the football life and who relaxes at home by listening to Verdi's ''Requiem.'' Even a losing season, the worst of his long career, could not shake his confidence, at least not in public.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Debt Default
description: Marking the beginning of what may be a string of defaults by revenue-squeezed local companies, the Argentine bread maker Alimentos Fargo missed a $1.5 million loan payment to Deutsche Bank. The company is renegotiating the terms of the $30 million loan. Fargo, which is owned by a local holding company, the Exxel Group, has had to reduce prices by about 10 percent the last two years as a protracted recession has cut deeply into sales. Local banks, fearing the country may default on its debt obligations, have frozen most new lending. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Record Labels Move To Short-Circuit Trial
description: The major record labels have asked a federal judge to issue a summary judgment in their copyright case against Napster, according to court papers made public yesterday. The brief was filed on Tuesday with Federal District Judge Marilyn Patel. Last month, Judge Patel ordered Napster to shut down until it could prove it was more effectively preventing the exchange of such files. An appeals court stayed the order, but Napster has remained offline. Sources close to the case said record labels' request for a summary judgment was essentially a procedural maneuver that was not a surprise. Judge Patel has not set dates for argument on the summary request or for the trial. Napster officials had no comment on the summary judgment request. But in their own papers, filed on Tuesday, they asked the appeals court to force Judge Patel to modify an injunction she issued in March that ordered Napster to prevent the exchange of copyright files. Napster said the order was overly broad. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, H. ROBERT
description: KRAUS-H. Robert, 76 of Kent, CT. Author, illustrator, publisher and cartoonist. Survived by his wife, Pamela (Evan Wong) Kraus, two sons, Bruce R. Kraus of New York, NY and C. William Kraus of Norwalk, CT and four grandchildren, Parker, Jack, Margaret and Vivienne. Funeral services Thursday, 2PM in the Kane Funeral Home, 41 Catoonah St., Ridgefield, CT. Burial to follow. Friends will be received at the Kane Funeral Home on Thursday after 1PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Art Students League of New York, 215 W. 57th St., NY, NY 10019.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: U.S. Bill Criticized
description: The government has criticized the United States Senate for passing a bill that would deny Zimbabwe debt relief and other financing until it meets certain conditions, including evicting black squatters from white-owned farms. Government officials, who have ignored eviction orders from the courts as they redistribute white-owned land to blacks, say the bill is racist. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUDOLPH, SELMA AND JACK
description: RUDOLPH-Selma and Jack Together for Eternity you shall remain. Thanks for touching my life. The Staff at 80th St. Residence Jack Rudolph walked toward the Path that grew dimmer and darker as each day passed. He grew Older with sadly no recollection to the previous years. He was held captive to this world, Stranded, with only darkness to Defeat his path, his discouragement enhanced by his fears, Trapped in a universe of illusions, His memories faded into black, He held no means of communication. He was left with no will or Way to find his way back, fate had Crippled him with Alzheimer's. A voice from the outside enters Into his world of solitude, a voice Somewhat familiar, beckoning, Calling his name, casting along his Path, the glory and warmth of Light, the voice gently guides him Towards this breathless sight, he Searches for words that he wants To say, tempting the strength of his Memory, his brilliant blue eyes Sparkle, igniting a vague recollection, no words need be spoken, She knows he knows, he has found The light, it is Selma, his high School sweetheart, his beautiful And determined wife, defeater of The toughest of battles, Cancer, a Marriage of 56 years filled with Love, devoted to Jack she Remained each and every day. The one value held dear that I Believe helped him carry on, was That his family chose to stay by his Side, they held together, they Stayed strong. His wife Selma, Their children, Pamela and Susan And their grandchildren, Rachel, Emily and Zack gave him all they Had. Selma's soft-spoken voice Magnificently lighting his path, While each daughter found their Own way to bring out similar Glimpses of an experience their Mom shared with their dad. To my friend Selma, Your love was tested, tried and by All means proven true, when the Journey ended here, you were Separated but for only hours of Few. I believe Jack was the light Waiting and calling for you. I bid You both A fond farewell. May God bless your journey as you Travel forth with each other, Together, as it was destined, I Know you shall remain. Choose not to remember them as They used to be. Choose not to Leave them alone to battle this Disease. This is what some relatives of Alzheimer's fail to see, to See them as they are now is what They need us to help them face

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANBY, JULIA MORRIS
description: GRANBY-Julia Morris. August 2, 2001, at New York City, NY. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin S. Granby; dear mother of Joseph R. and Sydney Morris of New York, NY; aunt of John M. and Rona Kahn of Framingham, MA; loving grandmother of Patricia Backer of Chicago, IL; cousin of Adele B. Gidwitz of Chicago, IL and Susan (Teiser) Giacomini of Kennett Square, PA; great aunt of Steven, Meredith, and Susan Kahn. She leaves her devoted friend and caregiver, Jean Goggins. A textile stylist in New York City, she worked for many years for CohnHall-Marx and later for Joshua Bailey, textile converters. She attended Washington University in St. Louis. Graveside services were held. In lieu of flowers, contributions appreciated to a charity of your choice or to Philadelphia University, formerly Philadelphia College of Textiles and Science, School House Lane & Henry Avenue, Philadelphia, PA. 19144.

title: Colombia Breaks Off Talks With Second Largest Rebel Force
description: President Andrs Pastrana broke off tense peace talks with the second-largest rebel force on Tuesday, and today guerrilla leaders harshly criticized the government for ''lack of will,'' while the Bush administration voiced support for the decision.

title: Relief for Rush Hour: Pay as You Go
description: TO avoid morning rush hour, Lim Chee Khoong gets into his BMW before 7, dropping his two children at school and making it downtown before 7:30. Kevin Chong waits until after 9:30 a.m.

title: Justice Hones His Swing as Yankees Hack Away
description: The starting lineup had been posted on the clubhouse wall for several minutes, but Paul O'Neill had not seen it, so he quizzed a reporter about it. O'Neill wondered if Tino Martinez was playing against the left-hander Nick Bierbrodt. He was. O'Neill asked who was playing third base. It was Clay Bellinger. O'Neill figured that Shane Spencer was in right field as his replacement, and he was right.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a front-page headline in Business Day yesterday about software used by companies to educate workers about policies against sexual harassment and discrimination failed to reproduce in some copies. It should have read: ''New Guards to Lessen Liability. Software Trains Workers to Avoid Improper Behavior.''

title: Nortel Networks Plans to Sell $1 Billion of Convertible Bonds
description: Nortel Networks, the communications equipment company, said yesterday that it expected to sell $1 billion of securities in a deal that underscores how large technology companies are increasingly seeking to raise money through unconventional techniques.

title: Special Teams Coach Is, Well, Special
description: The high punt turned over and then dropped suddenly, heading like a missile toward the Jets' beleaguered return team. The man in shorts snared it and tried to snake his way through a crowd of opponents. He ran a few yards -- and tripped over his own feet.

title: Irish Peace at a Crossroads
description: The chief protagonists in the Northern Ireland peace process are now so weary, petulant and frustrated with each other that the great prize they are working toward could slip through their fingers. Over the three years and four months since the signing of the Good Friday Agreement, the bare-knuckled unionist and republican fighters have slugged it out -- instead of building foundations for peace. They have now fought to a standstill, and in London and Dublin the equally weary umpires of this grudge match may at any moment call for time out.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Call For Harris To Resign
description: The Florida Democratic Party urged Secretary of State Katherine Harris to resign, after a review of the data on hard drives from computers in her office used during the presidential election recount in November. The examination, financed by several news groups, including The New York Times, showed that Ms. Harris's lawyers and aides used the machines to send and retrieve election-related e-mail messages, conduct legal research and prepare Ms. Harris for questions from reporters. Ms. Harris's lawyers had said the computers had been used solely to write news releases. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Beach Closings And Advisories Reach Record, Report Shows
description: A record number of pollution-related beach closings and swimming advisories were reported nationally last year, according to a report issued today by the Natural Resources Defense Council.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The dollar fell, undermined by falling United States stocks and a Federal Reserve survey showing stagnating growth. In New York, the euro settled at 88.08 cents, up from 87.74 cents on Tuesday.

title: Hooks, Naturally
description: Once again, inspiration strikes twice, this time in the form of branch-shaped, wall-mounted coat hooks. One variety is made of actual tree branches, below. The hooks are available in sets of three (6 to 7 inches high for $14.95 or 9 to 10 inches high for $18.95) from Ancient Graffiti, in Middlebury, Vt.; (888) 725-6632 or www.ancientgraffiti.com. The other, above, cast in pewter from the branch of a beech tree, is four and a half inches high and has an antique-brass finish. The company, a joint venture of AOL Time Warner and Venezuela's Cisneros Group, said it had lost $70.4 million, or 23 cents a share, compared with $46.7 million in last year's second quarter. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call were expecting a 28-cent loss. Although AOL Latin America quadrupled its revenue and added 238,000 new members in the quarter, sharply higher spending on sales and marketing hurt the company's bottom line. Shares fell 44 cents, to close at $5.34. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: A Facelift Recalls A Fin de Sicle Era
description: It was time to spruce up Jo Jo, above right, a French restaurant on East 64th Street, and the owner, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, handed the $1 million job of taking it back to a new future to Christophe Tollemer, 35, a designer from Provence all but unknown in the United States. Mr. Vongerichten, 44, had hired Mr. Tollemer to fix up a farmhouse in Mougins, France, where he has family. He wanted Jo Jo (his first restaurant, opened in 1991) to have ''a homey, neighborhood feel'' inspired by Parisian botes in the era of Zola and Proust. Mr. Tollemer, who likes neither minimalism nor computer renderings, made watercolor drawings of the two upstairs dining rooms (right, the front; above, the back) and a dining room downstairs. The look is reminiscent of Victorian club cars. Silk and velour furnishings have been ordered in contemporary shades of plum, lavender and green. The walls will be finished using an ancient tinted-plaster technique, and the terra-cotta floors will be courtesy of a 300-year-old teardown in southern France. ''I wanted something that would last,'' said Mr. Vongerichten, whose restaurant holdings have spread from Manhattan to Chicago, London, Hong Kong and the Bahamas. Customers may need to pack reading glasses for Jo Jo, which will seat 90: much of the lighting will come from reproduction 19th-century candle sconces. The ''closed'' sign comes down after Labor Day: 160 East 64th Street; (212) 223-5656.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Ratings Lowered
description: Standard & Poor's downgraded its rating outlook on seven Indian companies to negative after it also cut its rating on India's credit to negative from stable because of the country's rising budget deficit and rising domestic debt. The lowered rating may lead to a rise in the cost of borrowing for Indian companies, particularly in infrastructure projects, and may hurt investor sentiment. S.& P. said the credibility of India's privatization process was at risk as the government has divested itself of its stakes in only 2 of the 240 state-run companies.

title: A Time Capsule Returns: The Sound of Black Rock

On a deeper level the Black Rock Coalition wanted to kick-start a grass-roots network that would sustain small bands as the largely white independent rock scene of the 1980's did.

Both remain executive vice presidents at Burnett USA, part of the Leo Burnett Worldwide unit of the Bcom3 Group, where they will continue to oversee the Altoids and Maytag accounts.

title: Shortcuts Cut Down On Point-and-Click
description: Q. Why are some letters in Windows dialogue boxes underlined? I assume this is significant.

title: The Desktop That Does Elvis
description: JUERGEN SCHROETER, an expert in speech synthesis at AT&T Labs, has a vision of the future.

title: Human Toll of Layoffs
description: To the Editor:

title: Anticholesterol Drug Pulled After Link With 31 Deaths
description: Bayer A.G., the German pharmaceutical and chemical conglomerate, voluntarily withdrew Baycol, its highly profitable cholesterol-lowering drug, from the world market yesterday. Thirty-one patients have died while taking it, the company reported, because the drug caused an unusual condition in which muscle tissue broke down.

title: If Talk Is Cheap, So Is 911
description: Re ''Talk Is Cheap. But Is It Disposable?'' (Aug. 2): The marketing plans for the new ''disposable'' phones betray the short memories of corporate marketers in this country, who have seemingly forgotten the hard lessons of the single-use camera. After Kodak's Fling was introduced in 1987, the company faced protests over the amount of waste that would be created. Kodak, which was marketing the Fling as a throwaway, responded by saying that it would take the cameras back.

title: Landscape Long on Gangs But Short on Fathers
description: EDGEWATER ANGELS

title: . . .  Or Have Your Photo and Eat It, Too
description: AT Jim Litwitz's 80th-birthday party here, his son John recounted how a bakery once put ''Happy Birthday Bruce'' on his father's cake. Technology, John announced, had made such errors a thing of the past -- and with that the family rolled out a cake from a nearby Wegmans supermarket imprinted with a full color photo of the elder Mr. Litwitz, a retired Kodak executive.

title: Dressing Up The Closest
description: DOZENS of my New York friends and clients have had the same recurring dream: they open the closet door and see a whole other room, one they never knew was there. It is the ultimate New York windfall. Inevitably, by the light of day, the closet remains as they remembered it: crammed full of tattered shoe boxes and forgotten sweaters.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Representative To Run Again
description: Representative George Nethercutt, a Republican, said he would run for a fifth term next year. In 1994, Mr. Nethercutt ousted Tom Foley, a Democrat who was then the speaker of the House, in part on a platform of serving no more than six years. Mr. Nethercutt easily won a fourth term last year, overcoming advertisements criticizing him for breaking his pledge. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: More Is More (Mostly): From Cable to Satellite TV
description: BY now every American awake and functioning must be aware of the proliferation of satellite television services. The subscriber base for the satellite TV industry is now more than 16 million, about one-fourth that of cable (70 million), and it expanded by 18 percent last year alone. Headlines tracked plans by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which operates satellite services in Europe, Latin America and parts of Asia, to crack the Chinese and American markets. Now they chronicle the offer made by EchoStar's Dish Network to buy the dominant United States supplier, Hughes Electronics' DirecTV, which is owned by General Motors.

title: Analyzing Arafat: Many Lenses
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Daimlerchrysler To Offer At&t Wireless
description: DaimlerChrysler reached an agreement with AT&T Wireless yesterday to widen the offering of wireless communications services in its vehicles sold in North America. The deal calls for AT&T Wireless to develop voice and data communication services for Chrysler, Mercedes-Benz and Freightliner vehicles. DaimlerChrysler, like other car manufacturers, is seeking to increase the sophistication of wireless services in its vehicles. Terms of the agreement with AT&T Wireless were not disclosed. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: White Township: Two Prisoners Missing
description: Two inmates at the Warren County Correctional Center are missing and presumed escaped, officials said yesterday. The inmates -- Scott A. Hornic, 29, serving a sentence for parole violation, and John F. Struble, 37, imprisoned for theft and burglary -- were missing at a head count Monday afternoon. They may have escaped through a ceiling hatch, officials said.

title: ONLINE DIARY
description: Mining Ellis Island

title: Museum Raiders
description: THERE she was again. Lara Croft, the virtual character who has conquered the video game world, has appeared on magazine covers and has even been portrayed on film by Angelina Jolie, was up there on a big screen at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. But this film loop showed her dying as she was pierced by arrows -- and then dying, and dying again, endlessly.

title: Planners Try to Close Loopholes In Adult Entertainment Law
description: The City Planning Commission yesterday approved amendments to the 1995 zoning regulations governing so-called adult establishments, in a move intended to close what city officials have characterized as unintended loopholes in the law.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page picture caption yesterday with an article about Colombian ranchers who donated money to paramilitary forces referred incompletely to one rancher, Sergio Ochoa. He said he had come close to abandoning his ranch in the town of Montería because of leftist guerrillas' activity there, but decided to stay after the paramilitary fighters drove them off. He was not one of the ranchers who hired the paramilitary troops.

title: Aspen Festival Names Its Chief
description: The Aspen Music Festival and School has appointed Don Roth its president and chief executive. He succeeds Robert J. Harth, who was chosen in March to become the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall after 12 years at Aspen.

title: Wells, to Be Available Soon, Pays His Old Team a Visit
description: The wooing process has unofficially started between David Wells and the Yankees, with Wells taking the first subtle step. Wells, who will be without a team once the Chicago White Sox decline his $10 million option for next season, said he was shopping for a car nearby and needed Jorge Posada's autograph on a piece of memorabilia, so he decided to visit the Yankees at Tropicana Field today. Wink, wink.

title: 21 Apartment-List Firms Are Charged With Fraud
description: Angel Alicea lived in Queens but wanted to live closer to his job in Brooklyn. Seeking a one-bedroom apartment for up to $450 a month, he went to an apartment-listing company and paid $185 to be a ''member for six months,'' he said yesterday.

title: Letting the Golden State See Where the Grass Is Greener
description: For those whose Golden Dream of California has turned to nightmare, the Internet offers some help. At leavingcal.com, Randy Lee of Hayward, Calif., cites the reasons he is planning to move: choking traffic, inflated property prices, high taxes, pollution, increased energy bills, unbridled growth and ''to top it all off -- rolling blackouts.'' Not to mention, of course, the perennial possibility of drought.

title: In America; Let's Clear the Air
description: Take a deep breath.

title: Zoo Intruder Barges In, But Gorillas Go to Lunch
description: A man with a history of mental illness leapt into the gorilla enclosure at the Bronx Zoo yesterday, saying he wanted to ''be one with the monkeys.''

title: Corrections
description: An Arts Abroad article yesterday about the annual music festival in Verbier, Switzerland, misstated the given name of a horn player from Alaska who participated. He is Theodore Primis, not Thomas.

title: A Scholarship and a Crisis
description: The Palestinian uprising that erupted last fall put an abrupt end to Bill Clinton's efforts to secure a foreign policy legacy -- a lasting peace in the Middle East. Almost one year later, scores of Israelis and hundreds of Palestinians have been killed, with thousands wounded.

title: Argentine Protests on Austerity Ebb, and Stocks Rise
description: A nationwide wave of protests by unemployed workers and students against the government's austerity plans appeared to lose strength today. Demonstrations ebbed in much of the country, giving the financially pressed government and the investment markets a badly needed lift.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Aid Distribution System Criticized
description: Low-income New Yorkers retrieving food stamps and welfare benefits have had to pay a substantial amount in additional fees, according to an audit released yesterday by the state comptroller's office. The fees come in the form of surcharges at Citicorp automated teller machines. The fees average about $2 per transaction, but in just two months, welfare recipients paid more than $1.3 million in such fees. Citicorp administers the new electronic benefits system. But a spokesman for the state welfare agency said that it had already told recipients where surcharge-free A.T.M.'s are. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Aircraft Purchase
description: The Brazilian Air Force has announced it will buy 76 Super Tucano turboprop light attack airplanes from Embraer, a Brazilian company that is the world's fourth-largest commercial aircraft manufacturer. The purchase, part of a $3.35 billion modernization effort aimed at increasing the Air Force's ability to patrol the Amazon, comes a week after Brazil solicited bids on a $700-million contract for 24 jet fighter planes. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: A Site Whose Riches Bob on the Surface
description: THE white patchwork that greets visitors to ''HistoryWired,'' a new museum exhibition on the Web, might be likened to an aerial view of cornfields after a winter snow. But this is not Kansas. Instead, each of the grid's blank rectangles provides access to one of the 450 items in the virtual exhibition, including the scarecrow's costume from ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: How Do You Get to Carnegie Hall?
description: With his tan fedora set atop a headful of dark curls and a wine-colored velvet corduroy blazer worn over a T-shirt, Justin Kantor resembles a roving troubador with a cello. ''I just love music,'' he said, shrugging. ''I want to play whatever comes my way.'' A year away from completing a bachelor's degree at the Manhattan School of Music, he can perhaps afford to be dreamy. But one afternoon in May, after a four-hour practice session, Mr. Kantor looked in on the job-networking fair in the school cafeteria.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Arrest Powers
description: India's central government has granted sweeping arrest and interrogation powers to security forces in four Hindu-dominated districts of the state of Jammu and Kashmir. The move comes after two recent massacres of civilians. Anti-India militants are suspected in the deaths. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FROUD, HOLLY WEBB
description: FROUD-Holly Webb. On August 3, 2001. Loving mother of Holly Anne Havemeyer Barany, Peter David Auchinleck Darling, Michael James Auchinleck Darling and Sean Patrick Talbot Darling. Also survived by brother, Samuel B. Webb, Jr., son-in-law, Mike Barany; daughters-in-law Silvia Darling and Mary Darling; and six grandchildren. Memorial services at Trinity Episcopal Church, Shelburne, VT on August 14, 2001 at 11:00 A.M. Flowers may be sent. Bright colors to be worn please. Shelburne Funeral Chapel, 209 Falls Road, Shelburne, VT 05482.

title: World of Debating Grows, and Vermont Is Its Lab
description: Darong Kwon came to the University of Vermont this summer to learn how to speak. There is nothing wrong with Ms. Kwon's voice: she has been talking since she was a toddler, and picked up English as a child when her family lived in Australia. Now 19, she traveled 6,642 miles from her home in Seoul to the World Debate Institute here to learn how to speak up, speak out, speak her mind.

title: Singing of Loners but Playing to the Crowd
description: When Thom Yorke of Radiohead picked up his acoustic guitar and started to strum the oblique love song ''Fake Plastic Trees'' on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, a few fans held blazing cigarette lighters aloft. It was the venerable arena-rock ritual for a beloved ballad, yet only a handful of flames twinkled in the darkness. The rest of the audience may have decided that Radiohead is so artistic it would think the gesture was corny. But then Mr. Yorke cued the audience to clap along, and the houselights came up to encourage a sing-along. It seemed the band expected an old-fashioned arena-rock moment, with or without misgivings.

title: Stowaway Fell From Jet Near Airport, Police Say
description: The body landed hard in a dusty parking lot here between a condominium complex and a busy lobster farm.

title: A Mouse With No Tail And an Urge to Fly
description: Though the computer mouse has seen a fair amount of innovation in recent years, the basic notion of it as a block of plastic that slides around the desk hasn't changed much, until now. A new cordless mouse called the GyroMouse Pro can be waved around the room and lose none of its pointing power. Available for $99 from Gyration (www.gyration.com), the unit has built-in solid state gyroscopes that automatically track hand movement to guide the cursor. (A version for presentations, the GyroMouse Presenter, has a range of 100 feet, includes presentation software and costs $189.) The GyroMouse Pro may be the digital era's magic wand, but it will probably just aggravate the question of what to do with all those unused mouse pads.

title: Payton's Problem Is Trying Too Hard
description: Jay Payton tweaked his swing on Saturday. By holding back he was able to neutralize the slider that has plagued him so much this season. That alteration is another in a long list of changes Payton constantly makes. Payton may be the hardest working Met, based on man hours in batting cages and swinging at soft tosses. That may be part of Payton's problem, Manager Bobby Valentine said.

title: Bomb Attack in Jerusalem Kills at Least 14
description: JERUSALEM, Friday, Aug. 10 - A Palestinian suicide bomber took the Middle East conflict to the core of downtown Jerusalem on Thursday when he blew himself up in a crowded Israeli restaurant, killing at least 14 people besides himself, among them 6 children, and wounding about 130 others.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Sets Pact With Hitachi
description: Sun Microsystems announced a wide-ranging partnership yesterday with Hitachi to market and jointly develop big computer storage systems for corporate customers. For Sun, the deal is a step in its strategy to ''reinvent ourselves'' as a supplier not only of computers, but also software, storage and services, according to Ed Zander, left, the president and chief operating officer. ''We're rapidly becoming a full-service company,'' he said. The market leader in storage systems is the EMC Corporation. Sun's move is mainly an effort to round out the portfolio of computing offerings the company can sell to corporate customers as a package -- an approach that has proved to be quite successful for another Sun rival, I.B.M. ''It's an I.B.M. play as much as an EMC play,'' Mr. Zander said. Until now, Sun did not have a storage system to sell with its largest data-serving computers. ''This finally puts Sun in a position to compete at the high end,'' said John McArthur, an analyst for the International Data Corporation. Steve Lohr (NYT)

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Re "Talk Is Cheap. But Is It Disposable?" (Aug. 2): Don't throw those cell phones away! You missed the chance to make it more widely known that the F.C.C. mandates that cell phones be able to connect to 911 as long as the phone is charged (even if one's service contract has expired and the phone is otherwise unusable).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAVINO, MARIANNA (NEE PATALANO)
description: FAVINO-Marianna (nee Patalano). Beloved wife of the late Taddeo. Loving mother of Antonio and Beatrice. Devoted grandmother of Theodore and Antonio, Jr. Adored great grandmother of Kristen Lea & Michael. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Thursday 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 9:45AM, St. Vincent Ferrar R.C. Church, 66 St and Lexington Ave. Interment Saint Andrew's Cemetery, Sag Harbor, New York.

title: School-Building Switch Rejoins What Was Split
description: The idea of taking the Board of Education out of the business of school construction first came to Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy some seven years ago when Ramon C. Cortines was chancellor and Mr. Levy headed a special panel on improving school maintenance.

title: Impaired Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Put Your Face in the Line of Fire. . . .
description: MOST people don't smile or make silly faces when they step into the photo booth in the GameStop software store in this town near Dallas. Instead they try to look as menacing as possible.

title: Online and in the Flesh, Black Writers Commune With Kindred Spirits
description: Brandon Massey listens intently as Steven Barnes explains a martial arts maneuver. Both men are writers, and each is absorbed in the conversation: Mr. Barnes, explaining the technique, and Mr. Massey, concentrating on the nuance. Mr. Barnes, 49, has clearly assumed the role of mentor in this conversation. For the last two decades he has worked in film, television, theater, radio and print, and he won an Emmy for his script for an episode of ''Outer Limits.''

title: A Foe of Copy Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: MetroStars Win Tournament Opener, but Who Would Know?
description: The MetroStars started Copa Merconorte, the first international tournament in their brief history, with success on the field and disappointment in the stands tonight at Giants Stadium.

title: Treasures Of a Collector With an Eye For Glass
description: Prost! The German design connoisseur Torsten Brhan's prize collection of Polish, Czech, German and Austrian glass will be at the Smithsonian's Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum beginning Aug. 21. The exhibition, ''Glass of the Avant-Garde: From Vienna Secession to Bauhaus,'' was donated by Mr. Brhan and is on loan from the Museo Nacional de Artes Decorativas in Madrid. ''The kinds of things I collected were undiscovered, so they were of no interest to the auction houses,'' Mr. Brhan said. The exhibition has examples from the Wiener Werksttte including Otto Prutscher's Champagne glass (1907) and Josef Hoffmann's vase (right, 1914) as well as Peter Behrens's unadorned goblets (above) from 1900. Deborah Sampson Shinn, one of the curators, said that while glass represented ideas, ''the impulse was to marry good design with industrial production,'' resulting in pieces that are still being made. The exhibition runs until Feb. 24 at the Cooper-Hewitt, 2 East 91st Street (Fifth and Madison), (212) 849-8400. A catalog by Mr. Brhan and Martin Eidelberg, another curator, is $65 in hardcover, $48 paperback. MELISSA FELDMAN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTCHEK, BEATRICE
description: ALTCHEK-Beatrice. On August 8, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel, adored mother of Edgar and Henry, dear mother-in-law of Leah and grandmother of Daniel and Ruth. Graveside services today 11 AM at Mt. Hebron Cemetery.

title: Martin Huston -- Stage and TV Actor, 60
description: Martin Huston, an actor who appeared onstage and on television, died of cancer on Aug. 1 in Manhattan. He was 60.

title: Meandering to California, With a World to Learn
description: A couple of guys head out, looking for life and liberty. Yeah, happiness, too. Not to mention beer. Along the way they meet quirky characters, some with vital lessons to teach. One of those characters neatly frames the whole journey by asking, ''How can you hope to discover anything if you don't take risks?''

title: Chip Sales Are Expected to Fall 26%
description: Semiconductor sales worldwide will fall 26 percent this year, more than previously expected, because demand for computers and cellular phones has not picked up, the market researcher Dataquest Inc. said today.

title: Replicating Controversy
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Schwikert Grows Into Role As Top American Woman
description: When Tasha Schwikert was born, she weighed four pounds and quickly dropped to three and a half, and when she got home she was so small that for three months the only clothes that fit her came from Cabbage Patch dolls. When she was 13 and a promising gymnast, she competed in a national championship with a broken right big toe and survived the pain to make the national junior team.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Bombs Outside Banks
description: Three small bombs exploded outside several Banamex bank branches in Mexico City late Wednesday night in an apparent protest against the sale of Mexico's most powerful financial institutions to foreign companies. The sales have angered taxpayers, who have paid billions of dollars in taxes to help bail out several Mexican banks, and some people have said the investments threaten national sovereignty. Mexican television reported that a group called the People's Revolutionary Armed Forces had taken responsibility for the explosions, which caused no injuries. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: College Guys in Heat Leap at a Cool Summer
description: This summer the American movie audience seems to be suffering from an affliction like the one that plagued the hero of ''Memento,'' condemned to live in an endlessly repeating present without benefit of short-term memory.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CORN RISES. Corn rose on expectations that already parched fields in the Midwest would deteriorate without more rain. In Chicago, corn for delivery in December rose 2 cents, or 0.9 percent, to $2.315 a bushel.

title: Dr. Josef H. Weissberg -- Psychoanalyst, 72
description: Dr. Josef H. Weissberg, a psychoanalyst and a former president of the American Academy of Psychoanalysis, died on Aug. 6 at Columbia-Presbyterian Center in New York. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PARKER, SIDNEY
description: PARKER-Sidney. With deep ethical standards and a Jewish heart, you were ''the real thing.'' Happy Birthday. Your loving family.

title: Arthur Segall, Tax Lawyer And Prosecutor, Dies at 95
description: Arthur A. Segall, a New York tax lawyer who early in his career spearheaded an assault in Mayor Fiorello La Guardia's war on the shadier aspects of New York City's night life, died Aug. 2 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 95 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Testing Limits of the Northeast Grid
description: The scalding weather pushed the Northeast's power grid perilously close to its limits yesterday, smashing records for electricity use and driving prices to record highs, as officials scrambled for ways to avoid overloading the system.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: U.S. To Pay Expenses
description: The United States government has decided to pay China about $34,500 in compensation for expenses incurred during the stand-off over a Navy surveillance plane that made an emergency landing on Hainan island, officials said. The United States rejected the figure of $1 million that the Chinese demanded for the care and feeding of 24 crew members detained for 11 days and for other expenses during the three months it held the damaged plane. Pentagon officials said the amount of the compensation was nonnegotiable. Thom Shanker (NYT)

title: The Funny Foreignness Of Hamburgers and Coke
description: The veteran film editor Eva Gardos (''Mask,'' 1985; ''Agnes Browne,'' 1999) has written and directed her first feature, ''An American Rhapsody,'' and like many first films, it seems tightly bound up with the filmmaker's personal experience.

title: Search Rules Stricter for New Jersey Troopers
description: By mid-September, New Jersey state troopers will be required to get a sergeant's approval before conducting a type of vehicle search that has been at the heart of the turmoil over racial profiling.

title: Debussy, a Composer Unlike Any Before or After Him
description: Here are some favorite Debussy recordings of the classical music critics of The New York Times. CD's range in price from $10 to $15 for one CD, $15 to $20 for a two-CD set and $30 to $40 for three- and four-CD collections. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: An Islam Much Forgotten
description: Outside my window, I hear the sirens of ambulances transporting the dozens of victims of the latest suicide bombing, offered for the glory of God and Islam. From the Palestinian village across the road comes the muezzin's call to prayer, which for some Jews has become a reminder of violence and murder. However tempting, I resist that linkage, because I've known a different Islam.

title: Currying Favor From Beyond
description: OUT of the blue in 1989, a call came to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery from a man who said he owned a collection of scroll paintings that would ''forever change American opinion of Chinese art.'' His name was Richard G. Pritzlaff. The paintings were ''ancestor portraits.'' He wanted to find a home for them at the Sackler, which is, with the adjoining Freer Gallery, the national museum of Asian art.

title: EXIDE LOWERS EARNINGS ESTIMATE AND TRIMS JOBS
description: Exide Technologies, a leading maker of automotive batteries, said yesterday that it would cut 1,300 jobs and that second-quarter and fiscal-year earnings would be lower than expected as orders from telecommunications customers declined. The cuts represent about 6.5 percent of the company's 20,000 workers worldwide, said a spokesman, Tim Yost. Almost all of the jobs will be eliminated by the year of the year, said Tom Smith, Exide's vice president for development. The company had already cut 1,800 jobs as of March and closed four factories and four distribution centers to reduce overcapacity. Earnings excluding charges will be 10 cents to 20 cents a share for the quarter ending Sept. 30, the company said. Exide is based in Princeton, N.J.

title: AT&T to Be Allowed to Sell Some of Its Cablevision Shares
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation agreed today to permit AT&T to sell as much as $1 billion of its stake.

title: Hans Rathsack, 59, Wsthof Knives Chief
description: Hans Richard Rathsack, whose personal cheerleading as head of Wsthof knives in the United States helped make them a popular brand among chefs and cooking enthusiasts, died on Sunday while sailing on Long Island Sound. He was 59 and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Execution Approaches in a Most Rare Murder Case
description: J. Michael Luttig, a member of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Virginia, is considered one of the most influential and conservative federal judges in the nation, a jurist thought to be on President Bush's short list for the Supreme Court. He also has the awful distinction of being one of the few federal judges in history to have a father who was murdered.

title: Holik Vows to Test Waters of Unrestricted Free Agency
description: Devils center Bobby Holik described the salary arbitration process as a great learning experience that every player should experience. Surprisingly, Holik made his remarks after he received less than what he was asking for.

title: Israeli Aides Vow to Hold On to Seized Palestinian Offices
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 -- As Israel draped itself in mourning for its latest terrorism victims, senior Israeli officials vowed today to keep control of important Palestinian offices that the army and the police had seized overnight.

title: Each Side Finds Something to Like, and Not
description: President Bush's proposal for carefully limited federal research on embryonic stem cells was greeted with relief tonight by many abortion opponents and other conservatives, who had feared a much broader federal effort.

description: A federal appeals court has overturned sanctions imposed against a New York lawyer accused of breaching a confidentiality order in class-action cases against the Cendant Corporation.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Turkey: Broadcast Ban
description: The Turkish government's broadcasting watchdog ordered Germany's Deutsche Welle and Britain's BBC to stop their Turkish-language radio broadcasts in the country. Serpil Erdemgil, a BBC World Turkish Section producer said, ''We cannot really understand the reasons for this ban and find it very sad.'' The chairman of the watchdog agency, Nuri Kayis, said he did not agree with the decision and would ask an Ankara court to overturn the move. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

description: WHEN the temperature hit 105 degrees yesterday afternoon inside the Fulton Street subway station, the only sign of rebellion was a discarded silk necktie lying on the platform. The people waiting for a train looked too weak to complain.
