title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bank Profit Falls
description: The German bank Commerzbank A.G. reported a decline of 87 percent in second-quarter profit because it failed to control costs and the consumer-banking unit lost money. Net income fell to 94 million euros ($83 million), from 731 million euros, or 1.43 euros a share, a year earlier. Shares of Commerzbank rose as much as 4.6 percent on speculation that the chief executive, Klaus-Peter Mller, above, may be willing to find a partner to revive profit. Mr. Mller also plans to increase cost cuts to reduce losses in retail banking and asset management.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Solectron Buying C-Mac For $2.7 Billion
description: C-MAC, a Montreal-based supplier of electronics manufacturing systems, said it had agreed to be acquired by Solectron of Milpitas, Calif., in a stock swap valued at $2.7 billion, including assumption of debt. The companies said the deal would allow them to offer a broader range of products and services, and to expand their customer bases. In particular, Solectron, best known for its printed circuit board assembly business, will gain access to the automotive electronics market. Under the agreement, C-MAC shareholders will receive 1.755 Solectron common shares for each C-MAC share. Solectron expects the merger to generate $60 million to $120 million in cost savings and extra revenue, and to contribute to earnings in the fiscal year ending Aug. 31, 2002. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RESNIKOFF, PHILIP
description: RESNIKOFF-Philip. January 4, 2001, age 90-1/2. Retired instructor in psychology CCNY and avid book collector, he was the quintessential uncle-savant who taught and entertained us all to the end. Unveiling Sunday, September 2, 9:30AM Wellwood Cemetery Long Island (Workmen's Circle section) followed by memorial service 1PM West Side Jewish Center, 34 St, Manhattan (8th & 9th Ave).

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: High-Speed Access Rising Rapidly
description: More than seven million homes and businesses had high-speed connections to the Internet by the end of last year, an increase of 63 percent in six months, the Federal Communications Commission said. The number of digital subscriber line, or D.S.L., connections, which use ordinary telephone lines, doubled over the second half of the year, to about two million, though they were still outnumbered by cable modems, with 3.6 million subscribers. Satellite and wireless connections made up a small percentage of the market; however, those lines also doubled at the end of the year to more than 100,000.

title: Violence Continues to Mount in Macedonia
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia, Aug. 10 -- Tensions mounted again today in Macedonia after seven soldiers were killed, and nine others were wounded, when their truck ran over two anti-tank mines only a few miles from the capital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHEMTOB, RAYMOND
description: CHEMTOB - Raymond. Loving husband of Camille. Devoted father of Allan, Roland and Raymond. Adoring grandfather of Gil, Jesse, Ariana, Jack, Oliver and Spencer. Cherished father-in-law of Marsha and Nancy. Beloved brother of Odette, Lola, Claude and the late Andre. Services Friday, 10:30AM, Parkside Funeral Home, 66th Ave at Queens Blvd., Rego Park, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RUBY
description: BROWN-Ruby. On August 9, 2001. Beloved wife of Wayne. Loving mother of Holly Weisman and Michael Brown. Cherished grandmother of five. Services today, 12:45 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Debussy, a Composer Unlike Any Before or After Him
description: Here are some favorite Debussy recordings of the classical music critics of The New York Times. CD's range in price from $10 to $15 for one CD, $15 to $20 for a two-CD set and $30 to $40 for three- and four-CD collections. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Testimony In Beating Trial
description: The outline of a shoe print left near an abandoned building where two Mexican day laborers were attacked in September matches the size and shape of a boot belonging to one of the men charged in the attack, a forensic scientist testified yesterday. The scientist, Donald Doller of the Suffolk County Crime Laboratory, said that only the outline of the shoe print could be distinguished. It was consistent, however, with the sole of a black lace-up boot belonging to Christopher Slavin, above, the first of two men charged in the attack to be prosecuted, Mr. Doller said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENHUT, FLORENCE
description: GREENHUT-Florence. Congregation Rodeph Sholom records with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Florence Greenhut, widow of the late Felix A. Greenhut, our trustee & honorary secretary for life. Our deepest sympathy is extended to all their dear ones. Robert N. Levine, Sr. Rabbi Mark Biderman, President

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Equipment Slump
description: Orders for new machinery declined 6.6 percent in June from the month before, as businesses scaled back investment plans, a government report said. The decline was steeper than had been forecast, reinforcing the view that Japan has already slipped into another recession.

title: Profit Rises 9.1% At Pixar Animation
description: Pixar Animation Studios said today that its second-quarter profit had risen 9.1 percent on lower research and development and administrative costs.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Publisher's Profit Slips
description: Reed Elsevier, the biggest publisher of scientific journals, said that first-half profit fell 30 percent, as it paid for a number of acquisitions, including the $5.65 billion purchase of Harcourt General last month. Net income at the British-Dutch company fell to 71 million ($101 million), compared with 102 million a year earlier. Revenue increased 13 percent, to 2.07 billion. Crispin Davis, the chief executive, has been making acquisitions; reducing the work force; and building up sales at the Lexis-Nexis unit, a provider of legal information. The moves are part of a strategy to head off one of the worst advertising slumps in years. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Cossette of Quebec Buys Post & Partners
description: The Cossette Communication Group, a marketing and communications agency company in Quebec City, said yesterday that it had acquired its first agency in the United States, Post & Partners in New York.

title: Newcomers Ready for Marketing, Accounting . . . and, Oh Yes, Creating
description: What do young artists want? Perhaps what Freud said they want: honor, power and love. What about simply making good art? That traditionally has been what art schools help aspiring artists to do, leaving the more worldly ambitions to take care of themselves.

title: The Mighty (and Often Playful) Pen of 20th-Century Caricaturists
description: The modern art of caricature may have started in Italy in the late 1600's, but in 20th-century America it really took off. Between the two World Wars the general increase of public awareness about who was who, pushed by the movies, the press, the radio and other agencies, created a celebrity culture and recognizable identities that could be skewered by playful pens.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Harassment Case Reviewed
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology is reviewing its handling of a harassment case involving a sophomore who committed suicide in April. The student, Julia M. Carpenter, filed a complaint against a fellow dormitory resident in January, saying he was obsessed with her and was sleeping outside her door and searching through her computer files. Administrators removed him from the dormitory but said he could reapply to live there after he completed counseling. Ms. Carpenter's family said she was distressed at that possibility. The family also said it was considering a wrongful-death lawsuit against the institute, The Boston Globe reported.

title: Bill Murray as a Battlefield and Showing It
description: The world probably doesn't need one more parody of the stop-action fight scene in ''The Matrix,'' though it's time we got one with one of the original cast members participating. That's one of the minor virtues of the part live-action, part animated feature ''Osmosis Jones'': Laurence Fishburne of ''The Matrix'' gives voice to Thrax, the evil virus fighting to the literally feverish finish with Osmosis Jones (the voice of Chris Rock), the white-blood-cell cop charged with keeping his host's body healthy. That is an uphill battle, since the host, Frank (Bill Murray), is given to eating the worst possible food. He wakes up from a bad dream and gobbles the remains of an orange marshmallow peanut that sat on his chest while he slept.

title: A Crime-Writing Prosecutor Finds Success and Loses Job
description: Things were looking good for Senior Assistant District Attorney Rob Reuland back in February. He was rising through the ranks in the homicide bureau of the Brooklyn D.A.'s office, trying some high-profile cases. And his first novel, a portrait of a troubled prosecutor mourning the loss of his daughter, had earned him a six-figure advance and was about to hit the stores.

title: Body Heat
description: The Harlem River oozes like warm hydraulic fluid in the early sun. The Hudson seems almost impassive in the heat. People standing outside the studios of the morning television talk shows wave ineffectually and emit faint, depleted screams when the camera goes live on them. By late evening the barker at Madame Tussaud's, who shouts ''Three bucks gets you next to Samuel L.!'' -- meaning a lifelike model of Samuel L. Jackson -- would do more for business if he talked up the air-conditioning inside, which keeps the wax dummies from melting like so many humans. The sidewalks are full of reluctant pedestrians. Some move slowly, trying to walk without touching the cloth of their shirts yet unable to escape their waistbands. Others move quickly, trying to run up their own breeze.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Hunks of a Bygone Era Bolstered Beleaguered Masculinity
description: HOUDINI, TARZAN AND THE PERFECT MAN

title: McEwing Plays It Cool When No One Else at Shea Can
description: Joe McEwing saw Rey Ordez head out to shortstop in the eighth inning yesterday at Shea Stadium and thought he was out of the game. Anyone else would have been grateful to end his day early when his workplace became a cauldron. Not McEwing.

title: A Money Manager Faces New Fraud Charges
description: Alan B. Bond, a Wall Street money manger who is scheduled to stand trial in November on charges he took illegal kickbacks from brokerage firms, was arrested yesterday on separate fraud charges, federal prosecutors said.

title: DiFrancesco Raises Speeds At Toll Plazas
description: Less than a month after New Jersey began enforcing a creeping five-mile-per-hour speed limit for drivers using their E-ZPass cards at its toll plazas, Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco today bowed to widespread complaints and ordered the speed limit tripled.

title: Seeking to Regain Fliers, United Cuts Chicago Fares
description: United Airlines, trying to win back passengers from big rivals and to ward off competition from discounters, said today that it was reducing fares on some flights between Chicago and other large American cities.

title: Under a Rising Condo Complex, Lefties Struggle On
description: It takes a little stretching, but Crystal Field manages to rouse the rabble one more time in ''The Patients Are Running the Asylum,'' the Theater for the New City's 25th annual touring production of street theater. The show opened last weekend on East 10th Street next to the company's theater on First Avenue in the East Village and will tour the five boroughs on weekends through Sept. 16.

title: Make Way For Dragons
description: Meadow Lake at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens will be festooned this weekend with some 90 dragon boats, like the one at left. Their paddling teams will compete in various races as part of the 11th annual Hong Kong Dragon Boat Festival in New York.

title: YankeeNets' Network May Discover That Its Clout Has Eroded
description: The YankeeNets' television network is being created to mint vaults of money. Goldman, Sachs and the Quadrangle Group, the investment banks pouring cash into it, know that.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about an announcement by federal authorities that they had broken a global pornography ring misstated the title of Kenneth Weaver of the United States Postal Service, which helped conduct a sting operation. He is the chief postal inspector, not the inspector general.

title: For Vikings, Reflection Hits Hard
description: ''This is the way it's supposed to be, isn't it?'' Brian Crawford remembers thinking as he watched Korey Stringer stumbling near the end of a 90-minute practice in brutal heat on the second morning of training camp last week.

title: Angry Torre Criticizes Lilly's 6-Game Penalty
description: Ted Lilly was suspended for six games today by Major League Baseball for hitting Anaheim's Scott Spiezio in the helmet with a pitch last Sunday, a ruling that has outraged the Yankees. The Yankees are upset that Lilly received a suspension even though he was not ejected from the game.

title: Group Faults Drug Inhalers In 10 Deaths
description: At least 10 asthma patients may have died after using drug inhalers that were later recalled by the manufacturer, the Schering-Plough Corporation, according to reports filed with federal regulators that were obtained by a consumer group.

title: A Philosopher Fully at Ease In Uncertainty
description: The man President Bush said he was appointing as chairman of his Council on Bioethics, Leon Richard Kass, said in a telephone interview late last night that after 30 years of considering the moral implications of medical advances, he was not certain of many answers.

title: Patients' Real Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Accounts
description: Heineken, Amsterdam, to Betancourt Barba Beker Euro RSCG, Mexico City, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas Advertising, as the first agency for the brand in Mexico. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MISROCK, S. LESLIE
description: MISROCK-S. Leslie. The attorneys and staff of Fish & Neave note with sorrow the passing of Leslie Misrock, a worthy adversary, colleague, and leader of the Bar. Our condolences to his family and his partners at Pennie & Edmonds.

title: U.S.-Mexico Talks Produce Agreement on Immigration Policy
description: The United States and Mexico agreed in principle today to an expanded temporary worker program that would allow some of the estimated three million Mexicans living here unlawfully to earn permanent legal residency, officials from both governments said.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Ohio: A 7th Candidate For Cleveland Mayor
description: Mary Rose Oakar, a new state representative and a former member of Congress and the Cleveland City Council, has become the seventh candidate for mayor of Cleveland. Ms. Oakar, a Democrat, said her knowledge of Washington would enable her to win federal money for the city. She served in the House from 1977 to 1993, losing her seat after many House members were accused of repeatedly bouncing checks on the House bank. She denied wrongdoing but pleaded guilty to unrelated campaign finance violations and was placed on probation for two years.

title: Getting More Than They Bargained For When They Submitted the Low Bid
description: Brad Anderson's supernatural thriller ''Session 9'' opens with a pair of working-class Bostonians, Phil (David Caruso) and his Scottish-born business partner, Gordon (Peter Mullan), making a bid on removing the asbestos from a huge, abandoned 19th-century building.

title: On a Sworn Mission Seeking Pretenders To Military Heroism
description: Last April, in a dignified ceremony meant to honor a war hero, Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska pinned a Purple Heart on Timothy R. Webster, who stood humbly wearing a large eagle insignia, the kind worn only by members of the Navy's elite Sea-Air-Land units, the Seals.

title: Bronx All-Stars Struggling in Playoffs
description: Scoring 22 runs in their first two games, the Rolando Paulino Little League All-Stars from the Bronx looked unbeatable in the early going of the Eastern Regional Little League tournament, which began here on Sunday.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: $250,000 Bail Set for Officer in Fatal Crash
description: Joseph Gray, the police officer accused of killing a pregnant woman, her 4-year-old son and her sister while driving drunk, plead not guilty today as he was indicted and ordered held over on $250,000 bail.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Tattoo Regulation Approved
description: New Jersey minors will need written parental consent before receiving a tattoo or having a body part pierced under a law signed by Acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco. The legislation makes it an offense to provide either service to a person under 18. It is punishable by a prison term of up to six months and a maximum fine of $1,000.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Stabbing
description: A suspect has been arrested in the death of a woman found stabbed to death in her Bath Beach apartment, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Louis Poveromo, 26, faces murder and weapons charges in the July 15 death of Jane Marie Russo, 33, the police said. Officials said they focused on Mr. Poveromo after bite marks on his skin matched Ms. Russo's teeth. The police said that Ms. Russo had invited Mr. Poveromo to her apartment the night she was killed. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: 'The Holy Land Through the Eyes of Explorers'
description: American Bible Society

title: Corrections
description: A report in the TV Notes column on Wednesday about Cynthia Nixon, a star of ''Sex and the City,'' misspelled the surname of the actor who plays her boyfriend. He is David Eigenberg, not Eichenberg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILIN, FLORENCE
description: BAILIN-Florence. Of Beechurst, NY, 81. Beloved wife of the late William Bailin. Loving sister of Abe. Cherished sister-in-law of Terri and Bea. Adored aunt of David, Susan, Perry, Deborah and the late Michael, and great aunt (and a great aunt she was) of Jennie, Joanna and Benjamin. Died on August 8, 2001. A life of goodness, a legacy of love, she will be missed by the many she touched. Services Friday 1 PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Verity Shares Tumble On Loss Forecast
description: Verity Inc., a maker of search-engine software that had been forecasting a fiscal first-quarter profit, said it now expects a loss as a result of reduced orders by its customers, which include AT&T Wireless and Verizon Communications. The company's shares fell $3.08, or 24.3 percent, to $9.62. The loss will be as much as 12 cents a share on sales of $20 million to $24 million, in the quarter ending Aug. 31, the company said. Verity, which previously forecast sales of about $36 million, had been expected to earn 13 cents a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Some Odd Rest Stops On the Digital Highway
description: NEVER underestimate the drawing power of eccentricity, especially on the Internet. A Web site, even about the most arcane topics, is like the baseball diamond in the Iowa cornfield: if you build it, they will come.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Lord Archer Moved
description: Lord Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire novelist and disgraced former politician, left a high-security prison in London to continue a four-year jail term at Wayland prison, a lower-risk institution near Thetford, 70 miles northeast of London. Lord Archer was jailed last month on perjury charges. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Congress May Ease Plans For School Accountability
description: Negotiators working to reconcile House and Senate education bills are acknowledging that their original criteria for identifying failing schools are unrealistic, and they are moving away from the notion of penalizing schools based on a single year's test scores.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SUTTER, BEATRICE WEINBERGER
description: SUTTER-Beatrice Weinberger. August 10, 1992. Loved and remembered by all who met her or were taught by her. Her Family

title: A Haydn Display Piece Gives Soloists Chances to Shine
description: It has been nearly a decade since Christian Zacharias joined the parade of instrumentalists who also conduct, and he was recently appointed artistic director of the Orchestre de Chambre de Lausanne. But although he is a regular visitor to New York as a pianist, Mr. Zacharias had not conducted in the city until Tuesday evening, when he made his debut in that capacity with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Prowling the Forest For a Teasingly Elusive (And Delectable) Prey
description: I was standing in the parking lot as the group gathered.

title: Crouching Rowers, Spectacular Dragons, in Races in Queens
description: The 250-meter dragon-boat race doesn't take much more than a New York minute. In a long, narrow boat with a colorful dragon head at the bow and a spiky tail at the stern, 18 paddlers, seated two by two, dig their wooden paddles into the murky waters of Meadow Lake. Forcefully they pull back, as a 19th team member pounds a drum to keep their rhythm, and a 20th steers at the back with a long oar. They aim to move in perfect sync, propelling the boat across the finish line like an arrow.

title: Residential Real Estate; Corporate Walk-Ups Create a Niche
description: The term ''corporate apartment'' usually conjures up images of residential luxury writ large on the expense accounts that companies approve to keep their executives happy while they toil far from home.

title: Uniform Voting Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Center Gets $53 Million Science Grant
description: The National Science Foundation said it had awarded a $53 million grant to build the largest ''distributed computing'' center, letting scientists parcel out hefty tasks among machines at four different research centers. I.B.M. will provide server computers and storage gear and its services unit will manage the project, dubbed TeraGrid. The I.B.M. machines will use more than 3,300 of Intel's Itanium and McKinley chips, and Qwest Communications International will work with I.B.M. and Intel on the project. The largest part of the computing power will be at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications at the University of Illinois in Urbana-Champaign.

title: A Missile Shield: Feat or Folly?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have concluded that we should allow federal funds to be used for research on these existing stem cell lines, where the life and death decision has already been made.''

title: Patient's Family Plans Suit Over Death After Treatment
description: A New Jersey family filed legal papers today accusing the Westchester Medical Center of causing a 59-year-old woman's death by mistakenly placing a catheter in an artery, rather than in a vein, during a routine procedure.

title: Disappointed by Limits, Scientists Doubt Estimate of Available Cell Lines
description: For months, scientists have hoped President Bush would set an important precedent by allowing federal financing for embryonic stem cell research. Mr. Bush did just that tonight, but leading experts were sorely disappointed by his decision, describing it as a baby step, rather than a giant leap, for medical research.

title: Debussy, a Composer Unlike Any Before or After Him
description: A CENTURY later, the originality of the music of Claude Debussy is clear. But in an era when the likes of Mahler, Stravinsky and Schoenberg were trumpeting their innovations, Debussy insinuated his, wrapping them in the most sensuous of surfaces. Not surprisingly, therefore, they tended to be undervalued by the larger public if not by later composers.

title: Belgian Airline to Cut Jobs and Drop Flights
description: Sabena, Belgium's ailing national airline, said today that it would cut 1,600 jobs -- more than 10 percent of its work force -- and drop unprofitable flights to Washington, Tokyo and other cities in a final effort to avoid collapse.

title: Works for the Turns of Two Centuries
description: ''Debussy and His World'' is the focus of the 12th Bard Music Festival this weekend and next at Bard College, Route 9G, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Oct. 27 at Lincoln Center. The festival includes concerts, talks, panel discussions, film screenings and symposiums. Discussions, screenings and symposiums are free. Single performance tickets are $20 and $25; a series ticket is $192. Information: Bard College, (845) 758-3226; Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; Web site, www.bard.edu/bmf/.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOYNT, PAUL J.
description: JOYNT-Paul J. Unexpectedly on August 6, 2001. Mr. Joynt was an actor who appeared in various plays, movies and television. He is survived by two brothers William and James and seven nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Contributions may be made in Paul's name to ''The Actor's Fund of America,'' 729 7th Avenue, NY, NY 10019.

title: Editors' Note; Inside Art
description: The Inside Art column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: This Stock Pays 21% in Dividends, but Few Are Interested
description: THE business is declining, with new competitors and technological trends that could eventually destroy the industry. Many companies have better growth prospects. But even with all those problems, you might think that a 21 percent dividend would entice investors.

title: A Scholarship and a Crisis
description: The Palestinian uprising that erupted last fall put an abrupt end to Bill Clinton's efforts to secure a foreign policy legacy -- a lasting peace in the Middle East. Almost one year later, scores of Israelis and hundreds of Palestinians have been killed, with thousands wounded.

title: Questions of Leadership In a Close Council Race
description: Councilman Philip Reed spoke with unrestrained glee one morning this week over a report that showed that hospitalization rates for children with asthma were declining in New York City, particularly in East Harlem.

title: Violence on Both Sides in Macedonia Mars Peace Accord
description: ''Do you want to see my boy?'' Sabir Veseli asked. He climbed up to the porch where, on muggy nights like last night, his three children go out to sleep.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Zarela Martinez could mix margaritas and serve regional Mexican food at Zarela's for at least another 50 years and simply count the money. Instead, she decided to open Danzn, a sliver of a restaurant devoted to the cuisine of Veracruz. If geography is destiny, Veracruz has been blessed. The Gulf of Mexico supplies it with fish, and exposure to the West Indies and West Africa has lent its cuisine exotic touches that announce themselves as soon as you sit down at Danzn, where the premeal snack, instead of cornmeal chips and salsa, is roasted plantain chips dipped in a fiery Afro-Cuban peanut sauce.

title: On the Left: Chen and Leiter
description: Al Leiter has watched the Mets' collapse this season cost them the veteran pitchers Rick Reed, Turk Wendell and Dennis Cook. The rest of the season is being played with an obvious nod toward 2002, and as a veteran himself, Leiter is trying to make the last two months constructive.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Car Dealers Settle With State
description: New York State has reached out-of-court settlements with 47 auto dealers across the state accused of grossly misleading advertising and other shady business practices, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said yesterday. The dealers paid about $500,000 in fines to avoid being taken to court. Mr. Spitzer said a yearlong investigation had uncovered scores of misleading advertisements and scams. Some dealers, for instance, guaranteed $2,500 to customers trading in any jalopy but added that cost to the price of the new car. Others offered low prices for cars but put so many caveats in fine print that no one could qualify. In the settlements, the dealers denied any wrongdoing, but agreed to stop the ads and other practices.

title: Races Make Return to Fairgrounds
description: After a 29-year absence, thoroughbred racing has returned to the Brockton Fair in eastern Massachusetts.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: The Moving Hand

description: TANSILL-Donald B. Jr. Of Locust Valley, New York on August 8, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Nancy. Loving father of Audrey Montalto, Donald B. III and Robert P. Dear grandfather of seven. Funeral service Monday 11 A.M., St. John's of Lattingtown, NY. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Make-A-Wish Foundation. Further information Whitting Funeral Home, Glen Head, New York.

title: Even Paradise Needs Basic Maintenance
description: Seattle, long a self-styled paradise, is in serious trouble. The clearest manifestation is its traffic jams. Perennially at or near the top of various ''most livable cities'' lists throughout the 1980's and 1990's, Seattle placed second this spring on the national list of cities with the worst traffic, after chronic offender Los Angeles. The city's 20-year-long Silicon Rush has sent the population skyrocketing, with huge suburbs sprawling east from Lake Washington, spawned largely by Microsoft and its tech-industry descendants.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about therapy camps operated by Stephen A. Cartisano 3rd misstated the circumstances of the death of Michelle Sutton 11 years ago. She died at a camp in Utah run by former employees of Mr. Cartisano, not at a Pacific Coast Academy Camp, which he has represented as a marketing consultant.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: WebMd Loss Narrowed In 2nd Quarter
description: The WebMD Corporation, an Internet health information company that has lost more than $2 billion, said yesterday that its second-quarter net loss narrowed to $821.8 million, or $2.30 a share. The results were in line with analysts' estimates. The company reported second-quarter revenue of $178.7 million, up from $1.01 million in the year-earlier period. In addition, WebMD said it expected to post slightly wider losses for the rest of the year than Wall Street analysts are forecasting. The company, based in Elmwood Park, N.J., attributed the lower estimate to softness in the Internet advertising market and the consolidation of certain transaction services. The company reiterated its expectation that it would become profitable by 2002. Shares in WebMD ended the day down 34 cents, or 5.7 percent, at $5.63. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: When It Helped To Be a Bit Nuts
description: With all the dinosaurs, apes, robots, digital actors and artificial intelligence on screen, it's often hard to connect with anybody real. Not so during the Depression, when drama and the better screwball and romantic comedies had people to grab hold of.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Stipends For Foster Children
description: Gov. Donald Siegelman has ordered the State Department of Human Resources to send $200 to foster parents for each foster child's school needs. The one-time payments, totaling nearly $1 million, will come from Children First, a fund set aside from tobacco settlement money. The governor, a Democrat, has said he supports a permanent increase in stipends for Alabama foster parents, the lowest paid in the nation. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, JUDITH
description: GREENBAUM-Judith. The Yeshiva University family mourns the tragic murder of a gifted student at our Azrieli Graduate School of Jewish Education and Administration, who died in the Palestinian terroist bomb attack in the center of Jerusalem yesterday. Her devotion to chinuch and the advancement of Israel and the Jewish people will always inspire us. Our hearts go out to her husband, Schmuel; her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alan Hayman of Los Angeles; her uncle, Dr. Peter E. Hayman, a YU alumnus; and the entire family. Hashem yinkora damah. May the Almighty comfort them among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Moshael J. Straus, Chairman Board of Directors Azrieli Graduate School

title: Control of School Board
description: To the Editor:

title: O'REILLY TO BUY MID-STATE AUTOMOTIVE FOR $46.2 MILLION
description: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., an auto-parts retailer, agreed to buy Mid-State Automotive Distributors Inc., the United States parts retailing unit of the London-based Mid-States P.L.C., for $19.5 million. O'Reilly will pay that sum in cash and assume $26.7 million in debt to acquire the closely held Mid-State's 85 stores and 4 distribution centers in Indiana, Kentucky, Tennessee, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida and Georgia, the company said. The transaction is to be completed by Oct. 1. O'Reilly, which is based in Springfield, Mo., expects to open 200 stores this year.

title: A Missile Shield: Feat or Folly?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERZ, STEPHEN, JR.
description: HERZ-Stephen, Jr. Of New York City. Died August 9, 2001 in New Canaan, Connecticut. Husband of the late Marie Kohler Herz. Father of Marcia Cornel. Grandfather of Hallee Branin. Friend of Dorothy Umanski. Service will be held on Saturday, August 11, 10:30 AM at the Church of Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street at Fifth Avenue. Contributions in his memory to the Waveny Care Center, 3 Farm Road, New Canaan, CT.

title: Reinforcements in Place For Yanks' Stretch Run
description: The high profile of the Yankees' low Class A affiliate may have something to do with the attention the Staten Island Yankees receive from the organization. Last year, Staten Island received a number of players from the advanced Class A Greensboro Bats in time for a playoff run that resulted in a league championship. Last week, the young Yankees got some early reinforcements.

title: SUMITOMO MITSUI SELLING SOME OF ITS STAKE IN GOLDMAN
description: The Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corporation plans to sell about $500 million worth of shares in the Goldman Sachs Group to raise funds to write off bad loans and cope with slowing business in its home market. Sumitomo Mitsui, the second-largest outside shareholder in Goldman, can sell as many as 6.1 million shares after a registration with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Sumitomo, which bought 10 percent of Goldman in 1986 for about $500 million and has since reduced that holding to 3.1 percent, does not intend to sell the stock immediately, a spokesman, Seiichi Jo said. Sumitomo Mitsui, formed by the merger in April of Sumitomo Bank Ltd. and Sakura Bank Ltd., wrote off 783 billion yen of bad loans in the fiscal year that ended in March, cutting its problem lending to 3.36 trillion yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEFUCCIO, JEROME A. ''JERRY''
description: DeFUCCIO-Jerome A. ''Jerry'' of Jersey City on Thursday, August 9, 2001. Loving son of Mary V. (nee Hennessy) and the late Dr. Charles P. DeFuccio. Dear brother of Charles M. DeFuccio and devoted sister-in-law of MaryAnne DeFuccio. Beloved uncle of DeAnne DeFuccio. Dear cousin of Grace Gargiulo, Michelina MacGregor and Mary Kozak. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from McLaughlin Funeral Home, 625 Pavonia Avenue, Jersey City, NJ 07306 on Monday, August 13, 2001 at 9:30 AM. Funeral Mass St. Peter's Church, Jersey City, NJ at 10:30 AM. Interment Holy Name Cemetery, Jersey City. Visitation Saturday and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Parking opposite funeral home.

title: Microbe Warfare Hides the Enemy
description: For the past seven years, the United States has been negotiating a verification protocol to the Biological Weapons Convention of 1972, hoping to put teeth into the convention's ban on biological weapons production. The Bush administration recently rejected the latest draft of the protocol, viewing it as irredeemably flawed. This is a good time to ask what a new American strategy should be for security against biological threats. It is difficult to predict the likelihood or scale of biological attack. The right policy will provide benefits whether or not an attack occurs.

title: Hevesi Speaks on Policing; His Rivals Show Off Support
description: Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that as mayor he would make sure that the city does not ''slip back to the dark days of disorder and disarray and lawlessness,'' even as he called for changing many of the very tactics and strategies that the Giuliani administration credits with having driven down crime.

title: Clean Needles in Prison
description: To the Editor:

title: Fees for Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Ovitz, Hollywood Giant of a Few Years Ago, Comes on Hard Times
description: Three years ago Michael S. Ovitz, one of Hollywood's titans in the 1980's and early 90's, formed a management company to produce films and television programs as well as represent stars, directors, writers and sports figures. The venture was intended to place Mr. Ovitz firmly back in the Hollywood firmament after several years of setbacks.

title: Verdicts on Jurors (Some Are Civil)
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: Grant For Davenport Riverfront
description: Davenport has been awarded a $20 million state grant to help pay for a $113 million riverfront project, which will include a 500-foot-long elevated walkway and other new construction and renovation. The grant, approved by the state's Vision Iowa Board, will be used in Davenport's effort to attract tourists to its Mississippi River bank. To preserve its connection to the river, Davenport, which had major flooding last spring, decided years ago not to build a flood wall. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Feeling the Ripple Effect of a Marriage Rent Asunder
description: I have no excuse for having missed ''Dinner With Friends.'' It ran at the Variety Arts Theater in the East Village for a year and a half and won the Pulitzer Prize for drama. Everyone said good things about the playwright, Donald Margulies. I guess I just had trouble believing there was anything new to say about yet another baby-boomer marriage gone bad and the couple's best friends' getting all upset about it.

title: At One Resort in China, Two Distinct Worlds
description: Xihaitan Road leaves the center of this seaside resort and travels west toward another universe.

title: An Italian China Meets a Chinese China
description: In 1997, Zhang Yimou, the Chinese film director, and the conductor Zubin Mehta staged a production of Puccini's ''Turdandot'' in Florence. A year later, against much greater logistical odds, they brought the opera to the Forbidden City in Beijing. In ''The Turandot Project,'' Allan Miller's new documentary about their collaboration, much is made of the authenticity of the production, as though Puccini's work were being returned to the land of its origin, rather than the place where it happens to be set.

title: Debussy, a Composer Unlike Any Before or After Him
description: Here are some favorite Debussy recordings of the classical music critics of The New York Times. CD's range in price from $10 to $15 for one CD, $15 to $20 for a two-CD set and $30 to $40 for three- and four-CD collections. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: With Politics and Market in Mind, Megawati Picks a Cabinet
description: In her first step to define her new presidency, Megawati Sukarnoputri chose a cabinet today in Jakarta, winning immediate praise for her selection of an economic team and for the overall professionalism of her choices.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Candidate's Accusations
description: A leading opposition candidate in the presidential election scheduled for Sept. 9 said he planned to release ''sensational evidence'' soon implicating the nation's authoritarian government in the disappearances of several leading critics of President Aleksandr Lukashenko. The candidate, Vladimir Goncharik, said at a news conference that Belarus's former prosecutor general and two other former officials of the Lukashenko government had new information on the cases and could soon speak publicly. Mr. Lukashenko has dismissed reports of a government-backed death squad that singled out opposition figures, saying his opponents staged the disappearances to blacken his name. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Bridgeport: $1 Billion Project Advances
description: Mayor Joseph P. Ganim has announced a preliminary agreement with a company for a $1 billion development along Long Island Sound. The city has tentatively chosen RCI Marine Inc., a developer in Miami, for the Bridgeport Landing project on Steel Point. The 52-acre project, part of an effort to revive the city's moribund waterfront, will include retail, housing and office space as well as a conference center. Construction is expected to begin early next year.

title: Promoters' Battle Supersedes Fighters'
description: Oscar De La Hoya and his promoters have ended negotiations for a bout with Fernando Vargas.

title: Foreign Affairs; Strategic Warmth
description: When you ask China's president, Jiang Zemin, whether he is worried about relations with President Bush, in light of their rocky start and the Bush team's push for missile defense, Mr. Jiang gives a charmingly Chinese answer: I'm not worried at all -- I know the young man's parents.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE

title: President Bush Waffles
description: Last night George W. Bush had one of those rare opportunities a president gets to take a bold step that might define his administration. Instead, he ducked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISSBERG, JOSEF, M.D.
description: WEISSBERG-Josef, M.D. The members of the New York State Psychoanalytic Coordinating Committee wish to express our deep personal and professional loss with the death of our colleague, member and friend, Dr. Josef Weissberg. For over 15 years his wisdom, sense of proportion and compassionate interest in his profession helped guide us in our work. We will miss him deeply. New York State Psychoanalytic Coordinating Committee

title: Hobbling Moss Returns to Ask About the Fuss
description: Santana Moss was finishing his wobbly walk to the podium today, his left knee wrapped and in a brace, his metal crutches cast aside, when he wondered, as he eased himself into a chair, ''Why so many pictures?''

title: A Day of Painful Goodbyes To 4 Run Over by an Officer
description: After a week of rage and protests, Sunset Park paused yesterday to say goodbye to the four victims of a fatal accident that has shattered a family and raised questions about alcohol abuse among the police.

title: Cossette of Quebec Buys Post & Partners
description: The Cossette Communication Group ( news/quote ), a marketing and communications agency company in Quebec City, said yesterday that it had acquired its first agency in the United States, Post & Partners in New York.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: CAR DEALERS SETTLE WITH STATE

title: Women's Social Club Bridges Generations on the Stoop
description: The women -- wives, widows and the divorced -- emerge from their apartments just after 7 p.m., dragging lawn chairs, puffing cigarettes, toting grandchildren and bringing news of the day's winning lottery number.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the inability of Norman Siegel to obtain public matching funds to run for city public advocate included an outdated reference to his affiliation. Mr. Siegel resigned as executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union to run for office.

title: Chinese President Is Optimistic About Relations With the U.S.
description: Jiang Zemin has not yet met George W. Bush, but in their single telephone conversation last month, Mr. Jiang now says, ''from his voice I could feel that he was a president I could do business with.''

title: MetroStars Trade For Experience
description: The MetroStars acquired midfielder Ross Paule from the Colorado Rapids yesterday for Steve Shak, the first pick over all in Major League Soccer's 2000 draft.

title: WHOLE FOODS TO BUY ASSETS OF HARRY'S FARMERS MARKET
description: Whole Foods Market Inc., a leading natural-foods grocer, agreed to acquire most assets of Harry's Farmers Market Inc., an operator of fresh-food stores based in Roswell, Ga., for about $35 million. Whole Foods said it would buy three Harry's Farmers Market superstores in Atlanta, which had total revenue of about $100 million in the year ended Jan. 31. The purchase includes real estate, the Harry's Farmers Market name, a distribution center, commissary kitchen, bake house and offices. Whole Foods is based in Austin, Tex.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROY, JOSEPH F. REV. CSP.
description: TROY-Joseph F. Rev. CSP. On August 8, 2001 at age 93. Born in Dobbs Ferry, NY, he was ordained a Paulist priest on December 22, 1934 at the Lateran Basilica, Rome, Italy. During his sixty-seven years of priestly service, Fr. Troy served at parishes in Portland, OR; New York, NY; Austin, TX; San Francisco, CA, and Boston, MA. Under his guidance Saint Philip Neri Church was built in Portland and a church, rectory and school at Saint Austin's in Austin. A wake will be held on Friday, August 10, 2001 from 2 to 8 P.M. at Saint Paul the Apostle rectory, 415 West 59th Street, New York, NY. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 10:00 A.M. on Saturday, August 11, 2001 at Saint Paul's Church. Interment will be at Mount Paul Cemetery, Oak Ridge, NJ.

title: Metro Business Briefing | From Times Sq. To Lincoln Center
description: Wendy Leventer, the executive who oversaw the state's Times Square redevelopment project for the past four years, will be leaving her post this month to take on a new project -- Lincoln Center. According to real estate executives and state officials, she will be joining her predecessor in the Times Square project, Rebecca Robertson, who is now executive director of the Lincoln Center Constituent Development Project, a 10-year, $1.5 billion effort to renovate the arts complex on the Upper West Side. Ms. Leventer did not return calls requesting comment. There was no word from the state on her replacement. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Current Releases
description: ALPHA LIST-->

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about historically significant New Jersey train stations misspelled the given name of the Borough Council president in Madison, who discussed the restoration of the one there. She is Mary-Anna Holden, not Marianna. Because of an editing error, a caption misstated the total number of stations in New Jersey. It is 160, not 120.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Profit At Beverage Concern
description: With soft drink and beer sales surging, the Brazilian beverage company Cia. de Bebidas das Americas, or Ambev, posted net income of $55.2 million in the second quarter, in contrast to a loss of $41 million in the period last year. The company also benefited from an annualized $200 million in administrative and production efficiencies. The company expects sales growth to slow in the second half of the year, as the economy decelerates because of a severe energy crisis. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: KIDS HOLDINGS TO BUY CHILDREN'S COMPREHENSIVE
description: Children's Comprehensive Services Inc., a juvenile-justice services provider that works with 3,700 children in 14 states, is to be bought by Kids Holdings for about $43.3 million. Kids Holdings, a closely held company created for the acquisition, and its Ameris Acquisition Inc. unit, will pay $6 a share for the company, Children's Comprehensive said. The price was 40 percent more than the closing price of $4.29 on Wednesday. The transaction is expected to be complete in November. Children's Comprehensive is based in Nashville.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Bribery Investigation
description: Ukraine's prosecutor general pledged to follow Russia's lead and investigate accusations that a principal opponent of President Leonid Kuchma, Yuliya Timoshenko, bribed officials in Russia's Defense Ministry and violated customs rules. One inquiry stems from a 1995 incident in which customs officials seized $100,000 from Ms. Timoshenko's luggage at the Vnukovo airport in Moscow; in the other, she is accused of asking a friend to pass bribes to a Russian defense official accused of misusing $450 million in military funds. Ms. Timoshenko, who has fallen ill in Ukraine, denies the charges. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Now, Which of You Are Dead?
description: ''The Others,'' Alejandro Amenbar's suave new ghost story, takes place in an isolated house on the island of Jersey, in the English Channel. The year is 1945, but the house and its inhabitants -- a strict, high-strung mother, her two children and three servants dressed in funereal black -- belong to the timeless, vaguely Victorian world of classic English fright fiction.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: A Magical Childhood

title: Khatami vs. Khamenei
description: The friction between reformers and reactionaries in Iran was great enough this week to delay the inauguration of Mohammad Khatami to a second term as president. Mr. Khatami was finally sworn in on Wednesday, but he faces a protracted struggle with conservative clerics who have the institutional power to cripple his boldest initiatives.

title: A Strange Twist for Nascar
description: One result of Dale Earnhardt's death is that six months later, stock car racing is more popular than when he was alive. Two Earnhardt camps flocked to every race: one to see him win, the other to see him lose. No competitor was, depending on the T-shirt a fan wore, either more charming or more arrogant.

title: A Missile Shield: Feat or Folly?
description: To the Editor:

title: Each Side Finds Something to Like, and Not
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9  President Bush's proposal for carefully limited federal research on embryonic stem cells was greeted with relief tonight by many abortion opponents and other conservatives, who had feared a much broader federal effort.

title: New Video Releases
description: Chocolat

title: For One 'Storyteller,' a Temporary Gig in Politics
description: YOU'D think there would be pressure. Michael Palmer is a 26-year-old working on his first political campaign. He flew in about a month ago from Los Angeles to become the speechwriter for Mark Green, the Democratic mayoral candidate.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profits Fall
description: Two of the country's largest government-controlled companies reported sharp declines in net profits for the first half of this year. The Korea Electric Power Corporation said its net income from January through June totaled $667 million, down 25 percent from a net income of $890 million recorded in the first six months of last year. The Korea Telecom Corporation said net income in the first half dropped 28 percent, to $332 million, from $460 million in the period last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Erik Wesselo and Carol Bove
description: Team

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FETTE, HENRY
description: FETTE-Henry. Of Fort Lauderdale, FL, formerly of Clifton, NJ on August 7, 2001. Husband of Carolyn Chimento Fette. Former husband of Anne Fette. Father of Henry ''Bud'', Jr., Lawrence T., Dolores Richert and Maryanne DiLella. Also survived by 15 grandchildren and 17 great-granchildren. Visitation Monday, Aug. 13th, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Bizub-Quinlan Funeral Home, 1313 Van Houten Ave., Clifton. Funeral services will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Boy's and Girl's Club of Clifton, P.O. Box 798, Clifton, NJ 07015.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: SPARE TIMES
description: Museums and Sites

title: Nora Sayre, an Essayist on the Cold War, Is Dead at 68
description: T, Nora Sayre, a film critic and essayist best known for her commentary on the cultural effects of the cold war, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Science in Its Infancy, but With Great Expectations for Its Adolescence
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 — For months, scientists have hoped President Bush would set an important precedent by allowing federal financing for embryonic stem cell research. Mr. Bush did just that tonight, but leading experts were sorely disappointed by his decision, describing it as a baby step, rather than a giant leap, for medical research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, SEYMOUR D. DR.
description: FEINBERG-Seymour D. Dr., 85. Beloved husband of the late Dr. Constance Buxer Feinberg. Loving father of Andrew and Kenneth. Devoted grandfather of Caroline, Lance and Dylan. Loving brother of Bernard and Beatrice. Cherished father-in-law of Rikki and Adele. He enjoyed a distinguished career as a US Army Officer in WWII and as a Dentist for more than 40 years. He was a generous supporter of many causes, especially civil rights, medical research and the State of Israel. An avid tennis player and fan, he met his wife on a tennis court, where part of his heart always was. He will be missed. A memorial service will be held in September.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUCKENS, IRVING
description: RUCKENS-Irving. Age 88, died August 6, 2001 in Manhattan. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Ultimate New Yorker, loved traveling, history, politics, progressive causes and the performing and visual arts. He held an accounting degree from Columbia and before retirement was controller of The Juilliard School. Serving in the US Army in World War II, he performed intelligence work behind the German lines during the Normandy offensive. A long time resident of Lower Manhattan, he was involved in community affairs and arts. In the 1960s he founded Dynarts, a non-profit organization staging public music and theater events. In retirement, he and his wife remained active, attending concerts and plays. He was a strong supporter of Juilliard. He will be missed dearly.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Andrea Baca was named to the new post of senior account executive at Cartel Creativo, San Antonio. She had held a similar post at the New York office of Clarion Brand, part of the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles unit of the Bcom3 Group. Also, Gady Espinosa was named to the new post of senior copywriter at Cartel Creativo; she had been a creative director at Hispanica Advertising, Dallas.

title: How Do You Get to Carnegie Hall?
description: With his tan fedora set atop a headful of dark curls and a wine-colored velvet corduroy blazer worn over a T-shirt, Justin Kantor resembles a roving troubador with a cello. ''I just love music,'' he said, shrugging. ''I want to play whatever comes my way.'' A year away from completing a bachelor's degree at the Manhattan School of Music, he can perhaps afford to be dreamy. But one afternoon in May, after a four-hour practice session, Mr. Kantor looked in on the job-networking fair in the school cafeteria.

title: From the Stoops, Front-Row Seats On the City's Life
description: The rest of the country sits on porches, but New Yorkers sit on stoops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUG, PHIL
description: KRUG-Phil. Friends and colleagues in LSNY and elsewhere in the public interest legal community mourn the sudden death of Phil Krug in a car accident on August 7. For almost 3 decades Phil was a vigorous, dedicated staff attorney at Harlem Legal Services where he provided legal assistance to countless low income people in the Harlem community. He will be greatly missed.

title: Scramble to Avoid Blackouts As Record Heat Wilts Region
description: A five-day August heat wave reached a withering peak across a wide swath of the Northeast yesterday as temperatures soared to 103 in New York City, 105 in Newark and 100 or more in many cities, shattering records and straining power supplies across the region on the hottest day of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTCHEK, BEATRICE
description: ALTCHEK-Beatrice. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family acknowledges with sadness the passing of Beatrice Altchek, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague, Edgar Altchek, M.D., Attending Physician in the Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery. To Dr. Altchek and the entire Altchek family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Matthew E. Fink, M.D. President and CEO Sidney K. Stein, M.D. President of the Medical Board Mark R. Sultan, M.D. Chief, Department of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLOSHOK, RALPH E., M.D.
description: MOLOSHOK-Ralph E., M.D. Age 88. Died on August 3, 2001 as a result of heart failure. He is survived by his wife, Margaret, his daughter, Lynn Green, and son, James, grandchildren, Aram, Gillian, Lisa and Daniel and brother, Norman. Dr. Moloshok practiced pediatric medicine in New York City for over four decades prior to his retirement to Boca Raton, FL. He was a professor of pediatrics at The Mount Sinai Medical School and an attending physician at Mount Sinai Hospital. He will be remembered fondly by his many patients for his tireless devotion to their care.

title: Closer U.S. Ties Sought on Nuclear Disaster Plans
description: Two federal agencies responsible for ensuring the public's safety in the event of a radioactive accident at the Indian Point 2 nuclear plant need to coordinate better with local officials drawing up emergency plans, the federal General Accounting Office has concluded.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Ratings Lowered Again
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered its ratings on India's debt and currency, the second time this week that an international rating agency has downgraded its outlook on the country. Moody's echoed the warning issued by Standard & Poor's when it lowered its ratings, saying that the country was missing an opportunity for economic reform. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: National Briefing | West: Oregon: Wildlife Refuge To Get Water
description: The Klamath National Wildlife Refuge in the parched Klamath Basin will receive enough water for August after mediation between the federal Bureau of Reclamation and local irrigation districts. The refuge needs to begin attracting ducks so migrating bald eagles will have food in the winter. Water to the refuge and for irrigation by local farmers was cut this year to preserve levels for fish in Klamath Lake, as required by the Endangered Species Act. Farmers did not begrudge the birds the water. ''Almost all the crops are dead already,'' said Dave Solem, manager of the Klamath irrigation district.

title: Internet Cash Company Suspends Its Operations
description: Flooz.com, an Internet company that offered online currency that could be used at dozens of World Wide Web sites, has shut its Web site and is considering ceasing operations, executives close to the company said yesterday.

title: Verdicts on Jurors (Some Are Civil)
description: To the Editor:

title: Into a Den of Musical Alchemy
description: Everything seems old and dated on the snug enclave of 100th Street tucked away between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive -- from the row houses and prewar buildings slanting toward the Hudson down to the large 1912 sarcophagus commemorating the city's fallen firefighters, which seals off the block from a view of the drive and, beyond it, the river. On the other side of the sarcophagus, a large bronze tablet depicts three frenzied horses pulling a fire engine. I've often imagined such a spirited team racing along the drive and veering up the steep incline of 100th Street, the clatter of hoofs breaking the early-evening silence.

title: Yankees Pull Out Victory on Sojo's Double in Ninth
description: Esteban Yan's fastball was up around Luis Sojo's eyes, but that did not matter. Sojo had not played in the last four games, but that did not matter. Sojo did not have a hit in his last 19 at-bats, the longest drought of his career. But, as everyone should know by now, with Sojo, none of that seemingly pertinent data mattered.

title: Britain Suspends Northern Ireland's Government
description: HILLSBOROUGH, Northern Ireland, Aug. 10 -- Britain ordered the temporary suspension today of Northern Ireland's home-rule government, hoping to win time for renewed efforts to unlock a stalled effort to end 30 years of conflict that has claimed about 3,600 lives.

title: Detained Nigerian Girl, 8, Finds Home With a Cousin
description: An 8-year-old Nigerian girl who has been detained for 15 months in a Miami shelter was released tonight to live with a cousin in Hartford, United States immigration officials said.

title: Knockdown Relics Of Empire
description: ''Form follows function'' may have been a Modernist credo, but it is at least two centuries old. That is the delightful lesson of ''Britain's Portable Empire: Campaign Furniture of the Georgian, Victorian and Edwardian Periods,'' an exhibition at the Katonah Museum of Art in Katonah, N.Y., through Sept. 30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLMAN, JACK
description: HELLMAN-Jack. On August 7, 2001. Beloved husband of Anne, father and grandfather. Little Neck Jewish Center mourns the death of Jack Hellman, our esteemed member. His departure from this place has left our entire congregation shakened and bereaved. Our glory, our splendor has been diminished. A crown has been removed from us. He gave generously of his time and effort, his counsel and wisdom, expertise and his substance. He gave generously of himself to this institution. Little Neck Jewish Center will be forever remembered as the house that Jack built. The Congregation of the Little Neck Jewish Center Rabbi Joseph Prouser Rabbi Abraham P. Eckstein, Emeritus Cantor Julian Raber

title: Keeping Giants Healthy Is Fassel's Main Aim
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel has not won a preseason game in nearly two years, a losing streak that has reached six games. Although Fassel is aware of the streak, it has done little to change his approach to the preseason. Exhibition games are a time of contradictory objectives -- get players ready for the regular season and keep them out of harm's way -- and Fassel knows it.

title: John Bock -- 'Action'
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: In Jiang's Words: 'I Hope the Western World Can Understand China Better'
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Jiang Zemin by Arthur Sulzberger Jr., publisher of The New York Times; Joseph Lelyveld, executive editor; Howell Raines, who is to succeed Mr. Lelyveld next month; Thomas L. Friedman, foreign affairs columnist; Erik Eckholm, Beijing bureau chief, and three correspondents, Elisabeth Rosenthal, based in Beijing; Craig S. Smith, based in Shanghai; and Mark Landler, based in Hong Kong. Mr. Jiang spoke in Chinese, and a government interpreter translated his remarks.

title: Bush Backs Federal Funding for Some Stem Cell Research
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 9  Addressing the nation for the first time since his inauguration, President Bush said tonight that he would allow federal taxpayer money to be used for research into stem cells from human embryos. But he said that the research would be limited to cells that had already been extracted and that the government would not support the destruction of new embryos.

title: Sosa Hits 3 Home Runs And Hampton Hits No. 7
description: Sammy Sosa homered three times yesterday in the sticky, steamy confines of Wrigley Field. But that same oppressive heat in a 14-5 loss to the Colorado Rockies kept him from having one more at-bat.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rival Bid Offered For Comdisco Unit
description: Hewlett-Packard's $610 million acquisition of Comdisco's technology services division is facing a challenge from a rival suitor, SunGard Data Systems. SunGard, a computer services company, said that it had offered $775 million for the troubled Comdisco unit, but that Comdisco had turned down the higher bid because of antitrust concerns. ''We believe those antitrust concerns they had were very much exaggerated and out of proportion to the risk,'' said James L. Mann, left, SunGard's chairman and chief executive. A federal bankruptcy court yesterday set a schedule for the bidding process. Companies must submit their bids again before Sept. 30, and Comdisco will chose the winning buyer on Oct. 23. A spokeswoman for Hewlett-Packard, which announced on July 16 that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Comdisco unit, would not say whether the company would increase its offer. Separately, Hewlett-Packard said it agreed to acquire Trinagy Inc., a privately held maker of corporate management software, for an undisclosed price. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Rabbis Sentenced For Fraud
description: As dozens of their congregants looked on, two Brooklyn rabbis were sentenced yesterday to 33 months in prison each for skimming hundreds of thousands of dollars from a federally financed program intended to help Holocaust survivors. The rabbis, Efroim Stein and Jacob Bronner, both of Borough Park, pleaded guilty in February to defrauding Project Social Care, the nonprofit organization they founded that received a $2.5 million grant from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development in 1995 and 1996. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Toyota Earmarks $8 Billion for Diversification Efforts

Also survived by his brother Phillip & his wife Frances. He worked for the IRS 57 years and was president of the Manhattan Chapter of the IRS Employee Union. His kindness will be missed. title: National Briefing | Washington: Surgery For F.B.I. Director
description: Robert S. Mueller III, who was confirmed last week as F.B.I. director, is recovering from surgery to remove a cancerous prostate gland, a Justice Department official said. Mr. Mueller had the surgery on Aug. 2, the same day he was confirmed by the Senate. The official said that the operation was successful and that Mr. Mueller would be sworn in as the head of the F.B.I. early next month. David Johnston (NYT)

title: BUSH GIVES HIS BACKING FOR LIMITED RESEARCH ON EXISTING STEM CELLS
description: Addressing the nation for the first time since his inauguration, President Bush said tonight that he would allow federal taxpayer money to be used for research into stem cells from human embryos. But he said that the research would be limited to cells that had already been extracted and that the government would not support the destruction of new embryos.

title: Italy's Leader Defends Police Actions at Genoa Summit Talks
description: Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, today defended police actions at the Group of Eight summit conference in Genoa last month, declaring the meeting ''a political and diplomatic success'' even as officials elsewhere in Europe continued to question the heavy use of force against demonstrators there.

title: Italy Reports Slowdown In Economy As Sales Fall
description: Evidence mounted today that Europe is slowing down, as Italy reported that its economy contracted in the second quarter from the first quarter. The figures signaled that a decline in manufacturing and farming began to infect other areas, producing the first quarter-to-quarter fall in output in three years.

Herzfeld & Rubin, PC Herbert Rubin Justice Rose Luttan Rubin

description: Revealing another month of dismal sales, Gap Inc. said yesterday that sales in stores open at least a year fell 12 percent last month compared with a 1 percent decline in the month a year earlier. The decline was steeper than many analysts had predicted, and affected every division within Gap, from Old Navy to Banana Republic.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Interest Rate Cut
description: The Bank of Korea cut the basic interest rate by 25 basis points in response to what it said was concern that the economic slowdown might be more serious than it had expected. The rate cut, the third this year, lowered the overnight call rate charged to commercial banks from 4.75 percent to 4.5 percent amid hopes that business and industry would respond to easier access to credit by increasing production and raising exports. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Watch Workers To Unionize
description: More than 70 workers at a watch manufacturer, A Classic Time Watch Company, have voted to join the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, union officials announced yesterday. Although management urged the workers to vote against unionization, its employees voted 49 to 26 to be represented by Local 1102 of the union. Frank Bail, the local's president, said the workers voted to join the union because they were frustrated about low wages and the lack of medical coverage and vacations.

title: Charleston's Planters Inn
description: Three centuries in three days is quite a deal, and at the Planters Inn, a historic hotel in Charleston, S.C., it costs only $399 a couple, 20 percent less than usual. The two-night package, available Sundays through Thursdays until Sept. 14, includes a canopied bed, a carriage ride through the 18th-century historic district of the city, a boat tour to the 19th-century Fort Sumter in the city's harbor and admission to the new South Carolina Aquarium. The 62-room Planters Inn occupies a building built around 1844, near the City Market. For families, add $45 for each of two children. For information on the Three Days, Three Centuries package, (800) 845-7082 or www.plantersinn.com .

description: After decades of shopping in small, drab stores with generic names like ''food'' and ''furniture,'' Moscow is rapidly awakening to Western-style modern retailing. title: A Fresh Look at Debussy And Others Of His Era
description: A CENTURY later, the originality of the music of Claude Debussy is clear. But in an era when the likes of Mahler, Stravinsky and Schoenberg were trumpeting their innovations, Debussy insinuated his, wrapping them in the most sensuous of surfaces. Not surprisingly, therefore, they tended to be undervalued by the larger public if not by later composers.

title: Capturing Subjects Who Sit Extremely Still
description: Hiroshi Sugimoto practices a photographic legerdemain so sly he appears to be another oh-so-ironic postmodernist. Mr. Sugimoto, a conceptual artist based in New York, thrives on illusion. In the enigmatically repetitive portraits he has been producing since the 1970's -- especially of the interiors of ornate movie theaters and of sea and sky -- he compounds the camera's ability to deceive.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Two Men Arrested In Killing
description: A jilted boyfriend is suspected of paying a hitman $2,400 to kill his ex-girlfriend's new partner, the police said yesterday. The ex-boyfriend, Diomedes Colon, 40, of Manhattan, was charged with first-degree murder and second-degree conspiracy in the Aug. 4 shooting death of Kevin Medina, 26, also of Manhattan. An Orlando, Fla., man, Felipe Milan, 47, was also arrested in connection with Mr. Medina's death and charged with first-degree murder. The police said the shooting was the result of a dispute. Mr. Medina was shot three times in the back on the second-floor stairwell of an Upper East Side apartment building. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, MICHAEL
description: ROTHMAN-Michael. On August 8 in Enfield, CT. Loving and devoted husband of Gloria, loving father of Mark and Richard, beloved brother of Alvin, brother-in-law of Rita and uncle of Barry. He passed with dignity and courage and will be missed and never forgotten.

description: In September 1993, Robert Wendland of nearby Stockton crashed his pickup truck, an accident that left him brain-damaged and unable to walk, talk, eat or drink, or in any way communicate his wishes. Two years later his wife, Rose, asked doctors to remove the feeding tubes that kept him alive, saying he had told her not long before the crash that he would never want to live in so helpless a condition.

title: Of Principles And Politics
description: In his remarks to the country tonight, President Bush spoke of morality, medicine and what he deemed to be the proper amalgam of the two, positioning those concerns squarely in the foreground of his decision on federal support for embryonic stem cell research. But politics was also a part of the picture, and it was not that far in the background.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVACS, HANNA NAGY
description: KOVACS-Hanna Nagy. Born October 31, 1919 in Szeged, Hungary. Died August 4, 2001, peacefully at home in Pasadena, CA. She survived the depression and WWII in Hungary, but fled Hungary with her family in 1956 during the Hungarian Revolution. She received a Ph.D. in Organic Chemistry in 1945, and worked as a research and clinical chemist through her retirement in 1985. She had multiple scientific publications and was a member of The NY Academy of Sciences, and Sigma Xi. Since 1985, Hanna (Anyu to us) lived in Pasadena, CA, with her daughter and her family, helping to raise two children and sharing her life experiences. She is survived by her children Andrea and Joseph, their spouses Roger and Carol, and her grandchildren Nicky, Katie, JoJo, Steve, Mike, Nick, and Will, all of whom have fond and loving memories of her. We all miss her very much. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Camp Laurel, PO Box 93204, Los Angeles, CA 90093.

description: A federal judge has ruled that the Giuliani administration's requirement that art vendors in parks have permits is a violation of the city code, which unconditionally prohibits mandatory licensing for those who sell art and books.

title: Tiny Part of Settlement Money Is Spent on Tobacco Control
description: The settlement was perceived as a major victory for antismoking crusaders and state agencies paying vast sums to cover the health care costs of smoking. To end years of litigation, the major tobacco companies agreed to pay 46 states $205 billion over 25 years, with the expectation that a large part of it would pay for tobacco-use prevention programs.

title: Blumenthal Will Not Run For Connecticut Governor
description: Richard Blumenthal, widely regarded as the Democratic Party's best chance of retaking the Connecticut governor's office in 2002, said today that he would not seek the job next year and would run instead for a fourth term as attorney general.

title: Campaign Briefing | District Attorney's Race: Petitions And Litigation
description: The battle over the Democratic line for the district attorney's race in Brooklyn is set for trial in State Supreme Court on Monday. A lawyer, Sandra E. Roper, is challenging incumbent Charles J. Hynes, who has been in office since 1990. Several weeks ago, lawyers for Mr. Hynes filed a lawsuit accusing her campaign of filing petitions with forged signatures to get on the ballot. Michael M. Freeman, Mr. Hynes's lawyer, said, for example, that his office had spoken to people whose signatures appeared on the petitions who claimed they had never signed them. Ms. Roper's lawyer, Dominick A. Fusco, denied the charges. ''There's a concentrated effort to get her off the ballot,'' he said. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: ISRAELIS GRIEVE, AND STRIKE BACK
description: As Israel draped itself in mourning for its latest terrorism victims, senior Israeli officials vowed today to keep control of important Palestinian offices that the army and the police had seized overnight.

title: The Mideast Maelstrom
description: The escalating violence in the Mideast is horrifying, but the Palestinian leadership seems unwilling to rein it in. Israel, for all its military might, seems unable to deter it. Thursday's suicide bombing in Jerusalem, claimed by the militant Islamic group Hamas, was one of the worst outrages of the conflict. Israel's swift retaliation against Palestinian Authority targets, including the symbol of Palestinian political presence in East Jerusalem, was understandable but is unlikely to calm the situation.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Attention, The Good Kind
description: After the Tenants Political Action Committee endorsed Mr. Hevesi, and its treasurer, Michael McKee, accused Peter F. Vallone of weakening rent control laws, the Vallone campaign fired back instantly. It's not surprising, the campaign charged, that one client of Hevesi's consultants, Morris, Carrick & Guma, would endorse another of the firm's clients. The tenants' PAC is not and has never been a client of the firm, Mr. McKee said. He explained that his former group, New Yorkers to Save Rent Protections, was a client. And while the attack irritated him, Mr. McKee said he was pleased with the attention focused on rent control. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Man Charged in Beatings Is Said to Have Used Racial Slurs
description: A man charged with beating two Mexican day laborers last fall believed that blacks and whites should be kept separate, and used slurs to describe blacks and Jews, his girlfriend testified today.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: New Sentencing Plan
description: A proposal by Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift to toughen sentences for criminals would increase the state's prison population by 20 percent, a report by the nonpartisan State Sentencing Commission has found. The proposal would also increase state spending for new prison cells by $900 million and add $250 million a year in prison operating costs. Governor Swift, a Republican, offered her plan following a public outcry after a state judge sentenced a man who kidnapped and sexually assaulted an 11-year-old boy to home detention. Fox Butterfield (NYT)
