title: Foreign Affairs; Introducing the China Ruling Party
description: The world has grown so used to all the contradictions in China these days that ''the mother of all Chinese contradictions'' -- the July 1 decision by President Jiang Zemin to allow capitalists to join the Chinese Communist Party -- barely got a shrug. It deserved more.

title: PERFORMANCE FOOD TO PURCHASE FRESH EXPRESS
description: The Performance Food Group said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the closely held Fresh Express for $290 million, the third acquisition for Performance this year. Performance Food, a wholesaler, said it will pay $290 million in cash and assumed liabilities. The company will pay an additional $10 million if Fresh Express, the largest independent processor of fresh-cut produce, meets certain goals. Fresh Express, based in Salinas, Calif., had fiscal 2001 sales of $509 million. The purchase is expected to add 10 cents to 14 cents a share to earnings in 2002, Performance Food said. Fresh Express will be combined with Performance Food's Fresh Cut unit, which supplies produce to food-service customers and restaurant chains including McDonald's, the chief financial officer, Roger Boeve, said.

title: Governor Threatens to Bar U.S. Plutonium Shipments
description: Charging that a large shipment of plutonium from nuclear weapons may be on its way to permanent storage in his state rather than to the temporary stay needed for processing, Gov. Jim Hodges has ordered the South Carolina Highway Patrol to draw up plans for blocking the state's borders to federal trucks bearing it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMAN, DR. HARVEY G.
description: SELIGMAN-Dr. Harvey G. Passed away at his home in Marlboro, NJ, August 10, 2001. Beloved husband to Patricia (nee Moss). Devoted father to Stuart, Ellen Clark, Natalie Loeb and Andrew. Cherished grandfather to four grandchildren. Funeral services from Menorah Chapels, Inc., 2145 Richmond Ave, Staten Island, 9:30 AM, Sunday.

Loving grandmother of Christopher, Charles, Ryan, Amy and Mark. Services Sunday, 10 AM at ''Gutterman-Musicant'', 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ. Contributions to American Heart Association or Cancer Research Fund.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The macabre joke is that they were living in a most dangerous settlement. They were wanting to get away for a day. They thought in Jerusalem it would be safe. The angel of death is finding you any way he can.''

title: Three-Time Rhythmic Champion Relishes Higher Degree of Difficulty
description: Jessica Howard of Jacksonville, Fla., only 17, won her third consecutive national senior all-around championship today. She is one of America's outstanding athletes, but her sport, rhythmic gymnastics, is relatively obscure. And many who know and appreciate the beauty and grace of rhythmic gymnastics wonder if it is really a sport or just a souped-up aerobics class.

title: Combating AIDS on a Metal Band Tour
description: When Ozzfest 2001 rolls into PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J., today for the last two concerts of its summer tour, all the usual suspects will be there amid the nose rings, tongue rings, lip rings and tattoos. The event will include headliners like Marilyn Manson, groups like Pure Rubbish and all-around crowd-pleasers like the master of ceremonies, the Reverend B. Dangerous, who on the tour's swing last month through Camden, N.J., stapled his shirt to his tongue to great acclaim.

title: Edwards Stays Cool In Jets' Hot Seat
description: Herman Edwards has already weathered serious injuries to two of the most important Jets with nary a shudder, so what is a little debut as a head coach?

title: Group Wants to Prove City Is at the Elite Level
description: New York is having its first major triathlon tomorrow. It will not be as crowded as the one in Chicago known as Mrs. T's, nor will it be as grueling as the famous Ironman in Hawaii. In fact, some people might call the New York triathlon the Iron Stomach, in honor of those who can withstand the maligned waters of the Hudson River.

title: Conserving Television's Richness
description: Half a century ago, sight and sound were equal partners in television. Working from radio's model, stations gave pride of place to musical as well as dramatic performers, and variety shows were common. MTV, which recently marked 20 years of bringing youth culture to your living room, stood as an heir to this tradition as long as its centerpiece remained the music video. But lately the sounds of MTV, like the rest of television, have amounted to little more than voices, applause and the occasional band on a late-night talk show.

title: Lindros Initiates Talks With Rangers
description: Rangers General Manager Glen Sather said yesterday that Carl Lindros, the father and agent of the restricted free agent Eric Lindros telephoned him several times this week.

title: Storms End Hot Spell, but Conjure Their Own Problems
description: A six-day August heat wave came to a soggy end yesterday afternoon when thunderstorms descended on most of the region. But there was no letup for utilities, as the storm knocked down power lines and electricity was cut off at tens of thousands of households in the Northeast.

title: Joanne Minnich, 58, a Subject of Extraordinary Heart Surgery, Dies
description: Joanne Minnich, whose heart was cut out last November for removal of a cancer and then returned in an extraordinary operation that drew widespread attention, died on Thursday at her home in Mahopac, N.Y. She was 58.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the coming City Council elections referred imprecisely to the rules. Candidates are elected by plurality; unlike the contests for mayor and other citywide offices, these are not decided by runoffs in case of a close first round. A chart with the article misspelled the name of a candidate in District 1, which includes Chinatown. She is Elana Waksal-Posner, not Alana Wachs-Posner.

title: Bush Appears to Have Straddled a Divide
description: Republicans and even some Democrats say that in his proposal on limited federal support for embryonic stem cell research, President Bush appears at first blush to have defused a political time bomb that could have caused deep fissures in his relationships with conservatives and moderates in his own party.

title: Zimbabwe Book Fair Struggles On
description: Every year publishers, editors, poets and novelists from across Africa and around the world converge on Zimbabwe's capital for a week of book deals and literary debate that is unmatched anywhere else south of the Sahara. The Zimbabwe International Book Fair, as the event is known, hardly rivals its bigger counterparts, like Frankfurt or even Cairo, in size or stature, but its impact on publishing in Africa is undeniable.

title: Drop in 2 Gauges Raises Some Expectations on Rate Cuts
description: Industrial commodity prices fell this week to their lowest level in 15 years and the yield on the two-year Treasury note dropped to its lowest point since the fall of 1992, not long after the last recession.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Spare Times column of Weekend yesterday about Harlem Week 2001 misstated the dates for two outdoor music events on West 135th Street, between Fifth and St. Nicholas Avenues. ''Uptown Saturday Nite,'' offering jazz and blues, will take place on Aug. 18 from 11 a.m. to 9 p.m., not tonight. ''A Love Supreme,'' offering jazz, doo-wop and swing dancing, will be given on Aug. 19 from 2 to 8 p.m., not tomorrow.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Clinton, as John Q. Public, Campaigns for Array of Causes
description: With the $10-million-plus advance he secured for his memoirs, Bill Clinton would seem to be on his way to becoming a very rich man. In September, he will become even richer, when he undertakes a two-week paid speaking tour of Australia and Southeast Asia, continuing a string of such engagements since he left office.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a pledge by Toyota to diversify its work force and reach out to minority suppliers and customers referred incorrectly to the advertising that the Rev. Jesse Jackson saw as trafficking in stereotypes of blacks. It consisted of promotional postcards distributed in coffeehouses and nightclubs, not television commercials.

title: Biotech Stocks Are Pummeled After Decision On Research
description: After President Bush announced support for limited stem cell research, confusion reigned among biotechnology companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAJNZYLBERG, CHARLOTTE
description: FAJNZYLBERG-Charlotte. August 9, 2001, NYU Medical Center. Daughter of Henia Skalka. Teacher of French, Isaac E. Young Junior High School, 1965-1979; New Rochelle High School, 1979-1998. Tutor of French to students in Manhattan private schools, 1990-2001. Thank you for sharing the best of your talents with all of us, especially your love of and respect for the French language and your pride in your Jewish heritage, in particular its Yiddish culture. You were one formidable dame who fashioned your unique personality with pizzazz, with charm, with generosity-all reflected in that certain precious smile of yours. We do mourn. We will remember. Services Sunday, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations to the National Kidney Fund are appreciated. Jane, Yadja, Jeanette and Jim

title: After the Day of Terror in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Campaign Briefing | Public Advocate Contest: What Exactly Do You Advocate?
description: The job of public advocate might not seem glamorous -- all those press conferences on the price of matzo or the level of gas emissions -- but campaigning for the job can be. Last week, public advocate candidate Betsy Gotbaum managed to attract the actress Lauren Bacall and the former Texas governor, Ann Richards, to a fund-raiser on the Upper East Side. During the event, Ms. Richards said that when she was first told what Ms. Gotbaum was running for, she replied: ''Well, what is that? Only in New York.'' Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Hospital For Ex-Klansman
description: Three weeks after declaring that a former Ku Klux Klansman was mentally incompetent to stand trial in the 1963 bombing of the 16th Street Baptist Church, a judge in Birmingham ordered the former Klansman, Bobby Frank Cherry, committed to a state psychiatric hospital for further evaluation. At a brief hearing, the judge, James Garrett of Jefferson County Circuit Court, left, sent Mr. Cherry, 72, to a hospital in Tuscaloosa. Mr. Cherry, who has been found to have vascular dementia, is one of four men originally suspected in the bombing, which killed four black girls. Judge Garrett asked for a report in 91 days. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Cryptographer Held in E-Book Case Prefers Paper
description: Dmitri Sklyarov rarely reads electronic books. ''There are almost no e-books in Russian,'' said Mr. Sklyarov, the 26-year-old Moscow cryptographer who was arrested in Las Vegas last month under a 1998 digital copyright law. ''I prefer paper books. They're much easier to carry with me, and can be read anywhere.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, RUBY
description: BROWN-Ruby. Expressing our deepest condolences to the family. Renata and Alex Weiss

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BUY.COM Aliso Viejo, Calif., the Internet shopping site, said yesterday that it had agreed to be bought by its founder, Scott Blum. His company, SB Acquisition, is paying about $23.2 million in stock.

title: Administration Backs Affirmative Action Plan
description: In its first opportunity to take a stance on affirmative action, the Bush administration asked the Supreme Court tonight to uphold a Transportation Department program intended to help minority contractors.

title: Overseer for School Construction Is Named
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy yesterday appointed Rudolph J. Rinaldi, a construction industry consultant who formerly served as the top construction official for New York State and New York City, to oversee Mr. Levy's proposed reorganization of the Board of Education's division of school facilities.

title: Call It Deception, Not Theft, And Drop the Lawyer Jokes
description: A lawyer from Southfield, Mich., named Albert Silber has long been one of the best players in the Midwest. Those who think that all lawyers are thieves should study the diagramed deal played recently in a duplicate game in Florida. Remember that theft is greatly admired at the bridge table provided it is, oxymoronically, legal theft.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Acquittal Denounced
description: Robert Rivard, editor of the San Antonio Express-News, denounced the acquittal on Saturday of two Mexican suspects in the murder of Philip True, a correspondent for the San Antonio paper who was found dead after disappearing during a 100-mile hike in the state of Jalisco in 1998. Despite an initial autopsy which determined that Mr. True, 50, had been beaten and strangled, a local judge ruled that he had died in an accidental fall. The two suspects, Huichol Indian men, initially confessed to the murder, but later they said investigators had tortured them into confessing. The case will now be appealed at the state level. Mr. Rivard, who was in Mexico City to respond to the case, said that he trusts Mexican authorities to expose the truth. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: After the Day of Terror in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Giants Seek Compelling Sequel
description: ''We are going to have to work even harder to make a return. And we will be back.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Profit Falls
description: Switzerland's largest private bank, Julius Baer Holding, reported that its first-half profit dropped 45 percent, to $81.3 million. The 111-year-old bank, which specializes in clients with at least $1 million to invest, said it would begin a cost-cutting program, including a hiring freeze and would delay a planned online brokerage service, to reduce costs by $47 million yearly. Reflecting the general downturn in banking, Baer -- which is based in Zurich -- had an 80 percent decline in new deposits. The bank's profit was cut by one-time items, including setting up a brokerage firm in Stockholm, and a nearly $16 million write-down on its private equity portfolio. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: A Setback for Billionaire's Bid To Run Computer Associates
description: An influential shareholder-rights group dealt a potentially fatal blow yesterday to the flagging bid of Sam Wyly, the Texas billionaire, to take control of Computer Associates International.

title: Boy, 16, Dies in Late-Night Dive at City Pool
description: A dip in the neighborhood pool brought tragedy to a Brooklyn family early Friday morning. A teenage boy who scaled what city officials described as a 10-foot fence for a late-night swim in the sweltering heat, dived in and died.

title: Danger Lurks as Play Space Is Sought
description: Nana Nantwi loves children, which is why he is not entirely happy as the educational director at the Labor Bathgate Community Child Care Center in the Bronx. Although a playground sits next to the center, the children do not use it, and instead must cross busy Anthony Avenue to use Claremont Park if they want to play on the grass.

title: Globalization Now, A Sequel of Sorts
description: ''The inhabitant of London could order by telephone, sipping his morning tea in bed, the various products of the whole earth. . . . He could at the same moment and by the same means adventure his wealth in the natural resources and new enterprises of any quarter of the world, and share, without exertion or even trouble, in their prospective fruits and advantages. . . . He could secure . . . cheap and comfortable means of transit to any country or climate without passport or other formality.''

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Of Cities And Tales
description: So, just how many ways can New York City be divided? Eight years ago a former prosecutor named Giuliani campaigned for mayor with the slogan, ''One city, one standard.'' This year Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, has pitched his mayoral campaign at what he calls the ''other'' New York, which he describes as the city left behind during the recent economic boom and ignored by the Giuliani administration. One of his rivals, Alan G. Hevesi, disagrees, and keeps saying that this is one city and that it is divisive to define it as something else. Perhaps Mr. Hevesi forgot his own campaign Web site, which quotes him as saying, ''When it comes to health care, New York is truly a tale of two cities.'' Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Robot Aircraft to Try to Set Altitude Record
description: A giant solar-powered wing of ultralight materials will soon try to shatter the altitude record for propeller and jet-powered aircraft by cruising in air as thin as that found on Mars.

title: The Stem Cell Decision: No End to the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Twist In State Politics
description: The state's post-election political landscape continues to evolve. Earlier this year, Lt. Gov. Bill Ratliff said that he would not run for election as lieutenant governor in 2002 and might step away from politics altogether. Mr. Ratliff, who is also a state senator, had been elevated to lieutenant governor, arguably the most powerful position in state government, by a vote of his fellow senators after then-Lt. Gov. Rick Perry tool the top job when Gov. George W. Bush departed for the White House. This week, Mr. Ratliff said he would run for re-election to the Senate.

title: Mining a Musical Diaspora, From a Yoruban Beat to Jazz
description: ''Lagbaja'' is a Yoruba word for ''nobody in particular,'' and the Nigerian bandleader, saxophonist and singer who calls himself Lagbaja always performs with his face hidden to symbolize what he calls ''the facelessness of the so-called common man.'' But when he led his 10-member band at B. B. King on Monday night, this masked man was by no means ordinary. He was a highly individual musician, a cosmopolitan representative of Yoruba culture and a full-tilt entertainer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIOMBINI, MONSIGNOR MARIO G.
description: PIOMBINI-Monsignor Mario G. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of the pastor emeritus of St. Rosalia-Regina Pacis Church, Brooklyn, on August 8, 2001. Reposing at St. Rosalia, 14th Ave & 63rd St., Saturday, August 11th from 1-4 and 6-9PM and Sunday August 12th from 1-4PM. Mass of Transferral at Regina Pacis, 12th Av and 60th St at 7PM. Funeral Mass at Regina Pacis on Monday, August 13th at 10:30AM. All priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Working the Nostalgia Factor
description: Peter F. Vallone, a candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, has begun broadcasting his second television advertisement on New York 1, the local cable news station. Like the first, this advertisement features former Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: MERGING OF LUXURY-VEHICLE OPERATIONS IS PLANNED
description: Ford Motor will merge the North American business operations of its Aston Martin, Jaguar and Land Rover brands on Sept. 1 as part of an effort to raise sales of the luxury vehicles. The new organization, which is part of Ford's Premier Automotive Group, will perform sales, marketing and dealer relations for all three brands. Mike O'Driscoll, president of Jaguar North America, was named president of the merged group. Ford wants to expand sales of luxury vehicles, which have high profit margins. . Jaguar and Land Rover sold about 37,000 vehicles combined in the United States through July. The leading luxury brands, the Lexus from the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan and the BMW cars from Germany, each sold more than 126,000 vehicles in the period, according to the Autodata Corporation.

title: After the Day of Terror in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: West Nile Virus Found in Woman In Staten Island
description: A 73-year-old woman from Staten Island has tested positive for West Nile virus, becoming possibly the first human case of the virus in New York City this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLMAN, JACK
description: HELLMAN-Jack. The Board of Directors of the United Hebrew Geriatric Center mourns the passing of Mr. Jack Hellman, beloved father of Sheri and Ron Hellman. As a member of our Board of Directors, Ron has been a devoted friend and ardent supporter for many years. Our heartfelt sympathy and prayers are extended to the bereaved family. Peter Lane, President Malcolm Lazarus, Chairman Rita C. Mabli, Exec. Vice President

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about the influence of video games on art misstated the surname of one of those involved in Rhizome, an online repository of new-media art. He is Mark Tribe, not Pride.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Stock Investigation
description: Europe's biggest bank, Deutsche Bank A.G., is being investigated by the Hesse stock market regulator for suspected manipulation of Deutsche Telekom's stock price before it sold 44 million shares for a client. Deutsche Bank sold the shares -- worth 1.04 billion euros ($888 million) -- shortly after one of its analysts reiterated a buy rating on the shares and gave them a target price of 31 euros, the Hesse Exchange Supervisory Authority said. Deutsche Bank sold the shares at 23.60 euros apiece. The transaction, on behalf of an unidentified investor, came more than four weeks before other holders could sell 232 million new shares they received from Deutsche Telekom's $35 billion purchase of the VoiceStream Wireless Corporation in May. Deutsche Telekom's stock closed yesterday at 19.37 euros.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The yen fell after Japan said prospects for its economy were worsening and as officials suggested they did not want to see the yen rise. In New York, the dollar settled at 122.08 yen, compared with 121.92 Thursday.

title: Looking for Balance, the Knicks Trade Rice
description: The Glen Rice experiment is over after one season.

title: Athletics Steamroll Yankees
description: A colossal red tool chest sat on a table in the middle of the Athletics' clubhouse, surrounded by a fleet of remote-control model cars and trucks. The mechanics -- pitcher Jason Isringhausen and others -- tinkered busily before tonight's game, shouting above the persistent noise. Oakland second baseman Frank Menechino asked if the Yankees' clubhouse was like this.

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY/HAUNTED BY MOLD
description: It grows in the walls. It can choke children and render adults senseless. It is becoming homeowners' and insurers' worst nightmare. A report by Lisa Belkin in The Times Magazine.

title: Robert H. Rimmer, 84, Author of 'The Harrad Experiment'
description: Robert H. Rimmer, who wrote ''The Harrad Experiment,'' a 1966 novel about an elite Eastern college where male and female students lived in the same dormitory rooms and did pretty much what came naturally, died on Aug. 1 at his home in Quincy, Mass. He was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVINE, BONNELL
description: IRVINE-Bonnell. On August 9, 2001. Beloved husband of Josephine. Adored father of Cella Irvine. Loving father-in-law to Hart and grandfather to Giovanna and Hudson. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, Tuesday, August 14th, 4:00 PM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to The New York Historical Society, 2 W. 77 St., New York, NY 10024.

title: UAL Sees $270 Million Gain in Galileo
description: The UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, expects a gain of $270 million from the sale of its stake in the travel reservation company Galileo International Inc., which the Cendant Corporation has proposed to buy for $3.5 billion.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Jobs Lost
description: Canada's unemployment rate was unchanged at 7 percent in July, but rising job losses point to a further weakening in the economy. The latest data fueled predictions of another interest rate cut at the end of this month. Statistics Canada said that the economy lost 14,000 jobs in July, of which 12,300 were full-time positions. This brings the reduction in full-time jobs this year through July to 33,000, compared with an increase of 98,000 in the January-to-July period of 2000. Gains in manufacturing, management and administrative jobs in July were offset by a contraction in scientific and technical services, government and construction. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Mets Waste Best Start of Year as Their Modest Streak Ends
description: In the same ballpark against the same opponent, the Mets once had another first inning like this. It feels as if it happened in a different era, but it was really just last October. In Game 4 of the National League Championship Series at Shea Stadium, the Mets scored four runs in the first against the St. Louis Cardinals. The next night, they won the pennant.

title: Serenity and Turbulence With Room for Silence
description: Considering that she's a songwriter, Ely Guerra gives a lot of thought to silence and wordlessness. On Thursday night at the Queens Theater in the Park, she sang about the longing for an intimacy beyond words and for the quiet to find herself. ''Leave some silence,'' she sang in Spanish, ''to understand that a moment can be transcendent.''

title: Orange County Sheriff Settles in Corruption Suit
description: The sheriff of Orange County has admitted in a legal settlement with the state attorney general that he should have known about the corrupt practices of a band of deputies at a foundation they set up to support the Sheriff's Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHOSNER, JULIA (NEE SEEMANN)
description: CHOSNER-Julia (nee Seemann), on August 9, 2001. Wife of the late Bert Lescot and the late Henry Chosner. Graveside services Sunday, 11:30AM at the Mount Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: U.S. Tariff Put On Lumber From Canada
description: Siding with American sawmills, which complained that Canadian lumber producers benefited unfairly from government subsidies, the United States imposed a 19.3 percent tariff on Canadian softwood lumber today.

title: Trying to Balance Science and Humanity
description: As one might expect, Dr. Leon Richard Kass, the University of Chicago professor who will head President Bush's council on bioethics, has written on subjects like cloning, physician-assisted suicide and in-vitro fertilization.

title: Caucasus Abductions Raise Georgian Anxiety
description: Everyone driving out of the international airport here encounters a startling billboard a few miles down the only access road.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: INSIDE
description: New York to Add Capacity

title: Group Seeks Black-Latino Joint Effort For Mayor
description: A group of black elected Democrats, led by Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, has decided against endorsing any of the white Democrats running for New York mayor, and will instead seek to create a black-Latino coalition that is likely to support Fernando Ferrer's bid to become the city's first Puerto Rican mayor, Mr. Rangel said yesterday.

title: Officer in Drunken-Driving Case Posts Bail
description: A police officer charged with killing a pregnant woman, her 4-year-old son and her sister while driving drunk pleaded not guilty and was ordered held in $250,000 bail yesterday in a Brooklyn courtroom packed with friends and relatives of the victims.

title: The Old College Try At Summer Camp; Enriching a High School Rsum Leaves Students Tuckered Out
description: The campers are complaining about how tired they are, but not from strenuous canoe trips, late nights of gossip by flashlight or ghost stories around a campfire.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Khmer Rouge Tribunal
description: After years of delay and false starts, King Norodom Sihanouk signed into law a framework for a tribunal to try former leaders of the Khmer Rouge, which was responsible for the deaths of more than a million people between 1975 and 1979. The framework includes local and foreign judges and prosecutors, and the United Nations must review its provisions before agreeing to participate.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about a Los Angeles County judge's rejection of a $3 billion damage award in a smoker's lawsuit against Philip Morris referred incorrectly to the offer of $100 million that replaced it. The sum was proposed by the judge himself, not offered by Philip Morris.

title: The Stem Cell Decision: No End to the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Far Outspends Mayoral Rivals
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire businessman who wants to be mayor, is continuing to pour money into his campaign at a blistering rate, spending $16 million so far, just two months after going on the stump.

title: Vaudeville Haunts Not So Strange Bedfellows
description: What does Jiminy Glick asking Steve Martin about adult diapers have to do with Mae West asking her maid, Beulah, to peel a grape? Perhaps the heat of summer is warping a writer's sense of proportion, but Martin Short's impersonation of a ripplingly fat and obsequious talk-show host and Mae West's impersonation of a generously built woman of loose morals and tight corsets seem more similar than meets the eye.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Friend Of Rabin Assassin Released
description: An Israeli woman who was jailed for not telling the authorities what she knew about plans to assassinate Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin in 1995 was released from prison after serving two-thirds of her nine-month sentence. In a decision that reopened social and political wounds caused by the Rabin killing, President Moshe Katsav announced last month that he was commuting the sentence of Margalit Har-Shefi, 25. ''If I could have prevented this murder, I would have done everything I could,'' said Ms. Har-Shefi, who was a friend of the assassin, Yigal Amir, who is serving a life sentence.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Rob Reuland, a Brooklyn prosecutor-turned-novelist who lost his job, referred imprecisely to a letter written by State Senator Marty Markowitz. While it congratulated Mr. Reuland on his novel's positive reviews, it did not apologize for an earlier letter criticizing his published remarks about Brooklyn's murder rate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MARSHAK, BEN
description: MARSHAK-Ben. Happy Birthday. We miss you on your birthday today and every day. Much love. Janet, Edward and Alm

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Tax Evasion
description: The top executives of two of South Korea's largest newspapers were questioned by prosecutors about accusations that each of them had evaded approximately $4 million in taxes. The two executives, Bang Sang Hoon, president and publisher of Chosun Ilbo, and Kim Byong Kwan, honorary chairman of Dong A Ilbo, had no comment about the government's four-and-a-half-month audit in which 23 media companies were ordered to pay $388 million in back taxes and penalties. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Bloomberg Has Spent $16 Million on Race
description: Michael R. Bloomberg is continuing to pour money into his campaign at a rapid pace, spending $16 million in the two months he has been running.

title: Randolph All-Stars Lose to Delaware
description: The team from Wilmington, Del., beat Randolph, N.J., 4-3, yesterday in the Eastern Regional Little League tournament in Bristol, Conn.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Ruling Voids Part Of Drug Law
description: A federal appeals court panel has struck down a federal law that lets judges, after a jury conviction, add years to a prison term for a drug-trafficking offense based on the amount of drugs involved. In a 2-to-1 decision that may affect thousands of cases in nine Western states, the panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit said the law violated the constitutional right to a jury trial.

title: Days Before Signing of Macedonia Pact, Mines Kill Seven Soldiers
description: Tensions mounted here again today when seven additional soldiers were killed as their truck ran over two mines a few miles from Skopje, the capital. Nine other soldiers were wounded.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Farmers Denied Bail
description: The 21 white farmers who were jailed after a melee this week with black squatters near the northern city of Chinhoyi were denied bail, state television reported. The magistrate said the defendants' petition to be released was outweighed by the court's concern that the men might flee the country and its fear that they would not be safe in the community, which has been on edge since the confrontation. The case will return to court later this month.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the stage and television actor Martin Huston on Thursday misstated the date of his death in some copies. It was Aug. 1, not Aug. 8.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suharto Cooperation
description: The family of former President Suharto promised to help hand over one of his sons, Hutomo Mandala Putra, the police said. The son, known as Tommy Suharto, has been on the run since November, when he was sentenced to 18 months in jail for graft. The police now say they suspect him in the murder this month of one of the judges who sentenced him.

title: President Bush Finds His Voice
description: When President Bush addressed the nation on stem cell research from Crawford, Tex., on Thursday, he seemed unnaturally stiff and uncomfortable. He was right to feel awkward. The debate on stem cell research was a surprise conundrum, the first of his presidency, and the speech he was giving was a balancing act of three presidential decision-making styles, which we will probably see a lot more of.

title: When a Writer Is Punished for Not Being an Author
description: IF you see a child in the street with a car coming, you're going to step in and help,'' Vanessa Leggett said. ''I'm not a martyr, but I just don't think anyone else would act any differently if they were in my situation.''

title: Wicks Returns as Liberty Rallies to Defeat Miracle
description: At the start of the season, the Liberty set several goals, among them winning at least 13 of its 16 regular-season home games. Although the Liberty fell short of another goal -- defending its Eastern Conference regular-season title -- it reached its home-court objective last night by defeating the Orlando Miracle, 77-67, before 17,163 at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Stem Cell Decision: No End to the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Stem Cell Decision: No End to the Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Ipanema Journal; Still Tall and Tan, a Muse Fights for a Title
description: Helosa Pinheiro, better known as Hel, is undeniably the girl from Ipanema. Four decades ago, the mere sight of her walking inspired a hit song. But if the heirs of the two men who wrote it have their way, Ms. Pinheiro is going to have to give up the title.

title: A Long Process That Led Bush To His Decision
description: During his first weeks in office, President Bush and his advisers knew that a decision on federal financing for embryonic stem cell research awaited them, and they loosely set the middle of March as a potential target date to announce it, one senior administration official said.

title: Rumsfeld in Russia: Less ABM, More Warm Ties
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is about to travel 10,000 miles to Moscow and back for one day of talks on missile defense and nuclear reductions at which no agreements are expected -- because, many officials believe, the outcome is preordained and the American position has prevailed.

title: 'Illegal' Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Two Weeks in the Aegean
description: Swan Hellenic Cruises is trimming 15 percent from three cruises on its 300-passenger Minerva August through October. A 15-day Aegean cruise leaves Thessalonika, Greece, on Aug. 26 and ends in Izmir, Turkey. With the discount, fares begin at $4,318 a person, based on double occupancy. On Sept. 9, a 15-day cruise to Turkey, Greece and Cyprus starts in Izmir; prices from $4,346 a person, double occupancy. And on Oct. 7, a 15-day cruise to Greece, Albania, Croatia and Italy begins in Crete; rates begin at $4,453 a person, double occupancy. Prices include all shore excursions, transfers and tips, and round-trip air fare from London. Call (877) 219-4239 or www.swanhellenic.com .

title: Turkey Delays Ruling in Case Of Violations By U.S. Muslim
description: A court delayed a decision today on charges against a Muslim cleric from New York who was imprisoned for wearing clerical clothing and holding an unofficial prayer meeting in an apartment. The criminal court judge in this Aegean Coast city said he would decide next month on the case of Aydogan Fuat, a Sufi leader with a small following in New York.

title: 3 Executives Given Prison Terms For Rigging Food Bids to Schools
description: Three food company executives were sentenced to prison terms and ordered to pay fines this week after pleading guilty this year to charges that they rigged bids on more than $200 million of food contracts awarded by the New York City Board of Education.

title: Power Seeks to Gain Playoff Berth Today
description: The objective for the Power going into today's regular-season finale against the Washington Freedom is very simple. Win or tie, and it qualifies for the W.U.S.A. playoffs. Lose and it will have to hope that last place Carolina defeats San Diego tomorrow. And being that San Diego has not lost a game in nearly three weeks, Power striker Tiffeny Milbrett does not see losing as an alternative.

title: Albanians' Many Children Unnerve Macedonia's Slavs
description: The girl was blessedly ordinary, if viewed as a newborn and nothing else. Healthy, peachy, maybe a little wrinkly in the face, she was fast asleep two hours after coming into the world, the third daughter of a tired 28-year-old Albanian woman, Samije Jusufi.

title: Campaign Briefing | City Council Ballots: Knocked Off, But Not Out
description: Dozens of City Council candidates are still clinging to the corners of the ballot in race after race. George Martinez, the Democratic challenger to incumbent Angel Rodriguez in the 38th District in Brooklyn, says he will appeal this week's decision in State Supreme Court that knocked him off the ballot. He says Mr. Rodriguez's campaign is waging war with him because he's an insurgent working from his home. But Jeffrey C. Feldman, executive director of the Brooklyn Democratic Party, said Mr. Martinez's campaign interchanged addresses for Hispanic residents with the same names to try to validate certain signatures and allowed Mr. Martinez's father to sign as the witness on petitions that had been gathered by others. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, MARY
description: RYAN-Mary. On August 9, 2001. Beloved wife of the late John Ryan. Loving mother of John, Sister Maryellen S.U.S.C., Michael, Margaret Admirand and Patrick. Devoted grandmother of nine. Reposing at the O'Shea-Hoey Funeral Home, Inc. 29-13 Ditmars Blvd. Astoria, Saturday and Sunday 2-5 & 7-9:30 PM. Mass of the Resurrection will be at the Immaculate Conception Church, Astoria, Monday the 13th day of August at 9:45 AM. Burial to follow in the Sleepyhollow Cemetery, Tarrytown, NY. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Holy Union Sisters Missionary Retirement Fund at St. Mary's Church, 28 Attorney St, NY, NY 10002 C/O Sr. Maryellen Ryan.

title: Allies Bomb Iraqi Air Defenses In Biggest Attack in 6 Months
description: In the strongest attack on Iraq since February, American and British planes bombed three air defense sites in southern Iraq today, a response to Saddam Hussein's increasingly aggressive actions against allied pilots, the Pentagon said.

title: Joanne Minnich, 58, a Subject of Extraordinary Heart Surgery, Dies
description: Joanne Minnich, whose heart was cut out last November for removal of a cancer and then returned in an extraordinary operation that drew widespread attention, died on Thursday at her home in Mahopac, N.Y. She was 58.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Official Is Returned
description: Wearing a bulletproof vest and surrounded by security guards, former Secretary of Tourism Oscar Espinosa, the highest ranking former public official to be extradited to Mexico to face corruption charges, was returned to Mexico City. Mr. Espinosa, who fled Mexico last year and had been living under house arrest in Nicaragua, faces charges that he embezzled more than $45 million in government money during his time as the mayor of Mexico City, from 1994 to 1997. Mr. Espinosa has said that the charges against him are part of an effort to discredit him by the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party, which won control of the Mexico City government in 1997.

title: After the Day of Terror in Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title: Though Not at Her Best, Jones Overcomes Defeat to Win 200
description: Soothing but not erasing unpleasant memories of her stunning loss in the world championship 100 meters, Marion Jones returned to gold-medal form tonight, if not quite to top form, with a victory in the 200 that clearly came as a relief.

title: BIG AIRLINES RELAX STAY-OVER POLICY FOR LOWER FARES
description: For more than 20 years, the Saturday night stay-over has been the bane of corporate travel, with airlines forcing businesspeople to choose between being home for the weekend or getting a cheap fare. The airlines' bet -- that business travelers would pay more for less restrictive tickets -- paid off handsomely, helping turn them into the carriers' most profitable customers.

title: Campaign Briefing | Public Advocate Contest: Defending Ousted Schools Head
description: At the very same fund-raiser, Ms. Gotbaum took up a not-so-popular cause, coming to the defense of Patricia Zedalis, who was forced out of her job as head of the Board of Education's division of school facilities. Although plenty of political candidates have been assessing blame for the $2.8 billion in projected overruns in the $7 billion school construction budget, Ms. Gotbaum cited Ms. Zedalis's 20-year record in public service. She pledged: ''As watchdog, I do hope, Patricia, that I will be able to hold the School Construction Authority accountable. Somebody's got to do it and this is one of the great disgraces of New York. The School Construction Authority is supposed to build and renovate our schools. They have a $7 billion budget, the cost overruns are unbelievable and they are blaming Patricia.'' Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBINSON, GRACE (NEE CRISPINELLI)
description: ROBINSON-Grace (nee Crispinelli) of Elmsford and White Plains, NY. Good and loving wife of Frank, cherished daughter of Florence and Adam Crispinelli and beloved niece of Joan Crispinelli, Marion Rainaldi and Clara Rosner. Grace's untimely passing on August 9, 2001 has left her cousins and members of the Berglund, Crispinelli, Imperato, McGeary, Rainaldi, Robinson and Vetrano families with a profound sense of bereavement. During a teaching career, which spanned over 25 years, 12 of which were spent as a member of the religious order of The Divine Compassion, Grace touched the lives of parents, students and colleagues of the Westchester educational community. Grace will be missed by all who knew her and who now share in the grief and pain of her loss. A wake will be held Saturday and Sunday, August 11 and 12, from 35PM and 7-9PM at McElroy-Flynn Funeral Home, Elmsford, New York. A Mass of Christial Burial will be celebrated at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church in Elmsford on Monday, August 13 at 10:00 AM. Interment will be at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Economy Shrinks
description: Singapore's economy shrank an annual 10.7 percent in the second quarter from the first, more than earlier estimated, as falling electronics exports forced companies to cut production. The decline compares with an earlier estimate of a 10.1 percent contraction and confirms that Singapore is in recession for the second time since 1998 after the economy shrank an annual 10.8 percent in the first three months. Singapore maintained its 2001 growth forecast of 0.5 percent to 1.5 percent.

title: The Giants Show Little Life, and Tumble to the Patriots
description: The first preseason game of the year was never designed to make the Giants forget their Super Bowl defeat more than six months ago. To that end, the Giants' 14-0 loss to the New England Patriots tonight certainly did not overstep its aim. Next, the Giants will have to try to forget their uninspiring performance against the Patriots.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Unshakable Hand
description: Forget the rough-and-tumble of city politics, or even the competitive swing he showed at a game of stickball earlier this week with Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Green. Sporting a bandaged hand that left him unable to do the customary glad-handing yesterday, Mr. Vallone chalked his wound up to a game of volleyball with his son. Mr. Vallone's spokesman, Mattis Goldman, explained that he ''went up for a block, and the ball slammed into his thumb.''

title: Subject Of Homers Follows McGwire
description: Mark McGwire looked almost incredulous, with a half smile, when he was asked about the chances of his home run record being broken.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, SHOSHANA
description: GREENBAUM-Shoshana. The Officers, Directors, Administration, Staff, Students and Alumni of the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach note with profound sorrow the tragic murder of Morah Shoshana (Hayman) Greenbaum A''H, H''YD esteemed and beloved HALB Morah for the past decade; beloved wife of Shmuel Greenbaum and beloved daughter of Dr Alan and Shifra Hayman of Los Angeles. May the Almighty console the bereaved family, as well as the entire community, amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Lawyers Are Asking, How Secret Is a Secret?
description: If you're going to confide in someone, who should it be: a doctor, a psychotherapist or a lawyer? This is not the beginning of a joke.

description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Censures Two Big Firms On Charges Of 'Pumping'
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured ABN Amro and Oechsle International Advisors yesterday in what the agency called its first major enforcement action related to a Wall Street practice known as portfolio pumping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEINBERG, MILTON H.
description: FEINBERG-Milton H. Age ninety, formerly of New York, died August 9, 2001 in Kalamazoo, MI. Survived by his wife, Rena; two sons, Arthur N. and Seth J. Feinberg; three grandchildren, Lisa, Daniel and Alexander Feinberg.

title: U.S. Acts Quickly to Put Stem Cell Policy in Effect
description: Keenly aware of misgivings among patients' groups and scientists about the limits President Bush placed on federal financing for human embryonic stem cell research, the administration moved quickly today to put its plan into effect and announced that grant money would be available for the studies by early next year.

title: How My Electric Car Saves the World
description: My father would have had a few things to say to those automakers grumbling about government-mandated gas-mileage standards. He would have waved his fist in the direction of Detroit and thundered: ''Global warming! Alternative energy!''

title: Executive at Sony Pictures Delays Departure, to 2003
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment said yesterday that its chief executive, John Calley, who had been scheduled to retire in October, would stay on through March 2003.

title: Ex-Chief Will Leave Archer Daniels Board
description: Dwayne O. Andreas plans to step down from the board of Archer Daniels Midland in November, completing his exit from the company's management after more than three decades.

title: Opening Up A Bottleneck For Power; New York Acts to Modernize A Creaky Electricity Grid
description: Every time a heat wave pushes up electric use, operators at the New York Power Authority's transmission control center here face a frustrating challenge. There may be ample, inexpensive power to the north and west, huge demand in the megalopolis to the southeast and in between a transmission grid with lots of lines that are underused.

title: China With Food, and Freedom Too
description: During an interview with The Times this week, Jiang Zemin made a particularly revealing remark. ''I am 75 years old now,'' said Mr. Jiang, China's president, ''. . . and I can tell you with certainty: Should China apply the parliamentary democracy of the Western world, the only result will be that 1.2 billion Chinese people will not have enough food to eat. The result will be great chaos. . . .''

title: Star Hasn't Dimmed For Ageless Gelding
description: He is thoroughbred racing's answer to Jack Nicholson: seasoned (read old), pampered (turned out on the farm seven months a year with a devoted personal trainer) and accomplished (16 victories, $1.5 million in earnings). John's Call even projects old-world glamour: he sports a mask and sunglasses when walking outside his barn here to shield him from the sunshine to which he is allergic.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about a Los Angeles County judge's rejection of a $3 billion damage award in a smoker's lawsuit against Philip Morris referred incorrectly to the offer of $100 million that replaced it. The sum was proposed by the judge himself, not offered by Philip Morris.

title: Colombian Cattle Ranchers Set to Exploit a Big Break
description: Among Latin American beef exporters, Argentina and Brazil have always been the giants, and Colombia hardly figured at all. Now, though, ranchers in Colombia's seven northern provinces say they have achieved an edge over rival countries, one that they hope to turn quickly into lucrative global export sales: their herds have been certified free of foot-and-mouth disease.

title: Harvard, Feeling Squeezed, Looks to Boston, but Volunteers to Move Are Few
description: To promote Harvard University's expansion across the Charles River into Boston, administrators do not flash futuristic blueprints of architectural magnificence. Instead, they offer a before-and-after slide show from the university's 365-year history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELLMAN, JEANETTE
description: ELLMAN-Jeanette Happy birthday. We miss you. With eternal love, your family

title: The Wronged Man: C.I.A. Officer Mistaken for Spy Down the Street
description: Three months ago, the Central Intelligence Agency quietly reinstated a senior counterintelligence officer who had spent 18 months under investigation as a suspected Russian spy. There was no ceremony, no fanfare, no formal apology as he returned from professional exile. But in effect, the C.I.A was saying there had been a terrible mistake.

title: Remembrance Of Holocaust Has No Room For Irony
description: A controversy over a fund-raising campaign using the line ''The Holocaust Never Happened,'' subsided today with the removal of a billboard overlooking the site of a proposed Holocaust memorial near the Brandenburg Gate.

title: U.S. Argues Against Delay That Microsoft Is Seeking
description: The government urged a federal appeals court here today to swiftly send the Microsoft antitrust case to a new federal district judge to consider the remaining legal issues and set a new remedy.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Development Blocked
description: Environmentalists struggling to preserve one of the world's last sanctuaries for endangered green and loggerhead sea turtles won a significant victory this week when government authorities halted plans for the development of a resort hotel on a seaside property about 70 miles south of Cancn. The Spanish developer Sol Mela had purchased the Xcacel beach (pronounced shkah-SELL) for the construction of a 1,400-room resort. But after a series of public hearings, during which residents expressed their concerns about losing an important turtle nesting ground, government officials determined that water runoff from the hotel could harm the habitat. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Record Bid Ends For Team Adventure
description: Team Adventure's attempt at the transatlantic record ended at 5:30 a.m. yesterday, 110 miles south of Cape Sable, Nova Scotia, when the port bow broke. The crew is still assessing the damage, but it appears the boat struck something floating just below the water's surface.

title: Kerik Fires 3 For Drinking Near Station
description: Three police officers who drank beer after work outside their station house with a colleague in the hours before the authorities say he killed four people with his van were abruptly fired yesterday. At the same time, police officials began a citywide inquiry into whether supervision was adequate on the midnight-to-8-a.m. shift that the officers worked.

title: Lou Boudreau, a Longtime Player-Manager and Hall of Fame Shortstop, Dies at 84
description: Lou Boudreau, the Hall of Fame shortstop who both managed the 1948 Cleveland Indians and played inspired shortstop to lead them to their first American League pennant in 28 years and the World Series championship, died yesterday at a hospital in Olympia Fields, Ill. He was 84.

title: Cautious Concern on Arena Is Voiced by Newark Council
description: For the last several months, as officials around New Jersey have debated whether to help build a sports arena in downtown Newark, this city has spoken with one voice in support of it.

title: Club Owner Charged With Employing 14-Year-Old Topless Dancer
description: The police in Suffolk County said today that they had charged the owner of a Farmingdale nightclub with hiring a 14-year-old girl as a topless dancer.

title: More Room in the Skies
description: Flying out of La Guardia Airport is less of an ordeal these days than it was last fall, thanks to rationing imposed by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the airport's operator, and the Federal Aviation Administration. The two agencies acted late last year after Congress lifted longstanding limits on the number of daily flights allowed at La Guardia. Congress had intended to encourage more competition to underserved markets, but the airport was quickly overwhelmed as airlines rushed to add hundreds of takeoffs and landings a day. Three-quarters of flights were delayed more than 15 minutes last fall, and the airport accounted for one-fourth of all delays nationwide in 2000.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Executive Named
description: The struggling Swiss drug company Roche Holding named Erich Hunziker as its chief financial officer three months after letting the previous executive in the post go. Mr. Hunziker, 48, is now chief executive of Diethelm Keller, an international trading group, and had previously worked at Corange Ltd., a holding company Roche bought in 1997. The family-controlled Roche has been plagued by stagnant pharmaceutical sales and uncertainty because of the large stake bought by a rival, Novartis. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Knoblauch Is Rescued From the Waiver Pile
description: Chuck Knoblauch was claimed on waivers by another team earlier this month, but the Yankees chose to pull him back, rather than trade him or lose him for the minimal waiver fee.

title: Bridgestone Loss Is $251 Million
description: The Bridgestone Corporation reported a loss of 30.57 billion yen, or $251 million, today for its first half because of a sweeping tire recall and restructuring costs at its United States subsidiary, Bridgestone/Firestone.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Endorsement By Sunshade
description: If you were sitting in the park next to City Hall last week and suddenly spied a lot of leather sandals and organic cotton T-shirts, chances are a Mark Green endorsement rally was afoot. Mr. Green, who has tried to hang tightly to the middle of the political road when he's on the campaign trail, was surrounded by members of the Working Families Party, a party dominated by unions and community groups, including Acorn, the Association for Community Organization for Reform Now. And some Acorn members also stood on the steps of City Hall last week with Mr. Green as he called for abolishing the community school board system. While the blistering sun got to other candidates and those who endorsed them -- many wearing dark suits and ties -- Mr. Green's supporters went for super-cool, sporting tunics and random braided objects, including hair. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Britain Suspends Ulster's Home Rule, Stirring Concerns for Fragile Peace
description: Britain ordered the temporary suspension of Northern Ireland's home-rule government today, hoping to win time for renewed negotiations to resolve the stalled effort to end 30 years of conflict that has claimed 3,600 lives.

title: Sports of The Times; Layden's Moves Fail To Jazz Up Knicks
description: THE Knicks officially became Scott Layden's team last night, if not necessarily a better one. Two useful players he got credit for bringing to Utah without great fanfare became the latest names in a lineup from which we still can't pick out the new player who changes the Knicks from a nice team in a slow slide into one with serious playoff hang time.

title: For the Elderly, a Test Of Civics and Mettle, Too
description: WHY is the president's time in office limited to two terms?'' Menachem Sperling asked this spring as he sat in front of his 10 elderly students at the offices of the Brooklyn Refugee Project, a nonprofit group in Brighton Beach. ''Eight years,'' replied Yevgenia Pivovarova, 72. Mr. Sperling, frustrated at the wrong answer, exclaimed, ''Why?'' Ms. Pivovarova replied apologetically in her broken English, ''Big problem to see the American speech.''

title: At Least The Plan Will Float
description: IN a single morning last weekend, my 10-year-old nephew and I figured out how to end New Jersey's long-running trash war with New York, solved whatever financial problems the state government has and achieved several breakthroughs in classical physics. Also, one of us made a complete fool of himself in front of his entire town.

title: Interest Due To Co-ops On Escrow
description: FOR years, the Midland Gardens Owners Inc. -- a 230-unit co-op in Bronxville -- had earned interest on co-op money deposited in a tax escrow account held by the corporation's underlying mortgage lender. When the lender assigned its mortgage to another investor, however, the interest payments suddenly stopped.

title: Yegorova and Jones at Center Stage
description: Spreading a world track and field championship over 10 days leaves ample room for down time: days and nights thin on medals or memorable occasions. But the next-to-last day in this biennial event was as overstuffed as other sessions have been undernourished.

title: Allies on the Ticket Line: Bonding Against an Invader
description: THE SETTING -- With the dogged theatergoers waiting in line to buy tickets to ''The Producers'' on Wednesday. The line had its beginnings at 2:30 a.m., when Jad Michaelson, who works in Korea as an English language teacher, staked out a grubby sidewalk square near the entrance to the St. James Theater on West 44th Street.

Schwikert, 16, took her first national senior all-around title. Uzelac, 15, became the first woman to win the national junior all-around championship three times.

title: For Thrill-Ride Seekers
description: Although Amusementpark.com can be a bumpy ride, as Web sites go, it does offer one more research source for family-vacation planning. The site offers savings on admission tickets, which can be delivered by mail. It also includes news releases from theme parks, users' reviews of rides and attractions, and virtual tours of the parks. The site sells tickets to many major parks, including Walt Disney World, and the Universal and Busch parks, but not to Disneyland or the adjacent California Adventure park. Its listing of attractions nationwide includes zoos, water parks and botanical gardens, but it is by no means complete -- the Bronx Zoo and New York Botanical Garden are not included.

description: JACOBY-D. Paul. Of Palm Beach, FL, age 98. Retired partner of Asiel and Co. Beloved father of Jim, Jayne, Mark and Debbie. Adored grandfather of Karen, Richard, Jill, Matt, Laurie, Brian, Jon, Jenny and Ali. Cherished great-grandfather of Samantha, Jacob, Sarah, Anna, Nathan and Rebecca. His legacy is his ''family of love.''

title: McEwing's Light Shines on a Dreary Day
description: It was a dreadful afternoon for a game at Shea Stadium. A sprinkling rain delayed the first pitch by 62 minutes, and the skies were mostly gray. The Mets are slogging through a disappointing season, so their soggy fans needed to search for hope as Mark McGwire went deep into history yesterday. For the fans, it was a good day to watch Joe McEwing, because any day is good for that.

description: THEY'RE out there, circling. Not vultures, just crazed Kiehl's customers, impatient for the store at 109 Third Avenue at 13th Street to open for business at 10 a.m. Half a dozen 20-something women, for whom a 30-minute wait to buy their Tea Tree Oil Body Cleanser or Pineapple Papaya Facial Scrub seems tantamount to torture.

description: Katherine Hope Maggiotto, the daughter of Susan and Louis Maggiotto Jr. of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married on Friday evening to Timothy Scott Mehok, a son of Sue Mehok of Lake Worth, Fla., and John S. Mehok of Alexandria, Va. Jeanette Jones, a justice of the peace of Falmouth, Mass., officiated there at the Coonamessett Inn.

title: Exuding French Charm in Greenport
description: AS the song says, ''The times, they are a-changin'.'' But, despite the arrival of multimillion-dollar wineries, the North Fork retains a time-capsule, rural charm. Even in hamlets like Greenport, where gentrification has been most noticeable, there is an appealing blend of old and new.

title: OFF-TRACK BETTING
description: Acting Governor Donald DiFrancesco last week signed legislation that could bring up to 15 off-track betting facilities to the state. The New Jersey Racing Commission will supervise the venture, which expects to generate $500 million in wagers over the next five years. The commission plans eight parlors in the next two years at sites that have yet to be chosen; municipalities can veto their selection. The centers are described as upscale sports bars that will serve food and alcohol and show simulcast horse reaces. The legislation also allows accounts for telephone betting. Those who bet at the parlors on by phone must be 18 or older. John Holl

title: Near Vast Bodies of Water, Land Lies Parched
description: People who live at the emerald edge of this Chicago suburb have noticed that something seems out of whack this year. The water that once sustained a little pocket of life -- beavers, muskrats, frogs and cattails -- has disappeared, and the land around it looks puckered, despite a wet spring.

title: Ideas & Trends: Squeeze Play; A New Threat to the President's Agenda: The Tax Cut
description: THE way President Bush and his allies on Capitol Hill had it figured, passing a big tax cut would do more than score political points and boost the weakened economy. It would also take much of the projected budget surplus off the table, therefore imposing fiscal discipline on Congress and depriving the Democrats of the oxygen that sustains them in the battles over the size of government.

title: Even the Commissioner Does Two-a-Days
description: Paul Tagliabue is at 13,000 feet, in a slick Hawker 800 corporate jet traveling 500 miles an hour. His seat is comfortable leather and there is enough room, barely, for his 6-foot-5 frame to stretch out. Tagliabue should be relaxed but there is concern on his face, and it has nothing to do with the turbulence shaking the plane as it leaves Teterboro Airport in Bergen County, N.J., for Albany, the site of the Giants' training camp.

title: Habitats/Morningside Heights; Retired Teacher's Home Is Where the Heart Is
description: SALESMEN for real estate in Florida and Arizona would have people believe that every retiree in the Northeast who can afford it eventually moves to a warmer climate, away from the places they have spent decades of their lives. But actually the vast majority of people who retire remain in the towns and cities where they have been living; they stay in the places that for one reason or another they love.

title: August 5-11; Another Pricey Clinton Book
description: Former President Bill Clinton sold the rights to his memoir for a record advance of over $10 million to the publishing house Alfred A. Knopf. Knopf has scheduled its publication for 2003, the same year that Simon & Schuster has scheduled the publication of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's book, for which she was given an advance of about $8 million. That could set the stage for a race between publishers, but Robert Barnett, a lawyer handling the Clintons' book deals, said the publications will be coordinated.

title: North Hempstead's Move On Personal Watercraft
description: The article about action by Northport and Asharoken to restrict jet skiing in their territorial waters [''For Jet Skiers, A Little Less V-r-r-o-o-o-o-m,'' July 22] did not mention the local law prohibiting Jet Skis and similar personal watercraft recently passed by North Hempstead.

description: MARK BURBANK worked on the equipment in the strength room here at the Burke Adult Fitness Center, undistracted by the hum of like-minded people performing similar exercises on stationary bicycles, treadmills and weight machines.

Military Order of the Purple Heart. Husband, father, and grandfather. He is survived by his wife Julia, his four children Alison, Wendy, Adam, Peter and his four grandchildren Robin, Tarah, Kyle and Ethan.

title: August 5-11; Powerful Cuban Group Splits
description: Saying its ideology has softened, nearly two dozen members resigned from the board of the Cuban American National Foundation, the leading Cuban exile group. Known for pressing its anti-Castro cause in Washington and rallying Cuban refugees behind its agenda in Miami, the group is undergoing a divisive transition that pits old-school hard-liners against more moderate younger leaders.

title: A Social Security Solution
description: The overriding questions facing all Americans concerned that Social Security survive and thrive in the 21st century are fairly simple: Should Social Security save and invest for the future? And if so, who should do the saving, individual workers or the federal government? The President's Commission to Strengthen Social Security, on which I serve, dealt with these questions in its report released last month. The answers will determine the direction Social Security takes in coming decades.

title: Yonkers Gadfly Turns to Ministry
description: SINCE July 1999, Anthony J. Iovine has run The Yonkers Citizen, a Web site specializing in antagonistic news articles about City Hall.

title: A Century of Joy for Disabled Children
description: TUCKED away off a quiet country road in the backwoods of Southampton, there's a place where children have been going for a hundred summers now to learn who they can be. All have crippling disabilities -- cerebral palsy, spina bifida, juvenile rheumatoid arthritis -- that they can conquer by having fun, learning new skills and just being with other children with similar problems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PICKETT, RICHARD C. ''DICK''
description: PICKETT-Richard C. ''Dick''. Age 69 of Whitewater, WI, formerly of Deerfield, IL, died Thursday, August 9, 2001 at his home. He was born in New York City, NY on September 30, 1931 the son of Carlton and Mae (McRedmond) Pickett. He attended Fordham University, graduating in 1952, and later attended NYU Graduate School of Business Administration. He served in the U.S. Navy from 1954 to 1958. He married Patricia Dietzler on June 4, 1960 in Chicago, IL. Mr. Pickett had been employed, from 1953 to 1955, by Wm. Esty Co. as a timebuyer, for advertising. He then was hired by Foote, Cone and Belding, Inc. in New York starting as a timebuyer and worked his way to the position of Vice President, Associate Media Director, working for Post-Keyes-Gardner Inc. until 1969, rising to Sr. Vice President. In 1969 he became one of the first men to start his own media and marketing agency, the Media Bureau International, owning and operating that company until his retirement in 1991. He was a member of the Whitewater Country Club and enjoyed helping out people in the community in any way he could. He is survived by: his former wife Patricia of Northbrook, IL, two sons-William C. Pickett of Mount Prospect, IL and Michael R. Pickett of Southfield, MI, twin daughters-Victoria L. Walther of Gurnee, IL and Mary T. Knodle of Arlington Heights, IL, three granddaughters-Gretchen Knodle, Nora Walther and Emma Pickett and one sister-Maureen (Dr. Francis) Thomas of Madison, CT, many other relatives and friends. He was preceded in death by his parents. Visitation will be held on Tuesday, August 14, 2001 at the Olsen Funeral Home in Whitewater from 4 to 8 PM, then at the McMurrough Chapel in Libertyville, IL on Wednesday, August 15, from 4 to 9 PM. Funeral Mass will be held on Thursday, August 16, at 10:30 AM, at St. James Catholic Church, 820 North Arlington Heights Road in Arlington Heights, IL with the Rev. Bill Zavaski officiating. Burial at All Saints Cemetery in Des Plaines, IL will follow. In lieu of flowers the family is requesting memorial contributions be made to the Mercy Assisted Care Hospice in Janesville, WI.

title: S.I. Woman With West Nile Is City's First Case of the Year
description: Health officials determined yesterday that a 73-year-old Staten Island woman with West Nile virus contracted the disease recently, making her the first human victim in New York City this year.

title: Saratoga Victory Serves As Justice
description: No one blamed Jonathan Sheppard for the tremor in his hand that rocked his binoculars as With Anticipation rounded the final turn today in the Sword Dancer Invitational Handicap. With Anticipation, his gray flash, had led virtually every step of the way in the mile-and-a-half marathon, but only 41 days ago, Sheppard had seen things fall apart in the stretch.

title: The First Timing Pattern for the New Jets Coach Is the Bus Trip

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPA, DR. DOMENICK
description: PAPA-Dr. Domenick. A key contributor to the growth and success of Schering-Plough Corporation, died Sunday at his home in Scottsdale, AZ. He was 88. Concluding a career with Schering as Vice President, Corporate Scientific Liaison, Dr. Papa secured licensing agreements with several foreign companies such as Glaxo. He was also responsible for securing the patent for the antibiotic Garamicyn. Prior to this, as Co-Director of Scientific Research for Schering, Dr. Papa was instrumental in the development of the Trimeton family of drugs, some of which are still key products for the company today. In 1958, Dr. Papa received an award from the nation of Chile, recognizing his accomplishments in the development of an x-ray contrast agent, Priodax. However, what Dr. Papa considered his ''greatest triumph'' was the awarding of patents to Schering for Prednisone and Prednisolone following a long battle with several larger competing companies. Over the course of his career, Dr. Papa authored or coauthored over 60 papers in organic and medicinal chemistry. Also, Dr. Papa was named as inventor or co-inventor on 40 U.S. patents and several hundred corresponding foreign patents. Concurrent with his career as a chemist, Dr. Papa enjoyed extensive travel to Europe, South America and Asia. He developed an affinity for gourmet cooking and was as fond of his ''Skillet'' diploma as he was any of his other professional accomplishments. Following his retirement from Schering in 1976, he pursued a very active and successful enterprise in antique furniture collecting and restoration. Dr. Papa was born in NYC in 1913, graduated from Brooklyn College in 1935 and earned Masters and Doctoral degrees from Columbia University. He lived in NJ until early 1998 when he and his wife relocated to AZ. Dr. Papa is survived by his wife RoseMarie, daughters Fay, Janice and Cynthia, son William, brother Joseph, sister Mary, four grandchildren and one greatgrandson. Messinger Indian School Mortuary, Scottsdale, AZ.

title: A Reggie for an Andrew Jackson
description: Think of it as an ''Antiques Roadshow'' for baseball card collectors. Alan Rosen of Montvale knows all about what autographed bats, gloves, photographs and especially baseball cards are worth, and he will be at the Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center in Little Falls today from 2 to 6 p.m. to appraise visitors' items. Mr. Rosen, who got the nickname Mr. Mint during his Paterson childhood for his obsession with mint-condition baseball cards, has been a full-time dealer since 1982, and says he's bought and sold $115 million worth of baseball collectibles and his clients include Spike Lee, Len Berman and Reggie Jackson. Unlike the mavens on the PBS show, Mr. Rosen will put his money where his expertise is -- he may make offers, and will have $100,000 in cash on hand to make good on them. There is a limit of five items per person. If your mom sold your childhood baseball card collection, you learn what you lost. The museum, on the Montclair State University campus at 8 Quarry Road in Little Falls, will charge standard admission ($4; $2 for students and children; those 5 and younger are admitted free) for the event. Information: (973) 655-2378 or www.yogiberramuseum.org.

title: Faking It
description: Michael Lewis's engrossing article (July 15) is essentially about how poorly our criminal justice system treats the people who become entangled in it. Marcus Arnold spent his time responding to questions from those who have nowhere else to turn for advice. Defendants who cannot afford counsel cannot obtain even minimally adequate assistance. Public defenders typically handle thousands of cases a year.

title: AGRICULTURE SECRETARY RESIGNING
description: Art Brown Jr. is stepping down as New Jersey agriculture secretary, a position he has held since 1982. He is resigning effective Dec. 1 to take become part of the faculty at Cook College, Rutgers University in New Brunswick beginning sometime next year. Mr. Brown has served under four governors. Although New Jersey is the most urban state in the nation, the state ranks third in the Northeast in agricultural production and annually ranks in the top 10 nationally in the production of a number of fruits and vegetables. The eight-member State Board of Agriculture and the governor will appoint a successor.

Coop's Roadmap Guide to Volcanoes gives driving directions, the date of the most recent eruption and a telephone number for more information for each volcano.

title: Toy Story 3: A Shrinky Dink Comeback
description: In 1973, Betty J. Morris was a den mother trying to keep a pack of 10-year-old Cub Scouts busy. In a craft book, she and a friend learned of a plastic lid that shrinks in an oven. That sounded interesting, but the lids were too small to be much fun. Mrs. Morris found a company willing to send her plastic sheets, if she bought 1,000 pounds. She persuaded them to give her a dozen-sheet sample. The scouts loved coloring and then shrinking the plastic so much that they often fought over the scraps. Mrs. Morris organized a company to market the new toy and ordered the full shipment. When it arrived, her garage floor cracked.

title: The Joys of Being Watched
description: The characters in Elizabeth Searle's new collection, CELEBRITIES IN DISGRACE (Graywolf, paper, $14), don't jump off the pages so much as cling to them for dear life. An avalanche of sexual tension propels these narratives -- five short stories and one novella -- toward the occasional moment of self-discovery. The title novella, which features a woman who wants to portray the skater Nancy Kerrigan in a television movie, is a miniature masterpiece that holds a dirty mirror up to our often obsessive fascination with the rich and famous. Searle examines the tenuous relationship between one's public and private personas. Many of his characters are most comfortable in front of a camera or some imagined audience, and they gladly accept the personal compromises that accompany fame, or even infamy. The epiphany, if it comes, is awash in things that resemble bodily fluids, like the beige-pink makeup stain smeared on a burial dress that was owned by a spinster aunt in ''What It's Worth.'' Elsewhere a foil-wrapped condom is mistaken for a Hershey's Kiss, and ketchup is used to simulate blood in an amateur film production of Stephen King's ''Carrie.'' The result is a study in voyeurism seen from the perspective of the one being watched. Andrew Ervin

title: The House That Rudy Built
description: Fred Wilpon became a New York real-estate plutocrat, the builder of tall towers along gilded blocks of Manhattan avenues, by excelling at the art of the calculated risk. The grandson of an immigrant Brooklyn street peddler, Wilpon left Bensonhurst on a full scholarship to the University of Michigan, and by age 30, he was back in New York, betting everything he had on reviving faded uptown properties -- and making lavish returns. Later, Wilpon was in the East Village before the boutiques, and he saw potential in Bedford-Stuyvesant when others saw only vacant lots and broken glass. ''He has,'' says his son Jeffrey, ''a nose for this stuff.''

title: A Makeover for Cuban-Americans
description: A little reform proved too much for nearly two dozen of the most hard-line board members of the Cuban American National Foundation. They angrily resigned last week, protesting the conservative exile group's efforts to moderate its image, however tepid those efforts may be. The conflict within the Miami-based foundation that has long been influential in setting United States policy toward Cuba reflects a broader and healthy debate taking place within the Cuban-American community. That debate may eventually make it possible to set aside misguided policies intended to hasten Fidel Castro's departure from power that have had the opposite effect.

The 75-passenger craft connects three points on the city waterfront: the Queen Mary, the Aquarium of the Pacific in Rainbow Harbor and Alamitos Bay Landing, a seaside village with shops, restaurants and boat rentals. It runs every 90 minutes from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. through summer; an introductory fare of $1 each way. The new fares and post-summer schedules are not yet set. Call (562) 591-2301.
