title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HONIG, RICHARD EDWARD, PH.D.
description: HONIG-Richard Edward, Ph.D. Died of cancer at The Quadrangle in Haverford, Pennsylvania on July 31, 2001. He was a member of the staff at David Sarnoff Research Center, RCA Laboratories from 1950-1987. Dr. Honig is widely recognized for his study of the vapor pressures of the elements. He served as president from 1970-1972 of the fledgling American Society of Mass Spectrometry, which he had helped found. Dr. Honig was a Fellow of the American Physical Society and in 1986 was awarded the Science Medal from the Vrije University of Brussels. Dr. Honig is survived by his wife, Joan, brother, Jurgen Honig of West Lafayette, IN, daughter, Kaete B. Shaw of High Falls, NY, son, Daniel M. Honig and daughter-in-law, Norma of Wallingford, PA, stepdaughters, Jane May of Olney, MD, Margaret Beach of Ithaca, NY, and five grandchildren.

It will also immediately increase the speed from 5 to 15 miles per hour at E-ZPass booths on the parkway. They saw no hint that within two decades he would rewrite the history of art.

title: A Complaint Department of One's Own

Our job was to solve the problems and answer the complaints. Some of my colleagues resented this extra work, but I saw it as both a challenge and an opportunity to learn more about the business.

title: Loose Lips Sink Ships, Again
description: As the 60th anniversary of the bombing of Pearl Harbor approaches and books on World War II dominate best-seller lists, interest is also growing in posters, songs and other memorabilia from that era. Among the Newark Public Library's collection of 22,000 prints and 4,000 historic posters are World War II recruiting posters for Spars, the women's Coast Guard; advertisements for Coca-Cola that feature soldiers; and British posters warning about spies eavesdropping on everyday conversations. The collection of World War II memorabilia will be on display at the library through Sept. 8. In addition to posters, the collection includes song sheets of popular songs written to raise patriotic sentiment photographs, biographies of wartime leaders and posters printed between 1941 and 1945. title: Imaginative Menu, but a Bit Over the Top
description: JAKE'S GRILLE in Oceanside has many virtues. Consistency isn't one of them. It is an ambitious restaurant with a flair and creativity rarely encountered at the mid-price level. The chef, John Circharo, and his crew make their own bread and desserts including ice cream (king-size bargains at $6). There's a respectable selection of wines priced under $20. The nightly specials make for an enticing read with not-seen-elsewhere originals like braised endive cassolette; fluke Napoleon, layered with grilled vegetables; a salad with red tango and baby Lola Rosa, which are two types of lettuce; and scallion-crusted bassa, a grouper-like fish, with ''Belugian caviar lentils,'' which is not caviar but small black beans.

I have reread it at least 20 times (and continue to do so), each time thinking of my dad and wishing he were here to relate amazing stories of dramatic rescues. But since he's not around to tell me, Pat Brown's story was the next best thing. It brought me closer to my deceased dad.

Two exhibits of photographs of the women are being featured at the Shops on Ocean One in Atlantic City. The 30 photographs of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and President Kennedy were taken by Jacques Lowe, who was given unlimited access to the White during John Kennedy's presidency. The showing of the photos in ''The Making of the First Lady'' will be returned to the Kennedy family estate at the close of the exhibit, on the first floor oft Ocean One Mall until Sept. 16. The 39 photos of Diana included in ''Diana, A Lasting Tribute'' were taken by a variety of photographers and will be shown on the third floor of the from Aug. 22 through Sept. 9 in commemoration of Diana's death on Aug. 31. title: QUICK BITE/Normandy Beach; A Farm Stand With Sit-Down Service
description: If the staff don't know your name when you walk into Charlie's, a family-run cafe, cheese shop and farm stand in Normandy Beach, you can be sure they'll know it (and how you like your eggs) by the time you leave. The husband and wife team of Tom and Teri Lightner opened this seaside staple in 1979 when they inherited it from Charlie, Tom's father. Fresh Jersey ingredients have been their focus ever since. In the bright tented cafe, mornings start with homemade muffins packed with Jersey blueberries ($2), thick slices of apple-cinnamon-stuffed French toast ($5.95), Belgian waffles crowned with whipped cream and summer berries ($5.95), or fluffy omelets filled with your choice of cheese and farm stand vegetables ($4.25 to $5.50). Best of all, the warm staff keeps the freshly brewed coffee coming, with no need to ask for refills. If a sit-down breakfast is not your thing, head over to the cheese shop (stocked with 500 varieties) for a bagel and a schmear. Choose from a dozen cheese spreads (all made there) like Garden Vegetable, a blend of cream cheese, cheddar, peppers, scallions, and radishes, or Tijuana Hot, a blend of yellow cheddar and jalapeo, which will wake you up as surely as the coffee. For lunch, sandwiches like prosciutto, roasted peppers, and fresh mozzarella ($6.95) share menu space with juicy burgers. And for the bikinied crowd, there's a good selection of salads ($6.99 to $9.95). There's also a ''Light Nibbles'' menu with impressive little bites like bruschetta, crab cakes, prosciutto-and-melon wraps, and a nice fruit and cheese board. This is far from shore grub. Unfortunately, T Tom passed away last year, but left behind a legacy for all enjoy, season after season. Andrea Strong

title: Scenes From A Marriage

An elite, old-line company, Daimler-Benz, had asked for the hand of a beautiful, populist bride, the Chrysler Corporation, and its petition had been accepted. It was a dream match -- a ''wedding made in heaven,'' as Daimler's C.E.O., Jrgen Schrempp, called it in May 1998. The wedding party -- among it, Wall Street and its analysts and even major stockholders like the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian -- was enthusiastic. The new company's shares rose to a dream high of $108.62 a few months after its stock was first traded on Nov. 17, 1998.

This has given renewed vigor to those in the administration, including Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz, who favor firmer action. title: Haunted by Ghosts of Pinter Past

And by that standard, the recent Harold Pinter Festival, which was part of the Lincoln Center Festival, disappointed. Everything was thoroughly professional. Three theater companies -- the Almeida, the Royal Court and the Gate -- brought nine productions to New York. Mr. Pinter acted in one of his plays and directed two others. But so much felt dutiful or worthy, not inspired. Had the three theaters, which brought us productions they had already staged, grown a trifle weary? Did they have enough rehearsal time here? Were they burdened by their reverence for the writer and his work?

Thomas and Janice Reedy, who founded Landslide in 1997, were sentenced this week to life in prison and 14 years, respectively. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARROLL, RICHARD P.
description: CARROLL-Richard P. 70, of Kent, CT. Died at home on August 8 after a short illness. Born in Springfield, MA, graduated from Syracuse University; was a member of Theta Chi Fraternity; an artist, he worked for 22 years with Young & Rubicam in both New York and Detroit before forming his own business. After retiring and moving to Kent, he indulged his love of art and craft. It's the Madonna Drowned World Tour T-shirt, and it earns multiple status points at once: it's accessible only to the connected few who scored tickets to one of Madge's sold-out shows. It's a rare instant classic for fashionophiles who have been wearing cut-up vintage rock shirts for months. And all the styles -- tummy-baring ''Material Girl'' baby T's, sleeveless shirts silk-screened with Madonna's face, a red sequined top with leather laces up the sides -- are cool enough to wear the morning after the show, just as in high school.

title: 'American Son'
description: Tomas is the son who helps pay the mortgage by selling attack dogs to rich people and celebrities. He is the son who keeps our mother up late with worry. He is the son who causes her embarrassment by showing up at family parties with his muscles covered in gangster tattoos and his head shaved down to stubble and his eyes bloodshot from pot. He is really half white, half Filipino but dresses like a Mexican, and it troubles our mother that he does this. She cannot understand why if he wants to be something he is not he does not at least try to look white. He is also the son who says that if any girlfriend criticized our mother or treated her wrong he would knock the bitch across the house.

title: Travel to Exotic Places and Buy, Buy, Buy
description: FLUTED columns and an outsize copy of Michelangelo's ''David'' dominate the Forum and the Appian Way, the shopping arcades at Caesars Palace. But they were fleeting distractions to Rebecca Bennett, who toured the resort hotel on a summer day with only one object in mind. ''Since I got here this afternoon, I've done nothing but shop, said Ms. Bennett, 24, a student from San Diego. She burrowed into a gilt-embossed shopping bag and produced a pair of leather sandals. ''I have 10 more bags in my hotel room,'' she gloated, ''all shoes, all sandals, and I have even more CD's and a gorgeous chamois-colored leather jacket. I've been to Las Vegas six times, maybe seven. Each time, the only reason was to shop.''

title: Faking It
description: There will always be a demand for expert legal advice and for people willing to pay for it. But simple legal information ought to be readily available on the Internet. Perhaps the legal profession will develop a two-tiered approach, like that of brokerage houses. Full-service attorneys could provide a variety of expert services, but discount attorneys would be available to provide information about basic legal tasks like court filings and simple contracts. Other information providers -- accountants, travel agents, even health-care providers -- might also be forced to justify their fees for offering what is essentially public information.

title: From King of Wall Street to Sultan of Supplements
description: Ten years have passed since a Treasury bond trading scandal tainted the house of Salomon Brothers and brought down its tough-willed chairman, John H. Gutfreund. Salomon ultimately did not survive independently  it is now part of Citigroup ( news/quote ), which plans to scrap the Salomon name altogether next year. But Mr. Gutfreund, once known as the "King of Wall Street" for his gutsy trading instincts, survived, albeit less regally, as a financial adviser and venture capital investor. Last week, he got a job as the next chairman of a business that is as about as far removed from the Treasury bond trading pits as you can get: Nutrition21, a dietary supplements company that sells "Lite Bites" fat-fighting remedies and other food ingredients. Mr. Gutfreund, 70, had served on the board since February 2000. He succeeds Robert E. Flynn, former chief executive of the NutraSweet Company. Nutrition21 said in a statement that Mr. Gutfreund "brings an enormous wealth of knowledge and expertise," citing his years running Salomon but making no mention of the scandal in August 1991. Mr. Gutfreund did not return telephone messages. His office said he was traveling.

description: In a reverse migration of sorts, the National Jewish Theater has left Florida and found a new home in the suburbs of New Jersey. The National Jewish Theater is a nonprofit educational arts organization dedicated to presenting works by Jewish American writers. Founded in 1986, the theater company has presented over two dozen regional productions, but this is its first as the Y.M.-Y.W.H.A.'s Theater-in-Residence, and also its first optioned for a Broadway run.

title: Wrapper First, Baby Later
description: There is a great deal of magic for a child in understanding his or her place in the rhythms of the generations. Did the world exist before I got here? What did it look like? Was my mother ever a child? What did she do before I was born? At the start of MY BABY (Frances Foster/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16; ages 3 to 8), a slight and enchanting book written and illustrated by Jeanette Winter, a child in Mali learns from her mother how to make the traditional handmade mud-dyed cloth called bogolan. Nakunte Diarra, a real woman, as an author's note tells us, becomes a celebrated bogolan painter, and the book follows her through her marriage, wearing a bogolan painted by her mother, to her pregnancy, when she starts making one for her own baby.

title: GARDEN STATE PARK'S FATE
description: The developers of the former Garden State Park this week presented plans for a $500 million office, retail and residential complex on the 223-acre former race track site in Cherry Hill. Garden State closed its racing operations in May after 59 years and Realen Properties Inc., of Berwyn, Pa., got the rights to develop the property. Realen plans to build one million square feet of office space and 500,000 square feet of retail space on the site. In addition, the company plans four condominium villages, a conference center and a 150-room hotel with a seven-acre lake and 75 acres of open space through the entire complex. Most of the housing is planned to be age-restricted so that few children will live on the site, thus cutting down on the possibility that the development would cause school taxes to rise. The developers said it could take as long as 20 years before the whole complex would be completed. The plan now goes to the Cherry Hill planning board for review. Robert Strauss

title: Hey, Ginger And Fred, Glam Rocks
description: GLAM rock, which in the early 70's enlisted kinky lyrics, outlandish makeup and flamboyant costuming as weapons against the conventional sexuality and standard seduction narratives of most pop music, has been pretty much ignored by filmmakers. There are a few exceptions, most notably Brian De Palma's bold and hilarious ''Phantom of the Paradise,'' an underappreciated 1974 classic that borrowed from ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' ''Faust'' and the Brechtian underpinnings of David Bowie's stage persona to tell the tale of a jealous rock composer who haunts a rock palace much like the Fillmore. In 1975, with Tim Curry's corseted, lipsticked Frank 'N' Furter leading the charge, ''The Rocky Horror Picture Show'' made the case for glam decadence and became a camp touchstone during its initial release -- perhaps the first time such a thing had happened. And Todd Haynes's 1998 ''Velvet Goldmine'' recounted the story of a Bowie-like glitter rocker and his impact on a fan in a nostalgia-drenched glam scrapbook.

description: HUMMEL-Charles. August 9, 2001, age 100 of Birmingham, MI, formerly of New York. He attended Columbia University and received his CPA with distinction from the Walton School of Commerce in 1923. During WWII, he served on the Navy's Board of Auditors. He was a member of the Michigan and New York Society of CPAs; also past President of Bloomfield Hills Country Club and Chairman of the Board for Cranbrook-Kingswood Schools in Bloomfield Hills, MI. Still, both, at their young ages, have climbed high enough to warrant attention in the recent second edition of The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians. The names of the two are often bracketed, Tully Potter writes in Mr. Repin's entry, ''because of their similar backgrounds.''

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-12-01: Phenomenon; Sitcom Spirituals
description: Next month, in a stunning example of life imitating ''The Simpsons,'' Westminster John Knox Press, the company that brought us ''The Gospel According to Peanuts'' more than a generation ago, will publish ''The Gospel According to the Simpsons: The Spiritual Life of the World's Most Animated Family.'' The nonironic book, by Mark I. Pinsky, a religion writer for The Orlando Sentinel, is only the latest nod to the show's spirituality. A recent California State University study found that 70 percent of the show's episodes contain religious themes. Christian Century magazine put the family on its cover, stating that ''The Simpsons'' ''is exceptionally aware of the significant place religion has in the American landscape.'' And in the magazine Prism, from Evangelicals for Social Action, ''The Simpsons'' was called ''the most pro-family, God-preoccupied, home-based program on television.'' It appears that the show most memorably lambasted by Bush the elder in 1992 -- We need a nation closer to 'The Waltons' than 'The Simpsons' '' -- and criticized by Catholics and Hindus is now a model of family values. Bart couldn't have manipulated things better.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATIL, JEAN PAUL
description: LATIL-Jean Paul. Died on July 22, 2001 in Charlottesville, Virginia. Predeceased by wife Jacqueline. Survived by his sisters-in-law Lise Blum Elson and Genevieve BlumGayet. He also leaves his three children Martine, Catherine and Bertrand; six grandchildren Lisa, Anne, Alex, Alice, Ellie and Francine; one great grandchild Brooke; nephews Richard and David; his niece Becky and other family and friends. Jean Paul was born in 1906 in France and moved to the U.S. 60 years ago. He raised his family in Kew Gardens, N.Y. Jean Paul was an engineer & before retiring he and his wife owned and ran Genarco, a company in Jamaica, N.Y. In the 1950s he worked on solar lighting inventions. In their retirement years, Jean Paul and his wife Jacqueline enjoyed birding, mushrooming and origami. We thank him for sharing his breadth of knowledge and experience, his jokes and cartoons and funny tales. He will be missed.

title: Private Sector; The Shows Must Go On
description: By now it is no secret that Ben Affleck, star of ''Pearl Harbor'' and the upcoming Tom Clancy film, ''The Sum of All Fears,'' entered an alcohol-abuse rehabilitation center on July 31 in Malibu, Calif. And now, Hollywood is buzzing about what his absence might do to LivePlanet, the company that Mr. Affleck, 28, co-founded with a fellow actor, Matt Damon, and the producers Chris Moore and Sean Bailey. Mr. Affleck's absence should have little impact on coming projects. LivePlanet and its partner, ABC Entertainment, are co-producing the reality show ''The Runner,'' which has begun casting. ''This production is on course and full steam ahead for a January launch,'' said the executive producer, Michael Davies. The film ''Stolen Summer,'' the result of LivePlanet's screen-writing contest, Project Greenlight, has finished shooting. And LivePlanet has strengthened management, last month hiring David Haddad, former chief executive of Eparties, to be chief operating officer.

title: An Island of Idiosyncrasy on the AM Dial
description: AS the time neared 3 o'clock one Monday afternoon this summer, Joe Ferraro in all his guises manned the controls of WHVW-AM. The station was just finishing an hourlong set, ranging from Artie Shaw to Doc Watson to Ray Charles, that Mr. Ferraro had loaded into a broadcast computer earlier that week. Meanwhile, in his alter ego as J. P. Ferraro, rarefied host of ''Evening Concert,'' he was taping a Colorado Quartet CD of Schubert's ''Death and the Maiden'' with which to close that night's program. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEITELSON, MILTON
description: FEITELSON-Milton, 89. A former Executive Director of the United Services Organization (USO) and well-known on serving the recreational, educational and welfare needs of the armed forces, died on August 8, 2001, in Santa Cruz, CA. He lived in Scotts Valley, CA after having moved to be with his son and family from St. Petersburg, FL. Before his move to Florida at retirement in 1975, he and his wife had lived and worked with USO in New Jersy, Georgia, Pennsylvania and New York. A graduate of City College of NY, with post-graduate work at NYU, Columbia and Cornell, he devoted most of his career life to our nation's youth -first in the Civilian Conservation Corps in the thirties, where he was Educational Advisor for the U.S. Office of Education, and later to those who served in our armed forces in World War II, Korea and Viet Nam. He served in the Roosevelt administration and as consultant to President Truman's Committee on Religion and Welfare in the Armed Forces in 1950 and helped train its field staff. He was the author of ''A Study of Community Organization for Military Personnel'', two books on recruiting and using resources for youth in uniform and several articles relative to the American communities' responsibilities to their sons and daughters service in our defense. He was the recipient of many awards among which were the Freedom Foundation's Award for Community Organization, the Army Patriotic Civilian Service Award, the Commerce and Industry Association Award for securing employment for retiring veterans and recognition and honors from all five branches of our armed forces. He was a pioneer in USO work and retired after 34 years of service. Mr. Feitelson was a charter member of the National Association of Social Workers, a member of the Academy of Certified Social Workers, a member of the Navy League and served on many governmental and community committees. His major pastime was boating and fishing. Survivors include his wife Gertrude, a daughter Mrs. James (Ellen F.) Gallas, a son William N. Feitelson and his wife Jorie of Santa Cruz, CA, and two granddaughters, Jennifer and Kristin. No funeral services will be held. Donations may be sent to the USO of Metropolitan New York.

In the anguish of the dream I cannot account for having forgotten this house, forgotten that I am responsible for its maintenance. Abject, I investigate its dereliction, wandering through damp and fetid corridors. On waking I have to debrief myself. The house, in reality, ceased to belong to me several years ago. Actually, it has been demolished. And yet I can carry the shame with me well into the day.

Gabriel Axel made this delectable movie about a French-woman (Stephane Audran) in distress who goes to work as an unpaid house-keeper for two pious spinster sisters in a bleak Danish village. Fourteen years later, the housekeeper wins the French lottery and decides to blow the whole 10,000 francs on a dinner to end all dinners. Little do her employers know she was a renowned chef back in Paris. No other film has come this close to conveying on screen the bliss of blinis De-midoff with caviar and an 1845 Clos Vougeot. title: August 5-11; Britain Buys 6 More Weeks

The $53 million initiative, called KidsNeeds, has designated funds to expand many existing state programs, the largest of these being a $25 million increase in the budget of FamilyCare, which subsidies health care for low-income families. It also offers increased aid to grandparents and other relatives who care for children that are not their own. Annie Ruderman

title: A Retreat to the Familiar Ground of Zionism
description: Until last September, when the present wave of violence began, Israelis invested the better part of their political and cultural energy in internal matters. The conflict with the Palestinians seemed to be coming under control -- there was hope still that peace negotiation was progressing, albeit slowly -- and many Israelis seemed willing to re-examine fundamental issues of identity, including even the validity of the Zionist ideology itself. Indeed, Israeli society seemed to be going through a transformation, steadily moving toward a so-called post-Zionist, post-national stage of development. That movement now seems to be held off in the face of terrorist violence.

title: Splitting Hairs on Taxes Would Leave All Poorer
description: This letter is in response to a letter published Aug. 5, in which the writer expresses resentment that her tax dollars might be used for a beach replenishment project on Fire Island because she does not live there. Why does she not also resent monies used for road repairs in Albany, or funds used to refurbish jails in Brooklyn or schools being built in Utica -- all paid for by state taxes?

title: Toy Story 3: A Shrinky Dink Comeback

That sounded interesting, but the lids were too small to be much fun. Mrs. Morris found a company willing to send her plastic sheets, if she bought 1,000 pounds. She persuaded them to give her a dozen-sheet sample. The scouts loved coloring and then shrinking the plastic so much that they often fought over the scraps. Mrs. Morris organized a company to market the new toy and ordered the full shipment. When it arrived, her garage floor cracked.

title: Private Sector; A Bull in G.M.'s Shop
description: From factory floor to polished marble: E. Stanley O'Neal, the newest member of the General Motors board of directors, cannot be called a stuffed shirt who has never gotten his hands dirty. Mr. O'Neal, 49, joined the G.M. board last Tuesday, just two weeks after he was named president and chief operating officer of Merrill Lynch. But his relationship with G.M. spans three decades. In 1969, he attended the cooperative education program at the General Motors Institute, working part-time at the same G.M. plant in Doraville, Ga., where his father had worked. Mr. O'Neal said his most vivid memory was the body shop: ''They had these huge pneumatic bolters, sparks flying everywhere.'' He later worked as an assembly-line supervisor, won a scholarship from G.M. to attend business school at Harvard, received his M.B.A. in 1978 and returned to G.M. as a financial executive. Eight years later he joined Merrill Lynch. Until last week, he had resisted G.M.'s entreaties to join its board. ''From a personal point of view, it is coming back full circle,'' he said. Alex Berenson

title: From the Land of Oo-bla-dee
description: The pianist, composer and arranger Mary Lou Williams, who died in 1981, is being celebrated in a free exhibit, ''In the Land of Oo-bla-dee,'' presented by the Rutgers Institute of Jazz Studies at the John Cotton Dana Library at Rutgers's Newark campus, through September. The title is taken from a song Ms. Williams co-wrote that was made famous by Dizzy Gillespie. Her long career spanned boogie-woogie, the blues and bop, and she went on to write sacred music played in cathedrals. Her story is told in photos, music manuscripts, personal scrapbooks, mementos, her eyeglasses, rosary beads and purses -- all drawn from The Institute of Jazz Studies Mary Williams Collection. Her music will also be heard in the display area. Margo Nash

title: August 5-11; Genoa Criticism Widens
description: Italy's center-right government defended police actions at last month's Group of 8 summit in Genoa against continuing international criticism so widespread that even Austria's ultra-conservative government joined in. But though Italians are divided, polling shows a majority side with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who said it was protesters, not the police, who should go on trial. During a violent protest, the police shot one marcher dead; they are accused of brutalizing scores of others. ''There's a strong current of opinion here that says anyone who goes around looting and burning cars deserves to have their head bashed in,'' said James Walston, a professor of political science at the American University of Rome. ''The fact that the people who were burning cars weren't necessarily the same ones who had their heads bashed in, or that police are not supposed to beat up even nasty people does not always get through.'' title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEMCHEN, LEO
description: LEMCHEN-Leo. Of Maplewood, NJ and Boca Raton, FL on Wednesday, August 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Eleanor (nee Goldberg), loving father of Marc Lemchen, of Manhattan and Barbara Wolff-Reichert of Buffalo, NY, father-in-law to Deborah Schneider Lemchen & Jonathan Reichert. His memory will be a precious blessing to his grandson Andrew Lemchen, his granddaughters Nada Wolff Culver and Jessica Wolff & to his great grandchildren Nina and Harrison. He was a dear brother of Beatrice Epstein of West Orange, NJ, Phillip Lemchen of Seattle, WA and the late Helen Granett. He graced the lives of all he encountered. An award winning innovative kitchen designer both as the president of Barmark Kithens, East Orange and later under his own name, his work graced many of the loveliest homes of N.J. and N.Y. His concept of the ''Living Kitchen,'' introduced in McCall's magazine in the early 50's, made the kitchen a true center of the modern home. A member of the American Society of Interior Decorators he was among the founding members of the Certified Kitchen Designers. Funeral services were held at Congregation Beth El on August 9. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Leo Lemchen Living Kitchen Award Fund may be sent to Bourne, Noll and Kenyon, attention Charles Berman, 382 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ 07901.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Bebe Buell; Her Backstage Passes
description: SHE'S a legend in her own book. That Abba musical ''Mama Mia,'' about a girl with three potential dads, due to open in October? Bebe Buell already lived it, in 1977, when she had a baby girl with three potential dads: Todd Rundgren, the rocker she was living with; Steven Tyler, one of the rockers she had slept with; and Mick Jagger, who had not bedded her around the time she got pregnant but who teased her about being the real father.

description: THE California Supreme Court ruled last week that the maker of the Tec-9 assault pistol could not be held liable in a 1993 San Francisco rampage in which nine people died. That was presumably a boon for the maker, Navegar Inc. of Miami, whose product was also used in the 1999 Columbine High School shooting, in which 15 died.

title: August 5-11; Texas Woman to Face Death
description: Usually, prosecutors in Texas do not hesitate to seek the death penalty in murder cases, particularly when the accused has confessed. But the case of Andrea Pia Yates, charged in the drowning of her five young children, has been unique from the moment of her arrest in June, eliciting both public revulsion at the crime and sympathy for her history of mental illness. After weeks of deliberation, Harris County District Attorney Chuck Rosenthal announced that he would seek the death penalty. First, though, a hearing will determine if Mrs. Yates is competent to stand trial. Her lawyers have entered a plea of not guilty by reason of insanity. Jim Yardley

description: MOLOSHOK-Ralph E., M.D. Age 88. Died on August 3, 2001 as a result of heart failure. He is survived by his wife, Margaret, his daughter, Lynn Green, and son, James, grandchildren, Aram, Gillian, Lisa and Daniel and brother, Norman. Dr. Moloshok practiced pediatric medicine in New York City for over four decades prior to his retirement to Boca Raton, FL. He was a professor of pediatrics at The Mount Sinai Medical School and an attending physician at Mount Sinai Hospital. He will be remembered fondly by his many patients for his tireless devotion to their care.

title: Haunted by Mold
description: Melinda Ballard parks her cream-colored Jaguar next to her deserted dream house in Dripping Springs, Tex. -- a house she fled more than two years ago, leaving dirty dishes in the sink and unopened mail on the counter. Popping open the Jag's trunk, she pulls out two portable respirator masks. ''These won't screen out all the mycotoxins,'' she warns as she tosses one to me. ''That's the dangerous stuff, so we'll only stay a few minutes.''

title: Private Sector; Singing All the Way to the Bank
description: Shareholders of the Wachovia Corporation who voted in favor of a merger with the First Union Corporation this month, and against a hostile bid by SunTrust Banks, included a descendant of the family that founded Wachovia back in 1893. Henry Shaffner, a grandson of one of the founders, was so thrilled at the prospect of a deal that he and his wife, Roberta, wrote a song about it. The Shaffners, who are professional songwriters, called their ditty ''The Wachovia (W)rap.'' The song refers to ''Wachovia's suitors, both in thrall/To take this bank to the Bankers Ball.'' ''We really love the idea of the bank expanding,'' said Roberta Shaffner, whose husband is a grandson of the former chairman. ''We also love the idea that Wachovia will now be in the Philadelphia area,'' where the Shaffners live. Riva D. Atlas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHAMLIN, GEORGE M.
description: CHAMLIN-George M. Of Deal, New Jersey, died on July 10, 2001. We buried dear George on July 12, 2001-his body, but not his spirit. The man we all respected and loved. The man with a spark whose beautiful brown eyes reflected a light that guided us. The man whose resonant voice called to us, sang to us and spoke to us in the most encouraging, reassuring and caring way. The man whose strong, yet slender fingers touched us and caressed us. The man whose big and generous heart enveloped us with an unshakeable love. The man whose solid and supportive frame provided us with a base upon which to lean and rest. A trial attorney who had a deep and abiding belief in our Judicial system which enabled him to practice law in a highly principled manner. His diligence and resourcefulness, his compassionate nature and wit formed the foundation for his success and popularity. He was respected, not only as a trial litigator on behalf of his clients, but his principles garnered the respect and admiration of his adversaries and colleagues. Respecting and loving him was an honor, a gift, a joy. His loving wife, Isadora L. Chamlin

But as it watched its leading Dutch rivals, Elsevier and Wolters Kluwer, embark on global expansion programs, VNU worried that it would fall far behind.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the harmonica virtuoso Larry Adler on Wednesday referred incorrectly to ''Smiles,'' a Florenz Ziegfeld stage production in which he appeared. It was a musical play, not a revue. The obituary also referred incorrectly to his film role credits for ''St. Martin's Lane'' and ''Sidewalks of London.'' The titles represent a single film -- the first as released in Britain, in 1938, the second in the United States, in 1940.

title: Critic's Notebook; Back to Nature In Seattle On Rhine
description: If anything is clear about ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' it is that Wagner intended his multifaceted operatic telling of Norse myths to be set amid nature. The scenic descriptions are precise and poetic. ''Das Rheingold,'' the first of the cycle's four operas, begins under a greenish twilight in the swirling waters of the river. We meet the god Wotan and his wife, Fricka, atop a wooded mountain, with the castle of Valhalla visible on a summit in the background. Later scenes are set in the depths of the forest, subterranean caverns, wild craggy expanses and rocky cliffs bounded by pine forests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, RICHARD JOSEPH
description: ROSENTHAL-Richard Joseph. Of Miami Beach, FL, passed away August 11, 2001, after losing his wife Frances three years ago. Beloved survivors include his son Ron (Kay) Rosenthal, Susan Bender (Perry Scheer), his grandchildren Casey and Dylan, and his sister Shari Klarnet. Contributions may be made to the WWII Veterans Memorial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LATIL, JEAN PAUL
description: LATIL-Jean Paul. Died on July 22, 2001 in Charlottesville, Virginia. Predeceased by wife Jacqueline. Survived by his sisters-in-law Lise Blum Elson and Genevieve BlumGayet. He also leaves his three children Martine, Catherine and Bertrand; six grandchildren Lisa, Anne, Alex, Alice, Ellie and Francine; one great grandchild Brooke; nephews Richard and David; his niece Becky and other family and friends. Jean Paul was born in 1906 in France and moved to the U.S. 60 years ago. He raised his family in Kew Gardens, N.Y. Jean Paul was an engineer & before retiring he and his wife owned and ran Genarco, a company in Jamaica, N.Y. In the 1950s he worked on solar lighting inventions. In their retirement years, Jean Paul and his wife Jacqueline enjoyed birding, mushrooming and origami. We thank him for sharing his breadth of knowledge and experience, his jokes and cartoons and funny tales. He will be missed.

title: Influential Connecticut Welfare Plan Is Tested in Hard Times
description: Six years after Connecticut began one of the nation's more aggressive welfare reform efforts, the number of people on public assistance has been cut by more than half, to 25,000 from 58,000. Over the full six years, about 60,000 families have moved off the rolls, and state officials and researchers say that many of those former recipients have found work.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 13 — Twenty young Korean protesters chopped off the tips of their little fingers today while shouting "Apologize, apologize!" for offenses that they said the Japanese had committed against the Korean people.

title: Yes, It's Nice to Be a Favorite, But It's Nicer to Be a Winner
description: The favorites in major team championships are sometimes defeated in the early rounds, and they had more trouble than usual in the Spingold Knockout in Toronto last month. Three of the top five seeds went out in the first three rounds, losing to unheralded teams.

title: STATES DISMAYED BY FEDERAL BILLS ON PATIENT RIGHTS
description: State officials are expressing grave doubts about federal legislation on patients' rights, especially a bill passed by the House this month, saying it would override state laws that provide greater protection to millions of consumers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Shoots Himself In Robbery
description: A man shot himself in the foot while trying to rob a cab in Queens Saturday night, the police said yesterday. The man, Damien Vernon, 19, jumped into the front seat of a cab in St. Albans about 9 p.m. and demanded money from the driver. The police said Mr. Vernon shot himself in the foot during a struggle with the driver. He was charged with robbery and criminal possession of a weapon.

title: The Senate and the World
description: Americans concerned about the direction of President Bush's foreign policy are looking to the Senate for relief. Last week, the Democratic majority leader, Tom Daschle, outlined an alternative, more internationally minded view of America's role in the 21st-century world. If Mr. Daschle and his colleagues in the Democratic majority have the gumption to follow the example of J. William Fulbright, the Arkansas senator who used the Foreign Relations Committee as a battering ram against the Vietnam War, they can make White House policy more accountable to public opinion and more in line with America's broader national interests.

title: Pair Arrested After Girl Reports Assault
description: A man and a woman were arrested Friday on Long Island after a 15-year-old Massachusetts girl told the authorities that the pair, whom she met in an Internet chat room, held her captive for a week in Farmingdale, N.Y., and sexually assaulted her, the police said yesterday.

title: Autobiography Rendered in Large Sweeping Blocks
description: Cleo Parker Robinson Dance gave a clouded, windy evening a mellow spin on Saturday night at the Damrosch Park Band Shell. This Denver-based company, appearing as part of the Lincoln Out of Doors festival, put dynamic dancers through gentle paces to mostly interesting effect.

title: Slave Traders In Yale's Past Fuel Debate On Restitution
description: As it marks its 300th anniversary, Yale University is celebrating what it calls its ''long history of activism in the face of slavery'' -- the abolitionist faculty members who befriended the slaves on the ship Amistad in 1839, and today, the world's first center for the study of slavery.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits on Thursday about voice synthesis research at AT&T Labs referred incorrectly to the unit that produced a voice machine at the 1939 World's Fair and later figured in the making of ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' It was Bell Laboratories, then part of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. (A.T.& T. Bell Laboratories was the unit's name after the breakup of the Bell System in 1984; its descendants are AT&T Labs and Lucent Technologies' Bell Labs.)

She beat Jennifer Capriati in one event and Serena Williams in the other. Twice she beat Martina Hingis, the world's top-ranked player, who had recently dominated their matchups. title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: West Nile Virus Found
description: A third group of mosquitoes tested positive for West Nile virus, state health officials said last week. The virus was found in a small number of mosquitoes collected from standing water in Beaver Pond Park in New Haven. James Hadler, the director of infectious diseases for the Department of Public Health, said the mosquito infection rate was low, but he advised elderly neighbors of the site to protect themselves on hot evenings.

title: Thailand Tour
description: Although it can be rainy in Thailand in the fall, it is also the time when the Festival of Lights (Loy Kratong) is held, as it has been for over 700 years. Floating lanterns are set adrift in the Chao Phrya River in the town of Sukhothai to show respect to the waterway. Natrabu Indo-America Travel makes it affordable to pay homage, with an 11-day tour built around the festival Oct. 27 to Nov. 6 , for $1,499 a person, based on double occupancy. That includes five nights in Bangkok, one night each in Sukhothai and Lampang and two in Chiang Mai. Besides the Festrival of Lights, stops include the Royal Palace and an elephant-camp show. Also included are round-trip air fare from the West Coast and many meals. Information: (800) 628-7228 or www.natrabu-usa.com .

description: SKOPJE, Macedonia, Aug. 13 - The bitter and distrustful leaders of Macedonia's two main ethnic groups signed a peace deal today to end six months of fighting, although hours later the not-so-distant sound of artillery fire rumbled from north of the capital.

title: Family Feuds in Massachusetts
description: Although Massachusetts politics is legendary for tribal warfare, the damage rarely extends beyond state borders. However, this time a feud inside the state's Democratic Party could cost the United States Congress one of its most useful legislators. The potential casualty is Martin Meehan, a warrior in the struggle for campaign finance reform and co-author of the Shays-Meehan bill, which seeks to diminish the influence of soft money in American politics. The engine of Mr. Meehan's possible political destruction is Thomas Finneran, the powerful speaker of the Massachusetts House.

title: In Optus Deal, Australians Ponder How to Trust Singapore

title: Macedonia Peace Signed, but Soon After, Artillery Booms
description: The bitter and distrustful leaders of Macedonia's two main ethnic groups signed a peace deal today to end six months of fighting, although hours later the not-so-distant sound of artillery fire rumbled from north of Skopje, the capital.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Loudcloud Offers Smaller Packages
description: Loudcloud Inc., which manages Web sites for corporations, said it would sell services individually rather than only as a large package. Individually sold services will include Web security and database management, said Jeff Kupietzky, general manager of the solutions group at Loudcloud. The change is meant to attract more customers, because businesses are cutting spending amid a weak economy. Loudcloud, founded by Marc Andreessen, above, who helped develop Netscape's Internet browser, cut its fiscal 2002 sales estimate in June to $53 million from $57 million. Stock in Loudcloud, which is based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has dropped 74 percent since March.

title: A Fragile Peace for Macedonia
description: The conclusion of a national peace accord usually comes with fanfare and publicity. But in an indication of the perils awaiting Macedonia's new peace pact, ethnic Slav and Albanian politicians signed the agreement virtually under cover of darkness yesterday to avoid protests from Slavs. The accord also came during the worst week of fighting of the six-month guerrilla conflict.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid For Pubs Fails
description: Pubmaster, which operates a chain of pubs in Britain, said its hostile bid for its rival Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries had failed. It said its offer had lapsed after receiving support from only 47 percent of Wolverhampton's shareholders. Pubmaster's chief executive, John Sands, has said he wants to add 3,000 pubs to the 2,000 the company already owns. Pubmaster's bid of 513 pence a share valued the company, one of Britain's largest regional brewers and owner of 1,770 pubs, at 485 million ($690 million), a price that Wolverhampton had called too low. If left independent, Wolverhampton had promised to buy back shares and streamline operations. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Comdisco Posts A Loss
description: Comdisco Inc., which filed for protection under bankruptcy laws last month, reported a sharp fiscal third-quarter loss yesterday, hurt by charges related to write-downs of investments. Comdisco, the computer-leasing company based in Rosemont, Ill., posted a net loss of $164 million, or $1.08 a diluted share, for the quarter ended June 30, in contrast to net income of $17 million, or break-even on a per-share basis, in the period a year earlier. Excluding results from discontinued operations, Comdisco lost $168 million, or $1.10 a share, in contrast to earnings of $50 million, or 31 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue slumped 28 percent, to $585 million from $810 million.

title: United Auto Workers Make Bold, New Bid to Unionize Nissan Plant
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 14  The United Automobile Workers union asked federal officials here today to hold a vote among workers at the giant Nissan factory in nearby Smyrna, Tenn., on whether to unionize, setting up the nation's first such election in a dozen years at a foreign-owned auto assembly plant.

title: Car Dealership Stock Deal
description: Major Automotive Companies, a holding company for car dealerships in the New York metropolitan area, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Bruce Bendell, will sell about 2.14 million shares, or 67 percent of his 3.2 million shares, to Marshall Cogan. The company, based in Kew Gardens, Queens, said the shares represent about 27 percent of the company's outstanding stock. Mr. Cogan will become chief executive after the transaction, which is expected to close by the end of the year. Mr. Bendell will become president. Mr. Cogan, 64, is founder of the UnitedAuto Group Inc., one of the largest auto retailers in the nation, and chairman of Foamex International Inc.

title: Inner Child, Why Are You Angry?
description: ''It's really hard to be a young man or a young lady today,'' declared Kud, the singer of the new-metal band Mudvayne. Speaking in between songs -- while Gurrg, his lead guitarist, face painted bright red, glowered silently at the audience -- he was really getting wound up. He wore a bowler hat, ''Clockwork Orange'' style, over his painted, chalky face, and a pair of baggy farmer's coveralls, to signify perhaps that the band is from Peoria, Ill.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: Teacher Shortage Narrowing
description: With less than three weeks to go before the start of school, the Waterbury Board of Education is closing the gap on a teacher shortage but still has 24 positions to fill, officials said yesterday. So far, 29 of 53 openings have been filled and offers of employment have been made to 10 more prospective teachers, according to the board. Waterbury's troubled finances and rumors of a wage freeze for teachers have discouraged some applicants.

title: 2 Troubled Midtown Nightclubs Sold at Auction
description: Two problem-plagued Manhattan nightclubs, both owned by Peter Gatien, the former nightlife magnate, were up for sale yesterday at an auction in bankruptcy court in Manhattan.

title: Suit Seeks to Expand Access to Stem Cells
description: In a hint of the intellectual property skirmishes that may cloud future research on human embryonic stem cells, a Wisconsin foundation that owns a patent on the valuable cells filed suit today against a California biotechnology company that is seeking exclusive rights to develop therapies using them.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Pre-Election Violence
description: Political violence has rocked much of the nation. Various newspaper reports indicate that about a dozen people died during the weekend in skirmishes between supporters of the Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party. The conflicts occurred as campaigning heats up for national elections, which are expected in October. Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Automaker Profit
description: Often overlooked in the Korean motor vehicle industry, the also-ran Ssangyong Motor roared into the black in the first six months of this year. Once part of the Ssangyong group, the company, which manufactures vans and a luxury car called Chairman with Mercedes-Benz technology, reported a first-half net profit of $11.2 million on sales of $850 million, up 39 percent. That figure compared with a loss of $117 million in the first half of last year. Acquired by Daewoo Motor during the Korean economic crisis in December 1997, the company has been operating independently since the Daewoo group collapsed in mid-1999 and Daewoo Motor and Ssangyong fell into the hands of creditors along with other Daewoo companies.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Medical Examiner Resigns
description: The medical examiner of Spokane County resigned after state and federal drug agents found several marijuana plants and a large volume of prescription drugs in his home. The examiner, Dr. George Lindholm, was not immediately arrested, and officials would not say whether he would face charges. ''It's a situation related to depression, a divorce and a bad choice,'' Dr. Lindholm told The Spokane Spokesman-Review. He said he had smoked marijuana occasionally and had started growing the plants ''out of curiosity'' this summer. Sam Howe Verhovek (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | MTV May Get New Landlord
description: The 54-story tower in Times Square that is home to MTV Studios is on the auction block. The owner of the tower, at 1515 Broadway, the Equitable Life Assurance Society, has hired the Goldman Sachs Group to market the building, which has 1.9 million square feet and sits between 44th and 45th Streets, according to real estate brokers. Viacom, which owns MTV and rents much of the building, is the logical buyer. And Viacom had been talking to Equitable about swapping its stake in the CBS Building, 51 West 52nd Street, for 1515 Broadway. But nothing came of it, the brokers said, because the smaller CBS Building is worth less than the Times Square tower. The sales effort was first reported yesterday by Bloomberg News. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: For Gay Men, Health Care Concerns Move Beyond the Threat of AIDS
description: In the 20 years since the advent of AIDS, gay men have spent much of their energy and resources fighting the disease and caring for those stricken with it. But now that powerful drug combinations have reduced the death rate and extended lives, a handful of gay health care advocates want to send a message to both gay men and the medical profession: H.I.V. status should no longer be the sole barometer of gay men's health.

description: Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi visited a shrine honoring the nation's war dead today, after yielding to international pressure and abandoning a plan to go on Wednesday, the anniversary of the Japanese surrender in World War II.

title: Anguilla Resort
description: Arate of $2,625 a night may sound a little high, but when it is a five-bedroom suite with a private pool on a Caribbean island, it works out to something more reasonable per person. And the accommodations are in Cap Juluca, the luxury resort on Anguilla, at savings of more than 60 percent over high-season rates. There are smaller accommodations, too. A two-bedroom suite is $762 a night. These rates are good through Nov. 16, and require a four-night minimum stay; 8 percent sales tax and 10 percent service charge are extra. The hotel will be closed Sept. 4 to Oct. 25. Rates include Continental breakfast, all water sports, tennis and use of the health club. A full meal plan is $105 a day per person. Information: (888) 858-5822 or www.capjuluca.com .

title: Prohibited Meat Entered U.S., a Report Finds

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: 12 Charged In Farm Violence
description: The government said 12 men had been arrested and charged in connection with violence around the northern city of Chinhoyi, where dozens of white farmers have fled to avoid mobs of militants who have been invading farms and burning and looting homes. The authorities, who said farmers were exaggerating the extent of the violence, said they had recovered a substantial amount of stolen property. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Bush Says He Will Veto Any Bill Broadening His Stem Cell Policy
description: President Bush said today that he would veto any legislation that tried to push federal support for embryonic stem cell research beyond the parameters he has specified, which confine public financing to stem cell ''lines,'' or self-sustaining colonies, already derived from embryos.

title: Slave Traders in Yale's Past Fuel Debate on Restitution
description: As it marks its 300th anniversary, Yale University is celebrating what it calls its "long history of activism in the face of slavery"  the abolitionist faculty members who befriended the slaves on the ship Amistad in 1839, and today, the world's first center for the study of slavery.

title: Altered Tomato Thrives in Salty Soil
description: More than a quarter of the world's irrigated land has become so salty that many crops can no longer grow. But a genetically engineered plant that was recently developed can live extremely well in salty soil and still produce tasty tomatoes, a team of researchers says.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about the exhibition ''Britain's Portable Empire'' at the Katonah Museum in Katonah, N.Y., misstated the name of the Brown University library that lent a lithograph. It is the John Hay Library, not John Jay.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Airport Gets Runway Clearance
description: Seattle-Tacoma International Airport has cleared the last state hurdle in its plan to build a third runway, with the granting of a permit by the Department of Ecology. The state permit is needed to obtain one from the Army Corps of Engineers to build in wetlands. A report last month based on data from the federal Department of Transportation showed that arriving flights at Sea-Tac were late 31.3 percent of the time, the worst record of any airport in the country. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: State Appeals School Fund Case
description: Lawyers for New York State yesterday filed a brief seeking to overturn a landmark court decision that New York City's school system was constitutionally substandard and that its financing methods must be reformed. The lawyers argued that education at city schools plainly exceeded constitutional standards. The lawyers also contended that the trial judge, Justice Leland DeGrasse, used the wrong legal standards in his Jan. 10 decision and that his remedy infringed on legislative powers. The plaintiff, the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, is set to file arguments by Sept. 21. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

The company, the country's largest exporter, benefited from a nearly 7 percent devaluation in Brazil's currency this quarter.

title: Reckonings; Delusions of Prosperity
description: Three years ago, after the collapse of Long Term Capital Management, U.S. financial markets were in crisis. For a few weeks it looked as if the economy would succumb to panic, to self-fulfilling pessimism. Then the Fed surprised the markets by cutting rates without waiting for its next scheduled meeting. Confidence was quickly restored, and Alan Greenspan was promoted to demigod status.

title: Farm Income Expected to Be Most in 5 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (Bloomberg News)  Net farm income will be the highest in five years in 2001, as livestock and dairy prices strengthen and federal aid continues, the government said today. The Agriculture Department raised its farm income forecast to $50.4 billion for the calendar year, up 19 percent from the $42.4 billion expected in June, and up 8.6 percent from last year's $46.4 billion. It would be the highest since 1996 and the second highest ever. The new forecast included the $5.5 billion in the farm bailout aid plan President Bush signed in Texas today. Net farm income represents the broadest measure of farm profitability. The new estimates were announced last week. "Over all, the farm sector looks pretty good," said Larry Salathe, an Agriculture Department economist, citing livestock and dairy prices that are higher than those two months ago, along with smaller increases in crop prices. For grain prices, Mr. Salathe said, "we've reached the low point, and we're on the upswing again." The Modesto paper and The Fresno Bee, which are owned by the McClatchy Newspaper Group, concluded in editorials they ran on Sunday that Mr. Condit's conduct during the search for the missing intern Chandra Ann Levy had violated the public trust. title: Kenyan Leader Fails in Bid to Set Up Anti-Graft Body
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 14 — President Daniel arap Moi sought to restart the flow of international funds to Kenya today by striding into the Parliament and personally voting for a measure that would set up an anticorruption authority to investigate official misdeeds.

So instead of working on oil rigs, as many young Calgary men do nowadays, he spent time laying concrete sidewalks with his father, Phil, a part-time masonry contractor who also wrestled on the professional circuit under the name ''Killer Klein.''

title: Metro Business Briefing | Vanishing Ink Cited In Check Case
description: A former secretary at Bear, Stearns & Company and her husband were each indicted yesterday on 13 counts of grand larceny, forgery and other crimes after they were accused of stealing more than $50,000 from a partner at the brokerage house. The secretary, Anamarie Giambrone, was accused of using quick-fading ink to write checks that her boss, Eli Wachtel, then signed. Once the ink faded, prosecutors said, Ms. Giambrone made the checks out to ''cash'' and gave some of the money to her husband, Salvatore Giambrone, who used it to start a pizzeria in Queens. Ms. Giambrone worked for Mr. Wachtel for about eight months. She is being held in jail, unable to post the $250,000 bail. Her lawyer could not be reached for comment.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Democrat Will Try Again
description: Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, helped open the campaign office of a Democratic Senate candidate, Tom Strickland, a former United States attorney for Colorado. In 1996, Mr. Strickland lost a Senate race to Wayne Allard, a Republican, who has not formally declared whether he will run for re-election. Mindy Sink (NYT)

description: TIERMAN-Diane. Beloved wife of Jerome. Loving mother of Jane and Susan. Devoted grandmother of Joseph and Jessica Michaels, Stephanie and Matthew Kroll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFIELD, MAURICE ''REESE'' ULLMAN
description: ROSENFIELD-Maurice ''Reese'' Ullman. of Roslyn NY on August 12 at age 91. He is survived by his sons Robert and Jay, grandchildren Adam, Amanda, Daniel and Paul. His wife of 60 years, Harriet had died June 26, 1996. Maurice was the oldest of three brothers, Samuel Ullman ''Ullie'' and Jonas Jr. Grandson of the poet Samuel Ullman, whose poem ''Youth'' became a phenomenon in Japan after World War II. Reese served in the Navy, as a Chief Petty Officer, during that war and went on to a career in the publishing business. He formed his own company, Reese Publishing, in 1960 and published pulp fan and detective magazines. He retired at age 80 in 1989. He was a founder and president of The Periodical and Book Association of America (PBAA) and president of The Ethical Culture Society of Long Island during the years they were constructing their Nassau County chapter in New Hyde Park. He also served as president of the Roslyn Little League. For the last five years, he lived with his devoted, significant other, Georgette Spingarn of Manhasset, NY. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, August 19 at 10:30 AM at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck NY.

title: F.A.A. Orders Troubled Freight Carrier to Suspend Flights
description: The Federal Aviation Administration forced Emery Worldwide Airlines, a cargo airline with its hub in Dayton, Ohio, to ground its fleet of planes today because of extensive maintenance problems.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrest In Subway Pushing
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday after he tried to push a man off a subway platform and into an oncoming train, the police said. The man, Carl Beamon, 51, tried to push a 31-year-old man into an F train at the station at 42nd Street and the Avenue of the Americas around 3:10 p.m., the authorities said. According to the police, the 31-year-old, whose name was not released, and others overpowered Mr. Beamon. He was charged with attempted murder and reckless endangerment. Mr. Beamon was also charged in an earlier incident at the Times Square station, where, the police say, he pushed a 68-year-old man toward an oncoming E train. There were no injuries in either incident. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Remembering a Tax Cut, And Revisiting a Debate

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Jet Orders
description: Russia's main international airline, Aeroflot, said it would buy 30 regional jets to be produced in a joint venture between Boeing, and two Russian aircraft producers, Sukhoi and Ilyushin. The business plan for the project, valued at several hundred million dollars, will be completed by the end of the year, while the first test flights are scheduled for late 2004. Boeing, responsible for marketing the project, will hold talks with other Russian airlines this week to determine their financial capabilities and the scope of demand for such an aircraft. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Train Hits Rebel Mine In Angola; Scores Die
description: At least 152 people died Friday in an attack on a train south of Angola's capital, the state news agency said today. The rebel National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita, took responsibility.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Report Of Hyundai Deal
description: The American International Group is near a deal to buy a majority stake in two Hyundai group financial companies, according to Joongang Ilbo, a leading Korean newspaper. The paper, quoting a senior government official, said A.I.G. had agreed to pay about $850 million to gain control of Hyundai Investment Trust and Securities and Hyundai Securities. The report said the South Korean government agreed to pay $690 million as part of the deal, but the government denied the report. A spokesman for A.I.G. in Tokyo said the group did not comment on ''media speculation.'' A.I.G. and the government have been negotiating the deal for several months.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Heart Devices To Be Distributed
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that dozens of city-owned parks, pools, centers for the elderly and ferries would soon be equipped with defibrillators. The devices, which use electric shock to restore normal heart rhythms in heart attack victims, will be placed in 70 city facilities in all five boroughs. The city plans to distribute 1,500 of the devices over the next few years.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Restrictions On Cigarette Ads
description: Tobacco companies will be prohibited from using the words ''light'' and ''mild'' to market their cigarettes because such descriptions are misleading, Health Commissioner Allan Rock said. Mr. Rock said he had decided to ban the phrases after cigarette manufacturers ignored his warning that they voluntarily refrain from marketing low-tar cigarettes as being less harmful than regular cigarettes, which is not proved by studies. The new packaging requirements are to be phased in over the next few months. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Off Broadway, Little Dialogue
description: Contract negotiations between the Association of Theatrical Press Agents and Managers and the League of Off Broadway Theaters and Producers began to break down last week, union officials said yesterday. The discussions, which began June 5, are being held up over a contract provision on extra pay for press agents who promote shows that start out of town but are lured to Off Broadway theaters, said Maria Somma, president of the agents' group. After several days without communicating, the two sides yesterday scheduled a negotiating session for tomorrow. Ms. Somma said the theater owners and producers did not object to most of the union's provisions in the proposed five-year contract, which included raises of 5.5 percent a year. Ben Sprecher, the chief negotiator for the theaters and producers, said that the two groups had different views of what the difficulties were, but that they were working to resolve it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOLOSHOK, RALPH E., M.D.
description: MOLOSHOK-Ralph E., M.D. The Association of the Attending Staff of the Mount Sinai Hospital mourns the passing of our longstanding colleague, teacher and friend. Dr. Moloshok began his association with Mount Sinai in the Department of Pediatrics in 1940. After receiving training in General Pediatrics and Pediatric Endocrinology, he devoted the next 45 years to clinical teaching and to the superb practice of medicine. He will be fondly remembered for his exceptional wisdom and expertise, his traditional bedside manner, and his compassion for his patients. The AAS salutes Dr. Moloshok's outstanding commitment to Mount Sinai and his many years of service. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife and family. Anthony Squire, M.D., President Edward Raab, 1st Vice President Michael Harris, 2nd Vice President Vicki Lopachin, M.D., Secretary Amy Weinstein, Administrator

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Trial Set For Troopers
description: Two state troopers charged with falsifying records to obscure the race of motorists they had stopped will ask that the charges be dismissed, a defense lawyer said yesterday. A State Superior Court judge set a Nov. 13 trial date for the troopers, John Hogan, left, and James Kenna, on the records charges. But the troopers' lawyers said they would file dismissal motions by Sept. 14. The troopers were singled out because they were also charged in a shooting on the New Jersey Turnpike, said the lawyer, Jack Arseneault.

description: A storm that dumped up to three inches of rain on parts of the New York region caused delays for thousands of commuters yesterday, and also left three men injured, one critically, after they were struck by lightning in New Jersey.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Better Ratings For Chip Makers
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company gave its top stock rating to the semiconductor maker Intel, whose shares have fallen by more than half in a year, and three other chip makers, saying that business may improve in the fourth quarter. Terry Ragsdale, an analyst at Goldman, raised Intel, Analog Devices Inc. and Maxim Integrated Products Inc. to the recommend list from a market outperform rating. Intel shares rose 61 cents, to $30.56. Maxim climbed $3, to $51.19, and Analog Devices advanced $1.54, to $48.99. Mr. Ragsdale also increased his rating on Linear Technology to market outperform from market perform. Linear rose $1.51, to $45.83.

title: The Singer Seems Cheery, Even if His Songs Are Not

Marc Anthony Thompson, the man behind the persona and the band, may be the most entertaining showman currently working the New York stage. Take such praise as exaggeration, but hyperbole is the only form of rhetoric that suits this unusual artist.

title: F.D.A. Increases Efforts to Avert Drug-Induced Liver Damage
description: It is an unsettling truth, one that people who have to take medicine would probably rather not think about: occasionally, with little or no warning, prescription and even over-the-counter drugs can cause liver damage. Cases are not common, but they can be devastating, leading to death or requiring a transplant.

description: Bayer A.G., badly weakened after being forced to withdraw one of its most important new drugs from the market, all but admitted today that it might no longer be able to stand on its own in the pharmaceutical industry.

title: Brother, Can You Spare a Dime?
description: Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for mayor in New York City, has a wealthy older brother who has been raising money for the campaign. The brother, Stephen Green, has apparently brought in hundreds of thousands of dollars, mainly from his friends in the real estate industry. The potential problem with this demonstration of brotherly love is that Stephen Green has contracts with the city, which pays more than $10 million a year to rent space in buildings his company owns. If Mark Green is elected, questions about potential conflicts of interest will be bound to arise.

description: Robert S. Jones, respected editor of books by several authors, including Russell Banks and Oscar Hijuelos, as well as the author of two novels of his own, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. He was 47 and lived in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARRONSON, JULES ALEXANDER
description: ARRONSON-Jules Alexander. Of Palm Beach, FL, previously of White Plains, NY, died on August 12, 2001. Beloved husband of 45 years of Shavie Scher Arronson. Cherished father of Jill Bachman and husband Rik of Fairfield, CT, and Liz Rueven and husband Mony of Westport, CT. Adored grandfather of Daniel and Elana Rueven and Jennifer and Melanie Bachman. Devoted to immediate family and loved by greater extended family. Predeceased by brother Myron Arronson. His wisdom and love and concern for all will be missed. Past Treasurer of Shoe League of Greater New York. Former member of Temple Israel, White Plains. Memorial services at noon Tuesday, August 14, Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1652 Central Park Ave., Yonkers, NY. Donations to the Alzheimer's Community Care Association, West Palm Beach, FL, or Jewish Family and Children's Services, West Palm Beach, FL.

description: Calling it one of the worst sex crimes they had seen, investigators described today how a Long Island couple lured a 15-year-old Massachusetts girl over the Internet, kidnapped her and sexually abused her for a week.

description: Two patients with forms of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, one of which was contracted from eating infected beef, have been treated at a San Francisco hospital with an obsolete malaria drug that doctors hope will alleviate the fatal brain malady.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Names, Addresses, Conflict?
description: When Treasurer Shannon O'Brien, a Democrat who is planning to run for governor next year, asked for a copy of information about the state's voters, William F. Galvin, the secretary of state, gave her the names and addresses. But in compliance with a 1994 state law, Mr. Galvin, also a Democrat, withheld details about their occupations, dates of birth, party affiliation and number of times they have been to the polls. But Brian Cresta, the chairman of the state Republican Party, there was one problem: Mr. Galvin has his eye on the governor's seat himself. Mr. Cresta planned to ask the attorney general, Thomas F. Reilly, a Democrat, to look into the possible conflict of interest. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Carl Diedrich, 86, Engineer Who Applied His Talents to Coffee
description: Carl Diedrich, who developed a coffee roaster bearing his name and whose business later evolved into a chain of coffeehouses, died on July 31 at his home in Costa Mesa, Calif. He was 86.

description: Patients considering euthanasia are worried less about unbearable pain than about the social and emotional disintegration that accompanies terminal illness, a new survey has found.

description: ''Up! on the Roof'' has become an enjoyable staple of New York summer dance. Organized by Erin Reck and Amelia Derezinski, the three-year-old program offers audiences a chance to see new and unusual dance in the airy rooftop theater of John Jay College. Proceeds from the event, presented on Friday night, went to KIDS of N.Y.U., an organization supporting children's services at New York University Medical Center.

title: A Baffling Viral Outbreak? He's on the Trail

title: Editorial Observer; Wrestling With the Legacy of Slavery at Yale
description: Americans tend to believe that slavery was peculiar to the South and that the North, particularly the New England states, was ''free.'' This misbelief stems in part from mistaken ideas about the Civil War -- the central metaphor of American popular history -- and partly from the gargantuan reputations left by Northeastern abolitionists like Horace Greeley, William Lloyd Garrison and Harriet Beecher Stowe. The truth is that slavery existed all over the early United States. It lingered in Greeley's New York until 1827, and in Stowe's Connecticut until the late date of 1848. With the exception of architectural style, a traveler to the slave-era farms of New England would have found them virtually indistinguishable from the slaveholding regions of the rural South.

title: Econnect to Pay $1 Million to Ex-Chief
description: Econnect, which makes a device for making secure Internet purchases, settled a breach of contract lawsuit filed by its former president, Stephen Pazian, for about $1 million, according to a regulatory filing.

title: Childbirth: Prepartum Depression Also an Issue
description: Despite concern about postpartum depression, in reality, more British women are depressed during pregnancy than after giving birth, according to a study published last week in The British Medical Journal. The study, conducted by researchers at the University of Bristol, suggested that some of the vigilance now used to catch cases of postpartum depression should be directed at the previous nine months as well.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Caviar Crackdown
description: Weeks after Russia halted commercial sturgeon fishing in the Caspian Sea in an attempt to protect dwindling black-caviar supplies, border guards arrested two men in the neighboring Dagestan region who where trying to leave the country with 54 of the ugly fish, weighing 1,100 pounds. Nine were beluga sturgeons, source of the world's most prized caviar. Russia, Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan have banned sturgeon fishing until 2002, but poaching is widespread, as is pollution, leading to a 90 percent drop in the beluga population since 1980. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: VANISHING INK CITED IN CHECK CASE A former secretary at Bear, Stearns & Company and her husband were each indicted yesterday on 13 counts of grand larceny, forgery and other crimes after they were accused of stealing more than $50,000 from a partner at the brokerage house. The secretary, Anamarie Giambrone, was accused of using quick-fading ink to write checks that her boss, Eli Wachtel, then signed. Once the ink faded, prosecutors said, Ms. Giambrone made the checks out to "cash" and gave some of the money to her husband, Salvatore Giambrone, who used it to start a pizzeria in Queens. Ms. Giambrone worked for Mr. Wachtel for about eight months. She is being held in jail, unable to post the $250,000 bail. Her lawyer could not be reached for comment.   Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Ailing Churchill Biographer Says He Can't Finish Trilogy
description: Several times a month the phone rings at the New York offices of Little, Brown, the publishing house, with each of the callers posing an insistent and nearly identical question. When, the queries go, will William Manchester finally finish the third and final volume of ''The Last Lion,'' his hugely successful biography of Winston Churchill?

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 — Representative Gary A. Condit is fighting back against newspapers in his Congressional district that have demanded his resignation.
