description: BERGER-Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Arthur. Loving mother of Harold, Carol, Madeline and the late Joseph. Devoted grandmother of Michelle and Jordan. Dear sister of Ann Lieberman, the late Moe Werfel, William Werfel and Ceil Gelman. Lillian and Arthur were the owners of the famous Yonah Schimmel Knishes. Services will be at Riverside Chapel at 12:45 Thursday, August 16.

title: An Experienced Guide on the Electoral Paper Trail
description: SO many Cinderella candidates to shepherd through the scrum of this City Council race. So many scrawled petition signatures to study like tea leaves. So much nitpicking, backbiting and arguing at Board of Elections hearings when the Cinderellas-turned-litigants try to knock one another off the ballot before the voters can. So many billable hours for lawyers with a navigational knack for New York City's labyrinthine election law.

title: United Auto Workers Make Bold, New Bid to Unionize Nissan Plant
description: NASHVILLE, Aug. 14 — The United Automobile Workers union asked federal officials here today to hold a vote among workers at the giant Nissan factory in nearby Smyrna, Tenn., on whether to unionize, setting up the nation's first such election in a dozen years at a foreign-owned auto assembly plant.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Prison Population Drops
description: New Jersey had the second steepest drop in prison population last year, with a decrease of 5.4 percent, according to Justice Department statistics released yesterday. Massachusetts had the largest decrease at 5.6 percent. Officials at the New Jersey Department of Corrections attribute the decline to reduced parole backlog and a lower crime rate.

title: For Chancellor, Trying Times Erode Support
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has had an excruciating summer, with a new crisis erupting almost weekly since May and political support that has gone from emphatic to tepid at best.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS BRAZIL: PROFIT FOR JET MAKER Despite an energy crisis that is expected to shave at least 2 percentage points off Brazil's economic growth, the aircraft maker Empresa Brasileira de Aeronáutica S.A., or Embraer, said its second-quarter profit tripled to $135.9 million compared with the period last year. The company, the country's largest exporter, benefited from a nearly 7 percent devaluation in Brazil's currency this quarter.   Jennifer L. Rich (NYT) EUROPE BRITAIN: BID FOR PUBS FAILS Pubmaster, which operates a chain of pubs in Britain, said its hostile bid for its rival Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries had failed. It said its offer had lapsed after receiving support from only 47 percent of Wolverhampton's shareholders. Pubmaster's chief executive, John Sands, has said he wants to add 3,000 pubs to the 2,000 the company already owns. Pubmaster's bid of 513 pence a share valued the company, one of Britain's largest regional brewers and owner of 1,770 pubs, at £485 million ($690 million), a price that Wolverhampton had called too low. If left independent, Wolverhampton had promised to buy back shares and streamline operations.   Suzanne Kapner (NYT) ITALY: INSURANCE BID RULING Shares in the Ital- ian insurance company La Fondiaria Assicurazioni rose more than 8 percent after the Italian stock market regulator ruled that a domestic rival, Societá Assicuratrice Industriale, must make a bid for all of Fondiaria after acquiring a minority share. The regulator argued that Industriale cooperated with the Italian investment bank Mediobanca when it agreed last month to acquire a 29 percent stake in Fondiaria from the Montedison chemical and energy conglomerate. The purchase was agreed on the eve of a hostile takeover of Montedison by the Fiat group. Mediobanca owns 14 percent of Fondiaria, and under Italian stock market rules a bidder for more than 30 percent of a company's shares must make a public offering for the whole company. Industriale and Mediobanca denied any cooperation and are expected to appeal the ruling.   John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Internet Use Growing Slowly
description: Fifty-eight percent of Americans had Internet access in their homes in July 2001, compared with 52 percent in July 2000, according to new data from the Internet audience measurement service Nielsen/NetRatings. In July 1999, 39 percent of the population in the United States had access to the Web in their homes. Although the growth rate is slowing, the number of home users in the United States still increased 16 percent in the last year, from 88 million users to 102 million users. The amount of time spent online by home users is also increasing, to an average of 10 hours and 19 minutes a month in July 2001, up from 9 hours and 41 minutes in July 2000.

description: For anyone who lived in Russia during the height of the cold war, the experience of John E. Tobin Jr., the American Fulbright scholar, may resonate. When Mr. Tobin, accused of being a spy and jailed in Russia for six months on charges of marijuana possession, returned to the United States last week, he denied the accusations. In an e-mail message to officials of the Fulbright program, he also told of something that struck a chord with me -- efforts by Russian intelligence officials to recruit him as a spy.

The workers were arrested on charges of preaching Christianity. The Taliban now say they are looking into a possible conspiracy by Western aid groups to lure Afghan Muslims from their faith. title: Friends Crowd Debussy at His Own Festival
description: Since the host of the festival ''Debussy and His World'' is an academic institution, Bard College here, it's perhaps not surprising that so many of the works it presents are primarily of academic interest. The festival's first weekend, six concerts and a panel between Friday and today, felt very much like the first half of an undergraduate college course, with the emphasis on the ''and His World'' part of the equation. One emerged with a solid grounding in aspects of French musical history in the last decades of the 19th century and a tantalizing sense that the weekend was setting the stage for next weekend's payoff, when the focus will actually be on Debussy himself.

title: TRINITY INDUSTRIES AGREES TO ACQUIRE THRALL CAR
description: Trinity Industries, the nation's leading maker of railroad cars, agreed to buy the Thrall Car Manufacturing Company, which is closely held, for at least $364.1 million in cash and stock to expand into auto rack manufacturing. Trinity will pay $165 million in cash and issue 7.15 million shares of common stock to Thrall shareholders. The exchange of stock is valued at about $199.1 million based on Friday's closing price. Trinity, which is based in Dallas, will make additional payments to Thrall shareholders of as much as $45 million over five years, based on the number of rail cars sold in North America, said John L. Adams, executive vice president at Trinity. Trinity will relocate its rail unit operations to Thrall's headquarters, in Chicago Heights, Ill., Mr. Adams said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BREEN, DANIEL M., JR.
description: BREEN-Daniel M., Jr. January 31, 1959-August 14, 1998. Another year without you has flown by. Carter and Alexis Breen are your new nephew and niece; you'd be so proud. Your Mom had open heart surgery, but seems fine. Laura and I work together now, and I weigh less than I did when you met me. We all love you, miss you, and think about you every day of our lives. ''See'' you in the fall. Love Always, Howard

title: The Case of a Jailed Journalist
description: In a brazen assault on First Amendment values and the public interest in a free press, federal authorities have been holding Vanessa Leggett in a Houston jail since July 20. The 33-year-old woman, who plans to write and sell a book about a high-profile 1997 murder case, is being held in contempt of court for refusing to turn over to a grand jury all of her notes. Ms. Leggett has cooperated, up to a point, with both local and federal prosecutors who have worked on the case. But when she felt pressed to compromise confidential sources, she properly refused to cooperate further. In siding with the government and ordering Ms. Leggett jailed, a federal judge, Melinda Harmon, failed in her duty to protect Ms. Leggett's constitutional rights.

title: Kmart Diversity Officer
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that it had named Randy Allen to the newly created positions of executive vice president for strategic initiatives and chief diversity officer.

title: Planning a Nest of Concrete for a Landmark of Flight
description: The fight to save Eero Saarinen's T.W.A. Flight Center at Kennedy International Airport -- that sculptural, vaulted concrete gull of a building that seems poised to take wing itself -- will have a decided twist: No one is proposing to tear it down.

title: BE AEROSPACE AGREES TO BUY M&M, A FASTENER CONCERN
description: BE Aerospace Inc., which has made three acquisitions this year, agreed to buy M&M Aerospace Hardware Inc. for at least $177 million in cash and stock to add aerospace fasteners to its line of products. Shareholders of the closely held M&M, based in Miami, will receive $152 million in cash and $52 million in BE Aerospace stock. They may receive an additional $23 million based on the company's performance. BE Aerospace, which is based in Wellington, Fla., makes aircraft seats, kitchen gear and oxygen systems. The addition of M&M, which distributes aerospace fasteners, will enable the company to offer more products to airline makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOCHMAN, SUSAN
description: HOCHMAN-Susan. Passed away on August 13, 2001. She was the beloved wife of Robert Hochman who predeased her. She will be remembered with love by her family, her daughter Renee Kornet, her son-in-law Mitchell Kornet and her grandchildren Alison and Robin Kornet. She was a truly remarkable wife, mother, grandmother and teacher.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: New Greek Orthodox Patriarch
description: The Greek Orthodox Church elected Eireneos I, a 62-year-old bishop, as its new patriarch in the Holy Land. He was chosen by 17 bishops voting inside the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem and replaces Diodoros I, who died in December. After his election, a church official said, he met with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel, whose government had sought to disqualify him and four other candidates, citing ''security considerations'' and ''interests in Jersualem.'' The church, which has about 100,000 followers in the Holy Land, owns or leases large areas of Jerusalem.

description: The death toll rose to at least 86 in flash floods that have roared down mountainsides and swept through villages in the northern province of Phetchabun. Heavy rains set off the flooding Saturday that caught many people asleep in their homes. Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: In the face of a sluggish economy and a tough market for retailers, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and Home Depot Inc. each managed to report today that earnings rose in the second quarter.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Too Much Drinking, Official Says
description: The Irish are ''among the biggest boozers on the planet,'' said Deputy Arts Minister Mary Coughlan, calling on her countrymen to fight ''this self-inflicted plague.'' Alcohol abuse costs the economy and health care system around $2 billion each year, Ms. Coughlan said Sunday, speaking at the opening of a summer school, because ''when we get tanked up, we fight, we crash cars, we beat up our spouses and our children, we fall down and we miss days at work.'' Ireland ranks third in per-capita alcohol consumption in Europe, after Luxembourg and Portugal. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: Two large European advertising companies reported first-half results today that offered starkly different views of the sharp downturn in ad spending.

title: For Victims of Arizona Copter Crash, a Marathon of Grief
description: By the fifth funeral of the day, the people of Borough Park, Brooklyn, were worn down. Those who could not fit inside the Shomrei Hadas Chapels to mourn the victims in Friday's helicopter crash in Arizona listened to the broadcast from sound trucks, standing silent on the sidewalk or crying quietly at the bus stop on 14th Avenue as the five-hour marathon of grief ground on.

title: TOM JAMES OFFERS TO BUY OUT HARTMARX SHAREHOLDERS
description: The Hartmarx Corporation -- maker and seller of men's and women's clothing under the Hart Schaffner & Marx, Tommy Hilfiger and Austin Reed brands -- received a $4.50-a-share cash offer from the Tom James Company for the shares it does not already own. Spencer Hays, chairman of Tom James, which is closely held, said in a letter to Hartmarx that the offer was more than double Hartmarx's closing price Friday. Tom James owns almost 5 percent of Hartmarx. With 29.9 million Hartmarx shares outstanding Aug. 6, the offer would be worth $128 million.

title: Russians Resist Rumsfeld Effort To Set Aside ABM Treaty
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld met President Vladimir V. Putin and his defense minister today for talks that threw into sharp relief the disagreements over whether to deploy missile defenses, how to slash nuclear arsenals and whether arms control talks can even be the tool to bridge their differences.

title: You Wins By a Neck in Adirondack Stakes
description: Cashier's Dreams and You dueled the length of the stretch in the 86th running of the Adirondack Stakes yesterday before the jockey Edgar Prado nudged You past the undefeated favorite to post a neck victory in the Grade II six and a half furlong spring for juvenile fillies. You covered the ground in a rapid 1:15.16 and earned $90,000 for owner Edmund A. Gann. She paid $13 for a $2 bet to win.

title: Hunters' Camouflage: Not Just for the City Streets
description: Their clothes are designed expressly not to be noticed, in styles that used to undergo major change about once every 20 years. Their garments are often constructed so durably that people are known to include specific favorites in their wills. They exert a tremendous influence on capital F fashion, as evidenced by the recent proliferation of camouflage cloth garments from New York sidewalks to the runways of the Parisian haute couture. Yet the last group most people think of as fashion conscious are the 14 million people that the United States Fish and Wildlife Service estimates go into the woods each year with gun or bow.

title: Profits Fall 18% at May Department Stores
description: Fiscal second-quarter profit at May Department Stores fell 18 percent as the company, which owns Lord & Taylor and Hecht's, had higher costs and sluggish sales.

title: Louis Rayfield Purnell Sr., 81, Airman and Museum Curator
description: Louis Rayfield Purnell Sr., who went from decorated Tuskegee airman to curator of air and space relics at the Smithsonian, died on Friday at his home in Washington. He was 81.

title: Technology Briefing | Media: More AOL Layoffs Possible
description: AOL Time Warner stock fell yesterday on speculation that more layoffs were coming. Jim Whitney, a spokesman for AOL Time Warner, declined to comment, but Wall Street analysts and some employees said they expected layoffs to begin this week. The cuts would be the second major round of layoffs this year at the company, the world's largest Internet and media company. The company cut about 2,400 jobs in January. John Corcoran, an analyst at CIBC World Markets, who met with J. Michael Kelly, AOL Time Warner's chief financial officer, on Friday, said that the company was looking to cut costs in its cable and music divisions. Mr. Corcoran said he had no specific knowledge of layoffs and maintained a strong buy on the stock. Last month, Gerald M. Levin, chief executive of AOL Time Warner, said that advertising revenue was stabilizing and that he did not expect to make specific layoffs.

description: The Women's United Soccer Association's inaugural playoffs will begin Saturday with the third-seeded Power visiting the second-seeded Bay Area CyberRays and the fourth-seeded Philadelphia Charge playing in Atlanta against the Beat, the top-seeded team.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Jobs Lost In New Jersey
description: New Jersey's economy continued to slow last month, as the state lost about 5,200 private sector jobs, according to the New Jersey Department of Labor. title: At a Hip New Hotel, Food to Write Home About
description: SOME chefs are highly imaginative but can't quite seem to make their dreams come true on the plate. Others have a firm grasp of the fundamentals but don't have any brilliant ideas. (Type 2 is twice as valuable as Type 1.) Then there are the chefs, like Rick Laakkonen at Ilo, who seem to be effortlessly inventive but solidly grounded in the fundamentals of flavor, texture and harmony. No matter how wild his flights of fancy, they wind up seeming natural, even inevitable. Everything works in an understandable way. Ilo, a Finnish word meaning something like ''bliss,'' is in a hotel. This, too, seems both natural and inevitable these days. New York's buoyant economy has translated into a hotel boom, which in turn has translated into a new generation of hotel restaurants that have redefined the category. As recently as a decade ago, a hotel restaurant was staid, formal and luxurious. It served French food to an elderly clientele.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Microsoft Disputes Xbox Report
description: In a report released yesterday, a securities analyst said a flaw in Intel's motherboard design for Microsoft's forthcoming Xbox game console could set back the initial manufacturing schedule, but Microsoft repudiated the report. ''There's absolutely no problem with the design of Intel's motherboard,'' Microsoft said. ''We're still on track for a Nov. 8 launch.'' The analyst, Eric Ross of Thomas Weisel Partners, wrote in a research note on the graphics company NVidia that ''multiple sources throughout the Xbox supply chain'' had reported three- to four-week delays in the manufacturing schedule. Microsoft has committed $500 million to promote Xbox and has said it will release 600,000 to 800,000 of the machines on Nov. 8, in time for the critical holiday shopping season. Microsoft shares fell $1.14, to $64.69. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

He said he has conferred with the United States attorney for the Eastern District. The F.B.I. is also investigating whether a federal crime was committed. title: National Briefing | West: California: Changes For Horse Bettors

The measure also allows gamblers to place wagers only when they make advance cash deposits to cover the bets, and it includes protections to prevent gambling by minors. It also mandates improved living conditions for track workers. Governor Davis, a Democrat, said he signed the bill this time in part because of changes in federal law expanding Internet wagering in all states. James Sterngold (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEAGLE, RHODA WALKER
description: TEAGLE-Rhoda Walker. Age 91, of Woodstock, VT, formerly of NYC, died August 9 at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center, Lebanon, NH. She was born June 9, 1910 in New York City, one of five daughters of Roberts Walker, a senior partner of White and Case lawyers in NY, and the former Edna Morse. She was educated at the Chapin School in NYC, attended Bryn Mawr College and then studied music in Paris with Nadia Boulanger. Recently a debut prize was established in her name for audition winners of Young Concert Artists in New York. In 1931, she married the late John French Jr. of NYC and Woodstock, VT., & is survived by the three children of that marriage: John French III of NYC, Roberts Walker French of Santa Fe, N.M., and Mary French Moore of Cheyenne, WY. In addition to her three children, she is survived by one sister Katherine MacKenty of Martha's Vineyard, ten grandchildren and 13 great grandchildren. She moved to Woodstock, VT in 1948, and in 1955, she married Frank H. Teagle Jr. of Woodstock, who predeceased her in 1997. She was active all her life in community affairs. In 1943 she was one of the co-founders of The Officers Club at the Hotel Delmonico in NY, which became an internationally famous home-awayfrom-home until 1945 for Allied military officers from around the world. In 1942, she was also a volunteer air-raid warden, patrolling the streets of Harlem at night, twice a week, helping to secure the wartime blackout. She was an early member of the Cosmopolitan Club. She continued to be active in community affairs after moving to Vermont, and in 1997 was honored as Woodstock's Citizen of the Year. In 1999, at the age of 89, she was selected as the Queen of Woodstock's annual Rotary Carnival. She was a charter Overseer of the Dartmouth Medical School, and among many boards, served on the Vermont Institute of Natural Science, The Vermont Land Trust, The North Pomfret Congregational Church, the Vermont Children's Aid Society, Mt. Ascutney Hospital and the Ottauquechee Health Center, and was a Woodstock Village Trustee. She served as Secretary of the Woodstock Union High School Board, and recently the Library in that School was dedicated in her name. Demonstrating her commitment to her community, she and her late husband owned the Elm Tree Press, the Town and Country Shop and the Yankee Bookshop, all in Woodstock. Funeral services will be private and a memorial service will be held Saturday, August 18 at 11AM at the Unitarian Universalist Chapel in Woodstock. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center, One Medical Center Drive, Lebanon, NH 03756 or the Vermont Institute of Natural Science, 27023 Church Hill Road, Woodstock, VT 05091.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Group To Attend Northern Festivities

But the South later decided that the group could go, provided members did not participate in opening or closing exercises or endorse North Korean policy. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: DEERE WILL PARE ITS FARM EQUIPMENT PRODUCTION BY 25%
description: Deere & Company, the largest tractor maker, said yesterday that it planned to cut production 25 percent, resulting in a fourth-quarter loss that will erase most of its profit this year as bad weather and the slow economy hurt sales. The company also said that its fiscal third-quarter net income fell 58 percent, to $71.8 million, or 30 cents a share, compared with $172.4 million, or 72 cents, a year ago. Sales in the period ended July 31 fell 1.4 percent, to $3.58 billion from $3.63 billion. Deere, based in Moline, Ill., is scaling back production of large tractors, combines and cotton-pickers as four years of bumper corn, wheat and soybean crops have depressed prices, leaving farmers with less to spend on equipment.

title: Miscommunication in Moscow
description: After all the bonhomie between George W. Bush and Russia's president, Vladimir Putin, the frosty arms talks between American and Russian officials in Moscow this week were disappointing. Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld and Mr. Putin seemed to speak past each other on the core issues. Mr. Putin sought specific numbers and timetables on American nuclear arms reductions and missile defense plans. Mr. Rumsfeld wanted to limit the conversation to vaguely defined consultations. It was just an opening dialogue, but it did not augur well for Mr. Bush's and Mr. Putin's declared plan to link talks on offensive and defensive weapons.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Arrest In Reckless Driving

The man, Glen Wilson, 54, was driving with an expired inspection and registration tag that read ''ISLEY'' near 10th Avenue and West 57th Street when he was stopped by the police. Officer George Jensen, a police spokesman, said he could not confirm whether Mr. Wilson was a member of the Isley Brothers. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: A New Store With Greens Like Emeralds
description: At his new Paradise Market, Jai Rowe displays fruit, bunches of herbs and frilly greens as a jeweler would gems. The store, at 1614 Second Avenue (84th Street), is more than twice the size of his original one at 83rd Street and Madison Avenue, which he closed more than a year ago when the rent was raised. But his merchandising has not changed. ''I do not wash my lettuces, hose them down the way the others do,'' he said. ''They will last longer and stay fresher at home this way, and keep their nutrients. And I never put anything out on the street to bake in the sun.'' His berries are placed in an open case with a cooling unit. He has added fresh breads from Ecce Panis, cheeses, imported butters, D'Artagnan charcuterie, top-of-the-line oils, artisanal pastas and Ciao Bella ice cream. As for a salad bar, he doesn't believe in them. He has a small kitchen to make soups and sandwiches to go. Coffee with that sandwich? It will be Illy, strong and dark, and dispensed from his new coffee bar.

title: Tapas, Italian Style, Perfectly Cool in the Heat

Toyota RAV4's along with six other makes and models were wrapped in orange and yellow vinyl, turning them into rolling advertisements for Reese's Puffs, a sweetened breakfast cereal from General Mills.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Ebay Extends Pact With AOL
description: EBay, the online auctioneer, and AOL Time Warner said the two companies would expand AOL's promotion of eBay and extend the alliance for three more years. AOL, based in Dulles, Va., has promoted eBay through its online service for several years, but AOL's merger with Time Warner gave the company a range of new advertising opportunities, including Fortune, Time and People magazines and the cable TV channels TNT and CNN. The announcement comes six months after eBay struck a similar deal with Microsoft to promote the auction service on its online properties. EBay paid AOL $75 million in 1999; the companies would not disclose the financial terms of the current deal. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Espionage Conviction
description: A former official in the Russian Embassy in South Korea was sentenced to four and a half years in prison for passing state secrets to South Korea, the latest event in a string of espionage cases that some attribute to overly zealous prosecutors. The diplomat, Valentin Moiseyev, insists that he is innocent. A second former diplomat accused of passing secrets to Britain, Platon Obukhov, is being retried after his conviction was thrown out. And a military scholar, Igor Sutyagin, faces a 20-year sentence if convicted on charges of selling his analyses of unclassified weaponry documents to a British company that prosecutors say was a C.I.A. front. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Man Accused In Investor Fraud
description: A man was charged yesterday with bilking nine investors out of a total of more than $1 million in a real estate swindle. He promised investors rates of return from 30 percent to 70 percent. The New York State attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, said the man, Rudy Lavanture, 29, of Jersey City, attracted the investors through ads in The New York Times, then falsely told them that he was a broker representing the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, and that the agency would provide him with lists of available homes to be bought and renovated. He told the investors that their money would be used to buy and repair the homes, which would then be sold at a large profit, Mr. Spitzer said. He added that to perpetrate the illusion that there were such houses, Mr. Lavanture set up a company named HUD, which is how the housing agency is generally referred to, and had the investors give him checks made payable to HUD -- which he could then cash. Mr. Lavanture was charged with grand larceny and fraud. He pleaded not guilty in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. His lawyer, Barry Kenyon, did not respond to a telephone message.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Allianz Profit Falls
description: The German insurance group Allianz A.G. reported first-half earnings of 1.4 billion euros ($1.3 billion), down 12 percent from a 1.6 billion euro net profit posted a year earlier. The company reiterated its expectation of meeting a full-year net profit growth of 13 percent excluding results from Dresdner Bank. Allianz and Dresdner completed a merger in July. Dresdner reported results separately, posting a 12.7 percent drop in pretax profit. It cited weakness in international capital markets and an 18.6 percent rise in costs mainly from consolidation of its Wasserstein Perella investment unit. Net income at Dresdner rose 45 percent as income tax payments were significantly lower. Desmond Butler (NYT)

title: A Grant to Aid Hispanic Students
description: La Guardia Community College in Queens and New York City Technical College in Brooklyn have won a $3.1 million grant from the federal Department of Education to help Hispanic students from low-income families. The grant will pay for a system to let students post their work on the Internet so that teachers and administrators at both colleges can follow their progress and offer increased support. About 39 percent of the students at La Guardia and 28 percent at New York City Tech are Hispanic. Graduation rates for Hispanic students nationwide have been far below those for non-Hispanic white students. JO ANN LA PERLA, provost at New York City Tech and a co-director of the project, said she expected the program to improve graduation rates on both campuses. Karen W. Arenson

title: EASTMAN CHEMICAL TO CLOSE ALABAMA PLANT WITH 75 JOBS
description: Eastman Chemical, the largest producer of plastics used in soda bottles, said it would close a plant in Moundville, Ala., eliminating 75 jobs, as it continues to cut costs. Eastman will take a charge for the closing as it consolidates resins manufacturing for the coatings, adhesives and graphic arts industries, the company said. Eastman is planning to split into two companies, one involved in commodity plastics and fibers, and the other in chemicals, coatings and adhesives.

The company attributed the unit's loss primarily to investment write-downs. UBS's net income after tax fell to 1.39 billion Swiss francs ($822.5 million), or 1.06 francs a share, from 2.05 billion, or 1.73 francs a share, a year earlier. Now all that effort to make tennis a sport of the common people is being reversed by the United States Tennis Association at its premier event, the United States Open, which commences later this month.

title: Going Afar for a Debate
description: Nine members of Hunter College High School's debate team will head for Mongolia later this month to help develop a high school debate program there. Members of the Hunter team, the state champion, will debate secondary school and university students in English on a topic far removed from their urban experience: Should Mongolia seek economic alternatives to animal husbandry? NOEL SELEGZI, the team's coach, is also executive director of the International Debate Education Association, which has helped create debate programs in secondary schools and universities in Haiti, and in Europe and Asia. MOLLIE EISENBERG, a Hunter senior and team member who lives in Chelsea, said the trip, with visits to Ulan Bator and the Gobi Desert, seemed ''like going to Mars.'' Karen W. Arenson

description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's plan to reduce the bureaucracy at the Board of Education would eliminate up to 1,200 administrative jobs over the next three years and cut the board's budget by roughly $300 million, a city official and others familiar with the plan said yesterday.

title: A Peek Behind Sade's Veil of Heartbreak
description: In an era of unchecked self-expression and emotional outbursts, modesty and discretion made Sade a star. On Monday night she started her first of two sold-out shows at Madison Square Garden singing behind a scrim while casting a larger-than-life silhouette: a perfect reflection of the way she uses veiled tones and shadowy hints to draw listeners closer.

title: Researchers Discount a Caution In Debate Over Cloned Humans
description: In the highly charged debate over human cloning, experts cite deformities and deaths in cloned animals as evidence that making genetic replicas of people would be dangerous. Now scientists at Duke University are challenging this idea.

title: A Fate Worse Than Procrastination
description: EVERYONE has a task she puts off until it becomes infinitely more dreadful. Mine is filing my expenses. An equally delinquent friend of mine insists there is deep pathology at work here, and that our real fear, rooted in childhood, is that a ''father figure'' will reprimand us for having spent too much money. All I know is that I ''lend'' various publications frightening amounts of money because I can't get my expense statements out on time.

title: Hearing Metaphors for Life in a Choral Rarity
description: ''The Seasons'' almost wrecked Haydn's health. The huge success of ''The Creation'' three years before (Napoleon was nearly assassinated on the way to the Paris premiere) hung over him like a burden, and then there was Baron Gottfried van Swieten's flowery text adapted from James Thomson's poetic tribute to the rural calendar. It was a text Haydn largely disliked but conscientiously addressed.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Firefighter To Leave Hospital
description: The most seriously injured firefighter to survive a store fire that killed three of his colleagues on June 17 is scheduled to be released from Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens today, a hospital spokeswoman said. The firefighter, Joseph Vosilla, is in stable condition and will be taken to a rehabilitation center. An explosion shattered his pelvis and caused other internal injuries. The fire, started when two teenagers tipped over a gasoline can, was declared an accident. Yilu Zhao (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Air Treaty Challenge
description: Britain's third-largest airline, BMI British Midland, said it would file a complaint with European Union regulators in an attempt to nullify a British-American treaty that permits only two airlines from each country to fly trans-Atlantic routes between Britain and the United States. BMI said that it had been unable to fly to the United States from Heathrow Airport in London because of the treaty, which permits only British Airways, Virgin Atlantic Airways, United Airlines and American Airlines to fly the route. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYER, LOUIS
description: FLYER-Louis. Devoted husband to the late Ann Schapiro. Survived by daughter, Gladys, grandchildren Jeffrey, Kenneth, Elizabeth and his grandsons' wives, Susan and Harumi, great-grandchildren Jared and Emma Rose. Born in Russia in 1902, he came to New York in 1921, the last of eleven siblings to arrive in the U.S. Leaving behind extreme poverty, he ran his own jewelry company, Flyer Brothers, and became president of the Jewelers Association. A tireless worker for Israel, he was active in B'nai Brith and Hillel and helped found The Shul in Surfside, Florida, where he was at the center of activity for two decades. A dry wit, a careful eye, and a huge heart, he outlived his siblings and will be missed by his entire family. Services to be held on Thursday 10:30 AM at Boulevard Riverside in Hewlett, NY. (516-295-3100).

title: Student Housing at Marymount
description: Marymount Manhattan College, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, will open its first dormitory next month, coming to the relief of students who have had to find space in a nearby hotel and the 92nd Street Y, among other places. The college will own and occupy the first 31 floors of a 46- story high-rise at 231-235 East 55th Street. Marymount will have 114 suites for 493 students. The nonsectarian college is charging the residents $8,500 a year. Private apartments in the building rent for $3,200 to $15,000 a month.

title: Coming of Europe's New Cash Feeds Jitters Large and Small
description: PARIS, Aug. 14  Will chaos reign when much of Europe starts changing over to euro coins and notes on Jan. 1? Will lines clog the aisles of supermarkets as cashiers fumble trying to figure out euro change? Will citizens hoard their new euro coins as collectors' items? Will people feel so ill at ease with the new prices that they just won't buy anything beyond the basics?

title: Two Uneasy States of Independence
description: Today is Independence Day, and India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, will speak to the nation from the ramparts of Delhi's 17th century Mogul bastion, the Lal Qila. These days the address is delivered from behind a bulletproof screen. With one prime minister lost to Sikh separatists and a former prime minister to Tamil assassins, Indian security is tight. This year the fear is of a Kashmiri plot. So we celebrate a nation besieged, from without and within, by competing nationalisms. We cannot celebrate that paradox, yet we can hardly escape it.

title: India Leader Blames Pakistan for Peace Talks Breakdown
description: NEW DELHI, Aug. 15 — In his first direct address to the nation since the breakdown of peace talks with Pakistan a month ago, India's Prime Minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, today blamed Pakistan's military ruler for the failure. He said India would never accept the general's singular focus on the two nations' conflict in Kashmir.

title: Rangers Establish Their Boundaries For Lindros Deal
description: Rangers General Manager Glen Sather began negotiating directly yesterday with Carl Lindros one day after striking a tentative deal with the Philadelphia Flyers to obtain his son, Eric.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Razorfish Reports A Loss
description: The Web design and Internet consulting firm Razorfish reported a second-quarter net loss of $137.1 million, or $1.40 a diluted share. The company, which cut its forecast for the quarter in late July amid falling demand for Internet consulting services, said restructuring charges of $70 million had contributed significantly to the loss. In the second quarter of 2000, the company earned $5.1 million, or 5 cents a share. Sales dropped to $28.7 million from $76.6 million a year earlier. The report was the first under Razorfish's new chief executive, Jean-Phillippe Maheu, above, who has closed the company's offices in Helsinki, Finland, and Milan, consolidated other offices and eliminated 600 jobs. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Miss America as Reality TV, but Nobody Will Be Voted Off the Stage
description: Don't expect the sight of gowned beauties eating rats or conspiratorial huddles among contestants, but this year's Miss America Pageant will include elements of the wildly popular television series ''Survivor,'' with a dash of Oscar night hoopla and Super Bowl hoo-ha thrown in for good measure.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline rose after a fire shut a refinery near Chicago, bolstering expectations for a decline in inventories. In New York, gasoline for September delivery rose 1.11 cents, or 1.4 percent, to 81.27 cents a gallon.

description: In 1998, top executives from US Airways met with analysts and promised to transform the airline into a ''world-class carrier of choice.''

description: Just two days after Britain said that a lasting peace in Northern Ireland was ''tantalizingly close,'' the Irish Republican Army withdrew a plan today to dispose of its weapons, propelling the faltering peace effort once more toward collapse.

title: Players Take Back Their Bodies
description: Pro football players have always known that their sport is dangerous, that the game's violent collisions can naturally lead to torn muscles and broken bones, to concussions and paralysis.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Cray Wins A Big Contract
description: Cray Inc., the supercomputer maker, and Government Micro Resources Inc., which provides computer systems for NASA, said the aeronautics and space agency had awarded them a five-year contract worth as much as $4 billion. Marcin Skomial (NYT)

title: Young and Old Thrive Side by Side
description: As a woman in my 90's, I have empathy for those who will come after me and live into their 100's and beyond. They will, I trust, include my grandchildren and great-grandchildren, of whom I have quite a few. I have some thoughts for those planning the quality of life to be enjoyed by this stunningly larger older population to come. The way things are going now, as I see it, the 21st century will be witness to two segments of society -- the elderly and the rest of the human race. My word is: Please do not keep them apart.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Bombing Arrests
description: The police arrested five men in connection with the explosion of three small bombs outside banks, prosecutors said. The bombs, which caused minor property damage and no injuries, were planted on Aug. 8 at branches of Banamex, Mexico's second-largest bank, which is being bought by Citibank, the American financial institution. Prosecutors said the suspects were affiliated with a small leftist group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of the People, which opposes President Vicente Fox's free market policies. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ruling On Car Sales
description: An appellate court ruled that a supermarket chain did not violate any laws when it sold Fiat subcompacts through its stores last spring, loosening Germany's renowned restrictions on shopping. Edeka, a nationwide chain of stores, had offered Fiat Puntos in a $12,000 package that included either a laptop computer or a small motor scooter. Fiat went to court, charging that Edeka's unauthorized offer violated German laws because consumers would have too much trouble discerning the real value. But the dispute had a broader significance, because European carmakers still have the right to distribute their cars only through dealers they authorize. In ruling that Edeka's deal did not inhibit competition, the appeals court punched a big new loophole in the restrictions. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: North and South Korea Split Over Celebrating 1945 Japan Surrender
description: SEOUL  South and North Korea were similarly enraged by the Japanese prime minister's visit to a shrine honoring Japan's war dead, but they revealed their continuing differences Tuesday in discord over the North's plans for a joint celebration of the anniversary of Japan's surrender in 1945.

It was 1949. The reference was to a former practice of blocking traffic to the town on Sundays; that practice ended in 1980.

description: IF one thread of truth binds together that vast collection of wine regions known as Italy, it is that red is almost always best.

title: Enron's Chief Executive Quits After Only 6 Months in Job
description: Jeffrey Skilling, the chief executive of the Enron Corporation, stunned Wall Street today by announcing that he would quit after just six months in the job, calling the move a ''purely personal decision.''

title: Court Says Woman Can Bar Embryos' Use
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court yesterday upheld a woman's right to decide whether frozen embryos produced by her and her ex-husband through in vitro fertilization during their marriage can be implanted in another woman.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Casino Winnings Sag
description: Gambling revenue in Atlantic City fell 3.5 percent last month from a year earlier, the New Jersey Casino Control Commission said yesterday. Winnings fell to $414.3 million from $429.3 million. Revenue from slot machines fell 1.2 percent, to $303.2 million, while winnings from table games fell 9.2 percent, to $111 million, the commission reported. Harrah's casino, owned by Harrah's Entertainment Inc., and Caesar's casino, owned by Park Place Entertainment Corporation, were the only casinos that won more last month than they did in July 2000.

title: LUCENT PLANS TO LAY OFF 900 WORKERS AT GERMAN PLANT
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it planned to cut its work force in Germany by about 900 workers, or 26 percent, and sell or close a factory in Nuremberg. Lucent, which employs 3,500 people in Germany, gave itself three months to find a buyer for the plant or shut it, said the unit's spokeswoman, Martina Grueger. Ms. Grueger also said that 140 employees at Lucent's Augsburg fiber optic plant would be transferred to Furukawa Electric of Japan, which has agreed to buy the business. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., said last week that it planned to cut about 550 jobs in France, or 42 percent of its workers there.

title: School Vouchers Along the Color Line
description: For the past 10 years, African-Americans have been caught up in the school-voucher debate. Many black parents have become desperate for solutions to the problems of their children's schools. Vouchers are one solution being offered, and many black parents have grasped at them. But this is less an endorsement of vouchers than an indication of how bad some schools have become.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Governor Returns To Statehouse
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift, the first governor to give birth while in office, is officially back at work full time this month, ending a ''working'' maternity leave. After the birth of twin daughters in May, Ms. Swift spent most of her leave working from her home in western Massachusetts, but her absence from the Statehouse did not seem to bother her constituents. In a poll last month by the University of Massachusetts, 67 percent of voters said they viewed Ms. Swift favorably, an increase from a similar Boston Globe poll in October, when only 20 percent of respondents had a positive view of Ms. Swift, then the lieutenant governor. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Sykora Goes to Arbitration
description: The Devils and the 24-year-old right wing Petr Sykora took their respective cases before the arbitrator Michel Picher in Toronto yesterday. Picher has until tomorrow to render his ruling.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Orange: Path Cleaners Join Union
description: More than 200 workers who clean buildings and the PATH train stations have won a three-year union contract that provides for higher wages, job security and an expanded health plan. The contract follows a two-week strike in July. The workers are employed by TUCS Cleaning Services in Orange, where about 100 workers clean PATH stations. The workers have joined Service Employees International Union Local 32B-32J. The average wage for a cleaner is set to rise from a range of $6 to $8.67 an hour to $9.75 to $11.75 an hour.

title: Four Get Summer Fellowships
description: Four City College sophomores, LINCOLN AJOKU, OGHOGHO EDOMWONYI, ORLANDO GONZALEZ and BRANDON BOLIN, have started working as interns in the Jeannette K. Watson Summer Fellowship program. The program aims to give underprivileged students in New York training opportunities and encourages its participants to choose careers in public service. Each student was awarded an $18,000 stipend, to be distributed over three summers. Mr. Ajoku is an intern with the International AIDS Vaccine Initiative. Ms. Edomwonyi is an intern for the United Nations Fund for Population Activities. Mr. Gonzalez and Mr. Bolin are interns with justices on the New York State Supreme Court.

She performed last night at the Washington Township Center in Sewell, N.J., and is to appear tonight at Madison Square Garden and tomorrow at the Mohegan Sun Casino in Uncasville, Conn.

description: How do you spell education? Not e-d-u-c-a-t-i-o-n if you are running for mayor of New York.

title: Earnings Beat Expectations, Applied Materials Reports
description: Applied Materials, the world's largest manufacturer of chip-making equipment, reported third-quarter earnings today that beat Wall Street's expectations by 2 cents a share but said it could predict no end to the industry slump.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Union: Trash Transfer Center Advances
description: The Union County Board of Freeholders unanimously approved an ordinance Monday night for a plan to bring New York City garbage into New Jersey by barge and move it out of the state by rail. The plan involves a 16-acre, $50 million trash center in Linden that would receive between 6,000 and 10,000 tons of garbage a day. ''No matter how much we don't want to have New York City's garbage here,'' said Michael Lapolla, above, the Union County manager, ''as long as it is going to come through the county, we would much rather have it by rail than by truck.'' The plan now goes to the State Department of Environmental Protection for clearance.

title: Just for a Kick, 2 Old Friends Will Meet Again
description: Richie Williams played alongside Marco Etcheverry for five years in Washington, winning three Major League Soccer titles with D.C. United. Etcheverry made those deadly passes that earned him most valuable player twice, often getting the ball from Williams after he had won it in midfield.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Analyst Cuts AOL Forecast
description: An analyst said AOL Time Warner was unlikely to meet its 2001 financial targets because of an ''overall weak advertising market.'' Mary Meeker of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, who was one of the first analysts to promote Internet stocks, cut her estimate for AOL's 2001 revenue to $39 billion from $39.5 billion and for cash flow to $10.5 billion from $11 billion.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Hospitals Settle Suit
description: Aetna Inc. has settled a suit brought by 25 hospitals that charged the company with paying claims slowly or denying them unjustifiably, a lawyer for the hospitals said. The suit, which sought $95 million in damages, involved almost all of the hospitals that Aetna, the biggest health insurer in the United States, has contracts with in the Bronx and in six counties north of New York City -- Westchester, Putnam, Dutchess, Rockland, Orange and Sullivan, the hospitals' lawyer, Frederick Miller, said in a news release. He did not say how much the hospitals would receive. A spokesman for Aetna, David Carter, said the insurer had been settling with individual hospitals for 10 months. ''There was no global settlement,'' he said. ''Each claim is unique and was examined individually.''

title: Cable Provider Loses Money And Its Chief
description: United Pan-European Communications N.V., the European cable television operator with close ties to the Denver-based Liberty Media, reported a huge loss in the second quarter today and said its chief executive, Mark Schneider, was resigning.

title: Jets Duck and Cover as Edwards Goes Negative
description: For two weeks, the Jets have been stroked by the positive reinforcement schoolteachers use to motivate young students.

title: Spooning Up a Cloud
description: WHEN the crme brle was set down before my friend, I almost pitied her. We were at Eleven Madison Park, a restaurant where having crme brle seems rather pointless, given the wealth of inventive desserts. Then I watched as she cracked through the glasslike layer of caramel and her face lit up. My spoon wandered to her plate and I sampled it. Beneath the fragile caramel was something magical, and it wasn't just custard. We were silent for a moment before we looked at each other and said practically in unison, ''Crme frache.''

title: Europeans Critical of U.S. Foreign Policy, Polls Find

description: More than half of the 60 wholesale fish dealers at the Fulton Fish Market in Lower Manhattan have signed a 49-year lease for space in a long-planned distribution center in Hunts Point, clearing one of the last hurdles to the market's move to the Bronx, according to people involved in the negotiations.

title: Putting a Pinch on a Lobster
description: At Da Silvano, an Italian restaurant in Greenwich Village, lobster is served with this snazzy nutcracker. It is made by Deplimax in Italy and called the Cricco. The pincers close in stages as you squeeze the handles, providing gentle pressure. Push in the black levers on either side, and they snap open. It does a better job with walnuts (cracking the shells without pulverizing the nutmeats) than with lobster claws, especially if you're hungry and in a hurry to get at the meat. It is effective with smallish lobsters (less than two pounds) and crabs. It comes in red, yellow, green and black, and is $10.99 at Citarella stores in Manhattan and Water Mill, N.Y.

title: READER'S DIGEST HAS LOSS AFTER $60 MILLION IN CHARGES
description: The Reader's Digest Association had a fiscal fourth-quarter loss on lower sales and said yesterday that first-quarter results would fall short of estimates. The loss for the fourth quarter ended June 30 was $21.9 million, or 22 cents a share, after net income of $17 million, or 16 cents a share, a year earlier. The results included costs of $60 million, or 27 cents a share, for job cuts and write-downs related to investments, the company said. Excluding severance costs and write-downs, Reader's Digest said it would have had a profit of 5 cents a share. Reader's Digest, based in Pleasantville, N.Y., has a monthly circulation of 25 million, the largest of any magazine in the world.

title: Alltel in Hostile $6.1 Billion Bid for Phone Rival
description: The Alltel Corporation, the large telecommunications company, made an unsolicited $6.1 billion takeover bid yesterday for CenturyTel Inc., a smaller rival that provides phone services in rural areas, suburbs and small towns.

description: ASIA

title: National Briefing | Education: Steady Scores On Placement Test
description: The average score for the nearly 1.1 million students taking the American College Test -- an alternative to the Scholastic Assessment Tests that is commonly used outside the East Coast -- remained steady this year at 21.0 out of 36 for the fifth year in a row. Except for Asian-American students, average scores for minority students inched down and remained well below the national average. American College Test officials said 18 percent of students scored 16 or lower, suggesting that they were not ready for college-level work. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: DECONGESTANT FROM UCB OF BELGIUM GETS F.D.A. APPROVAL
description: UCB S.A., Belgium's No. 2 drug maker, said Zyrtec-D, a decongestant form of its top-selling allergy treatment, was approved by the Food and Drug Administration. The new form of Zyrtec will be jointly marketed by UCB and Pfizer, which already cooperate to sell regular Zyrtec in the United States. The approval will help UCB better compete with Schering-Plough's Claritin, which had revenue of $1.64 billion in the six months through June, more than double the 879 million euros ($788 million) in sales for Zyrtec. The decongestant form accounts for a quarter of revenue for Claritin, the best-selling seasonal allergy drug, analysts said.

title: Up to 18 May Have Died Of Overdoses in Houston
description: One man was found in a car, another slumped over a toilet. Others were discovered in their beds. They had gotten drowsy, officials say, maybe a little nauseous, and had fallen asleep. Only they did not wake up.

title: Star-Cross'd Lovers Meet Under the Stars, Where the Hudson Valley Plays Verona
description: One of the more persistent peculiarities of American culture has been the insatiable urge of actors, directors and audiences to pass hot summer nights congregating in city parks or country meadows for performances of the plays of William Shakespeare. Pioneered almost half a century ago by Joseph Papp and his New York Shakespeare Festival, the notion that declaiming Elizabethan blank verse is as much a part of summer as ice cream or watermelon has now grown into a national tradition.

title: Study of Heart-Device Defects Puts Makers on the Defensive
description: For a person with a pacemaker, the odds that the device's manufacturer will recall it or issue a safety alert over a one-year period are about 1 in 15, a new study has calculated.

title: National Briefing | South: Mississippi: Indigent-Defense Lawsuit
description: In arguments before the State Supreme Court, lawyers for the state asked for the dismissal of a lawsuit that claims counties are not providing adequate legal representation to indigent criminal defendants. The state maintains that the Legislature has the prerogative to assign responsibility to provide indigent defense to whichever government entity it chooses. Mississippi currently finances a statewide system of prosecutors, but the government leaves it to counties to provide for the defense lawyers for the poor.

title: Age-Old Question Is New Again
description: When does a human life begin? Scientists' desire to study human embryonic stem cells has raised this ancient question to new prominence.

title: Holmes's Injury Not Serious
description: Kenny Holmes, the Giants' major free-agent acquisition of the off-season, left the practice field today with a knee injury, but Giants Coach Jim Fassel said later that the damage to Holmes's knee was not serious.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERBERG, ARON L.
description: SILVERBERG-Aron L. On August 14, 2001. Survived by his wife, Barbara. Loving father of Marc. Son of Al and Anne. Brother of Alan Silverberg and Jerry Tunick. Services on Thursday, at 12 Noon at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: In This Lab, White Coats And Truffles
description: IN a city where culinary innovation is not part of the local lexicon, Il Laboratorio del Galileo is causing a sensation. As much of a sensation here as anything that does not involve sex and politics.

title: Texas Appeals Court Stays Execution
description: The high court of Texas this afternoon postponed the execution of Napoleon Beazley, just a few hours before he was to be put to death for the 1994 murder of a businessman during a carjacking gone awry.

title: Does 'Jackass' Have a Life?
description: The star of MTV's ''Jackass'' has cast its future in doubt.

title: Designated Donations
description: To the Editor:

title: Roy A. Rosenberg, 70, Rabbi at Mixed Weddings, Dies
description: Roy A. Rosenberg, a rabbi who saw intermarriage as inevitable and joyously performed thousands of marriages between Jews and non-Jews, died on Saturday from irregular heart rhythms while driving his car. He was 70.

title: Social Security Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Education: Grants For Colleges Serving Minorities
description: More than 100 colleges and universities that serve large numbers of minority students will receive grants totaling $27.2 million from the Department of Education. Most of the money is geared toward updating technology, increasing student achievement and developing faculty, with $4.5 million going to 38 institutions to boost the number of women and ethnic minorities studying science and engineering. A dozen tribal colleges serving American Indians are among the grant recipients. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bank of Japan Loosens Credit, Surprising Investors

title: Tobacco Companies Accused Of Still Aiming Ads at Youths
description: As part of a settlement with the states in 1998, the biggest tobacco companies said they would stop advertising in magazines with significant numbers of young readers. Three years later, that promise is largely unfulfilled.

description: To the Editor:

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Celebrity Lawyer's Busy Month

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Moscow: Oil Profits
description: High world oil prices helped Lukoil, Russia's biggest oil producer, triple its net income, to $3.3 billion in 2000, the company said yesterday in announcing financial results that it said comply with United States accounting standards. Lukoil, for years a favorite stock among foreign investors, has come under criticism for long delays in the release of financial reports. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: To the Editor:
