description: For an Up-to-date listing of restaurants, please call the Restaurant Update Line: 1-888-NYTPDATE (698-8732). This service is available 234-hours a day, 7 days a week.

title: Jones Joins List Of Her Critics
description: Poor Marion Jones. She had won 42 consecutive 100-meter finals since 1997, but if her time was a bit slower than usual or the race a bit closer than usual, people were disappointed and wanted to know what was wrong. Yesterday, the group of critics got a new member: Marion Jones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAMER, HILDA
description: KRAMER-Hilda. The Board of Directors of the United Hebrew Geriatric Center mourns the passing of Mrs. Hilda Kramer, beloved mother of Billie and LeRoy Kramer. As a Past President and member of our Board of Directors, LeRoy has been a devoted friend and ardent supporter for many years. Our heartfelt sympathy and prayers are extended to the bereaved family. Peter Lane, President Malcolm Lazarus, Chairman Rita C. Mabli, Exec. Vice President

title: Bush Emphasizes Teaching of Values to Children
description: President Bush took his ''Home to the Heartland'' tour to an altitude of 8,000 feet today, standing at a lectern high in Rocky Mountain National Park northwest of here to talk about the importance of teaching children values and creating ''communities of character'' all around them.

title: Delivering Simptico Patter Improvised to a Salsa Beat
description: Gilberto Santa Rosa and Victor Manuelle, two of salsa's top hit makers, shared the stage at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. They also shared a band, songs, jokes, insults, dueling timbales, professions of friendship, allegiance to Puerto Rico and an urbane determination to hold on to salsa traditions that are threatened by Latin pop, merengue and hip-hop. For the length of the show, as girls raced to the stage to snap photographs and teenage and adult fans sang along, salsa was as strong as ever.

title: One Part of the Festival Was Wholly Haydn
description: Conducting dynasties are not uncommon -- the Kleibers, the Jarvis -- but the brothers Ivan and Adam Fischer are notable for having both founded their own orchestras. As a recipe for professional advancement, it seems to have worked well. Ivan, having built up an active touring and recording schedule with his Budapest Festival Orchestra, recently took over as the music director of the opera house in Lyon, France. And Adam, who this season became the general music director of the opera house in Mannheim, Germany, was prevented from conducting the ensemble he founded, the Austro-Hungarian Haydn Orchestra, in its Mostly Mozart appearances this week because he was summoned to Bayreuth to replace the late Giuseppe Sinopoli as conductor of the ''Ring'' cycle -- a supreme example of an offer you can't refuse.

title: Delayed Report on Encryption Flaws to Be Presented
description: Today a group of Princeton computer scientists will present a research paper that has spurred debate over the freedom of scientific research and a 1998 digital copyright law that places restrictions on the dissemination of decryption information.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOPELOWITZ, HILARY (NEE LAZARUS)
description: KOPELOWITZ-Hilary (nee Lazarus). Of Scarsdale, NY passed away unexpectedly August 11th in Tel Aviv, Israel, and will be buried in Rehovot, Israel on August 14th. Beloved wife of Wally, devoted mother of Sasha, daughter of Molly Lazarus, sister of Richard. Despite many years of illness, Hilary faced life with tremendous courage, strength, kindness and passion. Memorial service Sunday, August 19, 12:00pm at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Ave, White Plains, 914-946-8851.

title: Big Enough for 3 Chickens, 30 Burgers or a Fat Bass
description: After a long quest for the perfect grill, I found happiness on the Web. I had a list of requirements drawn from past frustrations. Charcoal kettles were not convenient, but gas grills never got hot enough. Although the flames could be adjusted, the racks could not. I did not want to return to the kettle-style charcoal grill, because the distance between the coals and the food was fixed, it was hard to add more coals during cooking and I didn't like having to cover the grill to adjust the heat. But a fancy $3,000 outdoor kitchen was not for me. I ordered a Bar-B-Chef Texas Charcoal Grill from www.bbqgalore.com, the site of the country's largest grill and grilling accessories company, based in Los Angeles. Mine is big, with 589 square inches of surface, generous enough for 3 chickens or 30 hamburgers or a whole 9-pound striped bass. Yet the cast-iron grates have closely spaced openings, so small that shrimp do not fall through. There's a trapdoor in front to allow fuel to be added during cooking, and, best of all, a crank to move the coals up or down, with about eight inches of play. The unit comes on a cart or with directions for building it into a brick housing. It has two side shelves and a lid. A waterproof cover, warming rack and rotisserie are optional accessories. Without those, in black it's $589 plus shipping; in stainless steel it's $959 plus shipping. You have to assemble it, which took two people a little less than three hours. The company is very accommodating, replacing almost overnight one defective part that came in the kit. As for lighting hardwood charcoal, with a couple of chimney starters it takes only 15 minutes.

title: Joe Boxer Line at Kmart
description: The Kmart Corporation, a leading discount retailer, will sell the Joe Boxer line of clothing and accessories at its 2,100 retail outlets, starting in the fall of 2002. Terms of the long-term agreement were not disclosed. Joe Boxer clothing and accessories, including underwear and sleepwear, feature the brand's signature yellow smiling face.

title: State Legislators Gather, With Budget Woes High on Agenda
description: More than 7,000 state legislators, their staff members and assorted camp followers gathered here this week for the annual meeting of the National Conference of State Legislatures, four days of hobnobbing and debate on issues from the peculiar to the profound.

title: Restaurants Accepting TimesCard  Brooklyn
description: For an up-to-date listing of restaurants, please call the Restaurant Update Line: 1-888-NYTUPDATE (698-8732). This service is available 24-hours a day, 7 days a week.

title: Student Housing at Marymount
description: Marymount Manhattan College, on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, will open its first dormitory next month, coming to the relief of students who have had to find space in a nearby hotel and the 92nd Street Y, among other places. The college will own and occupy the first 31 floors of a 46-story high-rise at 231-235 East 55th Street. Marymount will have 114 suites for 493 students. The nonsectarian college is charging the residents $8,500 a year. Private apartments in the building rent for $3,200 to $15,000 a month.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: JOBS LOST IN NEW JERSEY

title: Personal Shopper
Architects Turn the Past Into Irreverent Prologue
Peace de Resistance
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Islam in Central Asia
description: The people of Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have always lived under despots. Their history is so dismal that Communism for them was a time of relative prosperity. Now, 10 years after they became independent nations, they have once again become sultanates, ruled by tyrants who maintain tight control of political and economic activity.

title: Forceful U.S. Effort On Mideast Is Urged
description: Egypt's top foreign policy official warned that the Bush administration's ''inaction'' in the Middle East could allow extremists to take hold in moderate Arab countries. This would be a consequence far graver than the administration's apparent fear of risking its prestige with an Israeli-Palestinian peace initiative, said Osama el-Baz, President Hosni Mubarak's national security adviser.

title: Mediator Is Appointed for Police Contract Talks
description: The State Public Employment Relations Board appointed a mediator yesterday to try to push forward the deadlocked contract talks between New York City and its largest police union, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about tobacco industry advertising misstated the nature of guidelines that discourage ads aimed at young people. The guidelines -- which deal with ads in magazines with more than two million readers younger than 18 or more than 15 percent of readers younger than 18 -- are not part of the master settlement agreement between the companies and the attorneys general of 46 states. The agreement included a pledge by the companies not ''to take any action directly or indirectly to target youth.'' It required the attorneys general to develop guidelines for enforcement. Enforcement is still negotiated case by case between the companies and the National Association of Attorneys General.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS RECALLS HORMONE TABLETS
description: American Home Products recalled two batches of its best-selling hormone-replacement drug, Premarin, yesterday after tests showed that some of the tablets did not meet certain quality requirements. The drugs failed to meet a government quality-control standard during what is known as a ''dissolution test.'' The dissolution problems have not affected Premarin's safety or how well it works, Audrey Ashby, a spokeswoman for American Home, said. American Home asked wholesalers to return any of more than 2,000 bottles of Premarin pills that are covered by the recall. The company is not asking drugstores to pull Premarin from shelves, though, and is telling patients to keep taking the medication they have.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, HENRY L., M.D.
description: BARNETT-Henry L., M.D. The Department of Pediatrics of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University & the Montefiore Medical Center mourns the loss of our beloved teacher, scientist, author, and humanitarian. As the founding Chairman of the Department of Pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, he led the Department to the forefront of academic pediatrics and was influential in the college's becoming a worldrenowned institution. Dr. Barnett is recognized as the father of pediatric nephrology in the United States. The International Study of Kidney Disease in Children, which he organized and directed, brought into collegial and professional relationships pediatric nephrologists from all over the world. Pediatrics has lost one of its truly great leaders. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his wife, Shirley, and their children. Michael I. Cohen, M.D. Professor and Chairman Department of Pediatrics Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center

title: Tuned In To the Love Of His Fans
description: Maxwell, Brooklyn's own singularly named young soul rebel, understood the gravity of taking the stage at the Apollo Theater on Tuesday night. He paused early in his show to pay respects to that great hall, but was soon interrupted by an admirer bearing a gift bag and a Mylar balloon that read, ''Hugs and Kisses.'' Maxwell stopped to offer the fan what the balloon instructed. Then he said: ''I'm a good giver. I'm not really good at receiving.'' Sure, Maxwell.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Profit At Daewoo
description: Daewoo Motor, which is negotiating a buyout with General Motors, recorded an operating profit in July for the fourth consecutive month, posting earnings before taxes of $10.4 million after sales of $350.1 million. A Daewoo spokesman said the report should demonstrate to General Motors that the company's aging plant in the Pupyong district of Inchon would be worth including in a deal. Inclusion of the plant in Pupyong has reportedly been a disputed issue in the talks, which G.M. hopes to wrap up in the next couple of months. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: A Fading of Emerging Markets; Investors Are Leaving After Years of Financial Crises
description: Philip Ehrmann of Gartmore Investment Management in London is still a believer in emerging markets. As head of the Pacific and emerging markets unit and a manager of about $1 billion, he has been trying to persuade investors to move back in to these volatile markets.

title: Same Bid, Similar Problems, But Quite Different Results
description: The final of the World Junior Team Championship, for players under the age of 26, began on Tuesday in Mangaritiba, Brazil, with a United States team facing Israel. After 64 deals of a scheduled 96, the Americans led by 81 imps.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Refunds On Car Leases
description: The Banc of America Auto Finance Corporation has agreed to refund overcharges it collected from New Jersey customers for what the company had called excessive wear and damage on leased automobiles, state officials say. To settle a lawsuit brought by the state, the company also agreed to pay the state $350,000 to cover the cost of its investigation and to finance future consumer protection programs, the agency said. The company did not admit any wrongdoing. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Planet System With Earth-Like Orbits Is Found
description: Astronomers observing a faint star in the Big Dipper have discovered the first distant multiplanet system in which the planets have near-circular orbits like those in this solar system.

title: For a Downtown Office Building, A Grown-Up's Garden of Verses
description: In the mid-1980's, San Francisco, worried about overdevelopment, began requiring commercial buildings to provide public space. The Poetry Garden, below, opened two months ago at 199 Fremont Street, an office building downtown. Perhaps only in this city would such a space be dedicated to poetry. Planned by the architectural firm of Kaplan McLaughlin Diaz, in collaboration with Robert Hass, a former poet laureate of the United States, the plaza includes granite boulders, a wall bearing a poem by Mr. Hass and a reflecting pool. Herb McLaughlin, the firm's director of design, below with his children, wrote the study ''Tall Buildings, Tight Streets,'' which influenced the city's open space plan. Open 24 hours a day, whenever the need for poetry strikes.

title: Man Group to Hire Brokers
description: The Man Group, a British broker and hedge fund manager, plans to hire a dozen brokers to bolster its financial futures business.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about the effect of proliferating multiplexes on ticket sales for summer films referred incompletely to the division of revenues on opening weekends. The studios receive 90 percent of box-office revenues on opening weekend, but only after the theater chain has taken a guaranteed minimum, negotiated with the studio.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Governors Draft Sales Tax Appeal
description: A group of more than 40 governors is calling on Congress to allow states to develop a system for collecting sales taxes on purchases made online. In a draft of a letter that the governors plan to send this week to members of the House and Senate, they wrote, ''If you care about a level playing field for Main Street retail businesses, and local control of states' governments and schools, extend the moratorium on taxing Internet access only with authorization for the states to streamline and simplify the existing sales tax system.'' The moratorium on Internet taxes expires in October. The states' effort was introduced last week at a meeting of the National Governors Association by Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, above, the Republican governor of Utah, a spokesman for the association said.

title: Cracking the Code Of Computer Memory
description: Q. When buying more memory for my PC, does it make a big difference if I purchase a 168-pin DIMM at 70ns or 80ns? What is the ''ns'' anyway?

title: Robots Tested in Mock Search for Urban Disaster Victims
description: A POWERFUL earthquake has just hit an urban center. Instead of search-and-rescue teams of people and dogs, robots enter a collapsed building to seek victims.

title: Zimbabwe Arrests 4 Over News About Police
description: The authorities in Zimbabwe arrested three senior editors and one reporter today from the nation's only independent daily newspaper. The arrests came a day after the newspaper, The Daily News, reported that militants had used police cars during a recent looting of white-owned farms.

title: Sports of The Times; For Tiger, The Bear Is Lurking
description: ON Tiger Woods's recent fishing trip to Alaska with Mark O'Meara and John Cook, he had just landed a king salmon when Cook yelled, ''There's a bear!'' not far away along the river bank.

title: Child-Size Remote Control With No 'Sopranos' Button
description: Not only are toddlers prone to gnawing on television remote controls, they also sometimes leave behind jelly fingerprints as they click past channels in search of cartoons. John Stephen, the founder of Fobis Technologies of Miami, developed the Weemote when his son was 5 to avoid haphazard channel-surfing. ''My concern was that he not come across a program we didn't want him to see,'' said Mr. Stephen, whose invention is available at www.weemote.com and is gradually reaching Target stores.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST CALIFORNIA: JUDGE LOSES SEAT OVER WAR CLAIM A judge who falsely claimed to be a decorated Vietnam veteran who worked undercover for the C.I.A. in Laos in the 1960's was removed from the bench after officials determined that he had lied about his background. The state Commission on Judicial Performance dismissed the judge, Patrick Couwenberg of Los Angeles County Superior Court, saying he "made misrepresentations in order to become a judge." Judge Couwenberg, who has been on the bench since 1997, had said he had received the Purple Heart for a groin wound in Vietnam, but later admitted that he was in the Naval Reserves and did not see combat. (Reuters) NORTHWEST OREGON: FINAL REDISTRICTING PLAN IS READY Secretary of State Bill Bradbury submitted a final version of the state's redistricting plan to the Oregon Supreme Court, where it is expected to undergo several challenges from state Republicans. Mr. Bradbury, a Democrat, was handed the redistricting job after legislators failed to reach an agreement by July 1 that Gov. John Kitzhaber would sign. A draft plan drew Republican charges of partisan influence in the process of redrawing the state's legislative districts to reflect population changes reported in the census. Matthew Preusch (NYT) MIDWEST MICHIGAN: BONIOR TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR Representative David E. Bonior announced that he would run for governor in 2002, seeking the Democratic nomination against at least two other candidates. Mr. Bonior, the House minority whip, said he had decided to run because he wanted to address issues of education, environmental protection and public transportation. But Mr. Bonior was also facing a more competitive Congressional race next year, because redistricting put Representative Sander M. Levin, a fellow Democrat, in Mr. Bonior's district. Recent polls have shown Mr. Bonior behind two declared Democrats, former Gov. James Blanchard and Attorney General Jennifer M. Granholm. Pam Belluck (NYT) PLAINS SOUTH DAKOTA: GAY GROUP SUES OVER ROAD PROGRAM A gay group has filed suit in federal court because the state will not allow the group to sponsor a sign in the adopt-a-highway program. The group, the Sioux Empire Gay and Lesbian Coalition, wants to sponsor litter cleanup along a section of state Highway 38 west of Sioux Falls. The state Department of Transportation says the organization does not qualify for a sign because it is an advocacy group. Pam Belluck (NYT) SOUTH FLORIDA: RIGHTS GROUPS CHALLENGE VOTING LAW The American Civil Liberties Union and two other civil rights groups filed a federal lawsuit against state and Monroe County elections officials, seeking to block several sections of the state's new election law as discriminatory. The suit challenges the posting in all polling places of a list of "Voter Responsibilities" that says a voter must "study and know candidates and issues." The lawsuit is brought under the Voting Rights Act, which outlaws any requirement that a voter be able to demonstrate the "ability to read, write, understand or interpret any matter," or demonstrate "knowledge of any particular subject." Dana Canedy (NYT) FLORIDA: SHARKS NEAR COAST LEAVE Hundreds of sharks that gathered off the west coast of Florida this week, prompting a safety alert, have left, the authorities said. The Pasco County Sheriff's Office, which issued an alert to swimmers and boaters on Tuesday, said officers checked the area three miles offshore and found only a few sharks, a spokesman, Kevin Doll, said. Marine experts said the sharks had probably been feeding on schools of fish and may have gone south to warmer waters. (Reuters) PUERTO RICO: AUTHORITIES ARREST POLICE OFFICERS Federal authorities arrested 29 police officers on drug charges after an undercover investigation into accusations of police corruption. The officers work for police departments in San Juan as well as the cities of Caguas, Fajardo and Humacao. The Justice Department said the officers "used their official positions to protect shipments of cocaine." All but one of the officers were charged with conspiring to possess and distribute cocaine and with carrying firearms while committing a drug offense. Dana Canedy (NYT) MID-ATLANTIC PENNSYLVANIA: HOSPITAL GIVES WRONG DOSE OF DRUG A hospital laboratory in Philadelphia used the wrong form of a chemical in conducting a routine blood test, leading hundreds of patients to receive incorrect doses of a blood-thinning medicine, and possibly causing five deaths, the state health department said. Officials at the hospital, St. Agnes Medical Center, have said that 932 patients may have received incorrect doses of the anticoagulant warfarin, better known by the brand name Coumadin, from June 4 to July 25. Warfarin is prescribed for conditions that increase the risk of blood clots. But a dosage that is too high can be dangerous, causing excess bleeding. (AP) WASHINGTON BUSH SELECTS ENERGY AGENCY CHIEF President Bush has named Pat Wood III, a longtime Texas ally, to head the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Mr. Wood, now a member of the commission, will take control of the panel on Sept. 1. His appointment had long been expected. The chairman of the commission, Curtis L. Hebert Jr., announced this month that he would resign at the end of August to make way for the Bush appointee. The agency has been at the center of political wrangling about California's power problems and high Western electricity prices. (AP)

title: Airport Film Rentals
description: To the Editor:

title: San Francisco Opens the Gate, and Modern Rushes In
description: FOR San Franciscans, the prospect of change has all the appeal of an earthquake. But like natural disasters, change is inevitable. A flood of technology money in the last decade or so added to runaway growth that threatened the city's famous livability.

title: Online, the Hiss Defense Doesn't Rest
description: THE Alger Hiss case, which swirled through the second half of the 20th century with low-tech evidence like documents that may or may not have come from a certain manual typewriter, has made it into the 21st century and onto the Internet. And so has the debate.

title: The Father-and-Son Presidencies
description: During his vacation this month in Texas, President Bush will be reading David McCullough's best-selling biography of John Adams, he told reporters. ''I'm particularly paying attention to that part about John Quincy Adams,'' Mr. Bush said with a smile. ''You might remember, Quincy and I have got something in common.''

title: Ethnic Albanian Leader Pledges to Disarm
description: SIPKOVICA, Macedonia, Aug. 16  Few people know the sound of his voice, or even what Ali Ahmeti looks like. He almost defines the idea of the shadowy guerrilla leader, a pale, graying dissident who today smoked one cigarette after another and, in a very quiet voice, sought to assure Macedonians that if peace comes, he is a man to be trusted.

title: Political Memo; Bush, Deep in the Heartland, Hears Discouraging Words
description: The second graders at Griegos Elementary School had apparently not absorbed the message of President Bush's month away from the nation's capital, because when he asked a group of them today if they knew where he was from, he did not get the answer he wanted.

title: At the Head of a Grassy Valley, All the Comforts of Stone
description: THE stonemason Jeronimo Perez Tapia has headed up the hill to harvest a wheelbarrow load of flinty rocks. For 12 years he and Ron Mann, a Sonoma interior designer, have been shaping, stacking and thwacking rocks into a formally organized compound of stone terraces, paths, walls and a sun-filled design studio.

title: Illumination First, Then Enlightenment
description: GOOD lighting at a good price? Good luck. Too many fixtures scream, ''look at me,'' while not providing nearly enough light. Here are some well designed but simple metal lamps and sconces (and one ceiling fixture) that will not break the bank but will fill some specific lighting needs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FALKENSTEIN, THELMA
description: FALKENSTEIN-Thelma. It has been three years since you left me. I miss you more every day and I'll love you forever. Arthur

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Final Redistricting Plan Is Ready
description: Secretary of State Bill Bradbury submitted a final version of the state's redistricting plan to the Oregon Supreme Court, where it is expected to undergo several challenges from state Republicans. Mr. Bradbury, a Democrat, was handed the redistricting job after legislators failed to reach an agreement by July 1 that Gov. John Kitzhaber would sign. A draft plan drew Republican charges of partisan influence in the process of redrawing the state's legislative districts to reflect population changes reported in the census. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Added Rights For Indians In Mexico Take Effect
description: After years of negotiation and debate, a law originally intended to expand the rights of the 10 million Indians in Mexico took effect today. But Congress watered down the law so much that it pleases few people and infuriates many.

title: A Dublin Diorama Reveals A Very Untidy Francis Bacon
description: There were a few excited gasps when the Hugh Lane Municipal Gallery here unveiled its most significant and most hyped acquisition recently. But most just stared and said, ''What a mess!''

title: Mideast Tragedies, Seen and Unseen
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Steam Leak At Plant
description: Consolidated Edison has reduced power by a third at its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant to repair a leaking steam pipe in a nonnuclear area of the plant, an official said. Engineers yesterday cut power to 65 percent of its nearly 1,000-megawatt capacity while employees worked on the pipe. The leak was discovered late Tuesday during a routine inspection of a metal pipe that is part of the system that feeds and discharges water to the plant, said Michael Clendenin, a spokesman for the utility.

title: Financial Problems Force Chain Of Computer Camps to Close
description: BUSINESSES may come and go, but when a nationwide chain of summer computer camps closed with little warning this month, it left counselors, campers and parents alike nonplussed. Many campers ending their session were left unsupervised while counselors, confused by the sudden news, packed up and left.

title: Opel Plan Includes 350,000 Fewer Cars
description: The loss-plagued German subsidiary of General Motors, Adam Opel A.G., unveiled a broad turnaround plan today that called for reducing production by about 15 percent, or as many as 350,000 cars a year.

title: Robert Kraus, Author And Cartoonist, 76
description: Robert Kraus, a children's book author and a cartoonist, illustrator and publisher, died on Aug. 7 in a nursing home in Kent, Conn. He was 76 and had lived in Manhattan in recent years.

title: As Midway Airlines Retrenches, the Competition Intensifies
description: Although the bankruptcy filing by Midway Airlines appears to be creating few problems for travelers, its long-term prospects are uncertain.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lyndhurst: 'Disruptive' Behavior Plan
description: Officials have postponed their vote on whether photography, tape recording and defamatory remarks should be banned from town meetings. The Board of Commissioners agreed yesterday to conduct more research on the measure, which would give Mayor James Guida the power to eject disruptive local residents from municipal meetings, including people who clap excessively. The township attorney, Jim J. Guida, who is the mayor's son, advised the board to postpone its vote, saying that state law guarantees news media access to government meetings. Opponents say the proposal, if adopted, would violate the First Amendment. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Europe's Ties With America:New Cause For Concern
description: "The problem with allies," Winston Churchill said, "is that they sometimes develop opinions of their own."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, AMELIA
description: LEWIS-Amelia. August 13, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Edward P. Lewis. Devoted mother of Willene. Cherished grandmother of Paul Sweeney and Craig Sweeney. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Thursday, August 16th, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, August 17, 2001, 10AM at Saint Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84 St.

title: Paris in November
description: If Paris looks too pricey now, look a little further ahead  into November. That is when France Vacations will start offering five nights lodging in Paris with daily breakfast and round-trip air fare from Newark starting at $439 a person, based on double occupancy. That price is based on using one of five two-star hotels, including the Sacre Coeur, Opera Montmartre and St.-Martin; there are higher-priced packages in higher-grade hotels. There are blackout dates in mid to late December, and airport fees of about $67 are extra. Information: (800) 332-5332 or www.francevacations.net .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VARDAKIS, A. CHARLES
description: VARDAKIS-A. Charles. The Board of Directors, Administration, Medical Board and staff of Peninsula Hospital Center, are saddened by the passing of A. Charles Vardakis, Benefactor and husband of Nancy Vardakis, esteemed member of the Board of Directors. Sincere condolences are extended to Mrs. Vardakis and to the entire Vardakis family. Joel A. Miele Sr., P.E., Chairman, Board of Directors Robert V. Levine, President & Chief Executive Officer Narendra K. Hadpawat, M.D., President, Medical Board

title: Jazzy Pottery From the 30's Comes of Age
description: BILL STERN, curator of ''California Pottery: From Missions to Modernism,'' at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, offers this prickly opinion of Fiestaware, the candy-colored 1930's dishware that is once again a fixture in America's kitchens and dining rooms: ''It's a rip-off.''

title: A Family Album That Morphs Online
description: THE memory of my worst lapse in judgment since becoming a parent is beginning to fade, so I am willing to share the horrifying details to help others avert catastrophe.

title: Nikon's New Digital Camera Fits Easily in a Pocket
description: In a world of bloated S.U.V.'s and rambling McMansions, there are times when smaller is better. The new Nikon Coolpix 775 is a case in point: a digital camera that fits easily into a pocket and weighs less than eight ounces (with battery).

title: Researchers Divided On Stem Cell Rules
description: Scientists are divided over President Bush's decision on human embryonic stem cells, with some saying that they are lucky the door has been opened as far as it has, and others expressing dismay that the move may lead scientists to abandon the United States for nations with fewer restrictions.

title: 2 Companies Pay $84 Million for Golden Books
description: A partnership of Random House and the entertainment company Classic Media agreed yesterday to acquire Golden Books Family Entertainment, the children's book company, for $84.4 million and the assumption of most of the company's liabilities.

title: Another Reality TV Show Is Under Fire
description: Reality television has come under criticism in recent months for crossing the line between documentary and contrivance.

title: Grave of Genghis Khan May Lie Near His Birthplace
description: When the conqueror Genghis Khan was buried in 1227, legend has it, all his servants and the soldiers who attended the funeral were immediately killed to preserve the secrecy of the tomb site. And a secret it has remained all these years, one of history's tantalizing mysteries.

title: Harkleroad: It's Substance Over Style
description: Sitting at the GHI Bronx Classic in Crotona Park, whispers about a young Anna Kournikova, the tennis world's epitome of style over substance, could be heard in the crowd discussing 16-year-old Ashley Harkleroad. The comparison is an easy one because Harkleroad is also young, attractive and plays tennis, and it is one she is comfortable with.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WAAGE, DOROTHY V.
description: WAAGE-Dorothy V. Passed away on August 13. She was the adored wife of the late Thomas O. Waage, dear sister of Elaine Karpf and of Raphael Cerino, and beloved aunt of Carol Baer and Paul Cerino. She was a serious student of Shakespeare and classic literature, an avid lover of opera and great theater and a dedicated fan of Lotte Lehman and Luciano Pavarotti. She will be missed by her many friends and family who enjoyed her gracious hospitality, her culinary expertise and sparkling wit.

title: She's Pleading for Love While It's Raining Flowers
description: Melissa Etheridge's solo performance at City Center, which finished a four-night run on Tuesday, was billed as ''Live and Alone.'' But she rarely sang by herself. In nearly every song, voices joined her from the audience, from women who knew and cherished every word. Ms. Etheridge, an openly lesbian rocker who has made million-selling albums, lifts her raspy voice in anthems of passion and self-affirmation, treating the search for a lover as a heroic quest.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Outlook
description: Prospects for an imminent reduction in interest rates seemed to recede after the release of data showing higher wage increases and reports of a reluctance among some Bank of England officials to cut rates. The bank surprised investors this month by lowering its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 5 percent. The bank disclosed that its monetary policy committee made the decision by a 6-to-3 vote, displaying more opposition to the cut among committee members than economists had expected. Additionally, the National Statistics Office said average earnings rose an annualized 4.8 percent in the quarter through June, compared with 4.6 percent in the three months through May, adding to inflationary pressures.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?

title: The Diabetes Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: US Airways Sets 3 Goals In a Revamping
description: Trying to return to profitability after its failed merger with United Airlines, US Airways announced yesterday that it would expand its fleet of regional jets, try to join one of the big global airline alliances and seek greater concessions from unions.

title: Reported to Be Vanishing, Cajuns Give a Sharp 'Non'
description: In the heat, the muddy water of the Bayou Teche moves so slow it seems not to move at all, like a flat pane of murky glass. Gnarled oaks, three times as old as the oldest man, grow more wide than tall.

title: Egghead Files For Chapter 11
description: Egghead.com, a computer retailer, filed today for bankruptcy protection after laying off two-thirds of its work force and agreeing to sell its assets to closely held Fry's Electronics, court records said.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Brocade Meets Expectations
description: Brocade Communications Systems, the largest maker of computer system switches, reported fiscal third-quarter earnings yesterday that were down 40 percent from a year earlier but managed to meet Wall Street's expectations. Net earnings in the quarter fell to $12.1 million, or 5 cents a diluted share, from $20.1 million, or 8 cents, in the 2000 period. Sales rose to $116.3 million from $92.1 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast a profit of 5 cents a share. In a statement, Greg Reyes, Brocade's chief executive, said that although the company was operating in what he called a challenging economic environment, it was nonetheless ''continuing to invest in all aspects of our business to position for growth in 2002.'' Brocade shares fell $1.82, or 5.6 percent, to $30.34. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Western Wildfires Leaving Crews and Equipment Spent
description: With the West running out of people and equipment to fight fires, the National Interagency Fire Center declared a Level 5 alert today, the trigger point for asking for help from the military.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a ceremony at Ronald Reagan's former ranch to commemorate the 20th anniversary of his tax and budget reductions misstated the size of President Bush's ranch in a comparison. The Bush ranch is about 1,600 acres, not 1,200.

title: Israelis Brandish Tanks as Threat; Kill Fatah Militiaman
description: Israel kept tanks poised today outside Bethlehem and other autonomous Palestinian towns in the West Bank, with Israeli officials warning they would strike if Palestinian gunmen started shooting again at a Jewish neighborhood on Jerusalem's southern edge.

title: A Car for the Not So Virtuous, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Acquisition Panel Approves $60 Billion Fighter Program
description: The Air Force and the Lockheed Martin Corporation have won approval to begin initial production of the F-22 Raptor, a $60 billion stealth fighter program that has already been criticized for cost overruns, Pentagon officials announced today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILENDER, EDITH MORSE
description: MILENDER-Edith Morse. Of Tucson, AZ and Chestnut Hill, MA on August 14, 2001. Beloved wife of Sumner N. Dear daughter of the late Alan and Theresa Morse. Devoted mother of Steven J. Milender of Fairfield, CT, Constance Gobel of Orange, CT, Linda Ortwein of Greenwich, CT., and Karen Shackford of Madison, NH. Loving sister of Alan Morse Jr. of Brookline, MA., and Ann Cohen of Overland, KS. Also survived by eight grandchildren. For further information, call Brezniak-Rodman Funeral Directors, 1-800-554-2199.

title: A New Bid For Dismissal In Skakel Case
description: A defense lawyer urged a judge today to dismiss the murder charge against Michael C. Skakel in the 1975 death of Martha Moxley, arguing that state law at the time included a five-year statute of limitations.

title: Young Performers, New Works at Tanglewood
description: In advance it looked disappointing that the Boston Symphony was again to be playing only a small part in the Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood, which opened last Thursday and closed Tuesday night. Charles Wuorinen's ''Machaut Mon Chou'' was the orchestra's sole acknowledgment of the lively activities taking place elsewhere on campus, the piece, which creates a compact yet grand mosaic out of sequences from the 14th-century composer Machaut's Mass, lasting just 11 minutes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; The many faces of Adam Smith: Rediscovering 'The Wealth of Nations.'
description: NOT long ago, I asked my research assistant, Melissa Clark, to track down a passage from ''The Wealth of Nations'' by Adam Smith. Although I expected her to consult the modern edition, she instead requested the original 1776 edition from Princeton's Rare Book Library. The librarian accidentally gave her the fifth edition, published in 1789, and therein she discovered a remarkable signature: George Washington.

title: Phone Deal Raises Stakes In Russia
description: The leading telecommunications companies in Sweden and Finland are uniting with a Russian partner to create a nationwide operator here, the latest sign of consolidation in Russia's rapidly expanding mobile phone market.

title: NATO Is Sending British Troops To Macedonia for Disarmament
description: NATO decided today to send 400 British troops to Macedonia as the first wave of a contingent to disarm ethnic Albanian rebels and to try to prevent months of conflict from erupting into the fifth Balkan war in a decade.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Replacement 'Seagull' Tickets
description: Reversing itself, the Public Theater is providing replacement tickets for the rained-out opening night of Chekhov's ''Seagull,'' starring Meryl Streep. Ticket-stub holders will get new tickets for one of six performances Aug. 21 and 26, officials said, if they go to the 425 Lafayette Street box office on Monday between 1 and 3 p.m. There had been public grumbling that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other prominent figures, unlike others among the 1,900 or so at the Delacorte Theater, had gotten replacement tickets. But Carol Fineman, head of publicity, said an erroneous announcement on Sunday promised a rescheduled performance. ''We had to do something to make it right,'' she said.

title: It's Art? Oh.
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia's Leader Outlines Her Ways to Cure Nation's Ills
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 16  In her first major speech as president of Indonesia, Megawati Sukarnoputri presented the outline of ways to deal with the country's many problems, stressing stability, human rights, fiscal responsibility and a battle against corruption.

title: Bill to Limit Abortion Foes Puts Vallone On the Fence
description: City Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone appeared to distance himself yesterday from a bill pending before the Council that would limit access by protesters to clinics that perform abortions.

title: The Jets' Offensive Line Escapes Edwards's Wrath
description: In a week in which Jets Coach Herman Edwards said he would curtail what he asks players to do until they can eliminate mistakes, the Jets' offensive line has been shielded from criticism by its consistent play.

title: Bush Administration Revises Medicaid Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 — The Bush administration proposed today to roll back some of the protections for Medicaid recipients that President Bill Clinton put in place on the day before he left office in January.

title: Fast-Food Giveaway Toys Face Rising Recalls
description: Each year, McDonald's distributes 1.5 billion toys worldwide, more than Hasbro or Mattel. And McDonald's and its fast-food competitors together give away nearly a third of all the toys distributed in the United States.

title: HOW IT WORKS; For the Errant Heart, a Chip That Packs a Wallop
description: JOSEPH BAUM had just started a bicycle ride for charity in Philadelphia last summer when he began to black out. A problem with his heart was causing it to beat at a dangerously fast rate. Within seconds, a device in his chest put out a powerful electric jolt, knocking his heart back on track.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRITCHETT, JANE HARRISON
description: PRITCHETT-Jane Harrison. Beloved wife of Rees. Loving mother of Susan Pritchett Post & motherin-law of Edward Everett Post, Jr. Devoted grandmother of James (Jacko) and Rosalie Claudianna (Anna). Dear sister of Hadelyn Morrow. Mrs. Pritchett died on Tuesday, August 14, in Glens Falls, New York, after a short bronchial infection followed by a stroke. She was born Nov. 23, 1924, in North River, New York, the daughter of the late Fred and Hazel Hudson Harrison. A memorial service will be held at the Helen Hughes Memorial Chapel at the Silver Bay Association, Silver Bay, N.Y., 2 P.M., Saturday, August 18. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Silver Bay Association, Silver Bay, New York, 12874.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Job Cuts At Chemical Maker
description: A leading maker of specialty chemicals, Clariant A.G., will cut 1,000 more jobs and close factories after a write-down of an acquisition led to a loss in the first half of 1.3 billion Swiss francs ($774 million). The latest job cuts bring the total to 2,000, or 6 percent of the company's work force. Clariant said the British maker of drug ingredients BTP, which the company acquired last year for $1.8 billion, would not make as much money as expected, so it took a write-down of 1.2 billion francs in the first half. Clariant said it planned to take a second-half charge of more than 350 million francs ($209 million).

title: National Briefing | South: Puerto Rico: Authorities Arrest Police Officers
description: Federal authorities arrested 29 police officers on drug charges after an undercover investigation into accusations of police corruption. The officers work for police departments in San Juan as well as the cities of Caguas, Fajardo and Humacao. The Justice Department said the officers ''used their official positions to protect shipments of cocaine.'' All but one of the officers were charged with conspiring to possess and distribute cocaine and with carrying firearms while committing a drug offense. Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: Chinese Censors Shut Down Marxist Journal Critical of Jiang
description: Censors have shut down a small but influential Marxist journal for attacking President Jiang Zemin's plan to bring capitalists into the Communist Party, a sign that Mr. Jiang will brook little dissent from any quarter as he tries to cement his place in the pantheon of great leaders.

title: Editorial Notebook; As the Mosquito Sees the World
description: Personification is something most entomologists try to live without. It sets unintended metaphors rolling, like boulders in an avalanche. Picturing insects with human traits creates unwanted, almost invisible implications and muddies the guarded language of science. But it's always interesting, if completely unscientific, to turn personification inside out, to wonder how we might appear to the other creatures of creation. A new book -- ''Mosquito,'' by Dr. Andrew Spielman and Michael D'Antonio -- suggests some of the ways a mosquito might read the human race.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROCHMIS, LOLA (NEE ZUCCA)
description: ROCHMIS-Lola (nee Zucca). Beloved wife of the late Max Rochmis, loving sister of Irma, Orlando and the late Carmen, sisterin-law to the late Jennie and Max Goldman and Kate and David Molinoff. Her sense of style, love of life and bravery will be missed by her nieces and nephews, Sandy and Billie Goldman, Hal and Diane Goldman and Ada Ann Molinoff. Her loss will be felt by her adoring grandnieces and nephews, Laurie Goldman and her husband, Liam Mahony, Julia Vivrette Goldman, Kristen Goldmansour and her husband, Adib, Shannon Goldman, Jason and Christopher Goldman. She will also be greatly missed by her great grandnieces and nephews, Nicholas Goldman, Chloe and Luca Goldmansour and Sander and Thea Goldman. Like the magnificent music she loved so well, her memory will resonate for a very long time. A memorial will be held on August 16 at the Empire Hotel, New York City at 44 West 63rd Street, at 6 P.M. Memorial donations may be made to the American Cancer Society and Doctors Without Borders.

title: Why Netflix Is Cool
description: When I tell people what I do for a living, the first question most people ask is: "Do you get to keep all those DVD players, computers and palmtops you review?"

title: Cash Tempts Mexican Truckers to Haul Migrants
description: Immigration agents say that when they began to search Samuel Medina's 18-wheeler, it was the smell of human sweat that revealed that he was hauling more than bananas.

title: Design and Dissent Roil Ivy Clubhouse
description: DISGRUNTLED members of the Harvard Club of New York are mounting a last-ditch court battle to protest the decision to build a modernist glass addition to the club's neo-Georgian clubhouse on West 44th Street.

title: Police Say Teacher Raped 2 of Her Students
description: A teacher was arrested yesterday on charges that she raped, sodomized and sexually abused two male students at the Manhattan high school where she taught.

title: Shadows Cast by Forgery; The F.B.I. Investigates Complaints About Lewis Hine Prints
description: How did one of America's most famous photographers manage to sign his name again and again on paper that did not exist in his lifetime?

title: Henderson Pays Back Mets for Snub
description: The Mets released Rickey Henderson last season, they said, for his failure to hustle after hitting a fly ball. They gave a National League championship ring to everyone who played for them last year, except Henderson.

title: CBS Executives Take a Journey To CNN Land
description: CBS News executives visited CNN's Atlanta headquarters yesterday as part of continuing discussions about a possible news-gathering partnership.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Y.& R. Ad Unit Lays Off 10 Workers
description: The New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, said yesterday that it had laid off about 10 employees, or about 1.4 percent of its staff of 700.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Pattern Seen In Sex Attacks
description: The police said yesterday that by using DNA evidence they had linked a sexual assault in the Bronx on Sunday with nine other cases there and in Queens. In the latest attack, a 20-year-old woman opened her door to a man claiming to be a plumber, the police said. The man attacked her, ordered her to take a shower and then fled with her skirt. The assault is one of 10 attacks since March 1997 involving victims ranging in age from 9 to 58.

title: Being Naughty and Nice In a Sitcom Sort of Way
description: In blurring the distinction between naughty and nice, rock 'n' roll helped update the archetype of the heroic troublemaker. A rabble rouser whose purpose may be revolution or just watching the dust rise, the iconic rocker constantly chooses between making people happy and making them uncomfortable. This late into the music's history, though, its threat is subdued, and artists can choose amiability without having to worry about appearing soft.

title: Pilot Pen tries out a campaign that doesn't star its president.
description: DR. GRIP and G-2 sound like names of characters battling the forces of evil in the latest action-packed summer blockbuster. They are, however, simply pen brands that are featured in new television commercials for Pilot Pen.

title: Forget About Fancy; Savor the Accuracy; 'The Mouth of the Moodna' Has It Right
description: There may be a great story about how the painting, called ''The Mouth of the Moodna,'' was lost sometime after its creation in 1869. Or maybe not. Perhaps the picture, with its gentle depiction of the Hudson River just north of West Point, was simply thrown out with the trash. Then again, it might still hang on a wall somewhere -- the kind of artifact that turns up on public television's ''Antiques Roadshow,'' bought for a dollar at a yard sale, or found in Grandma's attic.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Mark Berlinsky, an advertising sales manager at MetroChannels, New York, part of Rainbow Media Holdings, was promoted to director for integrated sales at Rainbow Advertising Sales Corporation, also part of Rainbow Media. Rainbow Media is a subsidiary of the Cablevision Systems Corporation.

title: Manila Auditions Try to Ensure Country Exports Only the Best
description: MANILA  Throughout the hallways of the Philippine Overseas Employment Administration, rock bands haul amplifiers, guitars and drum sets while groups of young women in skimpy outfits nervously apply thick makeup.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Land Grabbers Beware
description: Describing the recent spate of land invasions as ''unacceptable,'' government officials said they would toughen the criminal penalties for people who illegally occupy private property. The proposed law would allow the government to prosecute people who organize land invasions in addition to the squatters who occupy the land. Officials here have repeatedly said they will not tolerate the type of land seizures that have racked neighboring Zimbabwe. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: Scientists Divided on Limit Of Federal Stem Cell Money
description: Scientists are divided over President Bush's decision on human embryonic stem cells, with some expressing dismay that their work has been constrained and others saying that they are lucky the door has been opened as far as it has. But many researchers agree that the onus is now on them to show that stem cell research is as promising as they have been saying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARLAN, STEWART
description: KARLAN-Stewart. The members of SSTT mourn the death of Stewart Karlan, a devoted member of our congregation. We extend our condolences to his wife Jacqueline, his children Eric and Liz, Evan, and Ed and Karen, and the family. Stephen A. Klein, Rabbi Andrew J. Goodman, President

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Rights Groups Challenge Voting Law
description: The American Civil Liberties Union and two other civil rights groups filed a federal lawsuit against state and Monroe County elections officials, seeking to block several sections of the state's new election law as discriminatory. The suit challenges the posting in all polling places of a list of ''Voter Responsibilities'' that says a voter must ''study and know candidates and issues.'' The lawsuit is brought under the Voting Rights Act, which outlaws any requirement that a voter be able to demonstrate the ''ability to read, write, understand or interpret any matter,'' or demonstrate ''knowledge of any particular subject.'' Dana Canedy (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Bonior To Run For Governor
description: Representative David E. Bonior announced that he would run for governor in 2002, seeking the Democratic nomination against at least two other candidates. Mr. Bonior, the House minority whip, said he had decided to run because he wanted to address issues of education, environmental protection and public transportation. But Mr. Bonior was also facing a more competitive Congressional race next year, because redistricting put Representative Sander M. Levin, a fellow Democrat, in Mr. Bonior's district. Recent polls have shown Mr. Bonior behind two declared Democrats, former Gov. James Blanchard and Attorney General Jennifer M. Granholm. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: Brand Union Buys MJM Creative
description: Brand Union in London and New York, a branding and consulting unit of the WPP Group, said yesterday that it had acquired MJM Creative Services in New York, a conference and event production company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Earnings Rise 75% At Federated Stores, Aided by a Catalog
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the owner of Macy's and Bloomingdale's, said today that its fiscal second-quarter earnings rose 75 percent because of a one-time tax benefit and a rebound in the Fingerhut catalog business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, KEVIN (SKY)
description: HALL-Kevin (Sky). Age 41. Loving husband of Sharie Hall. Beloved father of Skyler Marie and Kolby Taylor Hall. Dear son of Sonny and Maureen Hall. Fond nephew of Robert A. Hall, and Alice Hall. Family will receive friends Thursday and Friday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at The Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Saint Margaret of Cortona R.C. Church (6000 Riverdale Avenue, West 260 Street, Bronx), on Saturday August 18th at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations please to: Kevin Sky Hall Memorial Fund for his children Skyler Marie, 2-1/2 yrs, and Kolby Taylor Hall, 7 months: C/O Andrew Williams, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, NY 10463-5599.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Stalemate In Religion Case
description: Diplomats from the United States, Germany and Australia are still trying to visit eight foreign aid workers arrested on charges of preaching Christianity. But so far Taliban officials have told the envoys they cannot see their countrymen until an investigation is completed. Twenty-four employees of the German-based Christian aid agency Shelter Now International -- including 16 Afghans -- have been detained for the crime of proselytizing, which can bring the death penalty. Barry Bearak (NYT)

description: In percent

title: Gold Miners Eager for Bush To Roll Back Clinton Rules
description: These are the hills that gold built, acres and acres of rubble piled more than 200 feet high, the detritus of mining operations that require the removal of 80 tons of rock to produce a single ounce of gold.

title: Sports of The Times; W.N.B.A. Playoffs Are in Wonderland
description: THE LIBERTY had just vanquished the Washington Mystics on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, and 18,213 fans exploded in celebration. This was the end of a successful fifth W.N.B.A. season, the beginning of another Liberty playoff run.

title: Critic's Notebook; Hudson River School Painter Kept a Low Profile
description: Despite his long, moderately successful career as a painter of landscapes in the second half of the 19th century, not much is known about David Johnson.

title: Homebuilders' Index Is at a 9-Month High
description: An index measuring optimism among homebuilders rose to a nine-month high in August, a sign of growing demand, an industry survey showed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'LOUGHLIN, MICHAEL J.K.
description: O'LOUGHLIN - Michael J.K., Professor of Literature at the State University of New York at Purchase, died Monday, August 13, 2001, at Greenwich Hospital. He was 64 years old. Michael was born October 22, 1936, in Forest Hills, NY, to Michael J. & Margaret (Langan) O'Loughlin. He received his M.A. and Ph.D. from Yale University. He was the author of ''The Garlands of Repose, Studies in the Literary Representation of Retired Leisure''. Michael is survived by his five children, Ellen T. O'Loughlin-Villa, Professor Paula L., Michael H., Alec L., & Jonathan C. O'Loughlin; two grandchildren, Francesca and Kevin, and his sister, Mary Ellen O'Loughlin. A memorial mass will be held at St. Thomas More Church, 268 Park Street, in New Haven, at 11 AM, on Saturday, August 18th, 2001. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to Purchase CollegeHumanities Division, SUNY, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, New York 10577-1400.

title: Cell Biologist Traded Religious Fervor for Scientific Zeal
description: WASHINGTON  MICHAEL WEST slipped into a chair in the restaurant of the Mayflower Hotel here, ordered a plate of shrimp and a glass of red wine, rubbed his furrowed brow and offered an immediate apology. "Forgive me if I'm a little distracted," he said. "I have a lot on my mind."

title: Woodstock Just Isn't What It Used to Be
description: As if anyone needed to be told, we've come a long way from Woodstock. The word itself no longer means simply a town in New York or even the music festival that took place nearby in 1969. It evokes the peace-and-love aura -- so radical then, such a clich now -- that turned the festival into a defining cultural event.

title: CHANCELLOR PLANS TO CUT 1,500 JOBS ON CENTRAL STAFF
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy announced a sweeping reorganization of the Board of Education staff yesterday, a plan that would eliminate more than 1,500 administrative jobs over three years and give far more autonomy to local school superintendents to make their own decisions about how to spend their money.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Three Chess Kings To Meet
description: Three Russian world chess champions -- -- Vladimir Kramnik, Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov -- plan to play one another in December for the first time in years in honor of the 90th birthday of the teacher who made them grandmasters, Mikhail Botvinnik. The head of the Moscow chess federation, Sergei Smagin, said the three would compete for $600,000 in prize money. Mr. Karpov was world champion from 1975 to the 1985, when Mr. Kasparov dethroned him; Mr. Kramnik, 26, thrashed Mr. Kasparov last year in London to claim the title for himself. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Cuba on the Morning After
description: The state of Florida, Dade County and the city of Miami have an extensive plan for handling the departure from power of Fidel Castro. They expect a fiesta of no common size. Cuban exiles danced in Miami's streets when Mr. Castro fainted a few weeks ago. They watched hopefully as he stumbled Monday, in Venezuela, while celebrating his 75th birthday. The end does seem nearer. The average life expectancy for a Cuban man is 68.4 years. Nonetheless, Mr. Castro's father lived to 82, his mother even longer. Having stumbled in Venezuela, Mr. Castro went on to denounce the United States, drink champagne and make merry until dawn. Miami's party had to wait, again.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Profit At PC Maker
description: China's biggest computer maker, Legend Holdings Ltd., posted a first-quarter profit that easily beat expectations, helped by higher sales and lower costs. Net income in the quarter, which ended in June, rose to 251 million Hong Kong dollars ($33 million). The result will help allay concerns that Legend, which has 30 percent of the Chinese market, would have to give up profits to maintain market share. Yang Yuanqing, president of Legend, said the company had introduced some new products to take advantage of low component prices and hoped to maintain a market share of 30 percent to 40 percent for PC's.

The Cube was acquired for the Modern's design collection, along with six other Apple products, shortly before Apple announced the Cube's demise.

title: P.& G. AND COKE SCALE BACK JOINT VENTURE
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and the Coca-Cola Company scaled back plans for a joint venture to sell Minute Maid and Sunny Delight juices and Pringles potato chips after Coca-Cola balked at giving up its faster-growing lines. Each company will keep its individual brands instead of contributing them to the venture as announced in February, Procter & Gamble said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The companies are in talks to distribute Procter & Gamble's Pringles on Coca-Cola's beverage trucks and to set up a smaller venture to sell healthy drinks, Procter & Gamble said. Coca-Cola decided to shrink the project because it wanted to retain its growing Minute Maid and Hi-C lines, while sales of Procter & Gamble's food and beverages fell 11 percent in the past year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Madison: 'Sopranos' And New Jersey's Image
description: People who watch ''The Sopranos,'' the television series set in New Jersey and starring James Gandolfini, have a more negative image of New Jersey than nonviewers, according to a poll released yesterday by Fairleigh Dickinson University. In a nationwide survey of 800 households from June 28 through July 9, the university's PublicMind Poll found that ''Sopranos'' viewers are more likely to think New Jersey has more crime and other problems than other states. While the show did not necessarily give viewers their negative impressions, poll officials said, the poll also found ''Sopranos'' viewers were more likely to have actually visited the state. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

But the products he develops when he's not designing buildings aren't likely to go unnoticed. There's his polyurethane Fingertip Surface, far right, for walls or furniture. ''It has expandable capabilities just like mold,'' Mr. Faulders said. Fingertip was part of the recent exhibition celebrating the 20th anniversary of Limn, the home furnishings shop. Coming soon from Beige, the PS Perf Screen, left, of PVC pipe. Mr. Faulders will receive an award for experimental design this fall from the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: AOL Alters Pager Pricing
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it had reduced the price of its America Online e-mail pager to $99.95 from $329.95, but raised the monthly access fee $10, to $29.95. The company also said it had revamped its AOL Mobile Communicator software to display e-mail messages faster, allow customization of ''away notices'' and better notify users of low-coverage areas. By cutting the price of its pagers by more than two-thirds, the company hopes to win customers for its AOL Anywhere products. AOL's device is made by Research in Motion Ltd., whose Blackberry pagers are popular with business users. The research firm Jupiter Media Metrix has forecast that 96 million United States consumers in 2005 will connect to the Web through cell phones and other wireless devices, up from 4.1 million last year. description: MasterCard International said yesterday that it planned to issue tradable shares to the banks around the world that own it. Under its share sale proposal, the 1,600 financial institutions that own the company and shareholders of its European partner, Europay International, will receive shares. MasterCard, which is based in Purchase, N.Y., competes with Visa International Inc. in trying to get banks to issue its cards to customers. MasterCard hopes to gain loyalty from its owners by giving them a stake in its success.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: SKIN-DEEP FISCAL HEALTH Cosmetics Plus, a New York chain of stores specializing in makeup and perfume, has filed for bankruptcy and has asked the court for permission to auction off its business name, leases and other assets. The family-owned company, which once had the specialty beauty market virtually to itself, has faced growing competition in recent years from newcomers like Sephora and Aveda. Industry experts say Cosmetics Plus was distracted by a failed Internet venture and also ran into trouble when it tried to expand to Southern California. Today, Cosmetics Plus has 22 stores in the New York area. The owners, Robin and Toby Bartosh, did not respond to a request for comment. Terry Pristin (NYT) REFUNDS ON CAR LEASES The Banc of America Auto Finance Corporation has agreed to refund overcharges it collected from New Jersey customers for what the company had called excessive wear and damage on leased automobiles, state officials say. To settle a lawsuit brought by the state, the company also agreed to pay the state $350,000 to cover the cost of its investigation and to finance future consumer protection programs, the agency said. The company did not admit any wrongdoing. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK BUCHANAN: STEAM LEAK AT PLANT Consolidated Edison has reduced power by a third at its Indian Point 2 nuclear plant to repair a leaking steam pipe in a nonnuclear area of the plant, an official said. Engineers yesterday cut power to 65 percent of its nearly 1,000-megawatt capacity while employees worked on the pipe. The leak was discovered late Tuesday during a routine inspection of a metal pipe that is part of the system that feeds and discharges water to the plant, said Michael Clendenin, a spokesman for the utility. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: New Foster Home Rule
description: State officials will limit the number of children in each foster home to eight, after a child drowned at a foster home with 15 children. The new limit will go into effect on Sept. 1. Joseph J. Delmar, a spokesman for the State Division of Youth and Family Services, said foster families would also be banned from having more than four children under the age of 6 or two children under the age of 2. But the 79 New Jersey foster homes with more than eight children will be allowed to keep their children. On May 27, Janean Johnson, 6, drowned in a pool outside her Howell Township home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATTER, HUMPHREY
description: STATTER-Humphrey. Died on Tuesday, August 14, 2001 in Greenwich, CT at the age of 93. He was born in Sioux City, IA, and graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard College, and Harvard Law School. During W.W. II, he served as a Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Navy. Until his retirement, he was in private law practice in NYC. He served as President and a Trustee of the Huguenot Society of America, and was a member of the Union Club, the St. Nicholas Society, and the Sons of the Revolution. His wife, Julia Brokaw Statter, died in 1998. Surviving are his daughter, Phyllis Statter Oxman, of Greenwich, CT, his son, Humphrey Statter III, of Melbourne, Australia, his grandchildren, Elena Grear Oxman and Lee Warren Oxman, his nephew, Fairfield Pope Day III, and his niece, Stella Day Parsons. Funeral services are private.

description: The medical examiner's office has ruled that the death of a man in a hospital from complications of a broken leg was actually a homicide. The dead man, Lewis Clark, 80, broke his right femur on Nov. 20 and suffered chest injuries in a dispute with another patient at the Veterans Affairs hospital at 423 East 23rd Street. description: William M. Mercer Inc., a consultant on employment-related matters and a division of the William M. Most of SCA's approximately 100 consultants will be absorbed by Mercer's executive compensation consulting business, which currently employs about 150 people, according to a spokeswoman for the company. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELBY, CHRISTINE ''KIKI'' (VAN ERK)
description: SELBY-Christine ''Kiki'' (Van Erk). Passed away on August 14. She was so many things: a mother, a wife, a sister and a friend. More often than not, a combination of them all. Those who were fortunate enough to have known her will miss her kindness, wit, humor, sense of adventure, fight & never ending optimism. No one could hope for a better legacy. She is survived by her husband Tom, daughter Katie, sisters Nina and Sally & brothers Ted and Garrett. Visitation at McGrath Funeral Home, 20 Cedar Street, Bronxville, NY, Thursday, August 16, 2-4PM & 7-9PM. A Funeral Mass at Saint Peter and Paul in Mount Vernon, East Birch St, on Friday, August 17 at 10 A.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to MSKCC, 1275 York Avenue, POB 315, NY, New York 10021. Designate Dr. Moynahan's Research Fund.

title: U.S. 'Inaction' Weakens Arab Moderates, Egypt Aide Warns
description: Egypt's top foreign policy official warned today that the Bush administration's ''inaction'' in the Middle East could allow extremists to take hold in moderate Arab countries. This would be a consequence far graver than the administration's apparent fear, he said, of risking its prestige with an Israeli-Palestinian peace initiative.
