title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ex-Producer Charged
description: Adela Holzer, who gained notoriety first as a bona fide Broadway producer and then as a con artist, was charged yesterday with 39 more counts of grand larceny and scheming to defraud for trying to defraud immigrants, Manhattan prosecutors said. As part of the scheme, Ms. Holzer convinced Spanish-speaking immigrants that if they paid her $2,000 to $2,700, she could get prominent political friends in Washington to pass private immigration-relief bills that would give immigrants permanent resident status, the authorities said. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: Bellinger Savoring Vacation At Third
description: Roger Clemens and Clay Bellinger could not have had more divergent professional careers. Each was a high-round draft pick, but while Bellinger needed 10 years to make his major league debut, Clemens has continued pushing the odometer on his body way past what should have been its prime.

title: A Face-Lift for the Old Emporium and a Brand-New Bloomingdale's
description: Despite a downturn in the economy, plans continue for a vast shopping mall connecting the once elegant Emporium department store, first built in 1896 on Market Street and now shuttered, to a new Bloomingdale's on the more down-market Mission Street. The project is an attempt to lure more shoppers to the area south of Market, called SoMa, and to the Yerba Buena cultural district. Besides shops, the 1.58-million-square-foot development will contain restaurants, a movie theater and a hotel and will be near Daniel Libeskind's planned Jewish museum. Several architectural firms are sharing the job. RTKL of Baltimore will handle the master plan and restore the Emporium's Market Street facade, complete with the original big windows, and elevate the 102-foot-wide rotunda, in the rendering at right. The Bloomingdale's store, far right, will be by Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates of New York. Like the old Emporium, the new store will make much of natural light, said Kevin Kennon, the principal designer, but this time with an exterior of transparent and translucent glass.

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Gay Group Sues Over Road Program
description: A gay group has filed suit in federal court because the state will not allow the group to sponsor a sign in the adopt-a-highway program. The group, the Sioux Empire Gay and Lesbian Coalition, wants to sponsor litter cleanup along a section of state Highway 38 west of Sioux Falls. The state Department of Transportation says the organization does not qualify for a sign because it is an advocacy group. Pam Belluck (NYT)

title: A Car for the Not So Virtuous, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BREGMAN, WALTER W.
description: BREGMAN-Walter W. August 16, 2000. Ward, dear, not a day goes by without your name being spoken, not a moment when you are not deeply missed. Your loving family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, ROY A.
description: ROSENBERG-Roy A. On August 11, 2001. Rabbi and Founder Temple of Universal Judaism. Author and scholar. Survived by his wife Ruth, children Raoul, Risa, Rani, Rianne and Remi, mother Sylvia, brother Paul, and grandchildren Daniel, August, Jason, Carly & Isaac. Services Thursday, 11:45 AM at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Slave Traders in Yale's Past Fuel Debate on Restitution
description: As it marks its 300th anniversary, Yale University is celebrating what it calls its "long history of activism in the face of slavery"  the abolitionist faculty members who befriended the slaves on the ship Amistad in 1839, and today, the world's first center for the study of slavery.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Skin-Deep Fiscal Health
description: Cosmetics Plus, a New York chain of stores specializing in makeup and perfume, has filed for bankruptcy and has asked the court for permission to auction off its business name, leases and other assets. The family-owned company, which once had the specialty beauty market virtually to itself, has faced growing competition in recent years from newcomers like Sephora and Aveda. Industry experts say Cosmetics Plus was distracted by a failed Internet venture and also ran into trouble when it tried to expand to Southern California. Today, Cosmetics Plus has 22 stores in the New York area. The owners, Robin and Toby Bartosh, did not respond to a request for comment. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: A Hopping Red Rubber Bar, Fusion Food and Gender Illusionists
description: The restaurant-lounge Asia SF, at 201 Ninth Street in the South of Market area, looks like a psychedelic opium den, and is attracting throngs. Designed by John Lum, a San Francisco architect, its ground floor, right, has a vivid red rubber bar-cum-runway, a blue ceiling and fat bamboo and shoji screens back-lighted in colors that change through the spectrum from lime green to bright pink. It serves Asian fusion food and offers entertainment by drag performers, called here gender illusionists. Skip Young, who owns Asia SF with Larry Hashbarger, says the restaurant's ''uniquely San Franciscan brand of all-encompassing human diversity'' will be replicated early next year in Los Angeles in a space on Hollywood Boulevard near Vine. Phone: (415) 255-2742.

title: India Vows to Halt Terrorism Tied to Pakistan
description: In his first direct address to the nation since the breakdown of peace talks with Pakistan a month ago, India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, said today that his government would ''not hesitate in the least to crush Pakistan-sponsored terrorism.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Crackdown On Militants
description: A day after Pakistan's military ruler outlawed two Islamic groups blamed for sectarian killings, the police arrested hundreds of militants, closed offices and searched homes. Gen. Pervez Musharraf banned Lashkar-e-Jhangvi, a Sunni Muslim group, and Sipah-e-Mohammed, a Shiite Muslim group, and threatened to ban other violent groups. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Your average American kid grows up in Cleveland, marries a girl from Texas, and settles in Kansas. Your average Cajun boy grows up in Crowley, marries a girl from Ville Platte and settles somewhere close to her mama. In Eunice. We tend not to stray so far.''

title: INSIDE
description: Court Halts Texas Execution

title: Composer Plans to Strike Up the Cell Phones
description: ASK not for whom the cell tolls. Golan Levin already knows. In fact, he will be making the calls.

title: Bronx Youngsters Living A Dream, but in Silence
description: The Little League winners from the Bronx looked a bit weary as they marched out from their dorm rooms to the bus this morning. It was hot and bright, and they were starting a 275-mile journey to Williamsport, Pa., where their World Series would begin on Friday. Their shoulders sagged under the weight of duffel bags, their eyes lingered on the sidewalk and they muttered a few words to each other.

title: Earl Anthony, 63, Bowling's First $1 Million Man, Dies
description: Earl Anthony, professional bowling's No. 1 title-winner and its first $1 million man, was found dead Tuesday at a friend's home in New Berlin, Wis., having fallen down a flight of stairs. He was 63.

title: South Korea Asks U.S. for Help in Peace Talks With the North
description: South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, called on the United States today to ''make its best efforts to resume talks'' with North Korea, as peace activists flew to North Korea to help celebrate the 56th anniversary of the end of Japanese colonial rule.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Majority Leader Will Run
description: George C. Jepsen, the State Senate majority leader, filed documents with the secretary of state's office yesterday officially declaring his candidacy for governor. Mr. Jepsen, a six-term state senator from Stamford, is the first Democrat to file documents to prepare for next year's election. Last week, William E. Curry, a former state comptroller and Clinton White House aide, announced his intention to run. A third candidate, John Nussbaum, a New Haven business executive, is also seeking the Democratic nomination.

title: Suit Calls for City to Create Welfare Jobs Established by Council
description: Several people on welfare and welfare advocacy groups filed a class-action lawsuit against the city yesterday, accusing it of failing to create 2,500 subsidized jobs for welfare recipients this year as part of a jobs program that was enacted by the City Council.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, ALAN LOCKHART, JR.
description: CAMPBELL-Alan Lockhart, Jr. Died on Tuesday, August 14 at his home in Falls Village, Connecticut, in his 74th year. He is survived by his sisters Marion C. Strong and Jessie C. Sibert, as well as nephews Edward M. Strong, William C. Strong, William C. Sibert, Jr., Alan C. Sibert, John W. Sibert and niece Jane Colby McManus. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, August 18 at 11AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, 484 Lime Rock Road, Lime Rock, CT. Contributions in Alan's memory may be made to Trinity Episcopal Church, Lakeville, CT 06039 or the Salisbury Visiting Nurse Association, Box 645, Salisbury CT 06068.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Killers Of 29 Still At Large
description: On the third anniversary of a car-bomb attack in Omagh that killed 29 people, the Irish and Northern Ireland police appealed to the public for information to help them catch the bombers. The Real I.R.A., a dissident republican group, took responsibility for the bombing, the deadliest single attack in 30 years of violence in Northern Ireland. The police have questioned more than 7,000 people but no one has been charged. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: After Decades of Frustration, the Picture Tube Slims Down
description: LIKE so many other objects these days, the bulky cathode-ray tube that produces images on most television sets and computer monitors is under a lot of pressure to slim down. A trimmer picture tube would take up far less space in living rooms and on desktops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIGHTON, SYLVIA
description: LEIGHTON-Sylvia, 88. Of Palm Harbor, FL, died August 13, 2001 at her residence. Formerly of Port Washington, NY and Palm Beach, FL, Mrs. Leighton was a member of Temple Ahavat Shalom, Palm Harbor, FL, Hadassah, and The Women's American ORT. Beloved wife of the late Kurt Leighton. Loving mother to Lennard (Len) A. Leighton, Clearwater, FL and Rhonda (Ronnie) H. Weston, Palm Harbor, FL; grandmother of eight and great grandmother of two. Funeral services and interment Wednesday (August 15), Temple Ahavat Shalom and Curlew Hills Memory Gardens, Palm Harbor, FL. The family prefers, if you wish, contributions to Temple Ahavat Shalom, 1575 Curlew Road, Palm Harbor, FL 34683 or The Hospice Foundation of The Florida Suncoast, 300 East Bay Drive, Largo, FL 33770. For further information, call Curlew Hills Funeral Home, 727-789-2000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, CLAUDIA
description: LEWIS-Claudia. With sadness, we wanted to let you know of the passing of Claudia Lewis this past Thursday-August 9th-at her home in Pennswood Village, PA. Claudia, who would have been 94 this fall, studied at Bank Street in the early 1930s and then joined the faculty of the graduate school, then known as the Cooperative School for Teachers. A contemporary of Charlotte Winsor and Barbara Biber, she played a critical role in the development of Bank Street and the principles we still hold today. We are still awaiting details from the family, but they have indicated that in keeping with Claudia's wishes, there will not be a memorial service.

title: Crash in Hamptons Is Re-enacted
description: The Lizziemobile, as some people now call the Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle that the publicist Elizabeth S. Grubman is accused of backing into a crowd of nightclubgoers, returned yesterday to the scene of the crash in Southampton.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, ELIZABETH
description: EISENBERG - Elizabeth. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of the beloved mother of our dedicated benefactor, Eunice Miller. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier Michael B. Weisbrod, President Seymour G. Siegel, Treasurer

title: The Chancellor Gets a B+
description: Schools Chancellor Harold Levy's new proposal for cutting hundreds of jobs from the administrative budget represents a bold attempt to manage New York City's school system more like a business and less like a patronage machine. But the muted welcome that greeted the Levy plan, along with the tensions between the chancellor and City Hall and Mr. Levy's recent rather fatalistic comments, are signs that a familiar and destructive pattern has been set in motion at the Board of Education.

title: A Few Steps Up From a Scooter, But Still Far Short of a Car
description: Two years ago, the Hoffman importing group had four little Scootcars for rent in San Francisco. Now there are 24. Next year, there will be 36. The Transportation Department classifies the 300-pound, gas-powered Scootcar, imported from France, as a motorbike, not a car. It is a two-seat vehicle, with three wheels; San Francisco limits the Scootcar to a top speed of 40 miles an hour. Hourly rates start at $33 at the rental office, 431 Beach Street; (415) 567-7994. Scootcars can also be rented in Maui, Hawaii, and at Daytona Beach and Key West, Fla. Want to buy instead of rent? Hammacher Schlemmer has the same thing, which it calls a Danish Police Runabout, for $5,999.95, in its window at 147 East 57th Street in New York; (800) 421-9002.

title: Spend Saturday Reprogramming Your Lawn Mower, Not Your VCR
description: Although the hot summer sun may be frying your lawn to lackluster shades of brown, a new robotic lawn mower will at least give it the manicured look while you relax in the shade.

title: CORNELL, A PRISON OPERATOR, TO LEASE BACK PROPERTY
description: The Cornell Companies, which operates 70 prisons in 13 states and the District of Columbia, said yesterday that it had sold and agreed to lease back 11 of its properties, giving the company $173 million to repay debts. The company, which is based in Houston, also said it earned $2.13 million, or 22 cents a share, in its second quarter, down from $2.19 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 19 percent, to $65.7 million from $55.4 million.

title: Sol Place Center On Injured List
description: The Miami Sol placed center Marlies Askamp on the injured list yesterday and activated center Levys Torres.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Worldcom To Use WebEx Services
description: WebEx Communications, a provider of technology to conduct meetings and share documents over the Web, said its technology and infrastructure would be used in a forthcoming version of WorldCom's Net Conferencing service. WebEx supplies the technology for Web conferencing services marketed to corporate customers by telecommunications carriers like AT&T and Global Crossing. It also offers its services directly to corporations. The Web-based teleconferencing service adds a visual element to traditional conference calls, enabling participants to simultaneously view documents, videos and other files via a Web browser. WebEx shares fell 88 cents, to $20.72. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing | Corning Cuts More Jobs
description: Corning Inc. said yesterday that its cable unit would cut 450 more jobs. That brings the total of jobs eliminated since May to 1,140 at the fiber-optic and copper communications cable unit, the company said in a news release. Corning said it has eliminated 5,900 positions companywide this year.

title: Hip-Hop Romeo, Hasidic Juliet
description: ''Brooklyn Babylon'' begins with some pointed intercutting between a Jamaican rap band in rehearsal and a Hasidic wedding in ecstatic progress. The director, Marc Levin, is establishing images of two cultures on a collision course -- the setting is the divided Crown Heights neighborhood in Brooklyn -- but he is also suggesting how much the two groups have in common.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Judges Back Putting Records Online
description: A panel of federal judges has recommended that court documents in federal civil and bankruptcy cases be made available for public review on the Internet. The judges said the electronic records should be edited to block the names of minors and other personal information, like Social Security numbers and birth dates, to protect against identity theft. But they said federal criminal case files should not be put online, citing safety issues for witnesses and victims. Court records are public documents, but people must visit courthouses to read them. ''The federal courts recognize that the public should share in the benefits of information technology, including more efficient access to court case files,'' the 14-judge panel said in its report to the Judicial Conference of the United States. The conference, headed by William H. Rehnquist, the chief justice of the United States, sets policy for the courts. The recommendations from the panel will be considered at the conference's September meeting.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SAUL, ROBERT
description: SAUL-Robert. We love you. Nancy and Elizabeth

title: One Week Later, Inspired Giants Are Much Sharper
description: Last week's spiritless performance in New England did not demoralize the Giants. It was, as several players said at the time, only the first preseason game. But as the Giants knew, that was an excuse that would work just once.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about research on embryonic stem cells referred incorrectly to the contract used by owners of stem cell colonies to impose restrictions on researchers. It is a material transfer agreement, not a memorandum of transfer agreement.

title: Regional Tensions Thwart Egypt's Hopes for Gas Sales
description: CAIRO, Aug. 16 — Egypt knows that it has plenty of natural gas, much more than it can use. And it has ambitious plans to earn badly needed hard currency by exporting gas. But it is having trouble turning those ambitions into reality; regional tensions stand between Egypt and its most promising customers.

title: A Trove Of Wheeled Treasures
description: Vintage car lovers from all over the world will descend on the Monterey Peninsula of California this weekend for the annual series of historic-car races, parties, classic-car parades and car auctions. The Bonhams & Brooks auction of ''Important Collectors' Motor Cars and Automobilia'' is tomorrow at the Quail Lodge resort in Carmel. Christie's auction of ''Exceptional Motor Cars'' is on Sunday at the Pebble Beach Equestrian Center.

title: As Shifty as a Mogul and His Double-Crossing Dame
description: The silver lighter snapped shut like a scared turtle. A cigarette flickered in the dark. Then the clichs began to flow with the smoke, first erratically, tentatively, like a drippy faucet that won't stop in the night, then in a mad, crazy flood. I knew the playwright was up to no good. Dawne Seifert. What business did a dame have taking a cheap 1949 dime-store novel by Robert Leslie Bellem (1902-1968), the poor sap who created ''Dan Turner, Hollywood Detective,'' and adapting it for the stage? Someone should tell her mother.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Audit Of Driving Teachers
description: New York driving instructors should not be permitted to teach driving, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said in an audit released yesterday, blaming the Department of Motor Vehicles for poor oversight. The department can deny an instructor's certificate to someone with a criminal history, but it does not have access to the state's database of criminal records, the audit found. In 50 driving schools, Mr. McCall's office found that 14 instructors had criminal convictions. It also found that instructors who had their licenses suspended or revoked should not have been allowed to hold certificates. In addition, the audit said, the D.M.V. did not keep required information on the schools' insurance and vehicle registrations. Joe Picchi, a department spokesman, said that the audit reviewed practices more than a year ago and that many of the problems had already been addressed.

title: The Electric City Sees Its Police In a Harsh Light; Officers' Pranks and Crimes Hit Home in Schenectady
description: Suspecting that David Sampson was up to no good but having no proof, the two white police officers chose instead to take him for a ride that summer's evening in 1999. A long, long ride.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on July 24 and a report in the National Briefing column on Aug. 9 about a NASA mission to collect particles ejected from the Sun referred incorrectly to precedents for bringing extraterrestrial material back to Earth. The mission will be the first to do that since a Soviet mission in 1976, not since the earlier Apollo moon missions.

title: Snooze Bulletins
description: August is a slow time for news, and never more than this year, with President Bush giving himself the entire month off. Some people in the press seem to be following his lead. Tom Brokaw started his holiday on June 22, saying ''You have a wonderful summer,'' and isn't expected back until after Labor Day. Dan Rather, meanwhile, advised viewers that discussing the stem cell controversy ''requires such depth into the complexities'' that viewers who wanted to know about it should buy a newspaper. The rest of the month promises some equally summery reporting:

title: Triathlon Swimmers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Crime's Effects Sear Body and Soul
description: There is something brave about Allison Anders's best films, a defiance of commercial and artistic conventions that makes her work audacious even when it's not totally successful. That ruthless honesty, as well as that unevenness, pervades ''Things Behind the Sun,'' her tough new semiautobiographical film about the after-effects of rape. Its most disturbing scene is not the flashback, late in the film, of the heroine's rape by a gang of neighborhood boys when she was 14 (as unsettling as that is). A more eye-opening, visceral scene is the one in which we see her in the present.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHN, BENNO
description: COHN-Benno. August 8, 2001, age 103. Graduate of CCNY, U.S. Army pilot in France 1917-9, French Medal Legion of Honor 1999, president Ferdinand Gutmann & Co, 1947-1990, Board, Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce. Memorial service in New York this autumn.

title: Nicholas Orloff, 86, Teacher And Stylish Ballet Master
description: Nicholas Orloff, a dancer, ballet master and teacher whose career spanned many companies and eras, died on Tuesday at the Tolstoy Foundation in Valley Cottage, N.Y. He was 86.

title: A Welcome Mat for Gay Customers
description: AFTER decades of treating gay consumers as the invisible minority they often were, automakers are courting them directly, often with messages that wave the rainbow banner of gay acceptance.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Wednesday about a performance of ''The Seasons'' by Haydn in the Mostly Mozart series misstated the work's history at the festival. It was presented in 1975; this was not its Mostly Mozart premiere.

title: Compromise Brings Hevesi $2.6 Million in City Funds
description: Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi struck a compromise yesterday with the Campaign Finance Board, which then released $2.6 million in city matching funds for his mayoral campaign and, perhaps just as important, lifted what had been a cloud over his candidacy.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Guardsmen To Go To Bosnia
description: About 250 members of the Connecticut Army National Guard are scheduled to be deployed in Bosnia as part of the peacekeeping operation there, National Guard officials said yesterday. One hundred soldiers from Company B, 102nd Infantry, and 150 soldiers from the 143rd Forward Support Battalion will leave for the Balkans later this month. The call-up is the largest for the Connecticut Army National Guard since the Korean War, State Guard officials said. Connecticut is one of 18 states participating in the peacekeeping effort, Guard officials said. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, ROSE
description: MILLER-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Emanuel. Devoted mother of David and Candice. Adored grandmother of Andrew and Beth (Fendell), Emily and Per Anders (Wendin) and Howard Miller. Loving great-grandmother of Daniel. We will all miss her.

title: Network Critic At N.A.A.C.P. Seeks a TV Job
description: Kweisi Mfume, the president of the N.A.A.C.P., who earlier this week accused network television of moving too slowly to increase racial diversity, has videotaped the pilot for an Oprah Winfrey-style talk show that would be syndicated by NBC.

title: Bloomberg Says Others Use His Proposals
description: Michael R. Bloomberg suggested yesterday that both Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy and Public Advocate Mark Green, a Democratic candidate for mayor, have been lifting Mr. Bloomberg's ideas about education. ''Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery,'' Mr. Bloomberg said.

title: Remaining Offices Of Bozell Are Closing
description: The remaining offices of Bozell Kamstra are being closed. Bozell Kamstra was part of the Bozell Group unit of True North Communications, before True North was acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies and Interpublic was reorganized last month.

title: Jockeying for Position as Roughest-Toughest James Guy
description: Luckily for the makers of ''American Outlaws,'' Jesse James (Colin Farrell), his brother Frank (Gabriel Macht) and their cousin Cole Younger (Scott Caan) seem to have arrived on the scene just in time for the invention of the electric guitar. It wails on the soundtrack and makes this western, which doubtless considers itself to be a reimagining (as did ''Planet of the Apes''), sound as if it came from the mind of Jon Bon Jovi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUSTER, ALAINE
description: JUSTER-Alaine. On August 16, 2001, of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. Beloved wife of Cyrus. Devoted mother of Fern, Holly and Laurie. Loving mother-in-law of Steven Swirsky and Keith Klefstad. Dear sister of Rabbi Moshe Feierstein. Adored grandmother of MaggieRose, Maxwell, Jacob, Samuel and Emma. Services Sunday 12 noon at Old Westbury Hebrew Congregation, Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Article 2001081790319281381 -- No Title
description: A lighter and bearded Rev. Al Sharpton was released from a federal prison in Brooklyn today after serving 90 days for trespassing on Navy property in protests over bombing exercises on Vieques, Puerto Rico.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: A Mandolin Is a Weapon in a Laid-Back War
description: If you've been longing to visit the Greek islands but haven't the time or money to make the journey, you could do worse than spend a couple of hours soaking up the scenery in ''Captain Corelli's Mandolin.'' Filmed largely on Cephalonia, the island that is the setting of Louis de Bernires's much-loved 1994 novel, ''Corelli's Mandolin'' (from which the film was adapted), the movie shimmers with a bluish-gold luminescence reflected from the turquoise waters of the Ionian Sea. This light lends the craggy landscape a hot coppery radiance that seems to emanate from inside the earth. Cinematographically (John Toll supervised), the movie is a glorious ode to the sun-baked island on which it was filmed.

title: Patent on Human Stem Cell Puts U.S. Officials in Bind
description: As they carry out President Bush's plan for government financing of embryonic stem cell studies, federal health officials confront a daunting challenge: United States patent 6,200,806, a claim to the human embryonic stem cell.

title: National Briefing | Education: School Enrollment Rising
description: Enrollment in American schools and colleges this fall is expected to be greater than ever before, with 53.1 million students entering kindergarten through 12th grade, and 15.3 million pursuing higher education. A report by the National Center for Education Statistics says that elementary and secondary school enrollment will break a record for the sixth consecutive year, while college and university attendance has broken records four years in a row. Projections suggest that higher education enrollment will continue to expand through the decade to 17.7 million but that enrollment in kindergarten through 12th grade will level off at about 53.4 million. The surge will be led by the West, while other regions of the country are expected to see slight enrollment declines. Jodi Wilgoren (NYT)

title: Liberty Unit to Buy On Command
description: The satellite-television unit of Liberty Media said today that it had agreed to buy its parent's stake in the pay movie service On Command for $703.8 million in stock.

title: A Campaign By Avon on Breast Cancer
description: ''Strength'' and ''Courageous Spirit'' probably do not conjure up images of bright red or raisin-colored lipstick. But they are, indeed, the names of two of six new lipstick shades being introduced in mid-September by Avon Products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESSY, TERRENCE W.
description: HENNESSY-Terrence W. Died August 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Virginia. Champion horseman and friend to many. Memorial services to be announced.

title: Clarke Issues Rangers an Ultimatum on Lindros
description: With the Rangers close to completing a contract to obtain Eric Lindros from the Flyers, Philadelphia General Manager Bob Clarke issued an ultimatum last night: complete the deal today or the Flyers will listen to an offer from a Western Conference team.

title: Lucent Is Allowed Changes In $4 Billion of Bank Loans
description: Lucent Technologies reached an agreement with its lenders yesterday to modify the terms of its $4 billion in bank loans.

title: Where the Pools Are Never Crowded, And Water Slides Are Nature's Own
description: The pool in the hard rock of the Bouquet riverbed was filled with dark and mysterious water. Was it 8 feet deep, 12 feet? Did it go to the center of the earth?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mount Vernon: Hearing On Pipeline
description: Federal regulators reviewing a disputed interstate pipeline, the longest proposed natural-gas pipeline in the country, have scheduled a public hearing here next month. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission will conduct the meeting at Thornton Elementary School, 121 South Sixth Avenue, at 7 p.m. on Sept. 4. The pipeline would run 425 miles from the Canadian border across New York State to Mount Vernon. The Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation of Fairfax, Va., proposed it in December 1997, but met opposition from those who fear environmental damage and the potential for explosions.

title: Williams Out As Red Sox Give the Ball To Kerrigan
description: Jimy Williams and Dan Duquette stood five feet from each other before the Boston Red Sox played the Seattle Mariners on Wednesday night, looking like awkward dance partners. They spoke, but their words were brief and they hardly looked at each other. The men shared a clumsy body language that indicated neither one embraced the conversation.

title: Defendant Found Guilty In L.I. Beatings
description: After less than five hours of deliberation, a jury convicted Christopher Slavin today on charges that he and a friend lured two Mexican day laborers to an abandoned building last fall by offering them work, then brutally attacked the men with a folding knife and a post-hole digger.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Bank Profits
description: Unio de Bancos Brasileiros, a major Brazilian bank, said net income rose 51 percent to $89 million in the second quarter of 2001, compared with the period in 2000. Higher interest rates, the fall in value of the Brazilian real and a marketing push that brought in 380,000 new accounts and expanded the bank's loan portfolio by 44 percent all added to the bank's profits. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Mystery Girl vs. Creepy Vampires? Scary
description: You don't have to be familiar with the convoluted pop mythology behind the Japanese anime film ''Blood: The Last Vampire'' to appreciate some aspects of a movie that seems destined for cult status. Anyone who desires to explore its world, which is really a genre-within-a-genre, is advised to do a little homework. But to an uninitiated film critic, what's most intriguing about the movie isn't its story but its digitally animated visual language which is determined more by technology than by content.

title: Report Faults U.S. Planning In Burning Chemical Arms
description: As the Army begins to step up its effort to destroy its stockpiles of chemical weapons, a new Congressional report says that thousands of people who live near three chemical depots face an unnecessarily high risk in case of an accident in incinerating the gases.

title: A Daley Considers Running for Illinois Governor, and the Race Begins to Catch Fire
description: The 2002 governor's race in Illinois is shaping up as a free-for-all, complete with the possibility of party-sundering primaries and a bitter debate over whether Illinois is ready for two Daleys, one to run Chicago and the other to run the state.

title: Cell Biologist Traded Religious Fervor for Scientific Zeal
description: WASHINGTON  MICHAEL WEST slipped into a chair in the restaurant of the Mayflower Hotel here, ordered a plate of shrimp and a glass of red wine, rubbed his furrowed brow and offered an immediate apology. "Forgive me if I'm a little distracted," he said. "I have a lot on my mind."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE CASTRO, ROBERT MASSY JOSEPH
description: de CASTRO - Robert Massy Joseph, 94. On 14 August 2001 in Brookhaven, GA., widower of Margaret Adams Walker, survived by cherished stepdaughter Ann Crowley Thorpe, New Milford, Connecticut, and cousins Capt J. Edmund de Castro, Jr., USNR (Ret), Julian E. de Castro, Alicia de Castro Kwietniewski of Buffalo, NY, and Lt. Samuel Fletcher de Castro, USN, Monterey, CA; Col. Carlos M. de Castro, MD USA (Ret) Houston, TX; Major Ralph de Castro, US Army Air Corps (Ret.) Melbourne, FL; and Christine de Castro Hatcher Duluth, GA., many cousins, friends, & esteemed Coast Guard and Navy shipmates. He was a grandson of Eduardo de Castro, a Patriot who advocated Puerto Rican independence from Spain, who with his brothers, established a N.Y.C. cigar manufactory at 3 and 5 Coenties slip on the Manhattan waterfront in the 1880's. Robert de Castro graduated from Manhattan College and attended Columbia Law School. He was a veteran textile representative of Joshua Baily & Co. and Pacific Mills. In 1936 he was a crew member of famous Naval architect, Henry M. Devereux's, cutter ''Pendragon'', participating in the Newport to Bermuda race, weathering a full gale, finally arriving in Bermuda. He was a founder of the Storm Trysail Club, a Larchmont, NY yacht club. A Coast Guard Ensign in WW II, he served in the cutter U.S.S. Tampa on the Greenland Patrol; and after the Coast Guard was assimilated into the Navy during W.W. II, he received a Navy commission, and when promoted to Lieutenant Commander, was executive officer of the U.S.S. Peoria (PF 67) on North Atlantic and Mediterranean convey duty. He participated in many attacks against German submarines. After the war he managed the New York City office of the Baily Co., and opened a Dallas, TX branch office. In addition to the Storm Trysail Club, he was a member of the East Lake Golf Club, Atlanta, GA, and the Coast Guard Combat Veterans Assn., the Greenland Patrol Assn. and the Peoria Reunion Assn. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Avenue at 66th Street on Saturday 18 August 2001 at 9:45 A.M. Burial will be at Mount Calvary Cemetery Queens, New York. A memorial Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Cathedral of Christ the King in Atlanta in September at the family's convenience. Contributions may be made to the donor's Charity of choice.

title: CBS Reruns Dropped As Advertiser Balks
description: CBS has decided not to broadcast a handful of rerun episodes of ''Family Law'' after a big advertiser, Procter & Gamble, said it would withdraw its commercials because it deemed the content too controversial.

title: CBS Pulls Show Over Concern From P.& G.
description: CBS has decided not to broadcast a handful of rerun episodes of the dramatic series ''Family Law'' after a big advertiser, Procter & Gamble, said it would withdraw its commercials because it deemed the content too controversial.

title: NATO Puts Off Its Decision on Sending Full Macedonia Force
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 17  NATO today put off until next week a decision on whether to send a 3,500-member peacekeeping force to Macedonia, and indicated that it would wait for a report from the task force's commanders, who began arriving today.

title: The Merger With Two Sides
description: When American companies cite foreign competition to justify blockbuster mergers, regulators should be careful to check whether that competition extends down to consumers. Oil companies, like car makers and airlines, face fierce global competition when it comes to production and financing. But they cater to domestic markets that are often less sharply contested. Last Friday Chevron and Texaco proposed a promising merger plan that begins to address this duality.

title: Documenting America, From Industrial Behemoth to Sweet Innocent
description: From the 1940's into the 60's, until television sets became a common fixture in American homes, magazines fed the American appetite for photographic essays.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Palm Buying Assets Of Be For $11 Million
description: Palm, the maker of hand-held computers and the Palm operating system, said yesterday that it would acquire the intellectual property of Be, developer of the Be operating system. The purchase price was $11 million, to be paid in Palm stock. Palm also offered jobs to Be's engineers for its software engineering group. Jean-Louis Gasse, Be's chief executive, who once led Apple Computer's product development efforts, will become a temporary adviser to Palm. Separately, Palm said that Alan Kessler, general manager of the company's platform solutions group, had resigned. Until a replacement is found, Eric Benhamou, Palm's chairman, will run the operation, which is responsible for developing and licensing the Palm operating system. Palm, based in Santa Clara, Calif., recently spun off the platform solutions group into a wholly owned subsidiary. Mr. Kessler declined to give any reason for his resignation.

title: Dell Loses $101 Million For Quarter
description: Dell Computer lost $101 million in the second quarter of its fiscal year, largely because of charges related to job cuts and other expenses, the company said yesterday.

title: Gale Cincotta, 72, Opponent Of Biased Banking Policies
description: Gale Cincotta, a plainspoken mother of six who became a neighborhood activist and went on to help ignite the national debate over bank lending policies that discriminated against minority home buyers, died Wednesday at a hospital in Maywood, Ill. She was 72.

title: Children Are Prey in a Medicaid Dental Scheme
description: Any mother would be unnerved to hear that a stranger had taken her child to the dentist. But when it happened to Cynthia Blue last summer, she was terrified.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Jet Sale Sets Record On Ebay
description: A Gulfstream II business jet sold on eBay for $4.9 million, the highest price paid for any item on the company's online auction sites. The aircraft was one of several offered by Tyler Jet on eBay's aviation site, an eBay spokesman, Kevin Pursglove, said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on July 24 and a report in the National Briefing column on Aug. 9 about a NASA mission to collect particles ejected from the Sun referred incorrectly to precedents for bringing extraterrestrial material back to Earth. The mission will be the first to do that since a Soviet mission in 1976, not since the earlier Apollo moon missions.

title: A Universe Of Art, Centered In Boston
description: UNLIKE some American cities, Boston stays open for the summer, promoting itself this year as a place for ''serious fun.'' Presumably, that includes art, not too hard to find in a megalopolis known for its formidable museums. From the quiet college town of nearby Wellesley to the swarming student-faculty hive of Cambridge to the deep-city precincts of the Fenway and Boylston Street, there are exhibitions for the taste of any viewer, traveling on foot, by cab or by Boston transit. Here are a few shows you might see on a summer's day.

title: BAYER POSTPONES PLANS FOR BIG BOARD LISTING
description: Bayer A.G. yesterday abruptly postponed its plan to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, citing its worsening situation in the wake of its decision to withdraw one of it most profitable drugs from the market. Bayer said the climate for its new listing had ''altered considerably'' since its decision to halt sales of Lipobay, a cholesterol-lowering drug. The company's shares in Germany have dropped more than 20 percent in the last week. Beyond losing a product that was supposed to generate nearly $900 million in sales this year, Bayer has now become a target of class-action lawsuits in the United States and new criticism by the German Ministry of Health, which contended yesterday that Bayer had waited for two months before turning over information it had on the drug's side effects. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

description: Earlier this year, Sega of America Dreamcast, which makes computer games and the machines to play them, went to court, suing one of its biggest customers over a $2.2 million unpaid bill.

title: Corrections
description: An article Wednesday about the decision of three Supreme Court justices to disqualify themselves from a Texas execution case referred incorrectly to the origins of the court. Though the court itself was established by the U.S. Constitution, the number of justices is set by Congress. The original court had six members.

Medi, a French-Italian collaboration, promises a dream vacation, part Mediterranean cruise, part overland trip to Tuscany. The restaurant is a collaboration between the legendary Roger Verg, the chef and owner of Moulin des Mougins in Provence, and Roberto Ruggeri, the president of the Bice chain.

Robert Lederman, a canny street artist who has waged three federal lawsuits for his First Amendment rights to display his art and opinions in the public eye, has Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Democrats immediately denounced the estimates as overly optimistic and politically self-serving.

Globalnet Financial.com, which is based in Santa Monica, Calif., but does most of its business in Britain, is almost out of cash and will cease operating if it does not find a buyer soon. Globalnet reiterated its support of a previous $9 million bid from NewMedia Spark, a British company that invests in start-ups. Shares of Globalnet were unchanged at 35 cents. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Mean-Spirited U.N. Conference
description: The United Nations World Conference Against Racism, which will take place later this month in South Africa, is one of those meetings that make people wonder about the usefulness of the U.N. Originally conceived as a forum to examine how to combat contemporary forms of racism, the meeting now threatens to dissolve into an unproductive debate about reparations payments for slavery, condemnation of Israel and such topics as whether the word ''Holocaust'' should be capitalized.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASHMAN, BETTY
description: CASHMAN-Betty, ''Coach to the Famous,'' nationally known drama coach for politicians and performers, died Wednesday after a long illness. She was 90 years old. A native of New York City she taught acting and speech skills to a wide range of public figures from the late director of the Central Intelligence Agency, William J. Casey, and the late New York City Mayor, John Lindsay, to actors, Jack Palance and Tony Curtis. She was born in New York and began her professional acting career at age 4. Betty graduated with honors from the American Academy of Dramatic Arts and began her coaching career in New York City. During the 1950's, Ms. Cashman received four consecutive ''Show Business Oscars'' for ''Greatest Development of New Talent in the Theatre.'' Over the years, her list of clients included Dr. Joyce Brothers, Nancy Sinatra, Zsa Zsa and Eva Gabor, Gene Shalit, and Eileen Ford. Co-Founder of Ford Models, Eileen Ford said that ''Betty Cashman was very much a part of my life and that of Ford Models in the early days of television commercials. She gave us lessons that not only improved our speech, but gave us all the confidence we all needed. Betty Cashman was the best there was. We all owed her a lot.'' In an interview with Charlie Rose on Rose's PBS program, Academy Award-winning actor, Jack Palance, singled Ms. Cashman out for praise as ''a fantastic coach.'' Bernadette Casey-Smith, daughter of the late CIA Director, William J. Casey, said her father called Betty Cashman ''a national treasure.'' Betty's technique attracted her to show producers who hired her as an ''Actor's Doctor,'' working with performers on a dramatic role. She was the author of several books on acting, one of which, ''Betty Cashman and You in Personality, Acting and Public Speaking,'' earned the coveted International Mark Twain Award. Betty is also listed in the ''Who's Who of American Women'' and ''Who's Who of the American Theatre.'' A celebration of Betty Cashman's life will be held at a later date. ''Liz'' Wickersham

title: Metro Business Briefing | Protest Against Radio Format
description: Several hundred people gathered outside the Forward Association's office in Midtown yesterday to protest its decision to switch the format of its radio station, WEVD-AM (1050), to an ESPN 24-hour sports talk channel on Sept. 1 as part of a lease agreement with the Walt Disney Company. The move would end several radio programs, including those of Bill Mazer, Alan Colmes and Edward I. Koch. The association, which owns The Forward, said that it made the agreement to pay for its money-losing newspapers.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Economic Standstill
description: The German economy slowed to a standstill in the second quarter of this year, the Bundesbank, the central bank, said today. It said the country was not sliding into a recession, which would require a broader and more long-lasting slowdown that affects most sectors of the economy. But it painted a gloomy picture that included weak growth in consumer spending, a decline in demand for machinery and equipment, weak growth in exports and a continued recession in the construction industry. The Bundesbank refrained from calling for a reduction in interest rates by the European Central Bank, of which it is a powerful member, but many economists say that the European bank will reduce rates at its next meeting at the end of August.

title: Northrop Grumman Hires New Agency

Had the first quarter not been revised, that would have met the traditional criterion for a recession: two consecutive quarters of contraction.

The police charged the journalists with publishing subversive material, which carries a maximum prison sentence of five years. The journalists, who work for The Daily News, Zimbabwe's only independent daily newspaper, were first arrested on Wednesday after the newspaper reported that militants had used police cars during the recent looting of white-owned farms. The action was another move to shed real estate holdings so that the authority could focus more on transportation. The 12-year-old, 20-story building on the Passaic River was built at New Jersey's request with agency funds in an effort to revitalize downtown Newark. Lewis Eisenberg, the Port Authority chairman, said the goal had been met with, among other things, the construction nearby of a new Federal Bureau of Investigation building and a riverfront promenade. title: Ciena Shares Fall After Warning
description: Ciena, the maker of fiber optic equipment, said today that profit for the 2001 and 2002 fiscal years would trail estimates. Its shares plunged.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Campaign For Sainthood
description: A 35,000-page report on the life of Mother Teresa, put together by a diocesan commission in Calcutta, will be sent to the Vatican in six sealed boxes. Her order, the Missionaries of Charity, hopes she will be beatified and eventually be made a saint. ''I pray that we will have Saint Mother Teresa of Calcutta in the near future,'' said her successor, Sister Nirmala. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEELMAN, MAX RANDOLPH, JR.
description: STEELMAN-Max Randolph, Jr. Died August 16 at age 66. He is survived by his wife, Shirlee, son, Max Randolph III, daughter-in-law, Kelly & grandson, Blake. Visitation will be at Follett Funeral Home, Westhampton Beach on Friday, August 17 from 7-9 P.M. Graveside service will be at the Westhampton Cemetery on Saturday, August 18, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be sent to the Lauren Meaney Fund, Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 East 91 Street, New York City 10128.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qualcomm Investing In Nextwave
description: Qualcomm, which licenses patents for mobile telephones used by 90 million people, will invest $300 million in NextWave Telecom, the bankrupt wireless carrier that holds claims to disputed airwave space in the United States. The investment depends on NextWave's completing a bankruptcy reorganization and getting the frequencies ''free and clear,'' a Qualcomm spokeswoman said. NextWave, based in Hawthorne, N.Y., is building a network based on a wireless transmission technology developed by Qualcomm, which is based in San Diego, Qualcomm said. NextWave, which sought bankruptcy protection in 1998, won a victory in June when a federal appeals court returned the frequencies the company lost after defaulting on a debt to the government.

title: Women Fired for Sexual Harassment Complaint, State Says
description: Two female employees of Caesars Atlantic City were fired for complaining about male colleagues' practice of using the casino's hidden surveillance cameras to ogle other women, according to a complaint disclosed yesterday by the New Jersey Division on Civil Rights.

title: Inside Art
description: The Inside Art column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertising Takeover Duel
description: WPP Group, the British advertising firm, has approached the Tempus Group about buying it in an effort to trump an earlier bid by Havas Advertising of France, Tempus confirmed. Although no formal offer document has been filed with regulators, WPP sent a letter to Tempus executives proposing a price of 550 pence to 555 pence a share in cash, or 440 million ($634 million), people close to the discussions said. Tempus had agreed last month to Havas's offer of 541 pence a share. Investment bankers from Tempus and WPP were meeting yesterday to negotiate details of the proposal. Although Tempus would typically be required to recommend the higher offer, the two bids are so close in price that the company can consider other criteria, like strategic fit and executive overlap, a person close to the talks said. Havas and WPP executives declined to comment. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBA, EDWARD A.
description: GARBA-Edward A. On August 15, 2001. Loving husband of Martha. Visitation today Friday 2-4 & 7-9 at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, 914-698-5968. Funeral Mass Saturday 10 AM, Sts John & Paul Church, committal at Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: Hollywood, an Eye on Piracy, Plans Movies for a Fee Online
description: Five major movie studios, including some of Hollywood's top players, unveiled plans today for a joint venture that would allow computer users to download rental copies of feature films over the Internet.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Philips To Quit Making VCR'S
description: Royal Philips Electronics says it will ''refocus'' its video activities by having another manufacturer make videocassette recorders for the European market. Philips said the shift would result in the elimination of 850 to 1,000 jobs by the middle of next year. The jobs affected are in Vienna and are part of a larger program to cut 1,200 jobs in that city. Philips will farm out the production of VCR's to the Funai Electric Company of Japan. Financial details of the deal were not disclosed. Philips said it planned to concentrate on marketing and sales and ''scale down its development activities for videotape recorder technology.''

title: Changing Face Of August
description: Now come the dog days of August. In summers past, the last month of the crowded summer movie season was often a dumping ground for lesser entertainments that didn't quite live up to their studios' expectations and were denied more coveted slots in the early summer.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the legal battle between the Giuliani administration and merchants at Mart 125, the indoor market on Harlem's main commercial strip, misstated the date of the city's takeover there. It was five years ago, not in 1986.

title: A Month in Macedonia Will Not Be Enough
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization expects to send some 3,500 troops to Macedonia in the next few weeks to collect rebel weapons. This decision, which is scheduled to be made today, is meant to signal that NATO is serious about its commitment to the region.

title: Op-Art
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Fort Lee: Bridge Worker Killed
description: A 29-year-old construction foreman on the George Washington Bridge died of head injuries Wednesday morning as he led a crew of workers who were sandblasting the underside of the bridge. The authorities are still unsure how the man, Jefferson Campos of Belleville, N.J., died and whether he was killed by a blast from the hose or by a company truck that was backing into position. He was injured about 9:30 a.m. in the lower westbound lanes and died a short time later at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: A Monster Of a Release
description: The date is Nov. 2, and if all the promotion has done its work, mall parking lots will be jumping with fans itching to storm any place that sells videos. Not a ''Titanic''-size rush perhaps, but definitely a video event on the order of, say, one of the big Disney releases back in the days when consumers soaked up animated features by the tens of millions of cassettes.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Television; Amid the Mournful Black, Life Unfolds With Vigor
description: Since ''Six Feet Under'' began in June, an amazing number of people who were put off by a show set in a funeral home have said, ''It's gotten better.'' Maybe they've synched into its skewed humor and warmed up to the deep but unsentimental bonds in the family that runs Fisher & Sons mortuary. Maybe they got used to looking at corpses at the beginning of every episode. But even for those of us who found it dazzling, funny and gripping from the start, the series has become only stronger.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Gotti's Son-In-Law Pleads Guilty
description: Carmine Agnello, the son-in-law of John J. Gotti, the imprisoned Gambino family boss, pleaded guilty yesterday to federal racketeering and tax charges. Mr. Agnello, 41, was indicted in January 2000 on charges of using arson and other strong-arm tactics to take control of the Queens scrap-metal industry. Under his plea bargain with federal prosecutors, Mr. Agnello will serve nine years in prison and forfeit $10 million in illegal profits. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: U.S. Pilots Fight Coca in Colombia
description: He was flying just above the tree line, moments after spraying herbicide on a patch of coca, when the machine-gun fire hit. Eight bullets, probably fired by leftist rebels or drug traffickers, struck the fuselage and tail, knocking out the radio as the cockpit filled with smoke.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Avon-By-The-Sea: Water Standards Criticized
description: In a three-year study of wastewater off the Jersey Shore, an environmental group, Clean Ocean Action, said it had found few or no government standards for toxins, and careless record-keeping by the state. Standards to protect marine life do not exist for 72 percent of the 124 potential wastewater toxins recognized by the Department of Environmental Protection, the study found. Bob Tudor, a deputy environmental commissioner, said the state does not assess ''toxin by toxin'' but uses a ''collective assessment'' that complies with federal guidelines. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: Prison Superintendent Demoted for Posting Bulletin-Board Insults
description: The superintendent of New York State's newest maximum-security prison was demoted on Wednesday after he posted a memo calling a corrections officer a ''poster child for birth control pills'' and challenging him to a fistfight in a parking lot.

title: Testing the Waters at a Gay Dealership
description: DENNIS LYNCH and his partner, Philip Hinkenach, needed a car but dreaded the buying process. Then Mr. Lynch saw an advertisement in a local gay magazine, Frontiers, announcing that Beverly Hills Ford had set up a showroom and lot on Olympic Boulevard with an all-gay sales staff.

title: In a Diverse District, Candidates Stress Experience
description: In a section of western Queens with new immigrants, severely overcrowded schools and an unusual mix of manufacturing and residential neighborhoods, the race for a City Council seat is brimming with candidates who praise their experience and say they have no need for on-the-job training.

title: U.S. Consumer Prices Decline At Steepest Rate Since 1986
description: The prices that American consumers paid for goods and services fell in July at the steepest rate in 15 years as gasoline prices plummeted, the Labor Department said yesterday.

title: Shadowy Rebel Assures Macedonia That He Seeks Peace
description: Few people know the sound of his voice, or even what Ali Ahmeti looks like. He almost defines the idea of the shadowy guerrilla leader, a pale, graying dissident who today smoked one cigarette after another and, in a very quiet voice, sought to assure Macedonians that if peace comes, they will see he is a man to be trusted.

title: Madugahawatte Journal; As Sri Lanka War Brings Ruin, Villages Live Off It
description: In this lush and placid village, no mortar fire disturbs the breezy nights, and only stars and a plump moon light up the sky. Trees are heavy with bananas, coconuts and jackfruit. But bounteous nature is matched by hard times. Good jobs are so scarce that many poor young men like K. W. Perera have gone to war for a paycheck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, ALAN LOCKHART, JR.
description: CAMPBELL-Alan Lockhart, Jr. Died on Tuesday, August 14 at his home in Falls Village, Connecticut, in his 74th year. He is survived by his sisters Marion C. Strong and Jessie C. Sibert, as well as nephews Edward M. Strong, William C. Strong, William C. Sibert, Jr., Alan C. Sibert, John W. Sibert and niece Jane Colby McManus. A funeral service will be held on Saturday, August 18 at 11AM at Trinity Episcopal Church, 484 Lime Rock Road, Lime Rock, CT. Contributions in Alan's memory may be made to Trinity Episcopal Church, Lakeville, CT 06039 or the Salisbury Visiting Nurse Association, Box 645, Salisbury CT 06068.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Autodesk Profit Slips 7.6%
description: The engineering design software maker Autodesk said fiscal second-quarter profit declined 7.6 percent, to $19.2 million, or 34 cents a share, from $20.8 million, or 35 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the period ended July 31 fell to $231.4 million from $232.8 million. The company forecast a third-quarter profit of 32 cents to 42 cents a share, excluding certain costs, on sales of $225 million to $235 million. Autodesk was expected to earn 45 cents on sales of $243 million. The company lowered its forecast for annual revenue about 3 percent, saying sales will be $970 million to $990 million. Sales last year were $936 million.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sanctioned For Marriage Plan
description: As conflict-of-interest sanctions go, this was perhaps the most bizarre in years. The Conflicts of Interest Board said yesterday that it had suspended and demoted an official, Milton Moran, for using his position to solicit a subordinate to marry his daughter and bring her from Ecuador so she could obtain legal status. Mr. Moran is the assistant chief of the Parking Control Division of the Department of Transportation. He was given a 30-day suspension without pay, demoted to a lower-paying job and forced to forfeit $2,500 of accrued leave time. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: A Month in Macedonia Will Not Be Enough
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization expects to send some 3,500 troops to Macedonia in the next few weeks to collect rebel weapons. This decision, which is scheduled to be made today, is meant to signal that NATO is serious about its commitment to the region.

title: Arbitrator Gives Devils' Sykora a 389 Percent Pay Raise
description: Right wing Petr Sykora of the Devils was awarded $3.3 million for this season and $3.5 million for next season by the arbitrator Michel Picher yesterday. But even though the award was closer to the $2.55 million the Devils had offered Sykora for next season than the $4.4 million Sykora had sought, Sykora was extremely happy with the news.

title: Balloonist Lands in Brazil, Ending Bid to Circle Globe
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 17  An attempt by the millionaire adventurer Steve Fossett to become the first person to travel around the world solo in a balloon came to an abrupt end early today when bad weather ahead of him forced him to land in a cow pasture near Brazil's southern border.

title: Is the Camera's Thrill Gone? Well, It's Trying to Liven Up
description: Watching a video of a fingertip slowly, slowly erasing a wet inky alphabet, letter by letter, on a glass plate, I wondered about the future of photography. The finger approached the glass from above like some strange damp worm, then landed softly and pressed, its whorls smearing and getting smeared with wet ink. It was mesmerizing. Can anything in photography compete with this?

title: Testing Our Ability to Fix Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Military Prepares to Join Fight Against Western Fires
description: With more than half a million acres ablaze across the West, fire management officials began calling in reinforcements today from the military.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Schools Sue Education Chief
description: A statewide consortium of 28 secondary schools filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Albany yesterday to block State Education Commissioner Richard P. Mills's policy on alternatives to the Regents examinations. In April, Mr. Mills decided to stop the practice of using end-of-year projects as alternatives to the Regents exams required for high school graduation. Mr. Mills cited concerns about nonuniform grading patterns at schools that use such assessments. But the schools contend his decision was arbitrary. Richard Davis, a lawyer for the schools, said, ''Normally one makes changes in schools that are failing, but Commissioner Mills is attacking schools that are highly successful.'' Lynette Holloway (NYT)
