description: Hannibal

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Maggie Burrows, St. Regis Hotel, Los Angeles, April 28, 2001

title: Report Finds Bias Against Religious Groups
description: Federal agencies refuse to give money to religious groups for their charitable works despite recent laws that allow the organizations to compete for federal grants, a White House survey released today says.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGRIST, FLORENCE
description: ANGRIST-Florence. Seventy-seven, of Lake Worth, FL. passed away on August 7, 2001. After fiftyone wonderful years of marriage, she remains adored by her husband Jack, a retired Deputy Chief of the New York City Police Department. Survived by devoted and supportive daughter Karen Voigt and son Richard, a physician. Cherished by affectionate grandchildren Kimberly, Kerri, Andrew and Brett. Held in highest respect by sister Shirley, son-in-law Emil and sister-in-law Ethel. Sublimely honored as an illustrious leader in the local community and as an esteemed President of the local Board of Governors. An acclaimed member of the Executive Board of Temple Beth Tikvah in Greenacres, FL and the Executive Board of Sisterhood. Florence was designated ''Woman of the Year'' in 1997-1998 by Sisterhood.

title: Waite at Home in Unfamilar Territory
description: Before today's unexpected events, Grant Waite's previous trips to the P.G.A. Championship had been short and sour.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend last Friday about Debussy recordings misstated Victoria de los Angeles's performance history in the role of Mlisande in the opera ''Pellas et Mlisande.'' She has indeed performed it onstage, at the Metropolitan Opera and elsewhere.

title: Regional Tensions Thwart Egypt's Hopes for Gas Sales
description: Egypt knows that it has plenty of natural gas, much more than it can use. And it has ambitious plans to earn badly needed hard currency by exporting gas. But it is having trouble turning those ambitions into reality; regional tensions stand between Egypt and its most promising customers.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 6.

title: Jeter's Odd Spin Leaves Some Yankees Dizzy
description: Derek Jeter was the middle man in a fourth-inning double play yesterday, taking a throw a little wide to his left from second baseman Alfonso Soriano, kicking the bag with his right foot, everything routine to that point. Then Jeter whirled 270 degrees and threw to first base to complete the play.

title: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Peace Group Alleges Pressure
description: A spokesman for a delegation of 311 South Korean peace activists, Lee Soo Un, said North Korean officials had pressed them to attend ceremonies at a new monument in Pyongyang dedicated to Korean reunification on terms not acceptable to the South. A third of the group attended the opening ceremony, on Wednesday, the 56th anniversary of the end of Japanese colonial rule on the Peninsula, according to South Korean newspaper reports. South Korean officials ordered those going to Pyongyang not to appear to endorse the North's position by visiting the monument. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the teachers' union endorsement of Alan G. Hevesi in the New York Democratic primary for mayor misspelled the surname of the spokesman for an opponent, Mark Green, who cited other unions' backing of Mr. Green. He is Joseph DePlasco, not DiPlasco.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I don't want people to see us as an 800-pound gorilla.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALL, KEVIN (SKY)
description: HALL-Kevin (Sky). Age 41. Loving husband of Sharie Hall. Beloved father of Skyler Marie and Kolby Taylor Hall. Dear son of Sonny and Maureen Hall. Fond nephew of Robert A. Hall, and Alice Hall. Family will receive friends Thursday and Friday from 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at The Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial, Saint Margaret of Cortona R.C. Church (6000 Riverdale Avenue, West 260 Street, Bronx), on Saturday August 18th at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations please to: Kevin Sky Hall Memorial Fund for his children Skyler Marie, 2-1/2 yrs, and Kolby Taylor Hall, 7 months: C/O Andrew Williams, 5628 Broadway at 232 Street, Bronx, NY 10463-5599.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility's Profit Up
description: Europe's No. 2 power company, E.ON A.G., said its first-half operating profit rose 52 percent, as cost reductions raised energy earnings for the first time since the German electricity market was opened to competition in 1998. Profit before taxes and including interest income rose to 1.96 billion euros ($1.8 billion) from 1.29 billion euros a year earlier, E.ON said. Net income fell 74 percent from a year earlier, when the company reported gains of 4.3 billion euros from the sale of assets.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: S.& P. DROPS POLAROID'S BOND RATING TO LOWEST LEVEL
description: Polaroid's bond rating was cut to the lowest level by Standard & Poor's after the company defaulted on $15.8 million in interest payments on Wednesday. The rating on $275 million in senior unsecured bonds was lowered to D, Standard & Poor's said. Polaroid defaulted on $11 million in interest payments on its two other notes last month so it could reorganize finances. Last week, the company, based in Cambridge, Mass., won a one-month extension of waivers on loan violations and $10 million in additional financing, as it seeks to avert a bankruptcy filing. Polaroid has lost money three quarters in a row.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Russian Sea Captain Arrested
description: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police have arrested the captain of a Russian tanker and two crew members and charged them with ramming an American fishing boat on Aug. 5, killing three men on board. A Newfoundland judge set bail at $9,500 (U.S.) each, pending extradition to the United States, where they are expected to be charged with manslaughter. Investigators suspect the tanker hit and sank the Starbound, a trawler from Maine, off Massachusetts. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STATTER, HUMPHREY
description: STATTER-Humphrey. Died on Tuesday, August 14, 2001 in Greenwich, CT at the age of 93. He was born in Sioux City, IA, and graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Harvard College, and Harvard Law School. During W.W. II, he served as a Lieutenant Commander in the U.S. Navy. Until his retirement, he was in private law practice in NYC. He served as President and a Trustee of the Huguenot Society of America, and was a member of the Union Club, the St. Nicholas Society, and the Sons of the Revolution. His wife, Julia Brokaw Statter, died in 1998. Surviving are his daughter, Phyllis Statter Oxman, of Greenwich, CT, his son, Humphrey Statter III, of Melbourne, Australia, his grandchildren, Elena Grear Oxman and Lee Warren Oxman, his nephew, Fairfield Pope Day III, and his niece, Stella Day Parsons. Funeral services are private.

title: School Plan: Basic Change
description: For weeks, as Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy prepared a long-awaited restructuring of the Board of Education's central administration, the focus of both the chancellor's supporters and his critics was on how many jobs would be cut and how much money saved.

title: Fast-Food Toys
description: To the Editor:

title: F.A.A. Says More Training Could Reduce Wiring Flaws
description: Wiring problems on old planes, recognized as a hazard since the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 five years ago, are caused not by natural decay but by clumsy maintenance, bad equipment design and improper installation, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: Yankees Await the Best After Sweeping the Worst
description: It has been three months since the Yankees played Seattle, and they are only vaguely aware of the Mariners' merciless assault on the American League. Just as New Yorkers might be dull to a snippet about Oregon wildfires, the omnipresent stories of the Seattle greatness haven't really made an impression on the Yankees. ''Are they ahead of our pace in '98?'' Paul O'Neill asked the other day.

title: On an Island That's Worth Remembering
description: Whenever I tell anyone I was born and raised in the city's so-called forgotten borough, the reaction is always the same: disbelief, sometimes tinged with a bit of disdain. ''Staten Island? You must be kidding.'' As if the only thing out there was the Fresh Kills landfill and now that it has closed, the borough has nothing left to redeem it.

title: For Peace in Macedonia
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CENSUS: Economics; Mixed Findings on Poverty in Survey of Bronx
description: The economic boom that changed the face of New York City in the 1990's appears to have had no impact on the median income of families in the city's poorest borough, according to the results of an experimental Census Bureau survey of Bronx households released yesterday.

title: Industry Standard Says It Will Cease Publication
description: The Industry Standard, a magazine that rose with the dot-com boom it was founded to chronicle but suffered when the bubble burst, has published its last issue barring a last-minute rescue by some unexpected savior, according to a statement released yesterday.

title: Mall in Tucson Is Sold
description: General Growth Properties Inc., the second-largest shopping-mall owner in the nation, said it had bought the Tucson Mall in Tucson for $180 million, giving the company two properties in the city. Major tenants of the 1.3 million-square-foot mall include Macy's, Robinson-May, Dillard's, Mervyn's, J. C. Penney and Sears. The mall was built in 1981 and expanded in 1991. The purchase is expected to add $15 million to net operating income in 2002, the company said. Net operating income for General Growth, based in Chicago, was $330 million in the first half of the year.

title: Sports of The Times; Double D Dominates Royal Threesome at the P.G.A. Championship
description: WHEN he opened with three straight birdies yesterday, a voice in his gallery yelled: ''Nice start, David. Keep it up.'' Later in his round, another voice shouted, ''Double D, you can do it.''

title: How Stem Cells Mix With Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Amnesty For Housing Scofflaws
description: Residents of public housing who have concealed their actual income in order to live in reduced-rent apartments will have 90 days to confess, pay up and avoid arrest. Beginning Sept. 1, the New York City Housing Authority will give amnesty to those who admit to this practice; those who don't will face criminal charges. In the last four months, the Department of Investigation has arrested 22 public housing residents on fraud charges. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about cutbacks in service by Midway Airlines included one destination erroneously among those scheduled to be eliminated. While Midway is ending service to Dulles International Airport outside Washington, it will continue to fly to Ronald Reagan National Airport.

title: Elin's Symbolism
description: To the Editor:

title: Floyd Spence, South Carolina Congressman, Dies at 73
description: Representative Floyd D. Spence, a South Carolina Republican who was chairman of the House Armed Services Committee until earlier this year and used the post to call for a larger military budget and a national missile-defense program, died today at a hospital in Jackson, Miss., after emergency brain surgery. He was 73.

title: Reckonings; Enron Goes Overboard
description: Whom the gods would destroy, they first put on the cover of Business Week. When the Feb. 12 issue featured a cover photo of Jeffrey Skilling, you knew bad things were about to happen both to Enron and to its new C.E.O. Sure enough, on Tuesday Mr. Skilling resigned for ''personal reasons.'' The next day he conceded that the most important of those personal reasons was the 50 percent drop in Enron's stock since January.

title: Northrop Grumman Hires New Agency
description: Northrop Grumman said yesterday that it had named the Los Angeles office of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its creative and media account. Spending was estimated at $7.5 million.

title: And Who Knew That Shakespeare Was a Southern Author?
description: If any contemporary American actor was born to play the melancholy Dane in Shakespeare's ''Hamlet,'' it is Campbell Scott, who conveys a smoldering intelligence softened by a residual tenderness. These qualities are embodied not only in Mr. Campbell's haunted eyes and sunken lips but also in a rich musical voice whose oratorical roll enfolds many quivering notes, including several shades of hysteria.

title: An Inspector Who Kicks While His Sidekick Talks
description: Rush Hour 2

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Plea For Sales Tax Increase
description: In a statewide television address, Gov. Mike Easley urged the public to accept his plan for a one-cent sales tax increase to balance the state budget. In recent weeks, Mr. Easley has warned that the state's fiscal condition is direr than it has been in decades, and presenting the tax plan as an alternative to sharp education cuts and other reductions in state services. Republican legislators, on the other hand, have said that a weakening economy is the wrong time to raise taxes, and have called for budget cuts. David Firestone (NYT)

title: Martin Starts, and Jordan Relieves
description: LaMont Jordan knows this much about Jets history: everyone talks about giving Curtis Martin a break, but not much actually gets done about it.

title: Residential Real Estate; Despite Good Market, Mortgage Problems Inch Up
description: Even as the real estate market remains strong in the New York metropolitan region and across the country -- in fact, national sales of existing homes are on track to make this year the second-best year ever, surpassing last year -- some housing observers point to a hairline fracture in the foundation: mortgage delinquencies and foreclosure rates have risen slightly.

title: Corrections
description: A profile on Tuesday about Huell Howser, a public television personality who chronicles life in California, misidentified the town where he interviewed Lee Iacocca, the former Chrysler chairman, about electric vehicles. It was Desert Hot Springs, Calif., not Palm Desert.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Bank's Co-Chief Steps Down
description: Banco Santander Central Hispano S.A. said one of two co-chairmen, Jos Maria Amusategui, resigned, capping a months-long dispute with the other co-chairman, Emilio Botin, left, over sharing power at the bank, the biggest in Spain. Mr. Amusategui, 69, also stepped down as chairman of the executive committee and as a director at a special board meeting, the bank said in a note to securities regulators. Mr. Botin, 66, becomes the unrivaled chief of a bank with $325 billion in assets in Europe and Latin America, with a freer hand to cut costs.

title: Hewlett-Packard Profit Falls but Beats Wall St. Estimates
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company reported fiscal third-quarter earnings today that fell 78 percent from the period last year, as the company, a computer industry bellwether, continues to struggle with a slowing worldwide economy.

description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

description: Stuart Appleby held a tearful news conference at the 1998 P.G.A. Championship, making his first public comments after the death of his wife, Renay, who was killed that summer when struck by a car.

title: Officer Reaffirms His Louima Testimony
description: Sgt. Eric Turetzky, the Brooklyn police officer whose eyewitness testimony essentially sent Charles Schwarz to prison for playing a role in the torture of Abner Louima, stood unwaveringly by his story yesterday during a remarkably brief but critical turn on the witness stand.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Wesley Hall was named Web applications developer at Archer/Malmo, Memphis. He had been a computer consultant. Also, Mark Miller was named art director at Archer/Malmo. He had been art director at the Rutland Group, Memphis.

title: Hello, Darkness
description: Winston Churchill led a double life during the last few decades of the 20th century -- or rather his life was being told in tandem. While Sir Martin Gilbert was writing the ''official'' Churchill biography in eight volumes, a task that began in 1966 and ended in 1988, William Manchester was working on a three-volume biography of the same man. Both authors welcomed the kinship between their books. If the more popular biography -- Mr. Manchester's -- depended on research done by Sir Martin, it also sent many readers to the more scholarly work.

title: New Judge to Preside in Retrial Of '98 Internet Sex Abuse Case
description: A judge who was sharply criticized for the way he handled the case of a Columbia University student charged with sexual torture said yesterday that he would not be available to handle a retrial of the case.

title: Corrections
description: Areport in the World Briefing column on Tuesday about a decision by Canada to prohibit tobacco companies from using the words "light" and "mild" in marketing cigarettes misstated the title of Allan Rock, who imposed the ban. He is Canada's health minister, not a commissioner.

title: UNITED PARCEL SAYS ITS CHIEF WILL RETIRE AT END OF YEAR
description: United Parcel Service said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, James P. Kelly, would retire at the end of the year. Mr. Kelly will be succeeded by the vice chairman, Michael L. Eskew, who will become chairman and chief executive on Jan. 1, the company said. Mr. Kelly, 58, became chairman and chief executive in January 1997. During his tenure, he oversaw United Parcel's initial sale of stock to the public in 1999 and broadened the company's range of services to include those that oversee and manage inventory and distribution and that provide loans. He also pushed the company to expand overseas.

title: After 90 Days, Sharpton Is Released From Prison
description: Aslimmer and bearded Rev. Al Sharpton was released from a federal prison in Brooklyn today after serving 90 days for trespassing on Navy property in protests over bombing exercises on Vieques, Puerto Rico.

title: Slave Traders in Yale's Past Fuel Debate on Restitution
description: As it marks its 300th anniversary, Yale University is celebrating what it calls its "long history of activism in the face of slavery"  the abolitionist faculty members who befriended the slaves on the ship Amistad in 1839, and today, the world's first center for the study of slavery.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Wild Booze and Drugs Make Hard Lives Harder
description: Why is it that even the most high-minded films have tended to romanticize acute alcoholism? Is it the very nature of movies to glamorize such extreme behavior? Even the much-admired ''Leaving Las Vegas,'' whose central character drinks himself to death, invests its suicidal protagonist with the heroic aura of a sacrificial victim whose flame burns a little more brightly than everyone else's. That 1995 movie was only the latest manifestation of what might be called the ''Under the Volcano'' syndrome (from Malcolm Lowry's autobiographical novel), in which marathon boozing assumes a Wagnerian grandiosity.

title: Utah, in Poll, Backs Stem Cell Money
description: Ever since Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah expressed support for federal financing of human stem cell research, some of his strongest backers, conservative Republicans, have been accusing him of betrayal.

title: Hobbling New Jersey's Campaign Law
description: New Jersey is no stranger to campaign spending excesses, having endured Jon Corzine's record-shattering Senate run last year. But the situation has been better when it comes to races for governor. For the past two decades, these have operated under a public financing law that was reasonably successful in keeping spending and donations under control. That restraint has regrettably been weakened just in time for this year's gubernatorial race.

title: Loose Construction Scaffold Stops Traffic Near Times Sq.
description: A wobbly elevator scaffold at the 45-story Westin hotel under construction in Times Square brought traffic to a halt yesterday afternoon as safety officials closed a blocklong stretch of West 43rd Street for about five hours.

title: Court Denies Microsoft's Bid to Delay Antitrust Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 — A Federal appeals court today rejected the effort by the Microsoft Corporation ( news/quote ) to delay the landmark antitrust case against it, setting the stage for the selection of a new trial court judge soon to consider the appropriate penalties against the software maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELTMAN, SUSAN
description: FELTMAN-Susan. On August 15, 2001. Loving daughter of the late Dr. James A. Feltman & Priscilla Savage Feltman. Ms. Feltman was an accomplished stage actress who also pursued a career as a nurse and healthcare consultant. She was respected and admired by her friends and colleagues for her warmth, loyalty and humor. Ms. Feltman lived and died with dignity and courage. She is survived by her brothers William Ross and Richard Andrews, her niece Julie and her nephew Wil Hopkins. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street today 5-9PM with funeral service on Saturday, August 18 at 9:30AM followed by burial at Flushing Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to ''The Actors Fund of America'', 729 7th Avenue, New York, New York 10019.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: AUDIT OF DRIVING TEACHERS New York driving instructors should not be permitted to teach driving, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall said in an audit released yesterday, blaming the Department of Motor Vehicles for poor oversight. The department can deny an instructor's certificate to someone with a criminal history, but it does not have access to the state's database of criminal records, the audit found. In 50 driving schools, Mr. McCall's office found that 14 instructors had criminal convictions. It also found that instructors who had their licenses suspended or revoked should not have been allowed to hold certificates. In addition, the audit said, the D.M.V. did not keep required information on the schools' insurance and vehicle registrations. Joe Picchi, a department spokesman, said that the audit reviewed practices more than a year ago and that many of the problems had already been addressed.    Richard Pérez-Peña (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JOHNSON ELECTRIC HOLDINGS, Troy, Mich., the second-largest maker of small electric motors, will acquire the electric seat business from ArvinMeritor's light vehicle systems unit for $11.7 million.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Flower Company Earnings Up
description: The flower company 1-800-Flowers.com, based in Westbury, N.Y., surprised Wall Street by reporting a quarterly net income of $226,000, compared with a $12.9 million net loss during the same period last year. The company said that strong Mother's Day sales this year and the addition of nonfloral gifts with higher profit margins led to record quarterly revenues of $132.3 million. Layoffs and the sale of a wholesale business decreased expenses, company officials said. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Shift in Battle at Computer Associates
description: Sam Wyly, the Texas billionaire, will no longer seek to become chairman of Computer Associates International, changing course after management won the support of two shareholder-rights groups.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARNETT, HENRY L., M.D.
description: BARNETT-Henry L., M.D. The Division of Pediatric Nephrology of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine records with deep sorrow the passing of our mentor, colleague and friend. His leadership led to the establishment of pediatric nephrology in this country and abroad, and to the creation of the International Study of Kidney Diseases in Children. He was rightly considered the father of pediatric nephrology. His research and teaching resulted in the improvement of the quality of life for children everywhere. He will surely be missed. Chester Edelmann, Jr., M.D. Ira Greifer, M.D. Adrian Spitzer, M.D. Frederick J. Kaskel, M.D., Ph.D.

title: Waiting for What's-His-Name, Mr. Right
description: Sex is an important part of Jezebel's life, but it doesn't always go well. Through a personals ad, she meets a talky forensic anthropologist and feels compelled to tell him, ''When you hold me and kiss me, I feel sick.'' Another man explains, ''You see, the thing is, I've looked into my soul and it's just emptiness.'' At a bar, she meets a man who compares his genitalia to ''a small child calling out to be hugged.''

title: Brunei: From Oil Rich to Garage Sales
description: It might seem hard to fritter away $15 billion, but apparently with a little perseverance, there's nothing to it.

title: Unlimited Spending on Schundler Worries Democrats in New Jersey
description: New Jersey Democrats said today that they would sue to stop Bret D. Schundler from capitalizing on an election law ruling that experts say could explode the state's system of publicly financed governor's races and dramatically alter the monetary balance of power in Mr. Schundler's campaign against James E. McGreevey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TITONE, REV. ROBERT A.
description: TITONE-Rev. Robert A. The Diocese of Brooklyn announces the death of a priest of the Diocese on August 14th, 2001. Reposing at Frederick Funeral Home, 192-15 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY, on Friday, August 17, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Gabriel Church, 26-26 98th St., East Elmhurst, NY on Saturday, August 18 at 10:30 AM. Priests are invited to concelebrate. He was a member of the Priests' Purgatorial Society. Most Rev. Thomas V. Daily Bishop of Brooklyn

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about research on embryonic stem cells referred incorrectly to the contract used by owners of stem cell colonies to impose restrictions on researchers. It is a material transfer agreement, not a memorandum of transfer agreement.

title: No Letup In a Lion Kingdom
description: SAMUEL E. WRIGHT has lions in his dressing room. Stuffed lions, carved lions, painted lions. Lions hanging from the lights, climbing up the mirror, pawing across the makeup table. He has collected them over the last four years. In addition to the white painted dots he dabs onto his face and the corset made of sea-grass rope and copper and brass beads that he squeezes into, the lions help make possible Mr. Wright's nightly transformation from a man into Mufasa.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Toddler Dies From Heat
description: A toddler left inside a car on a hot day died at a local hospital yesterday, apparently of heatstroke, the police said. While the medical examiner has classified the death as a homicide, it is up to the district attorney to file charges. Rafael Nunez, 2, had been left inside his mother's minivan last Friday for 30 minutes, with the outside temperature above 80 degrees, the police said. The boy's mother, Maria Nunez, who has four other children, had asked an older child to make sure everyone was out of the van while she carried groceries to her East New York apartment. But the police said that the older child had forgotten Rafael. Richard Lezin Jones(NYT)

description: NEW YORK

title: Japan's Budget Deficit Has Soared. It's Time for a Tax Cut.
description: NEARLY two decades ago, when almost everyone knew that Japan's all-powerful economic machine was vastly superior to ours, Russell Baker offered a modest proposal in these pages: In return for Japan's sending cars to us, we should export our lawyers.

title: Ventura's Cost to Mets Delays Deal With Yanks
description: The Mets want to contend next year, but unless they are able to move expensive players off their underachieving roster, they may be unable to afford it. Getting better will cost money, and trading third baseman Robin Ventura would free significant payroll.

title: When All Roads Lead to Wall Street
description: Get thee glass eyes,'' King Lear says to Gloucester, ''and like a scurvy politician, seem to see the things thou dost not.''

title: Leaving Las Vegas, Haste Makes Waste
description: Maybe the funniest moment in ''Rat Race'' comes when Gloria Allred -- that's right, Gloria Allred the lawyer -- turns up in a cameo to help a potential client file a lawsuit. She freezes in front of the camera, immobilized as if just stunned by a taser: she delivers her line, ''I'm a lawyer,'' with the English-as-a-second-language precision of Abba. Other parts of ''Rat Race'' are intermittently funny, possibly because ''Rat Race'' is so nonchalant about bad taste (unlike ''It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World,'' its closest ancestor).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACK, LAURETTA D.
description: SACK-Lauretta D. At age 85. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Devoted mother of Kenneth, David, Michael and Daniel. Adored mother-in-law of Robin, Suzanne andSandi. Loving sister of Larry Dorn. Cherished grandmother of Darren, Jeffrey, Elizabeth, Allison, Jennifer, Jacob, Myra and Leah. Services Friday 1PM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: 'Boy' by Rockwell Back in Coke's Den
description: A Norman Rockwell painting, missing for 70 years, has been discovered -- and purchased by the Coca-Cola Company for an undisclosed amount. The painting, ''The Barefoot Boy,'' which was made for a Coca-Cola calendar of 1931, was owned by a retired executive of a printing company. He had obtained it from the firm that produced the original calendar.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Leader Opposes Nuclear Shipments
description: State Attorney General Charlie Condon says he will sue the Bush administration to stop plutonium shipments planned for mid-October from Rocky Flats, Colo., to the Savannah River Site, a nuclear processing and disposal complex near Aiken. Mr. Condon said he agreed with Gov. Jim Hodges, a Democrat, that ''we will not allow South Carolina to be turned into a nuclear dumping ground.'' Mr. Condon is seeking the Republican nomination in next year's governor's race. Mr. Hodges has threatened to block the plutonium shipments at the state's borders. He says he fears that federal authorities intend to make the state the de facto permanent storage site.

title: PATAKI SUES, VYING WITH LEGISLATURE ON ALBANY BUDGET
description: Gov. George E. Pataki filed a suit against the State Legislature today, setting the stage for a constitutional showdown in court that lawyers for both sides say could forever change how state budgets are adopted.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Norwood: Tracing A Human Skeleton
description: A nearly intact human skeleton accidentally uncovered in a suburban backyard is ''many, many years old,'' the police said yesterday. Nonetheless, Bergen County prosecutors are treating the death as suspicious and are teaming up with police forensic anthropologists to determine the age and sex of the skeleton, as well as checking land records to trace ownership of the property. On Tuesday, workers building a deck found a human skull, and later the skeleton and several crude, handmade nails. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: After a Lifetime, a First Love's Reprise
description: It's not often that movies deal with the aftermath of a romance and the ache that unfulfilled dreams can leave so many years later. And when the minor-key soap opera ''Innocence'' is honest in trying to look at love that won't fade and its relationship to undiminished hope, the film is like the great scene in ''Citizen Kane'' in which Everett Sloane talks about a beautiful girl who caught his attention decades earlier. ''Not a day goes by that I don't think of her,'' he says, his voice breaking with longing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCLELLAN, JEANNE E.
description: McLELLAN-Jeanne E. Of Doylestown and formerly of New York City, died August 15, 2001. Relatives and friends are invited to her graveside service on Saturday, August 18th at 2:00 P.M. at the Kensico Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPARKS, MARIE B.
description: SPARKS-Marie B. On August 16th, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Lewis E. Sparks. Loving mother of Alice and Valentine Mateos, James and Margaret Sparks, and Patricia and Claudio Borghesan. Dear sister of Dorothy Smith. Also survived by 7 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren. Retired principal of P.S. 169 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Dr., Rockaway Beach. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Thomas More Church, Monday, at 10 AM. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery. Visiting Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Donations may be made in her memory to the Caffrey-Conroy Learning Center, 33 Beach 209 St., Breezy Point, New York 11697.

title: Rice Becomes a Rocket As Trade Is Approved
description: The Houston Rockets, who had held up the three-team trade involving Glen Rice for four days over concerns about his injured left foot, were satisfied with further medical evaluations and agreed to the trade yesterday while getting extra compensation from the Knicks and the Dallas Mavericks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, HENRIETTA
description: MILSTEIN-Henrietta. The employees of Loring Coat, Inc. wish to express their sincerest sympathy to the Milstein family on the passing of their loving wife, mother and grandmother, Henrietta Milstein. Abraham Fuhr, President

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Power Authority Seeks Rate Increase
description: The Bonneville Power Administration announced a possible 5 percent rate increase for its utility customers, an addition to a 46 percent increase announced in June. The new increase, if adopted, would raise electricity prices to 3.5 to 3.6 cents a kilowatt-hour from 2.4 cents. The administration said the increase was needed because it was losing money after buying electricity at high prices in anticipation of demand and now selling it for much less. A federal project that produces hydroelectric and nuclear power, the administration provides 45 percent of the Northwest's energy. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bank Merger Bid
description: United Overseas Bank said it won support from investors holding 67.5 percent of the shares of its rival, Overseas Union Bank, putting it in line to topple DBS Group Holdings from its standing as Singapore's biggest lender. United Overseas, which is offering 4.02 Singapore dollars and 0.52 of a share for every Overseas Union share, said it would extend its offer until Aug. 31.

title: Mets Beaten By Sheffield, A Player They Rejected
description: The Mets continue to lurch toward the end of their season with a sense of astonishment at exactly how far they have fallen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOUGHTON, DONALD E.
description: HOUGHTON-Donald E., 84. Formerly of Mattituck, Long Island, NY, died Sunday. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he was the widower of Helen Evensen Houghton. He was a retired architect for Ebasco Services, NYC. Memorial services will be held 2:00 PM September 15 in the Mattituck Presbyterian Church, 12605 Main Rd., Mattituck, NY. Memorial contributions to Southold Historical Society, PO Box 1, Southold, New York 11971.

title: Rumsfeld Says Plans for Military Transformation Are Limited
description: Seeking to quiet anger from some uniformed officers and in Congress, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld described his vision of military transformation today as one that may not even challenge current weapons programs or affect more than a ''modest fraction'' of the Pentagon's forces.

title: Is Truth True? Or Beauty? A Couple of Thinkers Go Deep
description: When Rabindranath Tagore and Albert Einstein met for the first time, in Germany in 1930, both had won the Nobel Prize, Tagore for literature in 1913, Einstein for physics in 1921. At the time of that meeting, Dimitri Marianoff, a relative of Einstein, described Tagore as ''the poet with the head of a thinker'' and Einstein as ''the thinker with the head of a poet.'' The conversation, he added, was ''as though two planets were engaged in a chat.''

title: Prosecutors Say Greed Drove Pharmacist to Dilute Drugs
description: In the relatively sedate and step-by-step world of the retail pharmacist, Robert R. Courtney was considered something of a swashbuckler, a wealthy, energetic businessman, adept at catching the next entrepreneurial wave.

title: Standing Up to Vivaldi With an Italian Bag of Tricks
description: Judging from the tide of recent recordings and the offerings at this year's Mostly Mozart Festival, the world of European period instrument bands is tilting toward the south, with the hottest groups no longer coming from England and the Netherlands, but from Italy. One of the newest is the Venice Baroque Orchestra, a group founded in 1997 by Andrea Marcon, who conducts it from the harpsichord. It is, not surprisingly, a youthful group that plays zestily and with a tightly drilled ensemble. And in the spirit of older bands like I Musici, all but its cellists and a lutenist perform standing.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Khmer Rouge Apology
description: Khieu Samphan, a former Khmer Rouge leader who could face trial for atrocities committed between 1975 and 1979, when more than a million Cambodians died, issued an open letter in which he apologized for the loss of life but denied having known what was going on. ''My mistake was that I was too nave and was out of touch with the real situation,'' he said. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Fortune in Hand, Russian Tries to Polish Image
description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, chairman of Yukos, Russia's second-largest oil company, and by some estimates the nation's richest man, says he has seen the light.

title: Henrietta Milstein, 72; Helped to Found Burlington Coat Factory
description: Henrietta Milstein, who bought a clothing factory in Burlington, N.J., with her husband, Monroe, and helped to build it into a chain of retail stores, died yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. She was 72.

title: ACCENTURE PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,500 POSITIONS
description: Accenture, the consulting firm that recently changed its name from Andersen Consulting, said yesterday that it would lay off 1,500 employees, including 1,000 consultants, because of the weak economy and the low rate of employee turnover. Accenture also said that it would expand to Europe and Asia its sabbatical program, which pays consultants 20 percent of their salary and maintains their benefits for 6 to 12 months if they take a leave from the company. The company also said it would defer starting dates for up to 1,000 incoming consultants. The job cuts amount to 2 percent of Accenture's staff of 75,000 and the company said additional cost-cutting measures are possible. Accenture said it would not take a restructuring charge in connection with the cuts.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Mets' loss to the San Diego Padres misstated the score. It was 6-5, not

title: Egypt Seeking U.S. Monitors To Help End Mideast Violence
description: Egypt pressed the Bush administration today to take a more active role in the Middle East and to consider sending American monitors as soon as possible to defuse the violence between Israelis and Palestinians, officials said.

title: Flip Phillips, 86, Saxophone Star With Bands in the Swing Era
description: Flip Phillips, a tenor saxophonist who was one of the last links to the swing era and who gained his greatest fame through his performances in the epic Jazz at the Philharmonic concerts of the 1940's and 50's, died yesterday at a hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 86 and lived in Pompano Beach, Fla.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Appointments At Ericsson
description: The Swed ish phone equipment manufacturer Ericsson named Per-Arne Sandstroem to the newly created position of chief operating officer. The move is intended to lend support to its embattled chief executive, Kurt Hellstrom, whose restructuring moves have failed to reverse mounting losses. Mr. Sandstroem, who heads Ericsson's North American business and will assume his new duties next month, will oversee a reorganization of the company along customer and product divisions. Ericsson also named Einar Lindquist head of its mobile systems division. Mr. Lindquist steered a turnaround at Ericsson's money-losing fixed-line infrastructure business.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Brunei: Here Come The Creditors
description: Prince Jefri Bolkiah, who has squandered billions of dollars of government money in the oil-rich sultanate, told his lawyers in London to accept a legal summons from creditors, allowing civil proceedings to go ahead. The move came one day after a weeklong auction in Brunei that sold off the remnants of his bankrupt development company. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DOBRER, JEAN
description: DOBRER-Jean. June 18, 1954August 18, 2000. Jeannie, you met the world head on with a smile, and the world couldn't help but smile back. We will miss you and love you forever and a day. Mom, Dad and Nina

title: 8 Marine Officers Are Charged In Osprey False-Records Case
description: A two-star general was among eight Marine Corps officers who have been charged with misconduct in the falsification of maintenance records of the V-22 Osprey aircraft, Marine officials said today.

title: F.D.A. Issues a Safety Warning On Imported Jelly Cup Candies
description: The Food and Drug Administration warned consumers yesterday that bite-sized jelly cup candies, popular treats in Asia that have begun to catch on with American children, may pose a choking hazard.

description: To the Editor:

title: FORD TO CURTAIL AUTO PRODUCTION AND CUT 5,000 JOBS
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was eliminating 5,000 salaried jobs in North America and planned to reduce production this fall, the latest signs that the auto industry may no longer be able to prop up the stumbling American economy.

title: Mariah Carey Gives Campers a Treat
description: City youths enjoying the great outdoors at the Fresh Air Fund's Camp Mariah had a surprise visitor this week.

title: Water: Mining a Scarce Resource

title: MARKETING GROUP CREATED TO LIFT ADVERTISING SALES
description: AOL Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had created a marketing group to increase sales of advertising across all of its businesses, including the Internet service America Online and People magazine. The unit, AOL Time Warner Global Marketing Solutions, will be led by Myer Berlow, said a spokeswoman, Wendy Goldberg. Mr. Berlow, 51, is a former president of America Online's worldwide interactive marketing. Cross-marketing agreements may help the company offset the recent decline in advertising growth that has affected many Web sites, television stations and magazines.

title: Once a Savior, It Now Saps Region's Recovery : China's Growth Weighs On Neighboring Countries
description: SINGAPORE  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED August 24, 2001:An article Saturday about the effect of China's economic strength on its Asian neighbors overstated the amount of production that ON Semiconductor Corp. will shift from Malaysia to China. The move will involve only some of ON's operations in Malaysia.

title: Economic Tombstones; The Industry Standard, Unplugged
description: In Silicon Valley, it may well go down as the day the buzz died. On Thursday The Industry Standard magazine, launched three years ago to serve as the ''newsweekly of the Internet economy,'' announced that it would cease publication and may have to seek bankruptcy protection. It is a dizzying reversal of fortune for a publication whose meteoric rise and fall mirrors the euphoric, then harrowing times lived by the dot-com entrepreneurs it covered.

title: The Arrests Of Protesters At a College Stir a Debate
description: The battle at Hostos Community College over possible cutbacks in classes on English as a Second Language and Spanish-language courses erupted this week with the arrest of four students and a professor in separate protests during registration.

title: Fighting Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTHERN UNION OFFERS EARLY-RETIREMENT PROGRAMS
description: The Southern Union Company has offered voluntary early-retirement programs to about 400 workers at its operating divisions, as part of a corporate reorganization and restructuring aimed at increasing cash flow and earnings. The company, which is based in Austin, Tex., and distributes energy, said it had also offered severance packages to 48 corporate employees. Southern Union, which expects to save $35 million to $40 million annually from the actions it completed to date, is decentralizing some corporate management functions and will transfer those functions to its divisions in Texas, Missouri, Pennsylvania and New England.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Governor Admits Lie On Form
description: Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift admitted that she and her husband, Charles T. Hunt III, lied on their marriage application in 1994 when they listed their marriage as the groom's second, when it was his fourth. She said this week that she knew of his three former wives, but had respected his wish to keep his past private. She said they would each pay a $100 fine for the perjury. The lie came to light when Mr. Hunt's son from his first marriage, who is gay, criticized Ms. Swift for her opposition to gay marriage. On the day the criticism became public, Ms. Swift was extending some domestic partnership benefits to gay and lesbian state workers. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: In P.G.A., Long Shots Lead the Long Hitters
description: Asked what he knew about Shingo Katayama, Phil Mickelson said, ''I just know that he wears some funky hats.''

title: Questions About John Negroponte
description: The Senate needs to look closely at the Bush administration's nomination of John Negroponte as America's next representative at the United Nations. With important issues facing the U.N. this fall, it is desirable to confirm a permanent representative without lengthy delay. But before any confirmation, some serious issues concerning Mr. Negroponte's conduct as ambassador to Honduras during Nicaragua's civil war two decades ago need to be fully explored.

title: U.S. Plane's Odd Trip From China
description: The collision on April 1 between a Chinese jet fighter and a Navy surveillance plane bruised relations between the two nations, killed the Chinese pilot and resulted in the 11-day detention of the 24-member American crew.

title: Support Local Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Is Seeking Support To Handle Protests at 2 Meetings
description: City officials said today that federal assistance would be needed to cover security expenses for the meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund scheduled to be held here in six weeks.

title: San Francisco Museum Director Resigns Suddenly
description: David A. Ross, the former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, resigned suddenly yesterday as director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, where he had spent three heady years and $140 million building up the museum's collection of contemporary art.

title: World Briefing
description: ASIA

title: The Old World Under the New
description: Standing on a hot stretch of sand and debris on Staten Island's western shore, Anne-Marie Cantwell fantasized how the bleak landscape of rotting piers and oil tanks might have looked to the Paleo-Indians who camped here 11,000 years ago.

title: Balloonist Calls Off His Global Conquest and Lands in Brazil
description: An American millionaire's fifth attempt to become the first person to complete an around-the-world solo balloon trip came to an abrupt end early today when a prediction of bad weather forced him to land in a cow pasture near Brazil's southern border.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: State Of The Debate
description: Debate season is beginning in earnest. The four major Democratic candidates for mayor will face one another on Tuesday. The debate will be broadcast at 7 p.m. on the cable news station NY1, which is sponsoring the event with The New York Times. The Campaign Finance Board has organized two other debates before the Sept. 11 primary. Voters who tune in to those will become acquainted with George N. Spitz, a long-shot candidate seeking the Democratic nomination. He will get to debate his better-known rivals because he is abiding by the city's campaign finance laws. Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican, is not, so he will not be invited to debate Herman Badillo. The first debate will be held on Aug. 28 and broadcast on television by WPIX-TV Channel 11 at 6 p.m. and on the radio by WNYC-AM (820) at 7 p.m. The second debate will be broadcast live on WABC-TV Channel 7 and WNYC-AM (820) on Sept. 9 at 11 a.m.

title: Sometimes a Beard Changes Everything
description: What is it about hair? Alexander Pope got it right as a sexual symbol in ''The Rape of the Lock.'' A snipped curl came to stand for lost virginity. Facial hair on men is also a powerful symbol. It represents nonconformity, masculinity and unruliness. Bill Clinton has all this without facial hair. George W. Bush has that smirk some women find cute. Al Gore needs a touch of the animal. He has found it in a beard.

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA DROPS ON REPORT OF WEAK DEMAND
description: Shares of Scientific-Atlanta Inc. declined 15 percent after the company, a leading maker of set-top boxes for cable television, withdrew previous earnings and sales forecasts as demand fell. Shares of the company, which is based in Lawrenceville, Ga., fell $3.77, to $21.24, The company said Thursday it could not predict sales for the first fiscal quarter ending in September or for fiscal 2002. It blamed slowing customer growth for digital TV, which uses a set-top box to get hundreds of cable channels. Cable operators are ordering fewer of the devices as economic growth slows and customers spend less.

title: Trade Deficit For the U.S. Grew in June
description: The United States trade deficit widened in June as slower growth abroad and a strengthening dollar pushed exports to their lowest level in 16 months, the government said today.

title: A Conductor and a Cellist Make New York Debuts
description: Much of the Mostly Mozart Festival's drawing power comes from its ability to attract relatively starry conductors, soloists and guest ensembles night after night. But debuts by musicians who are attracting interest elsewhere (meaning, for the most part, in Europe) have also been an important element of the festival, and because Lincoln Center's programming department keeps its ear to the ground, the festival's track record over the years has been good.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLOCK, DR. JAMES D.C.
description: BLOCK-Dr. James D.C. - 6/11/27-8/18/2000. Every year, on this day, I will give you an embrace so tight that your hands will slap the waves of the waters where you are now resting. My Beloved. Tita

title: National Briefing | Plains: South Dakota: Gay Group Wins Fight For Sign
description: Gov. William J. Janklow announced that the state would put up a sign requested by the Sioux Empire Gay and Lesbian Coalition as part of the state's Adopt-a-Highway program. The group filed suit in federal court this week after the State Department of Transportation refused to allow the sign because the coalition is considered an advocacy group. The group had volunteered to pick up litter along a section of state Highway 38 west of Sioux Falls. Mr. Janklow, a Republican, said all of the signs in the program would be taken down by the end of the year and replaced with generic signs acknowledging that concerned citizens were keeping the roads clean. John W. Fountain (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHATAN, CHAIM F., M.D.
description: SHATAN-Chaim F., M.D. Loving husband of Norma, beloved father of Gregory, Gabrielle, Jessica and Jeremy. Dear father-in-law of Deborah, Seymour and Karen. Adored grandpa and zaide of Nicholas, Max, David, Sarah, Jacob, Hannah and Noah. Services on Sunday, August 19, 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Fires Continue, but Officials See Improvement Over 2000
description: Though it is still early in the Western fire season, federal officials say a bit of luck and the presence of additional firefighters have made a big difference in limiting the number of acres burned to well below that of previous big fire years.

title: Journal; The Genius of George W. Bush
description: After months of deriding the president as an idiot, Democrats have to face the fact that he is at the very least an idiot savant -- and just possibly a genius.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Rejects Microsoft Request for Delay
description: A Federal appeals court today rejected the effort by the Microsoft Corporation to delay the antitrust case against it, setting the stage for the selection of a new trial court judge soon to consider the appropriate penalties against the company.

title: Officials Say Bush's New Stem Cell Policy May Streamline the Research Process
description: Biologists may find there are fewer restrictions on research with embryonic stem cells under the Bush administration than they would have faced under the Clinton administration, whose guidelines have been scrapped, officials at the White House and the National Institutes of Health said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KLAUBER, HILDE
description: KLAUBER-Hilde. Beloved wife of Roger. Devoted mother of Gordon and Rose and Mark and Judy. Cherished grandmother of Norbert, Lily, Joshua & Maya. Loving sister of Bernhard, Elizabeth, Leni, Greta and the late Norbert. Aunt to Melanie, Leslie, Marcus, Stefan, Cornelia and Gabriella. Services Sunday, 12:30 PM at ''RiversideNassau North Chapels'', 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the American Cancer Society would be appreciated.

title: Sports of The Times; Hard Lesson From Negro Leagues
description: THE Seattle Mariners barreled into Yankee Stadium last night for a muscle-flexing series with their old nemesis in the Bronx. Despite losing the first game of the series, 4-0, Seattle is the dazzling story in baseball this season. Here's a team that lost Randy Johnson in 1998, Ken Griffey Jr. before the 2000 season and Alex Rodriguez after the 2000 season. Now the Mariners are on pace to finish with the best record since the 1906 Cubs, who had 116 victories, and the 1998 Yankees, who won 114 games.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''It turned out to be a mine- field of thunderstorms.''

title: Editors' Note; COMING ON SUNDAY
description: GROWING FAMILIES

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: No Headline
description: Prince Albert Taylor Jr., a retired United Methodist bishop who was the first black president of the Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church, died on Wednesday at a hospital in Somers Point, N.J. He was 94 and lived in Ocean City, N.J.

title: Vitech Seeks Relief From Gateway Loans
description: Vitech America Inc. sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection today after a New York court ordered it to pay Gateway Inc. $41 million plus interest for defaulting on loans.

title: Jim Hughes, 78, Relief Pitcher Who Set Dodger Mark for Saves
description: Jim Hughes, a hard-throwing relief pitcher for the Brooklyn Dodgers of the 1950's who set a franchise record for saves that endured for 35 years, died Monday in Worth, Ill. He was 78.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: ''Mike!'' The Musical
description: Michael R. Bloomberg was on stage Monday night at Swing 46 in Midtown, talking to entertainment unions. It is unclear whether he won any votes, but he did win some laughs, particularly when he suggested he might like to have his autobiography, ''Bloomberg by Bloomberg,'' produced on Broadway. ''I'd have to go buy Disney,'' he said. Asked about his acting credentials, Mr. Bloomberg likened himself to the actor Joel Grey, at least when it comes to looks. ''I was once sitting watching 'Cabaret' when Joel Grey was doing it, and I sat down in the balcony, and somebody sat next to me, and they kept looking at me,'' he said. ''And this woman said: 'Excuse me. Aren't you supposed to be on stage?' She thought I was Joel Grey. I thought that was the most flattering thing anybody ever said about Joel Grey.'' Mr. Bloomberg, who has had a reputation for enjoying night life, offered one mayoral-style obfuscation. ''I was not in 'Cabaret,' '' he said. ''At least to the extent that I'm willing to admit it.'' Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about an effort for dismissal of the Connecticut murder charge against Michael Skakel, who is accused of having killed Martha Moxley in 1975, misspelled the surname of the lawyer involved. He is David Grudberg, not Grundberg.

title: Racism Across Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: Shares Fall Broadly on Poor Profit News From Big Names
description: Stocks fell sharply and broadly yesterday, as companies as varied as Dell Computer, Ford Motor and Gap provided Wall Street with further evidence that corporate profits appear unlikely to recover soon.

title: A Little Piece of Los Angeles Is a Wide Open Battleground
description: When the architect Frank O. Gehry signed on recently to design a hip new office park at an immense development here known as Playa Vista, the combatants in a 20-year war over the site finally had something they could agree on. To each side, Mr. Gehry seemed a savior.

title: Head of Religion-Based Initiative Resigns
description: John J. DiIulio Jr., the head of the White House's religion-based initiative office -- and its lone Democrat -- resigned today, raising new concerns about President Bush's signature social issue.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Congressional redistricting referred incorrectly to the census that will cause 8 states to gain seats in the House after next year's election and 10 states to lose them. It is the census of 2000, not 1990.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Advance For Asthma Drug
description: The German drug maker Altana said an asthma and bronchitis medicine had performed well in tests and would move into the final stage of testing, setting off a sharp rally in the company's stock price. The medicine, called Roflumilast, will move into the last of three testing stages for chronic bronchitis, after having shown good results in Phase 3 studies for asthma. The company, which is controlled by the billionaire Quandt family, is developing new products to reduce its dependence on Protonix, an ulcer treatment that accounted for almost one-third of the company's sales last year.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Corsica: Leading Nationalist Killed
description: Franois Santoni, a prominent Corsican nationalist, was shot and killed as he left a wedding. Mr. Santoni, 41, had survived two earlier attempts on his life. He broke with the armed struggle for autonomy for the French Mediterranean island and published a best-selling memoir last year saying the nationalist movement had become corrupted by infighting, money and the cult of violence. His co-author, Jean-Michel Rossi, was shot to death a year ago, shortly after publication of the book. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Hernndez, Feeling Fine, Says His Slider Seems Fine, Too
description: Orlando Hernndez was brought into the manager's office yesterday to talk about his six-inning outing for Class A Staten Island on Thursday, and he assured Yankees Manager Joe Torre and the pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, that he felt great, he felt strong.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Law To Aid Christian Women
description: The cabinet approved the introduction of legislation next week that would give Christian women greater equality with men in pursuing a divorce. A woman would be able to seek a divorce on grounds of adultery, as a man has long been able to do, without proving bigamy, cruelty or incest. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about a Colombian farmer's struggle to gain asylum in the United States referred incorrectly to guards at the Port Isabel Service Processing Center in Los Fresnos, Tex., where he was detained. The guards are unarmed; the Immigration and Naturalization Service says it is against policy to carry a weapon inside the compound.

title: Different Defense Is Planned For Second Trial in Beating
description: The lawyer for the next defendant to go on trial on charges he attacked two Mexican day laborers said that his client will take a very different approach than the first defendant, Christopher Slavin, whose trial culminated Thursday in a conviction.

title: Two Presidents, Alike but . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Done Deal: Lindros Is Coming
description: All that separates Eric Lindros from becoming a Ranger is dotting the i's and crossing the t's on a contract, according to an N.H.L. official.

title: The Bronx All-Stars Remain Carefree
description: The Little League players from the Bronx stared in fear. They had faced fastballs and grouchy umpires and tough coaches, but this was really getting to them.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil fell on expectations of ample inventories as the summer season of peak gasoline demand draws to a close. In New York, September delivery contracts fell 72 cents, or 2.6 percent, to $26.68 a barrel.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Debt Talks
description: The finance minister, Jin Nyum, increased the pressure for a rapid conclusion to negotiations between General Motors and creditors for the bankrupt Daewoo Motor. Mr. Jin said the government could not wait indefinitely, suggesting it would come up with its own solution if the banks fail to reach a deal. On Thursday, Lee Keun Young, chairman of the Financial Supervisory Service, said the government might have to develop a contingency plan for the company. An executive for one of the creditors said there were still many differences and nothing had been settled, according to the semi-official Yonhap News Agency.

title: Two Presidents, Alike but . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Counts on Milbrett's Scoring Touch
description: It is the quickness, speed, ferocious shot and competitiveness that make Tiffeny Milbrett of the Power the most feared player in women's soccer. She enhanced her reputation as the top player in the world this year by winning the scoring title in the Women's United Soccer Association with 16 goals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUMBERG, RUTH ELHASSID
description: BLUMBERG-Ruth Elhassid. Congregation Shearith Israel, the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, mourns the loss of its devoted member and extends its deepest sympathy to her family. Services Sunday 11:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St & Amsterdam Ave. Alvin Deutsch, Parnas

title: Iran Shifts War Against Drugs, Admitting It Has Huge Problem
description: Six addicts were milling around in the corridor of an unusual clinic here, waiting for the start of their third day of treatment, when a young patient suddenly emitted a deep bestial groan and collapsed to the floor, writhing.

title: Water: Mining a Scarce Resource
description: To the Editor:

title: SPRINT TO SELL 16 MILLION SHARES OF EARTHLINK
description: The Sprint Corporation plans to sell 16 million shares of the Internet service provider EarthLink Inc. in a public offering valued at $200 million. The shares, which are being sold at $12.50 each, are part of a stake acquired as part of a 1998 exclusive marketing agreement the companies have since dissolved. Earlier this month, EarthLink doubled the amount of stock that Sprint could sell at any time to 25 million common shares. This year, EarthLink's shares have more than doubled, while Sprint's have increased 13 percent. Sprint will use the proceeds to reduce its debt, a spokesman, Mark Bonavia, said. After the offering, Sprint will have 30 million EarthLink shares, he said.

title: Poor Profit Outlook Sends Stocks Down
description: Stocks fell sharply and broadly as companies as varied as Dell Computer, Ford Motor and Gap provided Wall Street with further evidence that corporate profits appear unlikely to recover soon. Heavy selling in Microsoft also put pressure on the stock market.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Police Chief's Marijuana Proposal
description: The Irish police commissioner, Pat Byrne, said that while decriminalization would not solve the problems caused by marijuana, the government should consider legalizing it for medical use. Eoin Ryan, the cabinet minister with responsibility for drugs policy, said that cannabis-based prescription drugs could be available as soon next year to alleviate the symptoms of terminal diseases. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: 2 Men Shot in Manhattan
description: Two men were shot on a busy section of Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan shortly after 7 p.m. yesterday, the police said. Both were hospitalized in stable condition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANGRIST, FLORENCE
description: ANGRIST-Florence. Seventy-seven, of Lake Worth, FL. passed away on August 7, 2001. After fiftyone wonderful years of marriage, she remains adored by her husband Jack, a retired Deputy Chief of the New York City Police Department. Survived by devoted and supportive daughter Karen Voigt and son Richard, a physician. Cherished by affectionate grandchildren Kimberly, Kerri, Andrew and Brett. Held in highest respect by sister Shirley, son-in-law Emil and sister-in-law Ethel. Sublimely honored as an illustrious leader in the local community and as an esteemed President of the local Board of Governors. An acclaimed member of the Executive Board of Temple Beth Tikvah in Greenacres, FL and the Executive Board of Sisterhood. Florence was designated ''Woman of the Year'' in 1997-1998 by Sisterhood.

title: Hevesi Calls Bribe Claim 'Despicable'
description: Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller and a Democratic candidate for mayor, yesterday defended using his staff to help a campaign contributor obtain a business meeting with Bell Atlantic in 1997, saying that ''we connect businesses all the time -- that's what I do as comptroller.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Advertising Sale
description: Scoot.com, an online directory company that was once high-flying but is now troubled, said it had sold Loot, a classified advertising business, to the newspaper publisher Daily Mail and General Trust for $65 million. This is about one quarter what it paid for Loot a year ago. The sale gave Scoot enough cash to last about six weeks and was seen as an eleventh-hour maneuver to stave off collapse. Shares in the company, which turned down a takeover offer of up to 15 pence a share from Vivendi Universal in April, rose 0.47 pence to 2.9 pence. The company said it was talking to potential buyers.

title: Sotheby's Ex-Chief Previews His Defense
description: Lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's chief shareholder and former chairman, yesterday outlined central elements of the defense he is expected to make against charges that he colluded with a counterpart at Christie's to fix commission rates governing tens of thousands of transactions.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday misidentified an advertising agency that is closing. The remaining offices of Bozell Kamstra are being closed, not those of the Bozell Group. (Bozell Kamstra was part of the Bozell Group within True North Communications before True North was acquired by the Interpublic Group of Companies.)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Governor Rejects Higher Speed Limit
description: Governor John Kitzhaber vetoed a bill that would have raised the state's speed limit on Interstate highways to 70 miles per hour from 65. ''I am unwilling to risk more lives on our Interstate highway system without being able to assure the citizens of Oregon that the speed limit will be adequately enforced,'' said Mr. Kitzhaber, a Democrat. Oregon's speed limit on Interstates is the lowest in the West. All five members of the state's highway safety commission had threatened to resign if Mr. Kitzhaber did not veto the bill. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: College Suspends Professor For Vietnam Fabrications
description: Joseph J. Ellis, the Pulitzer Prize-winning historian who admitted in June that he lied to his students and others when he said he had been a combat soldier in Vietnam, has been suspended for a year without pay by Mount Holyoke, the women's college in western Massachusetts where he has taught since 1972.

title: Court of Appeals Says Hitler Art Belongs to U.S.
description: A federal appeals court in Washington this week supported the government's continued ownership of four watercolors by Adolf Hitler as well as prewar and wartime photographs, some of which featured Hitler and other Nazi higher-ups and were used by prosecutors at the Nuremberg trials.

title: New Jersey Transportation Officials Seek Expansion of 65 M.P.H. Speed Limit
description: New Jersey transportation officials recommended today that speed limits be raised to 65 miles per hour on more sections of Interstates, toll roads and parkways, citing a three-year study that shows no noticeable increase in traffic fatalities on the roads that adopted the higher limits in 1998.

title: TEXAN GETS SOME BACKING IN COMPUTER ASSOCIATES FIGHT
description: Sam Wyly, the Texas billionaire waging a proxy fight for control of Computer Associates International Inc., won a second endorsement after scaling back his plans to oust the software maker's board. The latest endorsement came from Proxy Monitor Inc., which had recommended on Monday that Computer Associates shareholders vote for the slate of directors nominated by management. The group switched its support after Mr. Wyly said on Thursday that he would no longer seek to become chairman and would seek only four seats on the board, instead of all 10. Mr. Wyly won the support of the California Public Employees' Retirement System, which owns 3.1 million Computer Associates shares, on Thursday.

title: Stratton Provides Punch For Mets on the Farm
description: Binghamton's ROBERT STRATTON reacted to the 96-mile-an-hour fastball from Reading pitcher Franklin Nunez by rocketing it over the brick wall in left field and out of GPU Stadium in Reading, Pa., on July 3. The previous player believed to have hit a ball that far in Reading was GREG LUZINSKI in 1971.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, AUDREY
description: ROTHMAN-Audrey. Always in my memories. Forever in my heart. Lorraine

title: Citing Safety Gaps, U.S. Limits Links to Korean Air Carriers
description: The Federal Aviation Administration told South Korea today that its regulation of aviation safety fell short of international standards, and that as a result, Korean carriers flying to the United States would not be allowed to expand their service, use American partners or use airplanes other than those they are now flying.

title: Selection Made for Treasury Dept. Post
description: The Bush administration acted yesterday to fill the last major slot on its economic team by naming Richard H. Clarida, chairman of the economics department at Columbia University, to be assistant secretary of the Treasury for economic policy.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Who Was That Gas-Masked Man?
description: Only at a health care forum can a man show up in a gas mask and be ignored. The forum Tuesday at a City College building in Midtown was attended by all of the major mayoral candidates except Herman Badillo and focused on broad themes like the uninsured. But after most of the candidates had spoken, a man in the audience wearing a gas mask and white jumpsuit demanded to know why Green Party candidates had not been given equal time. ''Not a single major candidate has addressed the issue of pesticide spraying on Staten Island,'' bellowed the guest. ''You're wrong, you're wrong, I certainly have,'' came a response, also from the audience. It was George Spitz (see top item). Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 10 about an interview by The New York Times with President Jiang Zemin of China, and the textual excerpts with it, included an erroneously translated phrase from a Chinese government interpreter in some copies, regarding the spread of local elections. Mr. Jiang should have been quoted as praising direct election of leaders at the village level and the township level; he did not speak of the county level. His reference to townships, however, was apparently a slip; elections have not taken place at that level.

title: National Briefing | South: South Carolina: Suit Over Sauce Boycott
description: A Columbia restaurant owner and barbecue sauce entrepreneur whose products were taken off the shelves of several stores a year ago because of his views on slavery filed a suit against the stores in Lexington County Circuit Court on Thursday. The man, Maurice Bessinger, a former segregationist, has tracts in his restaurant that say that many slaves ''blessed the Lord for allowing them to be enslaved and sent to America.'' Stores have pulled his products, citing concerns about the literature. The suit asserts that the stores are violating fair-trade practices by refusing to sell the products. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Kerik Seeks to Speed Dismissal of Officers Accused of D.W.I.
description: Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said yesterday that he would expedite the dismissal process for a half-dozen officers accused in drunken-driving accidents, including Officer Joseph Gray, the man charged with fatally running down a Brooklyn family after a daylong drinking binge earlier this month.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TAYLOR, FRANCES L
description: TAYLOR-Frances L. Memorial service at St. John's of Lattingtown, Locust Valley, NY, Saturday August 25 at 11 A.M.

title: A Week in London
description: The Web site www.go-today.com hardly sounds like a site that espouses delayed gratification. Except that its packages to London Nov. 1 to Dec. 12 may make it attractive to go later. For example, round-trip air fare to London and a week's rental of a manual-transmission compact car costs $379 a person, based on double occupancy, from New York or Boston (departure taxes and weekend surcharges apply, too). That same deal for departures Sept. 4 to Oct. 25 is $449 a person, double. For those who want to stay put, six nights in an A-category London hotel with daily Continental reakfast, round-trip air fare from New York or Boston, transfers in London and hotel taxes is $449 a person, double, Nov. 1 to Dec. 12 and $599 Sept. 4 to Oct. 25. Information from the Web site or, for those who are somehow able to read this without benefit of Internet access, call (425) 487-9632.

title: The Ad Campaign; Schundler's Cause: Inclusion
description: Bret D. Schundler, the Republican running for governor of New Jersey, has begun running two new television ads -- one 30 seconds long called ''Together'' and one 60 seconds long called ''For the People.'' He is challenging James E. McGreevey, the Democrat. He is spending $200,000 a week so far on television ads, a very small amount.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 10 about an interview by The New York Times with President Jiang Zemin of China, and the textual excerpts with it, included an erroneously translated phrase from a Chinese government interpreter in some copies, regarding the spread of local elections. Mr. Jiang should have been quoted as praising direct election of leaders at the village level and the township level; he did not speak of the county level. His reference to townships, however, was apparently a slip; elections have not taken place at that level.

title: Dollar's Slow Slide Indicates Foreign Investors May Be Wary of U.S.
description: The dollar's slow tumble against the euro continued yesterday and analysts are not sure where it will stop, given the concern that the American economy may not begin to rebound as soon as many had expected. The dollar has also been slipping against the Japanese yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DICK, FREDERICK S.
description: DICK-Frederick S. On August 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Marion and his late wife Ruth. Father to Barbara and Michael. Grandfather to Alexandra, Matthew, Rebekka & Sofia. Born in Toronto, Canada, September 5, 1913. He practiced medicine for 62 years including during his service in the U.S. Army in World War II. He will be missed by all who knew him. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, on Sunday, August 19th at 9:30 A.M. Interment to follow at King David Cemetery, Putnam Valley. The family will be receiving at his home from Sunday, the 19th through Tuesday the 21st. In lieu of flowers please send donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, Melanoma Research, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021.
