title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, HERBERT J.
description: WEISS-Herbert J., Rabbi. On August 15, 2001. Formerly Rabbi of Temple Anshe Emeth of Pine Bluff, Arkansas, and Temple Emanu-El of Sarasota, Florida. Founder of Herbert J. Weiss Associates of New York, a financing consulting firm. Beloved husband of Deborah. Devoted father of David. Services Sunday 10:30 A.M. at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, NYC.

title: MORE DATA SOUGHT ON ZEBRA BID FOR FARGO ELECTRONICS
description: The Zebra Technologies Corporation, a leading maker of bar-code printers, said the Federal Trade Commission had asked for additional information regarding Zebra's planned purchase of Fargo Electronics Inc. for $104 million. Zebra did not specify what information the F.T.C. was seeking. A spokesman, Douglas Fox, said the company might need a couple of weeks to respond to the request. There will be a 10-day waiting period after the F.T.C. receives the information, further delaying the planned purchase.

title: Luxury Fleet Grows Nimble
description: Yachts are no Model-T's. Yet Joseph Brethom heads a team of a dozen workers -- joiners, plumbers, electricians -- who scramble over 30- to 50-foot sailboats as they inch along eight assembly lines in a sprawling factory in this provincial French town six miles from the Atlantic.

title: In Bid for Unity, Black and Hispanic Politicians Make Pledge to Back Ferrer
description: Trying to unite the city's largest minority groups behind a single candidate, a group of mostly black and Latino politicians threw their support yesterday to one Democratic mayoral candidate, Fernando Ferrer.

title: Judge Assails City Agency on Abuse Cases
description: Citing concern that children are being taken from their homes simply because their mothers have been battered, a federal judge said yesterday that he was giving the city's child welfare agency six months to improve the way it handled the removal of children from households where domestic abuse occurred.

title: Israelis and Palestinians Prepare for a Long Struggle
description: As if things were not bad enough for them, many Israelis and Palestinians gulped hard the other day when they read about what Israeli military strategists think may lie ahead. Army planners were said to have estimated that the bitter conflict consuming the two peoples for nearly a year could drag on until 2006.

title: Marty Geltman, 65, Who Held His Funeral in Time to Enjoy It
description: Marty Geltman, an ordinary man who faced death in an extraordinary way, with a living funeral in June attended by 200 family members and friends after learning his cancer was terminal, died at home in West Orange, N.J., on Wednesday. He was 65.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Ford to Cut 5,000 Workers And Reduce Output This Fall

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: 'Toughest Sheriff' Considers New Role
description: Maricopa County's colorful sheriff, Joe Arpaio, is considering a run for governor next year. Sheriff Arpaio, a Republican, has gained attention over the years for making inmates wear pink underwear and installing a live jailhouse Internet camera. Mr. Arpaio, 69, who calls himself ''the toughest sheriff in America,'' cited recent polls in a local newspaper that showed he was almost as popular as former Representative Matt Salmon, who has announced his candidacy. Because he would have to resign as sheriff, Mr. Arpaio said he would make his decision at the last minute. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLIS, NORMAN
description: GILLIS-Norman. Professor emeritus of anesthesiology and pharmacology at Yale University School of Medicine and adjunct professor of medicine at Tufts University School of Medicine, died in Boston at age 68 on August 16, 2001 after a short illness. Recognized nationally as a specialist in pulmonary vascular disease and for his pharmacological work, Professor Gillis published more than 250 scientific articles during his career. He chaired major international symposia focusing on medical issues & served on a number of advisory committees, including the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute and World Health Organization's Expert Committee on Primary Pulmonary Hypertension. Recently, he was appointed to serve on the committee of the National Academies Institute of Medicine. Professor Gillis was an associate editor of the journal ''Biomedical Pharmacology'' and served on the editorial boards of several other journals in his field. Throughout his career, he spoke at meetings and conferences in the United States and other parts of the world. He was a native of Glasgow, Scotland. Beloved husband of 41 years of Bonita (Dalnekoff) Gillis and dear father of Sharon D. Gillis and her husband Thomas J. Phillips of Chestnut Hill, MA, and Steven D. Gillis of McLean, VA. Adored grandfather of Alexandra Phillips and Andrew Phillips. Funeral services Sunday August 19th at 10 o'clock at the Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, 543 George St., New Haven, CT, 203-562-8244. Interment services to follow in the Young Israel Memorial Park, Brockett Pl., East Haven, CT. A private period of mourning will be observed. Remembrances in his name may be made to the Nature Conservancy (Memorial Fund #

title: Editor in Chief Of Variety Is Suspended
description: Peter Bart, the editor in chief of Variety and one of the most powerful journalists in Hollywood, was suspended today because of derogatory comments about blacks, Jews and gays that were attributed to him in a magazine article.

title: Moscow Journal; Red Square Is Suddenly Catching Up With Times
description: Red Square is such a vast affair, a sprawling stretch of windswept cobblestone and towering cathedrals, that it is easy for summer's swarms of tourists to miss its small charms, like the round dais from which czars addressed the masses. No one, on the other hand, will miss the skin cream ad.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARP, H. JACK
description: KARP-H. Jack. On August 15, 2001. Beloved husband of Rose Karp. Loving father of Richard Reed & Dr. Marvin Karp. Adoring grandfather of Stacey & Courtney Karp. Dear brother of Arthur and Milton Karp and the late Samuel Karp, Dr. Lewis Park and Linda Reiss. Funeral service on Sunday, August 19th, 1:30PM at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York.

title: Sports of The Times; O'Meara's 63 Is Truly a Major Achievement
description: IT'S a rare score in golf: 63 in a major. Only Greg Norman has done it twice, in the 1986 British Open, which he won at Turnberry, and in the opening round of the 1996 Masters before his final-round collapse against Nick Faldo.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMARICO, JAMES MICHAEL, MD.
description: POMARICO-James Michael, MD. Age 64, of New York City, died on Wednesday, August 15, 2001 in Presbyterian Hospital, NY. Dr. Pomarico attended the Columbus Boys Choir School in Princeton, NJ in the early stage of the school's development. As a student he traveled throughout the U.S. with the choir as a pianist. He continued his pursuit of music into his adult life and was a longtime member of the Metropolitan Opera Club. Dr. Pomarico gra duated from the University of Pittsburgh with his Bachelor of Science degree, and then furthered his education to receive his medical degree. He interned at St. Vincent's Medical Center of NY, and then became a resident at Mt. Sinai Hospital in NY. After his training, he maintained a private practice in Otolaryngology on 61st St. in Manhattan. His musical knowledge combined with his medical skills led him to treating many patients from the musical and operatic world. Dr. Pomarico also served in the US Army Medical Reserves in the late 1960's. Jim leaves behind many loving family members and close friends. Services will be held Monday 10:30 AM in the Lesko Funeral Home, 1209 Post Rd in Fairfield, CT and 11AM at St. Anthony of Padua Church, 197 S. Pine Creek Road, Fairfield. Interment in Oak Lawn Cemetery, Fairfield. Friends may greet the family on Sunday from 4-8 PM.

title: Leaving Prison, Sharpton Again Takes the Stage
description: On one side of the closed prison gate was the trimmer but still unmistakable figure of the Rev. Al Sharpton, waiting for his moment. On the other side were more than three dozen members of the media, their pens, cameras and boom mikes at the ready.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about the Schenectady Police Department referred incorrectly to photographs being displayed by a civil rights lawyer. They showed John Rodick, who settled a police brutality lawsuit against the city, not David Sampson, another man who has accused the police.

title: Must People Lie? Yes, Absolutely. Or Is That a Lie?
description: Is there anything more boring than thinking about lies? What is there left to learn? About lies, everyone is an expert; they are unceasingly seen, heard and produced. There is a story about Queen Victoria and Prince Albert challenging their company to find a common word that is not a common thing. One guest guessed: ''Is it 'truth' or 'honesty'?''

title: Giuliani Says School Cuts Are Too Small
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he would not release additional financing to the Board of Education without cuts to the school system's administrative ranks that went further than those proposed by Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy.

title: Is It Live or Is It Studio Tape-Splicing? Actually, It's Live
description: Jerry Gonzlez and the Fort Apache band are the beneficiaries of 1980's New York, when jazz and Latin music were conscientiously and empirically connected every week at the old Village Gate. The Monday night ''Salsa Meets Jazz'' series there, which ended in 1993, was an effective bit of modern thinking; it promoted and hastened a cross-fertilization, booking jazz improvisers to sit in with Latin bands, instead of leaving musical evolution to the slow vagaries of chance. And in its wake, New Yorkers had a better understanding of the fact that jazz and Latin music would be together for the long haul.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Archer To Appeal Jail Term
description: Jeffrey Archer, the millionaire novelist and former Conservative politician serving a four-year jail term for perjury and perverting the course of justice, plans to appeal his conviction, according to court filings quoted by the Press Association. Lord Archer, 61, was found guilty last month of asking a friend to lie in a 1987 libel trial. A judge will rule on whether the appeal may be heard. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Liberty Rolls Over the Sol in the Second Half
description: Teresa Weatherspoon, the Liberty point guard, knows about the playoffs. And she has a question she asks herself and her teammates every year as they get ready to start the postseason: ''Are you hungry enough to do what it takes to reach your dream?''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, RUTH
description: GOLDSTEIN-Ruth. On behalf of the children and families of Chai Lifeline we express our heartfelt condolences to our good friend and benefactor, Mr. Michael Goldstein, Chairman of the Board of Toys R Us, on the recent loss of his dear mother. May he be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Rabbi Simcha Scholar Executive Vice President Samuel Zaks Director of Development

title: That Same Gruff Suavity Masks a Blues Idol's Pain
description: With his church-trained growl and his husky, mink-lined baritone croon, Teddy Pendergrass spent the 1970's becoming a rhythm-and-blues heartthrob. He sold millions of albums as the lead singer for Harold Melvin and the Blues Notes until 1976 and then on his own, while he inspired equal numbers of adoring shrieks. Female fans called him ''Teddy Bear'' and flocked to concerts he gave for women only.

title: Balcony Scene (Or Unseen) Atop the World; Episode at Trade Center Assumes Mythic Qualities
description: The affair of the balcony ended, if indeed it ever began, with the appearance in July of a slender book of curious title, obtainable in very few places, one of them being an art gallery in a frosted storefront on Broadway near Franklin Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODERICK, JAMES
description: BRODERICK-James. 74. Died on August 17, 2001. He is survived by his loving wife Mary Broderick of 42 years; beloved father of his children James, Una and Kieran and his spouse Dardi and grandson Neil Stewart. He is also survived by his brothers and sisters; Joan Rompalski, Nan Kester, Louise Curry, William Broderick, Thomas Broderick and 28 nieces and nephews. Jim Broderick served as a Special Agent in Foreign Counterintelligence with the Federal Bureau of Investigation for over 26 years and served as a bank officer with Long Island Trust, Chase Manhattan Bank and Bank of NY. Family will receive friends Sunday, August 19 at the Wantagh Abbey, Park Ave. and Beech St., Wantagh, NY from 2PM-5PM and 7PM-9PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Frances de Chantel on Monday, August 20, at 9:45A.M., 1309 Wantagh Avenue, Wantagh, New York.

title: Other Paths to Success
description: To the Editor:

title: British Land in Macedonia To Start NATO Campaign
description: Forty-one British troops arrived here tonight as part of an advance NATO team that will help decide when and if Macedonia is safe and stable enough for a full contingent of 3,500 NATO troops to come in and disarm ethnic Albanian guerrillas.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Women's National Basketball Association playoffs omitted one name in listing winners of the most-valuable-player award. In addition to Cynthia Cooper and Sheryl Swoopes, Yolanda Griffith made the list, in 1999.

title: African Forms, by Way of Chicago, Enliven New York
description: It is not often that New Yorkers get to see the Muntu Dance Theater of Chicago. That's a pity, because the company put on a first-class show on Wednesday night at the Damrosch Park band shell, where it appeared in the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival.

title: Religion Journal; Lutheran Group Elects New Leader
description: The election held by the nation's largest Lutheran denomination last week to fill its top office turned out to be exceptionally close.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Green's Writings
description: One thing that aides to Mark Green have been anticipating is the emergence of examples of potentially controversial passages Mr. Green wrote earlier in his career as a consumer advocate. And one turned up yesterday: Mr. Green put his mentor, Ralph Nader, on the same mantel as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ''Timid politicians have historically allowed public-minded citizens to play a significant role in setting the national agenda,'' Mr. Green wrote in the introduction to ''America's Transition: Blueprint for the 1990's,'' which he edited. ''In the modern era, Martin Luther King and Ralph Nader are the most prominent examples.'' Mr. Nader is not a name that has crossed Mr. Green's lips much in this campaign, partly because of the perception, which Mr. Green shares, that Mr. Nader deserves some blame for Al Gore's loss. Mr. Green's spokesman, Joseph DePlasco, said Mr. Green stood by the observation: ''Martin Luther King Jr. and Ralph Nader, in the course of their respective careers, played a significant role in setting the national agenda.''

title: Economic Tombstones; Very Very Super-Luxurious
description: There is really no combination quite like unlimited wealth and an unbridled sense of regal entitlement, and no place where the two come together as completely as they do in Brunei, a small country on the northeast coast of Borneo. Oil and natural gas were discovered in the South China Sea, just off the Brunei coast, in 1929, and the royal family has been riding a tide of petroleum wealth ever since. That tide has withdrawn just enough, following the 1997-1998 Asian economic crisis, to leave one member of the royal family, Prince Jefri Bolkiah, younger brother of the sultan of Brunei, high and dry.

title: Beijing Judge Jails 4 for Promoting Falun Gong's Public Suicides
description: A Beijing court convicted four people of murder today for organizing the self-immolation in January by followers of the outlawed Falun Gong spiritual movement. One man was sentenced to life in prison, and the other defendants received terms from 7 to 15 years.

title: Police Commissioner Says He Will Leave With His Mayor
description: Although several mayoral candidates have said they would consider retaining him, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said yesterday that he would not serve in the post past Dec. 31, when the Giuliani administration leaves office.

title: South Korean News Executives Are Arrested on Tax Charges
description: In a case that has strained the country's political divisions and tested the power and policies of President Kim Dae Jung, the owners of two of South Korea's largest newspapers were arrested tonight on charges of tax evasion and embezzlement.

title: Certicom Plans Job Cuts
description: The Certicom Corporation, a maker of security software, said today that it planned to cut about 70 employees, or one-quarter of its staff, to trim costs. It was the second round of layoffs at the company in less than three months. The latest cuts will leave the company with about 200 employees by the end of the October. On June 4, Certicom said it would dismiss 30 percent of its workers. Certicom, based in Hayward, has been scaling back staff as customers spend less in a weak economy. The company makes software to protect people's identities when they make purchases over wireless devices.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Economy Shrinks
description: Taiwan's economy shrank for the first time in 26 years as a slide in electronics exports hurt investment and consumer spending, prompting the central bank to cut interest rates for the eighth time since December. Gross domestic product fell 2.4 percent in the second quarter from a year earlier. Economists expected no change in growth. The government said the economy would probably shrink 0.4 percent this year, the first annual contraction on record, after projecting 4 percent annual growth in May.

title: Green's Brother Helped Raise $672,000
description: Stephen L. Green, the brother of the mayoral candidate Mark Green and the chief executive of one of the city's largest commercial real estate companies, has helped raise about 12 percent of the $5.8 million in political donations collected by his brother, the campaign disclosed yesterday, far more than previous estimates had suggested.

title: For Jurevicius, Now Is the Time To Flourish
description: Nothing seems to motivate a player like the threat of losing his job. When Giants wide receiver Joe Jurevicius sat out Monday's practices because of back spasms, his replacement was Ron Dixon, a fleet, talented, but as yet unproven receiver.

title: Sex Bias Alleged in City's Vocational Schools
description: New York City's vocational high schools are deeply segregated by sex, with most girls enrolled in programs leading to ''traditionally female'' careers like cosmetology and boys predominating in schools geared toward high-tech, higher-paying jobs, a women's rights group has charged.

title: U.S. Defeats Israel to Win World Youth Championship
description: The World Youth Team Championship, played in Mangaratiba, Brazil, ended Wednesday in a victory for the United States.

title: Sexual Assaults at Hospital
description: The authorities last night were looking for a man who sexually assaulted two female patients at the Beth Israel Medical Center unit on the Upper East Side Thursday afternoon.

title: Yanks Send Message, Loud and Clear, to Mariners
description: Before last night's game, Lou Piniella expressed some concern about his team's recent ability to score runs. It seemed to be a questionable concern considering that the Seattle Mariners had scored more runs than any of the other 29 major league teams and in the past two weeks had scored five or more runs nine times in 12 games. For some teams, the Mets, for example, that output might be a month's worth of runs.

title: INSIDE
description: Marine General Is Charged

title: Forgotten Tenant Stands Between Mormons and New Harlem Chapel
description: Victor Parker moved north to Harlem from Virginia as a teenager and has been there ever since. He is 56 years old, says he does not read too well, and earns about $300 a week as a handyman in a Bronx laundry.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILLIM, SIDNEY
description: TILLIM-Sidney. Painter and critic. On August 16th in his 76th year. Dearly beloved husband of Diane Radycki-Tillim and the late Muriel Sharon. He is survived by his cherished niece Dena Dekel, the loving and supportive Tillim-Karlin family, and 38 years of devoted Bennington College students, no less than the worlds of art and bookcollecting that he engaged passionately. He will be greatly missed. Viewing Saturday 2-5PM and 7-9 PM and service Sunday 11:30 AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Interment Spring Valley, NY. A memorial service is planned for October. Contributions in his memory may be made to the New York Public Library for the express purpose of establishing a fund for the maintenance and preservation of Sid's papers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHILL, CHARLES A.
description: CAHILL-Charles A. The Board of Trustees and staff of Studio in a School note with sorrow the passing of Charles Cahill, father of their beloved Executive Director, Tom Cahill. They extend their deepest sympathies to Tom, his son Adam, and to the entire family. Agnes Gund, Founder Roy B. Simpson, Sr., Chairman Gail Gregg, President The Studio in a School Assoc., Inc.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Denmark Ends All Aid
description: Denmark, which had already cut much of its aid to Zimbabwe to protest the actions of President Robert Mugabe and his government, has now suspended all direct aid to the government, the Danish foreign ministry said. The decision follows the arrests of several independent journalists and a surge in attacks on white farmers in the country. As he runs for re-election next year, Mr. Mugabe and his party are facing a strong challenge for the first time, and political tension and turmoil have gripped the country. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SELIGMAN, PETER D.
description: SELIGMAN-Peter D. August 18, 2000. Roses are red, violets are blue. Time has not diminished our love for you. We think of you in the morning. We think of you at night. To us you are a star, forever shining bright. Your Loving Famil

title: Voting With Disabilities
description: The fact that the nation's elections are not quite state-of-the-art may have come as a surprise to many Americans in the aftermath of last November's presidential vote. But it was hardly news to the millions of citizens with disabilities, who for years have been struggling to get local election officials to grant them equal access to the polls. Congress must address their concerns as it takes up election reform this fall.

title: Body Is Missing Woman's
description: A corpse removed Thursday from a Philadelphia basement was identified yesterday as that of Kimberly Szumski, 36, a New Jersey woman who had been missing for more than three months, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLMAN, ROBERT M.
description: WOLLMAN-Robert M. On August 16th at age 79. After a long battle of Gauchers disease. Loving husband of Koka. Adored father of Jeffery and Glenn. Brother of Phylis Ain and Jack Wollman. Grandfather of Nathan.

title: Pragmatic Jets Finally Awaken, And They See Ravens Coming
description: The unrestrained optimism that engulfed the Jets when training camp opened two weeks ago has ebbed, replaced this week by reality-induced pragmatism.

title: OBITUARY : Ridgway Brewster Knight, 90
description: Ridgway Brewster Knight, 90, a former U.S. ambassador to Syria, Belgium and Portugal, died Wednesday at his home in Northern France.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Plant Closing
description: An American circuitboard manufacturer, General Semiconductor, announced the closing of its Irish plant in County Cork, with the loss of 670 jobs, citing a downturn in demand for its products. The deputy prime minister, Mary Harney, pledged to find a new employer for the predominantly agricultural region, where General Semiconductor operated for 20 years. Since January, 4,300 people have lost jobs at high-tech employers sponsored by the Irish government.

title: To One Judge, Cybermonitors Bring Uneasy Memories
description: THE 7-year-old boy charmed the workers at the weaving plant his father managed by showing them he could read. They held up the Communist Party newspaper, and he sounded out its name: Free Romania. Then the boy offered an editorial remark of his own.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Airline Shares Fall
description: Qantas Airways shares posted their biggest two-day decline in nearly five months, falling 11 percent, after analysts reduced their earnings forecasts following a 15 percent drop in second-half profit. Qantas's shares fell 15 cents, or 5 percent, to 2.87 Australian dollars, the lowest close since April 30 and extending yesterday's 6.5 percent drop. Qantas, based in Sydney, said Thursday that net income in the six months ended June 30 fell to 153 million Australian dollars ($81 million) from the year-earlier 180 million Australian dollars. Qantas said earnings might not revive this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, SYLVIA
description: WEBER-Sylvia on August 16, 2001. Beloved mother of Robert Weber and Lillian Silver, grandmother of Daniel, Elise, Danny and David, great grandmother of Sterling, Sloan and Sydney. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Assoc or the Metropolitan Opera.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Omagh Bomb Investigation
description: The newly appointed police ombudsman, Nuala O'Loan, has begun an investigation into accusations that security forces had advance knowledge of the bombing in Omagh in 1998, which killed 29 people. Ms. O'Loan's powers are to grow under a plan published by the British and Irish governments for reforms in policing in Northern Ireland. They include halving the police force's antiterrorist intelligence division, reducing police reserves and closing a controversial interrogation center. Northern Ireland Secretary John Reid called on all political parties to support the measures, but Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, quickly denounced the reforms as inadequate. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AGERE SYSTEMS INC., Allentown, Pa., the chip-making unit Lucent Technologies Inc. plans to spin off, will close offices in Berkeley Heights, N.J., and move 275 jobs to its Allentown headquarters.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Merchant Marine Loss
description: Hyundai Merchant Marine estimated that its losses from 30 months of ferrying tourists on luxury tourist ships from the South Korean port of Tonghae to the base of Mount Kumkang in North Korea totaled $115 million. The company, which has $5 billion in debt, said that it lost $35 million in the first year, when interest was at its peak. The South Korean government, viewing the tours as crucial to President Kim Dae Jung's policy of reconciliation with North Korea, subsidizes the twice-weekly trips on speedboats operated by Hyundai Asan, set up specifically for Hyundai's activities in the North. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Campaign Briefing | Borough President Contests: Charges On Staten Island
description: The battle between James P. Molinaro and Robert A. Straniere for borough president of Staten Island racheted up a notch this week. Mr. Molinaro's campaign filed formal charges against Mr. Straniere with the Campaign Finance Board. Mr. Molinaro, a longtime aide to the incumbent, Guy V. Molinari, won the Republican Party endorsement away from Mr. Straniere months ago and has questioned whether Mr. Straniere, a state assemblyman, really lives on Staten Island. In this latest skirmish, the Molinaro campaign charged that Mr. Straniere's disclosure statements show five payments totaling $6,000 for consulting to a company owned by Mr. Straniere's wife. Mr. Straniere did not return a call seeking comment. According to campaign finance records, Mr. Straniere is the only candidate registered with the program to have received any matching funds.

title: Another Day, Another Idea Is 'Stolen'
description: Overall crime may be down in New York City, but yesterday there was another reported incident of political thievery in the contest for mayor.

title: Cows Are Seized In Fraud Inquiry
description: The Iowa attorney general's office seized thousands of cows and other assets today from a $180 million investment company accused of defrauding hundreds of investors out of millions of dollars.

title: Campaign Briefing | Voting: For Wonks, A Wait
description: Election-obsessed wonks may have noticed that the city's Board of Elections Web site was down over the past week. According to Daniel DeFrancesco, the board's executive director, it was because of an erroneous report in The Los Angeles Times that people were hacking into the system to download music and movie files. Ever security conscious, Mr. DeFrancesco said, the city's Department of Investigation took the system offline while they checked for breaches. None were found. The system was back up and running on Thursday. ''I guess an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure,'' Mr. DeFrancesco said. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Slow Job Growth
description: French companies added fewer workers in the second quarter than at any time in the last two and a half years as declining orders spurred them to scale back production. Payrolls, excluding government and farm work, grew 0.4 percent from the previous quarter, to 14.9 million, the Labor Ministry said. That was half the first quarter's pace. Wages rose 0.5 percent after gaining 0.9 percent in the first quarter.

title: In Pursuit of the Yankees, the Mariners Stumble
description: Mike Mussina paused to glance at the ground before he made each pitch against Seattle last night, and the answers seemed to come easily to him, like solutions to his daily regimen of crossword puzzles. Two words, a pitch that Bret Boone chases: high fastball. A pitch that surprises Boone: sinker.

title: Dr. Henry Barnett, 87, Dies; Pediatric Kidney Authority
description: Dr. Henry Lewis Barnett, a pediatrician who was an expert on the diagnosis and treatment of kidney disease in children, died on Tuesday at New York Weill Cornell Center in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Yale and the Price of Slavery
description: In 1852 a wealthy Mississippi cotton planter, Robert Hairston, suddenly fell ill. With death overtaking him, he frantically dictated a will in which he revealed that he had a child, his only one, a 5-year-old girl who was a slave. With his last breath he commanded his family to have the girl set free and bequeathed to her his entire estate -- land, cash and slaves worth over $1 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEVRIES, TILLY
description: deVRIES-Tilly. Passed peacefully on August 16, 2001. Cherished wife of the late Lion, beloved sister of Albert Van Creveld and dear aunt of Reni de Verteuil, Knight in the Order Oranje-Nassau, bestowed upon her by H.M. Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands. Travel agent and tour director extraordinaire, jazz aficionado, avid bridge player, pillar of the Dutch community and a devoted friend to many. In lieu of flowers, donations to Lion de Vries Memorial Scholarship Fund, Hostra University, Hempstead, NY 11549. Memorial service on Tuesday, August 21, 6 PM, Marble Collegiate Church, One West 29th Street, New York City.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Alaska: Protection For Subsistence Living
description: A two-day conference convened by Gov. Tony Knowles ended with a recommendation that the state amend its Constitution to give priority in wildlife management to rural populations living primarily off wild fish, game and flora. Federal law protects subsistence living, practiced mostly by Alaska Natives, from incursions by industry and sport fishing and hunting enthusiasts. The State Supreme Court struck down a similar state law in 1989, but the State House approved a subsistence amendment in 1999. Mr. Knowles, a Democrat, said he hoped the recommendation would persuade Senate Republicans to support the amendment. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Airport Congestion
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: State Counts First West Nile Death
description: A 70-year-old woman has died in Atlanta of what is believed to be West Nile virus, said the state epidemiologist, Paul Blake. She is the first person thought to have died from the virus in Georgia. Several dead birds linked to the virus have been found in Georgia, Florida and Virginia since it turned up in a Florida man in July. Nine people have died in New York and New Jersey from the virus since 1999. The virus causes flu-like symptoms, affecting the elderly and those with weakened immune systems more severely. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Private-Prison Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAKRAIDA, MARY JO HUGHES
description: SAKRAIDA-Mary Jo Hughes. It is with tremendous sadness that we mourn the untimely loss of Mary Jo Hughes Sakraida, who passed away on Wednesday, August 15, 2001. Mary was a powerful force for good in the communities of Northern Westchester. As president of the Junior League of Northern Westchester and a member of the Auxiliary of the Northern Westchester Hospital Center, Mary nurtured the towns of Northern Westchester by leading many projects to benefit the community. Mary was also a wonderful friend, mentor, advisor, and guide to the many lives she touched. She combined incredible graciousness with a wicked sense of fun. Mary always sent flowers, gifts, and personal notes to friends and acquaintances to celebrate successes and console in times of trouble. She brought a wealth of positive energy to the many good works in which she was engaged. Mary was also the life of every party and the first one to erupt into laughter at the sublime or the ridiculous. Mary Jo was the beloved wife of Michael Sakraida, daughter of the late Robert J. and Mary B. (Sullivan) Hughes, sister of Robert Hughes (Meg, Orchard Park, NY), Daniel Hughes (LeAnn, Lancaster, NY), and Jennifer McMullen (William, Mt. Lebanon, PA), sister-in-law to Joseph Sakraida (Sheila), Vincent Sakraida (Teresa), and Kathleen Sakraida, daughter-in-law to Audrey Sakraida, and adoring aunt. Mary was born and raised in Buffalo, NY. She was graduated from Fordham University. The Junior League of Northern Westchester has renamed its scholarship program for graduating high school seniors engaged in community service the Mary Sakraida Scholarship Fund. Contributions to the Mary Sakraida Scholarship Fund may be made to: JLNW, 344 Main Street, Mt. Kisco, NY 10549. Viewing will be held at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah. Viewing times 2-4PM and 7-9PM on Saturday, August 18 and Sunday August 19. A Mass and funeral service will be held at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford at 10 AM on August 20.

title: Falling in Love With a Filly Called Flute
description: Bobby Frankel, a Brooklyn-born tough guy and scourge of jockeys on both coasts, has fallen hard for a filly. Her name is Flute and she is trying to add the Alabama Stakes to a rsum that so far is headed by a Kentucky Oaks victory.

title: Crown Heights: A Look Back
description: Ten years ago, the Brooklyn neighborhood of Crown Heights exploded in New York's ugliest spasm of racial violence in decades.

title: Trees Bind Angkor Temples in Perilous Grip
A 'Hamlet' in Which Pain Is No Metaphor
description: ALTHOUGH it is unlikely that either Hamlet or Shakespeare ever set foot in Elsinore, this coastal Danish town is shrouded in legends that make visitors feel as if they are treading on sacred literary ground. After walking down Ophelia Way and sleeping at the Hamlet Hotel, theatergoers at the Hamlet Sommer Festival's annual productions of Shakespeare's tragedy in the courtyard of Elsinore's seaside castle can nurture the illusion of communing with the play's characters on their home territory.

title: Poetry in Brief
description: Different Hours

title: I'm The Richest Girl In Estonia
description: As far as Communist dissenters go, Carmen Kass has a better figure than Lech Walesa and has been on more Vogue covers than Vaclav Havel. But when she added her voice to 300,000 others in Estonia's ''Singing Revolution,'' and joined hands across three countries in the ''Baltic Chain,'' she became part of the resistance that led to freedom for her homeland.

title: After the Chaos, A New Day for the Cultures Of the Soviet World
description: BY all accounts, the celebration of the 100th anniversary of the Moscow Conservatory Great Hall on April 17 marked a low point for Russian culture. Instead of an occasion worthy of Tchaikovsky or Shostakovich, the concert, sponsored by Rosinterfest, a commercial presenter, turned into a musical smorgasbord, laced with free martinis, ordered up by Russia's new rich.

title: Nancy Brensson, Michael Odell
description: Nancy Brensson, the daughter of Baiba and Juris Brensson of Alpine, N.J., and Michael David Odell, a son of Claire Odell and Dr. Peter M. Odell of Manhattan, were married last evening. Judge Michael B. Mukasey, chief judge of Federal District Court in Manhattan, officiated at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: Corn and Character
description: Some farmer's markets are offering more than corn and tomatoes. As of last week teenagers from the state juvenile justice system are getting a chance to develop skills in selling and courtesy by working at inner-city farm stands. The 2001 Youth Farm Stand Project, which is training 60 juvenile offenders and then sending them out to sell produce, is a combined effort of Rutgers University and the state Juvenile Justice Commission. Participants in the project are from residential group centers, which house young people convicted of lower-level crimes, and many are preparing to return home. The stands are open at the Rutgers University Camden Campus on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m.; the Hudson County Courthouse Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursday mornings; and at the Estell Manor in Atlantic City Tuesdays and Thursdays from 10 to 3. Anne Ruderman

title: Arrow's New Boss Faces an Early Trial by Fire
description: A YEAR ago, Arrow Electronics, the giant distributor in Melville, was well on the way to a third consecutive quarter of record-setting sales and earnings, and its new chief executive, Francis M. Scricco, engaged in a bit of prognostication. In the company's earnings report last October, Mr. Scricco said that he saw no signs of a fundamental shift in the industry nor any indications of a market shift anytime soon.

description: This

title: THE GUIDE
description: Best Bet

title: California Park With Theme From Past Raises Modern Concerns
description: If Alice in Wonderland took a walk through the new Bonfante Gardens theme park, it might remind her of a garden of her own.

title: The Family Mobile

title: The Way We Live Now; Cell Block

The whitewashed buildings, once part of a chicken farm, had been converted into a haven for people with H.I.V. infection. By scrambling and cajoling, the volunteer staff managed to get antiretroviral drugs for every infected child. But for the adults wasting away from unchecked H.I.V. infection, the future did not look bright. Had they been able to afford the medications, or for that matter, been residents of the United States, patients in my county hospital in El Paso, Tex., I felt they soon would have had flesh on their bones, the strength to sit up and the prospect of a future.

title: The Way We Live Now: Process; Canvassing the City
description: Over the last two years I have over a thousand places that I've archived. These are all taken from cities, from Washington, from Los Angeles, from San Jose, where I'm from, from New Jersey and from Long Island. And this painting, ''Convergence,'' was Washington. I was living there, and I thought, O.K., I'm going to drive all the way around the Beltway, around the suburbs, and go to these suburban retail centers, where you'll have a Wal-Mart and a Home Depot. I'd just take photographs of everything. (I started taking the digital camera with me wherever I went. That got to be impinging too much on my daily life.) I wanted to take the stance of a 19th-century scientist, creating a taxonomy of species. I was looking for the essence of the species McDonald's. Because these corporations do have, I'm sure, this bible of what the ideal McDonald's looks like. Or maybe not the ideal, but the code for it. And I've been trying to arrive at that code from the opposite direction. So it kind of has that mock-scientific quality.

title: A Surrealist And the Widow Who Keeps The Flame

Not all of his work was Surrealist, but the term does not, in my view, misrepresent the projects that hold the greatest interest for architects today. She was agreeable about it. Now I've kept my part of the bargain.

title: Mixed Greens

However, as McGrath points out, if you look at a country club during the most popular playing times, you will probably see only men on the course -- men playing with other men, and men entertaining their clients. title: Lives; Raising a Stink

When a neighbor based his new pork-raising hobby (11 pigs fattening up for the kill) on a corner of his property a stone's throw from our hammock, I hadn't considered it a hostile act. So what if he had acres to play with and his own house was upwind? We had bought a second home on this picturesque island two hours from the city because it was a ''real place'' -- the avowed ''UnHamptons'' -- where the Catholic Church hosts a Blessing of the Pets parade and year-rounders keep livestock pens with children's-book farm critters.

title: Poetry in Brief; The Lone Deranger Rides Again
description: Not many books of poems put you in mind of Robert Penn Warren, Lynyrd Skynyrd and the brainiac whimsy of McSweeney's quarterly at the same time. In his first book, LAWRENCE BOOTH'S BOOK OF VISIONS (Yale University, cloth, $19; paper, $12), Maurice Manning displays not just terrific cunning but terrific aim -- he nails his images the way a restless boy, up in a tree with a slingshot, nails anything sentient that wanders into view. Manning's book, which won this year's Yale Series of Younger Poets competition, is set in the rural South -- probably Kentucky, where the author was born -- and it's a cycle of hallucinatory, vinegary and often plaintive poems about the coming of age of a troubled boy. These are poems in which offhandedly shrewd images (''The night-time smells / like creosote and shirtless boys, mixed with june bugs and grease'') mingle with confusing and disturbing ones: in one poem, Lawrence's violent father -- who is referred to, variously, as ''Ole Dreadful Daddy,'' ''Ninety-Proof Daddy'' and ''Real Mad Daddy'' -- appears on a horse, drenched in kerosene, and bellows ''I love you like / a furnace, son! Heigh-Ho Silver, away!'' before lighting a match. That's a nightmarish snapshot -- one of many -- but Manning's book doesn't sink into a Big Muddy of gothic imagery. The poems here are frequently poured into playful forms: progress reports from teachers, court complaints, lists of nicknames, even a page of personal ads: ''Eccentric (?) gentleman (negotiable)- / tinker/farmer searching the heavens / for the true spark of love (breast-size unimportant). Please.'' File under: books that shouldn't work, but do. Dwight Garner

title: Food; My Blue Heaven
description: For almost a quarter of my life, I was so madly in love with a Cancer, it almost killed me. No wonder they are represented in the zodiac by a crab. Just like their crustacean counterparts, Cancers move mostly sideways, and they change directions with no notice -- or worse, they simply retreat into their shells. They can indeed be ''crabby,'' which Webster's defines as cross or ill-tempered, and ''crabbed'' (morose and peevish), and they are very adept at ''crabbing'' (making sour) what were, just moments earlier, the best of times. They are moody and sensitive and vulnerable, and you want to kill them, but they are saved by the fact that they also share the crab's more irresistible nature. Once you have had a taste of what lies beneath that hard and occasionally difficult shell, you find that it is more than worth the patience and the hassle. And that it is damn near impossible not to keep coming back for more.

title: Eisenstein's Unfinished Ode to an Idealized Mexico
description: WITH bold, stunning images, the director Sergei Eisenstein's ''Qu Viva Mxico'' set out to reflect the irresistible contrast that for him was Mexico. In one sequence, on a languid tropical afternoon, sunlight filters through palm leaves as bare-breasted young women brush their long, silky hair and strapping young men idle away the day in hammocks. In another, Roman Catholic pilgrims re-enact the sufferings of Christ, crawling on their knees, cactus crosses strapped to their backs. In still another, a smug, landowner has his way with a maiden, and young peasant men buried up to their necks in the hot sun await death by the trampling of their oppressors' horses.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Law of Averages: New & Selected Stories, by Frederick Barthelme. (Counterpoint, $15.) A hyperinventive troubadour of the commonplace casts his gaze over the Sun Belt, where many of his characters -- whether emotionally inert or animated by their delight in buying things -- suffer minor meltdowns that end up as compassionate comedy. The collection is uneven, Will Blythe said here last year, ''but when Barthelme is good, he's astoundingly good.'' Counterpoint has also reissued Barthelme's 1990 novel, Natural Selection ($14), a dissection of a middle-aged man's marital and emotional crisis, set in a faceless Houston subdivision. ''The shocker of the ending . . . serves as an old-fashioned moral,'' Amy Hempel wrote in these pages. ''Maybe, Barthelme seems to say, we don't know how good we've got it.''

title: PRISON POPULATION DECREASES
description: New Jersey's prison population decreased by 5.4 percent in 2000 to 29,784, from 31,493 in 1999, according to a report released last week by the federal Justice Department. The percentage decrease was second highest in the nation, after Massachusetts with 5.6 percent. The drop is the first after a decade of increases averaging 3.5 percent a year and is attributed to a decrease in the crime rate and the state parole board clearing a large number of backlogged parole hearings. Still, New Jersey's prisons remain at 41 percent above full capacity, well above the average overcrowding rate of 15 percent for all states. Karen DeMasters

After extended persuasion, in Jafar Panahi's improbably charming film THE WHITE BALLOON (1995), her mother agrees and sends her off with a 500-toman bill. After a couple of snake-charming con men on the street pretend to take her money, she actually loses it and spends the rest of the film trying to get it back. In the process she learns that some adults are kind and helpful and some aren't, and we revisit the unique helplessness and determination of childhood - Sunday at 9 p.m. and Wednesday at 6:15 a.m. on Sundance.

title: August 12-18; Pataki Sues on N.Y. Budget
description: New York's annual impasse over spending reached new depths when Gov. George E. Pataki sued the Assembly and Senate. In Albany, the governor submits appropriations that the Legislature can veto or reduce. Over the years, however, New York's governors have ceded control to legislative leaders, letting them bargain for additions and then resubmitting bills. Not Mr. Pataki, who submitted a budget and said his job was done. Unable to bargain, the frustrated Legislature passed a Spartan plan that cut his pet projects. He retaliated with a suit asserting a strict interpretation of the state constitution. If successful, the suit could turn back the clock to the 1930's, when the Legislature usually rubberstamped the executive's plan. James C. McKinley Jr.

''When viewed in the context of what happened around it,'' said Judy Stanton, executive director of the Brooklyn Heights Association, referring to construction last year of towers on Court Street and Montague Street, ''you can't help but be grateful.''

title: The Way We Live Now: Salient Facts: Bedbugs; Sleeping With The Enemy
description: This summer, if the concierge at your favorite hotel says, ''Don't let the bedbugs bite,'' take note. Bedbugs -- flat, reddish brown, wingless creatures -- are enjoying a feeding frenzy these days. Surviving on human blood, they attack only at night and leave red streaks on a victim's sheets as their calling card. Orkin, the Atlanta-based pest control company, estimates a 20 percent nationwide increase in bedbug calls in the last two years. Florida's hotels in particular have placed 10 times as many bedbug-related calls to fumigators since 1999, according to a University of Florida study released last month. Increased international tourism is to blame, suggests Phil Koehler, the urban entomologist that led the research team. And no hotels -- from hip boutique upstarts to rundown economy chains -- are safe. Tourists unwittingly carry them in their luggage, says Koehler, so every hotel is a potential target. ''Bedbugs are just as happy eating in a five-star resort as a youth hostel.''

title: The Real Studio 54
description: One of the advantages of working for Andy Warhol was that he made up in party invites what he withheld in paychecks. If you hung around the office -- aka the Factory -- late enough, say until 7, he might have asked you to accompany him to anything from a movie premiere or an art opening to Christmas drinks at Jackie O's. Andy's grander hosts sometimes objected to his unannounced entourages, and then his manager, Fred Hughes, would lay down the law. This excerpt from my 1990 memoir, ''Holy Terror: Andy Warhol Close Up,'' is about one of the first swell parties the boss, as we Factory workers called him, took me to.

Hope for the kind of donation that would make a real difference -- at least $1 billion from Washington -- resided with Senate Democrats. They have now made their recommendation. The total is essentially the same as the administration's -- $100 million this year and $150 million next year -- and even that might be cut during negotiations.

If somebody was H.I.V. negative and I could transport them into my body for a few days and let them feel the pain, I think they'd have a whole new understanding about the risks they're taking.''

title: August 12-18; Higher
description: Sometimes the race goes to the slow and fragile. Helios, a solar-powered flying wing built for NASA, broke the altitude record for non-rocket aircraft set 25 years ago. Powered by 14 small electric motors each turning a propeller, Helios climbed above the skies of Hawaii at barely 25 miles per hour to reach 96,500 feet, topping the old mark by more than 11,000 feet. The robot plane, made of lightweight materials covered with a plastic film skin, is a forerunner to craft that one day may soar in the rarefied air of Mars.

His crime: trespassing on the grounds of a military camp while protesting the Navy's bombing exercises on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques. During his incarceration, the black leader read several books, granted dozens of interview requests and staged a weeks-long hunger strike that cost him 30 pounds but gained him the admiration of many of the city's Hispanic leaders. Mr. Sharpton immediately rejoined the fray, mulling which New York mayoral candidate to endorse and contemplating a run for the presidency in 2004.

title: Crime

But one thing leads to another and before they know it, the minimart owner is dead and they're holed up in the home of a man named Smith, keeping him and his two children hostage while F.B.I. agents, sheriffs' deputies, news station helicopters, a team of mob hit men and a burned-out cop named Jeff Talley circle the perimeter. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, KENNETH REESE JR.
description: COLE-Kenneth Reese Jr. 63, beloved husband, father and grandfather, of Willsboro, NY, and Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, died peacefully in his sleep at his summer home on Thursday, August 16, 2001. He was born in NYC, on January 27, 1938. Ken grew up in Scarsdale, NY, and Westfield, NJ. He graduated from Bucknell University and was Lt. (jg) in the US Navy from 1961 until 1965. He served as the Director of the Domestic Council under Presidents Nixon and Ford. Ken enjoyed his summers in Willsboro, NY, where he was a member of St. John's Episcopal Church. He wintered in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. His sport of choice was golf, which he loved only second to his family. He is survived by his wife Marilyn (Slifer) Cole, two daughters and their husbands, Corinne and Robert Ryan of Charlotte, NC, and Megan and Kirk Kellogg of Summit, NJ. He is also survived by two sisters and their husbands, Priscilla and Thomas Perkins of Terrell, NC, Connie Cole and Donald Lidstrand of Denville, NJ, one brother and his wife Brady and Margaret Cole of Corinth, VT, and five grandchildren Aletta, Claire and Reese Ryan and Charlie and Caroline Kellogg. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Essex, NY, Monday, August 20, 2001, at 2 PM. In remembance of Ken, those who wish may make a contribution to the charity of their choice or St. John's Episcopal Church, Essex, NY, or the Smith House Health Care Center, Willsboro, NY.

title: August 12-18; Warning on Mideast Inaction

Arabs from Oman in the gulf to Morocco in North Africa are increasingly angry, Osama el-Baz said, at what they perceive as Washington's double standard: support for Israel while it bombs Palestinians. The danger is also growing, he said, that extremism will take hold in moderate Arab countries. Jane Perlez

title: The World; Thanks, We'll Be in Touch

The report, titled United Nations: Targeted Strategies Could Help Boost U.S. Representation, concludes that some countries, including Russia and India, tend to be overrepresented in various agencies, even when the United Nation's own formulas for hiring equity are used (see below).

The report said there was no statistical evidence that the race of a defendant affects the likelihood of getting the death penalty. The report is the first in what is to be a yearly review of the state's death penalty. John Holl

The police walked around inspecting all the bikes and asked the riders for their licenses, registration and insurance. Only the bikes were checked and not the numerous cars in the parking lot.

title: Untanning Lotions
description: In the waning days of summer, those who didn't slather on the requisite ounces of sunscreen may be searching for some damage control in a bottle. Suffering from no such lack of preparedness, cosmetic companies are releasing an army of reparative products designed to lighten skin, reduce wrinkles and generally reverse the effects of too much fun in the sun. This month, Clinique introduces its Total Turnaround Visible Skin Renewer ($30 at Saks Fifth Avenue), intended to remove dull and damaged skin with a mix of silicon and vitamins. Next month, Origins will offer A Perfect World ($30 at Origins stores), a cream that uses white tea as an antioxidant. Brandt Lightening Gel ($65 at Bergdorf Goodman) features hydroquinone in a glycolic acid base as its active restorative ingredient. And B. Kamins puts a rather unusual combination of maple sugar and alpha-hydroxy acids in its Cellular Renewal Serum ($88 at Barneys New York).

The twin forces of science and capitalism will undoubtedly unleash their magic, and if a cure is to be found, they are likely to find it -- here or, more likely, abroad.

The North Fork's understated spirit is also reflected within this rustic, nautical spot at 64300 Main Road (631-765-1010) where Halfshells had been.

Most of the people who came learned about the reunion from placards posted around this small South Shore village, on Barnum Island, just north of Long Beach, with a population of fewer than 5,000, weeks before, inviting ''everyone who 'hung out' at Island Park's Casino Beach'' during its heyday, from 1940 through 1969, to ''swing and swim.'' Even with leaden skies and the threat of rain, they gathered to reminisce. .

title: The Alchemy of OxyContin
description: You have probably received hundreds of letters from people who suffer from chronic pain worrying that the OxyContin problem will exacerbate concern about prescribing it. title: These Days, Layoffs Compete With Loyalty

title: The Way We Live Now: On Language; Clueless
description: Given my job at The Times, I seem to be perceived by some people as a superintelligent know-it-all who takes delight in tormenting them. Thus, it is understandable that some might take pleasure in exacting revenge by pointing out my own lapses -- mistakes that I've made or permitted to appear in the puzzles. Of all my mail, the largest portion is devoted to possible errors.

title: Hostile Environment
description: Christie Whitman arrives at the home ballpark of the Lowell Spinners, the Boston Red Sox' Class-A affiliate in the old mill town of Lowell, Mass. The stadium rises atop a cleaned-up toxic-waste site and is the kind of place administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency go. It's a glinting citadel of the new and well made, wedged among boarded-up factories. But there is no crowd waiting, only a few baseball staff members. When she was governor of New Jersey, Whitman caused a stir wherever she went; many expected her to ascend either to the United States Senate or to the vice-presidential slot on the 2000 Republican ticket. Instead she now visits toxic-waste sites. ''At least today is a clean day,'' Whitman notes. Often when she travels to inspect something, it's garbage or ooze or worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHMAN, RABBI MILTON, DHL, DD
description: RICHMAN-Rabbi Milton, DHL, DD, 80, Saturday, August 11, 2001, in Winchester, VA. Husband of the late Janet Kerber. Spiritual leader of Temple Hesed, Scranton, PA, for 31 years. Devoted to the teaching of Jewish life and values, he worked for social justice, civil rights, and established ecumenism in Scranton. Born in Brooklyn, NY, son of the late Morris and Ida Topor, he graduated from Yeshiva College, Hebrew Teacher's Institute, the New School, the Russel Sage School, and was ordained at Hebrew Union College, Cincinnati, OH, in 1952. He taught at Purdue University, Universities of Buffalo and Scranton, SUNY at Binghamton, Lord Fairfax CC, and Shenandoah University. Member of CCAR, UAHC, NAACP, and more. He fully retired in 1998. We remember his warmth, intellect, and joy of holiness. Joel Richman, Houston, TX Dr. Tobi Richman, Boca Raton, FL

They moved from Sugar Ray's, where Joe Louis and Jackie Robinson hung out, to Minton's Playhouse, where Count Basie or Dizzy Gillespie played, to Dot's, where jazz musicians jammed after hours.

title: August 12-18; The Price of a Spy Plane
description: First Washington and Beijing argued over who was at fault when a Chinese fighter collided with a Navy surveillance plane on April 1, then over when to release the American crew. Then came weeks of negotiations: the U.S. asked to repair the EP-3 and fly it home, but China refused. It was finally carted away, in pieces, by a cargo plane. Has America gotten the last word? China requested $1 million for the care of the plane's 24-member crew, which it detained for 11 days, and for other expenses; the United States sent $34,567. China angrily rejected the sum, but the U.S. says it is nonnegotiable. Thom Shanker

title: Aftershock
description: Toward the end of her essay (The Way We Live Now, July 29), Diane McWhorter writes, ''And McVeigh's destruction of the Oklahoma City federal building aggressively enacted the antigovernment rhetoric of Congress's triumphalist Republican Revolution.'' Hogwash. Timothy McVeigh's bombing of the federal building was the criminal act of a deranged man. Connecting his actions with the Republican Party in this manner is both absurd and shameful. Sowing seeds of discord does our country harm, not good. We should be thankful for the freedom that allows us to criticize others' political views openly, but the criticism should be fair and responsible.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Blockbuster Culture of Summer
description: Summer dwindles, even as high August comes. The roar of summer culture has reached its climax, and the county fairs are beginning to kick in. They are the grace notes that really signal the beginning of this season's coda. Since June, every arena, every theater, every amphitheater and grassy bowl in the country has sponsored a festival, a jamboree or a concert series of some sort. Rock-and-roll retirees are giving it one more go wherever they can, and so are the senior citizens of hip-hop. Opera glimmers from upstate New York. The fringe binges downtown. Everyone in the middle tries to see ''The Seagull'' in the park. Summer is still what New Haven used to be -- a place to open out of town -- and it's also still the mainest of the mainstream.

title: Daring to Make a Love Story of Life's Last Chapter
description: THESE days, I can never look at a face without seeing the skull,'' says Andreas, the attractive 70-plus gentleman in Paul Cox's ''Innocence.'' He has just met his first love, Claire, for the first time in more than 40 years and wants mightily to see her again. ''But with you, there was no skull.'' It's an odd compliment, not just because it's a far cry from your usual seduction line, but because the thought of death occurs often and explicitly in Paul Cox's films, and not with a feeling of revulsion but one of acceptance, even welcome. Or at least complicity. The skull lurking behind a face, long-gone parents invading their offspring's dreams -- these shadows that death casts over life are what give the films of this most unusual director their unique, complex flavor of morbidity and joy, eroticism and sly humor.

title: Portraits Picked Out of The Crowd

Nor is the art world so willing as in the past to accept documentary images as factual accounts of the world. That photographs advance a hidden agenda is one of the clichs of postmodern critical theory.

title: Still Haywire
description: Brooke Hayward is Hollywood royalty. Her mother was Margaret Sullavan, the revered stage actress and star of the Hollywood golden age who was married to Henry Fonda and William Wyler before she married her agent, Leland Hayward. Leland, Brooke's father, was an ber agent whose client list included the likes of Katharine Hepburn, Greta Garbo, Judy Garland, Jimmy Stewart and Fred Astaire. Leland later produced Broadway hits like ''South Pacific'' and ''The Sound of Music.'' After their divorce, he married Slim Keith, who was previously married to Howard Hawks and inspired Lauren Bacall's character in ''To Have and Have Not.'' After Slim, Leland married Pamela Digby Churchill, Winston Churchill's daughter-in-law and later the mistress of Gianni Agnelli, the Prince Aly Khan and Baron Elie de Rothschild. After Leland died, Churchill married the powerful and ultrarich Averell Harriman, became the United States ambassador to France and died after swimming laps in the pool of the Ritz Hotel in Paris. While Brooke was growing up, her best friends were Jane and Peter Fonda, who later made ''Easy Rider'' with Brooke's brother Bill Hayward and her husband, Dennis Hopper -- the actor, director and American icon. Brooke and Dennis had a daughter, Marin. In 1977, Brooke wrote ''Haywire,'' a best-seller about her extraordinary family. She is now married to Eddie Duchin's son Peter, who was raised by Averell Harriman, who was later married to Brooke's stepmother, Pamela. Confused? Imagine what it's like for Marin.

title: Style; The White House
description: As fashion fables go, there is one that has been floating around about the morning that Anna Wintour, editor of American Vogue, and one of her editors, Hamish Bowles, met Madame Courrges, the woman behind the designer Andr Courrges. He's nearly 80 and retired, and spends his days painting and sculpturing, while she runs the house that many credit with changing the fashion silhouette. Courrges has been on the tip of every fashionista's tongue, so it's no surprise that Anna wanted to have ''coffee.'' When Anna and Hamish arrived, Madame Courrges introduced herself, served them their ''coffee'' and walked out -- never to be seen again. This is the rumor of how that meeting went, and it has been repeated over and over again, making Madame Courrges a kind of folk hero. Politically correct she's not. So, who is this mysterious Coqueline Courrges?

Following are some examples of the constructive criticism that might greet you going home, over the course of a lifetime. My mother would like you to know that these comments are not based on anything she's ever said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, DR. BREWSTER S.
description: MILLER-Dr. Brewster S. A retired, medical director died on Monday, August 6 while at his daughter's home in Mystic, CT of cancer. He was 82. Born in Winthrop, MA and raised in Springfield, MA, Dr. Miller graduated from Tufts University in 1941 and received his MD from Columbia University in 1944. After serving in the US Navy as a medical officer, he served as the Director of Professional Education, American Cancer Society from 1948 to 1958. From 1958 to 1969 he was Medical Director of the United Cerebral Palsy Association. At the time of his retirement in 1990, he was the Director of Medical Education, Somerset Hospital, Somerville, NJ. He also was Medical Director of the Greenfield Nursing Home, Eastern Star Nursing Home and the Somerset Neighborhood Health Clinic. Dr. Miller also held appointments as Medical Advisor, Buckeye Pipeline, New York City, Medical Director of Johnson & Johnson Baby Products, Lecturer in Surgery, New York Medical College and as a consultant for the Fellowship Program, Atomic Energy Commission, Washington, DC. He was also a member of the American Medical Association, Association of Hospital Directors of Medical Education where he served as President from 1977-79, American Academy of Cerebral Palsy and the American Association of Cancer Research. From 1960-69 he served as the Secretary, World Commission for Cerebral Palsy and a delegate to the National Health Council 1961-66. Dr. Miller and his wife Regina ''Bunny'' (Feeney) Miller, retired to Phoenix, AZ in 1991. Mrs. Miller passed away in January 2001. Dr. Miller was a world traveler, an avid swimmer and walker. Survivors include two sets of twins, Bruce of Belmont, MA, Douglas of Scottsdale, AZ, Pamela of Boonton, NJ and Linda of Mystic, CT, a brother, Wesson of West Hartford, CT and three grandsons. A private graveside service will be held in Peacham, VT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Tufts University, Medford, MA 02155 or the American Cancer Society.

title: Premieres and Pop-Up Creatures

He went on to create the New Jersey Film Festival, presented by the Rutgers Film Co-op/New Jersey Media Arts Center, which shows 100 films year round and has drawn about 15,000 viewers annually. title: ASBURY PARK SUIT
description: Asbury Park has finally ended a lawsuit that had blocked the redevelopment of its blighted oceanfront for nearly a decade, clearing the way for new construction by the end of the year, officials said. The city had awarded redevelopment rights to a Connecticut developer, Carabetta Enterprises Inc., in 1986 but the company declared bankruptcy in 1992, leaving 48 oceanfront properties under protection of the court. Under a settlement agreement approved by a federal bankruptcy court judge last week, the city agreed to transfer the rights to Ocean Front Acquisitions LLC of Lakewood and end all litigation with Carabetta by Oct. 1. The company is an affiliate of an investment group that bought tax liens on Mr. Carabetta's properties from the city for $6.5 million on Aug. 1. Kirsty Sucato

title: August 12-18; Shrine Visit Draws Fire

Bolstered by protests from China, Taiwan and Vietnam, South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung asked: ''How can we make friends with people who try to forget and ignore the many pains they inflicted on us?'' The Japanese leader responded on the 56th anniversary of Japan's defeat, calling on his country to ''maintain and develop friendly relations with our neighboring countries to build eternal peace in the world.'' But the anger in East Asia showed how far the Japanese lag behind the Germans, their World War II military partners, in reconciling with their neighbors. James Brooke

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; A Dessert That Is the Un-Goo
description: If your idea of dessert is a brownie fudge sundae, you probably haven't been to the Ice Hut in Hoboken. But one taste of its Italian ices will make a convert out of you. Trust me, I know: I never fell for anything but gooey chocolate desserts until I tried a humble cup of lemon ice. A cross between sorbet and a Slurpee, it tasted crisp and tart, without the typical syrupy sweetness of store-bought lemonade. Just as pleasing was the texture -- evenly frozen, with no spiky crystals and enough liquid to keep it smooth. The Ice Hut makes 14 flavors, six of which are sold daily. Lemon is the only constant, while watermelon, orange, cherry, chocolate and others rotate in weekly. Up to three flavors can be requested together in a seven-ounce medium ($1.75) or four flavors in a nine-ounce large ($2) at no extra charge. The Ice Hut also sells a parfait-like Combo Cooler ($2.50 medium; $3 large), with your choice of ice layered between chocolate or vanilla soft-serve ice cream. Order an orange ice with vanilla ice cream and it's an upscale Creamsicle, chocolate with chocolate and it's, well, there I go on my gooey chocolate dessert trail. The Ice Hut is open from April through early October. After that, the doors don't close. The rest of the year he sells soup at the same walk-up stand called -- what else? -- the Soup Hut.

title: CAPE MAY-LEWES FERRY DEBT
description: The Cape May-Lewes Ferry is swimming in debt and the agency that runs it may be forced to increase tolls to defray costs. The ferry, which plies the Delaware Bay between the two resort towns, lost $4.38 million last year and may have a deficit of $5 million this year, according to the Delaware River and Bay Authority, which runs the 37-year-old line. Last year, the ferry carried a record 32 million passengers for $59.5 million in revenue, but the authority said passenger count was down about one percent so far this year. The 17-mile ride costs between $18 and $20 a vehicle depending on the time of crossing. Robert Strauss

title: The Cheese Whiz

''But,'' the artist continues, ''the sandwich was disqualified from 'The Guinness Book of World Records' because they used multiple slices of bread instead of baking just two enormous pieces for the outside.'' Koons isn't usually a trivia expert on food, but grilled cheese sandwiches are a whole other thing. For Proust it was a cookie that conjured remembrances of things past; for Koons it is that slightly salty, very buttery taste of pan-fried bread and oozing melted cheese that makes him feel as if he's gone back home to his 50's childhood in York, Pa.

title: The Alchemy of OxyContin
description: Paul Tough's article (July 29) is thought provoking. It is a curious story, full of unforeseen -- even paradoxical -- consequences: Everyman's old Aunt Ethel and Uncle Al trading an extra scrip for money to pay for the rest of their meds and accidentally ''hooking'' the honky-tonk crowd on something that hoists it higher than heroin. Some beer, weed, a few Percs, then backing down from gobbling increasingly expensive pills by copping a little heroin! All compliments of the local pharmacy. This ''oxy'' thing may be a new lesson in decadence.

title: Buyer's Meeting With a Co-op Board
description: Q -- I am trying to sell my co-op in Great Neck, and the people buying it still have to get board approval. The husband, however, will not be able to meet with the board because he will be in South Korea for the next six months and will not return in the interim. Even though the wife has power of attorney, the board says the husband must be present at the board meeting. This is an all-cash deal, and the apartment is selling for only $100,000. I suggested that the meeting be conducted by video conferencing, but the board rejected the idea without providing a reason. I do not want to lose this deal. Do I have any legal rights in this situation? . . . Karen Genauer, Great Neck, N.Y.

title: So Just Whose Business Is This Anyway?
description: THERE'S a real-life mini-drama unfolding this summer in the waiting room of the Old Greenwich train station and it's as full of intrigue and passion as any of the beach-reading novels commuters devour as they ride the trains every day.

title: Rich States, Poor Cities and Mighty Suburbs; In Connecticut and New Jersey, Urban Poverty Confronts Leafy Affluence
description: On South Orange Avenue a decrepit stretch of liquor stores, ramshackle grocery marts, and darkened bars in Newark's impoverished West Ward -- the idea that New Jersey could be the wealthiest state in the nation seems not only far-fetched, but downright ludicrous.

title: August 12-18; Vast Dental Fraud in Miami
description: In a scheme that preys on Florida's most vulnerable citizens, more than a dozen dentists and nearly 100 other people have been recruiting children as young as 2 to become Medicaid dental patients and then billing the state for often unnecessary and unsafe treatments, according to the Florida Attorney General's office. The scam has been going on for years and continues to grow by word of mouth despite the arrests of more than 100 people for Medicaid fraud, child abduction and other charges, investigators say. Recruiters hired by dentists offer the youngsters $5, Pokmon cards and Happy Meals to have treatments ranging from cleanings and fillings to X-rays and extractions, often without parental consent. Dana Canedy

title: Political Briefing; Senator in Louisiana Eyes Governor's Job
description: Still another United States senator is thinking about running for governor. This time it is John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana.

title: More Teachers, Fewer Screamers, Among N.F.L.'s Coaches
description: Following the death of Minnesota Vikings offensive lineman Korey Stringer, the National Football League has been criticized for holding harsh summer training camps. That calamity, however, has overshadowed a recent movement that contradicts the notion that professional football practices -- either in the summer or in the fall -- are too tough on players.

title: Berkshires Mansion Preserves the Gilded Age
description: Built by a sister of J. P. Morgan, paneled in rare Cuban mahogany and spreading over 28,000 square feet, Ventfort Hall was the kind of opulent ''cottage'' that a century ago made Lenox, Mass., the Newport of the mountains. But income taxes and World War I consigned some Berkshire mansions to second lives as schools or resorts, while dooming others to the wrecking ball.

title: A Way to Hear Bach Intimately, if Barely
description: FIFTY years ago, pianists and harpsichordists traded insults like ''purist'' and ''inauthentic.'' Now famous pianists practice Bach on the harpsichord, and harpsichordists admit to liking Bach on the piano. With tensions eased, do we really want to consider claims for yet another Baroque keyboard instrument?

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARKIN, ALBERT J.
description: ARKIN-Albert J. April 17, 1909 to August 19, 1985. Dad, you and Mom are together. Rest in peace. Love, Joan

title: West Meets East
description: ESASHI

title: Nothing Wilts Genius Like a Surly Audience
description: AT a recent performance of a well-known playwright's not particularly well-received play, I scanned the faces of the crowd -- and they looked mean. It seemed as if someone had forced the audience to the theater at gunpoint. Could they have bought their tickets when it was thought the play would be a hit, and since it wasn't they were enduring the evening because money had already been spent? Or were they simply part of a growing trend of playgoing as blood sport, and attending the theater only for the purpose of returning home to bash it?

title: Jeanne Loriod, Who Transformed Electronic Wails Into Heartfelt Music, Dies at 73
description: Jeanne Loriod, whose artistry playing the ondes martenot, a rare electronic instrument known for its haunting wail, made her the instrument's most celebrated performer, died on Aug. 3 at Juan-les-Pins, France. She was 72.

title: A Nice Break At a Meeting
description: It's clear why the fruity, piquant 2000 Kanu chenin blanc, a South African summer quaffer, captivated members of the Society of Wine Educators at their summer conference in Oregon. Soft-textured, subtle, impeccably balanced and capable of a 15-minute finish, Kanu scores 91 on my 100-point scale.

description: To the Editor:
