description: This

title: August 12-18; Western Wildfire Action
description: As President Bush cleared away underbrush at a national park in Colorado, and two of his cabinet secretaries touted a 10-year strategy to reduce the impact of wildfires, nearly 20,000 firefighters battled blazes in six western states. Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton said there have been fewer fires so far this year compared with last, 55,300 to 67,500 -- still, enough for her to consider calling out several military battalions. And a new radio campaign will warn homeowners of the dangers of living close to forests, she said, featuring celebrities like Jackie Mason, Andy Williams and Wayne Newton to appeal, at least, to older listeners. Michael Janofsky

title: Uptown, girl!
description: In the glory days of the Harlem renaissance, folks used to say, ''I'd rather be a lamppost in Harlem than governor of Georgia.'' Kelis, hip-hop's new It Girl, would like to second that emotion. ''I was born here and would like to die here,'' the 22-year-old singer says. A brownstone baby, she's now got her own uptown digs. ''It's a neighborhood where children play and people go to work,'' she says. ''You get to know people. There's not much of a feeling of that in New York. When you find it, you feel it. It's special.''

title: Come Out. Come Down. Come Back. Being Ellen.
description: Among the many moves that have constituted Ellen DeGeneres's life, one stands out as the most difficult, at least until recently. She was 16. Previously, her sad caravan of a family had merely relocated within New Orleans every few years, each time just one or two neighborhoods away, though still far enough to require Ellen to negotiate a new school and assemble a new set of friends. All of which she did smoothly: she was a fitter-inner who read the social map compulsively and knew how to find her place on it. But this move was different. Her mother, having divorced Ellen's father and remarried, was taking Ellen to live with her in Atlanta, Tex.: 300 miles away, population 6,000, so different in scale and style from New Orleans that it must have seemed the Big Uneasy.

title: Cooperating for Art's Sake
description: THE Hammond Museum in North Salem, known for its Japanese Stroll Garden and an esoteric collection of fans, was struggling in the early 1990's, after the death of its founder, Natalie Hammond. Just when it seemed the museum would go under, help came in the form of a municipal challenge grant from the Westchester Arts Council.

title: Reviving a Downtown by Building Upward

title: The PC? That Old Thing?; An Industry's Founding Father Has Better Things to Do
description: ED Roberts still recalls the day in late 1975 when William H. Gates, the co-founder of Microsoft, walked into his office, anxious and depressed. A rail-thin young man with a voice that cracked when he was excited, Mr. Gates had just turned 20. People were stealing his software, he complained, and the prospects for his fledgling company appeared dim.

title: RISING HOME PRICES
description: Prices for existing homes in Bergen and Passaic Counties increased by 17 percent in the second quarter of the year over the same period last year, the third largest increase in the nation, according to a survey released last week by the National Association of Realtors. The biggest increases were in Sacramento, Calif., and Washington, D.C. The median existing home price in the Bergen-Passaic area was $276,800, sixth highest nationally. Of the New Jersey areas studied, the Middlesex-Somerset-Hunterdon area had the second largest increase with a 12.3 percent jump and a median price of $238,900. Karen DeMasters

description: GOLF fans do not need a television weatherman to tell which way the wind is blowing on a championship course. Unisys, the computer software and equipment company, has found a way to give them information about wind speed and direction -- among the most important and fickle elements of golf -- as they watch tournaments at home.

title: Are Old Sitcoms Viable Texts for Bible Study Class?
description: Readers were cautious but many endorsed the idea of using old sitcoms to help teach the bible. Nearly everyone had caveats but the general feeling was that it couldn't hurt. Those that felt that sitcoms were an ineffective teacher felt that it cheapened the bible to bring modern culture into the mix.

title: Placing Bids in Their Passion for Pigeons
description: A PIGEON auction is not exactly Sotheby's. Fans whirred in the basement at Carleton Feeds and Needs, a pet supply shop in Islip Terrace, on a recent Sunday morning. Sellers placed cartons and carriers stuffed with live pigeons along the dingy cinderblock walls, then sat with the bidders watching the flocks go on the block.

title: The Nation: Terminator; Making Rules in the World Between War and Peace
description: ''WE are facing an implacable enemy,'' the top-secret report to the president said. ''There are no rules in such a game. Hitherto acceptable norms of human conduct do not apply.''

title: Your Vote or Your Life: Ads Focus on Old Crime Fears
description: Wailing sirens and flashing lights. Graffiti-scarred walls. Yellow crime-scene tape. A purse snatched from a woman in a white dress. Desperate-looking characters pose for mug shots. Cops march suspects, hands cuffed behind their backs, toward a patrol car, and, in the background, paramedics wheel a body away on a gurney.

title: August 12-18; Prison Population Declines
description: In what could be the beginning of a major change in the criminal justice system, the number of inmates in state prisons fell in the second half of last year, the first such decline since the nation's prison boom began in 1972, a Justice Department report said. The decline was modest, a drop of 6,200 inmates in state prisons. But it came after the number of state prisoners soared 500 percent over the past three decades, bringing the total number of Americans incarcerated to 2,071,686. Fox Butterfield

title: Beware of Gifts From Well-Meaning Gardeners
description: THERE'S a gardener out in Wisconsin who hasn't spoken to me since I sent her home with a flat of houttuynia, a dense scrambler with triangular leaves marbled in cream and tinged by blush red, nearly alway harboring cute, cone-like white blossoms.

description: Cycling through New York has seldom been easier, with city agencies and others opening some 300 miles of bicycle paths since 1997. Riders can even peddle from Battery Park City to the George Washington Bridge with nary a stop sign.

title: Fewer Investment Clubs
description: Given the stock market carnage of the past 18 months, you might expect considerable thinning in the ranks of investment clubs. You would be right: the number of clubs has shrunk every month since February 2000 and now stands at 33,500, down from 36,600. But that 8.5 percent decline is considerably less than the 12.7 percent average 12-month decline suffered in the first half of the 1970's.

title: Rabbi Avrohom Pam, 88, Dean Of Orthodox Brooklyn Seminary
description: Rabbi Avrohom Pam, an elder of the Orthodox Jewish community in the United States, died early Friday at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 88 and lived in Flatbush.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEANE, HUGH GORDON, JR
description: DEANE-Hugh Gordon, Jr, 84, a journalist, died June 25. He wrote two books, ''Good Deeds and Gunboats'' and ''The Korean War 1945-1953'' and contributed to The Nation, Christian Science Monitor and others. He was a founder of the U.S.-China Peoples Friendship Association and chief editor of its U.S. China Review. After Harvard, he travelled to China and wrote a ten-part series for the Monitor reporting that the Quomintang was losing support. Ten years later, he was blacklisted, a victim of the notion that conspiring Americans had lost China. From 1960-1986, he was associate editor and then editor of the Hotel Voice, a union newspaper. In 1963, he wrote one of the first anti-war critiques in ''The War in Vietnam'' with a forward by Bertrand Russell. Born in Springfield, MA, he was a descendant of Francis Cooke, a member of the Mayflower company. He was preceded in death by his wife Beverley and his daughter Winifred Deane Goldblatt. Survivors include his sons, Gordon and Michael; a brother Richard and two grandchildren, Julian Goldblatt and Greta Deane . A memorial service will be held on September 23 at The Ethical Culture Society, 4 West 64th Street, New York City, at 1 PM.

title: Hidden Barriers to Health Coverage
description: THE best possible method for getting health insurance under the current system, of course, is to be gainfully employed by a company that offers coverage. That is not to suggest that all care is created equal. Some employers pay all the premiums, while some pay less than half. Some offer plain-vanilla H.M.O.'s, others a fuller range of plans. And some are strong voices for employees in disputes with insurers, while others do very little to help.

title: The Case For Buying Japanese Stocks
description: JAPAN seems adrift, a land without a plan.

description: Susanna Gale Poulson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Poulson Jr. of Cooperstown, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Louis Busch Hager Jr., the son of the late Mary Whitaker Mithoefer and the late Mr. Hager. Canon George F. French, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Mark Green's 'Crime' Spot
description: Mark Green, one of the four Democratic candidates for mayor, began running his second television commercial yesterday, less than a week after he ran his first one, which focused on education. This ad, titled ''Crime,'' is 30 seconds long and features former Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, who has endorsed Mr. Green.

title: Designer Bacteria May Have a Future in Fashion
description: IMAGINE a world in which your clothes do all the work, turning sweat, odor and maybe even pizza stains into clean, fresh-smelling laundry while freeing up your weekends for more important things.

title: The Alchemy of OxyContin
description: Paul Tough writes that Purdue Pharma is working on solutions to the problem of OxyContin diversion and abuse. In fact, a partial solution already exists and was used by the manufacturer of another oral narcotic, Talwin, which was being crushed for illicit intravenous abuse in the 1970's. Naloxone, a narcotic antagonist, could be incorporated into the OxyContin tablets. Narcotic antagonists reverse the effects of opiates but are effective only intravenously. The oral effect of OxyContin would not be changed. But when injected, Naloxone would prevent an opiate high and would precipitate opiate withdrawal in a regular opiate user. This is only a partial solution, since it would not interfere with intranasal abuse, which is so common with OxyContin.

title: Oprah of the Other Side
description: In almost every episode of his show, there is at least one occasion, often many, when John Edward communicates specific, detailed information that he could not possibly or plausibly be expected to have guessed (Chris Ballard, July 29). How he achieves this, I do not know. Talking with the dead? Sounds silly and unlikely and defies my sense of reason. Nevertheless, Edward's best ''readings'' are impressive. Furthermore, to dismiss Edward by pointing out that he has many more bad readings than good ones misses the point: just one scientifically unexplainable event is a phenomenon worthy of serious consideration. Unless there is enormous, professionally orchestrated fraud involved, which I doubt (nor do I believe has ever been alleged), there is simply no way to explain the best of Edward's results. Glib gibes don't help those of us who, because of unexplainable experiences of our own or simply healthy curiosity, are trying to make sense -- scientific sense, if possible -- of what is apparently a very wacky universe.

Survived by his wife Katharine of Stamford, CT, sons Richard C. of Coco Beach, FL, Stephen P. of Rockville Centre, LI, Peter T. of Norwalk, CT, Robert D. of Boston, MA, seven grandchildren and one greatgrandchild. Memorial Mass Tuesday 11 AM, St. Michael's Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT. Visitation Monday 7-9 PM, Hoyt Funeral Home, Main Street, New Canaan, CT. Contributions to Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH or the charity of ones choice.

title: In Neighborhoods Where the Ballet Is a Rare Flower
description: CLASSICAL music spills out onto a dull street in the Bronx, mingling with unexpected sweetness with the pungent sounds of merengue down the block. Just inside the Sherman Avenue Community Garden, the finishing touches are being put on the impromptu wood stage that has just gone up. Two sleek young ballet dancers arch and spin in rehearsal, watched not only by their choreographer but also by passers-by, a woman leaning out a window across the street and men and women of all ages who have gathered to see these exotic flowers growing in their community garden.

title: Lose a Seat, Win a Reward
description: MY mother, Susan Hagedorn, has honed flying free into an art form. Always looking for a deal, she figured out about 15 years ago that she could essentially sell her seat -- on certain flights, especially at certain times of the year -- for more than she paid. She simply approaches the ticket desk, asks to be put on the list of people willing to volunteer their seats, waits it out for a bit and walks away with flight vouchers, plus a trip out on the next flight.

title: Francesca Mills, Patrick Purcell Jr.
description: Francesca Anne Mills, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael T. Mills of Concord, Mass., was married yesterday to Patrick Joseph Purcell Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Purcell of Weston, Mass. The Rev. Paul O'Brien performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of the Holy Cross in Boston.

title: 3 Fodor's Guides Focus on Children
description: How does a child catch a brass ring on the merry-go-round at the Jardin du Luxembourg in Paris? Where in Toronto can you make your hair stand on end, literally, and also ring bells from an Asian temple? (No, not at the same time.) Where in the greater London area can one see eagles, falcons, hawks and herons?

title: Tired Punch Lines
description: To the Editor:

title: A Tall Cold One? Not Just Yet, Thanks
description: Even on a good day you can imagine him here, beside you on one of the red-upholstered stools. Him nursing a cold one, his scythe leaning against the counter. You trying to keep the conversation light, then giving up to watch cars flowing toward the gape of the Lincoln Tunnel.

title: A Mysterious Algonquin And Two Men's Obsessions
description: Ted Kazimiroff Jr. and Bobby Weinstein both have stories about striving to keep a story alive.

title: Winfield Honored by Yankees
description: The Yankees painted the number 31 along the first-base and third-base foul lines for Dave Winfield Day yesterday, an afternoon when Winfield said, ''Here's a day we thought we might not see, but it's here and it's beautiful.''

title: The Way We Live Now: The Ethicist; Hot Wheels
description: My son races go-carts with other 5- to 7-year-olds. At their beginner level, engines must be unaltered, but some fathers do illegal modifications to give their kids an edge. Short of taking apart every engine, officials can't know this. It's disheartening when my son says dejectedly, 'Dad, I'm trying as hard as I can, but I can't keep up.' Do I tell him the truth and jeopardize his friendships with innocent kids who don't know what their dads have done, or do I keep quiet and leave him frustrated but honorable? -- Bob Jordan, Mahwah, N.J.

title: Linda Muri, Mattison Crowe
description: Linda Ellen Muri and Mattison Clark Crowe were married yesterday by the Rev. James Walworth, an Episcopal priest, at the Anabel Taylor Chapel of Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Seeking White Whales From a Distance
description: PART of the thrill of spotting a beluga whale in the Saguenay Fjord of Quebec is that it's mildly illicit. Under Canadian law, you're not allowed to set out in search of belugas by boat in that region, about 130 miles northeast of Quebec City. If you accidentally happen upon one, you must immediately steer a wide (and slow) course away from it, remaining at least 1,250 feet distant.

title: In New Jersey, a Plea for Patience Amid E-ZPass Troubles
description: E-ZPass is an unmitigated disaster, a bloated, bureaucratic, torture implement devised to slow New Jersey motorists down and then subject them to erroneous violations and egregious fines.

title: Battered and Smothered
description: IF a menu contains the words smothered, covered, battered and fried, it's likely that the food is traditional Southern/soul. At Delta's, it's a certainty. You can eat fried crayfish for an appetizer and fried catfish for dinner. You choose two sides with your entree, and the sides include macaroni and cheese and collard greens.

title: An Exhibition That Emphasizes the 'Work' in Artwork
description: ON some level, art is supposed to offer a respite from work, but in the word ''artwork,'' they are linked. ''Curious Images From the Workplace,'' an exhibition at the Blue Hill Art and Cultural Center, further examines their interaction. That the show is presented in a large office complex adds to its immediacy.

title: Changing the Board in Boardwalk to Plastic
description: IT'S probably not what the Drifters had in mind when their hit ''Under the Boardwalk'' turned these seaside esplanades into icons of summer romance. But through the efforts of two high school seniors and a tiny nonprofit Brooklyn group called Rainforest Relief, Long Island's boardwalks are being built of anything but the rare tropical hardwood that is commonly used along waterfronts elsewhere.

title: A Reverend of Small Things Finds a Place to House Them
description: Within blocks of the Williamsburg Bridge, under which nary a troll doth dwell, dozens of wild-haired creatures reside peacefully in the kingdom of the Lower East Side.

title: He Said What He Meant. Did He Mean What He Said?
description: When you step into the voting booth on Election Day, do you cast your vote based on what a candidate says he'll do or what you actually think he's going to do?

title: The Bath To Enlightenment
description: It was available only in Europe, so chances are you discovered it on your first trip -- maybe junior year abroad -- and brought home several cartons; and traveling friends would bring it back to you in their luggage. Sometimes, feeling generous, you would wrap the neat rectangular box, knowing your gift would mark you as a sophisticated and worldly, yet caring, person of impeccable taste.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMARICO, JAMES MICHAEL, MD.
description: POMARICO-James Michael, MD. Age 64, of New York City, died on Wednesday, August 15, 2001 in Presbyterian Hospital, NY. Dr. Pomarico attended the Columbus Boys Choir School in Princeton, NJ in the early stage of the school's development. As a student he traveled throughout the U.S. with the choir as a pianist. He continued his pursuit of music into his adult life and was a longtime member of the Metropolitan Opera Club. Dr. Pomarico graduated from the University of Pittsburgh with his Bachelor of Science degree, and then furthered his education to receive his medical degree. He interned at St. Vincent's Medical Center of NY, and then became a resident at Mt. Sinai Hospital in NY. After his training, he maintained a private practice in Otolaryngology on 61st St. in Manhattan. His musical knowledge combined with his medical skills led him to treating many patients from the musical and operatic world. Dr. Pomarico also served in the US Army Medical Reserves in the late 1960's. Jim leaves behind many loving family members and close friends. Services will be held Monday 10:30 AM in the Lesko Funeral Home, 1209 Post Rd in Fairfield, CT and 11AM at St. Anthony of Padua Church, 197 S. Pine Creek Road, Fairfield. Interment in Oak Lawn Cemetery, Fairfield. Friends may greet the family on Sunday from 4-8 PM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, E. DOUGLAS, PH.D.
description: DEAN-E. Douglas, Ph.D. August 15, 2001. The Board and members of the American Society for Psychical Research (ASPR) mourn the passing of E. Douglas Dean, Ph.D. Dr. Dean was a much beloved man of science who will be greatly missed; his wisdom, graciousness and lifetime commitment to research will not be forgotten. Memorial services will be held at the ASPR and at the Princeton Religious Society of Friends in the fall. Patrice Keane, Executive Dir.

title: The Other Route to Home Run History
description: OVER the last few seasons, the exploits of home-run heroes like Mark McGwire, Sammy Sosa and Barry Bonds have been baseball's dominant dramas. The amount of ink spilled on these Ruthian runs at long ball immortality seems to have made the homer slugged by a player not aiming at 50 or 60 less exciting to fans.

title: Armed and Friendly
description: Oswald, a roly-poly blue octopus with the voice of Fred Savage is the star of a new animated series for preschoolers that has its premiere tomorrow at 8 p.m. on Nickelodeon before settling into its daily 10:30 a.m. slot on Tuesdays. In the first episode, Oswald and friends (Henry the fastidious penguin; Daisy the daring flower; and Oswald's loyal dog, Weenie) chase down an ice cream truck and find that even a rainy day doesn't have to ruin a camping trip.

title: It Girl, Interrupted
description: Beverly Hills, 1976: Andy Warhol was in his element, surrounded by the biggest names in fashion, art, cinema and finance, as well as by Europeans with blood in various shades of blue. The Marchesa Cacciapuoti di Giugliano (better known as Gogo Schiaparelli) and her aviaphobe second husband, Gino, had traveled for weeks by land and by sea from Paris for the wedding of her eldest daughter, the former Vogue cover girl Marisa Berenson. A sometime actress and full-time beauty, 29-year-old Marisa (pronounced mah-REE-za) was the regnant queen of the international jet set, who had found her king in the industrialist James H. Randall, 32. The setting for this Hollywood hitchin' was suitably de trop: the swimming pool was covered with flowers, the altar in white leatherette; George Hamilton was the best man. Oblivious to the mayhem, the assiduously tanned designer Valentino calmly ironed the off-the-shoulder gown he'd created for the celebrated bride. Warhol snapped away for a behind-the-scenes book he was doing on the wedding, while Rona Barrett grilled guests like Jack and Anjelica for a television special on the event.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIS, CLAUDIA L., PH.D.
description: LEWIS-Claudia L., Ph.D. Died on August 9, 2001, in Newtown, PA, at the age of 93. Author, poet and teacher with a long, distinguished career as a professor at Bank Street College. She also gave courses at the New School in NYC, and workshops throughout the United States. Dr. Lewis received her Ph.D. from Teachers College, Columbia University and an honorary doctorate from Bank Street College. A ''Claudia Lewis Award in Poetry'' was established by Bank Street in her honor. Dr. Lewis authored several highly acclaimed books of poetry for young children, a book on writing for young children and anthropological studies of families of other cultures. Her final works were books of autobiographical poems about growing up with her family in Oregon. Dr. Lewis will be remembered as having a profound influence on the education of young children and on the literature for young children. She will be mourned by her professional colleagues, her former students, her family and her friends. She is survived by her brothers, Col. Hubert duBois Lewis, USA retired, of Marshall, TX, and Paul A. Lewis of Santa Barbara, CA, her sister Josephine Lewis Utley, of Seattle, WA, and many caring nieces and nephews. At Dr. Lewis's request, no memorial service will be held. Gifts in her memory may be sent to Bank Street College, NYC.

title: Playing Catcher, Stealing Secrets
description: Princeton graduate, major league baseball catcher and spy, Newark-born Moe Berg led a double life for many years as he spied on the Japanese and Germans for the government before World War II as he went on baseball tours around the world. Berg, who played for the White Sox, Red Sox and Senators, was a glamorous and popular figure who spoke nine languages, but had fallen into obscurity by the time he died in Newark in 1972. Today he is ''absolutely forgotten,'' according to Vivian Grey, who wrote a young people's book about him called ''The Spy Behind Home Plate'' (Jewish Publication Society, 1997) and will give a free lecture about Mr. Berg Tuesday at the Long Beach Island Foundation of Arts and Sciences, 120 Long Beach Boulevard in Loveladies. title: Can Eastern European singers solve opera's problems here?

Rare, that is, at least since its reigning czar, Valery Gergiev, took over in 1988, capitalizing on the spirit of perestroika that was sweeping Russia. The institution had taken repeated critical batterings during the Communist era, when it was forced to play poor relation to the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow. Ever since Mr. Gergiev's ascension, the Kirov has been seen to carry the cultural banner for Russia. But during a brief residency at the Royal Opera House here last month, it severely tarnished its reputation with the public and critics alike, and the sometimes hostile reception must have shocked a company more accustomed to accolades.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Downhill to Here
description: Trash, bare trees and granite skies; ragtag children and worn-out adults. The setting is Dorchester, Mass., its deteriorating buildings fronting on splotched and cracked sidewalks. In the mid-1970's, a young photographer, Eugene Richards, returned home to this working-class Boston neighborhood to photograph the life around him -- on the street, in bars, in empty lots, and, when he could wangle it, inside homes. The population had changed since he was a child, with a new wave of immigrants, so though Richards was not technically an outsider, neither was he an insider. He photographed in black and white, using a bare-bones, no-nonsense style, and he set about creating a body of work that would bear witness to the time and place. This included racial conflict, the passing of the older generation, social alienation and urban decline. In 1978, he self-published a book from his Dorchester photos. It marked the beginning of his distinguished career as a documentarian of the poor and alienated. Now DORCHESTER DAYS (Phaidon, $39.95) has been republished, recovered and refurbished. The new edition benefits from additional images as well as greatly improved design and printing. Artful touches, like text written in the photographer's hand, have also been added. The result is a book that is much more accessible to contemporary readers, but with the original photographs' rawness and intensity left intact. Rosemary Ranck

title: Christie Todd Whitman May Have the Most Thankless Job in Washington

The stadium rises atop a cleaned-up toxic-waste site and is the kind of place administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency go. It's a glinting citadel of the new and well made, wedged among boarded-up factories. But there is no crowd waiting, only a few baseball staff members. When she was governor of New Jersey, Whitman caused a stir wherever she went; many expected her to ascend either to the United States Senate or to the vice-presidential slot on the 2000 Republican ticket. Instead she now visits toxic-waste sites. ''At least today is a clean day,'' Whitman notes. Often when she travels to inspect something, it's garbage or ooze or worse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, PHILIP WALSH
description: MOORE-Philip Walsh. Died July 18, 2001, of cancer at Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. Graduated Princeton University Magna Cum Laude in 1942. Enlisted in U.S. Navy 1941 and served as commanding officer of a sub-chaser in both the Atlantic and Pacific. Phi Beta Kappa Junior year, Lyman Biddle Scholar 1942. Captain of undefeated Princeton Tennis Team, selected for Junior and Senior Davis Cup Teams/MBA from New York University 1950. Security analyst at First Boston Corporation, then Assistant to President of Schroeder Rockefeller & Co. Founded First Research Company (Miami/ firm acquired by J & W Seligman Moore). Served as President of Valuation Division of Seligman. In 1996 he was chosen to make the final valuation of the Zapruder film and set the valuation at $16,000,000. Moore was listed in Who's Who in America and Who's Who in Finance and Industry; also served as economic adviser to Florida Governer LeRoy Collins (1956-60) and as economic adviser to Archbishop Coleman Carroll, Diocese of Miami (1959-72). From 1955 to 1960 he served as Honorary Consul to the French Republic in Florida, and was also a member of the Administrative Committee of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts in New York City and was a member of the Downtown Association of New York. He is survived by a daughter, three sons, a sister and his widow Phaedra. He was a member of the Ponte Vedra Club, the Sawgrass Country Club and the River Club of Jacksonville, Florida.

He was born in NYC, on January 27, 1938. Ken grew up in Scarsdale, NY, and Westfield, NJ. He graduated from Bucknell University and was Lt. (jg) in the US Navy from 1961 until 1965. He served as the Director of the Domestic Council under Presidents Nixon and Ford. Ken enjoyed his summers in Willsboro, NY, where he was a member of St. John's Episcopal Church. He wintered in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. His sport of choice was golf, which he loved only second to his family. He is survived by his wife Marilyn (Slifer) Cole, two daughters and their husbands, Corinne and Robert Ryan of Charlotte, NC, and Megan and Kirk Kellogg of Summit, NJ. He is also survived by two sisters and their husbands, Priscilla and Thomas Perkins of Terrell, NC, Connie Cole and Donald Lidstrand of Denville, NJ, one brother and his wife Brady and Margaret Cole of Corinth, VT, and five grandchildren Aletta, Claire and Reese Ryan and Charlie and Caroline Kellogg. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Essex, NY, Monday, August 20, 2001, at 2 PM. In remembance of Ken, those who wish may make a contribution to the charity of their choice or St. John's Episcopal Church, Essex, NY, or the Smith House Health Care Center, Willsboro, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCALEER, JOSEPH J.
description: McALEER-Joseph J. Died on August 17, 2001, in Greenwich, CT, at the age of 72 after a courageous battle with cancer. Loving and devoted father of four sons, Andrew, Gregory, Joseph, Jr., and David; loving and devoted father-in-law to Valerie and Christina; loving and devoted grandfather to Stephanie Hope. Beloved husband for five years of Frances; beloved husband of 30 years of Hope Marie (deceased). Born July 12, 1929, in New York City, he was the son of the late Joseph E. and Mary McAleer. He attended All Hallows Institute High School in New York City, and obtained bachelor's and master's degrees from the City College of New York. He served in the U.S. Army from 1952-1954 during the Korean War. From 1955 until his death he was a shipbroker. He was founder and partner of two successful ship brokerage firms, Long, Quinn & McAleer (LQM) Associates, Inc., in New York City, and MCA Associates, Inc., in Greenwich, CT. He was an active and dedicated member of many boards and charities. He served on the board of trustees of Fairfield University in Fairfield, CT, and the American Merchant Marine Museum, Kings Point, NY. He was a former director of the Association of Shipbrokers and Agents and the Connecticut Maritime Association. He was founder and president of the Partners Circle of the Salesian Sisters of Saint John Bosco in North Haledon, NJ, where he worked tirelessly to encourage financial support for elderly and infirm nuns. A devout Roman Catholic, he was a member of Saint Michael the Archangel Parish in Greenwich, CT. His kindness and generosity to everyone he met knew no bounds. Calling hours are 4 to 8 PM on Tuesday, August 21, at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11 AM on Wednesday, August 22, at Saint Michael the Archangel Church, 469 North Street, Greenwich, CT, followed by interment at Saint Mary Cemetery, Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Salesian Sisters of Saint John Bosco, 659 Belmont Avenue, North Haledon, NJ 07508, or to the Nursing Oncology Fund of Greenwich Hospital, 5 Perryridge Road, Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: Inmate's Chosen Means of Execution Starts New Debate
description: As he waits on death row, John W. Byrd Jr. is attracting attention by demanding what he deems the grislier of his life's two remaining options. He is insisting on the electric chair rather than lethal injection as the more graphic way to demonstrate the cruelty of capital punishment in the face of his self-proclaimed innocence.

title: Corrections

title: Packed Race For an Office Few Voters Understand
description: In this most crowded of primary seasons, no major race is shaping up to be more crowded than that for public advocate, a position that has existed for less than a decade. But even though so many candidates are aspiring to an office that sometimes looks as if it involves little more than needling the mayor, few New Yorkers seem to know or care who any of the contenders are.

title: Debate Over National Monument Emphasizes Old West-New West Divide
description: On a treeless, sun-baked hill near here where two rivers flow together, the explorers Meriwether Lewis and William Clark came to a critical decision in 1805: they would follow the Missouri River and not the Marias in their quest for the Northwest Passage. The call was the right one, for the Missouri led to the headwaters they sought.

She was a devoted mother to Mabel Brodell, Eleanore Bass and the late Jerry Gordon. Loving mother-in-law to Dr. Robert Bass, Irwin Brodell and Adrienne Gordon. title: E-Commerce Report; Some businesses are starting to seek out dot-coms for new ventures.
description: FOR those who appreciate balance, e-commerce is playing out nicely. Having made public nuisances of themselves in the first half of 1998 and all of 1999 -- with all the ads, all the media attention, all the initial offerings -- e-commerce companies for the last 18 months have found their pleas for attention largely ignored by investors and executives waiting to see which players might survive the shakeout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEEDS, SYLVIA S.
description: LEEDS-Sylvia S. Died August 16, 2001. Cherished and loving wife of Charles Leeds and last surviving child of Morris and Sadie Smith, a succesful coutourier on lower 2nd Avenue until the 1920s. Sylvia graduated as an English major from Hunter College in 1933, but, because of the depression was unable to start her career as a teacher of English until 1937 at Manhattan Vocational High School. After her first husband, Stanley Feldman, died at 40, she was responsible for the care of Theodore, their son, at a time when facilities for people with disabilities were exclusively institutional. When ultimately Teddy was accepted by the Young Adult Institute into their expanding programs, she became president of its Family Association and a trustee of the New York League for Early Learning. In her leisure she was an avid reader and devoted to movies, theater, travel, good conversation and intensive friendships. Her philosophy was always to strive, to seek, to find and not to yield. There will be a service for Sylvia on Tuesday, August 21, 2:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY.

Barber, who has a broken left hand, wore a protective cast when he resumed practice Saturday. These were noncontact drills, but why take a chance by staying in blue?

title: TALKING POLITICS: Greenwich Village and SoHo; Concerns About Maintaining Successes of the Giuliani Era
description: Richard Fitzgerald, a 49-year-old chauffeur who lives in Greenwich Village, was settled on a bench on a hot and muggy morning in Washington Square Park the other day. A police officer on a horse clip-clopped up a path to the side. Children crowded a playground, while dog owners ran their unleashed pets through a fenced-in field.

title: Percussive Family Shares Traditions Of Africa
description: African drumming echoed off the glass and stone of Lincoln Center on Wednesday evening when Badenya les Frres Coulibaly, from Burkina Faso, played songs that carry venerable advice in a lattice of percussion. Badenya means family in the Bwaba language, and the group includes three brothers and their three nephews and a niece, all from a family of griots. Its songs have more rhythmic dimensions than the Cowsills or the von Trapp family could imagine.

title: A Dynamic Actor Mixes Versatility With Aplomb

By contrast Bryant Park, where the concerts have been moved during the museum's renovations, is a decidedly metropolitan setting, where the music plays against a background of passing buses, the neon of fast-food joints and a gentle hum of traffic.

title: New York's Art Wars Continue
description: By now it should be transparently clear to the Giuliani administration that it is not going to win the battle to require street artists to obtain permits before selling their wares on the streets or in certain park spaces. It has lost this fight at nearly every court level and usually for the same reasons -- that licenses are inconsistent with city law and with the broader purposes of the First Amendment. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, stubborn as usual, plans to appeal. He would be much better advised to let the artists go about their business while exercising the city's uncontested, legitimate right to decide where and when the vendors operate so that they do not pose crowding or public safety problems.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Cruise Ship Loses Power
description: A cruise ship carrying more than 1,400 passengers and crew lost power and stalled off Coney Island last night, according to the Coast Guard. The ship, The Regal Empress, blocked part of the Port of New York for several hours after an oil leak was discovered in its engine room around 6:10 p.m. The ship, which is owned by Regal Cruises Limited, drifted after its engines were shut off then anchored until the oil leak could be repaired. A Coast Guard spokesman said the vessel was declared safe around 11:30 p.m. and continued its voyage to Newport, R.I., part of a East Coast tour. There were no injuries. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: Ransom for a Stolen Chagall: An Israeli-Palestinian Peace

The theft was discovered the morning after the museum held a cocktail reception attended by more than 200 potential witnesses, and the painting vanished with little trace other than a lone metal screw that was left on the carpet.

title: Buddhist Shrine Is Consecrated in Colorado
description: The largest project undertaken by native-born Americans who have embraced Buddhism, a 108-foot-tall stupa, or domed shrine, was consecrated in a Rocky Mountain valley in Colorado. The monument, the Great Stupa of Dharmakaya, contains the ashes of Chogyam Trungpa Rinpoche, a Tibetan exile who brought Buddhist teachings to the West in the 70's. For some, the stupa symbolizes a new stage in Buddhism's American development. ''It seems to me, in the 70's, Buddhism was more of a sect,'' said Judith Simmer-Brown, chairwoman of religious studies at Naropa University in Boulder, Colo. ''Now, we're moving into a culture and a civilization.'' A12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROCKIE, EDWARD SIMMONS, JR.
description: BROCKIE-Edward Simmons, Jr. Died on August 15, 2001, at the age of 75 in West Barnstable, MA. Formerly of Englewood, NJ; he also resided in Vero Beach, FL. He attended the Englewood School for Boys, and was a graduate of Phillips Andover Academy, Andover, MA. Upon graduation from Yale University in 1946, he was commissioned as an Ensign, redeploying returning personnel from the Pacific at San Francisco's Treasure Island. In 1947 he began his insurance career with the INA, where his grandfather once served on the Board of Directors. He soon followed his father to R.C. Rathbone & Son, a well-known New York insurance broker. His accomplishments and abilities were quickly recognized when Fred S. James acquired R.C. Rathbone in 1968. At age 45, he was elected to the Fred S. James Board of Directors and served as President of their New York Office. After 41 years in the brokerage business, Mr. Brockie retired from Alexander & Alexander New York in 1988. He served as a councilman in Englewood, NJ; was both a committee chairman for the construction of the Englewood Public Library, as well as a chairman of the Yale Alumnae Scholarship Committee of Bergen County. His participation and love of sports remained with him throughout his life. He was a member of Pine Valley Golf Club, New York Yacht Club, John's Island Club, Knickerbocker C.C. and the Kittannsett Club. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Janice Murray; and four children, Janine B. McKee of Tenafly, NJ; Edward Simmons Brockie III of Danville, CA; Douglas M. Brockie of Englewood, NJ; Margaret B. Hill of West Barnstable, MA; and eight grandchildren: Alida and Jeannette McKee; Kate, Lauren, Jane and Ted Brockie; Rebecca and Ashley Hill; also his sister Margaret B. Escher of Englewood, NJ, brother Arthur H. Brockie II of Melbourne, FL, and predeceased by his sister Dorothy Brockie. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, September 15, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, NJ. Contributions may be made to Davenport-Mugar Cancer Center, Cape Cod Hospital, 4 Bayview Street, Hyannis, MA 02601, in memory of Edward S. Brockie, Jr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, ARNOLD BERNARD
description: PERRY-Arnold Bernard. Born April 25, 1925. Died August 17, 2001. Arnold Perry passed away at the age of 76 after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his beloved wife Muriel (Sonnenblick) Perry; his three children, David Mark Perry, Richard Cayne Perry and Jennifer Dana Perry; and his five grandchildren, Samantha, David, Amanda, Cameron and William Perry. Arnold was raised in Chicago, Illinois, and Muncie, Indiana. He graduated from the University of Indiana, where he was President of his fraternity. During World War II, he served as an officer within the Seabees division of the US Navy in the Philippines and New Guinea. As an adult, Arnold lived in Chicago, Los Angeles and New York. He was formerly CEO of Bohn Rex-Rotary and the principal owner of Me-Books Publishing Company. He had many dear friends and he will be missed. The funeral service is private. A memorial service will occur at the Beverly Hills Tennis Club on Tuesday, August 21, at 3:30 PM. The family requests that all contributions be made to the American Cancer Society.

Boys Town Jerusalem mourns with profound sorrow the passing of Mrs. Ruth Goldstein, mother of Mr. Michael Goldstein, whose generous support has enabled Boys Town to fulfill its mission of turning young boys from limited backgrounds into young men with limitless futures. We extend heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Rabbi Moshe Linchner, Dean Michael J. Scharf, President Raphael Benaroya, Chairman Josh S. Weston Honorary Chairman Rabbi Ronald Gray, Exec. V.P.

title: Stem Cell Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Dispute Over Christians
description: Christian leaders and the opposition Congress Party criticized Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee for saying that some missionaries were improperly offering welfare services to the poor in the hopes of converting them. They said his remarks would worsen the insecurity of the country's tiny Christian minority, which has been the object of attacks in recent years. Some Christians blame Hindu nationalist groups associated with Mr. Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party for inflaming anti-Christian sentiments.

title: Survey Indicates Business Travel May Pick Up
description: The sharp drop in business travel may be beginning to bottom out, a survey of travel managers indicated yesterday, but experts in the $185-billion-a-year industry warned that strong growth is unlikely to return for quite a while to airlines and hotels that cater to the corporate market.

title: A Beard Doesn't Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel and Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Violence In Workplace Deaths
description: Violent acts caused a high proportion of on-the-job deaths in New York City last year, but the overall number of workplace fatalities fell sharply, according to new data from the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. The number of fatal occupational injuries fell 7.5 percent last year, to 111 from 120; nationally, such deaths fell by about 2 percent, the bureau said. But 52 percent of these fatalities in New York City were caused by violence, a percentage second only to the District of Columbia's 62 percent. Nationally, highway accidents are the leading cause of on-the-job deaths. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALISCH, BUDD
description: CALISCH-Budd, 76, died at his home in Manhattan, August 3, 2001 after a lengthy illness. He was diagnosed with throat cancer in 1993. Budd Calisch was a prominent New York public relations and event planning specialist. His company represented many wellknown brands and companies and organized some of the city's major charity events. Mr. Calisch was born and raised in Toledo, Ohio. He lived in Paris during the early 1950's before moving to New York in 1955. He will long be remembered and missed by his many friends.

title: The Pain of Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNHARDT, MORTIMER
description: BERNHARDT-Mortimer, 81, of West Bloomfield, MI, died August 16, 2001. He was a jewelry dealer for 50 years. He is survived by his wife Jacqueline Bernhardt, sons Ric (Gail) Bernhardt, Greg Bernhardt, and granddaughter Justine Bernhardt. Graveside services today 10:30 AM at Beth Kehillah Cemetery in Egg Harbor, NJ.

title: Tiny Island Offers View Into Lives of Rare Birds
description: Motoring slowly across Long Island Sound, about an hour out of Niantic, Conn., the fishing boat comes upon hundreds of birds, diving headlong into the water in pursuit of small fish. It is a sign that the boat, and the researchers and volunteers on board, is nearing Great Gull Island.

title: Metro Briefing | Calendar: Today: Buffer Zone For Abortion Protesters
description: The City Council has scheduled a public hearing on expanding a 1994 law banning harassment by abortion protesters of patients and staff at clinics. The amendment would set a 10-foot buffer zone between protesters and those entering clinics. Council Chambers, City Hall, 10:30 a.m. Information: (212) 788-6850.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLINER, OSCAR
description: BERLINER-Oscar. On August 19, 2001. Beloved father of Alan and Lynn Silver. Loving grandfather of Jade and Starr Silver. Services Wednesday, 1 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: For Palestinians, a Daily, Dirty Obstacle Course
description: This is where the miserable part of Dr. Dima Amin's day kicks in, on the stretch of broken road running past a Palestinian refugee camp. This is where she finds out if it will take forever for her to get to work in Jerusalem, or just horribly long.

title: 'SportsCenter' Trips On Feeble Crossover
description: A few years ago, a spot in ESPN's ''This Is SportsCenter'' advertising campaign found the anchor Charley Steiner trading in his job to become a pool boy on ''Melrose Place,'' while the ''Melrose Place'' star Andrew Shue became a sports anchor.

title: A Male's Advantage From the Start
description: Baby boys with twin sisters tend to weigh more at birth than their sisters, and also more than twins who are both male.

title: The Pain of Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Do Unruly Kids Need Drugs?
description: To the Editor:

title: At Home Corp. Dealt Blow As Auditors Doubt Future
description: In papers filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Excite@Home, independent auditors reported that they had ''substantial doubt'' about the financial viability of the company, a once mighty Internet portal turned broadband provider, which has been battered by the downturn in online advertising.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Liberty Laments Giving Sol a Second Shot
description: The morning after it suffered a second-half breakdown and lost a crucial W.N.B.A. playoff game to the Miami Sol, the Liberty still had not fully recovered from the shock.

title: Support for Pets' Owners
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAZELL, HONORABLE MICHAEL P.
description: BAZELL-Honorable Michael P., passed away peacefully in San Francisco at UCSF on August 19th, 2001. Survived by his wife Jeannine, his children Jacelyn, Andrew, Frederika, Paul, Diana, Julie, Mario and Janine; his grandchildren Danielle, Jillian, Vanessa, Aimee and Matthew. He was dedicated to the legal profession as an attorney for fifty years and as an Administrative Law Judge for the Office of Hearings and Appeals in Los Angeles and Oakland. This special man will be greatly missed by those whose lives he touched. In memory of Judge Bazell, contributions may be made to the UCSF Foundation, Attention: Cardiac Care Unit, 44 Montgomery St., Suite 2200, San Francisco, CA 94104. Private services will be held.

title: Offense Is Going Nowhere For Frustrated MetroStars
description: There is a great deal of concern around the MetroStars about the team's lack of production. After the MetroStars' 1-0 loss to Columbus on Sunday, Coach OCTAVIO ZAMBRANO said the team's morale was at its lowest point of the season. After the game, a frustrated DANIEL HERNANDEZ, a defender, pointed the finger at the team's offense and ADOLFO VALENCIA.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: An Album Debut On AOL Site
description: Weeks before its retail release, an eagerly awaited album had its debut yesterday on Spinner.com, an Internet music service owned by AOL Time Warner. The unusual move for the recording industry involved the album ''Get Ready'' from the British synth-pop band New Order. It is scheduled for release in stores Oct. 16. Recording companies have avoided releasing early versions on the Internet, fearing that they would hurt sales and encourage piracy. As part of the release on Spinner.com, the album is being streamed in its entirety from Aug. 20 through Aug. 27. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: F.B.I.'s Inquiry In Cole Attack Is Nearing Halt
description: More than 10 months after two Arabic-speaking suicide bombers attacked the destroyer Cole in Aden, killing 17 American sailors, an F.B.I. investigation has virtually ground to a halt because Yemen has refused repeated American requests to widen the inquiry to include Islamic militant groups in Yemen.

title: Blind Player Finds the Gridiron Is a Safe Place
description: He trots onto the field with a teammate, side by side, touching occasionally until he finds his spot at guard. A football field for him is a safe place, he said, because there are no obstacles, no potholes, no 4-foot drops. Just flat and open. Nice.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Scott Gardner and Alfredo Muccino were named president and creative director, respectively, at Liquid Agency, San Jose, Calif., a new shop specializing in branding. Both had been executives at a San Jose office of Full Moon Interactive, which was acquired by Fusion Networks; Mr. Gardner had been managing director and Mr. Muccino had been chief creative officer.

title: Rare Alligator Is Threatened As China Feeds Its People
description: In China, the dragon is a symbol of royal power and good fortune, a creature so revered that it symbolizes the nation itself and is considered the mythical ancestor of all its people. Yet while China's imaginary dragons thrive in art and folklore, what could be called the country's only living dragon appears to be in serious trouble.

title: Clinton and Barak Discuss Rich Pardon in a Transcript
description: The Republican chairman of a House committee today released transcripts of telephone conversations that President Bill Clinton held in his final days in office with Ehud Barak, then the prime minister of Israel, about Marc Rich, a fugitive commodities trader.

title: BOEING TO EXPAND FACTORY WHERE SATELLITES ARE MADE
description: The Boeing Company will expand a factory in El Segundo, Calif., by about 30 percent as it transfers work from another plant. The factory has orders for more than 38 satellites and will add 12 Air Force satellites that previously were to be made in Seal Beach, Calif., Boeing said. The company acquired the El Segundo factory when it bought the Hughes Electronics Corporation's satellite-making business last year. Boeing said at the time that it would probably shift work to the Hughes plant, near Los Angeles, from Seal Beach. The Seal Beach plant had been unused, so there is no effect on jobs, a Boeing spokesman, George Torres, said.

title: Ex-Umps' Fate Hinges On Meeting This Week
description: A face-to-face meeting between Richie Phillips and Major League Baseball officials this week will determine the fate of the 22 umpires who have been trying to get their jobs back for two years. If Phillips agrees to drop his lawsuit against Commissioner Bud Selig and other officials, 10 of the 22 will be rehired and the others will receive financial settlements.

title: The Voting Booth at the Kitchen Table
description: The serious flaws that plagued some states in the 2000 presidential election have led to a string of well-intentioned calls for creating national standards in federal elections -- the latest being yesterday's report on voting irregularities issued by Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee. But as these various proposals get translated into potential laws, we must be careful not to fix what isn't broken.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Money Flowed From Stock Funds in July
description: Investors pulled $1.5 billion out of stock funds based in the United States during July, the first monthly outflows since March, while bond funds netted $7 billion, the most since January, a mutual fund research firm estimated.

title: Sell Peace, Not Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pain of Loss
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Harrison: Hospital Staff Joins Union
description: The workers at St. Vincent's Westchester Hospital have voted overwhelmingly to join 1199/ S.E.I.U., New York's Health and Human Service Union. The vote was 123 to unionize and 36 against. The bargaining unit at St. Vincent's, a 133-bed hospital, will include food workers, housekeepers, admitting representatives and engineering and maintenance workers. Union officials said that they hoped to negotiate a contract in which the workers in the Harrison hospital obtain the same benefits as the nearly 6,500 other unionized workers throughout the St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers New York network. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Schundler, Citing Debt Risk, Urges Referendum on Newark Arena
description: Bret D. Schundler, the Republican candidate for governor, called today for a statewide referendum on plans for a privately owned arena in Newark that would replace the Continental Airlines Arena in the Meadowlands as the home of the New Jersey Devils and New Jersey Nets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEGAL, MARVIN
description: SEGAL-Marvin. On August 19, 2001. Beloved husband of Lucille. Devoted father of Robert, Jonathan and Stephanie. Loving grandfather of Noah, Jennifer, Leah, Holiday, Timothy and Matthew. Attorney, composer and Major, U.S. Army. Service Thursday 11:15 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Learn to Earn
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Dispute On Islands Flares
description: Tokyo has protested to Russia over the granting of fishing rights to boats from South Korea, North Korea and the Ukraine in waters around the Kurile Islands, which are called the Northern Territories in Japan. Japan claims ownership of the islands, which were occupied by Soviet troops at the end of World War II. More than half a century later, the dispute prevents Japan from signing a peace treaty with Russia. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Crossing the Country in a Monologue Built for Two
description: Chris Burnside lay on the stage at one point in his performance-art solo ''Travelogue'' and talked of gazing up at the rock striations in the Grand Canyon. In ''Travelogue,'' performed on Friday night at the Lark Studio Theater, Mr. Burnside explored the striations of friendship, love and the sometimes bizarre behavior of human beings that he and his ''spouse'' Karl met on a 10th-anniversary journey by car around North America in 1997.

title: Profit Rises at Home-Improvement Retailer
description: The Lowe's Companies said today that its fiscal second-quarter profit rose 18 percent as the company, the second-largest home-improvement retailer, sold more appliances and paint and added stores.

title: Warning Questioned After a Drug Kills 31
description: When Baycol, a cholesterol-lowering drug, was approved in 1997, it appeared to be a lifesaving drug with few side effects. It had been tested on more than 3,000 patients, and no serious problems had turned up.

title: Slight Progress on Budget As Leaders Talk Compromise
description: Legislative leaders met with Gov. George E. Pataki early today and made some minor progress toward an accord on a supplemental budget that would patch the holes in the austere spending plan passed two weeks ago.

title: Tobacco Dealer Posts Profit Drop
description: Dimon Inc., the world's No. 2 tobacco-leaf dealer, said its fiscal fourth-quarter profit fell 15 percent because a delay in shipments from South America and a smaller crop from Brazil cut into its sales. Net income fell to $15.6 million, or 34 cents a share, from $18.4 million, or 41 cents, a year earlier. Revenue in the period ended June 30 fell 11 percent, to $290.8 million from $327.8 million a year earlier, Dimon said in a statement.

title: Amazon.com to Sell Products From Circuit City
description: Circuit City Group, the nation's second-biggest consumer-electronics retailer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its products online through Amazon.com Inc., the largest Internet retailer.

title: Sears to Focus on Variety Not Price
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, which spends $600 million to $1 billion annually on advertising, is overhauling its pitches to emphasize the variety of name-brand merchandise sold by its 860 stores rather than trying to compete on pricing with discounters like Wal-Mart Stores and Target.

title: Where Mozart, a Tribe and Parallels Will Meet
description: The setting is not quite the Metropolitan Opera House. But it is no less spectacular: the open-air powwow grounds of the Kalispel Indian Reservation, which lie along the Pend Oreille River in a valley framed by the Selkirk Mountains here along the Washington-Idaho border.

title: Going From Nowhere To Right Up There
description: Let's play a game of Name That Team. Jump in with the answer at any time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBECK, MARY E.
description: SOBECK-Mary E. On August 16, 2001 at 96 years. Beloved friend, preceeded in death by her husband Mike Sobeck. Survived by Fr. Aiden O'Driscoll, Fr. Kurin O'Driscoll and ''a family of friends'' in New York City and Ireland. Friends may call today at Mary Manning Walsh, 1339 York Ave at 9am. Mass of Christian Burial to follow at 9:30am. Interment St. Joseph's Cemetery, Hazelton, PA.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANKFATER, SAMUEL
description: FRANKFATER-Samuel. Beloved husband of Elaine. Devoted father of Joan and Gerald Glassberg, Laurie and Bruce Kaplan. Cherished grandfather of Ronald, Jill, Jessica and Julie. Loving brother of Florence Litoff. Graveside services Wednesday 1:30pm at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions may be made to The Whitestone Jewish Center.

title: Senator Cool Toward PAC's Starts One to Aid His Party
description: In a move that should fuel new speculation about a possible bid for the White House, Senator John Edwards of North Carolina is setting up a political action committee, a possibly awkward move for a politician who refuses to accept contributions from similar groups.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the international arms trade referred incorrectly in some editions to the growth in sales around the world from 1999 to 2000. When measured in 2000 dollars, the increase was 8 percent, not 6 percent or 13 percent.

title: Allen's Job at First May Be Returning Punts
description: Will Allen could be one of the Giants' top cover men, perhaps sometime this season. But while Allen, a first-round draft pick, tries to force his way into the starting lineup as a cornerback, the Giants have another opening that could suit him.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about people who spend their summers at bungalows in the Rockaways misstated the year in which subway service was introduced in the area. It was 1956, not in the late 1800's or the early 1900's. The article also misstated the middle initial of the New York mayor under whom hundreds of decrepit bungalows were destroyed. He was John V. Lindsay, not F.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Nursing Homes Fined
description: The New York State Department of Health cited 42 of the 45 nursing homes that it inspected last February for deficiencies. Of those, 13 were fined for violations that related to patient care and services. The Health Department has become increasingly aggressive in the last year in inspecting and fining nursing homes, after several years of what critics called weak oversight. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAAMA, HASSAN, M.D.
description: NAAMA-Hassan, M.D. The Faculty and Staff of Weill Cornell Medical College in New York City, the Weill Cornell Medical College in Qatar, NewYork - Presbyterian Hospital and the Department of Surgery of New York Weill Cornell Medical Center are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague Hassan Naama, M.D. An exceptional young surgeon, Dr. Naama had completed his surgical residency at New York Weill Cornell Medical Center in July and subsequently joined the full-time faculty and staff of the Department of Surgery. Dr. Naama had already accomplished much in his brief career and undoubtedly had a bright future, making his untimely death all the more tragic. We mourn his passing and extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 23, at 9 a.m. at New York Weill Cornell's Uris Auditorium, 1300 York Avenue (69th Street). A memorial fund is being established in Dr. Naama's name. Gifts should be made payable to the Surgical Residents' Fund-with the memo notation ''The Hassan Naama Memorial Fund''-and sent to the Surgical Education Office, Box 207, 525 East 68th Street, New York, NY 10021. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D., Dean Weill Cornell Medical College in New York Herbert Pardes, M.D., President NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Daniel Alonso, M.D., Dean Weill Cornell Medical College in Qatar John M. Daly, M.D., Chairman Department of Surgery New York Weill Cornell Medical Center

title: Economic Indicators Rose For the 4th Month in July
description: The index of leading economic indicators rose in July for a fourth consecutive month, suggesting that the economy will strengthen by the end of the year, a private research firm said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Trade Talks Agenda
description: Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee said that India was opposed to proposals that a new round of global trade talks be started at the next meeting of the World Trade Organization. Mr. Vajpayee, speaking at a conference in New Delhi on developing countries' concerns with the W.T.O. regime, said his country wanted disputed issues from the previous round of trade negotiations to be resolved before moving onto nontrade issues like the environment or labor standards. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Interpublic Unit Makes Personnel Shifts
description: Changes are being made as TN Media, the media buying agency of True North Communications, is folded into Initiative Media Worldwide, a division of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. The changes are part of the widespread reorganization of Interpublic after it completed acquiring True North.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Boy Accused Of Stabbing
description: An 11-year-old boy was charged with attempted murder yesterday in the stabbing of a police officer in Brooklyn this month. The police said the boy thrust a small knife into the back of Officer Edward Cook on Aug. 11 after the off-duty officer, who had been jogging, scolded a group of youths who were playing with cap guns near Schenectady and Atlantic Avenues in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Officer Cook was not seriously injured, the police said. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAUM, JOAN
description: DAUM-Joan. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Joan Daum. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Two Charged In Shooting Of Farrakhan's Son
description: The Chicago police charged two men in the shooting of one of the Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan's nine children. The two men, Clarence Goree and Jason Bailey, were charged with aggravated battery with a firearm and are being held without bond and scheduled to appear in court later this week. Joshua Farrakhan, 42, was beaten and shot once in each leg on Thursday in a home he was visiting. A Police Department spokesman said it believed that the attack stemmed from a dispute over money. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: A Vigorous and Clamoring Campaign in the City's Dominican Heartland
description: The streets of Washington Heights in upper Manhattan these days ring with the unmistakable din of a clamorous, vigorous political campaign. The posters are everywhere: on storefronts, lampposts, virtually any place they will fit. And every day, at any time of the day, sound trucks meander the streets, with an announcer promoting one candidate or another with meringue music blaring in the background.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GITTLEMAN, BEATRICE
description: GITTLEMAN-Beatrice. On August 19, 2001 at age 85. The matriarch of our family. Beloved wife of the late Max Gittleman. Extraordinary mother to Devorah Heller, Toby and Alan Edelson and Shula and Stuart Brudner. Adored grandmother to Lawrence Heller and Dayna Langfan, Michelle and Howard Edelson, Madelyn and Jonathan Brudner and Mark Heller. Devoted great grandmother to David Bennett, Penelope and Eve Heller. She will be forever in our hearts.

title: E. T. Hall, 77, Archaeologist Who Debunked Piltdown Man
description: E. T. Hall, an archaeologist and art historian who devised scientific tools used to unmask the fraudulent Piltdown Man and to try to determine the Shroud of Turin's age, died Aug. 11 in Oxford, England. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, HENRIETTA
description: MILSTEIN-Henrietta. She was an inspirational businesswoman, whom we will always remember for her devotion to her family and her warm and gracious manner. It was a privilege to know her. Our heartfelt sympathy to the entire Milstein family. May her memory be for a blessing. Barbara and Harvey Arfa

title: For This 2-Man TV Team, Politics, Vaudeville Style
description: THE mayoral candidates elbowing their way toward November do not have many things in common. But here is one: They could probably describe to you, in some detail, the inside of a small, modestly decorated room on the fourth floor of a former bus terminal on West 42nd Street.

title: America's Interest in an International Court
description: The prospects for American involvement in an International Criminal Court do not, at present, look at all good. The Clinton administration signed the necessary treaty, at the end of last year, only with reluctance. No one believes the Senate will ratify the treaty Mr. Clinton signed.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: A Crackdown On Truancy
description: In an effort to crack down on chronically absent students, Chicago public schools will start a pilot program in November that will require parents to attend counseling classes or perform up to 30 days of community service if their child misses 18 days of school for unexplained reasons. School officials say they will introduce the program in about 200 schools with the highest truancy rates. A state law passed in 1997 allows for the antitruancy program, but despite a push by the former chief executive Paul Vallas, it was never carried out.

title: An Environmental Nominee Is Opposed
description: Democratic critics and environmental groups are stepping up pressure to halt President Bush's nomination of Ohio's top environmental regulator to be the lead enforcer for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: An Appeal to the 'Greatest Generation'
description: Peter F. Vallone's mayoral campaign is scheduled to begin broadcasting its second network television advertisement today. A pitch to elderly voters, the commercial is titled ''Pacific,'' an allusion to the Pacific Theater of World War II and the veterans of that part of the conflict. The 30-second spot focuses on Mr. Vallone's latest proposal to subsidize prescription drugs for the elderly. It will be shown on six local broadcast stations.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Five Robbed At Casino
description: The police are searching for two men who helped tie up and rob five guests at the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort on Sunday night. One robbery victim managed to free himself from a 29th floor room and chased the three assailants through the lobby, firing a shot but hitting no one. The police seized the weapon and charged the victim, Jeffrey Barnes, 35, of Newport News, Va., with unlawful possession of a weapon. Mr. Barnes was free on bail. One suspect was arrested shortly after the robbery, which occurred after a dispute over money in a private game, the authorities said. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, FLIP
description: PHILLIPS-Flip. 86 years old. Graveside services will be held on Wednesday, August 22, 2001, 2 PM, at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens. Miraglia Funeral Chapels, Inc., 8519 New Utrecht Ave, Brooklyn, NY; 718-236-2442.

title: For Fall, Some Swash, Some Buckle and a Tougher Look
description: Reflected in the windows of Saks Fifth Avenue and Bergdorf Goodman last week were pedestrians in summertime straw and linen inspecting the latest crop of equestrian gear and racy peasant chic -- a reflection that if it's August in New York, it must be deep fall among the fashion peddlers.

title: 'Spin' Could Be Quantum Boost for Computers
description: Electronic devices like radios and computers work by shuttling around the electric charge of electrons. Hence, the ''electron'' in ''electronics.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, HANNAH
description: GORDON-Hannah. Beloved wife of the late Carl Gordon. Passed peacefully and with dignity on August 19, 2001. For 93 years she touched all who knew her with her gracious and selfless presence, her zealous love of life, her deep dedication to family, her sense of charity, and her brilliant and dry sense of humor. She was a devoted mother to Mabel Brodell, Eleanore Bass and the late Jerry Gordon. Loving mother-in-law to Dr. Robert Bass, Irwin Brodell and Adrienne Gordon. Proud grandmother to Evelyn and David Faichney, Michael Brodell, Jeffrey and Heather Bass, Paul Bass, Lisa and Laurence Gordon, Jon and Vicki Gordon, Laura Gordon. Adored great-grandmother to Connor Bass, Sasha, Jax, Evan, Jared, Ilona Gordon, Rob and Jay Faichney. In lieu of flowers please make donations to the Center for Developmental Disabilities, 72 Southwoods Rd, Woodbury. Services Tuesday, 1 PM, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, LI.

title: CALLAWAY, MAKER OF GOLF CLUBS, ELECTS A CHAIRMAN
description: The Callaway Golf Company, the nation's leading golf club maker, said yesterday that it had elected Ronald Drapeau chairman to succeed its late founder, Ely Callaway. Mr. Drapeau, 54, joined the company, which is based in Carlsbad, Calif., in 1996 and was elected president and chief executive on May 15. He also serves on the board's finance committee. Mr. Callaway died July 5 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 82.

title: Authentic Vision for Storybooks; Illustrating Familiar Tales for a New Generation
description: Jerry Pinkney inhabits a strange and inviting universe where lilacs smile, spruce trees brood and billowing clouds of wild horses gallop in masses of lavender pink.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: BONDS UP IN THE CATSKILLS A financial recovery in Sullivan County has led a Wall Street bond-rating agency to upgrade the county's debt rating to A, from A-minus. The agency, Standard & Poor's, raised the rating yesterday in advance of the sale of $8.7 million in bonds next week by the county, which is northwest of New York City in the foothills of the Catskill Mountains. The county's tourism-based economy is rebounding and becoming more diverse, S.& P. analysts said, and improved budgeting practices have turned a budget deficit into a surplus. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: At Senior Centers, Candidates Focus on Medicine and Crime
description: The Democrats who would be mayor of New York City turned their attention yesterday to one of the city's most reliable sources of votes: the elderly.

title: Kim Stanley, Reluctant but Gripping Broadway and Hollywood Actress, Dies at 76
description: Kim Stanley, whose infrequent but luminous stage portraits brought her to the edge of greatness, but who ultimately shrank from the pressures of performance and stardom, died yesterday at a hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 76 and lived in Santa Fe.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CODE-ALARM INC., Madison Heights, Mich., a maker of automobile security systems, said it would supply its PowerCode key-fob remote starting and security system to cars and trucks made by Ford Motor Co., Dearborn Mich., and grant Ford the option to buy a minority stake in Code-Alarm over five years. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Officials Drop Plan to Shift Latin Grammies to Miami
description: Months after announcing to considerable fanfare that the Latin Grammy Awards would move to Miami from Los Angeles, event organizers have pulled the show from South Florida over fears that Cuban-American protesters would disrupt the event.

title: The Voice of Experience Swings With a Buoyant Calm
description: Carol Sloane

title: Turning Down the Phantom Noise Inside the Head
description: Sidney Kleinman can't get a good night's sleep. The street can be still, the wind calm and the neighbors peaceful, but the racket and roar in Mr. Kleinman's head can become so loud that it jolts him out of the deepest slumber. There may as well be a block full of car alarms clanging through the night.

title: Credit Suisse First Boston Hires Former S.E.C. Official
description: Credit Suisse First Boston, which is at the center of federal investigations into how new stocks were sold on Wall Street in the late 1990's, hired Gary G. Lynch, a former director of enforcement for the Securities and Exchange Commission, as its general counsel yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Buchanan: Plant Back To Full Power
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear plant has returned to full power after repairs were completed on a leaking pipe in a nonnuclear area of the plant. The plant had reduced power by a third on Wednesday but returned to its output of nearly 1,000 megawatts late Friday afternoon, said a spokesman for Consolidated Edison, the plant operator. Workers clamped the troublesome metal pipe, which is part of the system that feeds and discharges water to the plant. Randal C. Archibold (NYT)

title: GERMAN PROSECUTORS WIDEN MANNESMANN INVESTIGATION
description: German prosecutors said yesterday they had widened an investigation into payments made during the Vodafone Group's takeover of Mannesmann last year. The inquiry will now include Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, and the chief executive-designate of Deutsche Bank, Josef Ackermann, who was on Mannesmann's supervisory board during the takeover. Prosecutors, based in Dsseldorf, are examining whether Mannesmann's former chief executive, Klaus Esser, and other executives agreed to the deal because Vodafone offered them large payments, sometimes called golden parachutes. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMYTH, JAMES VALENTINE

Loving grandfather to Sara Elisabeth. Beloved brother to John, Catherine and Dorothy. Beloved uncle to three generations of Smyths, Taylors and Franklins. His wisdom, gentility and love of life will be sorely missed. Viewing Wednesday, August 22, 2-5 PM, 7-9 PM, Hugh Reid Funeral Home, 153 Greenpoint Ave., Brooklyn, NY.
