title: Citing Drop in Surplus, Democrats Plan to Portray Bush as Reckless
description: With both the White House and Congress set to confirm that the budget surplus outside of Social Security has all but evaporated for the next few years, Democrats are planning to intensify their attacks on President Bush's fiscal management and to pin blame for the weakened economy on the White House.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Government Handouts
description: With its export-dependent economy in recession and elections due in less than a year, Singapore's government said it would begin issuing citizens a piece of future government surpluses in the form of shares. Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, left, who outlined the new plan Sunday, said owners of these ''New Singapore'' shares would be able to either redeem them for cash or hold them and earn a dividend each year and a bonus in bumper years. Last month, the government announced 2.2 billion Singapore dollars of economic stimulus measures ($2.3 billion), including increased government spending and extended tax breaks. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: Ad Downturn Fails to Deter WPP From Bid
description: Feeling the pinch from the sharp downturn in advertising spending, WPP Group said today that first-half sales grew slower than last year and that business was unlikely to improve this year.

title: The Madness for Gold Guided History's Path
description: Gold is so malleable that just an ounce can be drawn into a wire 50 miles long or hammered into a sheet of 100 square feet. But that can't be easy. Nor is it easy to take a sackful of factual nuggets (like the ones above) and turn them into a coherent television documentary. And while the producers of ''Gold!'' have obviously done their homework (mined their subject?) and provided some fascinating moments, they have ultimately been defeated by their rich subject.

title: Lawton Carries Torch for Baseball Family
description: Matt Lawton's father has a satellite dish and a computer, and if he is not beaming in a baseball game to his home in Gulfport, Miss., he is tracking the progress of one, pitch by pitch, on the Internet.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Agreement On Redistricting
description: The State Commission on Redistricting reached a tentative agreement on Sunday and will meet on Wednesday to complete borders for 35 legislative districts and 2 Congressional ones. The commission, with three Democrats and three Republicans appointed by the Legislature, is the first of its kind in Idaho. The new districts are being drawn to reflect population changes reported in the 2000 census. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

Benedett, principals at BBG, Westport, Conn., were named co-chief executives and managing partners at the Wilton, Conn., office of Marketing Drive Worldwide, which BBG was merged into earlier this year. They succeed Don Growhoski, who left, the company said, to pursue other interests. Marketing Drive is part of the FCB Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Ferguson Out for Year; Jets to Try Inexperience
description: The Jets' only unsettled unit on defense, the line, became more unsettled today when an M.R.I. exam showed that nose tackle Jason Ferguson will need season-ending surgery on his rotator cuff.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Trade Gap
description: Britain's trade deficit widened to a record 3.2 billion ($4.6 billion) in June, the highest level since such data was first recorded in 1697, the National Statistics Office said. The figure compares with a revised 2.5 billion deficit in May. Imports rose 2.5 percent, driven by aircraft and precious stones, while exports fell 1.7 percent. The office also said in a separate report that July tax revenue was higher than expected. The data showed the domestic consumer had been spending despite a worldwide economic slowdown.

title: Iron May Soothe Heart Patients' Coughs
description: ACE inhibitors are among the most widely used drugs used to treat heart disease and high blood pressure. But despite their proven benefits, many patients find they cannot take them because they bring on a persistent dry cough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, JUDY
description: MYERS-Judy. Of Aventura, FL, peacefully on August 18, 2001. Beloved wife for 48 years of Sidney. Devoted mother of Jody and Robert. Adored grandmother of Michael, Matthew, Ryan and Dylan. Loving sister of Linda. Cherished aunt of Robin, Jillian, Kevin and the late Jordan. Great-aunt to Kaitlyn. Dear sister-in-law of Philip and Jennifer. Whoever needed a sister, she was their sister, when someone needed a friend, she was that friend, whoever needed a confidant, she was that too. Her heart was big enough to accept all who needed refuge, understanding and comfort. She will be deeply missed and remembered forever. In lieu of flowers please send donations to your favorite charity.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: Altitude Sickness And Tourism
description: Altitude sickness may cost the state's mountain resorts millions of dollars, a researcher at the University of Colorado Medical School has found. Above 6,000 feet in elevation, people can suffer from loss of appetite, insomnia, headaches, nausea or just shortness of breath as a result of thinner air. The researcher, Dr. Ben Honigman, has determined that 25 percent of visitors to Colorado get some symptoms of altitude sickness and therefore curtail planned activities or cut trips short, costing business $25 million to $30 million. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: No Bond for Pharmacist Accused of Diluting Drugs
description: A federal magistrate said today that Robert R. Courtney, the Kansas City pharmacist charged with diluting cancer drugs he dispensed, was a flight risk, and ordered that he continue to be held without bond.

description: People with congestive heart failure do so much worse if they also suffer from major depression that they should routinely be given psychiatric assessments, a new study recommends.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 — President Bush went to Harry Truman's hometown today to defend his tax cuts and his vision of compassionate conservatism.

title: Monastery in Macedonia Attacked
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia, Aug. 21 — An explosion today ripped apart a 14th century monastery, one of the most revered Orthodox buildings in Macedonia, even as NATO officials maintained that the cease-fire here was generally holding.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR GAINS. The dollar rose amid speculation that its decline since July was not justified as prospects for economic growth improve. In New York, the euro settled at 91.33 cents, down from 91.74 cents on Friday.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Produce Exchange Seeks Protection
description: World Commerce Online Inc., which develops and licenses software that allows food and produce companies to conduct business on the Internet, said it had filed for bankruptcy protection. The company, based in Orlando, Fla., had hinged its business plan on changing the way industries work together, with producers, distributors and buyers doing business through a global exchange. But in the last two years, many exchanges have had difficulty starting and many others have closed.

title: Patrick Wall, 76, British Authority on Pain
description: Dr. Patrick Wall, a British neurophysiologist and educator whose research centered on the nature of pain, died on Aug. 8. He was 76.

title: R.V. Coalition Reviews Its Account
description: The GO RVing Coalition in Reston, Va., comprising recreation vehicle makers, dealers, suppliers and campground owners, is beginning a review for its account, which has been handled for six years by Eisner Communications in Baltimore.

title: The Coach Who Groomed Two Yankees
description: Roger Clemens stepped outside the Yankees' clubhouse the other day with a weight-lifting belt slung over his right arm, heading for a workout, but he saw a familiar face and stopped and turned and hugged his former coach. Andy Pettitte had a similar greeting for Wayne Graham, who coached both pitchers at San Jacinto Junior College in Texas and remembers them as pudgy teenagers willing to work.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Growth Data Due
description: Economists expect the Bank of Korea to report a disappointing number today when it releases its report on the country's gross domestic product for the second quarter. The central bank had earlier estimated a growth rate of 3.3 percent for the quarter and 3.8 percent for the year. Now, because of the slowdown in Japan and the United States, Korea's two largest trading partners, economists expect a growth rate of less then 0.5 percent for the quarter and less than 3 percent for the year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: War Games With U.S.
description: American and South Korean troops opened annual joint military exercises with about 10,000 troops taking part in war games that consist largely of simulated battles and maneuvers conducted on elaborate computer networks. The exercise opened as President Kim Dae Jung stressed the need for solid military security while pursuing reconciliation with North Korea. Officials also warned peace advocates who went to North Korea that those who violated a pledge not to join in North Korean reunification ceremonies while there face prosecution after they return to Seoul today. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cattle Prognosis Mixed
description: For the first time in six months, live cattle were auctioned in Britain yesterday, raising the possibility that the foot-and-mouth epidemic is subsiding. But two new cases of the disease were confirmed over the weekend in Cumbria and North Yorkshire, two of the harder-hit areas in Northern England. Frustrated by the government's handling of the worst outbreak of the disease ever, farmers protested outside Prime Minister Tony Blair's residence.

title: In the Inner Game, You Really Can Win for Losing
description: Recently, I paid a visit to my friend Ben Mondor, owner of the Pawtucket, R.I., Red Sox, Boston's Triple-A farm team. When I entered his field-level suite at homey McCoy Stadium, Ben gestured toward an older man seated at the conference table and asked me, ''Richard, do you know Frank Malzone?''

title: Christie Todd Whitman May Have the Most Thankless Job in Washington
description: Christie Whitman arrives at the home ballpark of the Lowell Spinners, the Boston Red Sox' Class-A affiliate in the old mill town of Lowell, Mass. The stadium rises atop a cleaned-up toxic-waste site and is the kind of place administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency go. It's a glinting citadel of the new and well made, wedged among boarded-up factories. But there is no crowd waiting, only a few baseball staff members. When she was governor of New Jersey, Whitman caused a stir wherever she went; many expected her to ascend either to the United States Senate or to the vice-presidential slot on the 2000 Republican ticket. Instead she now visits toxic-waste sites. ''At least today is a clean day,'' Whitman notes. Often when she travels to inspect something, it's garbage or ooze or worse.

description: BHP Billiton, one of the largest mining companies in the world, reported robust earnings for the year today, even as demand from the United States and Europe slumped and metal prices fell sharply.

title: The Lies of Joseph Ellis
description: By suspending Joseph J. Ellis without pay for a year, administrators at Mount Holyoke College have acted fairly and appropriately, though they must have done so with regret. Mr. Ellis, a history professor and the Pulitzer-Prize-winning author this year of ''Founding Brothers,'' admitted to lying in the classroom about his past over the last decade after an article about those lies was published in The Boston Globe in June. When the Globe article was published, Joanne V. Creighton, president of Mount Holyoke, rashly criticized the newspaper's motives. She has apologized for that statement, which must have been uttered in a moment of disbelief.

title: Jailhouse Artist Makes Mark on Murals; Addiction Another Form of Imprisonment for a Well-Regarded Painter
description: Anthony Jones can make concrete walls vanish with a stroke of his hand, turn blank closet doors into elegant marble hallways and transform drab rooms into opulent mansions. But he cannot stop using cocaine.

title: Tunnel Vision; An Old Rivalry, a Quiet Continuance
description: In the beginning was the IRT, the Interborough Rapid Transit subway, born in 1904 in a flamboyant burst of municipal foresight and robber-baron ambition. We now know it as the numbered subway lines, with their slender trains and elegantly attired stations.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Handspring Lowers Prices
description: The hand-held computer maker Handspring Inc. said yesterday that it would lower the prices of its personal organizers by as much as 25 percent. Handspring, based in Mountain View, Calif., dropped the price of its low-end Visor model by $20, to $129, and discounted the higher-end Visor Edge by $100, to $299. Other models were cut $30 to $50. The discounts come after similar cuts last spring by Handspring and its competitor Palm Inc., maker of the Palm series of hand-held organizers. Both companies have struggled with excess inventory amid cooling demand. Shares of Handspring closed down a penny, at $3.97. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: An Unresponsive Economy
description: All of a sudden, the light at the end of the economic tunnel doesn't seem to be getting any closer. For much of this year, analysts expected the Federal Reserve Board's half-dozen cuts in interest rates to shift the economy out of neutral by the fourth quarter. Now, as autumn nears, medium- and long-term interest rates remain prohibitively high, and each day brings news of more layoffs. Pundits seize upon any sign of a turnaround, such as last month's growth in new home construction. Clearly, however, companies are finding few reasons to increase their investments. One obvious problem is that the Fed and the Bush administration are working at cross purposes.

title: A Thumbs Up From Lindros, as Sather Strikes
description: Make no mistake, Eric Lindros's health was the main issue yesterday at Madison Square Garden as the Rangers introduced their latest big-name acquisition. A dominant force as a Philadelphia Flyer for much of his first eight N.H.L seasons, Lindros has not played since sustaining his sixth concussion in the 2000 Eastern Conference finals.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3com Settles Infringement Suit
description: The 3Com Corporation, which makes computer networking equipment, said yesterday that it had settled a trademark-infringement lawsuit with the MagiTech Corporation of Cleveland. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed. 3Com's complaint, filed in May, accused MagiTech of repackaging and selling more than 10,000 3Com network interface cards with counterfeit packaging, documentation and software. Brian Johnson, a spokesman for 3Com, said the repackaging was discovered by a 3Com employee. He said that 3Com discovered MagiTech had been buying the cards in bulk, altering the documentation and then reselling them. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: Federal banking regulators have named John D. Broderick to be president and chief executive of Superior Bank F.S.B., the suburban Chicago savings and loan that was taken over by regulators last month after losses depleted nearly all of its capital.

description: Edward Tian says he is on a mission to bring Western-style business practices to China. But what lured him back to his native land from Texas in 1995 was less a spirit of patriotism than a sense of insecurity.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Nepal: Treason Charges Dropped
description: The new government has withdrawn sedition charges against a top editor of the daily newspaper Kantipur and two executives of a company that publishes it. They had been jailed after the newspaper printed a column by a Maoist leader during the crisis that followed the massacre of much of the royal family. The government and the Maoists have recently agreed to hold peace talks.

title: Officer in Fatal Accident Offers an Apology
description: Saying he was not a ''monster'' or a ''mindless drunk,'' the Brooklyn police officer accused of killing four people while driving drunk earlier this month apologized to the family of the victims at a tearful news conference yesterday and described his life since the accident as ''an absolute nightmare.''

title: Martinez Is Hurt After Homer Lifts Yanks to Victory
description: Jerry Narron made the anticipated managerial decision when he summoned the left-hander Juan Moreno with the Texas Rangers leading the Yankees by one run in the eighth inning tonight. The Yankees had Paul O'Neill leading off and Tino Martinez batting third in the inning, and Narron wanted to neutralize the two left-handed hitters.

title: KORN/FERRY SAYS IT WILL LAY OFF 20% OF ITS STAFF
description: Korn/Ferry International, a leading executive-search firm, plans to lay off 500 employees, 20 percent of its work force, and said it had a quarterly loss as companies added fewer managers. The company lost 13 cents to 16 cents a share, excluding charges and gains, and revenue fell 34 percent to about $114 million in the quarter ended July 31. The chief executive, Paul Reilly, said fees dropped as companies reduced executive ranks. Korn/Ferry earns a fee of 30 percent of a year's salary for each executive placed. Korn/Ferry said it would take charges related to the job cuts and from combining computer and human resources operations of $1.10 a share in the first quarter, and of 64 cents in the second.

title: As Expected, Fed Cuts Interest Rates by a Quarter Point
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21  Citing a persistently weak business environment at home and slowing economic growth abroad, the Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point today and signaled that its campaign to avert a recession is probably not yet over.

title: Wresting Control Of Cupid's Arrows
description: Current rhythm-and-blues asks the impossible of women. The ideal is supposed to be tough on the street, polished in the office and prodigious in bed; well accessorized but not too materialistic; independent and brimming with self-esteem yet ready to give up everything for love. When two women meet, they're expected to battle it out for the attentions of a good man, staying honest while parrying underhanded schemes. And once a woman gets her man, it's up to her to prevent him from straying, whether that takes endless favors or eternal vigilance.

Mr. Hunt served as governor from 1987 to 1993, when he was forced to leave office because of a conviction on an ethics law violation. He was convicted of using $200,000 from his 1987 inaugural fund for private expenses. Mr. Hunt later appealed his conviction and in 1998 he received a pardon from the Alabama Board of Pardons and Paroles. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

In accordance with his wishes, there were no services.

title: Drug's Problems Raise Questions on Warnings
description: When Baycol, a cholesterol-lowering drug, was approved in 1997, it appeared to be a potentially lifesaving drug with few side effects. It had been tested on more than 3,000 patients, and no serious problems had turned up.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Equipment Maker Plans To Close
description: Triton Network Systems Inc., a manufacturer of high-speed wireless networking equipment, said it had decided to close the company and sell its assets, pending shareholder approval. Triton, based in Orlando, Fla., cited its financial struggles and its inability to find a merger or buyout partner. The directors predicted that shareholders would receive 75 to 95 cents a share, a premium over yesterday's closing price of 65 cents but a fraction of its 52-week high of $24.25. Triton, which posted a loss of $40.6 million in the first half of 2001, said it had begun to reduce its operations but was discussing a sale of remaining shares with another company.

title: Reckonings; Fabricating A Crisis
description: Last week the International Monetary Fund, which has no political stake in the debate over Social Security, told the prosaic truth: ''the long-term financing problems of Social Security are not large'' and ''could be addressed through relatively small adjustments in the program's parameters.''

title: National Briefing
description: NORTHWEST

title: A Step Forward for Genetic Engineering in New Zealand
description: The Royal Commission on Genetic Modification has recommended that research on genetically modified crops and animals ''proceed with caution,'' elating the nation's biotechnology interests while dismaying opponents of the technology, particularly the nation's influential Green Party.

title: NATO Ministers Decide to Send Troops Into Macedonia
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 21 — After hearing a favorable report from their top military commander, NATO ministers decided today to send a full 3,500-soldier task force into Macedonia to help disarm Albanian insurgents.

title: ABC Wins First Interview With Embattled Lawmaker
description: ABC, announced yesterday that its correspondent, Connie Chung, would interview Representative Gary A. Condit in prime time Thursday night.

title: Addressing Problems That Confront Aging Parents
description: ''Are Your Parents Driving You Crazy?'' by Dr. Joseph A. Ilardo and Dr. Carole R. Rothman, VanderWyck & Burnham, $14.95

title: Steering the Shuttle
description: Q. Why does the space shuttle roll after launching? How does it catch up to the space station without bumping into it?

title: Battling Competition, Ames Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday as competition with Wal-Mart Stores Inc. has left the company struggling to pay its debts.

title: Technology Briefing | Security: Companies Join To Fight Worms
description: Several computer security companies announced yesterday that they had joined to fight distributed-denial-of-service attacks, in which computers are flooded with messages from machines that have been surreptitiously commandeered. McAfee, a division of Network Associates, already monitors millions of computers for infection by computer worms (roving software like the recent ''Code Red'' that can turn computers into zombies that spread the worms and attack other computers). The company said that it planned to incorporate technologies developed by three companies -- Asta Networks, Mazu Networks and Arbor Networks -- to fight off or prevent distributed attacks.

title: Do Unruly Kids Need Drugs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about racing pigeons in Belgium misstated the location of England's annual Derby horse race in a facetious contrast of the formality of the scenes. The Derby is held on Epsom Downs, not at Ascot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAFTER, BERNARD
description: SHAFTER-Bernard, Attorney. August 25, 1907 to August 14, 2001. Husband of Dorothy C. Shafter, father of Allan D. Shafter (Roberta), and the late Eugene C. Shafter (Bonnie). Grandfather of Diana R. Shafter, Linda J. Shafter and Jonathan G. Shafter. Brother of Rhoda Shifreen and the late Alfred M. Shafter. Funeral services were held on August 17, 2001.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Air Safety Investigation
description: The decision by the Federal Aviation Administration to downgrade the air safety rating of South Korea is reverberating through the country. President Kim Dae Jung called for an investigation of the standards and procedures by which his government regulates civil aviation. Members of both his own party and the opposition demanded the ouster of the transportation minister, Oh Jang Seop, but Mr. Kim's spokesman said he first wanted all the facts behind the downgrade, which bans Korean Air and Asiana Airlines from expanding routes to the United States and code-sharing with American carriers.

title: Stepping Up Protection For Youths On Internet
description: In the wake of the kidnapping of a Massachusetts teenager after an encounter in an Internet chat room, public officials and law enforcement agencies are looking to step up their efforts to prevent Internet sex crimes exploiting young people.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Grand Jury In Grubman Case
description: A Suffolk County grand jury began hearing testimony yesterday in the case of Elizabeth S. Grubman, the Manhattan publicist who was charged with deliberately backing her sport utility vehicle into a crowd of people gathered outside a Southampton nightclub. Ms. Grubman, 30, said it was an accident. She was charged with reckless endangerment, leaving the scene of an accident and multiple counts of assault in connection with the July 7 incident, in which 16 people were injured. Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Aug. 14 about groups that warned that they would sue if protesters were kept from the meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank next month in Washington misstated the location of a civil rights lawyer, Mara Verheyden-Hilliard. She was the second from the left; Bob Brown, director of the Kwame Ture Work-Study Institute and Library, was at the right.

title: Martin Is Ready For Games
description: Kenyon Martin knew his twice-broken right leg had already healed by the middle of the summer. He no longer felt any pain, or any doubt, and during pickup games all he seemed to be seeing was the top of the rim.

title: Slump in U.S. Drags Mexico, and Fox's Agenda, Down
description: Mexico has been dragged into recession by the faltering American economy, taking a toll on millions of Mexicans and the political aspirations of President Vicente Fox.

title: 'Corelli's' Greek Isle Feels Burned and Bewildered by Instant Celebrity
description: A busload of British tourists stood in the square here on the Greek island of Cephalonia, where the film ''Captain Corelli's Mandolin'' was shot, squinting in the fierce sunlight at a nondescript stretch of pavement that used to be a movie set. This was the road, their guide said, where the Greek doctor's daughter, played by Penelope Cruz, waited for her Italian lover Corelli (Nicolas Cage). Another attraction is the completely ordinary house here where Mr. Cage stayed.

title: Toys 'R' Us Cites Costs Of Upgrading For Its Loss
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. reported a fiscal second-quarter loss today as it spent money to renovate stores to win back customers from Wal-Mart Stores Inc.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about racing pigeons in Belgium misstated the location of England's annual Derby horse race in a facetious contrast of the formality of the scenes. The Derby is held on Epsom Downs, not at Ascot.

title: Biggest Banks in Canada May Be Set for Marriages
description: Canada's five big banks began reporting quarterly results today. But whatever they have to say about past performance and future plans will be of less interest to investors and analysts than what may be taking place behind the scenes.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Arafat and Peres Set to Meet
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 21 — Relations between Israel and the Palestinians have deteriorated so thoroughly that any glimmer of diplomatic action, however faint, is instantly seized on here as a possible path toward a truce.

title: Labor Official Calls New Vote On Organizing At Hospital
description: A National Labor Relations Board official ordered a new unionization election yesterday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., after concluding that the hospital's management had improperly coerced workers to vote against unionizing.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Who ever thought crime would go down? Who ever thought we would run out of inmates?''

title: Fujitsu, Facing New Losses, to Cut 10% of Work Force
description: Fujitsu Ltd. said today that it would eliminate 16,400 jobs, or nearly 10 percent of its global work force, as it struggles with the slump in technology spending.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Kentucky: Hospital Names Artificial Heart Recipient
description: Robert Tools was identified as the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart, an official at Jewish Hospital in Louisville said. Mr. Tools, 59, received an implant of the AbioCor artificial heart on July 2. Hospital officials had declined to identify the recipient other than saying he was a diabetic man in his mid- to late-50's. Jewish Hospital is holding a news conference today where Mr. Tools, of Franklin, Ky., is expected to introduce himself and answer questions. Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Schundler Fiddled With Jersey City Tax Bills, Mayor Says
description: Bret D. Schundler kept tax collections artificially low in his last months as mayor of Jersey City to further his campaign for governor, his Democratic successor charged today.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: World Briefing | Europe: Azerbaijan: Tensions Rise With Iran
description: Security forces arrested six Muslim clergymen accused of spying for Iran in the latest incident of rising tensions between the Caucasus nation and its neighbor. The six are Azerbaijani citizens, Turan news agency reported. Tensions between Iran and Azerbaijan have been simmering since an Iranian warship threatened an Azerbaijani oil research vessel in a disputed section of the Caspian Sea last month.

title: Kalkan Journal; Come to Me, All You Big Spenders
description: The village rises gently from the bright brimming bay on the Mediterranean, its whitewashed houses climbing the folds of the hills in a more or less orderly fashion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHILLER, ROBERT A.
description: SCHILLER-Robert A. of Rockville Centre, NY on Sunday, August 19, 2001. Beloved husband and best friend of Patricia (nee Driscoll). Loving father of Robert and Roseann Schiller, Kristin and Joseph Vickery, Kathryn and Brian Donovan, and Mary Beth Schiller. Cherished ''Pops'' to six grandchildren. Dear brother of Richard and Jocelyn Schiller. Reposing Macken Mortuary, Inc., 52 Clinton Avenue, Rockville Centre today and Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass St. Agnes Cathedral Thursday 10 pm. Interment Cemetery of the Holy Rood, Westbury, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TILLIM, SIDNEY
description: TILLIM-Sidney. A superbly gifted artist with a uniquely American vision. He painted scenes depicting figures from The American Revolution, paintings not applauded by the art scene then or now. My respect for his courage, and artistic integrity has grown over 47 years. His last exhibit of paintings, showed a vision of art even more virile, more powerful, more hauntingly beautiful than ever. His subjects are iconic moments of recent history. ''The Death of Mrs. Silverman'' is clearly a masterpiece. I have lost a dear friend. My heart goes out to his loving wife and kin. Jules Olitski

title: Point Given in Travers After Fast Workout
description: The Mid-Summer Derby got an unexpected blast of star shine today when Bob Baffert announced that Point Given was coming here Saturday for the 132nd running of the Travers Stakes.

title: Ordinary? Not Tomatoes
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cosmic Theme's Comic Conversion
description: Inevitable perhaps, but sad: as part of the New York Fringe Festival, Mobius Group Productions is presenting ''a new adaptation'' by Jonathan Silver of Elmer Rice's 1923 classic, ''The Adding Machine.'' On this principle one might also say that Sherman adapted Georgia during the Civil War.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Evaporating Budget Surplus Sets Up a Political Battle

title: 2 Who Beat Adversity Join Ryder Cup Team
description: Choosing two players who have overcome career-threatening adversity, Curtis Strange named Paul Azinger and Scott Verplank to this year's United States Ryder Cup team.

title: Safari Savings for Solo Travelers
description: Starting next January, Conservation Corporation Africa will waive the supplements on single-occupancy rooms at 26 of its 27 luxury safari lodges in 6 countries (South Africa, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Kenya). Only Mnemba Island Lodge, in Tanzania, will still charge a single supplement. Information: (888) 882-3742 or www.ccafrica.com .

title: A Beard Doesn't Count
description: To the Editor:

title: With Primary in Three Weeks, Democrats Debate
description: Alan G. Hevesi and Peter F. Vallone battled over expanding legislation to restrict protests at abortion clinics. Fernando Ferrer attacked Mark Green for refusing to say whether the four police officers involved in the Amadou Diallo shooting should be fired.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RONER, GERDA (SPITZ)
description: RONER-Gerda (Spitz) formerly of New York. Wife of the late Fred Roner and Kurt Robitschek (Ken Robey). Mother of Helen and her husband Bernard M. Strauss and the late Deborah Robey. Sister of Julia Lederer. Grandmother of Kenneth and Elliot Strauss. Services Thursday, 1 PM at ''The Riverside'', Amsterdam Ave. at 76th St.

title: Do Unruly Kids Need Drugs?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business Briefing | Bonds Up In The Catskills
description: A financial recovery in Sullivan County has led a Wall Street bond-rating agency to upgrade the county's debt rating to A, from A-minus. The agency, Standard & Poor's, raised the rating yesterday in advance of the sale of $8.7 million in bonds next week by the county, which is northwest of New York City in the foothills of the Catskill Mountains. The county's tourism-based economy is rebounding and becoming more diverse, S.& P. analysts said, and improved budgeting practices have turned a budget deficit into a surplus. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: Ex-Minister's False W-2 Leads To Brief $5.4 Million Refund
description: A former minister with the Church of God and Prophecy who claimed $250 million in income on his 2000 New York State tax return, then briefly enjoyed the $5.4 million refund that the state wired to his bank account, was indicted yesterday on a grand larceny charge, the authorities said.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Chyd Denny, Judith Iam, Rabbi Ben Zion Levin, Miami, Dec. 17, 2000

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURA, RAYMOND
description: GURA-Raymond. Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun mourns the passing of its member, the beloved father of Sheryl Rosenberg and Nick Gura and extends heartfelt sympathy to all the members of the bereaved family. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein Rabbi Joshua Lookstein Chaim Edelstein, President

title: World Briefing | Africa: Insurance For Risky Region
description: Leaders of seven countries in East and Central Africa met in Uganda to start a new agency to provide political risk insurance to investors in Africa. The Africa Trade Insurance Agency, which will be based in Nairobi, Kenya, will begin with $105 million in start-up money from the World Bank. Burundi, Kenya, Malawi, Rwanda, Tanzania, Uganda and Zambia have joined the plan. The group, which will be open to all African countries, will cover such risks as embargoes, expropriations and civil disturbances and is intended to spur trade and investment. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Reared on Soy and Doing Quite Well
description: By some estimates, almost one in five babies are given formula made from soy instead of cow's milk during their first year, though little has been firmly established about what effect this may have on their future health.

title: JEFFERIES GROUP TO ACQUIRE LAWRENCE HELFANT
description: The Jefferies Group, a securities firm specializing in institutional trading, agreed to acquire Lawrence Helfant L.L.C. for an undisclosed amount, expanding its trading capabilities on the New York Stock Exchange. Jefferies, based in Los Angeles, gets about half its revenue from stock trading. The acquisition of Helfant will triple the number of Big Board seats Jefferies owns to 18, increasing the number of employees the firm can place on the floor of the exchange. The company will become the fourth-biggest floor-trading firm at the exchange, with daily trading volume of more than 100 million shares.

title: A Long Night In Dark Land Of Autism
description: ''Call security!'' the emergency room physician ordered a nearby nurse. ''I'm not about to wrestle with a 17-year-old autistic boy.''

title: Interference From a Noisy Planet
description: Modern radio telescopes are sensitive enough to detect a cell phone if it rings on Mars. But if one actually rings there, the astronomers operating the telescopes may have a hard time recognizing the signal.

title: California Governor Sees an End to Freeway Building
description: Standing atop eight lanes of grooved pavement and pristine yellow stripes in the kind of distant Los Angeles suburb made possible by endless highway construction, Gov. Gray Davis today dedicated the latest section of freeway to be built in California and declared that the project would be the last.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, BROTHER B. EDWARD, F.S.C.
description: O'NEILL-Brother B. Edward, F.S.C. On August 20 at Lincroft, NJ after a long illness. Son of the late Francis and Mary O'Neill. Beloved brother of Mrs. Kathleen Eschmann of Yonkers, NY and the late Alice Johnson, Edward, John and Arthur O'Neill. Revered uncle of many nieces and nephews. Family will receive visitors at the Christian Brothers Center of Manhattan College, 4415 Post Rd, Bronx, NY on Tuesday, August 21 from 3-5pm and from 7-9pm, and on Wednesday August 22 from 25pm and from 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at the Christian Brothers Center Chapel on Thursday August 23 at 10am. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to De La Salle Hall, 810 Newman Springs Rd, Lincroft, NJ, 07738 or to the Brother B. Edward O'Neill Scholarship Fund at Manhattan College.

title: New Middle East Peace Bid Brokered by German Envoy
description: Relations between Israel and the Palestinians have so thoroughly deteriorated that any glimmer of diplomatic action, however faint, is seized as a possible path toward a truce.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: He's 27, but Looks 26

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Grubman Witness To Testify
description: A nightclub security employee who was injured when the Manhattan publicist Elizabeth S. Grubman backed a sport utility vehicle into a crowd in Southampton last month is expected to testify before a grand jury tomorrow, said Christopher Modelewski, the employee's lawyer. Mr. Modelewski said that the employee, Scott Conlon, would not speculate as to whether Ms. Grubman deliberately backed into the crowd on July 7, injuring 16 bystanders. But in a sworn deposition immediately after the incident, Mr. Conlon said, ''I would swear that she was driving at me on purpose.'' Elissa Gootman (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: UBS Warburg Backs NextWave
description: The investment bank UBS Warburg has agreed to provide the bankrupt wireless communications company NextWave Telecom with $2.5 billion of debt financing for the construction of a nationwide network. In addition, UBS Warburg will serve as NextWave's financial adviser and assist with its reorganization plan. NextWave's fortunes improved when a federal appeals court recently ruled that the Federal Communication Commission improperly seized airwave licenses belonging to the company before auctioning them off to other wireless carriers for about $16 billion. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: New Leader Hits The Road
description: President Megawati Sukarnoputri departed on her first foreign trip as president since replacing Abdurrahman Wahid last month, meeting President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo in the Philippines, the first stop on a tour of nine Asian countries in eight days. Next month she is scheduled to visit the United States and meet President Bush, then stop in Japan on her way home. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Junior Players Find That Life Isn't Easy on the Fringe of the U.S. Open
description: The juniors who are invited to the United States Open qualifying often discover that winning age-group tournaments is far easier than beating the pro tour's unheralded players.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Heights for Andean Wine
description: THE awesome crags of the Andes glitter like icebergs in the early morning sunlight as the plane lets down here in western Argentina, across the grassy Pampas from Buenos Aires.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SAM
description: FRIEDMAN-Sam. On August 20, 2001. Survived by his loving wife, Marcy; children, Amy (Jeffrey), Andrew (Dorothy) and Richard; grandchildren, Michael, Ryan, Katie and Jenny. He will live in our hearts forever. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM, at Boulevard, Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: Applications Open for High Achievers
description: The new Bard High School Early College in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, an effort to let high-achieving public high school students start college two years early, has accepted about 100 students for 9th grade and more than 70 students who have completed 10th grade and now will begin the first year of college. The application window is open through next week. Applications are available on the Web at www.Bard.edu/BHSEC or by calling (212) 397-3055. Karen W. Arenson

title: Argentina Gets $8 Billion Aid From the I.M.F.
description: After nearly two weeks of negotiations, the International Monetary Fund announced tonight that it would provide up to $8 billion in emergency aid to Argentina to stabilize its economy.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Vineland: Ex-Officer In Sex Sting
description: A retired police captain was arrested after trying to lure someone he thought was a 12-year-old girl into a sexual liaison, the Cumberland County prosecutor said yesterday. The former captain with the Somers Point police is Lawrence J. Ceres, 56, of Egg Harbor Township. He is free on $10,000 bail after being charged with attempted sexual assault and other crimes. He is accused of arranging over the Internet to meet an under-age girl -- actually a police investigator -- at a park in Vineland, where he was arrested on Friday. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: ISLANDERS QUIET ON PECA REPORT
description: The Islanders would neither confirm nor deny a television report in Canada that said they were discussing an eight-year deal with Michael Peca, the restricted free-agent center. Peca's agent, Don Meehan, said yesterday that it would be a long shot for Peca to sign a deal for that long.

title: It's Graffiti, by Design, and Flying Cars to Come
description: STEPHEN SPROUSE is back in the limelight. But at this moment, the fashion designer would just as soon be someplace else. He is slight with piercing blue eyes and a weird pointy beard. And he is all jittery as he sits at a white, square table in an airy Chinatown loft.

title: What They Were Thinking
description: Chyd Denny, Judith Iam, Rabbi Ben Zion Levin, Miami, Dec. 17, 2000

title: High Noon in Albany
description: New York's governor is now suing the Legislature over the state budget. Meanwhile, schools are preparing to open without a clear idea of how much money they will have this year, and other important state services are in danger of running out of cash. The legal arguments must be suspended long enough to resolve the immediate crisis.

title: Fred Hoyle Dies at 86; Opposed 'Big Bang' but Named It
description: Sir Fred Hoyle, one of the most creative and provocative astrophysicists of the last half century, who helped explain how the heavier elements were formed and gave the name Big Bang, meant to be derisive, to the theory of cosmic origin he vehemently opposed, died on Monday in Bournemouth, England. He was 86 and lived in Bournemouth.

title: TRADING OF PROFESSIONAL DETAILING SHARES IS HALTED
description: Professional Detailing Inc., which markets drugs for pharmaceutical companies, said yesterday that it might end an agreement with GlaxoSmithKline after a court overturned an order blocking a generic version of Glaxo's antibiotic Ceftin. Shares of Professional Detailing, which closed Monday at $38.14, plunged as much as 30 percent in after-hours trading. The shares were halted yesterday during regular hours. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit ruled on Monday that Glaxo was unlikely to prove that the generic drug by Ranbaxy Laboratories of New Delhi, infringed its patent on cefuroxime axetil, the chemical name for Ceftin.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Chechnya Investigations
description: Chechnya's civilian prosector, Vsevolod Chernov, said that his office had completed investigations in 48 cases of crimes committed by Russian troops, but he acknowledged that many cases now await action by military prosecutors. Human rights groups have complained of the dual system of justice in Chechnya, where civilian investigators are denied access to military witnesses and evidence. Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

title: Deployment of Troops to Macedonia Approved by NATO
description: BRUSSELS, Aug. 22 — NATO formally gave the go-ahead today to its full 3,500-soldier mission to disarm rebels in Macedonia as a noon deadline passed without objections by any of the member countries.

title: Sports of The Times; What They Didn't Say: Speed Kills
description: IN every sport, when something goes wrong, the officials talk about fine-tuning.

title: Florida State Promises That the Sun Will Not Set on Its Dynasty
description: More than half of Florida State's players stayed here to practice on their own during the summer, a sign that the Seminoles do not intend to relinquish their grip as the country's most consistent college football program.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Keane Acquiring Smaller Rival
description: Keane Inc., a 36-year-old information technology consultancy, said it had agreed to acquire Metro Information Services Inc., another consulting firm, in a stock-for-stock transaction worth roughly $135 million. Each share of Metro common stock will be exchanged for 0.48 share of Keane common stock. In addition to cross-selling advantages, the merger will help Keane increase the size of its branches, the company said, as 26 of Metro's 33 branches are in geographic markets already served by Keane. Metro shareholders will receive shares representing about 9.6 percent of the combined company, which will have a market capitalization of $1.3 billion. Keane, which is based in Boston, will also assume Metro's debt, which as of July amounted to approximately $68 million. The deal is expected to close during the fourth quarter of 2001. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Father Wants Dead Baby Listed as Victim of Officer
description: A Brooklyn man whose 4-year-old son, sister-in-law and pregnant wife were killed two weeks ago after being struck by a minivan driven by a police officer accused of driving drunk said yesterday that he wanted the name of the child his wife was carrying to be added to the list of victims on the criminal charges.

title: Channel Surfing With a Diva, From BET to Playboy
description: Janet Jackson has been an underdog long enough. Her last name automatically put her in the shadow of her older brother Michael, although her hits since the mid-1980's have been forged with Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis, protgs of Mr. Jackson's sometime antithesis, Prince.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about a health care forum for mayoral candidates in which Michael R. Bloomberg questioned New York City's plan for the use of money from the national tobacco settlement misstated the amount the city is to receive. It is $6.7 billion over 25 years, not yearly.

title: Retailers Split Over Setting Sights on Tax Rebates
description: For taxpayers at loose ends over how to spend their rebates, Lowe's Home Improvement Warehouses has helpfully compiled a list of projects that cost from $300 to $600. Among the suggestions: put up a flagpole or build a playhouse.

title: Big Holders Heading for Exits at Deutsche Telekom
description: Deutsche Telekom executives have tried just about everything to prop up their company's share price: lashing out at the news media; pleading with big institutional shareholders; and even running full-page newspaper ads to beg for support from small investors.

title: Welcome Back For Hernndez? Only in Theory
description: The Yankees were enthusiastic about the mere sight of Orlando Hernndez on the mound again. Don Zimmer, the bench coach who is in his 53rd year in professional baseball and has watched thousands of games blend together, told Joe Torre over lunch that he was excited about tonight's game because he was so eager to see Hernndez. The mystery man was finally back.

title: Excerpts From the Hourlong Debate of the Democratic Candidates for Mayor
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's New York 1/New York Times debate of the Democratic candidates for mayor, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: 2 Accused of Staging Mercury Contamination
description: For a short while last year, the Fritzes of Arlington Heights became the first family of mercury contamination. Homeowners in northeastern Illinois had already been fretting about possible mercury leaks from a local gas company's meters, and the discovery of the toxic silvery beads inside the Fritz home last September seemed to confirm the worst fears.

title: Age Limit Is Urged for Motorized Scooter Users
description: Concerned about rising numbers of injuries, the Consumer Product Safety Commission will warn parents today not to permit children younger than 12 to ride motorized toy scooters.

title: Venus Williams Plans To Improve, Not to Quit
description: Brushing aside occasional suggestions by her father that she may be on the verge of retiring at the ripe old age of 21, Venus Williams came here this week in quest of her third straight Pilot Pen title, vowing to expand and improve her game and her work habits.

title: The Big City; O Optimism, Fragile Being, Tease Us Not
description: AT the start of yesterday's mayoral debate, one of the moderators noted a recent poll showing that New Yorkers are extraordinarily optimistic about the city's future. At that point in the debate, it seemed safe to predict that by the end of the hour a lot of New Yorkers would be rethinking their optimism.

title: UConn Quarterback Leaves School
description: With the start of Connecticut's season less than two weeks away, Ryan Tracey has decided to leave school, leaving the Huskies without an experienced quarterback.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Police Group Endorses McGreevey
description: James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, received the endorsement of New Jersey's largest police union yesterday and attacked his Republican rival, Bret D. Schundler, for his position on concealed weapons. Mr. Schundler said that if the Legislature approved the carrying of concealed weapons and the voters supported it, he would sign the measure. ''Mr. Schundler says that our state has the most restrictive gun laws in the nation,'' Mr. McGreevey said. ''I say, good.''

title: Sampras Revisits the Past, and Wins, Too
description: Pete Sampras used to be the world's top-ranked tennis player, an honor that had part of its genesis here, at the Hamlet Cup. When he played here in 1990, he went on the next week to capture the United States Open. At 19, he became its youngest champion.

title: NATO Clears Mission
description: NATO ministers gave the go-ahead to send a full task force of 3,500 soldiers into Macedonia to help disarm Albanian rebels if none of the 19 member nations object.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, SOPHIE BETESH
description: ADLER-Sophie Betesh, on August 20, 2001 at age 89. Loving wife of the late Morris. Mother of Harriet Weinstein and Marylin Silverman. Mother-in-law of Alan Weinstein & Joseph Silverman. Grandmother of Lisa, Mark, Andrew, Jennifer, Jordan, Renee, Kevin, Melissa, Lara, Katie, Elaine and Adam. She was simply the best. Services Thursday 12 noon at Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue & 91st Street, NYC. Contributions can be made in her memory to Palliative Care Center of The North Shore, 2821 Central St, Evanston, IL 60201.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Samsung Plans Bonds
description: Samsung Electronics has announced that it will issue three-year bonds worth 500 million won, or about $390 million, on Aug. 27 to cover maturing loans. The bonds, the first issued by the company since November 1998, will yield 5 percent a year, far below the prevailing corporate bond rate of nearly 10 percent. Samsung makes computer memory chips. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: GENERAL MOTORS AFFIRMS PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: The General Motors Corporation has affirmed its third-quarter profit outlook and production for the year, four days after the Ford Motor Company lowered its earnings forecast. Third-quarter profit at G.M. will be about 83 cents a share and production is expected to remain at about 1.23 million units, the company said. G.M. is forecast to earn 81 cents a share. Ford said on Friday that it would cut as many as 5,000 salaried jobs and earn about 70 cents a share this year, below the average forecast.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Cuts Interest Rates For Seventh Time This Year

title: Metro Business Briefing | AT&T To Add Monthly Charge
description: Beginning on Sept. 1, AT&T will add a monthly charge of $1.35 for in-state long-distance service to most residential customers' bills, the company has said. It said the charge was needed because it had to pay fees to local phone companies, predominantly Verizon, for access to networks to complete in-state long-distance calls. A Verizon spokeswoman, Ivette Mendez, said yesterday that there was no justification for the fee increase because the access fees Verizon charges have gone down. The disagreement is the latest in a dispute between AT&T and Verizon over fees AT&T pays to use Verizon's system. AT&T customers whose long-distance bills are less than $1 will not have to pay the new fee, nor will customers in its program for low-income customers. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Education Parties
description: The City Board of Elections agreed yesterday to allow Alan G. Hevesi's education-related party on the November ballot but again rejected the education party of Michael R. Bloomberg. The two mayoral candidates became embroiled in an unusual dispute last week when they each tried to place similarly named education parties before the voters. Mr. Hevesi originally submitted the Education Party and Mr. Bloomberg put forth the Education First Party. The board, saying that the parties sounded too much alike, ordered the two candidates to resubmit new party names that did not contain the word ''education.'' When Mr. Hevesi offered the Better Schools Party as an alternative, Mr. Bloomberg again asked the board to accept the Education First Party. The board rejected Mr. Bloomberg's effort. Dexter Filkins (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Property Company Sold
description: Oxford Properties, a commercial real estate group in Toronto, has agreed to be acquired for 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($971 million) in cash by the Ontario Municipal Employees Retirement System, one of Canada's biggest pension funds. The fund, which already owns 17 percent of Oxford, will take over 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($1.5 billion) in Oxford debt. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, MARCIA
description: COOPER-Marcia. Age 60, passed away peacefully following a long illness. Beloved wife of Fred, adored mother of Julie (John) Barber, and Seth Cooper, cherished daughter of Rose Epstein, sister of David Epstein. Services Thursday 11:30AM at ''I.J. Morris'', 21 E Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKOTOFF, MILTON M., HON
description: MOKOTOFF-Milton M., Hon. Age 84, of Sands Point, New York, died on Sunday, August 19. After sixty years of marriage, he remains adored by his wife, Shirley. Beloved father of Tama Bernstein, David Mokotoff, and Elaine Viders. Treasured grandfather of Marne Roskin (Tommy), Alexis and Leah Bernstein, Benjamin and Michael Mokotoff, Jared and Zachary Viders, and great-grandfather of Zoe Rose Roskin. Admitted to the New York State and Federal Courts and the United States Supreme Court, Judge Mokotoff graduated from St. John's School of Law and was admitted to the bar in 1941. He was the senior partner of the law firm Mokotoff & Mondshine and was a much sought-after arbitrator and mediator. Beyond the courts, he and his wife taught three generations the importance of living happily. He was an inspiration to all who had the good fortune to know him.

title: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Posts Loss
description: Intuit Inc., the maker of Quicken personal-finance software, reported a fiscal fourth-quarter loss on higher sales. The loss for the period ended July 31 was $61.3 million, or 29 cents a share, in contrast to net income of $17.1 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 18 percent, to $191.2 million from $162.3 million, the company said. Demand has waned for Intuit's small-business accounting software, leading the company to trim sales targets and focus on profit from newer products like payroll processing.

title: Mideast Peace Move By German Official
description: After weeks of violence, faint hopes for peace arose after announcements that the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, and the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, had agreed to a meeting arranged by the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer. But no one on either side was suggesting that it was a major breakthrough.

title: Hospital Details Failures Leading to M.R.I. Fatality
description: A poorly trained staff, technical malfunctions and lapses in communication among workers contributed to the death of a 6-year-old boy last month who was struck by an oxygen canister drawn into a magnetic resonance imaging machine at Westchester Medical Center, according to a report by the hospital released today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, EDNA HAWELKA
description: MEAD-Edna Hawelka. Died Saturday, August 18, 2001 at Somers Manor Nursing Home, Somers, NY. Mrs. Mead was a retired New York State Insurance Broker, life member of the Bronx Artists' Guide, life member of the Bronx County Historical Society and founding member of the Bronx Museum of the Arts and author of ''The Bronx Triangle: a Portrait of Norwood''. Born June 13, 1903 in New York City, she married Clarence Watson Mead who passed away on March 18, 1975. Survivors include two daughters, Louise Mead Tricard and son-inlaw John, of Cape Canaveral, FL; Jane Mead Peter of South Salem, NY; one grandchild Jonathan Mead Peter of South Salem and several nephews, grand nephews and nieces. Calling hours will be at Clark Assoc Funeral Home, Katonah, NY Wednesday 2-4 & 7-9pm. Service will be held Thursday, 11am at St. John's Episcopal Church, South Salem. Interment will follow at Woodlawn Cemetery, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to the Bronx Historical Society, 3266 Bain Bridge Avenue, Bronx, New York 10467.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Josh Dare was named vice president for corporate communications at the Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He succeeds Dean Jarrett, who has become senior vice president for business development at SLAY Public Relations, a unit of Martin. Mr. Dare had been vice president for marketing for SmartMouth.com, Boston, which closed.

title: Drug's Removal Exposes Holes In Europe's Net
description: When Bayer announced earlier this month that it was withdrawing its fast-selling cholesterol-lowering drug from the market, it pleased officials at the United States Food and Drug Administration, who had become alarmed by a rising number of deaths and severe reactions linked to the drug.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALDINGER, HERBERT, DR.
description: WALDINGER - Herbert, Dr. Though he has been gone for 16 years, our memories of his beauty and philanthropy are still alive in our minds and hearts, guiding us through our daily endeavors. He is remembered and cherished on this anniversary of his passing by his family and friends.

title: Wagner Doesn't Have to Wait This Time at the Black Course
description: Johnson Wagner did not have to sleep in his car tonight waiting to be first in line the next morning to play the Black Course at Bethpage State Park, site of next year's United States Open.

title: The Last Freeway
description: For at least a few minutes after it opened at 5 p.m. on Monday, the new six-mile stretch of the Foothill Freeway from Fontana to Rancho Cucamonga must have looked almost as fresh as the six-mile Arroyo Seco Parkway did when it first carried traffic from Pasadena to Los Angeles in December 1940. Together, these two stretches of concrete are the alpha and the near-omega of urban freeway construction in California. The Arroyo Seco Parkway, later renamed the Pasadena Freeway, opened just two months after the Pennsylvania Turnpike, becoming the first freeway in the West. The extension of the Foothill Freeway, which will fully link San Dimas and San Bernardino by 2006, may be the last. There are no new California freeways in the planning, a fact that gathers a lot of meaning when you consider that the Foothill Freeway was first sketched out in 1948.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page yesterday about the appointment of co-chief executives at the office of Marketing Drive Worldwide in Wilton, Conn., misidentified their predecessor. The executives, Christopher P. Barr and Kathryn A. Benedett, who were also named managing partners, are succeeding Chris Maher, not Don Grow hoski, who remains chief creative officer and a managing partner.

title: Social Security Query
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Mayor Offers Alternative To Klan Rally
description: Mayor Norm Coleman of St. Paul asked opponents of a Ku Klux Klan rally set for Saturday at the Capitol to attend a city-sponsored ice cream social and community gathering three miles away instead of protesting at the rally. But members of an anti-Klan group said they would attend the rally despite the mayor's contention that demonstrations would draw more attention to the Klan. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Business Travel; As the Concorde prepares to fly again, British Airways and Air France woo its customers.
description: ''THERE are people who start their week in New York, fly overnight to London and work a full day there, fly back to be in New York for dinner Tuesday night, work all day Wednesday in New York and then fly back over and work all day Thursday in London, and then fly back that night to spend Friday in New York,'' said Kelly Reed, a marketing executive for British Airways in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DANES, PETER
description: DANES-Peter. Beloved husband and father, died on August 20, 2001 at the age of 74. Peter was born in Czechoslovakia, but was forced to leave during World War II. He came to America as a young man in search of a better life. Peter went on to graduate from both Harvard and Harvard Business School and enjoyed a successful career on Wall Street. He was loved and respected by all who knew him, and will be deeply missed. He is survived by his wife, Liliana, and his son, Ari. We love you and will never forget you. Memorial services will be held on August 22, 2001 at 6 P.M. at Riverside Memorial, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILSTEIN, HENRIETTA
description: MILSTEIN-Henrietta. The entire YPO Metro Forum of Stephen Milstein wishes to extend with sadness our heartfelt condolences on the passing of his mother Henrietta. Andrew Klein Conrad Foa Walter Gardiner Joseph Cerniglia, Jr David Littman Marshall Kiev Nicholas Robinson Alan Ellman

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Arrest In Two Killings
description: A 28-year-old Bronx man was arrested yesterday in connection with the killings of a man and a woman whose badly decomposed bodies were found in the garbage at a trash-processing plant two weeks ago, the police said. The man who was arrested, Ryan Battle, was charged with murder. Sanitation workers at the plant on East 132nd Street found the bodies of Pedro Gonzalez, 65, and Josephine Gonzalez, 43, on Aug. 7. It was unclear last night how the Gonzalezes, who were both from the Bronx, were killed, and how their bodies ended up at the processing plant. Susan Saulny (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Inflation Slows
description: Canada's inflation rate, measured by the consumer price index, slowed to 2.6 percent for the year to July, Statistics Canada reported. The drop, from 3.3 percent in June and 3.9 percent in May, was largely because of lower energy prices, including a 9.6 percent drop in gasoline and an 8.4 percent decline in natural gas. Cheaper energy bills were partly offset by a 4.6 percent rise in food prices. Excluding food, energy and other volatile items, the core rate rose 2.4 percent in July, within the Bank of Canada's range of 1 percent to 3 percent. Bernard Simon (NYT)

title: Even Antique Glass Flowers Need to Be Rejuvenated
description: When it comes to sex, Lopezia coronata is an aggressor. Its pinkish flower, with its pouting, spoon-shaped lower petal and the offer of sweet nectar, lures an unsuspecting hover fly. But once the insect lands and sticks its head into the blossom's depths, the stamen, hidden inside the lower petal, springs into action, whacking the underside of the fly with a puff of pollen like an excitable makeup artist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, JUDY
description: MYERS-Judy. A friend is always there; whether you need advice or a pep talk or even a shoulder to cry on; a friend knows all your secrets, understands your fears, shares your dreams; a friend never stops believing in you even if you give up on yourself. You were a wonderful friend to me. With Love, Linda W.

title: U.S.T.A.'s Nighttime Final Fell Into Place
description: If anything crucial was missing in the marketing of the United States Open, it was a prime-time showcase for its finals. All the major leagues end their seasons at night. Why not the final Grand Slam tennis event of the year?

title: Brooks To Start For Saints
description: Aaron Brooks, an inexperienced backup when he was pressed into service last year, was named the starting quarterback for the New Orleans Saints yesterday, beating out the veteran Jeff Blake.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bid For Bank
description: JC Flowers & Company, a brokerage firm started by a former partner of the Goldman Sachs Group, Christopher Flowers, plans to bid for Bankgesellschaft Berlin, which had a loss of $1.4 billion last year. David Schamis, a principal at JC Flowers, said the company wanted to buy at least 75 percent of the bank. Losses at Bank Berlin, 56.6 percent owned by the city, will almost triple the city government's budget deficit this year.

description: European Focus on Cloning

title: Franchisees On Edge; Some Angry Ones Sue As GNC Competes
description: A decade ago, the General Nutrition Companies was a venerable but wobbly company in the business of selling vitamins and nutritional supplements, mostly to true believers in their health benefits. Then it decided to offer franchises to entrepreneurs who dreamed of being their own boss.

description: ASIA

description: The weak advertising economy has claimed another victim, as Hearst Magazines is closing Classic American Home.

title: National Briefing | Education: Campaign For Black And Latino Parents
description: With the achievement gap separating black and Latino students from whites showing no signs of narrowing, the N.A.A.C.P. and People for the American Way Foundation are starting a three-year campaign to urge black and Latino parents to become more involved in their children's education. The groups cited research showing the importance of factors contributing to children's academic success that parents can control, like setting high expectations and having books available at home. Diana Jean Schemo (NYT)

title: Bush Defends Size of Surplus And Tax Cuts
description: President Bush defended his tax cut today as affordable and essential to revitalizing the economy, and he waded into an intensifying battle with Democrats over who is to blame for the rapidly shrinking federal budget surplus.

title: Technology Briefing | Research: Oak Ridge Joins I.B.M. Project
description: I.B.M. is signing up the government's Oak Ridge National Laboratory to join in pursuing the next step in the company's Blue Gene supercomputing project. In a cooperative research and development agreement announced yesterday, I.B.M. and the government laboratory said they would work together mainly on the software required to solve complex scientific problems on a supercomputer with thousands of microprocessors linked together. The Oak Ridge computer scientists have faced similar software challenges from the laboratory's work in such fields as climate modeling and quantum mechanics. I.B.M.'s five-year, $100 million Blue Gene project, begun in late 1999, is pursuing one of life's basic biological mysteries: how amino acids fold into proteins. Though a research project, Blue Gene is seen by I.B.M. as an effort that will yield technologies and techniques that will move into the mainstream. ''Broadly, we want to take the equivalent of today's supercomputers and put them into businesses, even small and medium-size businesses, a few years from now,'' said David McQueeney, I.B.M. Research vice president for emerging business.

title: Why Put Out Every Wildfire in the Forests?
description: A year ago, crossing the Higgins Avenue bridge into downtown Missoula, I was unable to make out the Great Northern Railroad Depot five blocks away. The air was that thick with smoke. A dark, unblinking red sun hung in a sky that was reddish gray shading to black.

title: Liberties; Rip Van Rummy Awakes
description: When Rip Van Rummy came down from the mountain after 25 years, gray and lined, the village was much changed. Strange faces everywhere and a bustling, disputatious tone about it, bilious folk haranguing about politics. The very character of the people seemed different.

title: Explosion Wrecks a 14th-Century Monastery
description: An explosion today ripped apart a 14th-century monastery, one of the most revered Orthodox buildings in Macedonia, even as NATO officials maintained that the cease-fire here was generally holding.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Montana: Governor's Aide Faces Charges
description: The chief policy adviser to Gov. Judy Martz has been charged with negligent homicide in an accident last week that killed the majority leader of the state House, Representative Paul Sliter, left, who was a passenger in the car the adviser was driving. Prosecutors said that the adviser, Shane Hedges, who suffered only minor injuries in the crash, had a blood alcohol level of 0.15 percent at the time of the accident, well above the legal limit in Montana of 0.10. Investigators said Mr. Sliter was thrown from the car after Mr. Hedges drove off a dirt road and the car rolled down an embankment. Mr. Sliter, a Republican, was 32. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

Brandrup of Stamford, CT and Judith Claire Kerwin of San Francisco, CA. Devoted and loving grandfather to Kendra Claire Brandrup of NYC, Monika E. Hauge of Stony Creek, CT, Peter W. Brandrup of Ft. description: A LARGE direct marketing agency is expanding its offerings by acquiring a smaller one that specializes in marketing to Asian and Asian-American consumers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Peace Effort Leads To Jail
description: The police arrested 15 of 320 peace campaigners as they returned from North Korea, where they joined North Koreans for the 56th anniversary of the end of Japanese colonial rule over the Korean peninsula. Prosecutors planned to question them on why they apparently violated a pledge not to attend ceremonies at a new monument dedicated to North Korea's proposal for a North-South confederation. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Orientation Is Given the Old College Try
description: As our son neared the end of high school, my wife and I pondered deep and hard, soaked up reams of printed wisdom and decided that the ideal college for him would be small, rural and liberal arts.
