The family will receive friends from 2 until 5 P.M. and 7 until 9 P.M., Thursday at Ardrett Funeral Home.

title: Plan Ahead and Save
description: For couples who can plan ahead, three resorts on Jamaica are offering more than $1,000 off on a one-week stay from Jan. 1 to Dec. 21, 2002. Couples Ocho Rios, Couples Negril and Swept Away Negril will take $145 off each night if reservations are made by Sept. 26. With these discounts, a one-week stay starts at $2,135 to $2,415 a couple during the low summer season. Rates include all meals, drinks, activities, taxes and tips. Information: (800) 268-7537 or www.couples.com .

title: Countdown to the Great Labor Shortage
description: The daily flurry of layoffs is bringing major changes to the workplace as companies struggle with the economic downturn. But if government predictions play out as expected, soon there will be an equally big and opposite shift as baby boomers retire and the nation experiences one of its most severe labor shortages.

title: Suits Dismissed Against Morgan Stanley
description: A federal judge dismissed shareholder lawsuits against Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company and the analyst Mary Meeker, saying the complaints were ''an entangled mass of verbiage'' filled with ''market gossip.''

title: Above the Hudson, a Limestone Oasis
description: A few minutes' walk from the medieval complex at the Cloisters in Fort Tryon Park in upper Manhattan, another building deserves attention. What was once a tired restaurant concession in a 1930's limestone structure with chiseled arches near the park's southern entrance has been restored to elegance through the New York Restoration Project, an organization founded by Bette Midler to improve the city's parks and gardens. The renovated building now houses the New Leaf Cafe. A gas line has been installed for serious cooking. The restaurant is a cool, airy oasis, its dark oak contrasting with pale green walls. Profits from the restaurant will help maintain Fort Tryon Park. In a nod to the park's site above the Hudson River, Kristyn LaPlante, the chef, emphasizes Hudson Valley ingredients in the straightforward menu's salads, sandwiches, grilled chicken and steak. A snack bar on the lower level sells food to go. New Leaf Cafe is open for dinner every day but Monday. Lunch is served Tuesday through Saturday, brunch on Sunday. For reservations: (212) 568-5323.

title: Johnson's Big Opportunity Arrives With a Loud Ring
description: The phone in Nick Johnson's apartment in Columbus, Ohio, rang at 8 a.m. today, but he ignored the call. He planned to wait until noon before returning it. Then Johnson heard Rob Thomson, the Yankees' director of player development, leaving an urgent message that Johnson was needed in the major leagues. That changed Johnson's plan. He returned the call at 8:01.

title: Jilted by the New Economy, Tech Refugees Find Solace in the Old One
description: American companies have announced almost one million job cuts this year and more than one-quarter of them have come from the telecommunications and computer industries. Given those figures, it may be natural to assume that technology workers have suffered disproportionately as the economy has stumbled.

title: Dar es Salaam Journal; Tanzania Sees AIDS Lurking Between the Lines
description: Nobody would ever call Cheko a serious policy journal. And Zungu is not the paper to go to for world news. Kombora is rather risqu, and not much can be said for the intellectual heft of Mama Huruma or Chachandu or Kula Vitu.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Strike Again
description: Separatist rebels attacked a police station in eastern Sri Lanka, killing 15 constables and two station house workers. It was the biggest operation by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam since they sneaked into a military base and the country's international airport on July 24. The government retaliated for this latest assault with air attacks on rebel positions. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Bank Raises $739 Million
description: The United Overseas Bank raised 1.3 billion Singapore dollars, or about $739 million, in Singapore's largest corporate bond sale to date. The bank will use the money to offset its 10 billion Singapore dollars purchase ($5.7 billion) of the rival Overseas Union Bank. United had planned to issue $750 million Singapore dollars ($426 million) in 15-year bonds, but said it increased the issue after its underwriters, J. P. Morgan and Merrill Lynch, received a lot of interest. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Distracted, Wall St. Ignores Signs of an Economic Bottom
description: Falling unemployment claims. Rising housing starts. Declining inventories. An end to the slide in industrial production. Over the last month, signs of an economic bottom have appeared.

title: Panel Releases Report on Earnhardt's Death
description: Dale Earnhardt, the seven-time Winston Cup champion, most likely died of a fracture at the base of his skull Feb. 18 at the Daytona 500 when the unprotected part of his head hit either the steering wheel or the bucket seat inside his famous No. 3 black Chevrolet, a team of independent experts commissioned by Nascar said in a report that was released today.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Thwarted Diplomats Leave
description: Denied a chance to visit their jailed countrymen, three diplomats -- from the United States, Australia and Germany -- have left Kabul and gone to Pakistan. The envoys wanted to meet with aid workers who have been charged with trying to convert Muslims to Christianity. The ruling Taliban militia said its investigators were now inquiring ''whether these people were conducting these activities of their own choice or whether they had the support of a power.'' Barry Bearak (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Immigration Service To Begin Reorganization Soon
description: James W. Ziglar, President Bush's new commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said he expected to begin restructuring the service by early fall. The effort, he said, would take two to three years. Members of Congress have sought an overhaul of the agency, and Mr. Bush has said it must shorten the time it takes to deliver services. Mr. Ziglar decried a culture split between service personnel and enforcement officers, and cited two enforcement priorities: human smugglers and employers who mistreat illegal workers.

title: Freshmen in Hartford Study a Lesson Plan in Character
description: At first glance, few of Hartford High School's Class of 2005, sitting around miniature round tables in a sticky first-floor classroom today, seemed taken by any of the Seven Habits of Highly Effective Teens.

title: City Marshal Killed in Brooklyn Eviction Attempt
description: A city marshal trying to evict a tenant from a three-story Brooklyn apartment building yesterday afternoon was killed when an argument with tenants escalated into a vicious fight near the building's entrance that ended when he was set afire, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Credits were omitted last Wednesday for two recipes with an article about American-made crme frache. The recipes, for lemon chicken and for zucchini with crme frache pesto, were adapted from ''The Crme Frache Cookbook'' by Sadie Kendall (Ridgeview Publishing, 1989).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLANKINSHIP, W.H. (JOHN)
description: BLANKINSHIP-W.H. (John). Age 69 of Denville, died of lung cancer on August 21st. A leading figure in the New York printing industry, John and his wife ran Museum Press. He formerly held supervisory positions at Midwestern Litho, Corporate Printing, Sanders Printing, & Panorama Press. Survived by his mother Hazel, wife Yan, children Kevin, Gerry, Joan and John, and twelve grandchildren. John was an avid fisherman and hunter. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to American Cancer Society in memory of Worland Harry Blankinship. Mass St. Mary's Catholic Church, Myers Avenue, Denville, NJ, 10:30 AM Friday, August 24. NYC memorial gathering to be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GURA, RAYMOND
description: GURA-Raymond. Beloved husband of the late Estelle, devoted father of Sheryl Anne Rosenberg and Nick Gura. Loving grandfather of Ivana and Jahna. Services were held Tuesday, August 21, 2001. Shiva at the Rosenberg home.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Last Of The Great Lobster Runs?
description: Maine lobstermen say the abundant catches of the last dozen years may finally be thinning. Traps were full in July last year, but this year the lobsters have only begun to show up. The last four years set records, culminating in 2000 in a 57-million-pound catch worth $186.1 million. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Excite At Home Drops Its Critical Auditor
description: Excite@Home disclosed today that it switched accounting firms a day after its independent auditors expressed substantial doubt that the company, once a dominant Internet portal and now a humbler broadband service provider, could generate enough cash to stay in business.

title: Corny as New York in August
description: Lunchtime nibblers in Chelsea are carrying ears of fresh yellow-and-white corn with spiky husks left on like the Statue of Liberty's crown. Sold at City Bakery, 3 West 18th Street, the corn can be dressed with sea salt and cilantro oil or ancho chili oil, and foil-wrapped for eating later or on the spot, in the shop or on the street. The ears are $1.50 each. Next week, they will also be sold grilled with lime, chili and cheese, for $2. Ilene Rosen, the chef, said the corn would be sold until the season ends, in about a month.

title: Schundler Repeats Call For Referendum on Arena
description: Bret D. Schundler, taking advantage of an opportunity to differentiate himself from most of the state's political leadership in his campaign for governor, for a second day pressed his call for a referendum on a state-supported sports arena in Newark.

title: Liberty Conquers Sol Zone, And Gains Eastern Finals
description: The job the Liberty faced last night was simple: stop Ruth Riley, the Miami Sol's dominant rookie center; stop Yelena Baranova and Sandy Brondello, two of the best outside shooters in the Women's National Basketball Association; and penetrate Miami's tough zone defense, among other things.

title: Philip Crosby, 75, Developer Of the Zero-Defects Concept
description: Philip Bayard Crosby, a onetime assembly line worker who became an entrepreneur spreading the gospel of quality control in manufacturing, died on Sunday at a hospital in Asheville, N.C.

title: NATO Conditionally Approves Troops for Macedonia

Beloved brother of Mrs. Kathleen Eschmann of Yonkers, NY and the late Alice Johnson, Edward, John and Arthur O'Neill. Revered uncle of many nieces and nephews. Family will receive visitors at the Christian Brothers Center of Manhattan College, 4415 Post Rd, Bronx, NY on Tuesday, August 21 from 3-5PM and from 7-9PM, and on Wednesday, August 22nd from 2-5PM and from 7-9PM. title: Trying to Make It There So They Can Make It Anywhere
description: Frantically flapping their mouths like beached fish gulping the air on a polluted shore, the aspiring actors in ''Lisa Picard Is 'Famous,' '' are so thirsty for attention they confirm our lurking suspicions of the acting profession as a hotbed of whiny self-absorbed narcissists. This hilarious fake documentary, directed by Griffin Dunne from a script by Laura Kirk and Nat DeWolf, who costar, deserves a place beside the comedies of Christopher Guest in the hall of fame of semi-deadpan spoofs.

title: THE FINE PRINT: A Wilderness Gift; Alaska Land Transfer Puts Senator on Spot
description: Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, wants to give 1,505 acres of prime Alaska wilderness -- owned by the federal government and worth millions of dollars -- to a small restoration group headed by a longtime friend. Mr. Stevens tucked a one-sentence measure to do just that into the fine print of the $60 billion transportation appropriations bill, which the Senate passed earlier this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WIESEN, SADONIA ECKER
description: WIESEN-Sadonia Ecker, 86, died at her home in Flushing on 20 August. Mother, Grandmother, Friend, she left us all a legacy of love and courage, study and fortitude. Cherished wife of the late David Theodore Wiesen, she was a legal secretary for 20 years, and then a school secretary for the New York City Board of Education. She attended Queens College and the New School for Social Research. A life-long athlete, she loved to swim, play tennis, row boats, ride horses, drive cars, dance, and ''gahula.'' Her verve, vivacity, and fierce independence flourished to the end, and will remain forever with us. Blanche Wiesen Cook, Marjorie Wiesen Lessem, Clare Coss, Daniel Wayne Lessem, Doug Lessem, Richard Delewsky.

title: Helms Won't Seek Re-election in 2002, Associate Says; Senator Will Speak Today
description: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, a conservative stalwart for nearly 30 years, plans to appear on television in Raleigh on Wednesday evening to announce that he will retire from the Senate when his fifth term expires in January 2003, a person close to Mr. Helms said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOUREKAS, THEODORA N.
description: LOUREKAS-Theodora N. Of Garden City, NY, died Sunday, August 19, 2001, at age 77. She is survived by her daughter Virginia, her son Peter, and her grandchildren Alicia and Simona. Theodora, known at Teddy, worked for Long Island Trust Bank for over twenty years and became a Vice President in the Trust Department. She also was a Chartered Financial Analyst. Teddy served as President of the Garden City Community Club, from 1996-1999. Teddy established and served on the committee that published ''The Art of Greek Cookery'', one of the original and bestselling ethnic cookbooks. Viewing: Friday, August 24 at Fairchild Sons, Garden City (516) 746-0585. Service will be at 9:30 A.M., on Saturday, August 25 at St. Paul's Greek Orthodox Church, 110 Cathedral Avenue, Hempstead.

title: Judge Denies Bid by Gatien To Select Team To Run Club
description: A bankruptcy judge yesterday denied an 11th-hour request by the beleaguered nightclub owner Peter Gatien to turn over the management of his club, the Tunnel, to a team he had assembled.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Josh Dare was named vice president for corporate communications at the Martin Agency, Richmond, Va., part of the Partnership unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He succeeds Dean Jarrett, who has become senior vice president for business development at SLAY Public Relations, a unit of Martin. Mr. Dare had been vice president for marketing for SmartMouth.com, Boston, which closed.

title: My Hip-Hop Id
description: I like to think of hip-hop as a fountain of refreshment conveniently located as close by as my Walkman. I know this feeling is associated more with teenage boys than with a woman closing in on 30. Women sate themselves with the sentimentalities of R & B; for the most part, it is men who listen to hip-hop. Women particularly notice and are particularly repulsed by hip-hop's occasional, florid disavowals of intimacy. But the Woman Question is a minor subject in the music; it is money, willpower and self-respect that command the rapper's attentions.

title: National Briefing | Washington: One Small Sale For 'Fair Trade' Coffee
description: A group of 60 Democratic congressmen pressed the Capitol's cafeterias to sell coffee that yields higher profits to growers. The contractor providing food services for the Capitol agreed to a trial service for what supporters call ''fair trade'' coffee once a week in the Longworth Office Building coffee shop. Farmers who grow fair trade coffee and export directly earn $1.26 a pound compared with about 20 cents a pound for farmers who use middlemen, said Kimberly Easson of Transfair USA, a group that certifies the coffee.

title: Show Raises Reality Question

description: The two leading makers of mobile phones in Japan, NEC and Matsushita, said today that they would join forces to develop software and applications for the next generation of wireless technology, which would allow users to send and receive streaming video.

title: Christie Todd Whitman May Have the Most Thankless Job in Washington
description: Christie Whitman arrives at the home ballpark of the Lowell Spinners, the Boston Red Sox' Class-A affiliate in the old mill town of Lowell, Mass. The stadium rises atop a cleaned-up toxic-waste site and is the kind of place administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency go. It's a glinting citadel of the new and well made, wedged among boarded-up factories. But there is no crowd waiting, only a few baseball staff members. When she was governor of New Jersey, Whitman caused a stir wherever she went; many expected her to ascend either to the United States Senate or to the vice-presidential slot on the 2000 Republican ticket. Instead she now visits toxic-waste sites. ''At least today is a clean day,'' Whitman notes. Often when she travels to inspect something, it's garbage or ooze or worse.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Black Bear Kills Woman
description: A 93-year-old woman was killed in her rural home near Mora, N.M., by a black bear, a species not generally known for attacking humans. After finding the body of Adelia Maestas Trujillo on Saturday, the authorities said that an autopsy determined she had been mauled to death. Such attacks are exceedingly rare in New Mexico, even with the rising number of bear encounters with humans. State officials said the number of encounters rose by 50 percent, to 228, from July 2000 through June, compared with the previous year. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22  Gen. Richard B. Myers of the Air Force is expected to be named the new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff by President Bush on Friday, administration officials said today.

title: MetroCard Hours Extended for Students
description: Transportation officials have agreed to extend free MetroCard hours to 10:30 p.m. for Jewish students who attend Talmud classes late into the evening. Most students' passes are valid until 8:30 p.m. But STATE ASSEMBLYMAN DOV HIKIND worked with transit officials to extend the hours for yeshiva students in Grades 7 through 12, many of whom have class until 10 p.m. Abby Goodnough

description: Was it a brilliant bit of risk-taking and some routine corporate legerdemain, or the biggest fraud in California history?

title: Referrals to Special Education Are Down, Schools Chancellor Says
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that there had been a 24 percent reduction over the last three school years in the number of children referred for the evaluations that determine whether they should receive special education services.

title: Keeping Secrets at Too High a Price
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee, foiled last year only by President Bill Clinton's veto, is again putting together a bill that would establish the country's first-ever official secrets act. It is a remarkable post-cold war paradox: At a time when the rest of the world is looking to America for leadership on openness, Congress would make it harder for Americans to know what their government is doing and would give aid and comfort to every tin-pot dictator who wants to claim ''national security'' as the reason to keep his citizens in the dark.

title: A Kayak and Paddle Guide to Waterside Dining
description: New Yorkers have always relished finding out-of- the-way dining spots. Now urban adventurers are taking advantage of increasingly clean local waterways to extend the hunt with commando kayak dining. Unlike the dock-and-dine crowd, experienced kayakers tend to haul out like seals along remote channels and overlooked spits of sand. But developers are catching on. Plans for the new Guggenheim Museum downtown call for East River access and a cafe. Those with foldable kayaks can paddle up, put their boats into backpacks and check them at the restaurant door. Kayakers use New York's original mass transit system, riding currents that change direction about every six hours. For travel with experienced guides, the Manhattan Kayak Company (212-924-1788) leads weekend sushi tours, above, from Pier 63 in Chelsea to the Matsushima restaurant in Edgewater, N.J.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Utah: Lawmaker Dies In Accident
description: A prominent state lawmaker, Senator Pete Suazo of Salt Lake City, was found dead after the all-terrain vehicle he was driving on a hunting trip in central Utah apparently hit a tree. Mr. Suazo, a Democrat, had been hunting with friends when he did not return to their campsite on Sunday night. A search found Mr. Suazo's body on Monday morning, pinned under his vehicle. A lawmaker since 1996, he was 50. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Young Italians Stand at Attention, Which Their Ensemble Attracts
description: Judging from the tide of recent recordings and the offerings at this year's Mostly Mozart Festival, the world of European period instrument bands is tilting toward the south, with the hottest groups no longer coming from England and the Netherlands, but from Italy. One of the newest is the Venice Baroque Orchestra, a group founded in 1997 by Andrea Marcon, who conducts it from the harpsichord. It is, not surprisingly, a youthful group that plays zestily and with a tightly drilled ensemble. And in the spirit of older bands like I Musici, all but its cellists and a lutenist perform standing.

title: SHARES OF AMERICAN EAGLE FALL AFTER EARNINGS REVISION
description: Shares in American Eagle Outfitters Inc., which sells clothing for teenagers and young adults, fell 28 percent after the company said third-quarter earning would miss expectations. The shares fell $9.06, to $23.21. The company, based in Warrendale, Pa., said earnings in the third quarter would increase 45 cents to 47 cents, or 10 percent to 15 percent, from 41 cents a share, a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call is 49 cents. Same-store sales for the quarter will increase in the low single digits, the chief financial officer, Laura Weil, said. The company is planning more promotions.

title: GUIDANT SHARES RISE ON WORD OF WORK WITH STENTS
description: Shares of the Guidant Corporation, which makes medical devices, rose more than 11 percent yesterday after it said that it would work with Cook Inc. in an effort to bring to market a new stent -- a tube to prop open clogged arteries -- that is coated with drugs to stop the artery from becoming blocked again. Guidant said the deal would cut its schedule to bring a drug-coated stent to market by six months, which analysts said would narrow the lead of Johnson & Johnson to six to nine months. Guidant and Cook said on Monday that Guidant would become worldwide distributor of Cook's coronary stents. Shares of Guidant rose $3.40, to $35.

The Onslow County Board of Commissioners adopted a resolution on Monday opposing such exercises at Camp Lejeune, which the Center for Naval Analysis said was the top alternative to Vieques. President Bush has promised to end the Navy's involvement at Vieques by 2003. Lino R. Rodriguez Jr. (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Federal Cybercrimes Squad
description: The United States attorney's office in Brooklyn announced yesterday that it was forming a special unit to prosecute crimes in cyberspace. The new unit will investigate computer crimes, including hacking, the deliberate spread of viruses, economic espionage and the theft of trade secrets. James Walden, an assistant United States attorney who was recently the deputy chief of Brooklyn's organized-crime division, will lead the unit. His deputy will be Lauren Resnick, who was also transferred from the organized-crime squad. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Retreat on Clean Air
description: Christie Whitman says that one of her main goals as President Bush's chief environmental officer is to streamline the Clean Air Act without diminishing its effectiveness. On the face of it, this is a laudable objective. Even Mrs. Whitman's predecessor at the Environmental Protection Agency, Carol Browner -- who built a stellar record on clean air by aggressively using nearly every regulatory lever the act has to offer -- was heard to complain about its complexity.

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: AIDS Drug Sought
description: The Treatment Action Campaign, a group that lobbies on AIDS issues, asked a High Court judge to order the government to distribute the AIDS drug Nevirapine widely to pregnant women who are infected with H.I.V. The government has already begun small-scale distribution of the drug, which sharply reduces a pregnant woman's risk of transmitting the virus to her newborn. The Treatment Action Campaign says that the government program is too small and that officials have taken too long to get it running. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Economy Grows 2.7%
description: The economy grew in the second quarter at its lowest rate since the first quarter of 1999. The Bank of Korea said growth from April through June was 2.7 percent higher than in the second quarter of last year. The bank had originally forecast growth of 3.3 percent. The bank attributed the slowdown to declining semiconductor exports and investment in new plants. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: My Many Citizenship Quests
description: I was almost 7 when we left Cuba, and my brother, Pedro, was almost 9. My father owned a pineapple business, and the family was part of Cuba's high society, but the Cuban Revolution changed all that. One day I recall people knocking at the door. Some had guns. Men in olive-green uniforms took my father away. He was gone a couple of days. As soon as he was able to free himself, we left very quickly, within a day or two. My father feared that if he stayed something terrible would happen.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Norwood: Mystery Skeleton Was A Woman
description: Early tests show that the nearly intact human skeleton found last week in a Norwood backyard was that of a woman who died ''a very long time ago,'' the assistant Bergen County prosecutor handling the case said yesterday. The tests, conducted by a forensic anthropologist, indicate that the woman was about 5 feet 6 inches tall and 17 to 21 years old. The prosecutor said the remains, found last Wednesday by construction workers, show no evidence of homicide or assault. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: My Daily Dose of Murder
description: Years ago, when I was a uniformed police officer in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, a man walked up to me at a school crossing and started speaking Italian. I couldn't understand him, so I sent him to find someone who could translate. At the same time, a woman approached, walking her dog. The dog brushed up against a pole and got a bad shock. That's what the man had been trying to tell me, that there was a short inside the pole and not to let the kids touch it.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Symbian In Alliance With Intel
description: Intel and Symbian said they would cooperate to develop software for wireless devices based on Intel's Personal Internet Client Architecture and Symbian's operating system for data-enabled mobile phones. The Intel standard, also known as PCA, is designed to speed the development of software for low-power mobile devices that combine voice communications and Internet access. Symbian's operating system is already used by mobile phone manufacturers like Nokia, Ericsson, Siemens, Motorola and Panasonic. The two companies will issue joint development kits, create a design guide to assist developers and offer programs at conferences. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Melon Balls At the Top Of Their Game
description: Proof that Artisanal, 2 Park Avenue (32nd Street), is about more than cheese comes from a refreshing melon ''cocktail'' with a ginger and Sauternes-lime gele. Though served as a hot-weather first course, it could as easily be a dessert. To make it at home for six, start early in the day. Soften a teaspoon of plain gelatin in a tablespoon of cold water, bring two cups of Sauternes to a boil with a quarter cup of lime juice, remove from the heat and whisk in gelatin. Refrigerate until jelled. Whisk thoroughly and chill for two hours more. Scoop about eight cups of small melon balls (seven or so pounds of untrimmed melon). Place a tablespoon of the gele in each of six martini glasses, add the melon and the rest of the gele. Top with slivers of crystallized ginger mixed with strips of lime zest.

title: Target Reports Rise in Profit; Saks Says Its Losses Widened
description: The Target Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal second-quarter profit rose 5 percent as it lured consumers concerned about prices in the slowing economy, while Saks Inc. said its second-quarter loss widened because of declining sales at its Saks Fifth Avenue chain and regional department stores.

title: New York Public Library Buys Kerouac Archive
description: The literary and personal archive of Jack Kerouac, whose 1957 quasi-autobiographical novel ''On the Road'' helped to define the Beat generation, has been acquired by the New York Public Library's Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection, the library announced yesterday.

title: Midtown Playground for an Uptown Chef
description: FIRST, that burger. Like a Detroit prototype car, the $27 DB burger has been through many redesigns and modifications, picking up and dropping ingredients along the way, and only gradually working its way onto the main menu after serving an apprenticeship as a weekly special. It is now the chief ornament of Daniel Boulud's newest venture, a lively, even raucous restaurant that tries to pass for a bistro but can't quite disguise its high-class leanings.

title: F.T.C. SEEKS MORE INFORMATION ON BIOTECHNOLOGY DEAL
description: PerkinElmer Inc. and the Packard BioScience Company said yesterday that the Federal Trade Commission had requested additional information regarding PerkinElmer's purchase of Packard. PerkinElmer, which makes genetic-screening equipment and laboratory instruments, announced last month that it would pay $650 million for Packard BioScience, which makes equipment for biotechnology research. PerkinElmer and Packard said they would comply with the request.

title: Florida Journal; Smitten Beachgoers Still Brave The Water
description: Joe Wooden, deputy beach chief here in Volusia County, said he had experienced some vicious attacks in the past few days, not from the sharks but from surfers.

title: Metro Business Briefing | AltaVista Settles Inquiry
description: AltaVista, a popular online research aid, has upgraded its software to prevent personal information about people using its services from being inadvertently transferred to Internet marketers, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer of New York said yesterday. Mr. Spitzer discussed the service's action in announcing the settlement of a case in which many AltaVista users' home or work addresses were sent to an Internet marketing service, which was a violation of AltaVista's own privacy policy. Mr. Spitzer's office and AltaVista agreed that AltaVista had not been aware of the transfer, which it said had stemmed from a flaw in the software it used in its online Yellow Pages directory. AltaVista agreed to pay $70,000 in penalties and for the cost of the state's investigation. An AltaVista spokesman, David Emanuel, said that the unintended transfers occurred during a two-month period in late 1999, that the software problem had been quickly fixed and that none of the addresses had gone from the marketing service to an advertiser. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Joins In China Bid
description: The natural gas company in Russia, Gazprom, has received approval from the largest oil company in China, PetroChina, to join the Royal Dutch/Shell Group in a consortium to bid for a $6 billion pipeline. Gazprom and Shell will compete with two other consortiums led by units of BP and the Exxon Mobil Corporation. PetroChina is expected to decide in September which group will build the 2,600-mile pipeline that will link the western Xinjiang province with eastern Shanghai. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Sentenced For Baby's Death
description: Sylvia Hernandez, who pleaded guilty last month to manslaughter in the death of her newborn, was sentenced yesterday to seven years in prison. The baby's body was found in January in a city garage. Ms. Hernandez, who was 18 when she suffocated the infant, appeared before Justice Paul G. Feinman of State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Katherine E. Finkelstein (NYT)

title: THE CHEF
description: YOU don't see breast of veal on a lot of menus -- it doesn't seem as classy as, say, a veal chop or a loin roast. But it's a great cut for home cooks. It takes time, but you have something delicious and impressive that can be entirely prepared in advance. And it gives you a dozen servings.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: State Takes Custody Of Teenager
description: A 17-year-old girl who has told the authorities that she was paid to have sexual contact with Mayor Philip A. Giordano is now in the protective custody of state child welfare officials. Mr. Giordano was arrested last month on charges that he tried to lure a minor for sex. The teenager, who has not been publicly identified, is a cousin of two girls, ages 9 and 10, who have been described by family members and a family lawyer as victims in the Giordano case. Child welfare officials asked a juvenile court judge to order the 17-year-old into protective custody on Monday. State officials would not discuss the case. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

description: ''As long as I can hear the sound I know I am here.''

title: GOODYEAR CUTS PRODUCTION AS SALES TO AUTOMAKERS FALL
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will reduce production by an unspecified amount through September because of a decline in sales to automakers. The drop in sales reflected industrywide declines of 32 percent for light-truck tires and 5 percent for passenger-car tires in July from a year ago, the company said. A company spokesman, Keith Price, said that Goodyear, based in Akron, Ohio, had cut production every month this year as part of a plan to better match demand. While its second-quarter profit fell 90 percent, it gained more than 2 percentage points in market share from a year earlier, in part because of safety concerns from the recalls of Firestone tires. Shares of Goodyear fell 75 cents, to $24.67.

title: Paid by the Job to Wade Into Trouble
description: As officially appointed bearers of bad news, city marshals have occasionally come under physical attack and more often provoked simple vitriol. Their job, under centuries-old city and state statutes, is to serve papers, evict people and tow away cars.

title: A Fish Called Trigger
description: A fish rarely seen in restaurants is in season at some of New York's Greenmarkets. It is an Atlantic flatfish called trigger, after its retractable top fin, and has the sweet richness of crab but a firm, meaty texture, like cod with integrity. And it's easy to cook: just dust fillets with flour and saut them in hot butter for two or three minutes a side. You won't even want lemon. Blue Moon, of Mattituck, N.Y., is selling trigger for about $7.50 a pound through September at Union Square on Wednesdays and Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn on Saturdays; also at the Washington market (Greenwich and Chambers Street) in TriBeCa on Saturdays. It goes fast. The catch is small, and market regulars are catching on. REGINA SCHRAMBLING

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about interest in genealogy misidentified a research company that surveyed people about their interest in tracing their origins. It is Maritz Marketing Research, not Matrix Marketing Research. The article also misidentified the county for Mechanicsburg, Pa., home of a woman who traveled to Reading, Pa., to research her family tree. It is in Cumberland County, not Dauphin.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel To Unveil 2-Gigahertz Chip
description: Intel plans to begin selling the world's first two-gigahertz desktop microprocessor next week. Intel said it would show off the two-gigahertz Pentium 4 chip on Monday at a conference for hardware and software developers. The company took three decades to produce a chip that ran at one gigahertz, but only 18 months to double that speed. A chip's so-called clock speed, or frequency, is only one factor in its overall performance, but one that Intel has flaunted as a marketing advantage over its rival Advanced Micro Devices, which is preparing to release its fastest chip, the 1.5-gigahertz Athlon. ''Intel is playing the frequency hand,'' said Kevin Krewell, a senior analyst with The Microprocessor Report, a trade publication. ''They keep cranking them up.'' Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, NATHANIEL (TOM) H.
description: MENDELSON-Nathaniel (Tom) H. Age 92, of Boca Raton, FL., formerly of New York City, died August 20, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Yvette M. Mendelson. Dear brother of Jesse Mendelsohn, Albany, NY. Cherished uncle of Lori (Steven) Strong and Allan (Eileen) Mendelsohn. He started his career in the Youth Fashion Industry after graduating Union College and joining the Carl Company in Schenectady. Mr. Mendelson was the former Executive Director of the Youth Fashion Guild, Past President of the Association of Buying Offices and the Infants, Childrens, Teens Buyer Association. He was an author & professor of Children's Wear Merchandising. He was on numerous Government Advisory Committees on Sizing and Standards for the Children's Wear Industry and was also active in fund raising for both the United Jewish Appeal and Israel Bonds. He was an avid gardener and world traveler. Mr. Mendelson was presently the President of the Cedar Cay Home Owners Association in Broken Sound. He will be missed by all who knew him. Memorial services will be held Wednesday 1 PM at the Broken Sound Country Club, 2401 Willow Springs Drive, Boca Raton, FL. Donations may be made to UJA, Israel Bonds, or the Alzheimer's Association. Services entrusted to Philip M. Weinstein's Shalom Memorial Chapels, Margate, Florida, phone 1-877-554-7878.

title: From Italy, A Cool Summer Secret
description: ON a cold night last winter, I went with friends to Caffe Rosso in Greenwich Village. I was in the mood for veal and red wine. When the main courses came, the waiter set down my veal Milanese: a pounded chop as large as a frying pan, crusted with bread crumbs and smothered with a glistening mess of arugula and tomatoes. I squeezed lemon over the veal and set about carving. It was just what I was after: the tender meat was pounded paper-thin with fat on the edges and a thin, pebbly coating of bread crumbs. The peppery salad and lemon offered steady relief. But it left me with a single thought: to come back in the summer when arugula and tomatoes are in season.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Research Group To Offer Stock
description: The Nomura Research Institute, a unit of Nomura Securities, said it would list shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Oct. 2, the first time a major research center has gone public in Japan. The company, which draws much of its revenue from computer system solutions, will raise 22.7 billion yen ($188.14 million) by offering new shares and use the proceeds to pay off debt. title: Paper to Focus on Discrimination's Toll

His topic will be the accumulated disadvantages faced by black Americans because of centuries of discrimination, including the lack of wealth among the black middle class. Karen W. Arenson

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mount Vernon: Mayor Accused In Lawsuit
description: A former Mount Vernon police commissioner has filed a federal lawsuit against the city and its mayor, accusing the mayor of misusing federal drug forfeiture money and blocking police investigations against the mayor's friends. The ex-commissioner, Gertrude LaForgia, took the job in December 1998 and left abruptly last month. The lawsuit, filed on Aug. 15, also accused the mayor, Ernest Davis, of firing Ms. LaForgia and falsely telling the press she had resigned. Mr. Davis said Ms. LaForgia had resigned of her own accord, and called her accusations false and outlandish. Robert Worth (NYT)

title: A Kayak and Paddle Guide to Waterside Dining
description: New Yorkers have always relished finding out-of-the-way dining spots. Now urban adventurers are taking advantage of increasingly clean local waterways to extend the hunt with commando kayak dining. Unlike the dock-and-dine crowd, experienced kayakers tend to haul out like seals along remote channels and overlooked spits of sand. But developers are catching on. Plans for the new Guggenheim Museum downtown call for East River access and a cafe. Those with foldable kayaks can paddle up, put their boats into backpacks and check them at the restaurant door. Kayakers use New York's original mass transit system, riding currents that change direction about every six hours. For travel with experienced guides, the Manhattan Kayak Company (212-924-1788) leads weekend sushi tours, above, from Pier 63 in Chelsea to the Matsushima restaurant in Edgewater, N.J. Here are other possible destinations (information on navigating is available at www. nytimes.com/foodstuff):

title: My Hip-Hop Id
description: Ilike to think of hip-hop as a fountain of refreshment conveniently located as close by as my Walkman. I know this feeling is associated more with teenage boys than with a woman closing in on 30. Women sate themselves with the sentimentalities of R & B ; for the most part, it is men who listen to hip-hop. Women particularly notice and are particularly repulsed by hip-hop's occasional, florid disavowals of intimacy. But the Woman Question is a minor subject in the music; it is money, willpower and self-respect that command the rapper's attentions.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Parents And Children Killed

The attack, in a mainly Albanian region west of the capital, may have been aimed at the father of the family, a former member of the Serbian police force. Serbs and Albanians have continued to attack each other in the Serbian province since NATO drove out the Yugoslav Army there in 1999. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

''I'm breaking my own rule,'' said the singer-songwriter Freedy Johnston as his percussive strum signaled the beginning of a version of Barry Manilow's processed-cheese pop classic, ''It's a Miracle.'' Mr. Johnston had promised earlier that he would resist Mr. Manilow's oeuvre, but in this rambling, affable show, such restraint was unnecessary.

title: Where the Best Hold On for Dear Life
description: HERE on the rocky coast of northwest Spain, where the lives of humans and barnacles overlap, the ocean favors the barnacles. These unlikely looking delicacies grow all along the cliffs, but flourish best where the waves are highest and the wind is at its most fierce. The brutal waves wash barnacle fishermen to their deaths so regularly that the local marine rescue service cringes every time the phone rings.

Dickstein Shapiro merged with a New York firm, Roberts, Sheridan & Kotel, in January, and is looking for other acquisitions. It now has room for about 100 lawyers. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOWARD, DR. RICHARD A.
description: CLOWARD-Dr. Richard A. The Faculty, Advisory Council, Alumni Association, staff, and students of the Columbia University School of Social Work note with sadness the death of Professor Richard A. Cloward on August 20, in New York City. A 1950 M.S. graduate of the School and member of its faculty for 47 years, he was a prolific author, social activist and humanitarian whose scholarly writings and lifetime achievements brought distinction to Columbia and to the social welfare field. He will be long remembered for his unwavering commitment to the ideals of his profession and the welfare of the disadvantaged. His impact on social programs, education and the community will last long into the future. Sincerest condolences are extended to his wife, Dr. Frances Fox Piven; his children, Leslie Diamond & Daniel, Keith & Kevin Cloward, and other members of the family. Dr. Sheila B. Kamerman, Interim Dean

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Media Company Reports Loss

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Presses For Delay On Nextwave
description: The Federal Communications Commission has asked a federal bankruptcy court in New York to reject a request by NextWave Telecom for an Oct. 31 hearing to approve a reorganization plan. NextWave intends to raise as much as $5.5 billion to build a wireless data network, including a $2.5 billion loan from UBS Warburg and $300 million from Qualcomm. The F.C.C. said the appeals process would be disrupted by a ruling on the reorganization plan before the Supreme Court reviews a June decision that returned frequencies to NextWave. The filing is the latest step by the agency to keep wireless licenses it repossessed from Nextwave and resold in January for $16 billion. An appeals court said the agency illegally repossessed the licenses from NextWave, which had defaulted on $4.2 billion in debt, and ordered them restored.

title: Butler, Shine Acquires PeaBrand
description: Butler, Shine & Stern in Sausalito, Calif., has acquired PeaBrand, a design agency in San Francisco. Terms of the stock transaction were not disclosed.

title: Passive Resistance Not Enough For Yanks
description: Mike Mussina was on automatic pilot in the early innings tonight with everything unfolding as if he had scripted it. It did not matter who was batting for the Texas Rangers. Mussina peered in for another sign, made another reliable pitch and repeated the process. For three innings, the plan worked.

title: A Hayloft for the Heart
description: I HAVE wandered like some kind of lost farmer on the outskirts of cities most of my life. When my job was based in Boston, I lived on a salt marsh in Ipswich, in an open studio over an old garage. When I worked on Long Island, I lived in a ramshackle cottage on the Nissequogue River and gardened in the barnyard of an old horse stable.

title: The Art of Memory: What Rooms Reveal
description: ROBERT POLIDORI, a photographer, has the gaze of a blind man. His face appears to listen rather than look. Mr. Polidori's camera is his sight.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HALLMARK CARDS INC., Kansas City, Mo., acquired the rights to the American Girl brand of books and dolls from Mattel Inc., El Segundo, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: Election In October
description: A parliamentary election is to be held Oct. 1, a date the two main political parties declared acceptable. A caretaker government took over from Prime Minister Sheik Hasina on July 15 to organize the vote. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: When Packing for College, Which Computer?
description: SO there you are, standing dazed in Aisle 51 of CompUniverse or Soup-Up City, shopping for a computer for your off-to-college son or daughter. Aisles of beige boxes stretch as far as the eye can see. The sales clerks aren't even old enough to drive, let alone coherently explain the differences between the 900MHzAMD/128MB/ 10G unit for $799 and the 1GP3/256MB/ 20GB for $999. Maybe you should just give your Visa card to your kid and forget the whole thing.

title: National Briefing | South: Louisiana: Ban On Drug-Related Items
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit on Tuesday challenging a government ban on various items found at rave parties that the government says enhance the effects of the drug Ecstasy. Under a plea bargain with federal prosecutors, organizers of a rave in New Orleans agreed to ban items like pacifiers, glow sticks and masks. Jay Cook, director of the state's A.C.L.U. chapter, said the ban undermined freedom-of-expression guarantees in the First Amendment.

description: Stocks rallied yesterday as investors bet that positive comments from some companies could mean the economy was finally bottoming and the worst might be over.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARFUGGI, WILLIAM E.
description: MARFUGGI-William E., former New Jersey State Treasurer, West Point Graduate and a resident of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, passed away on August 21, 2001. Bill was appointed State Treasurer in '73 by then Governor William Cahill. Bill served as a Chairman of the Board, Victory Optical, Newark, NJ. His most beloved wife Rose survives Bill; his children; William Jr. and Sheila, Vincent James and Karen, Victoria Rose and Owen. In lieu of flowers the family respectfully request donations be made to The Hospice Foundation for Caring; Pediatric Team, 4266 Sunbeam Rd., Jacksonville, FL 32257 in William's name. Mass of Christian Burial will be Celebrated at 3:00 P.M., Sat., Aug. 25th in Our Lady Star of the Sea Catholic Church followed by a reception at Sawgrass. Services in Short Hills, N.J. will be held at 11:15 A.M., on Sat., Sept. 8th in the St. Rose of Lima Catholic Church. QuinnShalz, a Family Funeral & Cremation Centre, 3rd St. at Ponte Vedra Blvd., 904/249-1100.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about efforts by two companies, Corbis and Getty Images, to license digital collections of photos and art misstated Corbis's relationship to the consumer market. While the company has expanded into the licensing of images to news outlets, publishers and advertising companies, it also still sells images to consumers; it has not largely deserted that market.

title: Agency Alliance Seeks New Business
description: More than 35 independent public relations agencies that specialize in technology clients are forming an alliance to work together to gain new business regionally and worldwide.

title: Barretos Journal; Brazil's Wild and Woolly Side: Meet the Caubis
description: The bucking broncos and snorting bulls, the lanky cowboys in leather chaps and the vendors hawking pork rinds to spectators in the stands all suggest a setting somewhere deep in the heart of Texas. But the flag flying over the event here that bills itself as ''The World's Biggest Rodeo Festival'' is the green and yellow of Brazil, not red, white and blue.

title: Eight Colts Are Ready to Take Aim at Point Given in the Travers Stakes
description: This is the Midsummer Derby and the Big Red Train, Point Given, is here. But perhaps more surprising is that eight other colts have shown up to test him in the Grade I, $1 million Travers Stakes. Yes, the massive chestnut's Preakness victory was professional, his Belmont triumph was dominating and, in the narrow Haskell Invitational, he showed class and determination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRANDRUP, CLAIR L.
description: BRANDRUP-Clair L. Passed away peacefully at his home in San Francisco, CA on August 13, 2001 at the age of 86 after a long and fulfilling life. Loving father of Douglas W. Brandrup of Stamford, CT and Judith Claire Kerwin of San Francisco, CA. Devoted and loving grandfather to Kendra Claire Brandrup of NYC, Monika E. Hauge of Stony Creek, CT, Peter W. Brandrup of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, and Shannon Claire Kerwin of San Francisco, CA. He was the adored father-in-law of Patricia R. Brandrup of Stamford, CT and the beloved step grandfather of Phillip R. Corryn of New Canaan, CT and Barclay F. Tuck of NYC. A memorial service will be celebrated Friday, August 24, 2:00 PM at the First Unitarian Church, 1187 Franklin St., San Francisco, CA. Memorial contributions may be made to Save the Sound, Inc., 185 Magee Ave., Stamford, CT 06902 or to the San Francisco School, 300 Gaven St., San Francisco, CA 94134.

title: The Latest Gear; Turning Hand-Helds Into Handouts
description: WHENEVER school boards start swooning over the potential of new educational technology, skeptics often make a deflating point: In a few years, they warn, some gadget will come along that will make this one seem dated.

title: Denver Newspapers Spar Over Stadium's Name
description: Corporate naming rights to football stadiums, long a part of big-time sports, came late to Denver. Now that they have, the city's two daily newspapers are hissing at each other over what to call the Denver Broncos' new stadium, and an investment company paying $120 million to be part of the name has been embarrassed by an employee's alternative suggestion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRACY, PAUL S., JR.
description: TRACY-Paul S., Jr. Retired VP of Citibank. Died August 21, 2001, age 81. Memorial services St. James Episcopal Church, Titicus Road (Route 116) and June Road, North Salem, NY, August 25, 10:00 AM.

title: Wall Collapses on Mother and Son in Brooklyn
description: A woman and her 3-year-old son were seriously injured yesterday after a wall of a building that was being demolished in Park Slope, Brooklyn, collapsed on top of them, sending bricks and loose concrete blocks toppling onto their heads.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: New Charges For Milosevic Aide
description: A prosecutor has charged Slobodan Milosevic's secret police chief, Radomir Markovic, with four counts of murder for organizing the highway crash that killed four members of an opposition party in October 1999. Three other former secret police officials have also been charged in the murders. Mr. Markovic, above, is serving a one-year sentence for revealing state secrets. Carlotta Gall (NYT)

title: Religious Arrests Cast a Pall Over Afghanistan Aid Efforts
description: The evidence considered most damning includes Bibles translated into Farsi and Pashto, dozens of video and audio tapes about the life of Jesus and a book entitled ''Sharing Your Faith With a Muslim.''

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Phone Company Sale
description: The Australian government has approved a bid by Singapore Telecommunications for Cable and Wireless Optus, the country s second-largest telecommunications company. But the Australian treasurer, Peter Costello, has imposed conditions intended to protect national security, which include measures to keep separate some operations and safeguard confidential information. SingTel will control satellite and other communications that carry important government data. The deal, proposed in March and worth about $8 billion, had been delayed while Australia weighed concerns raised by the military and some intelligence offices. SingTel's chief executive, Lee Hsien Yang, said the conditions were not unreasonable or unexpected. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Excite Replaces Auditing Firm That Issued Warning
description: Excite@Home disclosed yesterday that it had switched accounting firms a day after its independent auditors expressed substantial doubt that the company, once a dominant Internet portal and now a humbler broadband service provider, could generate enough cash to stay in business.

title: A Graphic Designer's Cache With a Nod to the East
description: After working for many years as a graphic designer in SoHo, Melinda Slover, above, moved to Hudson to pursue her dream of selling housewares. But first, she did a test run of her taste for five months at the flea market at 77th Street and Columbus Avenue in Manhattan. Voil, Lili & Loo (the name is meant to reflect an East-West sensibility), opened in June. Water-buffalo-horn serving pieces from India are $16 to $95, Japanese paper lamps are $35 to $125. There are textiles from Italy and India, and plaster-and-acrylic classical heads, inset, cast and hand-colored by Ms. Slover, all fairly priced. Lili & Loo, 345 Warren Street, is open Thursdays through Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; (518) 822-9492.

description: The Argentine government told a weary population today that even deeper cuts in spending and more national sacrifice are in the offing, despite an emergency rescue agreement it signed with the International Monetary Fund on Tuesday.

title: SPRINT SAYS IT RAISED $2.3 BILLION IN SALES OF SHARES
description: The Sprint Corporation raised $2.3 billion from offering 70 million shares of the Sprint PCS Group and 60 million equity units similar to convertible securities. The offering included 57 million shares of Sprint PCS owned by Deutsche Telekom. A Sprint spokesman, Mark Bonavia, said the shares sold for $24.50 and equity units for $25. Underwriters exercised options for an additional 10.5 million shares and 9 million units, he said. Deutsche Telekom received $1.4 billion for its shares. Sprint, based in Westwood, Kan., also said it sold 40 percent, or 18.4 million shares, of the Internet service provider EarthLink Inc. Based on a price of $12.40, the sale raised $228 million.

title: City to Spray for West Nile In Central Park and Queens
description: New York City will spray pesticides this week to kill mosquitoes in Central Park, officials said yesterday, after announcing that they had found significant evidence of West Nile virus in the park's mosquito population for the first time this year. They also plan to spray two Queens neighborhoods, including the one that is home to a 75-year-old man who, officials said, is the second person this year in the region to fall ill and test positive for the virus.

title: Game Designer Who Breaks the Mold
description: SEVENTEEN years ago, when Neil Young -- not the American singer-songwriter but a British-born computer game creator -- was a teenager growing up near London, he played a video game that delivered a moment so electric, so charged with shock, that he actually fell out of his chair.

title: Destroy a Freeway, Save a City
description: It was a watershed moment on Monday when Gov. Gray Davis of California announced, at the ribbon-cutting of yet another new stretch of freeway near Los Angeles -- that mecca of elevated urban asphalt -- that this would be the last new major freeway in the state's future. The state that once eagerly welcomed all new freeways is now rethinking them.

description: The head of the state chapter of the Sierra Club today called Bret D. Schundler a ''threat to the environment in New Jersey'' and delivered a ringing endorsement of his Democratic opponent in the governor's race, James E. McGreevey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEEKLEY, MASON W. III
description: BEEKLEY-Mason W. III. Of New Hartford, Connecticut, a man of vision, dignity and compassion, died peacefully Monday, August 20, 2001 in Beverly Hills, CA. He was born on February 9, 1927 in Hartford, Connecticut, the son of Aline F. Beekley and F. Cheyney Beekley. Mason graduated from Kingswood School (West Hartford) & from Princeton University in 1949. He was predeceased by his wife of 42 years, Eliza Atlee Quarrier Beekley. A longtime resident of New Hartford, CT, he and his family lived at The Parsonage. He is survived by his children LizaLee Q.B. Kremer and her husband George of Lawrenceville, Georgia, Lorie Q.B. Cheney and her husband Dexter of Collinsville, CT, Sayre C.T.B. Wardell and her husband Daniel of Waitsfield, VT and Frances F. Beekley of Nahant, MA. He leaves five grandchildren, Brooke, Winston and Elektra Cheney, and MacKenzie and Tavish Wardell. He is also survived by his sister, Frances B. Haviland and her husband Samuel of Farmington, CT. Mason joined Beekley Corporation in 1952 to which he devoted his business career. He was Chairman & Chief Executive Officer. He was an entrepreneur and invested and/or contributed to the invention of proprietary information products. Today, Beekley Corporation, through teaching the many applications of its 35 radiological disposable Beekley Spots products, contributes to life-saving diagnostic radiology procedures such as mammography. These products, now used by more than 9,000 North American hospitals and clinics, are a new language of radiology that every day helps to save lives. In 1991 Mr. Beekley was honored as CEO of one of the most successful businesses in Connecticut. Mr. Beekley founded and underwrote the International Skiing History Association, which today has grown to 1,000 associates in 14 countries. He also was the founder of the Beekley International Library of Skiing Literature, currently comprising the largest such collection in the world. In 1992, Mr. and Mrs. Beekley purchased and donated 1.5 acres of land in the center of New Hartford to the town to provide the site on which to build a new library. In 2001 the library was renamed the Licia and Mason Beekley Memorial Library. In 1996 he initiated and underwrote a professional study New Hartford Center: A Vision Plan for the 21st Century, subsequently adopted by the town. Mason has donated a substantial amount of land on the Farmington River riverfront to New Hartford to be converted to parkland. This will be known as Riverviews Park. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to I.S.H.A., 499 Town Hill Road, New Hartford, CT 06057, the Licia and Mason Beekley Memorial Library, 10 Central Ave, New Hartford, CT 06057 or American Cancer Society, 45 Wintonbury Ave, Bloomfield, CT 06002. Arrangements for a memorial service are being made.

title: Condit Shifts, Going Public With His Side Of Events
description: Representative Gary A. Condit is emerging from his self-imposed silence with a flurry of public relations efforts. He gave a 90-minute interview here to People magazine on Tuesday, had 217,000 copies of a personal letter sent to his constituents in central California today and is to appear on a prime-time television interview with Connie Chung of ABC News on Thursday night.

description: Shares in the medical supply company PolyMedica Corporation fell 26 percent as F.B.I. agents began a second day of searching the main Florida office of the company, which makes diabetes test kits, officials said.

description: President Kim Dae Jung will receive the president of Vietnam, Tran Duc Luong, in Seoul today, the first visit by a leader of Vietnam. Don Kirk (NYT)

description: SAVING power saves both money and natural resources. And if the experience of some parts of California is a guide, average utility bills, now $1,300 a year nationally, may go up when utilities company caps are lifted elsewhere.

title: Keeping Up in Class With Software for a Hand-Held
description: THE days of the Trapper Keeper are over. An icon for students of the 1980's, the three-ring binder included folders for organizing schoolwork by subject and featured covers of popular rock and movie stars, all enclosed by a handy Velcro flap.

title: Officer Thwarts Central Park Sex Attack
description: A 34-year-old Manhattan woman narrowly escaped being raped in a busy section of Central Park yesterday morning when a police officer on his lunch break responded to her screams and arrested the attacker, police officials said.

description: The pressure is off.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Opposition Parties Unite
description: One of the two major opposition candidates in Belarus's presidential campaign followed an arranged scenario and dropped out of the race, effectively uniting pro-democracy forces behind the remaining candidate, Vladimir Goncharik. Mr. Goncharik is waging an uphill battle to oust Belarus's charismatic but autocratic president, Aleksandr Lukashenko, in the Sept. 9 election. The election commission said it would demand that the opposition candidate who quit, Seymon Domash, return all money he had received for his campaign. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Neil Cooper, 71, Who Founded A Rock and Reggae Record Label
description: Neil Cooper, the founder of the ROIR record label, which released music by underground rock and reggae bands, died on Aug. 13 at his home in Manhattan. He was 71.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER GAINS. Copper rose as a report of improved business confidence in Germany eased concern about a slump in demand. In New York, copper for September delivery rose 0.6 cent, or 0.9 percent, to 67.75 cents a pound.

title: Donor Groups Plan to Ease Blood Shortage in New York
description: The two groups that collect most of the nation's donated blood announced plans today to alleviate an impending blood shortage in the New York metropolitan region due to a proposed federal ban on European donations.

title: Subtle Mysteries of Celestials and Mortals
description: The celestial and the earthly coexisted with remarkable serenity on Tuesday night when ''Dance, the Spirit of Cambodia'' opened a weeklong season at the Joyce Theater. New Yorkers were exposed to the Cambodians' delicate yet robust dance and music 10 years ago at the Joyce. The return of the group, now on an American tour, is cause for rejoicing.

description: KAY-Nan Bennett. Vassar College mourns the loss of our trustee Nan Bennett Kay, Class of 1960. Nan Kay also served recently as president of her class and as a member of the Development Leadership Council. A warm, witty and generous woman, Nan had a fierce commitment to education, to young people, and to the arts. We extend our condolences to her husband, Stephen, and family. Richard Van Demark, Chair, Vassar College Board of Trustees Frances D. Fergusson, President, Vassar College

Loving grandfather of Rachel, Eve, Noah, Joshua, Zachary, Jordan, Samantha and Carly. Services ''Wien & Wien'' Hackensack, NJ, Thursday 11:30 AM (1-800-378-1892).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALKIN, FRANCES
description: ALKIN-Frances. The Board of Trustees, the Medical Staff, and the employees of Long Beach Medical Center join the members of the Long Beach Medical Center Auxiliary in expressing our profound sorrow on the passing of our colleague, Frances Alkin. For 25 years, she held the office of President of the Medical Center's Auxiliary and was a member of the Board of Trustees for almost 30 years. Her effectiveness, both as a Board member and Auxiliary officer, was unequalled in fundraising efforts and promoting good will within the communities we serve. title: It Does Floors (Lots of Them) All by Itself and Doesn't Complain
description: Tired of mopping? A Virginia company has created a floor-cleaning robot that will do the job for you. The EBot2 from Intellibot is designed to scrub up to 50,000 square feet on a four-and-a-half-hour charge without any human attention or programming. Unless you have a colossal weekend house outside Microsoft headquarters, you probably don't have anywhere near 50,000 square feet of floor; as might be expected, the machine is geared toward institutions.

title: National Briefing | South: Florida: Ex-Ambassador To Run For Governor
description: Pete Peterson, former United States ambassador to Vietnam, said he planned to seek the Democratic nomination for governor. Mr. Peterson, left, a former prisoner of war in Vietnam, is also a veteran Air Force pilot and a former congressman. Others seeking the Democratic nomination to challenge Gov. Jeb Bush, the incumbent Republican, include State Senator Daryl L. Jones of Miami, State Representative Lois J. Frankel of West Palm Beach, and a Tampa lawyer, Bill H. McBride. Former Attorney General Janet Reno is another possible Democratic candidate.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Toll Plan Criticized
description: A New Jersey group attacked Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's 10-year plan to eliminate tolls on the Garden State Parkway yesterday and proposed shortening the process to one year. ''We don't need that expense and inconvenience to the public,'' said Raymond Neveil, president of Citizens Against Tolls. The group advocates the dissolution of the New Jersey Highway Authority and the transfer of general maintenance costs to the State Department of Transportation as part of a rapid dismantling of the toll system. Mr. DiFrancesco, through a spokesman, declined to comment.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Police-Brutality Charges
description: Twenty police officers are under investigation over allegations of brutality during the Group of 8 summit meeting in Genoa. They were part of the 140-member force that raided a school housing protesters on July 22, two newspapers, La Republica and Corriere della Sera, said. One protester was shot dead and more than 200 people were injured during the summit meeting. A Food and Agriculture Organization meeting set for Rome in November will move to Africa, officials announced, and Italy will move a September NATO summit meeting to a military base from central Naples.

title: State Faults Amtrak For Tunnel Neglect
description: A state transportation report on Pennsylvania Station accuses Amtrak of neglecting costly improvements to 15 miles of potentially dangerous tunnels that serve the passenger station, the busiest in the country.

title: Police Say Antigay Threats Were Hoax
description: During the spring semester, when it seemed that the treasurer of the gay student organization at the College of New Jersey near Trenton had become the target of death threats and hate messages, students rallied to show their support. There were anti-hate demonstrations and candlelight vigils, and security was doubled at the student's dormitory building.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: An Increase In Confidence
description: The closely watched survey of German business confidence by the Ifo economic institute jumped in July for the first time since May 2000. The increase was modest, but forecasters had been expecting another decline. Though analysts warned that the survey was prone to unexpected one-month bumps in either direction, economists at Deutsche Bank said that it might signal a ''start to the bottoming-out process'' and that growth this year could exceed 1.5 percent. For the last three months, analysts said, growth has been virtually zero. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERSHBERG, CHARLOTTE
description: HERSHBERG-Charlotte. Died on August 21, 2001 in West Orange, N.J. Beloved wife of Emmanuel. Devoted mother of Elliot (Karen), Robert (Eileen), Barbara (Abbott). Adored grandmother of Lisa (James), Julie (Jeffrey), Miriam, Sara and Aaron and cherished great-grandmother of Samantha and Benjamin. Services will be private.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Senators Join E.P.A. Fight
description: The state's two senators have joined the battle against President Bush's nomination of Donald Schregardus of Ohio as the top enforcement officer for the Environmental Protection Agency. Senators Robert G. Torricelli and Jon S. Corzine, both Democrats, wrote Mr. Bush a letter yesterday saying that Mr. Schregardus was lax during his tenure as the director of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency. They also cited the ruling of an administrative law judge that Mr. Schregardus had illegally retaliated against a whistle-blower. A Republican Senate aide said the senators were positioning themselves for the battle over the president's energy plan. Katharine Q. Seelye (NYT)

title: Relentless Search for Growth Humbles a Mutual Fund Star
description: James D. McCall was one of Wall Street's best stock pickers in the late 1990's, his hand so hot that Merrill Lynch, eager to revive sales of its mutual funds, paid a ransom to his previous employer to win his services. Starting early last year, Merrill's brokers collected more than $1.5 billion from their clients for Mr. McCall to invest.

It's just that as a longtime promoter of everything from roller-skating nights at the Roxy to tea dances at Flipside, whose discount admission cards have been called practically mandatory for a gay man's wallet, John Blair is the first to arrive and among the first to leave (early, like 2 a.m., he says).

title: How to Spend the Tax Rebate? Democrats Offer to Accept It
description: Alan Greenspan wants people to spend their tax refunds, to help the economy. Supporters of public education are asking people to give the money to schools. Many people are tempted to pay down their credit cards.

title: Kenneth Reese Cole Jr., 63, Aide to Nixon
description: Kenneth Reese Cole Jr., a White House aide in the Nixon era and an occasional commentator on Watergate, died on Thursday at his home in Willsboro, N.Y. He was 63.

title: Macedonians Await NATO, Some Wary of Mission
description: On one side of the ethnic divide there is wariness. Stephan Terziovski, a Slav and the owner of a seed shop, had just one question about NATO's formal decision today to send 3,500 troops here to collect thousands of weapons from ethnic Albanian guerrillas.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Publisher Lowers Forecast
description: The Dutch publisher VNU, whose magazines include Billboard and The Hollywood Reporter, cut its earnings forecast for the year in half and said first-half profit slumped to 75.5 million euros ($69.2 million), compared with 92.5 million euros ($84.8 million) a year ago. Last March, VNU said earnings per share would rise 10 percent, but it cut that to at least 5 percent. Its shares fell as much as 7.7 percent. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From timing chains to unstable tires, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Relaford Sparkles as Appier Throws a Gem
description: Desi Relaford is the Mets' Everyman. A switch-hitting infielder, he never knows when or where he may play, but when he does, he seems hungry for the opportunity. Last night he played every part of the game with more than mere utility.

description: Dear Thermostat

title: George O'Toole; Novelist and Historian, 64
description: George O'Toole, a novelist and historian who specialized in the history of American espionage, died on Aug. 10 at a hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 64 and lived in Mount Vernon.

description: Manhattan

title: Accounts
description: Symantec Corp., Cupertino, Calif., which makes the Norton line of computer security software, to the Los Angeles office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group, after just seven months at the Los Angeles office of a WPP sibling, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide. Billings were estimated at $25 million. The Ogilvy team of about a dozen employees that worked on Symantec will move to Thompson.

title: National Briefing | South: Virginia: No Charges For Gun Protester
description: Prosecutors in Fairfax County dropped trespassing charges against Tom Mauser, the father of a boy killed at Columbine High School in Colorado in 1999, after no one from the National Rifle Association appeared at a hearing to testify against him. Mr. Mauser, who has become a vocal advocate for gun control, was arrested in June at a demonstration at the N.R.A. headquarters. Mr. Mauser said he was seeking a response to a letter he sent to the group's president, Charlton Heston, asking why the group did not favoring banning the type of assault weapon that two students used to kill his son, Daniel, and 12 others.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Justice Thomas Gets A Building
description: Ending a two-month dispute, officials at the Carnegie Library in Savannah voted to name an addition to the building for Justice Clarence Thomas, a Georgia native. The board settled on the name after receiving a $150,000 pledge from an anonymous friend of Justice Thomas. Donations for the revitalization of the library, which was established in 1906 by blacks who were barred from the Bull Street Library by segregation, and an addition to it had been slow since structural damage closed it in 1997. Opponents protested naming the addition after Justice Thomas because of his opposition to affirmative action.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
