title: 'Senator No' Says Goodbye
description: It is always tempting, when old warriors retire, to lament their passing from the political stage. In the case of Senator Jesse Helms, that is a temptation to be resisted. Few senators in the modern era have done more to buck the tide of progress and enlightenment than Mr. Helms, who last evening announced that he would not seek a sixth term in the Senate next year. From the civil rights movement that transformed his native South to international treaties that promised a safer world, Mr. Helms rarely missed an opportunity to put his parochial interests ahead of the national interest.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Arrest In Russian Fraud
description: The Federal Crime Office in Wiesbaden said a special task force had made its first arrest in a probe of Russian money-laundering, after years spent on investigating money transfers through Germany, Canada, Lithuania, Luxembourg and Spain. Prosecutors said they had arrested a 40-year-old German man in a case involving a Russian company that received $7 million in Russian government subsidies in 1995 to produce mineral water and baked goods.

title: China, in a Switch, Concedes It Is Facing AIDS Epidemic
description: BEIJING, Aug. 23  In a departure from the Chinese government's general reticence on the subject of AIDS, a senior official openly admitted today that China is facing an epidemic that is threatening to outpace official efforts to control it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NICHOLAS, PETER
description: NICHOLAS-Peter. Died August 22, 2001. Loving son, brother and uncle. Services 11 AM Friday at Annunciation Greek Orthodox Church, corner of 91 Street & West End Avenue, NYC. For further information call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: The Jockeying Starts As Helms Yields to Time
description: Speaking of the toll of time, Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina announced tonight that he would not run for re-election in 2002 and would retire after a momentous 30-year career.

title: The Reality Behind the Slogan; Saturn Unit, Once a Maverick, Is Looking a Lot More Like G.M
description: General Motors created Saturn 16 years ago as a different kind of car company, a friendly, unconventional brand aimed at Americans for whom Detroit represented a failed past.

title: Gimelstob Won't Let the Might-Have-Beens Bother Him
description: Justin Gimelstob had just overpowered Ytai Abougzir in a United States Open qualifying match yesterday when a familiar face appeared. It was William Bill, one of Gimelstob's coaches when he was growing up in New Jersey.

title: An Energizing Fusion From African Rockers
description: In what has probably been the best summer ever for African rock in New York, two more African superstars recently came to town: Baaba Maal, headlining Celebrate Brooklyn's 10th annual African Festival on Sunday afternoon at the Prospect Park Bandshell, and Papa Wemba, who performed on Tuesday night at the Lion's Den in Greenwich Village.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit Down At Lufthansa
description: Second-quarter profit at Lufthansa fell 60 percent because of slowing traffic growth, higher fuel costs and pilot strikes. The airline, however, did not change its profit forecast for the year. Operating profit for the quarter fell to 100 million euros ($91 million). While sales rose 13 percent, cargo sales, regarded as a crucial indicator, fell, and are down 2.8 percent for the first six months. The airline's second-half operating expenses rose 14 percent, with first-half costs up 12 percent, including a 31 percent increase in fuel costs. Lufthansa also said it was cutting a planned increase in capacity.

title: Nursing Home Shuts Down After U.S. Finding of Danger
description: Nearly a month ago, federal inspectors visited a Westchester nursing home and quickly determined that the residents were in ''immediate jeopardy'' because of medical neglect, stifling heat and unsafe conditions.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: DOLLAR IS MIXED. The dollar fell against the euro and rose against the yen. In New York, the euro settled at 91.70 cents, up from 91.14 cents on Tuesday. The dollar traded at 120.45 yen, up from 119.75 yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABBOTT, KEENE
description: ABBOTT-Keene, 95. Of Jamesville, New York, died August 18 at his home. Living the motto, ''You best serve yourself when you first serve others,'' Mr. Abbott spent a lifetime touching the lives of others through community service. A longtime resident of the Utica, NY area, he was a member of the First Presbyterian Church of Utica for over forty-five years and was an elder of the church. He served as a member of the Advisory Board of the Salvation Army of Central NY; a director of the Presbyterian Home of Central NY; and Chairman of Operation Sunshine, a Christmas charity. In the Syracuse area, he was a member of the DeWitt Community Church. Born in New York City in 1906, Mr. Abbott graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1929 and Harvard Business School in 1931. He married Florence Finch of Bronxville, NY in 1935. They had met in the third grade in Bronxville. She died in 1998, and this year he established an endowment at Mt. Holyoke College, of which she was an alumna, in her memory. Mr. Abbott was a marketing and sales executive at Utica National Insurance Group for 27 years, retiring in 1968. He is survived by two sons, Gordon K. Abbott of San Mateo, CA, and Norman F. Abbott of New York City; three grandsons and two great grandsons. A memorial service will be held at 2 P.M. on September 7 at the DeWitt Community Church, 3600 Erie Boulevard East, DeWitt, NY 13214. Contributions may be made to the church. Burial will be in the Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: W. G. Clark, 77, Illinois Jurist And Critic of War in Vietnam
description: William G. Clark, a former chief justice of the Illinois Supreme Court and an outspoken critic of the Vietnam War in 1968, both at the Democratic National Convention and as a candidate for the Senate, died on Friday in Skokie, Ill. He was 77 and lived in Chicago.

title: Wide Disparity On Promoting Failing Pupils
description: Two years after the New York City Board of Education adopted a policy intended to do away with the automatic promotion of failing students, the rules are being applied inconsistently across the city and in some districts seem hardly to be in effect at all.

title: State Faults Amtrak for Neglect of Tunnels
description: A state transportation report on Pennsylvania Station accuses Amtrak of neglecting costly improvements to 15 miles of potentially dangerous tunnels that serve the passenger station, the busiest in the country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALKEDIS, THEODORE
description: HALKEDIS-Theodore. August 21, 2001. Devoted son of the late John and the late Simela Halkedis. Beloved husband of Aristea. Devoted brother of Elpis Kyriazis and Haralambos Halkedis. Loving uncle of Arthur and John Kyriazis, Semele, John and Anne Halkedis. Born in Philadelphia and graduated from Pennsylvania State University and later served in the U.S. Army. He spent his lifetime career in the international shipping industry. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st. St. Thursday, August 23, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Friday, August 24, 12 noon at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 St. between First and Second Avenues. title: Multicultural Bronx Stars Strike Nationalistic Chord
description: The day before the Rolando Paulino All-Stars played here in their third game of the Little League World Series, Belkis Garcia and several other parents walked to a grocery store looking for American flags. Sure, there had been plenty of flag-waving during the previous games. But what most of the Bronx fans had eagerly unfurled was the red, white and blue of the Dominican Republic.

title: UPN Weighs Ad Logos In Prime Time
description: The constantly blurring line between programming and advertising on television may get even wavier as at least one network considers an idea to sell to marketers the ability to superimpose small transparent logos, brand names and other commercial trappings in a corner of the screen.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Hearing On Rental Car Dispute
description: The State Department of Consumer Protection took testimony yesterday for its investigation of a car rental agency that used global positioning satellite equipment to monitor when customers drove faster than posted speed limits. The customers were then penalized by the company, which charged customer credit and bank accounts $150 for each speeding incident. The practice came to light earlier this summer when a customer, James Turner, sued Acme. The court deferred the decision to the Department of Consumer Protection. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Drug Company Stake Is Sold
description: The pharmaceutical company Merck K.G.a.A. has agreed to sell its 43 percent stake in the generic drug maker Pharmaceutical Resources of Spring Valley, N.Y. Merck said that the stake would be sold to investors for more than 400 million euros ($366 million) and that the money would be better used elsewhere. The shares will be sold for $27 each, 14 percent below their closing price on Tuesday. Merck K.G.a.A., which is not related to Merck & Company of the United States, bought the shares in 1998 for $2 each and expects a gain of about 250 million euros ($229 million).

title: Inquiry Focuses On 'Spoofing' Of Stock Prices
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is investigating 11 cases in which brokers may have tried to manipulate the market in a practice known as spoofing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFELD, RABBI LEONARD
description: ROSENFELD - Rabbi Leonard. The entire Yeshiva University family is saddened by the sudden passing away of one of the most senior and outstanding alumni of Yeshiva College ('37) and the affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary ('40). A distinguished educator and former head of the New York Board of Jewish Education, he served in pulpits in the United States and for the last decades he lived in Israel. He was a man of exemplary character and learning. We offer our heartfelt condolences to his wife Rosalie, to his son Ezra (YC '77), his daughter Tirzah (SCW '67) and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University Robert M. Beren, Chairman Yeshiva University Board of Trustees

description: Digital camera makers just keep on packing in the pixels. On Tuesday, Sony introduced the Cyber-shot DSC-F707, a digital still camera that takes the kind of rich, high-resolution pictures that until recently were available only with costly professional models.

description: The proposed Millennium Pipeline, the longest natural gas line under review in the nation, has suffered another setback with the announced withdrawal last week of its Canadian backers because of the project's repeated delays in winning approval in the United States.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Fine For Illegal Roach Bait
description: The state has fined a pesticide maker $950,000 for continuing to sell a brand of roach bait recalled in 1994 that could cause irreversible reproductive and developmental damage in humans. The company, S. C. Johnson of Racine, Wis., has said the continued sale of the product was an accident. S. C. Johnson was fined for distributing Raid Max Roach Bait Plus Egg Stoppers, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer and Commissioner Erin M. Crotty of the Department of Environmental Conservation announced yesterday. The bait, which contains the chemical sulfluramid, was found last year in a New York City store.

title: Can Hacking Victims Be Held Legally Liable?
description: Suppose, Margaret Jane Radin of Stanford Law School wrote recently, that a Web site operated by a securities brokerage suffers a crippling attack by hackers. The ability of its customers to conduct trades is hampered for several hours, or even blocked entirely. Imagine, too, that on the day of the attack the stock market is volatile, and that many customers are trying unsuccessfully to buy or sell stocks in a flash.

description: An article on Tuesday about Beatrice Muller, who lives permanently aboard the Queen Elizabeth 2, misstated the given name of a celebrity she has met there. He is Marvin Hamlisch, not Martin.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Defrauding Immigrants
description: A Long Island man has been charged with posing as a lawyer and stealing nearly $10,000 from immigrants by promising to help them with immigration matters like work permits and green cards, Denis E. Dillon, the Nassau County district attorney, said yesterday. The man, Manuel Herrera, 52, of Mineola, was arrested when he appeared in court on a violation of probation he received after a 1999 guilty plea to similar charges, Mr. Dillon said. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Chancellor Levy's Evaluation
description: The Board of Education met in private for six hours yesterday to review the performance of Chancellor Harold O. Levy. He gave the six board members there a lengthy presentation about his 19-month tenure and his priorities for the next year. Terri Thomson, the board's representative from Queens, said she was ''extremely impressed'' by Mr. Levy's presentation. Mr. Levy described the meeting in Riverdale as a ''constructive conversation.'' Board members will now submit written comments on their perceptions of Mr. Levy's performance over the last year, which will be collected and released next month. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

title: It's Computer vs. Computer, And the Dummy Has 3 Aces
description: A realization that a dummy containing three aces may be short of entries can be difficult for humans and computers alike.

title: In Town, a Little Farmhouse Grows a Cottage Garden
description: Four years ago, Benjamin and Margaret Eaton, below with their daughter Lucy, took three burned-out city lots and turned them into the Secret Gardener nursery. The couple, landscape designers in the Hudson Valley for the last 12 years, created a miracle on Warren Street: a small-scale Greek Revival-style farmhouse that incorporates the beautiful wooden doors from the 1850's that were already on the site. ''It was a challenge to fit the building into the existing cityscape,'' Ms. Eaton said. The house will become a flower shop and horticulture center this fall. Right now, fall plants are on display. The Secret Gardener, 250 Warren Street, is open Thursdays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; (518) 822-0992.

title: Economic Scene; With evolving technology, good monitors make for better contracts.
description: BEFORE 1998, video rental stores bought tapes from distributors for about $70 each. Because the tapes were so expensive, the stores bought relatively few of them, with the result that customers had to wait to see their favorite films. To paraphrase a noted amateur economist, the hits were so popular that no one was able to rent them.

title: Statistics Will Be Required On Police's Stop-and-Frisks
description: The City Council yesterday easily passed a bill championed by Peter F. Vallone, the council speaker and a candidate for mayor, requiring the Police Department to release information on the race and gender of those who are stopped and frisked. At the same time, a group of council members introduced a bill to define and ban racial profiling, at the behest of Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president and one of Mr. Vallone's Democratic mayoral rivals.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Makers' Index Rose In July
description: A leading index of semiconductor stocks gained 5 percent yesterday after a trade association reported that the chip equipment industry's book-to-bill ratio improved in July. The trade group, Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, based in San Jose, Calif., said this week that North American manufacturers booked $764 million in orders in July, for a book-to-bill ratio of 0.67, compared with a revised figure of 0.56 in June. That means chip-equipment manufacturers took in $67 in orders for every $100 of products shipped. The trade group said the gain in the ratio, which advanced for the third consecutive month, suggested that the industry's plunge had reached bottom, but it warned that manufacturers remained cautious. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index rose $27.72, to $564.75.

title: Officials In N.F.L. Consider Job Action

Lexan, a strong polycarbonate material with a frosted blue-gray color, is ideal for Mr. Soul's concept. ''I wanted something that would look funky in summer, but would really stand out against the snow in winter, and look sculptural,'' he said. The slightly Japanese-looking arbor (as shown below, $1,800, seen at a Bastille Day party in the garden tucked behind his shop) has a rope light inside that imparts a lovely glow as evening falls. All pieces are made to order by Escabelle Design, also at 307 Warren Street; (518) 822-0222.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel And Compaq In Wireless Pact
description: In a deal aimed at advancing wireless Internet access, Intel and Compaq Computer said they would work together to develop wireless hand-held communications devices and applications used to access and transmit data over the Internet. As part of the effort, the two companies will work together to make multimedia applications that run on the Intel Personal Internet Client Architecture. ''Compaq understands the benefits of separating computing and communications functions in a hand-held computing device so that both functions are maximized,'' Ron Smith, senior vice president of Intel's wireless communications and computing group, said in a statement. Additionally, Compaq will support Intel in its efforts to incorporate Compaq iPAQ Pocket PC's as reference platforms in Intel developer kits. On Tuesday, Intel announced a similar arrangement with Symbian, a consortium set up by Ericsson, Psion, Nokia and Matsushita Electric Industrial that has created an operating system for wireless devices. Shares in Intel rose 89 cents, to close at $27.96. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Miscellany
description: Millward Brown, Warwick, England, a unit of the WPP Group, acquired Delfo Milan, a qualitative research agency. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Pharmacopeia In Stock Deal For EOS
description: Pharmacopeia Inc. has agreed to buy the closely held Eos Biotechnology Inc. for about $197 million in stock in an effort to expand its line of tools used to develop drugs for cancer and inflammatory diseases. The value of the deal was based on the $18.51 closing price of Pharmacopeia shares on Tuesday and includes $44 million in cash from Eos. Under the agreement, Pharmacopeia will issue about 10 million shares of common stock and assume options and warrants to acquire an additional 600,000 shares of Pharmacopeia.

title: INGERSOLL-RAND ACQUIRES KRYPTONITE, A MAKER OF LOCKS
description: The Ingersoll-Rand Company, which makes products like Schlage locks, said yesterday that it had acquired the Kryptonite Corporation, maker of U-shaped bicycle locks. Kryptonite, founded in 1972 and based in Canton, Mass., had about $27 million in sales last year and employs about 60, an Ingersoll-Rand spokesman, Paul Dickard, said. The company will join Ingersoll-Rand's residential-security business.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Being part of the Senate is not just another job but I had to choose between that and my family.''

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Stepping Up To Vote
description: Officials said 80 percent of eligible voters had registered to take part in the first election for local leaders, scheduled for February. The election is for heads of 1,600 communes to replace appointed officials, some of whom have held their jobs for more than 20 years. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAMINSKY, ALEXANDER
description: KAMINSKY-Alexander. Son of Benjamin and Ida Kaminsky died August 19, 2001, at his home in Neponsit, NY. He was interred at Old Montefiore Cemetery on August 21. Born in Brooklyn on May 19, 1915, he was a graduate of Boys High School in 1930, Columbia College in 1934, and received an MBA from NYU in 1936. He worked as a certified public accountant until his retirement ten years ago. He is survived by his devoted wife Dorothy of 64 years, his son Robert Kaminsky and daughter Emily Cennamo, daughter-in-law Lee Kaminsky and son-in-law Vincent Cennamo, his grandchildren Benjamin Grassini, Samuel Grassini, Marjorie Sautner, David Kaminsky, Greg Kaminsky and Rachel Starr, and great-grandchildren Chelsea Kaminsky, and Hannah & Molly Sautner. He was predeceased by his only brother Abraham Kaminsky of Albany, NY.

title: Butler, Shine Acquires PeaBrand
description: Butler, Shine & Stern in Sausalito, Calif., has acquired PenaBrand, a design agency in San Francisco. Terms of the stock transaction were not disclosed.

title: Artists, Weighing Risks, Cancel Dates in Israel
description: The show planned for next week at Yarkon Park in Tel Aviv was to have been Israel's biggest pop concert of the year: an appearance by Red Hot Chili Peppers, the veteran rock band from Los Angeles.

title: Kmart Falls After Posting a Second-Quarter Loss
description: Avariety of retailers, including Kmart, reported declining sales today, reflecting consumers' increasingly cautious spending patterns.

title: BUSH SAID TO PICK AIR FORCE GENERAL AS MILITARY HEAD
description: Administration officials said today that they expected President Bush to nominate Gen. Richard B. Myers, a former head of the Air Force's space command, as the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Tennessee's Fiscal Troubles Grow After Futile Push for Income Tax
description: It was only two years ago that Tennessee was considered a model of good financial management, one of only nine states whose governments had top-drawer credit ratings from all the rating agencies and the envy of Southeastern states struggling to modernize.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERENSON, BIRDIE
description: BERENSON-Birdie. 97. Died on August 21, 2001. Compatriot of Eleanor Roosevelt. U.N. & human rights activist. Past President of B'nai Brith. A woman of valor. Loving mother of David and the late Robert. Cherished mother-inlaw of Joan and Marion. Grandmother of 5. A graveside service will be held today at 11AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Jewish National Fund for the State of Israel, 42 East 69th Street, NY, NY 10021.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Giants' Offensive Line Is Old and (Thankfully) in the Way
description: The goal was modest at first. When Lomas Brown broke into the league in 1985, the offensive tackle thought a 10-year career would be quite an accomplishment. Eventually, Brown's longevity climbed into the teens.

title: Christie Todd Whitman May Have the Most Thankless Job in Washington
description: Christie Whitman arrives at the home ballpark of the Lowell Spinners, the Boston Red Sox' Class-A affiliate in the old mill town of Lowell, Mass. The stadium rises atop a cleaned-up toxic-waste site and is the kind of place administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency go. It's a glinting citadel of the new and well made, wedged among boarded-up factories. But there is no crowd waiting, only a few baseball staff members. When she was governor of New Jersey, Whitman caused a stir wherever she went; many expected her to ascend either to the United States Senate or to the vice-presidential slot on the 2000 Republican ticket. Instead she now visits toxic-waste sites. ''At least today is a clean day,'' Whitman notes. Often when she travels to inspect something, it's garbage or ooze or worse.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Administration To Pay Some Security Costs
description: The Bush administration said it would pay more than half of the roughly $30 million that the District of Columbia expected to pay for security during the meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund at the end of September. But city officials said more help would be necessary to pay the extraordinary costs of the event. They called for the two institutions to provide financial support. But the I.M.F. said security ''has traditionally been the responsibility of the host government,'' in this case the United States. Last week, law enforcement officials said they expected up to 100,000 protesters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUTERSTEIN, KATHERINE MEBANE
description: LAUTERSTEIN-Katherine Mebane, 70. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died peacefully at her home in Stamford, Connecticut, on Monday, August 20, 2001. Katherine was born in Knoxville, Tennessee on September 19, 1930, and raised in Rockwood, Tennessee. She graduated from Radcliffe College in 1952. A brilliant woman with a keen wit and sense of humor, she will be deeply missed by her husband, Henry Lauterstein, two daughters and their husbands, Dorothy and Eric Doppstadt and Margaret and Jonathan Mandell, all of New York City. She is also survived by four loving grandchildren, Daniel and Natalie Doppstadt and Emily and Lucas Mandell, and her half brother, Bart Mebane. She is predeceased by her son, David Lauterstein. Services will be private.

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From sightseeing in Beijing to dining in Toronto, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: A House Divided, Lovingly
description: ROBERT B. PARKER and his wife, Joan, have been together for almost half a century, have raised two children, and since 1987 have worked together turning his famous detective novels into TV movies. He dedicates his books to her, and she appears in them, thinly veiled, as a major character named Susan.

title: In America; A Campaign of Caution
description: The four men in gray suits took their seats at the table and waited quietly for the televised debate to begin. Reporters leaned forward -- poison pens poised -- hoping that one of these unfailingly polite men would just lose it, say something outlandish, or maybe snarl at somebody (like a certain mayor we know), and enliven a campaign that so far has been a snooze.

title: California's Alternative To Rap's Tough Core
description: Mystic, the California-based rapper who performed on Thursday as part of the Sam Goody ''Home Before Midnight'' concert series at South Street Seaport, has the kind of talent that creeps up on listeners on little cat feet. ''I'm about to give you a cool-out, mental show,'' she announced before her short set, apparently expecting New Yorkers to accept hard-core rap or nothing. But Mystic's tranquil music had a fiery core, and she won listeners over without having to resort to posing.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Write-Offs By Telenor
description: The big Norwegian phone company Telenor wrote off hundreds of millions of dollars of its Internet and wireless investments, pushing its second-quarter figures into a net loss of $179 million. Its shares fell as much as 5.1 percent. The biggest write-off was related to Sonofon, a Danish cell phone company in which Telenor had bought a 54 percent stake for $1.6 million. Telenor said it had written off half that amount, reflecting the decline in telecommunications and technology stocks across Europe. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TEITELBAUM, LEW
description: TEITELBAUM-Lew. My sweetheart, my darling, our 37th wedding anniversary. We were ''Sooky & Lew'' for 40 years; from 2 wildly in love college kids, until our last day together. My excellent strongman. I will miss you and love you forever. Your Sooky

title: Beethoven's 'Macbeth' Bubbles to the Surface
description: The National Symphony Orchestra announced today that it would perform a version of a Beethoven orchestral work pieced together from ideas the composer set down for an opera based on Shakespeare's ''Macbeth.'' The opera was never written, but Beethoven's preliminary jottings survived.

title: Johnson Has Uncle and Supporter in the Phillies' Dugout
description: Nick Johnson was only 7 when Larry Bowa, his uncle, retired after a 16-year career in the major leagues, so Johnson does not have many memories of Uncle Larry as an All-Star shortstop. But Johnson has endless memories of Bowa, the manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, as someone who constantly imparted baseball wisdom to him, even now.

title: Full-Employment Prisons
description: A recent Times article about the economic woes of upstate New York towns dependent on prisons raises a nagging little fear about the future of criminal justice reform. As crime has been falling and jailhouse populations stabilizing, towns that believed a prison was a recession-proof industry are beginning to worry about layoffs. Advocates who found it difficult enough to convince state legislators that drug treatment is better than incarceration for low-level offenders are wondering if they will also have to fight the perception that a vote for reform is a vote for unemployment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERRY, ARNOLD
description: PERRY-Arnold. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons notes with sadness the passing of Arnold Perry, beloved father of Richard Perry. We extend our deepest condolences to Richard & his family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: Take-Home Test: Adding PC's to Book Bags
description: ON a May morning in Mary Kay Rendock's fifth-grade classroom here, the sounds of the dawning school day were echoing everywhere. Lockers banged outside in the hall, 10-year-olds chattered as they settled into their seats -- and a crescendo of chimes emanated from 15 laptop computers as every student in the room booted up.

title: RUSSELL ATHLETIC WILL MAKE UNIFORMS FOR LITTLE LEAGUES
description: The Russell Athletic division of the Russell Corporation, which has provided uniforms to the Little League World Series for 30 years, has been named the official supplier of uniforms to Little League Baseball Inc. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Russell, based in Alexander City, Ala., said the four-year agreement with Little League Baseball coincides with the Little League World Series, which began last week. About 2.9 million children worldwide participate in Little League baseball, the company said.

title: After Rumblings of Mideast Talks, Lots of Skepticism
description: The funeral procession moved briskly on foot past Amjad Shakah's furniture store today. It had all the usual trappings, which is to say it had impassioned cries of Palestinian nationalism, angry threats against Israel and an ear-shattering barrage of shooting into the air.

title: Turn a Spotlight on Hate Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: Just Relax, Surf the Net And Give Us Your Blood
description: How about a movie to go with those cookies and juice? A medical equipment manufacturer has designed a chair to help donors while away the time electronically as they sit with tubes in their arms.

title: U.S. Open Routes To a Title Are Drawn
description: The Williams sisters have yet to dominate every tennis major, but they discovered a tantalizing chance to sweep a prime-time slot and collect the family's third United States Open title in a row when the draw unfolded yesterday.

title: Friends Confounded by Pilot's Fatal Plummet
description: A flight instructor who died on Tuesday after an airplane controlled by his student plummeted to the ground was an accomplished flier who was known for training young pilots, his friends said today.

title: Editorial Notebook; What's in a Name? Today, Not Much
description: One is called Calibrus, one is called Calibra. Which one is the Internet start-up and which is the coupe made by General Motors? These days it's hard to tell. (Calibra is the car.) An entire industry of namers has sprung up to coin vaguely hip terms for the new economy's companies. The process of inventing and promoting a name can cost millions of dollars. It could also do more harm than good.

title: Moving Midcentury From SoHo To Warren Street
description: In 1982, Mark McDonald began dealing in midcentury modern designs in New York at the Fifty/50 Gallery in SoHo. In 1995, he opened the Gansevoort Gallery in the meatpacking district. His new store opens today in Hudson. Mr. McDonald (who has a second home in the Hudson Valley) has stocked the shop, 330, with furniture by Aalto, George Nelson and Eames, whose shell chairs, below, are $400 apiece in red or yellow. ''I am charmed by Hudson, and the cultural energy happening here now,'' he said. The store will also feature new and out-of-print books on architecture and design. It is at 330 Warren Street; open Thursdays through Sundays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. or by appointment; (518) 828-6320.

title: Devils Send Ferraro To Washington
description: The Washington Capitals acquired center Chris Ferraro from the Devils, three weeks after signing his twin brother. The Devils will receive future considerations in the trade.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MP3.Com Faces New Lawsuit
description: The Internet music company MP3.com said yesterday that it faced a new copyright infringement lawsuit, this one filed by more than 50 music publishers and songwriters, including the country artist Vince Gill. The lawsuit, filed last week in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York, asserts that an online ''locker'' service offered by MP3.com permits users to exchange copyrighted music. The online locker service lets subscribers store songs and receive access over the Internet to music they already own. But, the lawsuit asserted, this method of storing and retrieving made it possible for the songs to be given to people who might not own them. MP3.com, based in San Diego, declined to comment on the suit. People acquainted with the technology, however, said the suit might be frivolous because subscribers could easily turn their music into a tradeable format without the assistance of MP3.com. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Thwarting Impostors At America Online
description: Q. I know AOL workers are not supposed to ask people for passwords, but how can I be sure that e-mail from them is legitimate, even if it has an official AOL address?

title: Mexico's Universal Singer Calls Borderlands a Home
description: On the first page of ''Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,'' Huck grumbles over the meal before him. ''Everything was cooked by itself,'' he complains. He prefers a richer stew: ''In a barrel of odds and ends it is different; things get mixed up, and the juice kind of swaps around, and the things go better.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Circuits last Thursday about Internet use on the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk referred imprecisely to the ship's distinction within the fleet. It is the oldest active warship; the Constitution, while not in active military use, is the oldest commissioned warship still afloat; it was launched in 1797.

title: A Shop With an Artist's Eye And Hands
description: John Krynick, above right, and Fran Nestor ran the Cottage and Camp shop in Woodstock, N.Y., for five years. This summer, they moved to Hudson, Mr. Krynick said, ''to join in on what's happening here.'' A merger with a shop already in Hudson has resulted in Hulsey-Kelter Antiques and Cottage and Camp. Finds include painted wooden outdoor chairs and the Murano glass lamps above left ($690 each). If you visit, you may find Mr. Krynick knitting ribbons, drywall tape, computer cable wire, even old newspapers into wall hangings. (His big project is knitting a ''Sunset Boulevard'' screenplay into a scroll.) The shop, 521 Warren Street, is open Thursdays through Tuesdays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; (518) 822-1927.

title: Warnaco Expects to Report A Wider Loss for the Quarter
description: Warnaco Group Inc., the struggling maker of Calvin Klein jeans and Speedo swimwear, said yesterday that it expected to post a significantly higher quarterly loss and restate earnings for the last three years.

title: A Simple Glass of Water
description: Recently, on a day so blistering in Chicago that authorities issued a heat warning, telling people to stay inside when possible, I was out early with my wife and 10-year-old son, hoping to run errands before the temperature topped 90. Alas, at 9:45 a.m. we were too late, and the heat hit. We wanted water. We went into a coffee shop and ordered a latte for my wife, an iced decaf coffee for my son, and please, a glass of water for me.

title: The Unknowns of the Mechanical Heart
description: Now we have seen his face, heard him talk and learned his name: Robert Tools is the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart, following in the footsteps of Barney Clark, who became, in 1982, the first recipient of a permanent artificial heart.

title: Study Finds 3-Strikes Measure In California Much Overrated
description: Seven years after its enactment, California's three-strikes law has increased the number and severity of sentences for nonviolent offenders -- and contributed to the aging of the prison population -- but has had no significant effect on the state's decline in crime, said a new study by the Sentencing Project, a nonprofit group that supports prisoners' rights.

title: Mesa Gets Loan Accord
description: The Mesa Air Group, which runs commuter flights for larger airlines, said today that it had reached an agreement with Raytheon that ends a default on aircraft loans.

title: TD Waterhouse Has Its First Net Loss
description: The Internet brokerage firm TD Waterhouse Group said yesterday that it had its first-ever net loss in its fiscal third quarter as investors shunned stock trading and costs increased for employee layoffs and the closing of branches.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Chechnya: Rebel Said To Be Wounded
description: A deputy commander of Russian forces in Chechnya claimed that the army had wounded the elusive leader of that province's separatist rebels, Shamil Basayev, and killed as many as six of his bodyguards in a firefight on Tuesday. Other military sources claimed 22 rebels had been killed in four separate attacks. But the rebels made no mention of Mr. Basayev and claimed to have killed 30 Russian soldiers in southern Chechnya on Tuesday. Both sides have long exaggerated the extent of their success in battle. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Colombian Deal With Rebels Is Vexing U.S.
description: Bush administration officials are voicing rising impatience with the concessions President Andrs Pastrana of Colombia has granted to leftist rebels in his country. The officials say that a large swath of territory ceded to the guerrillas is being used to train terrorists, run prison camps and traffic in drugs.

title: Office Rents Decrease Sharply
description: Office rents in the United States registered their biggest decline in nine years in the second quarter, as companies laid off workers and reined in expansion plans amid a slowing economy, a study released today showed.

title: A Boon to the Elderly
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOOSE, THOMAS TRENTMAN
description: FOOSE-Thomas Trentman. Died in Cobble Hill Nursing Home August 16. A longtime resident of Brooklyn Heights, and before that Manhattan. Born and raised in Dayton, OH, he would have been 84 on September 10. He was an only child. His sole surviving relative is Martha June Baker, who resides in Dayton. He served four years in the Armed Forces in the South Pacific in W.W. II. He came to New York where he practiced his love for the theatre. For quite some years he was a Theatre Historian for Otis Guernsey, founding editor of ''The Best Plays of the Year.'' He was a drama critic for the brief revival of The Brooklyn Eagle. He also worked on theatre projects with Terese Hayden for 50 years.

description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Tim Farish and Deb Medsker were named vice presidents at Starcom North America, part of the Starcom MediaVest Group unit of the Bcom3 Group. Mr. Farish is a strategy director, based in San Francisco. Ms. Medsker is a media director, based in Chicago.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  USDAN, IRWIN
description: USDAN-Irwin. AMIT is deeply saddened by the untimely passing of the beloved brother of our most generous benefactors, Hadassah (and Marvin) Bienenfeld, and Arlene (and Moshe) Kupietzky. Irwin Usdan was deeply devoted to Torah tradition, the State of Israel and Klal Yisrael. He will be sorely missed. Heartfelt condolences to the entire family. Sondra Sokal, President Marvin Leff, Executive Director

title: Haydn, Party of 4: Exploring the Quartet Master
description: Haydn was the Big Bang of the modern string quartet. There may have been quartetlike entities floating through the ether before him, but his 68 works in the genre were instrumental in establishing and consolidating this form as we understand it today: the ne plus ultra of chamber music.

title: BUSH PROJECTIONS SHOW SHARP DROP IN BUDGET SURPLUS
description: Ending a brief but giddy era of fiscal plenty, the Bush administration released projections today showing that the federal budget surpluses outside the Social Security system will dwindle to almost nothing for the next several years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITCHELL, BERNARD L.
description: MITCHELL-Bernard L. The Jewish Center of the Hamptons mourns the passing of Bernard L. Mitchell, beloved father of Susan Wald. We extend our deepest condolences to Susan and her family. Rabbi David J. Gelfand Rabbi Alon Levkovitz Cantor Debra Stein Donald Zucker, President

title: CALENDER
description: Digital Dreams

title: IN COST-CUTTING MOVE, MAYTAG WILL OPEN PLANT IN MEXICO
description: The Maytag Corporation said yesterday that it planned to open a factory in Mexico next year to provide components for appliances like washers and dryers, reducing manufacturing expenses. Maytag is spending about $2 million for the plant, which will employ about 230, the company said. The plant is expected to open in the first quarter of 2002; its location has not been determined, Maytag said. Workers at the Mexico plant will assemble components to be used in Maytag products, Maytag said.

title: Footlights
description: Folkies

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday about nutrient deficiencies in the elderly misstated the amount of the mineral selenium in a supplement that a study found beneficial. It is 20 micrograms, not milligrams.

description: ABoon to the Elderly

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NEWMAN, JEANNETTE
description: NEWMAN-Jeannette. You remain in our hearts. Jeff & Charles & their families

title: More Signs of Trouble for Ireland's Technology Boom
description: Baltimore Technologies, the security software developer that was once the darling of Ireland's nascent technology industry, said today that it would halve its work force, delist from the Nasdaq stock market and sell nonessential businesses.

title: For Artists and Photographers, Pen Is Mightier Than the Mouse
description: Many graphic artists and professional photographers favor electronic pens and tablets over a computer mouse for drawing or retouching. But since those gadgets can cost well over $800, few amateur photographers or home-based digital artists take them to hand.

title: Heading North, and Losing Your Way Along the Way
description: Visiting Hudson these days means more than picking apples and buying expensive antiques. It is now home to musicians, artists, performance groups and shops selling home furnishings -- many of them on Warren Street between Second and Sixth Streets, near the jumping Red Dot bistro. Partial credit goes to the Fourth Down Association, founded two years ago to increase business below Fifth Street. The Wigsten Farm's five-acre corn maze, above, in Pleasant Valley, about halfway to Hudson, might make a nice stop on the way. It is open from Sept. 1 to Oct. 31, weekdays from 4 to 7 p.m., weekends from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. Adults, $7.50; those 5 to 12, $5; under 5, free. Information: www.cornfieldmaze.com or (845) 635-1570.

title: DELTA AND UNITED FOLLOW AMERICAN IN CUTTING AGENT FEES
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. and United Airlines, the unit of the UAL Corporation, have followed American Airlines in reducing the maximum commission paid to travel agents to $20 from $50 on round-trip travel in the United States and between the United States and Canada. American, owned by the AMR Corporation, made the change on Friday. The three airlines kept the commission rate at 5 percent of the ticket price, up to the $20 maximum. The maximum commission on one-way fares will be $10, down from $25.

title: People
description: Tom Burr, executive vice president and managing director at Hakuhodo Advertising America, New York, was named to the new post of chief operating officer.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: A Mission To Aceh
description: A delegation of government ministers and military leaders toured Aceh, the province where a separatist insurgency and a continuing military campaign have caused widespread bloodshed. It was the first step by the new administration of President Megawati Sukarnoputri to find a solution to the long-running conflict. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Malaysia's Internet Road Show
description: NAFIZAH ISMAIL had heard of the Internet, but she had never used it until one day in April when a special bus rolled up to her school, deep in Malaysia's northern rice bowl.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YASEEN, GERTRUDE KUBA
description: YASEEN-Gertrude Kuba, 94, on August 18, 2001, of Bal Harbour, Florida. Wife of the late Benjamin and the late Joseph Yaseen. Beloved mother of Donald Kuba. Loving grandmother of David and Melissa Kuba. An avid bridge player all her life.

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROXMEYER, JOSEPH SOLOMON
description: BROXMEYER-Joseph Solomon. Beloved husband of Lorraine, devoted father of Mark and Tracy, Gary and Lisa, Susan, and the late Neal, beloved son of the late Samuel and Anna Broxmeyer, loyal son-in-law of the late Morris and Lillian Rothstein, dear brother of Marvin and Stanley Broxmeyer, Muriel Cantor, Pearl Schefflan, and the late Roslyn Becker, loving grandfather of Michael and Dana, Evan, Daniel, Rebecca, Marissa, Matthew, Noah, Dara, Jennifer, and David. Adored great grandfather of Jacob, and Justin. Cherished stepfather of Terry, and Roger Eckstein. Services today 10 A.M. at ''Gutterman's'', 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Honoring War Dead
description: In the wake of Asian anger over the visit by Japan's prime minister to a Shinto shrine to war dead, the government is discussing a nonreligious way of honoring the Japanese soldiers who died in wars over the last 150 years. Koreans and Chinese protested last week when Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi visited Yasukuni Shrine, a focus of World War II militarism. While the religious shrine honors fallen soldiers as gods, a cenotaph would give the nation a secular memorial, the newspaper Yomiuri Shimbun reported. James Brooke (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Roselle Park: Missing Baby Found
description: A 3-month-old baby, missing since Sunday from his home in Roselle Park, was found in Newark yesterday with his baby sitter, the police said yesterday. The baby, Ni'eem Nelson, was in good condition. The baby sitter, Toni Bell, 17, had been scheduled to watch him Friday night through Saturday morning, but asked his mother for an extra day to bring the baby to church, the police said. When they did not return on Sunday night, the boy's mother contacted the Roselle police. An anonymous tip expanded the search to Newark, where, Ms. Bell said, she was helping a friend, according to officials.

title: High-Powered Control At a High Price
description: Home theater aficionados who dote on their expensive components now have a universal remote control to call their own: The Pronto Pro from Philips Electronics. The Pronto Pro, with specifications that make many hand-held computers seem inadequate, features eight megabytes of memory, a backlighted touch screen that displays 256 colors and a database of 500 infrared codes for controlling just about any type of electronic device in the home.

title: Texas Tarantino, Keeping Alive Those Killer B's
description: There's no better place than this for the Quentin Tarantino Film Festival, which is called ''QT V'' this year, since it's having its fifth outing. QT V, which began last Friday and ends Sunday, thrives in this town, which has carved out an identity for itself as a place wholly different from film capitals like New York or Los Angeles.

title: To Help North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Advocate's Job
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Will Defy Patent on AIDS Drug Made by Roche
description: After months of negotiations on price cuts ended in deadlock, Brazil said today that it would break the patent on an AIDS drug produced by the Swiss drug giant Roche.

title: Nestl Says Emerging Markets Help It Show Rise in Profits
description: Nestl, the world's biggest food company, said today that sales of its packaged food increased in emerging markets, compensating for slower growth in the United States and in Western Europe and helping to lift first-half profit 13 percent.

title: Building the Creative Spaces For Culture to Happen In
description: In the 80's, Windle Davis, top left, and Dini Lamot, top rear, were part of a band known for the song ''(I Want to Be) Jackie Onassis.'' Now, they have opened the Hudson Puppet Theater in their 1890's brick building. (Downstairs is Cottage and Camp -- see above.) ''We had no idea there were so many working artists here,'' Mr. Davis said of Hudson. Next month, there will be cabaret performances. This Saturday and Sunday, a children's puppet show, ''Fairy Tales of the Brothers Grimy,'' is at 11 a.m. and 1 p.m. Tickets are $8 in advance, $10 at the door, at 521 Warren Street (518-822-8189). The classical pianists Vladimir Pleshakov and Elena Winther, above, bought a Greek Revival building (formerly a bank) for $400,000 in 1999 and put $400,000 into it. Now, the Pleshakov Music Center, 544 Warren Street, is their home as well as home to a concert series and a planned museum (with a rare 1825 Tischner piano). On Oct. 20, there will be a benefit concert (tickets, $125 to $500). Information: (518) 671-7171.

title: Long Legal Battle Over an Apartment
description: The woman accused of killing the city marshal who tried to evict her from her apartment in Bedford-Stuyvesant had been in court for nearly two years with her landlady over unpaid rent and repairs and had vowed never to leave, people familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: It's Not the Computer; It's How (and Where) You Use It
description: Statistics on computers in schools fly fast and furious. Nearly all of the public schools in the United States are now hooked up to the Internet, but the location of computers in the school and how often students have access to them may make all the difference.

title: Better Than New: Restored Cars
Better Than New: Restored Cars
Can Hacking Victims Be Held Legally Liable?
description: Suppose, Margaret Jane Radin of Stanford Law School wrote recently, that a Web site operated by a securities brokerage suffers a crippling attack by hackers. The ability of its customers to conduct trades is hampered for several hours, or even blocked entirely. Imagine, too, that on the day of the attack the stock market is volatile, and that many customers are trying unsuccessfully to buy or sell stocks in a flash.

title: Ready to Play Dead at the Drop of a Hat
description: Sic McGraw is an actor famous for his death scenes. He is so good at them -- and enjoys them so much -- that he tours in a special production of ''Hamlet,'' in which he plays all the parts. Needless to say, he's in his glory in the final scene, in which Claudius, Gertrude, Laertes and the title character all bite the dust. Trouble is, McGraw (Nick Boraine) is now dying in real life, and predictably enough he isn't handling it with Shakespearean eloquence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIRONE, DR. DOMINICK JOSEPH
description: PIRONE-Dr. Dominick Joseph. Of Mt. Vernon, NY, on August 23. For 25 years he was a beloved faculty member in the Biology Department of Manhattan College and the College of Mt. St. Vincent in Riverdale. Dominick is survived by his wife Joan, two sons Joseph and Robert, a sister Mary Grace Barrett, a sister-in-law & a brotherin-law, Sandra and Richard. Friends may call at the Yannantuono Funeral Home, 584 Gramatan Avenue, Mt. Vernon, NY, on Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Ursula's Church, Monday, 10 AM.

title: Boy With a Decent Spirit That No One Can Burst
description: ''Bubble Boy'' is the oddest Disney picture ever, and certainly one of the freakier films of the year. Like several other new releases, it's about tolerance. By no means does it work consistently, and some of the jokes are bound to offend, but its need to push and prod means the film comes through at least 36 percent of the time, a higher average than much more highly touted pictures.

title: Oakland School's Military Bearing Rankles Some
description: The 12-year-olds standing at attention in shiny black boots and crisp tan military uniforms in the chilly morning fog recently were more used to spending their time listening to ''Bootylicious'' by Destiny's Child. Now they had a new anthem: reveille.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: World Briefing
description: AFRICA

title: Daredevil Drops In, Delaying Vacationers' Visit to Statue of Liberty
description: The Statue of Liberty, France's most cherished gift to the United States, acquired an extra piece of Gallic decoration yesterday: a French daredevil in an orange-red parachute dangling helplessly from Lady Liberty's golden flame after an aborted attempt to land on the statue's torch.

title: Quiet Bats Leave Mussina Speechless
description: When reporters asked Mike Mussina if his refusal to answer questions after Wednesday's 8-1 loss to the Rangers extended to today, he asked what they wanted to discuss. When told the subject would still be his performance on Wednesday, he said his silence would probably persist.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Uncertain Economy Spurs Interest in Law Degrees

title: Residential Real Estate; Apartments Replacing Vacant Yonkers School
description: After sitting vacant for about 30 years, the old public school that towers prominently at the fork of McLean and Park Hill Avenues in southwest Yonkers is getting a second life, much to the relief of residents and city officials.

title: Case of the Arch Gumshoe
description: ''The Curse of the Jade Scorpion,'' Woody Allen's latest small-time movie featuring big-time movie stars, is set in 1940, and its sense of period details -- the fedoras and highball glasses, the cigarette lighters and plump, upholstered furniture -- is impressively meticulous. Santo Loquasto, Mr. Allen's longtime production designer, has put together a series of camera-ready interiors, which the cinematographer, Zhao Fei, photographs as if through a filter made of butterscotch syrup. The film is a ready-made high-end collectible, a charming trifle that flatters the good taste of everyone involved: the cast, the audience and, not least, the writer-director.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: The Rangers' Next Wish Is a Goalie
description: Brett Hull turned down much more money from the Montreal Canadiens and a chance to play with Eric Lindros and Mark Messier on Broadway to sign with the Detroit Red Wings yesterday.

title: Insurer Says Hyundai Deal Could Falter
description: The American International Group, the world's largest insurer, warned today that a $1.16 billion deal to take over the financial units of the crumbling Hyundai empire could collapse, just hours after a preliminary agreement with the South Korean government was signed.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Qwest To Supply Access For DirecTV
description: The DirecTV Broadband unit of Hughes Electronics said it would work with Qwest Communications International to provide high-speed Internet access to customers before the end of the year. The agreement will let it sell fast Internet access over Qwest's network in Seattle, Phoenix, Denver, Portland, Minneapolis and Salt Lake City. Terms were not disclosed. DirecTV, based in El Segundo, Calif., is the largest provider of satellite television with more than 10 million customers. Earlier this month, DirecTV said it planned to offer high-speed satellite Internet service to its television customers by next quarter. Qwest shares fell $1.63, or 7.4 percent, to $20.47.

title: Luminous And Crisp Ideas That Broke The Mold
description: PUTTING aside the question of gold for the moment, much that glitters is actually glass, gracefully shaped, exquisitely decorated and sparkling with light. Since its invention 3,500 years ago, glass has been revered for its purity, beauty and usefulness, and at times for its supposedly magical powers. It has occasionally been valued as highly as gold or silver, with the skills and formulas required for its production guarded like state secrets. The master glassmakers of Venice were forbidden to set foot off Murano, the island to which the industry was removed by a government decree in 1291. Those who managed to escape were pursued by assassins, it is said, when offers of money, appeals to local pride and threats to family failed to bring them home.

title: One Run and Almonte Propel Bronx to U.S. Final
description: It does not take much for the boy named Rocky to miss the streets of the Bronx. That is what friends and family call Rolando Torres, who phoned his great-aunt on Wednesday night to tell her how much he longed for his family, her rice and fried chicken and his two dogs, Jeter and Princess. The Little League World Series was here, in this verdant valley, but his heart was elsewhere.

title: Human Genome Appears More Complicated
description: After a humiliating deflation this February, human dignity is on the recovery path, at least as measured by the number of genes in the human genome.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TRIPP, MARY
description: TRIPP-Mary. What is precious is to remember love as I remember yours. You are always in my heart Norma

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE RISES. Coffee gained as roasters bought up cheap supplies in preparation for the winter, when demand peaks. In New York, coffee for December delivery rose 1.1 cents, or 2 percent, to 55.95 cents a pound.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LANGERMAN, BEA
description: LANGERMAN-Bea. Redhead, How lucky we were to be touched by you. Never will you be forgotten. Love always, Herb and Brian.

title: Ex-Guard's Prison Term Doubles After He Appeals
description: A former Nassau County jail guard who pleaded guilty to federal civil rights charges in the 1999 beating death of an unarmed inmate was resentenced yesterday to 27 years in federal prison, a term more than double his original sentence, which he had appealed.

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: RUMSFELD INSISTS BUSH WON'T PARE SPENDING REQUEST
description: Responding to calls on Capitol Hill for paring back the administration's Pentagon budget request, Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that President Bush would insist that Congress approve all of his proposed $18.4 billion increase in military spending for the coming year.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Passaic: Dispute Over School Safety
description: A dispute has broken out between state authorities and the mayor over the safety of temporary classrooms for 3- and 4-year-olds. The mayor, Sammy Rivera, has ordered a halt to construction of school trailers at two sites because, he contends, the state has failed to obtain the proper zoning permits, leaving him without assurance that safety measures will be followed. A spokesman for the state's Economic Development Authority said no zoning permits were required by law and the authority was confident that it had met all safety concerns. The trailers were to accommodate about 250 preschoolers in an early-childhood education program. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: OFFICE DEPOT SAYS IT WILL MEET 3RD-QUARTER ESTIMATES
description: Office Depot said yesterday that it expected to meet analysts' third-quarter profit forecasts as sales of office supplies in North America and Europe increased. Legal matters will prevent the company from beating estimates, Bruce Nelson, the chief executive, said on a conference call, without elaborating. The company is expected to earn 20 cents a share in the quarter ending Sept. 29, according to Thomson Financial/First Call. Mr. Nelson has been closing stores, revamping displays and trying to improve customer service since he was appointed in July 2000. He said that sales at stores open at least a year had shown ''meaningful improvement'' this quarter and that gross margin, or the percentage of sales that remains after product costs are subtracted, was improving. Shares rose 32 cents, to $13.22.

title: GYMBOREE SHARES RISE 18% ON REVISED SALES FORECAST
description: The Gymboree Corporation, a maker of children's clothes, raised its forecast for August same-store sales because of strong back-to-school business. The news set off a sharp rally in its stock price, with shares rising $1.07, or 18 percent, to $6.86. The company, based in Burlingame, Calif., gave the forecast after the close of trading on Wednesday. Gymboree expects August same-store sales to increase 28 percent to 32 percent from a year ago. Earlier, it forecast an increase of 12 percent to 15 percent. The company said its loss in the second quarter ended Aug. 4 narrowed to $7.33 million, or 26 cents a share, from $17.1 million, or 62 cents, a year earlier.

title: Introduction
description: In Western cultures, at least, few modern home cooks ever get very close to food while it's still a living, breathing thing. To that, most of us would say, amen. But the lobster is the single common exception. We buy it live because of its propensity to decompose rapidly when it's dead. And we have to steel ourselves to do the deed ourselves. Few of us would force ourselves to endure that ordeal if the food itself were anything but transcendent, sweet, moist, almost unmatched in its succulence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNELL, WILLIAM F.
description: CONNELL-William F. Of Swampscott, MA, formerly of Lynn, MA, age 63 years. Husband of Mrs. Margot C. (Gensler) Connell. Son of the late William J. & Theresa G. (Keaney) Connell. Father of Monica C. Healey & her husband D. Thomas Healey Jr. of Beverly Farms, Lisa T. McNamara & her husband John E. McNamara of Lexington, Courtenay Connell-Toner & her husband Edward W. Toner Jr., William C. Connell, Terrance A. Connell & Timothy P. Connell, all of Swampscott. Grandfather of Paris, Eamonn & Declan Healey all of Beverly Farms, Meghan, Sarah, John & William McNamara all of Lexington. Brother of Mrs. Kathleen M. Muckian of Lynn & Rev. John K. Connell of Swampscott. Also survived by several nieces & nephews. A concelebrated Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Monday, August 27th at 10:00AM, in St. Mary's Church, Lynn Common at City Hall Square, Lynn, followed by burial in St. Mary's Cemetery, Lynn, MA. Relatives & friends respectfully invited. Visitation period in St. Mary's Church on Sunday, August 26th, from 3-7PM, followed by a vigil service at 7:00PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Mass. General Hospital, Melanoma Research Fund, 55 Fruit St., Boston, MA 02114. For information Solimine, Landergan & Rhodes Funeral Homes, Lynn, MA. Directions & guest book. www.legacy.com

description: ''I've been married 34 years. I have not been a perfect man. I have made mistakes in my life.''
