description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about census data on same-sex couples referred incorrectly to figures for such couples who form households in three states. The figures -- 16 percent in California, 8 percent in New York and 7.2 percent in Texas -- represent those states' share of the 594,391 same-sex households in the United States. They were not the percentages of households in the three states headed by same-sex couples.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESTON, SUSAN
description: PRESTON-Susan. On August 22, 2001, age 57, passed away peacefully following a long illness. Survived by children Michael, Lisa and Jeffrey, who revered and adored her; beloved parents Kate & A. Edward Schneyer; cherished brother Richard Schneyer; Robert Preston; devoted friends Shelley Remler, Linda Allen and Margie Zeiger. Her strength, compassion, humor and love profoundly impacted the lives of all who knew her. Services August 24th 11:30AM, Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, New York. The family may be reached at 19 John Bean Court, Port Washington, NY 11050.

title: Quizzing Condit
description: For months, Representative Gary A. Condit has seemed little more than a mystery man, often shown fleeing television cameras in slow motion, or strangely smiling at Congressional hearings as pundits have picked apart his every facial tick and body movement.

title: Editors' Note; Inside Art
description: The Inside Art column will resume with the new art season in the fall.

title: 'Together'
description: Directed by Lukas Moodysson

title: Bush Declares U.S. Will Quit ABM Pact
description: President Bush said flatly that the United States would withdraw from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty ''at a time convenient to America.'' But he insisted that he had ''no specific timetable'' for when he would scrap the treaty in order to begin testing a missile defense system.

title: Patents Could Block the Way to a Cure
description: At faculty meetings, we are often visited by our university's lawyers who specialize in patent law. They urge us to file patents on anything that might be the next medical miracle. After such meetings, many of my colleagues eagerly surround these lawyers to pitch their scientific ideas. But the notion that someone could own the rights to a lifesaving treatment remains disconcerting to those of us who cherish the ideal of the altruistic scientist searching for cures for human diseases.

title: As Public Records Go Online, Some Say They're Too Public
description: A new Web site that makes New York City voter registration records -- including home addresses -- freely available on the Internet has become the latest example of a growing tension between the individual's right to privacy and the public's right to public records in an electronic age.

title: 'Best' List for Colleges by U.S. News Is Under Fire
description: Be careful if you ask Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College in Annandale-on- Hudson, N.Y., to discuss the U.S. News & World Report annual "America's Best Colleges and Universities" issue.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.

title: Christie Todd Whitman May Have the Most Thankless Job in Washington
description: Christie Whitman arrives at the home ballpark of the Lowell Spinners, the Boston Red Sox' Class-A affiliate in the old mill town of Lowell, Mass. The stadium rises atop a cleaned-up toxic-waste site and is the kind of place administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency go. It's a glinting citadel of the new and well made, wedged among boarded-up factories. But there is no crowd waiting, only a few baseball staff members. When she was governor of New Jersey, Whitman caused a stir wherever she went; many expected her to ascend either to the United States Senate or to the vice-presidential slot on the 2000 Republican ticket. Instead she now visits toxic-waste sites. ''At least today is a clean day,'' Whitman notes. Often when she travels to inspect something, it's garbage or ooze or worse.

title: Capriati Settles Down and Advances to Semifinals
description: Jennifer Capriati, getting stronger as the match wore on, overcame 18-year-old Jelena Dokic of Yugoslavia, 6-4, 6-3, today to advance to the semifinals of the Pilot Pen tournament.

title: Punchless Mets Surrender To Rockies' Rookie Pitcher
description: Last night contained yet another cruel example of the Mets' futile season: Jason Jennings, a 23-year-old right-hander making his major league debut for the Colorado Rockies, not only pitched a shutout against the Mets, but also had three hits. One was a home run over the right-field fence to begin the ninth inning to stamp his most memorable night.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts Abroad article on Tuesday about the boom created by the film ''Captain Corelli's Mandolin'' on Cephalonia, the Greek island that is its locale, misspelled the name of a local wine that was one of the few sources of income before the movie. It is Robola, not Robolo.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Arrest In Killing
description: A 15-year-old girl was arrested last night and charged with second-degree murder in the fatal stabbing of a Brooklyn woman on Wednesday, the police said. The woman, Nneka Grant, 23, was stabbed once in the chest while standing outside a building on New York Avenue in East Flatbush. She later died at Kings County Hospital Center. Ms. Grant and the girl were involved in a late-night dispute, the subject of which the police said they did not know.

title: Bonds Makes This Year's Run For the Books
description: Perhaps the most intriguing aspect of Barry Bonds's prolific home run production this season is that no one has focused on how close he is to 60 or 61, for years and years the yardstick by which home run hitters were measured. The 1927 season of Babe Ruth and the 1961 season of Roger Maris already seem like obscure, irrelevant history.

title: CHINA NOW FACING AN AIDS EPIDEMIC, A TOP AIDE ADMITS
description: Departing from the Chinese government's general reticence on the subject of AIDS, a senior official openly admitted today that China was facing an epidemic that threatened to outpace government efforts to control it.

title: Lobster Fricassee
description: This preparation is startlingly fast, somewhat unusual and very striking, so it's ideal for entertaining. The fricassee only employs the main parts of the lobster -- tail and claws primarily -- but we save everything else (the stuff you'd normally throw away) for the next two preparations, the lobster butter and the bisque. This dish also calls for raw lobster meat, so you don't have the luxury of just dropping the lobster head first into the water; you need to use a knife to kill it quickly.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Tlcom Layoffs
description: France Tlcom said it would cut 3,000 jobs, about one-fifth of the work force, at Equant, the Dutch-registered data carrier. France Tlcom has a 54.3 percent stake in Equant, the biggest data network of its kind, extending to 220 countries, which it merged with its Global One unit in June. The job cuts will cost $40 million to $50 million and save $100 million annually, France Tlcom said. Shares in Equant rose as much as 1.9 percent while France Tlcom stock fell as much as 2.7 percent. France Tlcom paid $2.4 billion for a controlling stake in Equant, but investors are concerned that business data and communications businesses are struggling with shrinking margins. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: Sports of The Times; Vociferous Liberty Fans Set the Tone
description: TAMIKA WHITMORE is used to noise, having played in a 3,000-seat bandbox in college at Memphis that was, by her senior year, filled to every last cranny and nook. ''The Elma Roane Field House,'' she recalls, fondly. ''One of those packed little things.''

title: Sehorn Is in Jeopardy Of Missing the Opener
description: Cornerback Jason Sehorn left the Giants' training camp this morning fully intending to have arthroscopic surgery on his right knee this afternoon in New York. Sehorn hoped to reduce swelling in his knee so he could be fit for the start of the season. He entered the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan, but his surgery was delayed by a complication that clouded his status for the Sept. 10 opener at Denver.

title: 'Cupid's Mistake'
description: Directed by Young Man Kang

title: Wailing the Pain Of Affluence; Musical Angst Prospers In Tranquil Connecticut
description: In the dark musical demimonde of Connecticut hardcore, there is an unwritten rule that says: the richer the town, the more unholy must be the title of the band it spawns.

title: Partners Who Felled a Giant Now Feud Over Serbia's Path
description: A leading newspaper cartoonist depicted the country's two top leaders with sharp humor this week. The Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica, was kneeling before the patriarch of the Serbian Orthodox Church, while Zoran Djindjic, the prime minister of Serbia, was on his knees before a Western financier.

title: Metro Business Briefing | More Rooms, Fewer Guests
description: Developers are adding New York hotel rooms at about twice the pace of past years, just as demand is falling with a decline in corporate travel. About 2,000 hotel rooms will open in Manhattan by the end of 2002, increasing the size of the market by 3.3 percent, said Keith Mills, an analyst for UBS Warburg. Projects include a 511-room W Hotel in Times Square, owned by Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide, and a 287-room Ritz-Carlton overlooking Central Park. The new hotels will compete with the current ones in New York, which have a total of 60,000 rooms and an occupancy rate that has fallen to 75 percent this year from 83 percent in 2000, according to PKF Consulting, which researches the hotel industry. The new hotels could delay any rebound in occupancy beyond next year, when business travel is expected to pick up, Mr. Mills said.

title: Income Rises 65% at Krispy Kreme; Its Shares Fall
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc. said here today that its fiscal second-quarter profit rose nearly 65 percent as it opened more stores, and the company increased its estimates of profit growth.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Continue Attacks
description: The 18-year-old ethnic conflict between the government and separatist Tamil rebels flared again as rebels attacked two army camps in the northeast. Fifteen people died. The fighting has grown since the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam infiltrated an air base and the international airport a month ago, wreaking havoc on both the military and civilian air fleets. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Tehran Journal; Dog Lovers of Iran, Beware Growling Ayatollahs
description: Periodically, the guardians of all things revolutionary and Islamic in Iran decide that the country's pet dogs must go.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVI, IRVING
description: LEVI-Irving. Founder and President of OSI Oil Services. Beloved husband of Lillian. Loving father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend. A real mensch. He will be missed by all who knew and loved him. Services ''Boulevard-Riverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI. 1:30 PM on Friday.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: New Mexico: Dr. Lee's Supporters Gain
description: James A. Parker, the federal judge who apologized to the nuclear scientist Wen Ho Lee at his sentencing, has agreed to hear arguments on whether sealed government documents should be examined for evidence that Dr. Lee was singled out for prosecution because of his race. The request came from Asian-American groups maintaining that Dr. Lee, above, a Taiwan-born scientist removed from his job at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, was a victim of racial bias. At a hearing last September, Dr. Lee pleaded guilty to one charge of mishandling nuclear data, the government dropped 58 other charges, and he was freed, having spent nine months in confinement awaiting trial. Judge Parker apologized to him then for what the judge described as harsh and unfair treatment by the government.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: New Charges In Pharmacy Case
description: A federal grand jury indicted Robert R. Courtney, a Kansas City pharmacist, on 20 new felony charges related to accusations that he diluted cancer drugs. Mr. Courtney, who was charged with one felony count last week, now faces eight counts of tampering with consumer products, six counts of adulteration of a drug, and six counts of misbranding a drug. The defendant, being held without bond, will plead not guilty to all counts, his lawyer said.

title: Drug Control Office Reopening Bidding
description: The White House Office of National Drug Control Policy said yesterday that it would reopen the bidding for the media planning and buying duties for its antidrug campaign.

title: U.S. Investigating Johns Hopkins Study of Lead Paint Hazard
description: Amid growing concern about the safety of medical research involving humans, the Department of Health and Human Services opened an investigation on Wednesday into a lead-paint study in Baltimore overseen by Johns Hopkins University.

title: Current Releases
description: ALPHA LIST-->

title: Favors for Donors Seem Legal But Need a Look, Experts Say
description: It is the kind of thing that makes good-government types squirm: a campaign contributor wants a favor, and an elected official is only too happy to comply. But while such arrangements may not always smell quite right, legal experts said yesterday, they are not necessarily against the law, either.

title: De Beers, With Net Off 15%, Will Curb Its Diamond Buying
description: As the economic slowdown blunts American appetites for costly baubles, De Beers Investment, the diamond giant, said today that its first-half profit fell 15 percent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAGIN, GEORGE
description: NAGIN-George. Our special dadone of a kind. Poppy to Melissa, Nicole, Hannah, Jordan and Rebecca. Second father to Linda. Devoted husband to Rhoda. Did a wonderful job, that was almost complete. You will always be remembered, your spirit is inside all of us. Services to be held at The Riverside, NYC, on August 24 at 11:45 AM. Harvey Nagin, Helene Goldberg

title: Foreign Affairs; A Way Out of the Middle East Impasse
description: The Middle East conflict has gotten so violent and depressing, you wonder how the two sides can ever find a way out. We need a new idea. I'd like to propose one -- but first some background.

title: Distilling Theater To Television Size
description: In ''Changing Stages,'' a six-hour series starting on Sunday on PBS, the director Richard Eyre, left, examines the ephemeral art of the English-speaking theater in the 20th century. He begins with ''our theatrical DNA'': Shakespeare.

title: Golfing in Florida
description: Golfers can skip the greens fees through Sept. 30 at The Registry Resort in Naples, Fla. Room rates of $99 a person a night weekdays and $129 a person Thursday through Saturday night include a daily round of golf at the Naples Grand Golf Club, with cart and use of the driving range. These rates are based on double occupancy with a two-night minimum stay, and are subject to availability. Taxes and daily resort fees are extra. The 18-hole Naples Grande course, which opened last year, was designed by Rees Jones. Information: (800) 247-9810 or www.registryresort.com .

title: New Video Releases
description: Kippur

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POWERS, STEPHEN J.
description: POWERS-Stephen J. Age 52, of Bronxville, New York and Edgartown, Massachusetts died Friday, August 17, 2001. Mr. Powers was the son of Charlene Powers and the late Shannon Powers of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. He is survived by his daughter Anne C. Powers and son Stephen J. Powers Jr., of Westport, Connecticut; his brother R. Scott Powers of Greenlawn, New York; his sister Karen E. Powers of Lexington, Massachusetts and his mother. Mr. Powers was the founder of Cronus Partners, Inc. an investment banking firm with offices in New York City and Norwalk, Connecticut. Mr. Powers was a graduate of Princeton University with a degree in Political Science and received his Master's degree from UC-Santa Barbara. Mr. Powers was an active alumnus of Princeton, and was president of his 25th reunion class. A private family memorial will be held on Martha's Vineyard Thursday, August 23. In addition, there will be a memorial service held at the Princeton University chapel on October 20 at 11 A.M. The family requests any contributions be given to the American Liver Foundation, 75 MaidenLane, Suite 603, New York, New York 10038, (tel. 212 668-1000).

title: Russia Raises Oil Output and Exports
description: Russia, the world's second-largest oil exporter, is increasing its production and export of oil, just as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is seeking to cut back output.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Ridgewood: Student Survey Revised
description: Parents in the Ridgewood school system can prohibit their children from being surveyed on sex and other personal topics, under a policy adopted after parents filed a lawsuit accusing the district of violating their children's privacy. The suit is now under appeal after being dismissed in February by a federal judge who found that the 1999 survey involved was voluntary and anonymous, and therefore not intrusive. Nonetheless, the district's board president, Charles V. Reilly, said that a policy adopted three to one on Monday night required that parents get advance notice of such surveys, allowing their children to opt out.

description: Directed by Mike Tollin

description: DICK-Frederick. Our deepest sympathies to Marion and the entire Pokoik and Dick families on the passing of Fred. He was a man of great compassion and understanding. He will be sorely missed. Partners and Employees of Steinberg & Pokoik

description: The surplus seems to have vanished while Washington is on vacation.

description: Won't Tell, Don't Ask Her

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEVINE, SAMUEL
description: LEVINE-Samuel. Another year has passed. My memories and my love have not diminished. Mildred

title: Fast-food marketers worry about contests after a rigging scandal.
description: ADVERTISERS and agencies are trying to determine how the disclosure that promotional games at McDonald's restaurants were rigged during the last six years -- costing customers the chance to win more than $13 million in cash and prizes -- will affect the growing use of contests and sweepstakes to woo consumers.

title: A Political Straitjacket
description: For the last few years, across two presidents' administrations and an increasingly bitter partisan divide in Congress, Republicans and Democrats have agreed not to touch the portion of the federal budget surplus coming from the Social Security system.

title: NATO Troops Could End Up In Macedonia Past 30 Days
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder acknowledged today that NATO troops could end up staying in Macedonia beyond the 30 days currently set aside for their mission to disarm ethnic Albanian rebels, and he pledged to get new approval from Parliament if Germany's troops stay longer.

title: Peter Maas, Writer Who Chronicled the Mafia, Dies at 72
description: Peter Maas, who turned real-life good guys and bad guys into the stars of a long string of nonfiction best sellers, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: A 'Sex and the City' With Grunge Added
description: Science fiction and romantic comedy are generally about as compatible as sushi and whipped cream. That's why Brad Anderson's sci-fi romance, ''Happy Accidents,'' could be described as a daring film. In merging the genres, it tries for a nearly impossible fusion of two kinds of fantasy, one pseudo-logical, the other gauzy-sweet. And at odd moments, this cleverly plotted movie, which opens today at the Union Square Theater, actually makes this forced marriage work.

title: New Judge Named in Microsoft Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  The government's landmark antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation ( news/quote ) was assigned today to Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, a seasoned trial court judge and Clinton appointee to the Federal bench, to determine how to penalize the company for abusing its monopoly power in the software business.

title: Philippine Armed Forces Helped Kidnapping Gang Escape, He Says : The Fighting Priest
description: LAMITAN, Philippines  The Reverend Cirilo Nacorda, the Roman Catholic parish priest in this small seaside town, says he carries his .45-caliber handgun only when he's tending to his flock in nearby villages. Otherwise, when he's at home in his rectory here, his two bodyguards stand among the wooden pews of his church and keep watch.

title: Reckonings; Pants On Fire
description: To: Mitch Daniels, Office of Management and Budget

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Travelocity To Sell Theater Tickets
description: Travelocity.com will offer theater tickets to its users through the Hollywood Media Corporation, which provides online entertainment news. Hollywood Media's chairman, Mitchell Rubenstein, said Travelocity will put Hollywood Media's Broadway.com on its main page and will include the service in its new concierge-services feature. The tickets on offer will be for performances in New York, London, Las Vegas and Toronto of such shows as ''Phantom of the Opera,'' ''The Lion King'' and ''The Producers.'' Broadway.com plans to add more cities in the future, Mr. Rubenstein said.

title: Democrats Sue To Block Spending On Schundler
description: James E. McGreevey's gubernatorial campaign sued Bret D. Schundler and the Republican National and State Committees today, seeking to block a Republican plan to sidestep New Jersey's campaign-spending limits and pour untold millions into advertisements promoting Mr. Schundler or attacking Mr. McGreevey.

title: Bush Says Dwindling Surplus Will Halt Government Growth
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 24  President Bush said today that there was a benefit to the government's fast-dwindling surplus, declaring that it would create "a fiscal straitjacket for Congress." He said that was "incredibly positive news" because it would halt the growth of the Federal government.

title: Album of the Week
description: P. DIDDY AND THE BAD BOY FAMILY: ''The Saga Continues . . .'' (Bad Boy/Arista). What if Sean (Puffy) Combs looked like Suge Knight? What if, instead of prancing around the Hamptons in a pink Oxford shirt, dating celebrities, cozying up to Regis and rapping gangsta lite in an effete mumble, he was a huge, intimidating ex-bodyguard who flaunted gang affiliations and a beyond-the-law hard-core-rap empire?

title: Separate Journeys for Holocaust Survivors
description: Some men are born to fight, others to reflect. Despite similar European Jewish backgrounds, a fighter and a philosopher may end up with notions of the past that are as opposed as their temperaments.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Medical License Suspended
description: State health authorities have suspended the medical license of the former medical director at the Albany County Jail and banned him from working in a correctional center because of actions described by a review board as ''inhumane'' toward prisoners who were his patients. The former director, Dr. Artur Torian, who resigned in 1998, cannot practice medicine for a year. He deliberately withheld vital insulin from a diabetic patient and later did not diagnose an obviously ruptured appendix in the patient, a review board said. In another case, it was determined that Dr. Torian had not ordered tests for a patient later found to be dying of cancer. Dr. Torian's lawyer, Carolyn Shearer of Albany, did not return calls seeking comment.

title: Print the Recipes
description: Boiled Lobster

title: Vallone and Bloomberg Win Backing From Citizens Union
description: Peter F. Vallone and Michael R. Bloomberg received the backing yesterday of the Citizens Union, a nonpartisan civic organization, in their respective primary races for mayor.

title: G.E. Plans to Shut Factory
description: General Electric plans to close a Philadelphia plant where 216 workers make protection devices for industrial turbines. The company expects to buy the devices from outside to cut costs. Nearly half the workers are eligible for early retirement, said a spokeswoman for GE Industrial Systems, the division that makes the equipment. The plant mostly supplies another unit, GE Power Systems.

title: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Scores Improve on State Test As Scoring Method Changes
description: Ever since New Jersey set higher academic standards in 1996 and began administering statewide tests two years later, local educators and parents have argued over the tests and the way they are scored.

title: After 9 Years, Man Is Caught In Drug Case
description: After running from the law for more than nine years, a Westchester County man was arrested last week and charged with being one of the biggest wholesale marijuana suppliers in the New York area over the last two decades.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Hutchison's Profit Falls
description: The diversified holding company Hutchison Whampoa said its first-half profit fell 77 percent as the value of stakes in mobile-phone companies fell and port business growth slowed. Hutchison, owned by Asia's richest man, Li Ka-shing, had net income of 7.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($923 million), or 1.69 Hong Kong dollars a share, compared with 31.1 billion Hong Kong dollars, or 7.30 a share, in the first half of 2000.

title: Tap Water, in a Bottle
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTER, JOSEPH
description: WINTER-Joseph. Died August 23, 2001. For further information call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 212-769-4400.

title: Making Magic With Young Feet
description: CHILD performers have long been a part of dance, bobbing up, for the most part, as mice, insects and youthful characters. Today, however, children seem to perform -- in roles not necessarily tailored to their ages -- even more often than they watch from the audience.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on Page 8.

title: At Met Open, The Amateur Strikes Again
description: Johnson Wagner will have to find room in his car for another trophy before he heads back to Virginia Tech on Friday. Wagner, a 21-year-old from Garrison, N.Y., added the M.G.A./Met Life Open title yesterday to the Met Amateur championship he won earlier this month.

title: Yankees Use Time Off To Their Advantage
description: When the visitors' clubhouse opened three and a half hours before tonight's game between the Yankees and the Rangers, the spacious room resembled a bus terminal at 3 a.m. There were barely any Yankees around, a drastic difference from the normal routine, and the reporters outnumbered the players 8 to 2.

title: Deerfield Snags Rare Bird
description: The massive colonial New England settle, or bench, dated about 1730, looks quite crude. It is 75 inches long and 47 inches high and has a white oak frame and an 18-inch-wide rope seat. Its high back is a single plank of water-sawn sweet gum, a New England tree. Its crest rail is decorated with a panel of oak carved with a tulip and leaf motif. It still bears traces of blue paint.

title: Mideast Obstacles
description: To the Editor:

title: In Nepal, Too, Desire Defies Modern Times
description: ARRESTING GOD IN KATHMANDU

title: Learning About the Birds, The Bees and the Petri Dishes
description: ''Maybe Baby,'' Ben Elton's fearless and funny comedy about infertility, is all but stolen by the British comic Rowan Atkinson in the small role of an alarmingly enthusiastic gynecologist. Disclosing the results of an unpleasant internal examination, the beaming doctor exclaims delightedly to his patient, Lucy Bell (Joely Richardson), that she has ''super guts,'' then rushes on to compliment her on the magnificence of her bowel and stool. This is the same specialist who in an earlier scene is shown proudly exhibiting his instruments to a wide-eyed student doctor with the glee of a sadist showing off tools of torture while Lucy, who is about to be probed, watches anxiously from the examination table.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Oklahoma: Help For Mexican On Death Row
description: A state psychiatrist recanted his testimony against Gerardo Valdez, a Mexican citizen sentenced to die for a 1989 killing. The psychiatrist, Dr. Cecil F. Mynatt Jr., said in an affidavit filed with an appeal in Oklahoma City that new information convinced him that Mr. Valdez was temporarily insane when he shot his victim, Juan Barron. Dr. Mynatt said ''homosexual panic'' brought on paranoia in Mr. Valdez at the time of the shooting. The new information that helped change the doctor's mind was the discovery by an investigator for the Mexican government that Mr. Valdez had a history of head injuries.

description: To the Editor:

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASHLEY, JANE MORSE
description: LASHLEY-Jane Morse. We mourn the passing of Jane Morse Lashley, the mother of our esteemed partner, David W. Morse. She was a gifted and dedicated educator who began her forty-five year career as an elementery school teacher and recently retired as the Chair, Department of Education at Cameron University. Her devotion to church included teaching Sunday school & service as a choir member and soloist, and lay leader. In 1956, she married the Rev. Don G. Morse, last of New York City, NY, now deceased and in 1984 married Dr. F.J. Lashley of Walters, OK. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Lashley, David, his wife Catharine W. Trimble, their children, Colin, Sean, and their families. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Cameron University Student Scholarship Fund, Lawton, OK or First United Methodist Church, Walters, OK. Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, PC

title: World Briefing | Asia: Bangladesh: More Crowded Than Ever
description: The population of one of the world's most densely populated countries rose to 129 million from 106 million over the past decade, according to the 2001 census, a 22 percent increase. The number of people per square mile grew to 2,269 from 1,865. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Karen Garrison, director for corporate communications at Primedia Business Magazines and Media, Overland Park, Kan., part of Primedia, was promoted to vice president for corporate communications.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Woodbridge: Parkway Tokens May End
description: The sale of tokens may be eliminated from the Garden State Parkway under a plan recommended by the New Jersey Highway Authority yesterday. Ending token sales would encourage the use of E-ZPass electronic tolls. Tokens would no longer be sold after Jan. 1, 2002, though the tolls would continue accepting them indefinitely. But no action will be taken until the end of the public comment period that begins now and continues through fall, a spokesman said.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Switchboard Revamps Viacom Deal
description: Switchboard Inc., an Internet directory company, said yesterday that it had given up $72.5 million in advertising credits from Viacom so that it could recover about a third of its stock from the media giant. In June 1999, Viacom, which owns the CBS broadcast network, acquired an equity stake in Switchboard in exchange for $135 million worth of promotion and advertising. With yesterday's move, Viacom's stake in the Switchboard, based in Westboro, Mass., will be cut to about 3 percent from 32 percent. ''Our business has really shifted,'' said Dean Polnerow, president and founder of Switchboard. ''We are much more oriented to technology licensing to partners now.'' In the last year, Switchboard, like many Internet companies, has refocused on technology licensing and partnerships as once-plentiful advertising opportunities have dried up. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Bush Flatly States U.S. Will Pull Out of Missile Treaty
description: President Bush said flatly today that the United States will withdraw from the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty ''at a time convenient to America.'' But he insisted that he had ''no specific timetable in mind'' about when he would scrap the agreement so that his administration can begin testing a missile defense system, which the treaty forbids.

title: Record Year for Ski Areas
description: After two years of declining visits, the nation's ski areas enjoyed a record season during the winter of 2000-2001, according to a survey released by the National Ski Areas Association, a trade group. The survey found that early snowfalls in many parts of the country contributed to 57.3 million daily visits by skiers and snowboarders, a 9.8 percent increase over the previous winter and the most since 54.6 million daily visits were recorded in the winter of 1993-1994.

title: Yes, That's Norman Atop the Leader Board in Ohio
description: For the past few years, it has become rarer to see Greg Norman at golf tournaments and rarer to see him in contention.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the arts pages on Wednesday with an article about foreign performers who are canceling dates in Israel for fear of terrorism misstated the number of people killed by a suicide bombing outside a Tel Aviv discothque in June. It was 21, not 18.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPECTOR, AARON
description: SPECTOR-Aaron. The Partners and staff of Spector, Rothenberg & Co., LLP acknowledge with sadness the passing of Aaron Spector, beloved father of our friend and colleague, Martin Spector. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Spector family.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: President Says He Won't Run
description: President Jos Eduardo dos Santos, who has held office since 1979, said he would not run in the country's next election, according to news reports from the capital, Luanda. But with the country still racked by civil war and with vast stretches of the nation in the hands of rebels, when elections would be held and when Mr. dos Santos would actually leave office is far from clear. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)

title: Friendly, but Only for a New York Minute
description: To the Editor:

title: How Bright the Sky
description: If you travel far enough from the major cities of the world, out onto the steppes or savannahs, into the mountains or deserts, it is still possible to look up at night and see the stars in the sky, as many stars as you can imagine seeing. If the moon is down, the patterning of the stars becomes readily apparent, and especially the one great pattern, the thick band of stars that lies along the central axis of our galaxy, the Milky Way. It is an unforgettable spectacle and as much a part of the human heritage -- a fundamental element in our historical consciousness of life on this planet -- as the sight of the sun rising every morning. But in the places most of us live and work, the Milky Way is only a memory.

title: Amid Slump, Cisco Announces a Revamping
description: Mired in the sharpest slump in its history, Cisco Systems, the computer networking giant, said today that it would restructure its business as its decline in sales showed signs of easing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, STANTON
description: WEINBERG-Stanton. American Friends of The Hebrew University mourns the passing of Stanton Weinberg, father of Richard D. Weinberg, Member of AFHU Council of Trustees and Greater New York Board of Directors and Chairman of the AFHU New York Lawyer's Division. On behalf of AFHU, we extend our deepest condolences to Rick and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: American Express Loses Appeal
description: A federal appeals court today denied the American Express Company a $199 million tax refund, saying the company could not change its accounting method to defer income from fees it received for issuing charge cards.

description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Not Funny, Police Say
description: The police said they planned to question an entertainer who parodied a patriotic song at a gathering at the home of former President Abdurrahman Wahid. The police action fed fears that limits could be imposed on freedom of expression under the new government of President Megawati Sukarnoputri. Seth Mydans (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOWARD, RICHARD
description: CLOWARD-Richard. Passionate advocate for economic justice and empowerment of low income communities. Founder of the Welfare Law Center in 1965 and friend and supporter ever since. Your memory inspires us. Henry Freedman, Executive Director

title: Hitchhiking in a Hurry: What Does That Tell You?
description: ''That's what the Internet's for: slandering others anonymously,'' asserts the Garden State slacker Banky (Jason Lee) in ''Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBUD, NAIDA (NEE ROBARE)
description: EISENBUD-Naida (nee Robare). On August 22, 2001. Wife of Leon Eisenbud. Mother of Barbara Mandell of Ellicott City, MD and Robert Eisenbud of Washington, DC. Mother-in-law of Ira Mandell. Grandmother of Kenneth Mandell, Jessica Mandell and her fiance Michael Curley. Sister of Floyd Robare. A memorial service will be announced at a later time. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be directed to Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 200 E. Jopa Road, Suite 300, Baltimore, MD. 21286, or Friends at Barefoot Beach Preserve, Inc., P.O. Box 1321, Bonita Springs, FL. Sol Levinson & Brothers.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Stafford Township: Drowning Report
description: A police report blames poor supervision by a school staff for the drowning of an 8-year-old boy last month. The State Department of Human Services is also investigating the death. The boy, Keshawn Banks of Atlantic City, drowned July 13 at Ocean Lakes Park. According to the report, released earlier this week, the organizers of the outing, the Coastal Learning Center of Tuckerton, had no clear chain of command for supervisors. The Police Department does not plan to file charges against the school. Timothy Middleton, the school's lawyer, said the report ''miscategorized the situation as a whole.''

title: Now That the Money Is Gone . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Governing Party Names Candidate
description: The governing Movement for Mulitparty Democracy named Levy Mwanawasa its candidate to succeed President Frederick Chiluba in an election planned for later this year. A lawyer, he was vice president under Mr. Chiluba when the latter was elected in 1991 but resigned from his post and the party in 1994 after he was sidelined by the party leadership. Chiluba supporters had mounted a campaign to keep the president in office beyond the two terms allowed by the constitution but encountered widespread public opposition and abandoned the effort.

title: Making Room for DVD and VHS
description: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies. In short, there isn't money or shelf space for everything. More obscure titles that were once distributed routinely, if not profusely, on videocassette are being dropped by studios more interested in developing the biggest and best known older films in DVD special editions that will sell by the bushel at mass outlets like Best Buy and Wal- Mart.

title: Variety of Retailers Say Sales Will Remain Slow for Rest of Year
description: Kmart and other retailers said yesterday that sales would remain slow for the rest of the year, reflecting consumers' increasingly cautious spending patterns.

title: Woman, Daughter and Friend Are Charged in Nassau Killing
description: A Massapequa woman, her boyfriend and her teenage daughter were arraigned today on charges that they drugged to death a crane operator, whose body was then buried in a shallow grave at a nature preserve, the police said.

title: A Mixed Field for a Mixed District Expected to Gain in Political Strength
description: It is a district made up of Brooklyn neighborhoods with different personalities. There is Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, with their immense population of black, middle-class residents and trendy restaurants and shops. There is Crown Heights, with its Orthodox Jewish enclave in a largely Caribbean neighborhood. There is also the Brooklyn Academy of Music and the adjacent area with its growing populations of middle-income transplants from Manhattan, both black and white.

title: World Briefing | Asia: China: Talks On Missiles With U.S.
description: American and Chinese officials met in Beijing for what were described as ''technical'' discussions on the spread of ballistic missiles. In an agreement reached last November, China said it would not help any country develop missiles able to carry nuclear weapons and promised to put strict export controls on missile technologies. American officials have suspected violations and are seeking details from China on how it will carry out the agreement.

title: Now That the Money Is Gone . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: The Innocent Yet Sinister Aspects of Japanese Animation
description: Out of the to and fro of cultural influence between Japan and America, one of the more intriguing products to be tossed up on our shores in recent years is anime, a type of cartoon animation that emerged in Japan in the 1960's. With a sleekly hyperactive linear style, anime offers a weird mix of innocence and experience. It depicts big-eyed, male and female heroes who look like children or teenagers but engage in adult levels of violence and sexuality, usually in some apocalyptic, futuristic setting. Anime and manga -- the comic books from which it derives -- are hugely popular in Japan, and related video games have gained a cult following among young Westerners.

title: Rumsfeld Says He Is Limiting Role Because of Stock Holdings
description: Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld said today that he had avoided making decisions involving weapons programs, AIDS policy and defense mergers because of potential conflicts caused by his once-vast stock portfolio.

title: Editors' Note; On Stage and Off
description: The On Stage and Off column will resume with the new theater season in the fall.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Lakewood: Police Officers Suspended
description: Three police officers charged with beating a driver and then lying to conceal it have been suspended without pay, a township committee has announced. On Tuesday, the three officers, Steven Kelusak, 30, Christopher Spagnuolo, 32, and Joseph Qualiano III, 28, were indicted by a grand jury on charges of aggravated assault, official misconduct, falsifying records and conspiracy. The township announced the suspensions Wednesday.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Political Bombing Suspected
description: A powerful explosion caused extensive damage to a building housing the offices of the right-wing Northern League party in the town of Vigonza, near Padua. No one was injured in the blast, which appeared to have been caused by a bomb. The Northern League, born as a separatist party and now part of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi's government, is known for the blunt and sometimes anti-immigrant remarks of its leader, Umberto Bossi, now Minister of Reforms.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 6 about a speech by Ralph Nader in Portland, Ore., misstated the number of states in which his name did not appear on the 2000 presidential ballot and the number that did not record any votes for him. He was not on the ballot in seven states, not five. States that recorded no votes for him though he could have received write-in votes numbered three, not five.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Nintendo Delays Gamecube Release
description: Nintendo delayed the North American release of its GameCube video game console until the Sunday before Thanksgiving, but said it would ship about 25 percent more of the devices than it had originally planned. At a trade show in Japan, Nintendo executives said they would ship 700,000 GameCubes in time to begin selling on Nov. 18, 10 days after Microsoft's new console, the Xbox, lands on store shelves. Edward S. Williams, an analyst with Gerard Klauer Mattison, said he expected Nintendo's delay to have little effect on sales of either console. Executives from Nintendo of America suggested that they wanted to avoid the production troubles of the Sony Corporation, which shipped only 400,000 of its PlayStation 2 consoles at the product's introduction last November before recovering to take the lead in the console industry. Nintendo said it expected to release 500,000 GameCubes in Japan on Sept. 14, as planned. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Rises End
description: After raising interest rates for five straight months to keep a lid on inflation, the Brazilian central bank left rates unchanged this month at 19 percent to avoid aggravating an economic slowdown that may lead to recession. The bank had increased rates 3.75 percentage points since March in an effort to reduce pressure on the currency brought on by a local energy shortage and the economic crisis in neighboring Argentina. Brazil also recently negotiated a $15 billion loan package with the International Monetary Fund to help support the currency, the real. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the arts pages on Wednesday with an article about the Kinsey Sicks, a drag performance quartet, reversed the identities of two performers in rehearsal. In the background, Ben Schatz was on the left and Chris Dilley on the right.

title: Marquee Firm In California Cuts Lawyers
description: Cooley Godward, one of the San Francisco area's highest-flying law firms during the Internet boom, told employees yesterday that more than 10 percent of the firm's lawyers would be laid off.

title: Out of Fray, The Mayor Lets Picks Be Known
description: For several weeks now, Rudolph W. Giuliani has resisted even the tastiest of baits to annotate the race for City Hall or to comment on its contenders. While Mark Green has bragged about suing the mayor and Fernando Ferrer has developed much of his platform around his distaste for him, Mr. Giuliani has remained more or less mum.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  TAVCAR, LAWRENCE R.
description: TAVCAR-Lawrence R. I can hear your laughter and see your smile like it was yesterday. You are always with me, and will always be my hero and inspiration. Love always, your son, Bret

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKOTOFF, MILTON M., HON.
description: MOKOTOFF-Milton M., Hon. Age 84, of Sands Point, New York, died on Sunday, August 19. After sixty years of marriage, he remains adored by his wife, Shirley. Beloved father of Tama Bernstein, David Mokotoff, and Elaine Viders. Treasured grandfather of Marne Roskin (Thomas), Alexis and Leah Bernstein, Benjamin and Michael Mokotoff, Jared and Zachary Viders, and great-grandfather of Zoe Rose Roskin. Admitted to the New York State and Federal Courts and the United States Supreme Court, Judge Mokotoff graduated from St. John's School of Law and was admitted to the bar in 1941. He was the senior partner of the law firm Mokotoff & Mondshine and was a much sought-after arbitrator and mediator. Beyond the courts, he and his wife taught three generations the importance of living happily. He was an inspiration to all who had the good fortune to know him.

title: LAW SCHOOL CALLS AS ECONOMY SLOWS
description: When Kevin Haeberle graduated from Georgetown University with a degree in English literature two years ago, the last thing on his mind was law school.

title: Food Shortage in Mountains Sends Hungry Bears to Town
description: The calls started coming in about 9 this morning, all Signal 67, which is police lingo for bear. As in a black bear halfway up a pine tree off Sixth Street. Or another bear chewing on apples on Moulton Street. Or a third bear scurrying down a drainage canal after a wildlife officer chased him out of a tree.

title: Greenwich Gets Its Wish as State Lottery Officials Stop Sales of Powerball Tickets
description: The town of Greenwich today won permission to suspend sales of Powerball multistate lottery tickets on Friday, a move town officials said was needed because too many players with too many dreams of a $280 million jackpot were crossing the border from New York and creating nightmarish conditions for residents and the local police.

title: The Big City; Civility Pays, At Least if You Hold a Leash
description: THE mayoral candidates have pledged to continue Rudolph W. Giuliani's crusade against quality-of-life offenses, but they've also promised New York a kinder, gentler mayor. How do you reconcile these two goals?

title: Brokers Back Conflict-of-Interest Plan
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the Goldman Sachs Group and other brokerage firms have endorsed a regulatory plan to require stock analysts to disclose potential conflicts of interest, while asserting that analysts should not be forced to give details during television appearances.

title: First Voting In East Timor Gives a Taste Of New Rights
description: Exactly two years after the people of East Timor voted, at great cost, to break away from Indonesia, they are tasting the fruits of their freedom with the first democratic election in their history.

title: Hasbro Combines Units After Interest in Some Toys Falls
description: Hasbro, the nation's second-largest toy maker after Mattel, said yesterday that it was consolidating the last of its semi-independent divisions.

title: Death Row Inmate Is Freed After DNA Test Clears Him
description: Charles Fain has been on death row for almost 18 years for the rape and murder of a 9-year-old girl who was snatched off the street in Nampa, a small town west of here.

title: Initial Jobless Claims Rise as Unemployment Benefits Surge
description: The number of workers filing new claims for jobless benefits rose last week and an increase in those continuing to receive payments suggests that the laid-off employees are having trouble finding work.

title: Lucent Maps Out Route to Profit by the End of Next Year
description: Lucent Technologies, which has lost more than $6 billion and 80 percent of its market value in the last year, mapped out its comeback trail yesterday, reaffirming its intention to return to profitability by the end of next year.

title: Bush Names Air Force General to Head Joint Chiefs of Staff
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  President Bush nominated Gen. Richard B. Myers of the Air Force today to be chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, calling him exactly the right person to lead the United States military into the 21st century.

title: California Home Prices Up
description: Prices for homes in Southern California rose in July at their fastest rate since 1989 and sales surged, helped by low mortgage rates and pent-up demand for lower-cost homes, a new report said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: West Nile Spraying Delayed
description: Pesticide spraying for adult mosquitoes in Central Park scheduled for early today was postponed because of rain, which interferes with the pesticide's effectiveness, city officials said. The spraying, in response to the discovery of five mosquito samples and three birds that tested positive for the West Nile virus, is now planned for early Monday, from midnight until 5 a.m. if the weather permits. Spraying of residential and nonresidential areas in Queens, in response to the second person sickened with the virus, is still scheduled for 10 tonight until 5 a.m. tomorrow.

title: Condit Denies Any Knowledge Of Levy's Fate
description: Battling for his political life, Representative Gary A. Condit of California acknowledged in a tense, nationally televised interview tonight that he had had a ''very close'' relationship with Chandra Ann Levy, a Washington intern from his home district. But he declined to say whether it was sexual and repeatedly said he knew nothing about Ms. Levy's disappearance nearly four months ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINTZ, MARVIN
description: MINTZ-Marvin. Of Manlius, New York, died August 23, 2001. Loving husband of Susan and devoted father to Jonathan and Elizabeth. Father-in-law to Beth. Son of Selma Silverman. Marvin, a retired psychologist, was owner of Bouckville Books. He will always be remembered for his compassion, kindness and gentleness. We will miss Marvin forever.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Russian Seeks To Have Charges Dropped
description: Defense lawyers are negotiating to have charges dropped against Dmitri Sklyarov, left, a 26-year-old Russian cryptographer accused of violating a 1998 digital copyright law. A court hearing scheduled for yesterday in San Jose, Calif., was delayed for a week until Aug. 30. ''By next week, we will know if this case is going to go forward or if it is going to disappear,'' said Joseph M. Burton, a partner at Duane Morris who represents Mr. Sklyarov. Scott Frewing, an assistant United States attorney, would not comment on the case. Mr. Sklyarov was charged with trafficking a program that decrypts electronic books from Adobe Systems. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Art May Not Be All Fun and Games, but Some of It Certainly Is
description: Taking cues from the Surrealists and Grandpa Duchamp, the foxiest player of them all, more than a few artists are incorporating games and game themes into their work. They are prompted, too, by current video and computer pastimes, and maybe the slots at Las Vegas.

title: INSIDE
description: Israel Moves into Hebron

title: U.S. Rowers Surge to the Finals
description: The United States brought an untested squad to this year's world rowing championships, but in the qualifying heats, which began last Sunday, it has advanced 11 boats to the men's and women's finals this weekend.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Race Tight, Police Move In
description: As polls showed the Sept. 9 presidential election contest tightening, the police closed two publishing houses that support pro-democracy forces campaigning against the nation's autocratic leader, President Aleksandr Lukashenko. The police sealed the pressroom of Magic Press, which prints Nasha Svaboda and 15 other independent newspapers in a nation where the press is largely state-controlled. The second concern, Znameniye Publishers, was shut down after printing state-approved leaflets for the opposition's presidential candidate, Vladimir Goncharik.

description: To the Editor:

title: Expos in India Spawns a Risqu Second One
description: Several Internet journalists whose expos of corruption in military procurement caused the resignation of India's defense minister in March now find themselves the subject of an expos about how they got the story.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRATSKEIR, CLARA
description: BRATSKEIR-Clara. Our heartfelt condolences to the family of Clara Bratskeir. She was the epitome of grace and the source of love and warmth to all who knew her. Our thoughts are with her son Stan and his wife Anne, grandchildren Lauren, Amy, Nick, Katie, Rob and his wife Susan and great-grandchildren Jae and Ethan. Peggy, Marc, Ryan, Adam

title: If Theater Doesn't Work on TV, Make the Most of It
description: Richard Eyre's first, most unarguable point in ''Changing Stages,'' his lively, sometimes dazzling survey of English-speaking theater in the 20th century, is that theater cannot be captured on television. Like a legendary sculpture that Michelangelo once made in snow, he says, the theatrical experience lives in an evanescent present tense that ''melts away like a snowman in the sun.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about California's ''three strikes'' law for mandatory sentencing misstated its application. Criminals who have two prior convictions for any of the state's 41 most serious felonies are subject to the mandatory sentence of 25 years to life when they commit a third felony, regardless of its seriousness. Those who have committed two less serious felonies are not subject to the law when they commit a third felony.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: JOHNSON CONTROLS, Milwaukee, a maker of automotive interiors and seats, said it would acquire the closely held Hoppecke Automotive, Brilon, Germany, a maker of car batteries. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Now That the Money Is Gone . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Armor Rolls Deep Into Hebron in 2-Hour Raid
description: Israeli tanks and armored vehicles pushed deep into Palestinian-controlled areas of Hebron on Thursday night, leveling two hilltop houses used by Palestinian gunmen to shoot at Israelis living below in that ever-roiled West Bank city.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Portugal: Joint Auto Venture
description: Portugal's biggest oil and gas company, Galpenergia SGPS, and Midas Inc. are discussing a joint venture to open as many as 60 car parts and service stores. The discussions follow the successful opening of a test-store two months ago, said Nuo Moreira da Cruz, a Galpenergia board member.

title: Enticing Third World Youth; Big Tobacco Is Accused Of Crossing an Age Line
description: Sara Bogdani had just turned 17 last summer when she slipped into a short skirt and started working as a Marlboro girl.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Iowa: More For Education
description: Despite sluggish state revenue and a tight budget, Gov. Tom Vilsack vowed to push for more education spending. To begin with, he said he would ask for money in the next legislative session to increase teacher salaries, on top of the raise provided by a $40 million bill enacted this spring. The governor did not specify how much new education spending he would seek or how he proposed to finance it.

title: Roche Asks for Meeting With Brazil Health Minister
description: The dispute between the Brazilian government and Roche, the Swiss drug maker, intensified yesterday as the company asked to meet with the country's health minister, who repeated his threat to authorize generic copies of Roche's AIDS medicine Viracept.

title: Levy Says $200 Million May Have to Be Cut a Week Before School Opens
description: The budget brinksmanship between the Board of Education and City Hall reached a new peak yesterday as Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy warned that he might announce budget cuts of up to $200 million next week, just a week before students return to school.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AOL TIME WARNER, New York, named Robert Friedman, president for AOL TV, to the post of president at AOL Interactive Marketing. He succeeds Myer Berlow, who was named president at a new AOL Time Warner Global Marketing Solutions group.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: When a pan-Asian restaurant serves an appetizer called ''assorted Asian jewels'' and broadcasts Jimi Hendrix on the soundtrack, something odd is going on. Tiger Blossom, as the slightly overripe name might suggest, uses the vast expanse of Asian cuisine as a palette of exotic colors. Christopher Cheung, the chef and owner, grew up in Chinatown but spent his formative professional years at places like Ruby Foo's, Celadon, Nobu and Vong. He has a hipster's view of Asian food and a florid sense of fantasy. Tiger Blossom is his Xanadu.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: ING'S Profit Grows
description: The Dutch financial services company ING Groep said second-quarter profit rose 21 percent, helped by acquisitions and lending income. Despite an ''uncertain'' economic outlook, ING said it still expected full-year earnings to rise 17 percent. Last year, ING spent $13.8 billion to increase its presence in the United States life insurance industry, buying ReliaStar Financial and two units from Aetna. Profit, excluding one-time gains, rose to 1.27 billion euros ($1.15 billion), or 65 cents a share, compared with 1.05 billion euros, or 54 cents a share, last year. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Profit Up At Rolls-Royce
description: Helped by increased sales of commercial jet engines and spare parts, Rolls-Royce said its first-half profit rose more than fourfold. Net income increased to 85 million ($123 million), or 5.35 pence a share, compared with 18 million, or 1.15 pence a share, last year. Sales grew 15 percent, to 3 billion ($4.3 billion). Sales of commercial jet engines grew 40 percent, and the number of engines already on planes that require spare parts and servicing is on the rise, the company said. The No. 2 engine maker in the world, Rolls is winning market share at the expense of Pratt & Whitney, a unit of United Technologies, which is the industry's third largest. General Electric remains the market leader. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Transcript of Ann McCormick's Visit to the Drug Policy Forum
description: On Thursday, August 23, the NYTimes.com's Drug Policy forum hosted Ann McCormick of Compassionate Moms. This discussion was part of the speaker series organized by forum participants.

title: Stocks End Higher on Cisco News
description: Stocks ended the day sharply higher with technology issues leading the way after Cisco Systems ( news/quote ), the computer networking giant, said it was restructuring its business and that it saw signs that its business was stabilizing.

title: Travel Agent Group to Protest
description: The American Society of Travel Agents has asked agencies to close their offices for two hours next Thursday in the first nationwide protest of reductions in fees paid to them by airlines.

title: Gephardt Criticizes Condit for Remarks in TV Interview
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24  Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said today that he was disappointed with his colleague Representative Gary A. Condit and said he would talk to other House members about possible disciplinary action.

title: Showdown at O.K. Corral, With Zombies
description: John Carpenter has to be the last hippie still making movies. He has dug in his heels and continues to pack his films with anticonformity messages; there can't be another director who has worked the theme of losing one's individuality more consistently. That theme is also the basis of ''John Carpenter's Ghosts of Mars.'' Unfortunately, though its heart and mind are in the right place, it's like a zombie picture directed by one of the undead.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALTSCHULER, ETHEL BOBROW
description: ALTSCHULER-Ethel Bobrow. On August 18, 2001 at age 91. Loving wife of the late Richard. Mother of Jon and Olivia, Michael and Coco. Aunt of Jackie and Kenny. Sisterin-law of Judy Bobrow. Grandmother of Chris, Eric and Randy. Great grandmother of Finneas, Benjamin and Daniel. Memorial service to be announced.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Aug. 16 about Jack N. James, a rocket engineer and technical team leader for several space missions, misstated the destination of the Viking spacecraft. It went to Mars, not to the Moon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, JOHN T. JR.
description: HARRISON-John T. Jr., died of a stroke August 22nd at his home in Essex, Connecticut. He was 89 years old. Born in Corona, Long Island, he was a resident of New York City for most of his life. He attended the Allen Stevenson School, graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., in 1931 and from Yale University in 1935. After training for two years with the Insurance Company of North America, he entered his father's firm of Flynn, Harrison and Conroy, Insurance Brokers, where he remained until he joined the Navy in 1942 as a commissioned officer rising to the rank of Lieutenant Commander. After the War, he resumed his career as an insurance broker, becoming a general partner of Flynn, Harrison and Conroy in 1952. He served as Director of the Insurance Brokers Association of the State of New York from 1955 to 1974 and was President of the Association from 1962 to 1964. He also was Treasurer of the National Association of Insurance Brokers from 1959 until 1966. Following the merger of his firm with Marsh and McLennan in 1966, he was appointed Vice President of that company where he remained until his retirement in 1974. He was a member of the vestry of the Church of the Heavenly Rest and President of the Heavenly Rest Day School. He was also a Trustee of St. John's College in Annapolis, Maryland, and Santa Fe, New Mexico. In 1980, he became a Trustee of the Bennington Museum in Bennington, Vermont, and he subsequently served as Chairman of the Museum's Board of Trustees from 1990-1993. He is survived by Patricia Wood, his wife of sixty-three years, and four children, Frederick Wood Harrison, Virginia Harrison Berstene, John T. Harrison, III, and Daniel Hall Harrison. He was a loving and kind husband and father, as well as a devoted grandfather of six. His funeral service will be held at St. James Church, Arlington, Vermont, on August 26th at 3 o'clock. In lieu of flowers his family encourages a contribution in his memory to the Bennington Museum.

title: An Uninspiring Peace Corps Nominee
description: President Bush's intention to nominate Gaddi H. Vasquez as director of the Peace Corps amounts to a missed opportunity. The altruistic agency is a unique diplomatic and humanitarian asset in need of forceful and imaginative leadership. Any number of prominent figures from the foreign policy community, the business world or the nonprofit sector would be thrilled at the opportunity to lead it.

title: Finger Lakes Riesling Is New York Wine Star
description: A 2000 riesling from a winery in the Finger Lakes region defeated 485 wines, the largest number ever entered, to be named the best New York wine of 2001 in a major contest of the state's wines this week. The wine trade increasingly recognizes the Finger Lakes as one of the world's most promising new riesling regions, which was borne out by the choice of the 2000 off-dry riesling, a white from Red Newt Cellars, a winery on Seneca Lake in Hector.

title: Russia Launches Pontoon In a Race Against Time To Help Raise Sunken Sub
description: A naval band struck up a patriotic medley as the wife of an executive of the Dutch maritime company Mammoet smashed a Champagne bottle against the steel-plated hull of a 300-foot-long structure possessing all the elegance of an ocean-going lunch box. Still, the yard workers treated it like the Queen Mary, and a Russian Orthodox priest sprinkled holy water on the hull and blessed it before it inched forward toward the White Sea.

title: Medical-Pump Pricing Inquiry
description: Abbott Laboratories, Novartis A.G. and Tyco International Ltd. said today that they were among the targets of a federal investigation of businesses that sell products used to feed critically ill patients through tubes.

title: Albany, Without Politics
description: Albany brings to mind images of legislators rather than landscapes, but along with the surrounding region it offers inviting attractions from Hudson River cruises to country vistas to the Empire State Plaza's performing arts center known as the Egg, above.

title: Dr. Amram J. Cohen, 47; Provided Heart Surgery to Poor Children
description: Amram J. Cohen, a heart surgeon who built a program that brought hundreds of children from developing countries to Israel for lifesaving cardiac operations, died on Aug. 16 while climbing Mount Kilimanjaro in Tanzania. He was 47.

title: S.E.C. Rejects Rule for Online Folios
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission denied a request by the $7 trillion mutual fund industry to regulate as traditional mutual funds some online services that let individuals create their own baskets of stocks, known as folios.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Holocaust 'Denial' Poster Is Legal
description: A fund-raising poster for Berlin's Holocaust memorial that sought to attract attention with the words ''The Holocaust never happened'' did not violate laws against hate propaganda, prosecutors said. Smaller print under the slogan made clear that the aim was to denounce denial of the Holocaust, but the Foundation for the Memorial to the Murdered Jews abandoned the campaign after complaints about it. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Selling a New Armed Forces
description: Since the Vietnam War, the American defense debate could be characterized as Republicans wanting more of the same (tanks, ships and planes) and Democrats wanting less. There were some important differences between the parties over questions of intervention and strategy, peacekeeping and war fighting, but when it came to military programs and hardware, the political divide was simply a matter of scale.

title: LEVEL 3 BUYS BACK TRANS-ATLANTIC NETWORK FROM VIATEL
description: Level 3 Communications, which is building a global phone and data network, bought back the trans-Atlantic fiber optic network it sold to Viatel Inc. more than a year ago. Viatel, a New York-based seller of phone and data services, sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors in May. As part of the transaction, Level 3 is to release Viatel from $9 million in debt registered with the bankruptcy court and keep all cash payments made under an April 2000 contract, including $94 million paid by Viatel at the end of last year. Level 3, based in Broomfield, Colo., also paid $100,000 in cash. Level 3 now owns half of the fibers on the submarine cable that connects London and New York.

description: A CAR can be restored many times, but it is original only once.

description: To the Editor:

title: Enjoying Upstate Wonders Under the Supervision of a 5-Year-Old
description: A cluster of five stark white towers that dominate the Albany skyline receded behind the treetops as our Dutch Apple cruise boat headed south on the Hudson River. Over the loudspeaker, the captain informed us that one of them, the Corning Tower, at 42 stories, was the tallest building in the state outside of New York City. A white-haired woman in a Yankees cap pointed to one of the towers and said to her friend, ''That's where I renewed my driver's license.''

description: NORTHWEST

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Henson Is Unable to Put Football Behind Him
description: DREW HENSON, the former University of Michigan quarterback, signed a six-year, $17 million contract with the Yankees in March stipulating that he would give up football and focus solely on baseball. So Henson ended up playing for the Columbus Clippers, in a city where the fans' attention is primarily on Ohio State's football team.

title: National Briefing | Plains: Nebraska: Doctor And University Settle
description: A doctor who performs abortions agreed to drop his lawsuit against the University of Nebraska and was reinstated to his volunteer faculty position at the university's medical center in Omaha. The suit by the doctor, LeRoy Carhart, said the reason the university terminated his position last year was pressure from abortion opponents. A spokesman for the university said it had now agreed to pay about $65,000 to cover Dr. Carhart's legal fees. Dr. Carhart, a vocal supporter of abortion rights, earlier led a challenge to the state's ban on an abortion procedure described by opponents as partial birth. As a result of that challenge, the United States Supreme Court overturned the ban last year.

title: Condit on Chandra Levy's Disappearance
description: Following are excerpts from an interview of Representative Gary A. Condit by Connie Chung about the disappearance of Chandra Ann Levy. The interview was shown last night on the ABC News program ''Primetime Thursday'' and was recorded by ABC.

title: Kathleen Freeman, 78, Actress Playing Comic Character Roles
description: Kathleen Freeman, the veteran character actress whose salty comic talents were most recently on display in the current Broadway musical ''The Full Monty,'' died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 78.

title: Metro Briefing
description: NEW YORK

title: Documenting Ordinary Scenes Of South Africa Then and Now
description: David Goldblatt's photographs have borne witness since the late 1940's to life in his native South Africa. More than 150 of his pictures are in a retrospective of the years 1948 to 1999 now at the Axa Gallery.

title: Invoking Marcus Garvey While Looking Ahead
description: The Studio Museum in Harlem, which has had a strong year, rounds out the season with two exhibitions that point toward the future. One is its annual artist-in-residence showcase; the other, ''Red, Black and Green: Loans to and Selections From the Studio Museum Collection,'' is a wish-list version of a new-acquisitions display.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hotels to Be Replaced
description: HOTELS TO BE REPLACED A powerful New Jersey casino development agency plans to spend up to $10 million to buy and raze a stretch of shabby $30-a-night hotels along Route 40, replacing them with a big hotel, an office building or both. Built mostly in the 1950's, these squat roadside motels  with names like Sea Breeze, Hi Ho and Santa Maria  have increasingly become home to low-rolling gamblers, prostitution and illegal drug use. Under a partnership with Egg Harbor Township, the state agency, the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, plans to acquire 27 properties on the north side of the road, known to generations of seashore-bound travelers as the Black Horse Pike, over the next five years and then raze them, assembling enough land for a bigger new development. Not all are motels. Some vacant properties and at least one auto repair shop are among them. (AP)

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET

title: Nothing Settled for Ex-Umps
description: A half-hour telephone conversation yesterday did not resolve the plight of the 22 major league umpires who lost their jobs two years ago.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Temporary Chief For Arts Endowment
description: President Bush, who has not yet nominated a chairman for the National Endowment for the Arts, has selected Robert S. Martin to be acting chairman. Mr. Martin, a former director of the Texas library commission, has already been confirmed by the Senate to head the Institute of Museum and Library Services. He will fill both posts beginning on Oct. 1. William Ivey, current chairman of the endowment, said in April that he would resign at the end of September, eight months before the end of his four-year term.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Missouri: The Budget Takes a Trim
description: Gov. Bob Holden announced that to balance a state budget that took effect in July, he would cut $28.5 million in education and social services spending. The cuts will focus on travel, training and equipment, and will leave hundreds of job vacancies unfilled. The governor has said that to balance the $19 billion budget, he must cut, or withhold at least temporarily, almost $323 million. The cuts in education and social services are a first installment; he is expected to announce reductions of $80 million more next week as a review of 16 state agencies continues. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HALKEDIS, THEODORE
description: HALKEDIS-Theodore. August 21, 2001. Devoted son of the late John and the late Simela Halkedis. Beloved husband of Aristea. Devoted brother of Elpis Kyriazis and Haralambos Halkedis. Loving uncle of Arthur and John Kyriazis, Semele, John and Anne Halkedis. Born in Philadelphia and graduated from Pennsylvania State University and later served in the U.S. Army. He spent his lifetime career in the international shipping industry. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st. St. Thursday, August 23, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Friday, August 24, 12 noon at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, 319 East 74 St. between First and Second Avenues. The family will accept flowers at Frank E. Campbell or contributions to a charity of your choice.

title: Dive to Wrecks, Feel Like One
description: It's an odd pleasure, diving to see shipwrecks. Coral reefs are beautiful, and swimming among schools of brightly colored fish is like being admitted to another world.

title: A Champion of the Police Is Zealous About His Beat
description: DR. THOMAS REPPETTO certainly hadn't journeyed to Lieutenant Petrosino Square in Lower Manhattan for the inspirational view. As he surveyed the forlorn three-hundreth-of-an-acre triangle of asphalt and cement at the junction of Lafayette and Kenmare Streets, he seemed to clench his Dick Tracy jaw in frustration that the Petrosino name could not adorn some greater, well, civic grandeur.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Judge Approves Comdisco Credit
description: Comdisco Inc. won a bankruptcy judge's final approval of a $450 million credit line to provide financing during the Chapter 11 restructuring of the company, which is involved in technology services and Internet investment. The amount was reduced from $600 million because the financial situation of Comdisco, based in Rosemont, Ill., has improved, the company's bankruptcy lawyer said. Comdisco was forced to seek protection from creditors last month after sinking $3 billion into start-ups that failed to repay loans or turn a profit. The company listed $7.52 billion in assets and $6.74 billion in debts in its bankruptcy filing.

title: To the Rescue, With a Heart of Gold and a Colt .22
description: Evil lurks in the hearts of the smartest characters in the century-old melodrama ''No Mother to Guide Her,'' criminals seasoned on the streets of wicked New York City. But in the end baying bloodhounds track them down, and the nave rural upstate people they've robbed, enslaved and subjected to their insatiable lusts triumph over them.

description: Flashback To the Future
