title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: SUNY Board Nomination
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced that he had nominated Gordon R. Gross, a Buffalo lawyer, to the 16-member board of trustees of the State University of New York. If confirmed by the State Senate, Mr. Gross, left, would serve until 2008, replacing Erland E. Kailbourne, who resigned last year. Mr. Gross attended Oberlin College and the State University at Buffalo and graduated from the SUNY Buffalo Law School. He was on one of the governor's judge-screening committees in 1997. He has worked with a variety of nonprofit groups, including St. Mary's School for the Deaf.

title: Lobster Bisque
description: This classic, intensely flavored soup, doesn't even require the use of fresh lobster meat -- instead, it uses the trimmings left over from the lobster butter preparation.

title: To Defend Gold, U.S. Calls Upon Younger Players
description: Lyndsay Wall watched with wide eyes as the veterans skated by her at the beginning of the tryouts for the United States Olympic women's hockey team in Lake Placid last week. ''Everything's so fast,'' she said nervously.

title: Jets Acquire Established Return Man
description: When Santana Moss sustained the knee injury that will shelve him until midseason, the Jets' special-teams coach, Mike Westhoff, who had counted on Moss to inject a spark into a dormant kick-return game, said he would move on to Plan B.

description: Chyd Denny, Judith Iam, Rabbi Ben Zion Levin, Miami, Dec. 17, 2000

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, HY
description: COHEN-Hy. Dear Uncle, remembered always and sorely missed. Irene, Martha and Nick

title: Making Room For DVD and VHS
description: As DVD gains on VHS, some elbowing has broken out between the formats, especially when it comes to old movies. In short, there isn't money or shelf space for everything. More obscure titles that were once distributed routinely, if not profusely, on videocassette are being dropped by studios more interested in developing the biggest and best known older films in DVD special editions that will sell by the bushel at mass outlets like Best Buy and Wal-Mart.

title: Lobster Butter
description: Lobster butter is one of those life-saving ingredients that you're always thrilled to have in the refrigerator or freezer because it transforms the ordinary into the extraordinary. You can use it to spread over fish before broiling (choose a bland fish, like halibut or cod, that needs this enhancement) or, on just about any cooked fish -- place a dab of the butter on the center of the serving to add panache. It's also great for enriching a sauce, perhaps after deglazing.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Kidnapped Businessman Freed
description: A Lebanese businessman abducted by armed men in Tbilisi on June 7 has been freed by his kidnappers. Charbel Aoun, 33, was confined to a bed and forced to wear a mask during his imprisonment and underwent simulated killings, his employer, Fady O. Asly, said. Mr. Aoun's photograph was posted on 50 billboards in Tbilisi, the capital, in an unusual campaign by Mr. Asly to press the Georgian authorities to obtain his release.

title: AUSTRIAN DRUG COMPANY WINS APPROVAL FOR FACTORY
description: Sanochemia Pharmazeutika of Austria has won American regulatory approval for a factory that produces galantamine, a chemical used in Reminyl, a treatment for Alzheimer's disease. The company's shares rose 11 percent. Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., and the Shire Pharmaceuticals Group of Britain already have Food and Drug Administration approval to sell Reminyl. Sanochemia is the exclusive supplier of galantamine. Reminyl may have peak annual revenue of $650 million, according to analyst estimates. Sanochemia, based in Vienna, has said Reminyl may be used to treat other diseases, lifting sales.

title: Car Insurance Rules for Accident Claims Will Become Stricter on Sept. 1
description: Stricter no-fault auto insurance regulations that the Pataki administration says are needed to fight fraud are to go into effect in New York State on Sept. 1. They will sharply reduce the time limit for accident victims to notify insurance companies and for doctors to seek payment for treatment.

title: The Legacy Of Jesse Helms
description: To the Editor:

title: N.H.L. Officials Reach a Deal
description: The National Hockey League and its officials association have reached a tentative agreement on a new four-year contract.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Drug Trafficker
description: Federal authorities said they had arrested a long-sought Columbian cocaine trafficker, Gino Brunetti, in the Mexican resort city of Cancn. They cited the arrest as an example of deepening cooperation between Mexican and United States drug-enforcement officials. A United States official described Mr. Brunetti as ''a key lieutenant'' in the Arellano Flix drug organization, which is reputed to be Mexico's most violent cocaine cartel. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Introduction
description: In Western cultures, at least, few modern home cooks ever get very close to food while it's still a living, breathing thing. To that, most of us would say, amen. But the lobster is the single common exception. We buy it live because of its propensity to decompose rapidly when it's dead. And we have to steel ourselves to do the deed ourselves. Few of us would force ourselves to endure that ordeal if the food itself were anything but transcendent, sweet, moist, almost unmatched in its succulence.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press yesterday about tests for colon cancer misstated the age at which medical guidelines suggest that a person with no family history of colon cancer first undergo a colonoscopy. It is age 50, not 60.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose amid speculation that companies were bringing home overseas earnings before the end of Japan's fiscal first half on Sept. 30. In New York, the dollar settled at 119.79 yen, down from 120.45.

title: 2 Big Booksellers' Results Beat Wall St. Expectations
description: Barnes & Noble, the nation's largest bookstore chain, posted fiscal second-quarter results yesterday that easily surpassed Wall Street expectations. The second-largest chain, Borders Group, modestly topped forecasts.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 6 about a speech by Ralph Nader in Portland, Ore., misstated the number of states in which his name did not appear on the 2000 presidential ballot and the number that did not record any votes for him. He was not on the ballot in seven states, not five. States that recorded no votes for him though he could have received write-in votes numbered three, not five.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: New Welfare Report
description: A new report on the city's welfare policy contends that welfare changes have resulted in rising hunger and homelessness among the city's poorest residents. The report, by the City Bar Association, noted that the public assistance rolls dropped about 45 percent from the 1995 level to 497,113 in July. But rising requests for emergency food and growing numbers of homeless people in the city's shelters point to worsening conditions for the poor, the report said. The group recommends that the next mayor start a policy of paying workfare participants enough to lift them out of poverty.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Automobiles section last Friday about automakers' efforts to reach gay consumers misstated the location of Moon City Productions, an advertising agency that created a Subaru campaign. It is New York City, not San Francisco.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank's Profit Is Up
description: A leading Canadian bank, Toronto-Dominion, said its profit rose 20 percent in its fiscal third quarter on an increase in lending and securities trading and lower tax payments. The bank, Canada's No. 2 bank by assets, lent more, increased trading at its securities business, and paid less tax. Profit rose to 321 million Canadian dollars ($208 million), or 51 cents a share, from 267 million Canadian dollars, or 42 cents, a year earlier. Revenue rose 3.4 percent to 2.68 billion Canadian dollars from 2.59 billion.

title: WORKERS STRIKE AT MITSUBISHI PLANT IN ILLINOIS
description: Auto workers at the Mitsubishi Motor Company plant in Normal, Ill., went on strike yesterday after failing to come to an agreement with the company over wages. The 2,700 members of the United Automobile Workers union at the plant walked off their jobs after the current agreement expired at midnight Thursday. The sides have been negotiating since June 20. The factory builds Galant sedans and Eclipse coupes for Mitsubishi and Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Sebring coupes for DaimlerChrysler. Analysts said that if the strike was not settled in weeks, Mitsubishi could run low on autos.

title: Stocks Surge After Cisco Says Business Is Stabilizing
description: Stocks soared yesterday with technology issues leading the way after the computer networking giant Cisco Systems said it saw signs that its business was stabilizing.

title: Brosius Won't Be Back Soon
description: The Yankees hoped that third baseman Scott Brosius' broken hand would heal quickly and that he could rejoin the team by the first days of September. But General Manager Brian Cashman said today that a more realistic timetable would have Brosius rejoining the club by Sept. 15.

title: Campaign Briefing | Public Advocate Race: Who Did Not Invite Her?
description: Viewers who tuned into NY1 Thursday to see a face-off among the Democrats running for public advocate may have noticed that one, Sheila Flaxman, was not there. The night before, at the first debate required of participants in the campaign finance program, cosponsored by WNYC radio, all seven candidates were invited and all showed up. But at NY1, said Claire Brinberg, executive producer of political news, they wanted to limit the group to ''leading contenders,'' a category that left Ms. Flaxman out because of her lack of financing and campaign staff. But Ms. Flaxman, who said she was disappointed, did not go entirely unacknowledged. As the debate wound to a close, Norman Siegel, the civil liberties attorney, cried out, twice, ''You should have had Sheila Flaxman.''

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Setback For Sampo
description: Sampo, Finland's largest insurer, suffered a setback in its $2.3 billion bid for its Norwegian rival Storebrand, when Norwegian regulators refused to lift a rule that requires financial companies to acquire more than 90 percent of a target's outstanding stock. Only 86.3 percent of Storebrand investors have turned over their shares to Sampo, not enough to secure a deal under the requirements. The Norwegian government was widely expected to enforce the rule, in part because it did not want the country's largest insurer to fall into foreign ownership. Den Norske Bank, Norway's largest bank, has hindered the deal by refusing to sell its almost 10 percent stake in Storebrand to Sampo. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Jews in Hebron Only Wish That the Army Would Stay
description: If grades were handed out, Israeli soldiers would have received maybe a B-minus today from the small community of Jewish settlers who are shielded by the army in this city of faith and pain.

She was deeply loved by friends and family, and will be greatly missed by all who knew her. He has a horse named Volponi running in the $1 million Travers Stakes Saturday and a brush with cancer behind him. But first he wants to talk about some of the people and animals that have made for a rich life.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Test Flight For Concorde
description: Air France took a Concorde jet for a test flight for the first time since one crashed into a hotel shortly after takeoff on July 25, 2000, killing 113 people. A burst tire was blamed. To prevent similar accidents, the plane now has tougher tires and Kevlar-lined fuel tanks. The test plane broke the sound barrier on a two-and-a-half-hour flight over the Atlantic, but did not reach its Mach 2 cruising speed. British Airways has already tested some of its rebuilt planes. Concordes may return to service late this month. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: After Years, Much of the 'Gunks' Is Protected
description: They're not as grand as the Adirondacks, as historic as the Catskills or as easily pronounced as either one, but the Shawangunk Mountains are increasingly getting attention from environmentalists intent on turning these stark white cliffs 80 miles northwest of New York City into a protected wilderness area.

title: Campaign Briefing | Voting: Seeing A Scandal In Worker Switch
description: Bronx voters in northern reaches of the borough may notice on Primary Day that many of the neighborhood regulars who for years have directed them to voting machines are missing. That has some Riverdale political activists charging that a conspiracy is afoot. The controversy involves more than 150 poll workers assigned to Riverdale, Woodlawn, Van Cortlandt Village and Kingsbridge. The Board of Elections this year did not reappoint most of the workers who had been nominated by local Democratic leaders. State Assemblyman Jeffrey Dinowtiz, a Democrat from the neighborhood, charged the change was an effort to retaliate against him and a local political club that went against Bronx party leaders by backing Public Advocate Mark Green for mayor and City Councilwoman June M. Eisland for borough president. Roberto Ramirez, the of the Bronx party chairman is backing Fernando Ferrer for mayor and City Councilman Adolfo Carrion Jr. as borough president. Mr. Dinowitz predicted the new workers, most of whom are not local residents, would process voters more slowly. ''It is part of an effort by Roberto Ramirez to suppress the vote in certain communities, which they believe will not vote for their candidates such as Carrion, Ferrer,'' Mr. Dinowitz said. Mr. Ramirez dismissed the charge, saying that the Board of Elections decided to change the workers and that the new poll workers were qualified.

description: Bob Williams, who had been a New York Post television columnist for 21 years, died on Monday at St. Vincent's Manhattan Hospital. He was 86 and lived in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.

description: Even the Mets arrived at Shea Stadium last night expecting to see home runs. Barry Bonds is here, one player kidded a clubhouse attendant before the game. You ought to move the cars.

title: New York Yearns For an Institution Of Historic Proportions
description: ''History tends to be down there at the nerd end of things,'' said Ric Burns, the director of a 12-hour documentary on New York City. Compared with, say, the city's museums and theaters, parks and restaurants, music and dance, New York's history has been about as popular as the high school chess club.

title: Worried Scientists Are Told Ample Stem Cell Lines Exist
description: Administration officials took pains yesterday to emphasize the wide opening given by President Bush for government-financed research on human embryonic stem cells, and to quell the fears emerging among scientists of various obstacles in their path.

title: Understated Elegance Spiced With Surprises
description: The pianist Emanuel Ax is an elegant Mozart player, as he showed again on Tuesday night in a performance of Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 22 in E flat with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall. There was a wonderfully understated beauty to his playing, with its impressive fluidity and soft-spoken grace. Given the size of the hall and the subtlety of Mr. Ax's playing, the effect might have come across as overly elegant. Mr. Ax prevented this by constantly surprising you with a highlighted inner voice, or an unexpected emphasis on some quick harmonic turn. It was especially fun to hear him give playful nudges to a series of off-beat notes in a rollicking episode of the final Rondo.

title: Trapped in a Body at War With Itself
description: Jerusalem's main intersection has existed for more than a century, and generally it elicits wonder because of its simplicity, which borders on shabbiness. Its two rows of ancient, outdated stone buildings are plastered with huge billboards. The X-shaped crosswalk painted in the middle is the city's heart. There is no child in Jerusalem who does not know it, and for many it is one of the quotidian symbols of civilian Jerusalem -- if you've crossed the street there, if you've gotten mixed up, as everyone does, in the face of the flow of people coming at you, you're a native.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Hotel Company Faces New Bias Suit
description: A year after agreeing to pay $1.08 million to settle an employment bias lawsuit for firing a group of bellhops, mostly nonwhites, at the Mondrian hotel in Los Angeles, Ian Schrager Hotels has been sued by a valet company in San Francisco, which contends that its contract was terminated because of race. In a lawsuit filed in San Francisco Superior Court, the Ethiopian-born owners of the Royal Valet Parking Company say they were told that their predominantly African-American and Asian employees did not fit the ''image'' of the hotelier at its Clift Hotel in San Francisco. A representative of the hotelier denied the claim. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

title: It's a Friendly Rivalry, But There's Work to Do

title: Children and the Demons of Pop Culture
description: Is ''Sex and the City'' a tart and playful romp through the singles scene of New York or an offensive piece of prurience that promotes promiscuity? Is ''Lethal Weapon 4'' a harmless exercise in fantasy violence or a goad to aggressiveness and hyperactivity in kids? The debate over the effect of popular culture on children, and what to do about it, continues, but breaking through the usual rhetoric seems as elusive as ever.

title: TRIBUNE AND KNIGHT RIDDER TO EXPAND JOBS VENTURE
description: The Tribune Company and Knight Ridder, two newspaper publishers, agreed to buy the online job service HeadHunter.net Inc. for $200 million to expand their CareerBuilder recruitment joint venture. The companies will pay $9.25 a share for HeadHunter.net, which is based in Atlanta. The price was 33 percent more than the closing price for HeadHunter on Wednesday. Tribune, publisher of The Chicago Tribune and The Los Angeles Times, and Knight Ridder, publisher of The Philadelphia Inquirer, will each pay half of the purchase price, the companies said in a statement. The publishers plan to add the CareerBuilder brand to newspapers.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Whitman Lobbies For Nominee
description: In response to mounting questions in the Senate, Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has begun a public lobbying campaign on behalf of Donald Schregardus, President Bush's nominee to be the agency's top enforcement officer. In a letter, Ms. Whitman cautioned senators not to be misled by the ''raw numbers'' presented by environmental groups contending that Mr. Schregardus was lax in enforcing environmental laws in Ohio, where he directed the state's environmental office. title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Sorry, Right Number
description: The telephone message at the Madison Avenue offices of Hank Morris, the consultant to Alan G. Hevesi, has been changed in a way that reflects the unusual dual-nature that Mr. Morris's suite of offices serves. ''You have reached Morris, Carrick & Guma -- and the Hevesi campaign,'' the recorded voice says. Unlike the other Democratic candidates Mr. Hevesi has as a cost-saving measure not opened campaign headquarters. He is paying Mr. Morris' firm some money for the use of some of the space there, which has irritated his more freer-spending opponents. Mr. Hevesi's spokesman, Josh Isay, from his office in Mr. Morris's suite, said that the message had been changed ''a few weeks ago.'' He declined further comment.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Power Plants Purchased
description: Seeking to expand further into the electric power business, Centrica, a British gas and home services supplier, paid $250 million to buy two power stations in eastern England, the company said. The plants, which were bought from the TXU Corporation of Dallas, have a combined generating capacity of 705 megawatts. TXU said the sale brought to about $1.4 billion its proceeds from selling plants. Centrica, which bought a 60 percent stake in a 1,260-megawatt power station in northern England in May, said the latest acquisition meant it could supply power from its own generators to 30 percent of its 4.5 million electricity customers. It plans to increase the number of its electricity customers to seven million. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, JOHN T. JR.
description: HARRISON-John T. Jr., died of a stroke August 22nd at his home in Essex, Connecticut. He was 89 years old. Born in Corona, Long Island, he was a resident of New York City for most of his life. He attended the Allen Stevenson School, graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., in 1931 and from Yale University in 1935. After training for two years with the Insurance Company of North America, he entered his father's firm of Flynn, Harrison and Conroy, Insurance Brokers, where he remained until he joined the Navy in 1942 as a commissioned officer rising to the rank of Lieutenant Commander. After the War, he resumed his career as an insurance broker, becoming a general partner of Flynn, Harrison and Conroy in 1952. He served as Director of the Insurance Brokers Association of the State of New York from 1955 to 1974 and was President of the Association from 1962 to 1964. He also was Treasurer of the National Association of Insurance Brokers from 1959 until 1966. Following the merger of his firm with Marsh and McLennan in 1966, he was appointed Vice President of that company where he remained until his retirement in 1974. He was a member of the vestry of the Church of the Heavenly Rest and President of the Heavenly Rest Day School. He was also a Trustee of St. John's College in Annapolis, Maryland, and Santa Fe, New Mexico. In 1980, he became a Trustee of the Bennington Museum in Bennington, Vermont, and he subsequently served as Chairman of the Museum's Board of Trustees from 1990-1993. He is survived by Patricia Wood, his wife of sixty-three years, and four children, Frederick Wood Harrison, Virginia Harrison Berstene, John T. Harrison, III, and Daniel Hall Harrison. He was a loving and kind husband and father, as well as a devoted grandfather of six. His funeral service will be held at St. James Church, Arlington, Vermont, on August 26th at 3 o'clock. In lieu of flowers his family encourages a contribution in his memory to the Bennington Museum.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Explosives And Basques Seized
description: The police arrested six suspected Basque separatists in Catalonia and seized 550 pounds of stolen explosives. In addition to the explosives, the police said they seized firearms, false license plates and electronic detonating equipment in a number of apartments in Barcelona. Elizabeth Nash (NYT)

title: CENDANT PREDICTS MARKETING DEAL WILL HELP NEXT YEAR
description: The Cendant Corporation said yesterday that it expected its 2002 earnings to benefit from a marketing agreement between its Trilegiant Corporation affiliate and the America Online unit of AOL Time Warner. In early July, the former management of Cendant's membership services and loyalty units formed Trilegiant. Cendant bought $20 million in preferred shares, equal to a 20 percent equity stake, and committed $100 million in cash for marketing. As part of a 40-year agreement, Cendant will outsource its membership business to Trilegiant, in return for 5 percent of the affiliate's revenue beginning in the third quarter of 2002.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Campaign Financing Delay
description: Candidates for state office have yet to receive any of the $23 million set aside for the state's new campaign financing law, and an interim state budget will only extend their wait. Candidates who meet the law's fund-raising and spending restrictions were supposed to be eligible for matching public money on Aug. 1, but the Legislature continues to argue over how the law should be administered. Some legislators threatened to shut down the state government by holding up the emergency budget if it did not include the campaign financing, but relented to get the overdue budget passed. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: New Rainbows In Gas
description: The largest oil producer in Russia, Lukoil, said yesterday that it planned to put red and blue dyes into the gasoline it produces to fight bootleggers who sell low-quality fuel under the company's trademark, Bloomberg News reported. As Lukoil moves to international quality standards for its gasoline, it is trying to stamp out illegal sales under its brand name. The company has already begun experimenting with dyed fuel in the Volgograd and Perm regions. Sales from those regions rose one-fifth after Lukoil began dyeing the fuel it markets there. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Did She Or Didn't She?
description: In a scramble earlier this week, the mayoral campaigns of both Alan G. Hevesi and Fernando Ferrer claimed that Diane Gordon, an assemblywoman from Brooklyn, had endorsed them. On Thursday, Mr. Ferrer issued a news release trumpeting Ms. Gordon's support and quoting her as saying that he was ''uniquely qualified to lead our city.'' But Ms. Gordon did not attend Mr. Ferrer's City Hall news conference announcing the endorsement. By early evening, aides to Mr. Hevesi were putting out the word that Ms. Gordon had endorsed him. Nathan Bradley, an aide to Ms. Gordon, confirmed that the assemblywoman had previously endorsed Mr. Hevesi. But Mr. Bradley would not say whether Ms. Gordon had been talking with the Ferrer camp about jumping ship. Ms. Gordon did not respond to phone messages.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: 'That Bad Boy Smokes Ya!'
description: In one of Michael R. Bloomberg's latest pitches, he said that he would like to equip police officers with a new generation of stun weapons that would, he believes, reduce injuries and deaths -- and improve relations between residents and the police. But the company brochure for the weapons, known as the Advanced Taser M-26, reads more like a trailer for a Rambo movie than a primer for community outreach. It includes a photograph of a man identified as a former instructor in hand-to-hand combat for the Marines. ''I have been hit by hand grenades yet still completed my mission,'' the man says. ''The Advanced Taser is the only thing that has ever stopped me.'' In another testimonial, a police officer from Arizona marvels, ''It just takes your legs out. It's like a jackhammer going kaboom, kaboom, kaboom!'' And a man identified as a corporal with the Dickson County sheriff in Tennessee says, ''That bad boy smokes ya!''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEFFERNAN, MIRIAM MARGARET, PH.D.
description: HEFFERNAN-Miriam Margaret, Ph.D.. Age 89, of Manhattan, on August 23, 2001 after a long illness. Dear daughter of the late John J. & the late Mary (nee Daly), loving sister of Dorothy (Heffernan) McVeigh of Valatie, New York (formerly of Brooklyn), the late John J. Heffernan, Jr., the late William Heffernan and the late Anne Heffernan (Sr. Mary Jean, O.P.). Devoted aunt of Andrew P. McVeigh of Barrington, IL and John J. McVeigh of Columbia, MD. Grand-aunt of Sean P. McVeigh of Columbia, MD & Doreen, Caitlin and Drew McVeigh of Barrington, IL. Caring niece of the late Sr. Miriam Margaret S.C. and the late Anna McCrae. Dr. Heffernan was retired after many years of distinguished scholarship as a Professor of English Literature at Brooklyn College of the City University of New York. Dr. Heffernan received her undergraduate training at Brooklyn College and completed graduate study at Columbia University and New York University. She returned to Brooklyn College as an instructor and spent her career in service to the institution and its undergraduate and graduate students, receiving numerous awards for teaching & research in the field of American Studies. Born and raised in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn, Dr. Heffernan was a longtime resident of Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan. Visitation will be held at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St., NY, NY (212532-6579) from 2-5PM and 7-9PM on Saturday & Sunday, Aug. 25th & 26th. A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated at Immaculate Conception R.C. Church, 414 E. 14th St., Monday, Aug. 27th at 10AM. Mass will be followed by interment services at St. John's Cemetery in Middle Village, Queens, NY. Dr. Heffernan was a loving family member, a devoted friend, and a kind and caring teacher. Her loss will be deeply felt by her family and all others who knew her.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Meeting With Energy Company
description: Executives from the Russian natural gas company Gazprom met in Moscow today with a delegation from China's largest oil company, the China National Petroleum Corporation, to discuss cooperation in developing natural gas fields in China. Gazprom's new chief executive, Alexei Miller, left, and Chen Geng, vice president of China National Petroleum, also discussed the construction of a pipeline and supplying Russian natural gas to China. The Chinese delegation will meet next with Gazprom executives in St. Petersburg, as well as in the Siberian cities of Tomsk and Irkutsk. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

description: The South African Reserve Bank governor, Tito Mboweni, who has been outspoken in his criticism of Zimbabwe, lashed out again at the government of President Robert Mugabe. Mr. Mboweni, who has watched South Africa's currency slide as the situation in neighboring Zimbabwe worsened, said the country's problems must be resolved in an orderly, legal way. He criticized a leader of a small South African opposition party who expressed support for the chaotic land reform undertaken by Zimbabwe.

title: FLEETBOSTON ARRANGES $6 BILLION LOAN FOR FINOVA GROUP
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation said it had arranged the biggest-ever securitized loan, $6 billion to be used by the Finova Group, a commercial lender that came out of bankruptcy court this week. FleetBoston arranged the financing for Berkshire Hathaway, controlled by Warren E. Buffett, and Leucadia National, which formed a joint venture to lend Finova money to pay off its creditors. FleetBoston and 17 other banks are selling commercial paper to investors and providing backup lines of credit. FleetBoston said the arrangement got more commitments and better pricing because the commercial paper is backed by the assets of Finova and is guaranteed by Berkshire Hathaway. The GE Capital Corporation and the Goldman, Sachs Group together also proposed financing, then lost a bidding war to Mr. Buffett, the billionaire investor, and Leucadia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, HOWARD B.
description: DEAN-Howard B. Died August 23rd in Southampton Hospital of respiratory failure. He was 80 years of age and a resident of East Hampton, New York. Mr. Dean attended the Browning School in New York City, Pomfret School and Yale University. During World War II, he served with Pan Am Africa and the Chinese National Aviation Corp AVG in India and China. He received commendations from the Chinese National Government and the United States Air Force for his service in the Asia Pacific Theatre. An active member of the Wall Street community for forty years, Mr. Dean was a partner at Harris Upham before becoming a Senior Vice President of Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc. He served on the Board of Governors of the Investment Bankers Association, the American Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. He was a member of the Vestry of St. Luke's Church, East Hampton, New York, and served for a number of years as Senior Warden. He served as a member of the Board of Trustees of Browning School, of Pomfret School and as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. George's School, Newport, Rhode Island. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Hospital for Special Surgery and the Freedom Institute, both of New York City. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Andree Maitland Dean, three sons, Howard B. M.D. (Judy) Governor of Vermont, James H. (Virginia) of Fairfield, Connecticut, and William G. (Beth) of Dover, Mass. and ten grandchildren; two sisters, Marianne Hill of Cold Spring Harbor, New York and Nancy Felch and her husband, William C. Felch M.D. of Carmel, California. He was pre-deceased by a son Charles, who died in Laos in 1974. Above all, his memory is defined by his friendship, humanity, integrity, and humor which will be missed by all of us. Funeral Services will be held on Thursday, August 30th, 2001 at 11 A.M. at St. Luke's Church, James Lane, East Hampton, NY 11937. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Luke's Church Endowment Fund.

title: Corrections

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the author Peter Maas yesterday omitted the cause of his death and the names of his survivors. Mr. Maas died of complications after surgery for an ulcer, said his son John-Michael Maas. The author is also survived by his wife, Suzanne, and their son, Terrence. Mr. Maas was married twice before -- to Audrey Gellen, who died in 1975, and to Laura Parkins, from whom he was divorced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASHLEY, JANE MORSE
description: LASHLEY-Jane Morse. We mourn the passing of Jane Morse Lashley, the mother of our esteemed partner, David W. Morse. She was a gifted and dedicated educator who began her forty-five year career as an elementery school teacher and recently retired as the Chair, Department of Education at Cameron University. Her devotion to church included teaching Sunday school & service as a choir member and soloist, and lay leader. In 1956, she married the Rev. Don G. Morse, last of New York City, NY, now deceased and in 1984 married Dr. F.J. Lashley of Walters, OK. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Lashley, David, his wife Catharine W. Trimble, their children, Colin, Sean, and their families. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Consolidation Of Wireless Units
description: The J-Phone Group, the third-largest mobile carrier in Japan, said it would abandon its holding company framework and merge its three regional companies into one entity to compete better with its powerful domestic rival NTT DoCoMo. The new company will be called the J-Phone Company. Japan Telecom, a long-distance phone carrier, will own 45.1 percent, and Vodafone will own 39.7 percent. J-Phone has 10.7 million cellular subscribers and a 17 percent share of the domestic market. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Thomas Coughlin, 63, a Chief Of Prisons in New York State
description: Thomas A. Coughlin, a former state trooper who modernized New York State's mental retardation and prison systems, died on Thursday at a hospital in Syracuse. He was 63.

title: Singer With Many Voices Uses Dramatic Tableaux
description: Cabaret music in America -- and that now includes a lot of what's called ''world music'' these days -- caters to the specifications of its audience members, who want to be momentarily tickled by high-minded earthiness and then get on with their busy lives. Performers have to satisfy this particular position of urbanity precisely; if they're too messy-bohemian or too broadly commercial, they've come to the wrong party.

title: Latin Bands Cook a Stew of Spicy Alternatives
description: Odd things happen when rock crosses borders. Old styles find new fans; established meanings get twisted; unlikely hybrids emerge. Those effects and more were conspicuous at the third annual Watcha Tour, a six-hour, eight-band showcase of Latin rock that came to Hammerstein Ballroom on Wednesday night. Its zealous, Spanish-speaking audience was equally ready to sing along, squeal for rock idols and plunge into mosh pits. And despite national loyalties, everyone cheered when musicians shouted, ''Viva la raza Latinoamericana.''

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: New Voter In State
description: In the clearest sign yet that she intends to run for the Senate in her native state, North Carolina, Elizabeth Dole registered to vote in Salisbury, where she was reared and where her mother still lives. Mrs. Dole, a former Republican presidential candidate, said she would decide ''soon after Labor Day'' whether to run for the seat being vacated by Senator Jesse Helms. On Thursday, Mrs. Dole terminated her voter registration in Kansas, the home state of her husband, former Senator Bob Dole. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Op-Art
Court Won't Suppress Statement in Bombing
description: A federal court ruled yesterday that a man who has been charged in the conspiracy to bomb two United States Embassies in East Africa in 1998 could not suppress statements that he made to German and American officials while being questioned in Germany in September 1998.

title: Bronx Team Out to Prove It's the Real Deal
description: The boys stepped up to home plate on the dirt diamond in the small Dominican town of Moca, broomsticks in their hands. But the pitches came so fast that many of them flinched and jumped back. The objects burst out of 9-year-old Danny Almonte's left hand like satellites flung out of orbit. He threw ragged baseballs, or tiny metal rings stripped off milk bottles, or whatever could be scavenged.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: STAR GAS PARTNERS, Stamford, Conn., the largest distributor of home heating oil, bought the ProvEnergy Oil unit of Southern Union Co., Austin, Tex., a producer of natural gas. ProvEnergy has 15,000 customers in Rhode Island and Massachusetts. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Bonds's Focus Is on a Ring. So He Says.
description: In his first few years with the San Francisco Giants, Barry Bonds waxed poetic about playing at home with the only team he ever really wanted to play for. He would conveniently forget that if the Boston Red Sox had said yes to his agent's request for a seven-year contract for about $50 million, he would have signed with them in December 1992, and not the Giants.

title: India-U.S. Fight on Basmati Rice Is Mostly Settled
description: A Texas company's attempt to patent a type of basmati rice became a touchstone for anti-globalization protest in the 1990's. But the long-simmering issue was largely settled this week, when the United States granted a narrower patent to the company, Ricetec of Alvin, Tex.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: New Zealand: Winery Pursuit Dropped
description: Australia's second-largest brewer, Lion Nathan, has abandoned a yearlong struggle to buy the Montana Group, one of New Zealand's largest wine companies. Lion Nathan will sell its 43 percent stake in Montana to Allied Domecq of Britain, which has been competing for control of the winery. Topping Allied's bid of 4.80 New Zealand dollars a share ($2.12) would have been too expensive, Gordon Cairns, Lion Nathan's chief, said yesterday. After the transaction, Allied will hold 70 percent of Montana, and Lion Nathan will make 127 million New Zealand dollars ($56.2 million) on the sale of its stake. Lion Nathan has identified other opportunities in the wine business, Mr. Cairns said. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

To cover the payment, FirstEnergy plans to cut as many as 225 nonunion jobs in New Jersey within a year after the $10.7 billion buyout closes, a spokesman, David Poeppelmeier, said. After three months of negotiations, New Jersey regulators and the state's advocate for utility customers agreed to the GPU purchase by FirstEnergy. GPU, based in Morristown, N.J., has spent $368 million in the last 18 months buying power at prices higher than it could charge its one million New Jersey customers.

title: PILOTS REJECT PROPOSAL THAT WOULD LIMIT STRIKE RIGHTS
description: Pilots at American Airlines rejected a company contract proposal that would have increased pay as much as 22 percent immediately in exchange for the union's giving up the right to strike. The Allied Pilots Association, which represents more than 11,000 pilots at American, turned down the four-year offer a week before a deadline set by the company. The plan would have provided immediate raises of 15 to 22 percent to match the industry pay leader, Delta Air Lines, before settling other issues. American made the proposal in an attempt to avoid prolonged talks and a possible strike threat from pilots. The carrier estimates that new contracts, including an eventual pilots' accord, may raise American's labor costs $500 million this year and $700 million in 2002.

title: The Rural Life; August Corn
description: A few days ago, at the edge of a desolate mall in the Mohawk Valley, I saw a young Amish woman sitting on the back end of a horseless carriage -- horseless, because the horse was elsewhere. She was selling sweet corn. Everyone is selling sweet corn right now and selling it with an almost touching earnestness, knowing that this is the season of sweet-corn glut. I've come across a few ears and a coffee can lying on a board beside a garden. I've seen children's wagons mounded with dark ears parked on the sidewalk. At some of the bigger roadside stands, it looks as if the proprietors are really selling brown paper bags and using the corn to hold them up. The bags absorb the moisture the corn gives off and collapse while being carried into the house. Everyone says the best way to prepare sweet corn is to remove it from the stalk, husk it on the way to the kitchen and drop it into already boiling water. I get good results if I drive it home, drop it on the lawn when the bag breaks and then prepare it as usual.

title: Campaign Briefing | The Mayoral Race: Who Invited Him?
description: Political forums are usually staid affairs, with the candidates showing their earnestness while often driving the audience toward slumber. A mayoral event Thursday night organized by the National Organization for Women in the East Village was different, and the difference was named Christopher Brodeur. Mr. Brodeur, a Green Party candidate, poked fun at the other candidates and offered suggestions that seemed to come from a college dorm room. Among his ideas: to sell Gracie Mansion and to use undercover agents, posing as criminals, to catch abusive officers. Mr. Brodeur got laughs from the audience and even managed to rankle two of his opponents, who showed flashes of humor themselves. When Mr. Brodeur chided the candidates for posing in photographs that show them reading to children, Alan G. Hevesi, a Democratic candidate, shot back with a smirk, ''I will continue as mayor to read to children.'' And when Mr. Brodeur, who is white, labeled the candidates ''all wealthy white men who don't care about the little people,'' Fernando Ferrer, a Bronx native of Puerto Rican descent, rose, saying, ''I want to thank my friend from the Green Party for the ephiphany-like revelation that I am a wealthy white man.'' That line got the most laughs of all.

title: 'Sunlight at Midnight: St. Petersburg and the Rise of Modern Russia'
description: From the southern tip of lake Ladoga, the largest lake in all of Europe, the Neva River flows forty-one miles west to the sea. As it nears the Finnish Gulf, its fast-moving currents divide into more than a dozen branches, the twistings and turnings of which have carved out an intricate archipelago from the low-lying marshes around them. At the beginning of the eighteenth century these islands numbered over a hundred, but today there are only forty-four, the narrow streams and channels between them having been filled in as a city took shape. None of these islands have any topographical irregularities. There are no hills or outcroppings as in Paris, Athens, Florence, or Rome. No point on the delta stands more than thirty feet above the sea.

The company, Hugo Neu Schnitzer East, a large scrap metal dealer, is contributing $24 million toward the project, and the New Jersey Office of Maritime Resources is paying $20.5 million. The project involves dredging the narrow, two-mile Claremont Channel by Jersey City, now as shallow as 10 feet, to a depth of 34 feet, treating the silt in Jersey City, and shipping it via a newly constructed rail spur to the Bark Camp mine in Penfield, Pa., where officials say it will keep mine acid from being carried by rains into nearby waterways. title: 'Maria Callas: An Intimate Biography'

Mrs Kalogeropoulos's Persian lamb coat hung in the small wardrobe alongside two formal gowns she had brought with her. Packed in the steamer trunk in the hold of the ship were her silver candlesticks, tableware, icons and lace dinner cloths. Litza, as the five-months-pregnant Mrs Kalogeropoulos was familiarly known, was not going to arrive in a foreign land as a poor, dispossessed refugee. Coming to America had been her husband's idea and he had sold all their assets to finance their move before consulting her. Young and headstrong (only twenty-five at the time), she had fought bitterly in an attempt to get him to reverse his decision. George refused and, if she had not been carrying their child, she would have kept Jackie and remained with her family.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: PEOPLE seem to remember three things about ATLANTIC CITY (1980). Susan Sarandon stroking her arms, shoulders and cleavage with lemon juice at her kitchen window. Burt Lanaster's comment ''The Atlantic Ocean was something then.'' And the fact that this very American story, about a resort town in painful transition, was directed by a Frenchman, Louis Malle. Not everyone remembers, however, that it was written by John Guare, before he became a star playwright with ''The House of Blue Leaves'' and ''Six Degrees of Separation.'' Ms. Sarandon plays a young woman from Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, working at a sushi bar at one of the new casinos, attending dealer school and studying French, with a dream of working in Monte Carlo someday. Lancaster, 67 and white-haired, plays a criminal whose exploits in the old days weren't nearly as glamorous as he pretends. Gun in hand, he finally does something he always dreamed of - Saturday at 2 p.m. on Channel 9.

title: August 19-25; Lead Study Under Review
description: Johns Hopkins, already under fire for the death of a healthy volunteer in an asthma study, is now under federal investigation for its oversight of another research study, this one using healthy children to test different methods of lead abatement in cheap inner-city rental housing. The Maryland Court of Appeals compared the research to Nazi medical experimentation and the infamous Tuskegee syphilis study -- and reinstated two mothers' lawsuits against Kennedy Krieger Institute, the Hopkins affiliate that conducted the study.

title: After Years of Lows, Football in Oregon Reaches a New High
description: College football in this state has endured many low moments over the last three decades, perhaps none lower than Nov. 19, 1983, when the University of Oregon Ducks and the Oregon State Beavers had their season-ending confrontation. It was, as Irving Howe wrote in ''World of Our Fathers,'' his classic study of Jewish immigrant life, ''pushcart territory,'' a narrow lane teeming with vendors of ''shawls, bananas, oilcloth, garlic, trousers, ill-favored fish, ready-to-wear spectacles.''

title: Who Is Having the Most Input on President Bush's Environmental Policies?
description: Responding loudly, nearly unanimously, and remarkably consistently, readers flooded the response line with the belief that the energy companies and utilities were having far and away the most influence over the Bush administration's environmental policy. The most variety within the hundred and hundreds of outraged readers came from those who argued that the question was invalid because Bush has no environmental policy, either because of his anti-environmental cabinet picks or because of a lack of intellectual ability to create a consistent policy of any type.

title: August 19-25; Big Dealer
description: The United States remained the worldwide weapons dealer of choice last year, especially in developing countries, as international arms sales grew by 8 percent globally to nearly $36.9 billion in 2000. A study by the Congressional Research Service, an arm of the Library of Congress, found that American arms manufacturers signed contracts for just under $18.6 billion, or about half of all weapons sold on the world market in 2000. Third World nations bought 68 percent of the American arms. Other major players were Russia, with $7.7 billion in sales last year; France, with $4.1 billion; Germany, with $1.1 billion; Britain, with $600 million; China, with $400 million; and Italy, with $100 million. Thom Shanker

title: City of Light Loses A Bit of Its Glitter

The good news is that the glittering lights -- never intended to be more than a short-term millennial attraction for the year 2000 -- will be back permanently by early 2003.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-26-01; Hurts So Good
description: All summer long, the daily standings of the major league baseball teams have listed three of the game's oldest franchises -- the Chicago Cubs, the Philadelphia Phillies and the Boston Red Sox -- in or near first place. Yet experience and probability advise that nothing good, like a World Series victory, will come of it. The Cubs, after all, have not triumphed since 1908. The Red Sox last won everything in 1918. And while the Phillies did succeed in 1980, that was thoroughly out of character; the team had never won a World Series before, it has not won one since and in recent years the Phillies have played as everyone who loves the Phillies expects the Phillies to play, which is to say abysmally.

title: There's a Price You Pay for Getting Too Real: Delay
description: I WAS in Australia working on ''The Thin Red Line'' as an actor in August 1997 when I was called with the offer to direct a film titled ''O,'' a modern-day adaptation of Shakespeare's ''Othello'' set in high school. In initially turning the project down, without reading it, I wondered when would it end, this ruining of classic texts by teening them down? There had been the successes, beginning in 1995 with ''Clueless,'' based on Jane Austen's novel ''Emma,'' but many subsequent adaptations of literature typified the film industry's appetite for soullessly copying previous hits. When I finally did agree at least to read ''O,'' I found Brad Kaaya's script as provocative as it was challenging, setting myself (and many others who would work on the film) on the strange journey of making ''O'' and then navigating it toward release.

title: 'Lake Wobegon Summer 1956'
description: Saturday night, June 1956, now the sun going down at 7:50 P.M. and the sprinkler swishing in the front yard of our big green house on Green Street, big drops whapping the begonias and lilacs in front of the screened porch where Daddy and I lie reading. A beautiful lawn, new-mown, extends to our borders with the Stenstroms and Andersons. The dog under the porch scootches down, pressing his groin into the cool dirt. A ball of orange behind the Stenstroms' house, flaming orange shining in the windows, as if the Mr. and Mrs. had spontaneously combusted because of a faulty fuse, a frayed electrical cord, or a box of oily rags in the basement. The shadow of their elm reaches to our porch, a wavery branch flickers across my right arm in gray shade. I wish my cousin Kate would come by. She said she would but it doesn't look like she will. I wrote her a poem:

title: August 19-25; The Amazing Dwindling Surplus
description: Remember the budget surplus? Most of it has melted away, thanks to the weakening economy and President Bush's tax cut. The White House projected that the surplus outside of Social Security has withered to almost nothing for the current fiscal year and several to come. The government is still running big surpluses in Social Security, money that the two parties have reserved to pay down the national debt.

title: Museum Building In the Budapest Style
description: WHEN communism expired in Hungary a dozen years ago, the art world eyed the changes with mixed feelings. On the one hand, a more open society was going to eliminate bureaucratic controls and nurture a dialogue with the West. On the other, it would enable the market to throw art into the hands of profit-hungry dealers and new-rich collectors. The situation has turned out to be more complicated, of course, but strong, independent art institutions are still a rarity. And old habits die hard.

title: August 19-25; Some Way to Treat a Treaty
description: The guessing game about the deadline for the United States to announce its withdrawal from the 1972 ABM Treaty intensified as the Pentagon said it would begin clearing ground in Alaska for the construction of a missile defense base. Meanwhile, John R. Bolton, under secretary of state, told a Moscow interviewer that Washington wanted Russia to agree to modify the treaty soon or else Vladimir V. Putin and Mr. Bush would have nothing to talk about in Crawford, Tex., in November. Mr. Bolton the next day said he had not meant to suggest that was a deadline, though it is clear that if the White House does not want to violate the treaty -- which it says it does not -- it must give six month's notice before digging holes in the tundra. Mr. Bush then weighed in, saying the U.S. would withdraw from the treaty on ''our timetable'' -- but, he added, ''I have no specific timetable in mind.'' Patrick E. Tyler

title: Gravity's Rainbow

Eating wasn't much fun because the food had to clear the several hurdles of swallowing upward, which led to frequent choking.

title: More Doubts About Safety Of Restaurant Site
description: Re ''Unease Over Restaurant Atop Toxic Site'' [Aug. 12], about a plan by Sbarro to open a restaurant at a hazardous waste site in Port Washington: We would like to update you on this extremely important issue. Though the level of perchloroethylene in the air at the former Munsey Cleaners site was under the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation limit of 100 parts per million as of the last sample taken in May, the adjacent store, which shares a basement, was found to have levels exceeding these standards. Even with the Sbarro site in compliance with these state standards this brings new concerns to light. Because an active source of perc is still in place at the site, this may result in the perc going above the acceptable safety limits. Just because a narrow reading of the law may permit commercial use of the site once a final remediation plan is in place, it doesn't mean that approval of a restaurant to open for business makes any sense. This is especially true with this site, which is adjacent to our local public high and middle schools.

title: August 19-25; New Head for Joint Chiefs
description: President Bush knew what he needed when he began searching for a new chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff: someone who can handle the technological complexity of missile defense and the diplomatic complexity of dealing with Asia at a moment when China's military is expanding, Indonesia is in chaos and India and Pakistan are still building nukes. He found his man in Gen. Richard B. Meyers, a soft-spoken fighter pilot during the Vietnam War, former commander of United States Forces in Japan, former head of the Space Command -- and current vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs. The general, a native of Kansas, said not long ago that about once a month he likes to pop back into the pilot's seat and fly something -- not only to stay in practice, but to hear firsthand ''what our men and women are complaining about.''

title: The Low-Cost Way to Battle M.B.A.'s
description: In the race to the corner office, it's tough for ordinary folks to outshine pedigreed people with M.B.A. degrees. But a new book, "M.B.A. Jungle: B-School Survival Guide" (Perseus), offers tips that anyone can use. Everyone knows that it's important to impress the boss, for instance. As guidance, the book lists "Nine Things You've Got to Know About Face Time"  including a warning against mentioning "vacation day" for at least six months, but also advice to take off once you're entitled to show that you can manage your time.

title: Oprah of the Other Side
description: If John Edward is in communication with dead people, why not channel some truly interesting spirits (Chris Ballard, July 29)? Perhaps the descendants of Thomas Jefferson can at last get the real dope on Sally Hemings. Wouldn't Nicole Simpson have something interesting to say about her murder? Or Thomas Edison some new idea he's had during his stay in eternity? But no. Edward's show is about letting a needy daughter know that her dead mother ''loves the new perm.'' Yeech.

title: Marina District Tunnel Is Open in Atlantic City
description: Visitors to Atlantic City can now travel to the city's Marina District and the nearby town of Brigantine using the new extension of the Atlantic City Expressway. After two and a half years of construction, the $330 million project, named the Expressway Connector, includes a 2,200-foot tunnel, along with 10 bridges and 15 ramps. The two-and-a-half-mile route links the former end of the expressway, at the foot of McGann Bridge, with the Marina District, home of the Trump Marina casino and Harrah's, and with the Brigantine Bridge.

title: The Pro-Choice Extremist
description: Before she had a ship, before she had any money for a ship or a nurse to go with the ship or a media representative to handle all the reporters who would want to know what she was doing with the ship, Dr. Rebecca Gomperts had an idea. It was 1997, and she was a 31-year-old abortion doctor based in Amsterdam, and to her, the idea seemed straightforward and reasonable, as so many ideas do before they take on the weight of reality. She wanted to buy a ship and sail it around the world, providing abortions at sea for women who could not otherwise get them. Gomperts, whose activist roots stem from a stint as the resident doctor on Greenpeace's Rainbow Warrior II boat, planned to visit countries where the procedure is either illegal or highly restricted and transport women seeking abortions into international waters, 12 miles offshore. There, a Dutch-registered ship would be subject to Dutch law, and she could legally perform abortions -- something she intended to do free. ''In my trips with Greenpeace, I became aware of the enormous and invisible suffering of women due to illegal abortions,'' Gomperts says. ''To me, this is a basic human rights issue.''

title: Discrimination Accusations Divide a Virginia University

But if the guidebook conjured up one more category for the most polarized institution, Virginia State University would stand a good chance of pocketing the title.

title: Free at Last; The Enduring Legacy of the South's Civil War Victory
description: THE United States is only now beginning to recover from the Confederacy's ideological victory following the Civil War. Though the South lost the battles, for more than a century it attained its goal: that the role of slavery in America's history be thoroughly diminished, even somehow removed as a cause of the war. The reconciliation of North and South required a national repudiation of Reconstruction as ''a disastrous mistake''; a wide-ranging white acceptance of ''Negro inferiority'' and of white supremacy in the South; and a distorted view of slavery as an unfortunate but benign institution that was damaging for whites morally but helped civilize and Christianize ''African savages.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Slackers in Ireland
description: Julian Gough has written a first novel that's full of sardonic yet good-humored riffs. As JUNO & JULIET (Nan A. Talese/Doubleday, $23.95) begins, two sisters from Tipperary, Juno and Juliet Taylor, are trying to cope with their first day at the University of Galway. The young women are identical twins, 18 and beautiful to a fault -- if we are to believe Juliet, the narrator, who sometimes uses descriptions of her sister as a sly way of commenting on herself. (We're told, for example, that Juno's beauty ''refines and upgrades itself constantly.'') Their student life is amply complemented by liquor, drugs and sex; they are also studying English, apparently in moderation. Juno gets her romantic life in order with dispatch. Juliet takes longer, perhaps because for a while she doesn't realize she's in love with her tutor, a young lecturer named David Hennessey. David is ferociously critical of literary theory, but in ridiculing fashionable academics he somehow manages to sound even more pedantic than they are. There is one dark area in this ostensibly carefree narrative: someone is writing obscene and threatening letters to women on campus, including Juno and, later, Juliet. But this malefactor's tragic end, when it finally comes, seems utterly out of place, even to the other characters. As a narrator, Juliet is consistently, agreeably flippant, and from time to time comes across with a truly memorable line. (''Ah, the old make us philosophical. No wonder we avoid them.'') ''Juno & Juliet,'' with all its adolescent ironies, still manages to be intelligent, lighthearted and thoroughly entertaining. William Ferguson

title: From Prisons, Art With Raw Power

While it is uplifting to see the expression of raw feelings, there is always the realization that the art has been made with constrictions that don't hinder artists on the outside. There is also the awareness that what motivates many prisoners to make art is endless time on their hands. These days it's not harsh treatment that epitomizes prison life but instead the tyranny of tedious routine.

title: Don't Mess With Aslan
description: C. S. Lewis was not a man to equate modernity with progress. In ''The Allegory of Love'' (1936), his first work of criticism, he made the case for Edmund Spenser's ''Faerie Queene,'' the 16th-century chivalrous epic, dismissed in Lewis's day as outdated. It was Spenser, he said, not the later Romantics, who shaped our view of marriage as a bond of love -- a notion, he added dyspeptically, that seemed on the verge of being forgotten: ''Feminism in politics . . . and, above all, the discoveries of the psychoanalysts, have undermined that monogamic idealism about sex which served us for three centuries.''

She had not dreamed much in her middle years; or, if she had, the busyness of her days, converging on her the moment she awoke, had pushed her dreams right out of her head, and any fragments that remained were as busy and prosaic as the day itself. She had only the one son, James, but she had also mothered her younger sister after their parents died, and she had done all of the office work during the years when her husband’s small engineering firm was getting on its feet. And Julius’s health had not been too good, even then; it was she who had mowed the lawn and had helped Jamie to learn to ride his bicycle and pitched balls to him in the backyard until he learned to hit them.

title: 'Word Freak'
description: The cops arrive, as they always do, their Aegean blue NYPD cruiser bumping onto the sidewalk and into the northwest corner of Washington Square Park. There are no sirens or flashing lights, but the late- model Buick does emit a staccato bwip-bwip to signal to the public that business is at hand. The drug dealers usually shuffle away, perpetuating the cat-and-mouse game that occurs hourly in this six- acre plot of concrete, grass, dirt, and action in Greenwich Village. The druggies whisper, "Sense, smoke, sense, smoke," as they have for twenty or thirty years, seemingly in tacit agreement with the cops to ply their trade as long as they do it quietly. But now, instead of allowing the dealers to scatter as they normally do, officers in short-sleeved summer uniforms, chests bulging from flak jackets, actually step out of the cruiser, grab a man, and slap on cuffs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOORE, PHILIP WALSH
description: MOORE-Philip Walsh. Died July 18, 2001, of cancer at Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla. Graduated Princeton University Magna Cum Laude in 1942. Enlisted in U.S. Navy 1941 and served as commanding officer of a sub-chaser in both the Atlantic and Pacific. Phi Beta Kappa Junior year, Lyman Biddle Scholar 1942. Captain of undefeated Princeton Tennis Team, selected for Junior and Senior Davis Cup Teams/MBA from New York University 1950. Security analyst at First Boston Corporation, then Assistant to President of Schroeder Rockefeller & Co. Founded First Research Company (Miami/ firm acquired by J & W Seligman Moore). Served as President of Valuation Division of Seligman. In 1996 he was chosen to make the final valuation of the Zapruder film and set the valuation at $16,000,000. Moore was listed in Who's Who in America and Who's Who in Finance and Industry; also served as economic adviser to Florida Governer LeRoy Collins (1956-60) and as economic adviser to Archbishop Coleman Carroll, Diocese of Miami (1959-72). From 1955 to 1960 he served as Honorary Consul to the French Republic in Florida, and was also a member of the Administrative Committee of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts in New York City and was a member of the Downtown Association of New York. He is survived by a daughter, three sons, a sister and his widow Phaedra. He was a member of the Ponte Vedra Club, the Sawgrass Country Club and the River Club of Jacksonville, Florida.

At the end of May, the Ocean County bookstore stocked up with 32 copies of Susanne Antonetta's environmental memoir, ''Body Toxic.'' Then employees waited for what they were sure was to be a storm of protesters and counterprotesters all enraged one way or another at the latest bit of testimony against a New Jersey wasteland. There wasn't one.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay, by Michael Chabon. (Picador USA, $15.) Set during the golden age of the adventure comic book, this carnival ride through American pop culture, which won a Pulitzer Prize, follows the exploits of a young Jewish artist in Brooklyn fresh off the boat from Prague and his cousin, who fulfill their fantasies of liberty and power by creating a superhero named the Escapist. ''The depth of Chabon's thought, his sharp language, his inventiveness and his ambition'' result in ''a novel of towering achievement,'' Ken Kalfus wrote here last year.

title: The Oranging of Summer
description: This summer seems drenched in orange. On Fifth Avenue, in the environs of Tiffany's, complete strangers pass one another in shades of nasturtium and tangerine. Many wearers use orange as an accent for beige and white separates. Others prefer the Halloween contrast with black. In the parade of orange, the T-shirt is the favorite, followed by trousers, shirts, backpacks, caps, shoes, handbags and shawls. A few women are even wearing designer orange for office and evening. Suddenly, the crews digging up the Avenue of the Americas and a polo team and its ponies in the Hamptons are fashion stars.

title: August 19-25; Condit Talks, but Says Little
description: Roughly 30 percent of Americans watching television tuned to ABC to see Representative Gary A. Condit of California acknowledge a ''very close'' five-month relationship with Chandra Ann Levy, 24, a former government intern from his district who has been missing since April. But Mr. Condit declined to tell his interviewer, Connie Chung, whether the relationship was sexual and insisted that he knew nothing about Ms. Levy's unexplained disappearance. In the interview, and in similar words in a letter to his constituents, Mr. Condit said simply: ''I have not been a perfect man.''

title: When the Epicenter of Pop Had a Broadway Address
description: AT my local supermarket, a checkout counter cashier recently welcomed the end of her shift by bursting into a few bars of ''This Magic Moment,'' a song of soaring romance written by Doc Pomus and Mort Shuman that was a hit for the Drifters and then for Jay and the Americans decades before the cashier was born.

title: Haunted Getaway
description: It's a long way to go just for a good fright, but Sea Land Air Travel, of Stayton, Ore., is offering a Haunting Tour of Britain Oct. 24 to Nov. 1 that traces the trail of Jack the Ripper and includes dinner in a haunted house and visits to haunted castles. The price is $2,198 a person, based on double occupancy, and includes five dinners, four nights' accommodations in London, four nights in Edinburgh, daily breakfast and all transfers and taxes; air fare is extra. Call (800) 255-2206. JOSEPH SIANO

title: Clemens Pulls His Weight, and Yanks Tag Along
description: Somewhere along the way, Roger Clemens went from being the hitchhiker on the championship ride to the ox pulling the Yankees behind him. Maybe it was that playoff game in Seattle last year, when he came within a couple of inches of pitching a no-hitter, or when he dominated the Mets in the World Series. Maybe it was when he cajoled Andy Pettitte into working out with him.

title: Boutique Owner
description: Erstwhile downtown shopping grottoes like Calypso and Scoop may have smoothed the edge off their nervy pop style and moved uptown, but Ana Abdul, owner of the SoHo boutique Language, still shuns the chain-store mentality. As the boutique's sole buyer, Ms. Abdul stocks the room as if it were her own closet, making Language that rare shop not dedicated to one designer, thus reflecting a singular eclectic vision. This fall, for both her business and her person, Ms. Abdul leans toward a blend of 60's Continental chic, 80's glam rock and 90's deconstructionism.

title: Susan Balaban, Jared Abrams
description: Susan Joy Balaban, a daughter of Nancy Berke of Chicago and Richard Balaban of Deerfield, Ill., was married on Friday to Jared Abrams, the son of Jeri Hamilton of New York, and the stepson of Robert M. Ruenitz. Cantor Chayim Frenkel officiated at the Los Angeles River Center and Gardens.

Lain Garrett III, the son of Jeanne and Robert L. Garrett Jr. of Vestavia Hills, Ala. The Rev. John Boehning performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Venus Williams Sends a Message In Her Victory Over Davenport
description: Demonstrating that she may be the player to beat when she goes after her second straight title in the United States Open, Venus Williams lost only one service game -- her first -- in beating top-seeded Lindsay Davenport, 7-6 (6), 6-4, today to win the Pilot Pen tournament for the third year in a row.

title: 'The Southern Woman: New and Selected Fiction'
description: Maybeth’s father had a business in the town, which was about a mile from where they lived, but he had about forty acres of land below the house that he planted in cotton and corn. The land was down the hill from the house and it was on two levels of ground: twenty acres, then a bluff covered with oak sprouts and vines, then a lower level, which stretched to the property line at the small creek. You could see it all from the house—the two fields and the creek, and other fields beyond the creek—but from the upper field you could just see as far as the willows along the creek bank.

title: POSTINGS: Former Smalls' Paradise in Harlem; Nightclub Site To Riff Into A School
description: The three-story building at 135th Street and Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Boulevard in Harlem has been vacant since the mid-1980's, but it has had an illustrious past. In the 1920's Smalls' Paradise, as it was named, was widely known as one of Harlem's famous nightclubs -- one with elaborate floor shows and waiters who danced the Charleston while balancing trays of whiskey. In the 1960's the club was owned by the basketball star Wilt Chamberlain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOKOTOFF, MILTON M., HON
description: MOKOTOFF-Milton M., Hon. Age 84, of Sands Point, New York, died on Sunday, August 19. After sixty years of marriage, he remains adored by his wife, Shirley. Beloved father of Tama Bernstein, David Mokotoff, and Elaine Viders. Treasured grandfather of Marne Roskin (Thomas), Alexis and Leah Bernstein, Benjamin and Michael Mokotoff, Jared and Zachary Viders, and great-grandfather of Zoe Rose Roskin. Valued father-in-law to Michael Bernstein, Jay Viders and Susan Mokotoff. Admitted to the New York State and Federal Courts and the United States Supreme Court, Judge Mokotoff graduated from St. John's School of Law and was admitted to the bar in 1941. He was the senior partner of the law firm Mokotoff & Mondshine and was a much sought-after arbitrator and mediator. Beyond the courts, he and his wife taught three generations the importance of living happily. He was an inspiration to all who had the good fortune to know him.

title: Just Can't Stop Dancing, Even In Spare Time
description: A PROFESSIONAL ballet dancer lives a physically gruelling life. A typical day starts around 10 a.m. with a strenuous workout to ensure that technique is kept sharp. Hours of rehearsal follow -- sometimes of several different ballets -- and then often a performance. One would think that when the chance for a break occurs, dancers would gratefully rest their hard-worked bodies.

title: Beefsteak and Beyond
description: The aficionados buzz about the bouquet, the texture, the balance of acidity and sugar, the smooth finish. A wine tasting? This is New Jersey and it's late August: It's a tomato tasting. It will take place Wednesday at the Melda C. Snyder Teaching Garden, part of the Rutgers Snyder Research and Extension Farm in Pittstown, from 6 p.m. until dark. There will be more than 100 varieties of tomato to taste, all grown at the garden and some picked just an hour before the event. Mimi McWold, a coordinator at the garden, recommends the Brandywine, pink, with ''a complexity of taste''; the Costoluto Genovese, with a ''wonderful acid-sweet balance'' and a lobed shape that makes lovely fluted slices; and the ''stunning'' purplish Black, with -- what else? -- a ''winey'' flavor. Admission is free. To provide enough samples, the organizers ask those who will attend to call (908) 713-8980.

title: Battlefield: Space
description: Did anyone else see a connection between the article on space-based warfare and John Tierney's ''Here Come the Alpha Pups''? Seems like Hasbro is priming young boys for the space force described in Hitt's article. It's a bit Orwellian to read about ''destructo swarmbots'' and ''robo-bugs'' in one article and then find that young boys are being trained as fighters in small-scale versions of intergalactic ''viral'' space wars. It certainly seems that the $30 these boys are getting for ''playing a game'' is more like a deposit on their enlistment in a soon-to-be militarized outer space. So much for being the ''cool kids.'' When it comes time to gear up for the Pentagon's ''Full Spectrum Dominance,'' it looks as if they'll once again just be ''test kids.''

title: Woods Breaks His Slump at NEC
description: AKRON, Ohio, Aug.26 - Even Tiger Woods, a man who has won in almost every conceivable fashion, could not have anticipated today's marathon at the NEC Invitational.

title: A Game of Chance, a Chance for Socializing
description: WHEN Susie Cella, 45, packed up her home in San Diego five years ago after her husband, Mike, had accepted a job in New York City, she knew she couldn't pack the one thing she'd really miss: her Bunco group. It was a dozen women with whom she'd played a simple dice game each month, mindlessly rolling while they chatted about family, nursery schools, vacation plans and the PTA.

Unfortunately, that infrastructure is sorely lacking in many areas.

title: The Music of Jerome Kern
description: Jerome Kern left Barringer High School in Newark a month before graduating in 1903. But that did not seem to hurt the career of one of America's greatest popular composers. His songs from ''Showboat'' will be among the classic show tunes the 20-piece Garden State Concert Band will perform at the Preakness Shopping Center in Wayne at 7 p.m Thursday. Some of the songs from ''Showboat'' may have been written while Kern was a student at Barringer, according to his biographers and Pat Restaino, former principal and the historian for the Barringer High School Alumni Association. Mr. Restaino said that Kern wrote for the senior minstrel show, and a description of one of the songs is similar to ''Ol' Man River.'' Margo Nash

title: STUDENT SURVEYS
description: Ridgewood parents can block their children from taking part in surveys on sex and other personal topics, under a policy adopted last week following a controversy over a survey in 1999. A suit by three parents claiming their teenagers' privacy was violated by the survey is pending appeal after it was dismissed in February by a federal judge, who found that because the survey was voluntary and anonymous it was not intrusive. The new policy requires that parents get notice of such surveys, with the option of contacting the district to excuse their children from participating. Steve Strunsky
