description: It looks like money, fits into a wallet like money, and the local government certainly hopes it will be accepted as money.

title: A Lost Generation And Its Exploiters
description: WHEN the writer and director John Singleton made his most recent movie, ''Baby Boy,'' released in June, he set out to take a critical look at those strutting young Los Angeles black men who father children by various women and make little or no effort to support them. And he stepped into what has long been a serious mess. That is because any time one goes down into the more sinister ranges of the Afro-American world, there is the danger that what one finds there can so easily be placed within the dead world of the stereotype. In such a world, characters exist only as lifeless puppets pulled into action for the perpetuation of poisonous myths about the unchanging essence of a purportedly inferior group.

title: The Way We Live Now: 8-26-01: The ethicist; Lawn Scare
description: I live in a suburb where my neighbors take pride in their well-manicured lawns. Having learned about the dangers that pesticides and chemical fertilizers pose to the environment, I believe that allowing my grounds to return to a more natural state is the moral course. My neighbors think I am devaluing the area and have an obligation to follow their customs. Do I? Len Sanders, Parsippany, N.J.

title: In a Nutshell Lies One Firm's Fruit
description: To get to the Cardolite Corporation, you have to navigate this city's manufacturing strip along Doremus Avenue, trundling over railroad tracks, hoping to avoid the misplaced nails and groaning 18 wheelers common to the gritty industrial district.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSSON, GERTRUDE (NEE TEPMAN)
description: ROSSON-Gertrude (nee Tepman). Age 99, in Beverly Hills. Former long time resident of Forest Hills with her husband Gilbert. In later years resided in Florida. With profound sorrow her family mourns her passing. Cherished mother of Ellen and Ronald; terrific mother-in-law of Helene Rosson and Sol Liebster. Devoted grandmother to Wendi and Michael, Marla and Jeff, Bill and Allison, Steven, Cindy and Jake, Brad and Lori. Loving great-grandmother to Joey and Kimberly, Cole, Jenna and Tess, Amy and Julia, Jake. We will all sorely miss her patience, guidance and thoughtfulness. She will live forever in our hearts. We were all so fortunate to have had her for such a long life. She lived through a historical, everchanging century!! Private graveside service in New York. 212-644-9032. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cedars Sinai Hospice Fund, 444 So. San Vicente Blvd, LA, CA 90048.

description: Books for Taking

title: The Sound of Uncertain, Uninspired Grad Students
description: THESE are hard times for young composers and, therefore, in an important sense, hard times for music. Orchestras and other organizations responsible for commissioning new scores are looking more and more to the same few established names, those of people now in their 40's or older. Opportunities like the one John Adams had two decades ago, when, still in his early 30's, he was appointed composer in residence at the San Francisco Symphony, are unlikely to recur soon. Teaching jobs, too, are thin on the ground: colleges and conservatories are eager to attract new composition students but not so encouraging when it comes to providing faculty positions.

title: Holden Reconsidered
description: To the Editor:

title: The Right Way to Fight Forest Fires
description: There has been little positive to say so far about the environmental policies of Interior Secretary Gale Norton and Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman, neither of whom seems to care much about giving this country's natural resources, especially its forests, the protection they need. But both deserve credit for accepting, albeit under some duress, the basic elements of the Clinton administration's strategy for preventing forest fires. Although repackaged as President Bush's own ''10-year plan,'' it is essentially the same sensible approach agreed to by Western governors and Congress in the wake of last summer's disastrous fires, which consumed 6.7 million acres.

title: Political Briefing; In Tennessee, Eyes on the Senate
description: The political buzz in Tennessee is that former Gov. Lamar Alexander, who twice failed to win the Republican presidential nomination, has his eye on the Senate, if the incumbent, Fred Thompson, also a Republican, does not seek re-election next year.

title: Still Working, Boomers 'Retire' to Resorts
description: With their children grown and out of the house, Georgina and Richard Davis faced something of a dilemma. They could have mothballed the empty bedrooms in their rambling Colonial and continued paying the lawn doctor, the pool cleaner and the guy who picked up after their dogs in the yard. Or they could have followed their parents' generation and migrated to a low-maintenance retirement complex in Florida.

title: August 19-25; Boudin Remains Jailed
description: Kathy Boudin, who made headlines in 1981 ago for her part in a politically motivated armed robbery that left a Brink's guard and two policemen dead, was denied parole. A former member of a radical Vietnam-era group, the Weather Underground, Ms. Boudin has spent nearly 20 years in prison for the robbery, which occurred in Rockland County, N.Y. The parole hearing was controversial, with supporters arguing for release while opponents, including Rockland police and politicians, holding a rally to urge that she stay in prison. Robert Worth

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, HOWARD B.
description: DEAN-Howard B. Died August 23rd in Southampton Hospital of respiratory failure. He was 80 years of age and a resident of East Hampton, New York. Mr. Dean attended the Browning School in New York City, Pomfret School and Yale University. During World War II, he served with Pan Am Africa and the Chinese National Aviation Corp AVG in India and China. He received commendations from the Chinese National Government and the United States Air Force for his service in the Asia Pacific Theatre. An active member of the Wall Street community for forty years, Mr. Dean was a partner at Harris Upham before becoming a Senior Vice President of Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc. He served on the Board of Governors of the Investment Bankers Association, the American Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. He was a member of the Vestry of St. Luke's Church, East Hampton, New York, and served for a number of years as Senior Warden. He served as a member of the Board of Trustees of Browning School, of Pomfret School and as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. George's School, Newport, Rhode Island. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Hospital for Special Surgery and the Freedom Institute, both of New York City. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Andree Maitland Dean, three sons, Howard B. M.D. (Judy) Governor of Vermont, James H. (Virginia) of Fairfield, Connecticut, and William G. (Beth) of Dover, Mass. and ten grandchildren; two sisters, Marianne Hill of Cold Spring Harbor, New York and Nancy Felch and her husband, William C. Felch M.D. of Carmel, California. He was pre-deceased by a son Charles, who died in Laos in 1974. Above all, his memory is defined by his friendship, humanity, integrity, and humor which will be missed by all of us. Funeral Services will be held on Thursday, August 30th, 2001 at 11 A.M. at St. Luke's Church, James Lane, East Hampton, NY 11937. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Luke's Church Endowment Fund.

It was the spring of 1966, and the morbid teen death anthem ''Last Kiss'' was always bopping out of my transistor radio. As shy as we were, it probably would have been months before Nancy and I did kiss, but in my preteen mind we were the couple in the song. I imagined not only that Nancy had died in my arms, like the girl in ''Last Kiss,'' mortally wounded after her date crashes his daddy's car, but also that I would die next, if not by the end of spring, surely by midsummer. I wrote Nancy a poem, thinking it would probably be my last. Much to my adolescent, angst-ridden chagrin, however, life went on. And so would death.

Mass will be followed by interment services at St. John's Cemetery in Middle Village, Queens, NY. Dr. Heffernan was a loving family member, a devoted friend, and a kind and caring teacher. Her loss will be deeply felt by her family and all others who knew her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIND, MERI
description: LIND-Meri. Beloved sister, aunt, great-aunt, friend and mentor, died in peace at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. Born in Moscow in 1918, she lived in Berlin and Paris before immigrating to New York in 1938. Following her father's deportation to Auschwitz, she was the driving force in bringing her mother and sister to the United States in 1947. She loved all things beautiful: nature, art, theater, music and dance. Once a professional dancer, she received an MFA from Queens College. She translated the fluid beauty of the body into insights about character, creating a vision called Imageology. Knowing how important self-image can be, especially for those struggling with cancer, she pushed tirelessly for increased use of creative and alternative therapies, especially dance, music and art therapies, to enhance the quality of patients' lives, even as she herself was battling debilitating illness. She was well ahead of her time in recognizing the value of these creative therapies in helping patients. Surviving her are her beloved sister Vera Stern, her six nephews and nieces by birth and marriage, her five great-nephews and great-nieces, and her many friends and students. Both she and her family are grateful to Patricia and Precilla, and all the doctors, nurses and staff on the 12th floor of Memorial Hospital. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Integrative Medicine (1246 2nd Ave, NYC 10021; attn: Dr. J. Holland), where she made her mark and was so well treated. Services will be held this Sunday at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, at 2 PM.

'63, Oxford Doctoral Studies '69-'71; pioneer of the International Baccalaureate program; Director of Santiago College, Santiago, Chile 1964-1968 and 1991-2000, Headmistress of San Silvestre, Lima, Peru 1975-1976, Academic Dean of UN International School, New York, USA 1978-1991. In 1968, she was decorated by the Chilean Government with the Order of Merit ''Bernardo O'Higgins'' of the Comendador Order for her outstanding work in education and its progress in Chile. She was much loved and respected by many throughout the world. She leaves her husband, Ingo, of Forest Hills, New York, USA, and children, Ian and Ophelia. title: 'Spectacular Happiness'
description: Isaw you today on the midday news: a teenage boy, skinny body draped in an oversized Chicago Bulls shirt, eyes shaded by a Swoosh cap, matching red, with brim curved just so. I knew you instantly, before the label was added to the picture, before you spoke. I was struck by an emotion that had more force than direction. It could as easily have been despair as elation. A phrase ran through my mind: already grown. Words that toward the end of his life my father repeated when he caught sight of me. In the midst of disorientation, what abides is wonder at a child's taking adult form.

title: August 19-25; Cole Inquiry Stalled
description: When Islamic militants chose Yemen for their most audacious attack yet on an American target, the suicide bombing of the U.S.S. Cole in Aden last Oct. 12, they chose well. They killed 17 American sailors by catching the United States in a state of political denial, sending Navy ships to re-fuel in a country that the State Department had characterized only months earlier as a ''safe haven'' for terrorists. Now, 10 months on, the inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been stymied. With Yemen's network of militant Islamic groups declared off-limits by Yemen's president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, the bureau's chances slipped further away of proving its ''working theory'' -- that the Cole attack was the latest directed by Osama bin Laden, the Saudi Arabian millionaire who has become an icon among Islamic militants for his ''holy war'' against the United States. John F. Burns

title: 'Year of Wonders: A Novel of the Plague'

The rumble of the apples tumbling into the cellar bins. Smells and sights and sounds that said this year it would be all right: there'd be food and warmth for the babies by the time the snows came. I used to love to walk in the apple orchard at this time of the year, to feel the soft give underfoot when I trod on a fallen fruit. Thick, sweet scents of rotting apple and wet wood. This year, the hay stooks are few and the woodpile scant, and neither matters much to me.

title: In Familiar Corridors, an American Vision of Despair
description: AS a young man in the 1970's, I taught English and drama in a midsize suburban Montreal high school, one of those sprawling, blocky buildings without a single architectural quality to distinguish it from dozens of other schools. One evening, in a fervor to impress a group of parents whose children would be the next crop of freshmen, a vice principal swept through the corridors removing every handmade poster from the walls -- every indication that there was extra-curricular life in the place -- as if it were trash. The next morning I watched this man face a delegation of students who wanted to know why their posters had been ripped down, and what I remember most vividly is his unwavering tone of certainty, his absolute conviction that he had behaved reasonably and in everyone's best interests.

title: French Pop's Witty Rou
description: SPECTACULARLY debauched, scatologically obsessed, ugly, French and dead, Serge Gainsbourg may be the least likely pop star of 2001. When Gainsbourg died a decade ago at the age of 61, few outside France took notice. In the Anglophone world, the news was greeted with a few grudging column inches: obituaries remembered Gainsbourg as a Gallic curio, primarily as the man behind ''Je T'Aime . . . Moi Non Plus,'' a notorious piece of pop pornography that topped the British hit parade in October 1969 and, in a poetic fluke that its creator must have relished, reached the Billboard charts at No. 69.

title: QUICK BITE/Englishtown; From the Orchard to Your Waffle Cone
description: A smiling Dave Folts was touting the latest batch of ice cream: peach, with the main ingredient coming from an orchard only a couple of miles down the road from his Jack Frost Homemade Ice Cream and Luncheonette in Englishtown. It is a Freehold orchard, coincidentally, in which he used to pick strawberries and other fruit when he was 12 years old. The ice cream -- peach and 14 other flavors, including chocolate cake, chocolate nut surprise and rum raisin -- gets top billing on his menus, particularly during the summer. A double scoop is $1.95; three scoops, $2.45. Soft ice cream is a bit less. ''People pass three or four other ice cream places to come here,'' he said, coming to sample hard and soft ice cream and yogurt, plus 12 flavors of Italian ices (which Mr. Folts also wholesales to other places) and sherbet. ''It's all about weekends,'' he explained of the crux of his business. Mr. Folts has owned the 40-year-old unofficial landmark for seven years. It seats 55 at a time, with 12 tables, plus six stools at the counter facing the ''Jack Frost BBQ Pit'' preparing ribs, chicken and hot dogs. Breakfast and hot and cold lunch items also are available in the $3 to $7 range. Mr. Folts and his partner, Vinnie Lanza Jr. -- from whose father Folts bought the business -- have a staff of about 30, mostly teenagers. For the 36-year-old Folts, Jack Frost is more than a business. ''It's my passion.'' he said. Norm Oshrin

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOWENSTEIN, FRANK WOLFGANG, MD, DPH
description: LOWENSTEIN-Frank Wolfgang, MD, DPH, 92. Died Friday, July 6, 2001, in Poughkeepsie, New York, formerly of Berlin, Germany. Son of Ernst Lowenstein, a German Federal Judge in Berlin, and Else Greifenhagen, daughter of Department Store founder Hyman Greifenhagen, Frank was an accomplished pianist who finished his medical studies at the University of Berlin in 1933 and received his Medical Doctorate from the University of Basel, Switzerland. He trained in Silesia and Hamburg where he married Senta Frankel. They immigrated to the U.S. in September 1938 with their infant son Michael. He practiced in Tupper Lake and Rochester, New York then joined the US Public Health Service in Columbus, Ohio, received a Doctor of Public Health specializing in nutrition from Columbia University in 1954, spent five years with the Agency for International Development in Brazil, 10 years with the World Health Organization in Geneva, Switzerland and Accra, Ghana, six months with the UN Secretariat in NYC, another 1-1/2 years with AID in Tunisia, back to the PHS near Washington, DC as a consultant to the HANES, before retiring in 1982. He is survived by his wife Senta, his son Robert E. Lowenstein PhD, MD of Clinton, NY, his daughter Eva H. Cagianese, M.Ed, of LaGrangeville, NY, & grandchildren Hilde, Hendrik, Hillary, Hayden, Sarah and Michelle. He was predeceased by his sister Hilda and his son Michael. Sincerest thanks to all those who helped care for our beloved father and husband. A thought: when a great evil is done to you, should you not turn and try to save the world in return?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEAN, HOWARD B.
description: DEAN-Howard B. Died August 23rd in Southampton Hospital of respiratory failure. He was 80 years of age and a resident of East Hampton, New York. Mr. Dean attended the Browning School in New York City, Pomfret School and Yale University. During World War II, he served with Pan Am Africa and the Chinese National Aviation Corp AVG in India and China. He received commendations from the Chinese National Government and the United States Air Force for his service in the Asia Pacific Theatre. An active member of the Wall Street community for forty years, Mr. Dean was a partner at Harris Upham before becoming a Senior Vice President of Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc. He served on the Board of Governors of the Investment Bankers Association, the American Stock Exchange and the Association of Stock Exchange Firms. He was a member of the Vestry of St. Luke's Church, East Hampton, New York, and served for a number of years as Senior Warden. He served as a member of the Board of Trustees of Browning School, of Pomfret School and as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of St. George's School, Newport, Rhode Island. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the Hospital for Special Surgery and the Freedom Institute, both of New York City. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Andree Maitland Dean, three sons, Howard B. M.D. (Judy) Governor of Vermont, James H. (Virginia) of Fairfield, Connecticut, and William G. (Beth) of Dover, Mass. and ten grandchildren; two sisters, Marianne Hill of Cold Spring Harbor, New York and Nancy Felch and her husband, William C. Felch M.D. of Carmel, California. He was pre-deceased by a son Charles, who died in Laos in 1974. Above all, his memory is defined by his friendship, humanity, integrity, and humor which will be missed by all of us. Funeral Services will be held on Thursday, August 30th, 2001 at 11 A.M. at St. Luke's Church, James Lane, East Hampton, NY 11937. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Luke's Church Endowment Fund.

title: What Only the Embryo Knows

Of these three, posterity has largely forgotten von Baer, who suffered a severe mental breakdown in the 1830's, but then recovered and moved to Russia (not uncommon for a German-speaking Estonian national), where he enjoyed a distinguished second university career, largely in anthropology and lasting well into the 1870's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, CHARLES TITUS III.
description: YOUNG-Charles Titus III. Of Lyme, CT, and Vero Beach, FL, died on August 24, 2001, at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, CT. Son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Young Jr., of Branford, CT. He was born September 8, 1917, in Brooklyn, NY. He is survived by his wife of 31 years, Nancy; his sister Sally Young Gevalt of Lakeville, CT; his children Charles A. Young of Guilford, CT; Lavinia Y. Davis of Newtown, CT, and David L. Young of Guilford, CT; his stepchildren Elizabeth M. Kafta of Guilford, CT; Douglas C. Milliken of Berkeley, CA; Tracy M. Fengler of Los Angeles, CA, and Nancy G. Milliken of Los Angeles, CA, and 11 grandchildren. He was a graduate of the Taft School and Williams College class of 1939. He was a Major in the United States Marine Corps, serving in the Pacific Theater during WWII. He was awarded the Purple Heart and the Bronze Star for wounds received and meritorious service in the battle for Okinawa. He was later promoted to Lieutenant Colonel. Among his business achievements he held executive positions with Young & Rubicam; Ketcham, McCloud & Grove; Schieffelin & Company, and was the president of the Double Colas Company of Chattanooga, TN. He was an accomplished sailor with experience ranging from working on the bowsprit of a 70 foot schooner in the middle of the night during a Bermuda race, to cruising with family up and down the East Coast from Maine to the Caribbean. He was a member of many clubs including the Cruising Club of America, the New York Yacht Club, the Essex Yacht Club, the Moorings Club and the Moorings Yacht Club, and the Old Lyme Country Club. He was also the past Commodore of the Pine Orchard Yacht and Country Club. During his retirement, he was on the Board of Directors and later an honorary Trustee of the Schepens Eye Research Institute of Boston, MA. Along with many other interests, he was an accomplished maritime artist. He was a loving husband and devoted father. Donations may be sent to the Schepens Eye Research Institute, 20 Staniford St, Boston, MA 02114. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, August 30, 2001, at 11 AM, in the First Congregational Church, Lyme St, Old Lyme, CT. Burial will be private. There are no calling hours.

title: A Finale, Entirely, for Mozart and Schwarz
description: The finale of this year's Mostly Mozart Festival, on Saturday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, was also Gerard Schwarz's swan song as the festival's music director, a post he has held, with slight variations in his title, since 1982. He has presided, sometimes actively and sometimes as a figurehead, over a period of considerable change, not all of it at his urging. For much of the last decade there has been a backstage tug of war, with Mr. Schwarz carrying the banner for the festival as it was originally conceived -- a rotation of the resident orchestra with invited chamber groups, all hewing closely to the mission suggested by the festival's name -- and Lincoln Center's programming department pulling for an updated approach.

description: ''I woke up and there was the outline of a man standing over me,'' said Wendy Reilly. ''And then, as my brain started registering what was going on, I realized that the reason I woke up was because he was pulling a pillow case over my head.''

title: E-Commerce Report; Seller of Online Currency May Have Been Victim of Fraud
description: Flooz.com, a purveyor of online currency used as electronic gift certificates, officially ceased operations over the weekend, according to its chief executive, Robert Levitan. It fell victim to a softening economy and a sour investment atmosphere. But Internet fraud may have sped its demise, a person close to the company said.

title: Hevesi Quarrel With Giuliani Intensifies
description: Signaling a new and potentially risky strategy, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi turned an already nasty dispute with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into a head-on personal confrontation yesterday, calling Mr. Giuliani a lame-duck Republican who is trying to disrupt the Democratic mayoral primary with ''pathetic lies.''

title: OBITUARY : Jack Monet, Former IHT Editor
description: PARIS  Jack Monet, 70, a former editor for the International Herald Tribune, died here Wednesday of complications from a lung infection. He had been suffering from multiple systems atrophy, a rare neurological disorder.

title: Compressed Data; Unleashing Icons and Embracing Desktop Clutter
description: Remember the ''clean desktop'' for Windows XP? That was the original plan for the new Microsoft operating system, a default desktop screen with a pristine countryside scene uncluttered by icons. Instead, the user would go to the ''start menu,'' and a single click would bring up a menu of eight iconlike links to software applications, Internet services or Web sites. At least three of them would be Microsoft offerings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARTON, HARRY LANG
description: BARTON-Harry Lang. Artist and illustrator, on August 12, 2001, at age 93. He is survived by daughters Linda Drohan and Joan Barton, both of Connecticut, and his sister Virginia E. Marshall and brother Stuart Barton, both of Seattle. Remembrance program Wednesday, August 29, at 2 PM, Messiah Lutheran Church, 42-15 165th St., Flushing, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be directed to the Development-Scholarship Fund for Needy Students, Art Students League of New York, 215 West 57th St., New York, NY 10019.

title: A Quarterback, a Legacy and a Lot of Pressure to Win
description: When the college football season began a year ago, Notre Dame was coming off a 5-7 record and Coach Bob Davie was hearing doubts about his job security. The Fighting Irish were beginning two years of probation for an embarrassing scandal involving sex and other favors for players. The female booster involved was convicted and jailed for embezzlement from a private business.

title: A Storyteller Finds Comfort In a Cloak Of Anonymity
description: In the late 1990's I wrote a book from the point of view of a young black woman who has barricaded herself in her college dorm room pursued by a man, either real or imagined, who finally materializes as the father she has never known. What I was searching for, what I'm always after, is understanding character and in this case the mind of a young woman who has slipped into the fog of adolescence.

title: MediaTalk; Basketball, Subliminally, Enters Funeral Parlor
description: Despite critical acclaim and high ratings, the two-episode season finale of ''Six Feet Under'' on HBO last week was not without its glitches.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Murder In Brighton Beach
description: Two men were shot, one fatally, in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn yesterday evening, the police said. The unidentified victims were at Westend Avenue and Oriental Boulevard when the bullets were fired at 9:30 p.m., the police said. One victim, 31, died from a wound to the head, and the other, 43, was taken to Coney Island Hospital in critical condition. The motive was unknown. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLODNY, MARTIN
description: KOLODNY-Martin. Of Riverdale, died peacefully at home on August 25, 2001, after a long battle with lung cancer. He will be forever missed and remembered by his wife Sandra, sons Richard and David, and grandchildren Steven, Lauren and Jonathan. Dear brother of Ruth Levy-Stroh. He was a graduate of Stuyvesant High School and City College and became a Certified Public Accountant. He was a managing partner of Edward Isaacs and Co. and its successor RSM McGladrey, Inc. Services Tuesday, 1:15 PM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. We love you.

title: Aaliyah, 22, Singer Who First Hit the Charts at 14
description: Aaliyah, a multimillion-selling, precociously sultry rhythm-and-blues singer and actress, died on Saturday in the crash of a small airplane, The Associated Press reported. She was returning from Abaco Island in the Bahamas, where she had been making a video clip, to Miami in a private plane, which crashed on takeoff. Eight other passengers were also killed. Aaliyah was 22 years old.

title: Bronx Team Enjoys a Final Moment at Series
description: A familiar image flew into Carlos Garcia's head as his homer sailed out of the ballpark this afternoon.

title: Facing Huge Loss, Toshiba Cuts 19,000 Jobs
description: TOKYO, Aug. 27 - In a sign that the problems besetting Japan's big technology companies are deep and far-reaching, the Toshiba Corporation said today that it would eliminate some 19,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and that it expected to lose almost $1 billion in the current fiscal year. Plummeting prices for memory chips were at the heart of the trouble, the company said.

Iraqi Opposition Ready to Broadcast Satellite TV Program Financed by U.S.
description: Iraqi opposition groups will open a new front in their battle to topple Saddam Hussein when a satellite television program financed by the United States goes on the air in a few days to beam news, political profiles and even call-in shows and music videos throughout the region.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLUB, HYMAN
description: GOLUB-Hyman, 92. On August 26. Survived by sister, Rose, 102; children, Robert and Joyce, and four grandchildren. Services will be held at Aston-Basagic Funeral Home, Hunter, New York, on Tuesday, August 28, 10 AM.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Big Bomb At Airport
description: A huge car bomb exploded in a parking garage at the Madrid airport, causing extensive damage but no injuries. The Basque separatist group E.T.A. took responsibility. The police received a warning and cleared the area before the vehicle, packed with more than 100 pounds of dynamite, exploded around 8 a.m. The blast destroyed 120 cars, gutted the three-story building and produced smoke and flames visible for miles. The explosion, the latest in a summer campaign against tourist spots, came a week after the police carried out two major raids that they said had thwarted future attacks. Elizabeth Nash (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENRY, CARL
description: HENRY-Carl. Americans for a Safe Israel/AFSI mourns the passing of our esteemed boardmember. He served as a colonel in the 80th Infantry Division of Patton's Third Army, graduated from Harvard, and created a successful business. His later years were marked by his devotion to Torah study and to Israel's survival. AFSI is proud to have had such a distinguished and ardent supporter. Herbert Zweibon, Chairman, AFSI

title: Serena Williams Escapes Rocky Start
description: It was not true to her style, but Serena Williams was coordinating the caution-light yellow of her outfit with a tentative approach to the unassuming Anca Barna last night.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Hair Salon Chain Sells Rights
description: Haircolorxpress International Inc., a franchiser of beauty salons that specializes in custom-blended hair coloring and cosmetics, announced the sale of franchise rights for eight areas in New York, New Jersey and other states for $4.7 million yesterday. The buyers will in turn try to sell individual franchises. Each area is assigned a number of franchises based on a formula linked to population, according to Larry Feldman, president of Haircolorxpress, which was founded in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in June 2000. Mr. Feldman said there are three operating franchises so far, all in Florida.

title: An Online Archive With Mountain Roots
description: An example of the Aspen center's ability to percolate ideas was on display one recent day in the form of Dr. Paul Ginsparg, a string theorist from Los Alamos National Laboratory who is better known as the inventor and proprietor of the Web site on which physicists post and read their papers.

title: Market Place; Shareholders May Be Ready For Rebellion
description: Computer Associates will probably defeat Sam Wyly's attempt to replace four members of its board when shareholders vote at the company's annual meeting tomorrow, independent analysts say.

title: AUSTRALIAN COMPANY ADDS TO ITS U.S. MALL HOLDINGS
description: An Australian investor in real estate, Westfield Holdings, bought a quarter of Rodamco North America for $490 million from Stichting Pensioenfonds, a Dutch pension fund, increasing its ownership of shopping malls in the United States. Westfield, based in Sydney, said it would pay Stichting 51.12 euro ($46.60) a share for 24 percent of Rodamco, a 19 percent premium to its price Friday. Rodamco North America owns 41 malls including the Galleria in Houston; the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J.; and the Century City Shopping Center in Los Angeles. Westfield owns stakes in 40 shopping centers and manages the shopping concourse in the World Trade Center. Building up its holdings would put Westfield in a stronger position to negotiate with mall tenants like Gap Inc. and Limited Inc., said Matthew Ostrower, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

title: Panoramic Gains 10 New Employees
description: Ten employees of the defunct New York agency Warwick Baker O'Neill, including three top executives, are joining Earle Palmer Brown in New York, part of Panoramic Communications.

title: Council Endorsements: Bronx
description: Here are our choices in three very competitive Democratic primaries for City Council seats in the Bronx. In each case the primary election is tantamount to election.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Police Seek Recruits
description: The Hartford Police Department is seeking recruits to increase the number of officers to its authorized maximum of 460, Chief Bruce P. Marquis announced yesterday. Currently, the department is 40 officers short of that goal, officials said. Its efforts to hire qualified recruits have been impaired in recent years by city requirements that officers live in Hartford and by several scandals involving patrol officers, including federal indictments last year accusing officers of sexually abusing prostitutes while on duty. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Suit Says Lilly Failed to Act On Dilutions
description: Cancer patients and their families have filed lawsuits against Eli Lilly & Company, saying that it should have told federal authorities about suspicions that a pharmacist in Kansas City, Mo., was diluting cancer chemotherapy drugs.

title: Bryans Hit Low Notes In First-Round Losses
description: Bob and Mike Bryan pulled out their computer and clicked through the United States Open draw late one night only to find they had met an astonishingly similar fate.

title: Miami's Ocean Point Resort
description: Those looking for one last getaway before summer ends can try the Ocean Point Resort and Club in the Sunny Isles Beach section of Miami. Through Sept. 30, one-bedroom suites in the 166-room oceanfront hotel will start at $139 (regularly $385), and studios will start at $99 (regularly $240). Guests will also receive $150 in coupons good for food and spa services. Rates do not include tax ands a resort fee of $6 a person a day, and are based on availability, with some blackout dates. Information: (866) 623-2678 or www.oceanpointresort.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWSON, ROBERT T.
description: LAWSON-Robert T., 74. Longtime member and supporter of St. Bartholomew's, died August 12 at home in Brooklyn. Funeral service Tuesday, August 28, 4 PM at St. Bart's, Park Avenue at 51st Street.

title: Momentum Swing Disturbs the Mets
description: Robb Nen was the only player on the field as torrential rain hit Shea Stadium before the bottom of the ninth inning. He jogged in from the left-field bullpen, held his glove up and asked Umpire Jerry Crawford to throw him a baseball, but Crawford never obliged because the game was about to be delayed. Nen was like a lonely 10-year-old standing in the park -- in the rain -- with no ball.

title: No 'Seagull' for Broadway
description: If you did not see the Public Theater's starry production of ''The Seagull'' in Central Park, you are not going to have another chance. Despite speculation and negotiations to move the play to Broadway, officials at the Public said yesterday that a transfer would not be possible because of scheduling conflicts among the cast.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the obsolete Redbird subway cars that were dumped in the ocean off Delaware to serve as an artificial reef misspelled the name of the city where they were manufactured. It is Berwick, Pa., not Berwich.

title: A Young Heir Has New Plans At Old Company; Bill Wrigley Is Aggressive In Meeting Rivals Head-On
description: For 38 years, William Wrigley carrying on a long family tradition dating back to the 1890's -- was in charge of the chewing gum company founded by his grandfather. He was healthy, it seemed, certainly wealthy, and thought to be wise in the way he managed the famously secretive company, the Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company. He was expected to lead Wrigley into the new century.

title: Jane Greer, 76, Film Noir Star Who Returned to Do a Remake
description: Jane Greer, whose dolorous but luminous dark eyes and world-weary beauty made her the ideal femme fatale opposite Robert Mitchum in ''Out of the Past'' and ''The Big Steal,'' film noir classics of the 1940's, died Friday in Los Angeles. She was 76.

title: The Bronx's Little League Ace Faces Questions Over His Age
description: Little League officials are investigating whether Danny Almonte, the ace pitcher for the Rolando Paulino All-Stars from the Bronx, is 14 years old and should have been ineligible to play the past two seasons and during this year's World Series, which ended Sunday.

title: U.S. SAYS KILLINGS BY ISRAEL INFLAME MIDEAST CONFLICT
description: The Bush administration said today that Israel's policy of pinpoint killings of Palestinians was inflaming the Middle East conflict and urged the Israelis to alleviate what it called the humiliations of the Palestinian people.

title: The Liberty Loses Its Crown, as the Sting Regains Its Poise
description: The game and a third straight Eastern Conference title were there for the Liberty to win. It took a 9-0 lead in the first seven minutes as the Charlotte Sting missed its first nine shots. The Sting shot so badly in the first half that while one player, the venerable Dawn Staley, sank 4 of 6 shots, her teammates combined for 1 of 20.

description: In percent

title: Some Towns Begin Allowing Beach Access
description: As town officials here consider whether to appeal a ruling forcing the town to open its beaches to nonresidents, most town leaders elsewhere in Fairfield County say they have opened their beaches and lakefronts to the wider public.

title: Musical Revival to Close
description: ''Annie Get Your Gun,'' a revival of the Irving Berlin musical, with a new book by Peter Stone, is to close after the evening performance on Saturday at the Marquis Theater, 1535 Broadway, at 45th Street. The show, directed by Graciela Daniele, will have run for 1,046 regular performances and 35 previews.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Power Failures Reported
description: A fast-moving thunderstorm knocked out power for as many as 7,000 business and residential customers last night in southern Connecticut, said a spokeswoman for the United Illuminating Company. Lightning strikes and trees hitting power lines disrupted service in Fairfield, Hamden, Stratford, Woodbridge and Trumbull.

title: Schools Official to Investigate Treatment of Asian Students
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has assigned a superintendent to look into possible discrimination against Asian immigrant students at Lafayette High School in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, school officials said yesterday.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Franklin: Beekeeper Killed
description: A beekeeper was killed Sunday, apparently by bees he had acquired for his hobby, but entomologists were puzzled by the aggressive nature of the bees. State entomologists have collected a sample of the bees that killed the beekeeper, Ernest William Jennings. Mr. Jennings may have unknowingly bought a stock of aggressive Africanized honeybees instead of European honeybees, Louis Magnarelli, the state's chief entomologist, said yesterday. ''It is very, very unusual for European bees to attack like that,'' he said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Hip Implant Maker to Offer Shares to Litigants
description: Plagued by liability claims in American courts, Sulzer Medica, the Swiss manufacturer of orthopedic appliances like artificial hip joints, is offering to give claimants a piece of the company in a class-action settlement meant to minimize damage to the company.

description: Study Says Bush Budget Would Tap Social Security

title: Hotter Than a Crawford Ranch
description: All those reporters who are always clustered around President Bush should have been suspicious the minute he started stomping around his ranch in the middle of August. Instead, sweating and gullible and, frankly, kind of pathetic, they earnestly reported the president's rhapsodic remarks about going home to Texas in the summer. They bought the implication that Texans wouldn't miss a Texas August, even if it is 110 degrees in the shade (except there's not any shade).

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Pap Smear Bill Signed
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco signed legislation yesterday that will require health insurers to pay for all costs related to Pap smears and similar tests used to detect cervical cancer. According to the bill's sponsors, previous legislation required insurers to cover only initial testing, creating a loophole for private insurers and health maintenance organizations to avoid payment. Making sure that follow-up Pap smears are covered by insurance is ''a no-brainer,'' said Senator Shirley K. Turner, a Ewing Democrat and one of the bill's sponsors.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Feeling Good
description: More Irish people say they are healthy than people of any other European nationality, with 80 percent saying their health is good or very good, according to a study by the Economic and Social Research Institute. Higher income and education levels contribute to a greater sense of well-being, and people living in the countryside report more health problems than Dubliners. The study, intended to measure satisfaction with Ireland's ailing health service, found that 95 percent of those surveyed favored increased government spending to shorten hospital waiting lists. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Streaming the Classics; A Record Label Hopes to Grow Into Musical Grandeur in Cyberspace
description: About five years ago Alain Coblence, a French lawyer with a practice in New York, had an idea for a business that would draw on his lifelong passion for classical recordings. It began as a comparatively simple idea: he was going to start a record label, called Andante.

title: Former Police Officer Sentenced To 13 Years for Crimes on Duty
description: A former Brooklyn police officer was sentenced yesterday to 13 years in a federal prison for living a secret life of crime that included holding up drug dealers while in uniform and helping members of a violent crew of robbers avoid arrest.

title: From Tapes That Shook A President's Footing
description: Laura Strausfeld must have been determined that her play about Monica Lewinsky and Linda Tripp not look static. That play, ''Snatches,'' is a one-act comedy made up of verbatim dialogue from the tapes of the two women's conversations, most of them by telephone, so audiences might expect to see two women sitting on stools on opposite sides of the stage, possibly with transcripts in hand.

description: Midas Inc. has narrowed a review for its American creative and strategic account, with billings estimated at $60 million, to four agencies from nine.

description: MOLONEY-F. Daniel. Of Lake Ronkonkoma, NY, on August 26, 2001, in his 63rd year. Founder of the Moloney Family Funeral Homes, Brookhaven Town Tax Receiver, member of the Board of Directors of St. Charles Hospital, longtime member and Commissioner of the Lake Ronkonkoma Fire District. Adored son of Mary and longtime companion and friend of Cheryl Tully. Devoted father of F. Daniel Jr., Virginia Wagenknecht, Michael S., Kathleen Anderson, Peter G., Thomas E., Christine Lentz and Melissa Moloney. Loving brother of Jack Moloney and the late James. Father-in-law of Denice, Jacqueline, Abbie, Christine, James Lentz and John Anderson. Cherished grandfather of Nicholas, Danielle, Brian, Cory, Meghan, Ryann, Paige, Molly, Anna Kathleen, Hunter, Lars, D. J., Connor, Kathleen, Liam, Erin and Luke. Visiting Tuesday and Wednesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Moloney's Lake Funeral Home, 132 Ronkonkoma Ave., Lake Ronkonkoma, NY. Services Tuesday evening, 8 PM, by the St. Regis Council, Knights of Columbus, followed by the Royal Order of the Moose and the Guy Lombardo Lodge Order of the Sons of Italy. Services Wednesday, 7:30 PM, by the Lake Ronkonkoma Fire Department. Prayer service Wednesday, 8 PM. Liturgy of Christian Burial Thursday, 11 AM, at St. Joseph R.C. Church, Ronkonkoma. Interment following Holy Sepulchre Cemetery, Coram, NY. The family would gratefully appreciate donations to St. Charles Hospital in Dan's memory.

title: Leslie Sbrocco's Cellar Suggestions
description: As if the South of France isn't blessed enough with gorgeous Provencal landscapes, ancient Roman ruins, and inspired rustic cuisine. Now there are two stellar vintages of wine on store shelves - 1998 and 1999 - ready for the dinner table or the cellar.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Bellsouth Buys Alcatel D.S.L. Gear
description: BellSouth, the biggest local phone carrier in the southeastern United States, signed a contract with Alcatel, Europe's fourth-largest maker of telecommunications equipment, to buy gear for fast Internet access. Financial terms of the three-year deal were not disclosed. The contract is part of BellSouth's plans to almost triple its digital subscriber line customer base to 600,000 by the end of the year and make D.S.L. available to 70 percent of households in the Southeast, the company said in a statement. The company, which is based in Atlanta, sells local service in nine states from Florida to Kentucky.

title: Letters: A Union Opportunity
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: New Boot Camp To Open
description: A new military-style boot camp will be opened this fall by the same organization that runs a camp where a 14-year-old boy died in July, prompting accusations of abuse. The group, American Buffalo Soldiers Re-enactors Association, will open the youth camp outside Phoenix on Sept. 8. Parents and children who showed up for orientation were greeted by protesters angry over the drowning on July 1 of Anthony Haynes, which has been ruled accidental. Mindy Sink (NYT)

title: Macedonia Disarming Begins, Hours After Briton's Death
description: Taking no chances hours after a British soldier became the first NATO peacekeeper to die in Macedonia, the alliance today dropped some of its toughest troops into this village held by the ethnic Albanian rebels the soldiers came to disarm and started to collect the guerrillas' guns.

title: Genes Reveal Africa's Elephants as 2 Separate Species
description: Africa's reclusive forest elephants and the herds that trundle across its savannas are as genetically distinct as leopards are from lions, and thus should be reclassified as separate species, geneticists say.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Robbers Get $244,000
description: Two armed men dressed as security guards held up a bank in Little Neck yesterday, holding a gun to a customer's head before fleeing with $244,000, the police said. No one was injured. The authorities said the gunmen entered the Chase Manhattan Bank at 252-34 Northern Boulevard at 10:15 a.m. and fled on foot after ordering the bank manager to fill a blue duffel bag with cash. There were no arrests, the police said. C. J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Somalia Is Making Progress Toward Peace, Leader Says
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, Aug. 27 (AP) — A year after taking office, President Abdikassim Salad Hassan acknowledged today that some of the problems that pitched Somalia into chaos and lawlessness remain, but he insisted that his government had made progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDLER, RICHARD V.
description: BANDLER-Richard V., 85. On August 25, 2001, in Boston, MA. Formerly of Riverdale, NY. Retired Associate Regional Administrator, U.S. Securities & Exchange Commission, New York, and an associate of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver, and Jacobson. Active lay leader in Jewish education. Devoted husband of the late Jeannette (Finkelstein). Beloved father of Michael & Leah Bandler of Silver Spring, MD, and Naomi & Michael Nadelberg of Newton, MA. Cherished grandfather of Jonathan, Jeremy, Daniel, Sara, Ari, Amanda, Oshi, Brianna, and Stacy. Dear brother of the late Samson. Graveside services were held Monday in New Jersey. Shiva will be observed at his children's homes. Donations in Richard's memory may be made to the Richard V. Bandler Education Fund of the Board of Jewish Education, 426 West 58th Street, New York, NY 10019, or to the Alumni Association Fund of New York University Law School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, SEYMOUR JAY
description: GOLDMAN-Seymour Jay. Father and grandfather. June 3, 1909August 25, 2001. With death comes closure. The pain and anger will subside. Hopefully, you, too, will find the peace that you have sought for so long. Arnie

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Holbrook: Red-Light Cameras
description: A Suffolk County lawmaker plans to introduce legislation today asking the state to allow the county to use surveillance technology to discourage drivers from running red lights. If approved, the legislation would allow the authorities to install cameras at busy intersections throughout Suffolk. State law allows such equipment only in New York City. The legislator, William J. Lindsay, a Sayville Democrat, cited an 18 percent nationwide increase in fatal motor vehicle crashes at traffic lights from 1992 to 1998. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: No. 2 Official at I.M.F. Offers a Bleak Forecast
description: The world economy is skirting the edge of a recession, harmed by Japan's predicted contraction and the rapid slowing of the United States economy, the International Monetary Fund's No. 2 official said today.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Loss At Inspection Concern
description: The world's largest goods inspection and testing company, Socit Gnrale de Surveillance, reported an unexpected 25 percent drop in profit for the first half of this year. Its profit fell to $26 million after losing about $36 million worth of contracts with the governments of the Philippines and the Ivory Coast. Socit Gnrale, which has been trying to move away from its reliance on contracts with customs authorities, also is trying to recover another $125 million in overdue payments from Manila. The company, which is based in Geneva, said it still expected to meet its goal of 10 percent sales growth in the coming year. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLODNY, MARTIN
description: KOLODNY-Martin. McGladrey & Pullen, LLP, formerly Edward Isaacs & Company LLP, is saddened by the loss of our dear friend and partner of 41 years. Martin will be remembered for his dedication to the Firm, the Clients and the Accounting Profession. We express our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Services are scheduled for today, Tuesday, August 28th at Riverside Chapel, West 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue at 1:15 PM.

title: Officers Who Drive Drunk May Face Tougher Penalties
description: The New York Police Department is looking to toughen the disciplinary sanctions for officers who abuse alcohol and is considering a new policy under which it would move to fire any officer found to have been driving while intoxicated, police officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWITTES, AARON
description: LEWITTES-Aaron. Died August 27, 2001 at the age of 88 years. Cherished husband of the late Estelle. Devoted and proud father and father-in-law of Deborah and Dr. Morris Stampfer, Naomi and Dr. Jack Levenbrown, and Ann Lewittes. Adored grandfather of Dr. David and Amy Stampfer, Sharon Stampfer and Dr. Matthew Weitzman, and Andrea Levenbrown. Loving great-grandfather of Alexandra & Jessica Stampfer and Gavriela and Micah Weitz man. Beloved brother of Dr. Jacob Lewittes. Aaron, an attorney, was a partner in the New York law firm of Leventritt Lewittes and Bender. Earlier he served the United States government on the National Labor Relations Board, as Special Assistant to the Attorney General of the United States, and as a legal advisor to the White House during the Truman Administration. Funeral services will be held at Boulevard-Park West Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY Tuesday, August 28 at 11:30 A.M.

title: 3 Experienced Candidates Battle, Cordially, in Middle-Class Area of Queens
description: For the last 30 years, a swath of neighborhoods in central Queens has been represented in the City Council by Morton Povman, a quiet-spoken legislator who rarely if ever faced serious challenges. But the city's term-limit law has prevented Mr. Povman from running again, and a competitive, if cordial, battle is under way for the Democratic nomination to succeed him.

title: 2 Companies Err in Results
description: AGL Resources and Piedmont Natural Gas said today that they might have lower-than-expected fiscal 2001 earnings because their SouthStar Energy Services energy-marketing venture overstated revenue and net income.

title: Star-Crossed Ideas of How Pyramids Came to Point North
description: Nine months ago, a British Egyptologist reported that she had probably solved the puzzle of how the ancient Egyptians had aligned the pyramids of Giza to true north and approximately when they did it.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''These people are subsistence farmers in a world that is not a subsistence world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUFRIN, OSCAR
description: SUFRIN-Oscar. Beloved husband of the late Helen. Loving father of Dr. Gerald and Dr. Janice Sufrin and Leslie and Roberta Sufrin, cherished grandfather of Lisa, Peter, Carolyn, Michelle and Douglas. Dear brother of Matilda Ingber and Florence Swerdloff. Services Tuesday 11 AM at Mount Zion Cemetery, Maspeth, Queens.

title: World Business Briefing | South Africa: South Africa: Gold Mining Shift
description: AngloGold, the biggest gold miner in the world, said it hoped to more than double annual production from South America to one million ounces within five years, reducing dependence on high-cost South African mines. The company could increase South American production from last year's 439,000 ounces by buying out minority partners, expanding mines it owns and digging new pits to produce metal that would be worth about $273 million a year at current prices.

title: Days of Boredom, Minutes of Fun; Where Side Bets Mount Up and the Egos Flutter in the Breeze
description: They smoke $30 cigars. Their big boats can swallow 500 gallons of diesel in a single fishing trip. Sure they wanted to bag the biggest fish and one of the six-figure prize checks. But they were really after the catch that would fuel years of barroom braggadocio.

title: Executive Changes at Media Firms
description: Kevin Patsel was named executive principal and managing director for public relations at the San Francisco office of Publicis Dialog, part of Publicis in the U.S., a division of the Publicis Groupe. He succeeds Ned Purdom, who was named to the new post of executive principal and account director, overseeing technology accounts. Mr. Patsel had been partner for marketing and creative services at the San Francisco office of Porter Novelli, part of the Omnicom Group.

description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27  The game kickball is well-known to schoolchildren. But the players here at a recent match on the National Mall looked suspiciously mature.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Another Summit With Pakistan
description: Despite a rocky July meeting in India that ended without any substantive agreement, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, right, has decided that he will meet a second time with Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Perez Musharraf, left, next month on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly session. They will talk about a variety of issues including the two nations' conflict over Kashmir, the Himalayan territory. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: Social Security (as We Know It) Is Here to Stay
description: SHELTER ISLAND, N.Y. -- Buried under layers of argument, analysis and sophistry, the real issue in the Social Security fight has become invisible. That issue is the nature of the obligation. Is Social Security a firm contract with its beneficiaries, as a government bond is a contract with its holders? Or is it simply another government program that can be modified or even abandoned at any time by Congress and the president? Through the years of the big deficits — the early Bill Clinton years as well as the years of Ronald Reagan and the first George Bush — presidents insisted that all the revenues from Social Security taxes were available to be spent for other purposes, just as the revenues from other taxes were. Borrowing from the so-called Social Security trust fund was a routine way to pay the government's bills.

title: Most Japan Carmakers Report Gains in Global Production
description: Toyota Motor and Honda Motor led gains in global production among Japanese automakers in July as they raced to meet demand for new models at home and in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESSMAN, LEONARD J., MD
description: ESSMAN-Leonard J., MD. On August 25, 2001. The Board of Governors and the medical staff of Rye Hospital Center, Rye, New York mourn the untimely loss of their devoted member, and extend deepest sympathy to his wife, Zora, their children and grandchildren. Jack C. Schoenholtz, MD President and CEO Elliot Roy Singer, MD President of the Medical Staff

title: U.S. Says Beit Jala Occupation Makes Matters Worse
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28  The United States urged both sides again today to "break the pattern of violence" in the Middle East. It said too that Israel should withdraw from a West Bank town that it partially occupied early today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOSS, HOPE
description: MOSS-Hope. Of Miami, Florida and formerly of Westhampton Beach, NY and New York City, died on August 1, 2001. Hope is survived by her children, Paul and Jane Roseman & Robin and John Moss Hinchcliff; by her sister, Joy Moss Kohoutova; by her grandchildren; & by many cousins and life-long friends. Hope was predeceased by her true friend & companion, Sam Adel. A celebration of Hope's life will be held at the Heller Gallery in Manhattan on August 30th, with calling hours are from 6-9 PM. Hope's warm friendship, love, loyalty and good humor will be greatly missed.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Share Price Grazes Cut-Off Level
description: Sagging stock prices could cause one of the conditions that would allow Portugal Telecom SGPS to back out of its $1.6 billion bid for the remaining shares of a So Paulo wireless telecommunications provider, Telesp Celular Participaces. In May, Portugal Telecom said it would issue 253 million shares to swap for the 58.8 percent it does not own in Telesp Celular, Brazil's largest cellular company. But the company said a 10 percent drop in its shares would allow them to back out of the deal. Although the stock broke that level in early trading, the shares recovered to 7.10 escudos, slightly above the 7.02 cut-off by the close. Portugal Telecom has said that it intends to follow through with the deal. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORKIN, NATHAN
description: SORKIN-Nathan. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Manhasset, NY, on August 27, 2001. Lieutenant, U.S. Navy, WW II. Past President, B'nai B'rith-Greater Flushing Chapter. Supporter of UJA-Federation, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, U.S Holocaust Memorial Museum, National Yiddish Book Center. Co-Founder of Temple Judea, Manhasset, NY. Past President of the Printer's League. Trustee of the Printer's Pension Fund. Loving husband of 62 years to Rosalie Sorkin, father to Ira & Joel, grandfather to Roger and Peter. Funeral on Thursday, August 30, 11 AM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery. Shiva held at the home of Ira Sorkin, Thursday, August 30, and Friday afternoon, August 31.

title: Morrisville Journal; Sisters Give Up the Cows And Gain Richer Lives
description: Now that she no longer has to get up at 3:30 a.m. to milk the cows, Gert Lepine likes to lounge in bed until 6, reading the books she never had time for when she was farming. She has discovered Cormac McCarthy and reread much of Steinbeck and Hemingway. She has read Willa Cather's ''My ntonia'' twice.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Profit Up At Fortis
description: The Belgian-Dutch banking and insurance group Fortis said its operating profit rose 4 percent in the first half of this year to 1.5 million euros ($1.37 million). The banking divisions posted a 5 percent increase in operating profit, while gross premium income at its insurance units reached a new high of 12 billion euros (almost $11 billion), Fortis said. Fortis benefited from its acquisition of the Dutch insurer ASR Verzekeringsgroep in December. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: Florida Minister Defies Drug Dealers, Despite Threat on Life
description: The Rev. John Guns is 5-foot-3 and thick, like a steamer trunk in a blue pin-striped suit, but he moves light and fast across the dais at St. Paul's Missionary Baptist Church. An electric organ moans, a drum booms and Mr. Guns begins to proselytize. ''We are the people of God,'' the minister shouts, and lifts up his congregation even as, one by one, the worshipers drop on their knees.

title: Bloomberg Pitches Plans to Make Police More Accountable
description: Michael R. Bloomberg called yesterday for measures to make the police more accountable to the public, saying that racial data on stop-and-frisks should be posted on the Internet and that the Civilian Complaint Review Board should report to the mayor rather than to the police commissioner.

title: An Exhibition A Stubborn Artist Might Have Hated
description: One of the great unanswered questions about late-20th-century American painting is, What will become of the Clyfford Still estate?

title: STUDY IN CONGRESS SEES NEED TO TAP SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Congressional budget analysts warned in a report made public today that the economic downturn and President Bush's tax-cut package would force the federal government to spend $9 billion from the Social Security surplus this year and billions more over the next three years.

title: Plotting an Attack On Your Cholesterol
description: If you are like most people I know, chances are you are thoroughly confused about cholesterol and what you have to do to reduce your chances of suffering a heart attack or stroke. For those who must take cholesterol-lowering drugs, the confusion has been compounded by the recall this month of a leading medication, Baycol, after 31 deaths from kidney failure caused by excessive muscle breakdown.

title: Stocks Fall on Consumer Confidence Report
description: Stocks fell sharply today in a slump felt across many sectors of the market after a new private economic report showed that consumer confidence fell unexpectedly this month.

title: India and the Bomb
description: The Bush administration will reportedly soon ask Congress to lift the ineffectual American military and economic sanctions imposed on India after it tested a nuclear weapon three years ago. While this step may be warranted to encourage already improving relations between the United States and India, it should not be done in a fashion that suggests that Washington has lost interest in trying to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons to nations that have not had them. That must remain a bedrock American policy goal.

title: Giants Explore Kicking Options
description: As teams throughout the N.F.L. trim their rosters, the Giants are looking particularly closely at available place-kickers. Possible candidates include the former Giant Brad Daluiso, whom the team did not pursue as a free agent during the off-season, as well as other veteran free agents like Al Del Greco, Morten Andersen and Cary Blanchard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBB, ELIZABETH BLISS PARKINSON
description: COBB-Elizabeth Bliss Parkinson. On August 24, at Meadowlakes, Hightstown, NJ, at age 93. Beloved wife of the late Henry Ives Cobb. Survived by her daughter Zaidee Parkinson; her son John Parkinson III and her daughter-in-law Charlotte; her stepchildren Alex and Sheila Ewing, Ian and Victoria Mackintosh, and John and Bayard Cobb; five grandchildren, John Parkinson, Allston Parkinson, Elizabeth Parkinson-Wyner, Basil Dufallo and Cornelius Dufallo; and three great-grandchildren, Jack Wyner, Miles Wyner and Schuyler Parkinson. A memorial service is plannned for October. Friends may make donations in her memory to the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd St, NYC 10019.

description: Last August, top executives from Microsoft, Barnesandnoble.com and several book publishers assembled at a Midtown Manhattan hotel for a news conference to usher in the coming age of the electronic book.

description: Ron Carey, elected president of the Teamsters union in 1991 as an anticorruption crusader, went on trial yesterday on federal charges that he lied repeatedly to investigators looking into fund-raising improprieties in his re-election campaign five years later.

title: PRICE-CUTTING AT BARNEYS NEW YORK LEADS TO WIDER LOSS
description: The luxury retailer Barneys New York reported yesterday that its quarterly loss widened as it cut prices to draw shoppers. The loss for the period ended Aug. 4 increased to $3.86 million, or 28 cents a share, from $3.59 million, or 26 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales rose 1.1 percent, to $85.1 million. Sales at stores open at least one year, an important measure of performance, fell less than 1 percent. Gross profit narrowed to 46 percent of sales from 48 percent. The company's main stores are in New York, Chicago and Beverly Hills. Barneys also operates 5 other regional full-price stores and 12 outlet stores.

title: Chip Maker In Korea Is Battling Over Loan
description: South Korea's debt-ridden Hynix Semiconductor opened a public battle with its foreign creditors yesterday as Korean bankers considered rescue plans that would provide a combination of more than $3 billion in new loans and stock swaps.

title: Family Fined in First Ruling Based on State Abortion Clinic Access Law
description: A federal judge has fined members of an upstate family $80,000 for their aggressive tactics during abortion protests, a decision that lays out a legal road map for interpreting the state's 1999 clinic access law.

description: Medical textbooks are filled with quaint old names for specific maladies. Chickenpox, for example, has little to do with the barnyard fowl.

The Fighting Irish were beginning two years of probation for an embarrassing scandal involving sex and other favors for players. The female booster involved was convicted and jailed for embezzlement from a private business.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Opposition Leaders Freed
description: The authorities released from detention the chairman and vice chairman of the opposition National League for Democracy -- U Aung Shwe and U Tin Oo -- bringing the total of releases in recent months to nearly 200. The party's leading figure, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, said in a statement that she would work hard for the success of talks now under way with the military government. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Environmental Groups to File Suit Over Missile Defenses
description: Hoping to slow the Bush administration's missile defense program, several environmental groups plan to file a lawsuit on Tuesday asserting that the Pentagon's plans for a missile defense test range in the Pacific would violate federal environmental rules.

title: Company Name Change
description: The Kroll-O'Gara Company, a provider of security and private investigation services, has changed its name to Kroll Inc. and its ticker symbol to KROL, effective immediately. Kroll, which formerly used the symbol KROG in Nasdaq stock market trading, completed the sale of its armored-vehicle manufacturing unit to Armor Holdings Inc. last week. Kroll now is focused on its corporate investigations business, which provides asset tracing, substance-abuse testing and other surveillance services.

title: Democrat to Resign F.C.C. Seat
description: Gloria Tristani, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, will leave the agency, which regulates telecommunications and media companies, on Sept. 7 and may become a candidate for office in New Mexico.

title: Metro Business Briefing | College Leases Dormitory Space
description: The School of Visual Arts has signed a lease for dormitory rooms and retail space in a building under construction at 215 East 23rd Street, between Second and Third Avenues. The school, which rents housing for its students in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Jersey City, recently signed a lease for 55,000 square feet in the new building, which is going up next door to its main offices. It plans to rent the ground floor to retail tenants and to house 360 students on the other floors, according to the Staubach Company, which represented the School for Visual Arts. In a separate transaction, the New York City Department of Environmental Protection and the Department of Finance have leased the entire building at 30-03 Review Avenue in Queens. The two agencies, which were represented by Cushman & Wakefield, will move more than 200 employees to the building, which has 171,000 square feet, from two other sites in Queens. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE BUYBACK OF STAPLES.COM STOCK
description: Shareholders of the office-supply retailer Staples approved a plan yesterday to buy back shares of Staples.com held by venture capitalists and employees, ignoring opponents who complained that the price was too high. About 85 percent of Staples' shares were voted in favor of the proposal. Staples first proposed the buyback in March, after the market for Internet stocks plummeted and the company abandoned plans to sell shares in the online business to the public. Under the repurchase program, investors and employees would receive the equivalent of $7 worth of Staples stock for each Staples.com share they own. Opponents had protested that the proposed price was more than twice the $3.25 a share paid by venture capitalists.

title: Battered Women Face Pit Bulls and Cobras
description: The cobra is a real snake in the grass, quiet and focused before striking its victim with little or no warning. The pit bull's fury smolders and builds, and once its teeth are sunk into its victim it won't let go. Men who batter women are either like cobras or pit bulls, say two professors of psychology at the University of Washington who have spent a decade studying violent marriages, and the distinction can make a difference in the severity of the harm they inflict, the ability of women to escape a relationship and the risks the women face if they do leave.

title: Midas Narrows Account Review
description: Midas Inc. ( news/quote ) has narrowed a review for its American creative and strategic account, with billings estimated at $60 million, to four agencies from nine.

title: Out of Many Sources, One Infectious Latin Groove
description: NO problem finding the rehearsal room where Bobby Sanabria is working his big band. Clave, the distinctive five-beat rhythm of Afro-Cuban jazz, is bursting through the soundproofing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AUERBACH, FLORENCE
description: AUERBACH-Florence. Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn Heights, New York mourns the passing of our beloved member Florence Auerbach. We extend heartfelt condolences to her husband, Shay, and family. Alan B. Lucas, Rabbi Rose Schecter, President

title: Sharpton Endorses Ferrer in Mayoral Race
description: In the cramped and steamy basement at the Mount Sinai United Christian Church on Staten Island yesterday morning, the Rev. Al Sharpton stood next to Fernando Ferrer and announced that after four months of rather public courting, he was unequivocally supporting Mr. Ferrer's bid to become mayor of New York.

title: Blood Product From Biopure Passes Tests For Approval
description: Biopure said yesterday that its manufactured substitute for human blood had met the major safety targets set by the Food and Drug Administration in a crucial clinical trial. As a result, the company expects to be ready to apply before the end of this year for F.D.A. approval to market the product.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GOLDFEIN, PAULINE R.
description: GOLDFEIN-Pauline R. It is now eighteen years since you left us. Your family and friends still miss you. Phi

title: U.S. Airlines Lower Fares to Spur Demand
description: Most major United States carriers followed Northwest Airlines today in reducing some leisure fares, the latest airline discounts designed to spur demand.

title: Corrections
description: The On Tennis column yesterday about the seedings in the United States Open misspelled the name of the top-seeded men's player in some editions. He is Gustavo Kuerten, not Kuertan.

title: Calumet Mayor Convicted
description: CHICAGO, Aug. 27 — The mayor of Calumet City, Ill., who had promised to clean up the Chicago suburb, was convicted today of accepting kickbacks and using city employees for personal work on city time.

title: The Only Constant Is Change In the Yankees' Batting Order
description: Gary Denbo types the Yankees' lineup into a computer and prints a copy, the letters capitalized and in black ink, each name in the batting order separated by boxes, and Denbo tacks or tapes the batting order onto a centrally situated wall in the clubhouse.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Latin Wireless Giant Buys Stake
description: The Mexican mobile telecommunications provider Amrica Mvil concluded its $400 million purchase of a stake in Brazilian wireless provider ATL-Algar Telecom Leste that had belonged to the Williams Communications Group. With the deal, Amrica Mvil, which was spun off from the Mexican telecommunications giant, Telfonos de Mxico, will raise its stake in the Brazilian wireless provider to 72 percent. Williams Communications, which is based in Tulsa, received $300 million at the deal's close and will receive another $100 million for the stake on May 15, 2002. Amrica Mvil is the largest mobile phone company in Latin America. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: SingTel Is a Step Away From Australia
description: Singapore Telecommunications said today that it had won all necessary regulatory approvals from Australia and the United States for its $7.5 billion purchase of the Australian company Cable and Wireless Optus. The approval was seen as a triumph over political objections to Singapore's increasing business role in Australia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULSKY, RUBIN
description: SHULSKY-Rubin. Hebron Yeshiva in Jerusalem, its Rabbis, students and alumni mourn the passing of Rubin Shulsky, a revered philantropist and ardent supporter of the Yeshiva. Rubin Shulsky was highly admired for his leadership, generosity and kindness. Our deepest condolences and sympathy to his beloved daughter, Rena. Rabbi I. Hebroni Yeshiva President Benjamin Hager, President American Friends of Hebron Yeshiva

title: Teasing in More Ways Than One: Seeking Universal Truths in Hairstyles
description: Jawole Willa Jo Zollar and her Urban Bush Women company and collaborators do not mince words or moves. They dive into the lives they see around them and come up, in Ms. Zollar's best pieces, with some surprisingly universal truths. The cultural significance of black women's hair is the subject of Ms. Zollar's new ''Hairstories,'' for instance. But like a stone thrown into water, the piece creates almost endlessly widening circles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, REV. JOHN, C.M.
description: MURRAY-Rev. John, C.M. The St. John's University Board of Trustees notes, with profound sorrow, the passing of its colleague, Trustee Emeritus Rev. John P. Murray, C.M. He dedicated himself to God in a priesthood that spanned more than fifty years. He was a member of the Board of Trustees of St. John's University for more than three decades, providing a model of wisdom in humility and compassion in strength. The University community expresses its affection and esteem but, moreover, its gratitude for the many ways by which he enriched us by so generously sharing his many gifts and extraordinary faith. Our love and prayers are with his family and his Vincentian confreres. Denis P. Kelleher, Chair Rev. Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, CECILLE MERL
description: FRIEDMAN-Cecille Merl, 92. On August 26 in Phoenix, AZ. Loving wife of Leo J. Friedman who passed away in July. Mother of Roger and Jeffrey. title: Waterbury Aldermen Vote to Cut A Salary Deal With Jailed Mayor
description: Ruling out any chance of firing Mayor Philip A. Giordano, who has refused to leave office after being indicted last month on charges that he arranged to have sex with two children, the city's Board of Aldermen voted instead tonight to cut a deal with him.

title: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: New Zealand: Trade Deficit
description: New Zealand's trade balance turned to deficit for the first time in seven months, reflecting a seasonal decline in the amount of meat, wool and cheese available for export, while demand for imports rose. The July trade deficit was 46 million New Zealand dollars ($20 million), Statistics New Zealand said. That reversed a surplus of 146 million New Zealand dollars in June, but was better than a deficit of 126 million a year ago.

title: Technology Briefing | People: At&t Executive Joins Palm
description: Palm Inc. has appointed David C. Nagel president and chief executive officer of a new software subsidiary. Mr. Nagel, 56, has served as AT&T's chief technology officer since 1996 and is already a member of the board of Palm, the hand-held computer maker. Before coming to AT&T, he headed research and development at Apple Computer. The move comes soon after Palm bought the software created by Be Incorporated, an innovative operating system company formed by another Apple alumnus, Jean-Louis Gasse. Like many high-tech companies, Palm has suffered a drop in sales this year. In a statement, Mr. Nagel said that he was ''delighted to lead the Palm platform business'' into such new areas as wireless communications and multimedia. John Schwartz (NYT)

And with Ike Hilliard still sidelined by an injury and Amani Toomer also slowed by one, the breakout game by Dixon, a second-year wide receiver who plays behind them, could not have come at a better time.
