Brodeur will be elected, but he does have a campaign pledge that suits New York in August better than discussions of debt service and Palm Pilots for the police. ''Instead of having an inauguration, I will use that money to install industrial fans in subway stations,'' said Mr. Brodeur, a candidate in the Green Party primary.

Toddlers with cerebral palsy are ensconced in partial body casts. Paraplegics are slung in harnesses and made to walk on treadmills, with automatic equipment moving their feet. Even the blind are having their brains reconfigured with a special camera that allows them ''see'' via a device worn on the tongue.

description: THOMAS-H. Emerson, 98. Former mayor of Westfield, NJ died August 25, 2001. Known to those in the propane gas industry as ''Mr. LP-Gas'', he was a founder and former president of the National LP-Gas Association. Predeceased by his wife, Helen, he is survived by two sons, H. Emerson Thomas, Jr., M.D. and Gordon B. Thomas; a sister, Helen Greene; 8 grandchildren and 7 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be at the Presbyterian Church in Westfield on September 8, at 11 A.M. For more information, call Memorial Funeral Home at 908-322-4350.

title: Children Star in Fall Ads, but Don't Expect Happy Families
description: This month, editors at Harlequin Enterprises announced that they would soon be introducing a line of books revolving around the antics and foibles of single professional women like Bridget Jones. Flouting the standards of romance fiction, the novels will not force heroines to date anyone named Igor or Sven. It is more significant, though, that they won't always end with their heroines yoked to men who are their destiny. The news of Harlequin's foray into literature verit came not long before Sarah Jessica Parker disclosed in an interview that ''Sex and the City'' might eventually terminate with her character, Carrie Bradshaw, alone.

title: Intel Selling Two-Gigahertz Chips
description: The Intel Corporation today began selling versions of its Pentium 4 chips that run at two gigahertz, or two billion cycles a second, a largely symbolic performance landmark that nonetheless opened Intel's speed lead in desktop computers.

title: Diana Golden Brosnihan, Skier, Dies at 38
description: Diana Golden Brosnihan, who lost a leg to cancer at 12, won a gold medal in disabled skiing at the 1988 Calgary Olympics and played a key role in public appreciation of disabled athletes, died Saturday at a hospital in Providence, R.I. She was 38.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: No Rush To Deal
description: The Dutch telecommunications group Royal KPN appears to be in no rush to make a deal with its southern neighbor, the Belgian government-controlled Belgacom. The Belgian government together with a consortium of the main minority shareholders wrote to KPN in a bid to speed the process. KPN replied to that letter last week, but the company has not determined how to value Belgacom, which is not listed on the stock market, said a KPN spokesman, Marinus Potman. Other companies believed to be interested in Belgacom include Deutsche Telekom and Vivendi Universal of France. ''If Belgacom does a deal with a bigger player it will become an affiliate. We are the only ones offering Belgacom the opportunity to be an equal partner,'' Mr. Potman said. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: How Bad Luck Tipped the Scales to Disaster
description: In March 1912, two months after reaching the South Pole, Capt. Robert F. Scott froze to death in a tent just 11 miles from a depot of food and heating oil.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGUIRE, AUGUSTUS S. CSP
description: McGUIRE-Augustus S. CSP. On August 27, 2001 at age 69. Born in Nashau, NH, he was ordained a Paulist priest in 1959. His assignments included nineteen years in Toronto, Canada, seven years in Houston, TX, eleven years at Good Shepherd Parish in New York, NY, and the past six years in Clemson, SC. Fr. Gus was fluent in Spanish and Italian which served him well in his assignments. He was awarded two Master's degrees from St. Joseph's, Dunwoodie, New York. He is survived by brothers John and Robert and his sister Lucy Ann Phillips. Viewing will be at Saint Paul the Apostle Church in Seneca, SC at 6:30 p.m. on Wednesday, August 29, 2001 followed by a Mass of Christian Burial at 7:30 p.m. Burial will be at the Sparkman Hillcrest Cemetery, Northwest Highway, Dallas, TX at 1:30 p.m. on Friday, August 31, 2001.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, IDA RUSS
description: SCHWARTZ-Ida Russ. One of the daughters of NYC's famous Russ & Daughters appetizer store, died on August 24, 2001, at the age of 86, in Pembroke Pines, Florida. Ida and her sisters, Hattie and Anne, were the daughters of Joel Russ, who opened his appetizer store in 1914. Having no sons, he named the Houston Street business Russ & Daughters. Ida worked in the business for many years, before opening her own store in Massapequa in 1954, and then going into the antique business. Mrs. Schwartz is survived by her daughter, Lorraine Commanday of Charlottesville, Virginia, and her son, Martin Russ Pulvers, and granddaughter, Sarita of Mountainview, Calif., and her sisters, Hattie Gold and Anne Federman, both of Pembroke Pines, FL.

description: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell will not attend a United Nations conference on racism and it is possible that the United States will boycott the gathering, which opens Friday in South Africa, his spokesman said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARBOUR, FREDERICA P. (NEE PISEK)
description: BARBOUR-Frederica P. (nee Pisek), 97. On August 17, 2001 at the Quadrangle, Haverford, PA (since 1989). Formerly of Manhattan and Nashville. Editor, educator, activist for education, wife, mother, friend and inspiration to many. Parents: Godfrey R. and Rosalie (Paul) Pisek. Lincoln School, NYC; Vassar College (PBK), 1925. Married to Franklin Field, 1926-33; Alvan L. Barach, 1933-1977; James C. Barbour, 1979-1982. Sons: Jeffrey Alvan Barach, New Orleans; John Paul Barach, Nashville. Grandchildren: Andrea Barach Schine, David J. Barach, Jeffrey Barach, Jr., and five great-grandchildren. Editor, Review of Reviews; Editorin-Chief, Golden Book Magazine; teacher, creative writing, Sarah Lawrence College; OWI Liaison and Executive Secretary, Writers War Board; Assistant Professor English, Barnard College; Trustee and Board Chairman, Public Education Association; Board, United Negro College Fund; Trustee and Board Chairman, Vassar College; Trustee and Board Chairman, Bank Street College of Education; Board, Yorkville Civic Council. Who's Who in America 1975. Clubs: Cosmopolitan; University.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Arrests In Killings
description: The police yesterday announced the arrests of three people charged with killing a Bronx couple in 1996 with their three children present. Shortly after the crime, the eldest child, a boy of 6, calmly called police as his 4- and 5-year-old siblings cried in the background. Detectives arrested Keisha Washington, 27, and Denise Henderson, 34, in July, and Kevin Washington, 26, on Thursday, the police said. It was not known if the Washingtons were related. All three were charged with second-degree murder and robbery. The police were also looking for a fourth man, Robert Mitchell, 26. The four fatally shot and stabbed Esteban Martinez, 29, and Linda Leon, 23, during a robbery in Parkchester, the police said. Daniel J. Wakin (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Thailand: Phone Concern Surges
description: Stock in Advanced Info Service, which serves more than half of Thailand's mobile phone users, surged to a five-year high on optimism it would post a record profit. Advanced Info Service, controlled by the family of Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra, left, rose 20 baht, or 4.3 percent, to 490 baht ($11), the highest level since 1996. Advanced Info said last week that it added a record number of subscribers for a fourth consecutive month in July. It has 3.27 million total subscribers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPELON, ESTHER GOLD MILIKOWSKY
description: COPELON-Esther Gold Milikowsky died on August 26th. She was born in New Haven, Ct. on April 27, 1919. She was the youngest of six children of Jacob Lyon & Sarah Freida Meltzer Gold. Her father was in the wholesale dairy business in New Haven which he started after emigrating from Minsk, Russia several years before her birth. In 1934 the family lived their dream of making aliyah to Palestine to help create a Jewish state. Her father worked the land as a farmer in Herzeliya where Esther grew up. Esther met her husband Matthew Milikowsky in Herzeliya and they were married in 1938. Their first son Nathan was born in Tel Aviv. In 1946 they came to New Haven. Their daughter Michelle (Mady) & son Daniel were born in New Haven. Esther was an integral part of the Jewish community, was asked to join many charitable boards, and became a leader at Hadassah, Brandeis, Technion, the Jewish Theological Seminary, the New Haven Hebrew Day School, & the Jewish Museum of New York. Over the years, she was honored by many of these organizations. Matthew died in 1969 and in 1976 she married Herman Copelon. They spent winters in Palm Beach, FL, where she also became involved in many Jewish organizations, and each summer they returned to New Haven. She is survived by her husband Herman H. Copelon, her children Nathan & Rebecca Milikowsky of Chestnut Hill, Ma., Danny & Sharon Milikowsky of New Haven, Ct., Mady & Sandy Harman of Manhattan, and stepdaughter Rhonda Copelon of Brooklyn. She is also survived by her grandchildren; Brina & Shira Milikowksy, Matthew, Jonathan, & Jennifer Milikowsky, and Matthew & Jamie Harman, & her sister Harriet Goodman of London, England. Esther was the sister of the late Rhea Zimmerman of Manhattan, Leah Fein of Ct., Rose Reina of San Mateo, Ca., & Solomon Gold of Manhattan. She is survived by many loving sisters-inlaw, brothers-in-law, & nieces & nephews. Funeral services at Cong. B'nai Jacob, 75 Rimmon Rd., Woodbridge, Ct. Tuesday afternoon at 2:00 o'clock with interment services to follow in the B'nai Jacob Memorial Park, Wintergreen Ave., New Haven. Any contributions offered in her memory should be sent to The Esther Milikowsky Copelon Fund at the New Haven Hebrew Day School, 261 Derby Ave., Orange, Ct. 06477. Shiva will be observed at the home of Sharon & Dan Milikowsky, New Haven, thru Friday. For information Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, New Haven.

title: Technology Briefing | Games: Vivendi To Distribute Games
description: Vivendi Universal has acquired exclusive rights to distribute new video games from Interplay Entertainment, the North American unit of Titus Interactive of France. Titus, the maker of Dark Alliance and other games, is trying to shed marketing and distribution costs after Interplay last week reported a first-half loss of $20.8 million. Characterizing the deal with Vivendi as the first step toward reorganizing its North American subsidiary, Titus said the agreement would save roughly $10 million a year. The contract excludes Never Winter Nights, which will continue to be distributed by Infogrames in North America, Titus said.

American drug-enforcement authorities have praised Mexico for arresting and extraditing an increasing number of criminal suspects wanted in the United States. Tim Weiner (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Economy: Cell Phone Shipments Slow
description: Growth in cell phone shipments will slow to 3 percent this year from 43 percent last year, as makers like Motorola, Ericsson, and Nokia ship fewer phones, the market researcher IDC said in a report yesterday. Carriers failed to upgrade networks for faster Internet access in 2001 because of higher-than-expected costs for licenses and equipment, while phone makers did not understand the related technical challenges, IDC said, making it hard to predict growth. IDC said it expected 412 million phones to be shipped worldwide this year, rising to 672 million in 2005.

title: Shakespeare Finds a New Habitation in the Berkshires
description: The ''rude mechanicals'' of Shakespeare's ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' are builders, carpenters, tailors, weavers. They are the kind of figures who work backstage, costuming actors, constructing sets, keeping the drama's machinery in repair. So when they plan to present a play to celebrate their duke's wedding, they focus on mechanical stagecraft, on how to represent a wall or on how to create the play's requisite moonlight. They even consider checking an almanac to see if the real moon will be shining on the night of the performance. They finally settle on crude illusion: a man holding a lantern.

title: Drought Creates Food Crisis For Much of Central America
description: A merciless and stubborn summer drought has left almost 1.5 million of the poorest farmers in Central America with no crops to sell or food to eat.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Security Council Aide
description: The White House announced the appointment of Anna M. Perez as head of communications for the National Security Council. Ms. Perez, 50, served as press secretary to Barbara Bush from 1989 to 1993 and then moved to Los Angeles, where she handled media relations at the Creative Artists Agency Inc., and later became a vice president for government relations at the Walt Disney Company, the White House said. title: CHRYSLER TO INTRODUCE FOUR LOWER-PRICED MINIVANS
description: The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler announced yesterday that it would add four lower-priced minivan models by October. The 2002 models, to begin production next month, are the Chrysler Voyager eC, Dodge Caravan eC, Chrysler Town & Country eL and Dodge Grand Caravan eL, the Chrysler Group said. With the additions, Chrysler will have 21 minivan models. Chrysler is the largest seller of minivans, though it faces increasing competition. It has reported sales of 270,179 minivans in the United States in the first seven months of this year, down 10 percent from the period a year ago.

description: A federal appeals court panel ruled unanimously today that the admissions policy of the University of Georgia, which gives a slight preference in bonus points to nonwhite applicants, was unconstitutional.

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Cuts Its Debt
description: Nextel Communications, the wireless telephone company controlled by Craig McCaw and AT&T Wireless Services, said yesterday that it would cut its debt load $857 million by exchanging bonds from its Nextel International affiliate for 21.6 million shares of Nextel common stock. The terms of the debt reduction are quite favorable to Nextel. At its current stock price, the company is exchanging less than $300 million of its stock to retire over $850 million of debt. The company said the extraordinary gain, which it will record in its third quarter, was due to the substantial discount of the exchange relative to the book value of the senior notes. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: RYDER SYSTEM WINS A NEWSPAPER DISTRIBUTION CONTRACT
description: The truck-leasing company Ryder System said yesterday that it had received a multiyear contract to manage delivery of The Los Angeles Times from printing plants to distribution centers. The financial terms were not disclosed. Ryder, based in Miami, said that it would provide vehicles, drivers and fleet management and maintenance services. The newspaper had been handling its distribution. Ryder said it provides similar services to The Chicago Tribune, The Dallas Morning News and The Miami Herald.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Camera Stores Close
description: Wolf Camera has closed the two sleek stores it opened only last year on Manhattan's Upper East Side, on 86th Street near Lexington Avenue and on Third Avenue and 69th Street. But a third Wolf Camera, a former Westside Camera store that has been at Broadway and 88th Street for 29 years, will remain in business, possibly under another name, said Stephen M. LaMastra, an executive vice president of Wolf. The Atlanta-based Wolf Camera, founded in 1974, filed for bankruptcy protection in June and announced last week that it was seeking court approval to merge with its chief competitor, Ritz Camera, based in Beltsville, Md. Mr. LaMastra attributed the company's financial problems to its acquisition of 450 Fox Photo and CPI Photo stores in 1998.

title: Conservative Group Joins Effort To Bring Charges Against Condit

title: California Maps Network of Open Space as Animal Lifeline
description: The bobcat looked stunned, as if it had been caught in the glare of headlights. It had just been startled by a research camera's flash, triggered by an infrared sensor, as it traveled through the Tenaja corridor, one of the tenuous natural stretches connecting wildlife habitats in California.

title: List of Stem Cell Researchers Shows Hands Had Been Tied
description: An unexpected new order of world powers has emerged, at least in the field of human embryonic stem cell research. The roster, say scientists who back the research, is evidence of the inventiveness of the newcomers but also shows how much the usual powerhouses of biomedical research in the United States and Europe have been held back by political and ethical debate.

title: Guard the Secrets, Then Catch the Spies
description: Last Thursday, when Brian P. Regan entered a metal detector at Dulles airport in Washington, he held a high security clearance and worked at one of the nation's most sensitive intelligence agencies. Before he could reach his plane he was under arrest for conspiracy to commit espionage. Grabbed by the Federal Bureau of Investigation as he was about to board a flight to Switzerland, Mr. Regan became the latest in a long line of people accused of marketing America's deepest secrets -- in this case, according to news reports, to Libya.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TOPPS CO., New York, maker of baseball trading cards and Bazooka bubble gum, said it had acquired thePit.com, White Plains, which operates an online trading exchange, for $5.7 million in cash to expand in the sports trading cards market.

title: The Big City; Scooping Up For Civility, Or $5 Bribes
description: CAN New Yorkers be bribed to behave?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Death In Chechnya
description: Land mines exploded on Sunday and yesterday at two places in the center of Chechnya's capital, Grozny, killing 5 police officers and wounding 14 others, the Interfax news agency reported. The explosions followed a blast in an outdoor market in Gudermes, a nearby city that served as Chechnya's wartime capital until this year, that killed 3 people and wounded 11. Although Russian troops exercise nominal control over Chechnya, such incidents are almost daily occurrences as the war with separatist rebels enters its third year with no end in sight. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Canada Shuts Atlantic Coal Mines for Efficiency
description: Alex Morrison has seen horrifying things in his two decades in and around the Cape Breton mines. But nothing spooked him more than watching the first freighter of imported coal dock here, right in the heart of Canada's coal country.

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Grants Held Back
description: Gov. Don Sundquist plans to eliminate some state grants and withhold parts of others to protect the state's precariously balanced budget against lower-than-anticipated revenues. Programs affected include libraries, incentive pay for law enforcement officers, school safety programs and public television stations. The state budget was passed this month over the veto of Mr. Sundquist, a Republican who has said that tax increases are needed to put the state on firm fiscal footing. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Feaster Regains Form to Lead Sting
description: At the start of the W.N.B.A. season, Allison Feaster, a 5-foot-11-inch forward the Charlotte Sting acquired last October from the Los Angeles Sparks, was struggling with her shot. Her range and rhythm and timing were off. Her confidence faded with each air ball.

Goodkind Labaton Rudoff & Sucharow LLP

title: SAT Scores Aren't Up. Not Bad, Not Bad at All.
description: THE College Board released its annual SAT report yesterday. Average scores, math and verbal combined, were 1020, barely higher than a quarter-century ago. The other college testing service, the ACT, has also announced a stable average score, of 21 (equivalent to about 990 on the SAT).

title: Former Official Of City Union Is Sentenced In Vote Rigging
description: A former top official at District Council 37, New York City's largest municipal labor union, was sentenced yesterday to one and a third to four years in jail for helping to rig a 1996 contract ratification vote.

description: What do you get when Quincy Jones, Ossie Davis, Don King, Percy Sutton, Nate Archibald, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, Max Roach, Gloria Lynne, Ornette Coleman and Harry Belafonte put their heads together?

title: Warning: Don't Try to Crush These Cartons
description: My mother would never put a carton of milk or juice on the table: they were decanted into pitchers. I have the same habit, which is why I welcome Chiasso sleek stainless steel carton holders with rubber handles. The metal also helps keep the liquid cold. The cartons come in pint size ($24), quart size ($28) and half-gallon ($30). To keep the weight down, the half-gallon carton holder is actually stainless steel over aluminum. The holders are available from (800) 654-3570 or www.chiasso.com. Shipping is extra. There are Chiasso stores in cities around the country, including Boston and Short Hills, N.J., but there are none in Manhattan.

title: Israeli Army Captures Buildings In Palestinian West Bank Town
description: Israeli tanks and soldiers took control of parts of this Palestinian town south of Jerusalem today in an operation that Israel called necessary to protect its citizens but that Palestinian officials denounced as a ''reoccupation'' of areas supposedly under their control.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the New York City Board of Education's plan to replace ethnic programming with classical music on its radio station, WNYE-FM (91.5), referred incorrectly to another station, cited by opponents of the change as an example of an outlet where such music is already available. The station, affiliated with The New York Times, is WQXR-FM (96.3), not AM.

description: ALMOST

title: Government Asks Court to Speed Up Microsoft Case
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 29  The new federal judge presiding over the Microsoft ( news/quote ) antitrust suit today ordered the parties to meet with her on Sept. 21 to discuss the status of the case.

title: City Will Close Office Running Foster Program
description: New York City's child welfare commissioner said yesterday that he would close the city office that directly runs foster homes in Manhattan and Staten Island because it had scored at the bottom of a systemwide performance evaluation -- far below the worst-performing nonprofit foster care agency under contract to the city.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: New President's Plight
description: On a visit to Malaysia, President Megawati Sukarnoputri said she was ashamed to have to beg for economic aid from neighboring countries. ''If I were an ostrich, I would bury my head in the sand in shame,'' she said. ''Can you imagine how it feels asking help from your neighbors when you come from a country said to be the biggest in the region, and with the most potential?'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Old Feuds, Not Policy Disputes, Put Bite in a Bronx Race
description: The two candidates agree on virtually all the issues. Whether the subject is the need for new schools, the obligation of the city government to make health care more widely available or their resolve to improve sanitation services, there are few if any differences.

title: Attacked by Mayor, Hevesi Runs as the Anti-Giuliani
description: Alan G. Hevesi released a new television commercial yesterday, the sixth in his campaign for mayor.

title: Trouble for Seed Company
description: The Delta and Pine Land Company, a leading cotton-seed company, said today that it would take a charge of $6 million in its fiscal fourth quarter for job cuts and a plant closing and announced that its president had resigned. The company, based in Scott, said it would lay off 50 of its 700 workers and close a plant in Chandler, Ariz. The president and chief operating officer, Steven Hawkins, resigned and Murray Robinson, chief executive and vice chairman, has assumed the president's post. Shares of Delta and Pine fell 72 cents, or 3.5 percent, to $20.03.

title: Elizabeth Parkinson Cobb, 93; Helped Shape Modern Museum
description: Elizabeth Bliss Parkinson Cobb, a vital and effective presence at the Museum of Modern Art in New York for nearly 70 years, died on Aug. 24 in Hightstown, N.J. She was 93 and lived in Hightstown.

Proud grandmother of Matthew and Annabel Schaenen, Jennifer and Alexandra Laptook, Zachary and Sydney Susskind. The family wishes to acknowledge the loving care given by Dr. Flavia A. Golden and the entire staff of 5 West at New York Presbyterian Hospital. Services private.

title: Penalties Urged for Hiring of Migrant Workers
description: Four months after Suffolk County lawmakers defeated a proposal to open a hiring hall for the immigrant day laborers who stand along county roads each morning waiting for work, one legislator has proposed another solution: penalizing contractors who hire undocumented workers.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Women's Aid Leader Honored
description: Chanthol Oung, 34, who leads a women's aid group called the Cambodian Women's Crisis Center, became the first recipient of a new annual Ramon Magsaysay Award for emergent leadership. The Magsaysay awards, which are known as Asia's version of the Nobel Prize, honor achievement in various fields. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: Blake Learns From Experience
description: James Blake went to dinner with a couple of heavy hitters before the Open began. Jim Courier and Todd Martin talked to Blake about their work ethic, their path to championships. Blake, the 21-year-old Yonkers native who left Harvard after his sophomore year to become a professional, listened like a serious student.

title: Little League Team Celebrates Under Cloud
description: As the Rolando Paulino All-Stars received glittering keys to New York yesterday from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on the steps of City Hall, the Dominican government started an investigation into why there are apparently two conflicting birth records for the team's ace pitcher, Danny Almonte.

title: Lehman Names a New Provost
description: ANTHONY J. GARRO, the former vice dean of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, has become provost and vice president for academic affairs at Lehman College. Dr. Garro, a microbiologist who studies cancer and birth defects associated with alcohol abuse, was a professor at City College and director of microbiology at its Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education. Dr. Garro also competed and finished in the New York City triathlon this month. He succeeds ROSANNE WILLE as Lehman's provost. Karen W. Arenson

Reposing at the Hodder Funeral Home, 899 McLean Avenue, Yonkers, NY, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, August 29 and 30. Funeral Mass at St. Barnabas Church, Bronx, New York, Friday, August 31 at 10:30 AM. Interment at Arlington National Cemetery, September 5 at 9 A.M.

description: Opening a new debate over the process to expand the pool of Internet names, Sun Microsystems has moved to prevent others from registering dozens of names for which the company says it has trademark claims.

title: Graves of the Missing Haunt Sri Lanka
description: CHEMMANI CHECKPOINT, Sri Lanka  The bones of 15 people, most bearing marks of blunt trauma, have been unearthed from hidden graves around this desolate military checkpoint, where soldiers fighting local rebels had beaten the victims to death and buried them.

title: Willing to Do Messy Work
description: When I was about 8 years old, my father put me to work testing the honesty of clerks in stores. This was back in 1949, when they had those big cash registers, and my job was to go into a store and buy something.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hauppauge: Heart Machines
description: A Suffolk County legislator introduced legislation yesterday that would vastly expand the county's use of emergency technology to correct dangerously irregular heartbeats. Machines known as automated external defibrillators would be made available in county schools, parks, police cars, golf courses and other public facilities. Andrew A. Crecca, Republican of Hauppauge, cited the death last year of Louis Acompora, 14, a lacrosse player who died after a ball struck his chest. A defibrillator on the field might have shocked his heart back to a correct rhythm, Mr. Crecca said. A spokesman for the Suffolk County executive said the proposal's costs and legal implications would have to be studied. Al Baker (NYT)

title: Singer Is Mourned and Celebrated in Detroit
description: As people here began recovering from the shock of the singer Aaliyah's death, they started to realize today how much she meant to their own self- image and their hopes for their city.

title: Economists Back Projection That It Will Be Necessary to Dip Into Social Security Surplus
description: New budget projections from Congressional analysts and the White House show that the Bush administration and Congressional leaders are almost certain to violate their promise not to dip into the Social Security surplus to pay the government's bills, prominent economists said today.

title: Job Cuts Hurt Confidence Of Consumers
description: Consumer confidence fell in August to the lowest level in four months, a survey showed today, suggesting that the economy may struggle to rebound after a yearlong period of the weakest growth in a decade.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Rescue Plan
description: The government-controlled Korea Exchange Bank has proposed a new rescue plan for Hynix Semiconductor that would cover at least $4 billion of the company's debts. The plan calls for swapping approximately $3 billion of the company's debts for equity and rolling over the rest. Hynix has said it will not issue new bonds to cover those that are maturing. One reason is that Korea's investment trust companies are resisting exposure to more of the company's debt. Another may be that the government-owned Korea Development Bank, which also buys Hynix bonds, is sensitive to United States charges that the company is surviving in part on government subsidies. Hynix creditors are expected to decide on the rescue plan this week.

title: Hevesi Takes Giuliani Fight To Airwaves
description: Alan G. Hevesi released the first negative television commercial of the mayoral campaign yesterday, attacking not his rivals for the Democratic mayoral nomination but the lame-duck Republican incumbent he is seeking to succeed -- Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: FOLLOWING MOODY'S, S.& P. LOWERS SAKS DEBT RATINGS
description: The debt ratings of Saks Inc. were lowered yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, a day after Moody's Investors Service downgraded the retailer, on concern the company will have trouble increasing profit in the slowing economy. S.& P. cut Saks's corporate credit rating and senior unsecured debt to BB from BB+, or two notches below investment grade.

title: Two Veteran Kickers To Work Out for Giants
description: The Giants' kicking situation will get a lot more competitive Wednesday when Brad Daluiso, the team's former kicker, and Morten Andersen, a free agent, work out at the practice facility at Giants Stadium.

title: Cowboys and Indians Vie, Politely, for a Museum; A Los Angeles Collection Considers Two Suitors
description: It is hard to avoid an almost electrical surge of emotion when browsing in the storerooms of the Southwest Museum here, which has one of the country's leading collections of American Indian artifacts. The floors are concrete and the shelves cold steel, but everywhere there are signs of a vivid, hand-crafted world humming with an inner life, lost but for many of these objects.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Detective Sues Chief
description: A detective who accused police officers of misconduct in a murder investigation has filed a federal lawsuit against the New Haven chief of police, Melvin H. Wearing, left. The officer, Keith Wortz, claims the department retaliated against him after he reported that his colleagues had hindered his investigation into a 1996 murder. One officer is awaiting trial and others have been reprimanded in connection with Officer Wortz's allegations. Asked about the lawsuit, Chief Wearing replied, ''That's what he says.'' Hope Reeves (NYT)

description: ROSEN-Dora. Of White Plains, NY, on August 24, 2001. Beloved wife of Seymour. Mother of Barry, Beth and Howard. Grandmother of Marin, Evan, Eitan and Eliana.

description: The good news about Hubbard Street Dance Chicago is that its dancers are as sleek, personable and technically adept as ever. The less happy news is that the company, which performed on Saturday night at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in the Berkshires, seems to be moving in the direction of gimmick-driven choreography.

title: European Panel Approves Takeover of Montedison
description: The European Commission approved the takeover of the Italian power company Montedison by Italenergia, a holding company led by the Fiat Group, today after a routine one-month investigation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOLLAND, GAVIN JOHN

McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 7 to 9 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial, Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, Pelham Manor on Thursday, August 30 at 10 AM.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Prostate Surgery For McCain
description: Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who battled a malignant form of skin cancer last year, will undergo surgery today to remove part of a benign but enlarged prostate. The problem, discovered in a quarterly checkup on Aug. 17, was unrelated to his skin cancer. It had led to bladder stones and blood in the bladder. Mr. McCain was declared free of cancer after the checkup. The senator, who turns 65 today, will undergo the surgery at the Mayo Clinic Hospital in Phoenix, and is expected to stay there for one to two days.

title: The Restaurant That Launched a Thousand Chefs
description: THE great French restaurants that once dominated the New York food scene, rigidly formal places like Le Pavillon and La Cte Basque, could not have a more unlikely successor than the River Caf, a restaurant literally floating on a barge under the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUSHNER, JOSEPH M.
description: KUSHNER-Joseph M., 93. Died at his home in Bay Harbor Islands, Florida on August 26th, 2001. He is survived by his wife of 71 years Lillian; children James and Mary Kushner of Salt Lake City, Utah and Barbara and Samuel Cantor of Provincetown, MA; granddaughters Cathy, Constance, Jane and Nina; great-grandchildren: Sunny, Michael, Gregory and James. title: Posada Plays On Despite Painful Toe
description: Jorge Posada never thought that he would miss any games because of his injured left big toe. Even if he had broken the toe, Posada said, he would still have been able to play. But Posada and the Yankees were still relieved that X-rays on the toe were negative and that he could catch without much pain against the Toronto Blue Jays last night.

description: IN the 1980's, I tried roasting just about everything. It was an experimental phase. I liked the way roasting concentrated flavors and deepened colors, and the nice touch of browning it added around the edges. I even tried roasting a whole head of cabbage.

description: The Bush administration is engaged in a strenuous effort to influence the agenda of a special United Nations conference next month on the rights of children so that the session's final declaration does not appear to lend support for abortion counseling, American and United Nations officials said today.

description: The United States will impose duties up to 215 percent on imports of a type of coke from China that is used by American iron foundries to make products ranging from car and truck engine blocks to cast-iron sewer pipes.

title: A Coffee Crisis' Devastating Domino Effect in Nicaragua
description: With no land and no work, thousands of coffee-field hands here can plant only one thing: themselves, on the roadside, as they beg for food, jobs or attention to their needs.

title: Technology Briefing | Economy: The Ranks Are Thinner
description: Job cuts at dot-com companies fell to a 12-month low in August, with 4,899 announced through Aug. 27, compared with 8,697 jobs cut in July, according to the job firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. But with 21 dot-com companies shutting down in August, up from 9 closings in July, the decrease in layoffs was tempered by the industry's continuing troubles. Since January, dot-coms have announced 87,795 job cuts, more than double the number of cuts announced in all of 2000. John A. Challenger, chief executive of the company, said in a release: ''The decline in job cuts may not necessarily be an indication of an imminent turnaround. It is more likely that dot.com firms are running out of employees to cut.''

title: Barnard Caters to Its Commuters
description: Never let it be said that Barnard College does not care about its commuting students -- all 16 of them in the freshman class of 540 women. Barnard's new student orientation program, which is going on now through Monday, is providing commuters a series of social events, an intimate lunch with their own dean and even a slumber party at the top of Sulzberger Hall.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: Deportation Sought
description: Authorities have asked a federal judge to order the deportation of an Egyptian teacher linked to a terrorist group responsible for the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in Africa. Intelligence service documents say the man, Mahmoud Jaballah of Toronto, belongs to the terrorist group Al Jihad and was repeatedly in contact with members who played a role in the deadly attacks. Authorities say they have more information about Mr. Jaballah, who was held in 1999 on similar charges that were later dropped for lack of evidence. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, ROBERT D.
description: LANE-Robert D. Peacefully, after a struggle with cancer, August 28, at 76 years. Survived by his wife Ro, his sons Bob, Rich and Skip, daughters-in-law Pat and Margaret, grandchildren Becca, Mason, Adam and Eric. Former president of Hygrade Printing Corp., he served as president of IBFI/PIA, chairman of the board of the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York (now, Assn. of Graphic Communications) and leader of, or advisor to, many organizations including the YPO and the Junior Achievement Program of New York. title: OTIS ELEVATOR PLANS TO CUT JOBS IN INDIANA AND MEXICO
description: The Otis elevator unit of the United Technologies Corporation plans to cut as many as 580 jobs at plants in Indiana and Mexico as it consolidates production of high-rise elevators and cuts costs. Otis, the biggest elevator maker, will stop production at a Mexico City plant that makes parts for low- and midrise elevators. Work will be moved to Nogales, Mexico, or contracted outside the company, a spokesman, Mark Granato, said. United Technologies, based in Hartford, said last month that it might close some plants tied to lower order volume. Otis is based in Farmington, Conn.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Oregon: Higher Toll From Shipwreck
description: A federal report shows that the environmental damage from the grounding of a freighter on the Oregon coast in 1999 was much greater than thought. Scientists now say oil from the wreckage of the freighter, the New Carissa, killed 2,358 birds, including 262 marbled murrelets, an endangered species. Larry Mangan, a biologist with the United States Bureau of Land Management in Coos Bay, said the government hoped to gain money for restoring the coastline from a lawsuit against the ship's owners. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Across the River and Back to Basics
description: NOTHING could have been simpler or better than an appetizer of cacciatorino with mozzarella and roasted peppers ($6.50). Thin slices of the earthy cacciatorino, a dried sausage, went beautifully with the pillowy, nutty-tasting mozzarella, and the tart sweetness of the peppers was a refreshing counterpoint.

title: Playing Roles of Candidates in Search of a Difference
description: The conventional wisdom portrays the Democratic candidates for mayor as barely distinguishable from one another. But yesterday, during their third debate, all of them subtly but distinctly displayed differences in style, if not substance, by hewing closely to the character roles they have developed for the campaign trail.

description: The Lab That Shot to the Top of the Charts, turning out to have more embryonic stem cells than anyone else, is actually a warm little closet in Building 9A of Sahlgrenska University Hospital here.

title: Hot, Hotter and Hottest, All in One Package
description: A clever package of chili peppers, in red, green, orange and yellow, makes up a primer of heat. There are 8 to 10 of them in a small plastic box. It has a chart on the back, which serves as a guide to their fire, from the mildest skinny Dutch chilies and Thai chilies to the hottest habaneros. Each of them will be milder if the seeds are discarded. It's a good idea to wear rubber or plastic gloves when cutting the chilies, or put plastic sandwich bags over your hands, because their oils can sting and should not come in contact with your eyes or hands. The chili kits are $1.99 at Agata & Valentina, 1505 First Avenue (79th Street), and $3.98 at Jerry & David's Red Horse Market, Montauk Highway, East Hampton, N.Y.

title: Farewell in Salzburg (Hold the Schmaltz)
description: After 10 tumultuous, transformative years as artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, Gerard Mortier has delivered his last two new opera productions, which will be playing in repertory until his last festival ends on Aug. 31.

title: U.S. Asks Israel To Pull Troops From Town In West Bank
description: The Bush administration urged Israel today to withdraw its forces from Beit Jala, in the West Bank, but the Israeli Defense Ministry announced that its troops would stay indefinitely.

title: Cendant Shareholders' Lawyers Dealt a Setback
description: Lawyers representing shareholders in a securities class-action lawsuit against the Cendant Corporation were dealt a blow yesterday when the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit upheld a $3.2 billion settlement but tossed out $262 million in legal fees.

description: Personal Touch for Kerik

title: EM.TV SAYS KIRCH HAS DROPPED PLAN TO BUY A STAKE
description: EM.TV and Merchandising A.G. of Germany, the unprofitable owner of the Muppets, said Kirch Holding, the company that led its bailout last year, abandoned a plan to buy a stake on antitrust concerns. The stock lost 15 percent. The two companies yesterday withdrew their application for antitrust approval of Kirch's plan to take a 25 percent voting stake. EM.TV, which wants to focus on children's television programs, will now have to find new ways to pay for Kirch's 50 percent stake in their ''Junior'' TV joint venture, analysts said.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Bomb Threat Disrupts Lawmakers
description: A bomb threat forced state lawmakers to evacuate the legislative building in Raleigh on Monday night as the House prepared to vote on a plan to raise $1 billion in taxes over the next two years. No bomb was found, but House and Senate leaders, standing on steps of a museum across the street from the building, adjourned their houses for the night. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Chocolate Memories of the Czars and Rasputin
description: One of the first lessons Alexandra and Nicolay Mazhirov learned when they came to the United States was that they had to think big. Mrs. Mazhirov had owned a small chocolate factory in Odessa, Russia, and her husband was its manager. They came to New York in 1992 and five years ago started selling chocolates to the Russians in Brooklyn, from a little storefront at 6502 20th Avenue in Bensonhurst.

title: A creative executive, formerly of Kirshenbaum Bond, moves to Ogilvy & Mather in New York.
description: A LEADING creative executive is joining the New York office of a giant agency.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Opposition Figure Flees To U.S.
description: A prominent member of Uganda's opposition said he fled from Kampala to Washington because he feared for his life. Kizza Besigye, left, a former aide to President Yoweri Museveni, sought to unseat his former boss in the presidential race earlier this year. Mr. Besigye said that after his court challenge to Mr. Museveni's victory the government trailed him and barred him from leaving Uganda. Mr. Besigye slipped into Kenya on Aug. 17. He vowed to continue his political involvement. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hoping North's Leader Will Visit
description: The visit of China's president, Jiang Zemin, to Pyongyang next week has renewed hopes in Seoul for a visit by North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il. Officials said they expected Mr. Jiang to urge the North Korean to go to Seoul in the interest of North-South reconciliation. South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, and Kim Jong Il met in Pyongyang last year. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Compaq Gets $100 Million Contract
description: Sabre Holdings, the largest distributor of airline reservations data and travel services, said yesterday that it would switch roughly a third of its computer operations from I.B.M. mainframes to the Himalaya line from Compaq Computer over the next three to four years. Sabre expects to install 192 Himalayas in the first phase of the deal, which will generate more than $100 million in revenue for Compaq over the next few years. The Himalayas will gradually take over the task of searching databases for fares, flight availability and schedules, while mainframes continue to handle booking and ticketing. Sabre said the Himalayas would provide substantial savings in maintenance and software development costs and a simpler path for expected expansion.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Steel Maker's Profit Falls
description: The German steel maker ThyssenKrupp, one of the biggest in Europe, lowered its forecast for full-year earnings for the third time after profit again plummeted. The company said third-quarter profit before taxes and a one-time gain through June 30 fell 89 percent, to 44 million euros ($40.1 million) compared with 408 million euros ($372.1 million) a year earlier. ThyssenKrupp also said it no longer expected its sales this year to match last year's. Its shares fell 0.06 euro (5 cents), to 15.16 euros ($13.83).

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Profit Drops At Computer Maker
description: The computer maker Acer said that profit in the second quarter all but evaporated as customers like I.B.M. placed fewer orders. Net income in the three months ended in June fell to $5 million from $84 million a year earlier. The company said it had an operating loss of $18 million in the first half of the year and expected to extend its losses in the third quarter. ''Our strategy is now aimed at minimizing losses, not boosting profit,'' said Philip Peng, the chief financial officer of Acer.

title: Top of the Order, Bottom of the Order
description: As part of The Baseball Report e-mail from The Times on the Web, Buster Olney will rank the eight best -- and worst -- teams in the major leagues based on their performance during the past week.

title: ACCENTURE IN TOKYO OFFERS STAFF UP TO 12 MONTHS' LEAVE
description: Accenture Ltd., the world's largest consulting and project-management company, offered 2,000 staff members in Japan leave on reduced pay as it prepares to cut about 1,500 jobs worldwide. Accenture will allow its employees in Japan to take leave ranging from six and a half months to a year on 30 percent of annual salary for the first four months and 20 percent after five months, a spokeswoman, Ritsuko Onodera, said. Accenture, formerly Andersen Consulting, started its business in Japan 12 years ago. The company offers clients consulting, technology and outsourcing services. The company blamed slowing demand in the United States, where 1,000 consultants will lose their jobs, and a drop in the number of employees retiring or resigning last year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, MORTON R.
description: GOLDMAN-Morton R., 79, of New York City passed away August 27, 2001, after a long illness. He was a W.W. II Veteran serving in North Africa, Italy and Austria as a member of the Psychological Warfare Branch of the U.S. Army. He was CEO of Crestwood Fabrics Inc. He was also associated with Xantex Corporation. With a Master's degree in social work he developed a private practice counseling teenagers. He developed stress management classes utilizing Yoga techiques for Headstart children. He was in great demand as a specialist in this area. He wrote poems and had his art displayed at the 92nd Street ''Y''. Beloved father, grandfather, brother and uncle he leaves behind his daughter Leslie M. Goldman and son-in-law Dr. Matthew Peake, grandsons Jonah and Mattias Goldman-Peake of Saxtons River, VT, sister Florence G. Fisch of Delran, NJ, nephews Matthew Owen Fisch of Needham, MA, David, Andrew and Richard Goldman of Riverdale, NY, nieces Susan M. Bennett of Mt. Laurel, NJ, and Barbara Mae Cole-Kelly of Westfield, NJ. Services will be held Thursday, August 30 at 11:15 AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment to follow at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Family will welcome relatives and friends at 5 PM at 225 W. 86th St, Apt Penthouse G. Memorial contributions may be made to the Compass School, P.O. Box 177, Westminster Station, VT 05159.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHULSKY, RUBIN
description: SHULSKY-Rubin. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff of the Continuum Center for Health and Healing (CCHH) in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Rubin Shulsky, beloved father of our benefactor and former Beth Israel Trustee Rena M. Shulsky. To Rena, her family and all of her father's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees Matthew E. Fink, M.D., President & CEO William Sarnoff, Trustee Liaison, CCHH Woodson C. Merrell, M.D., Executive Director, CCHH

title: Business Travel; Delta's chief generates a debate over airport runways.
description: EARLIER this month, this column was devoted to comments by Leo F. Mullin, the chief executive of Delta Air Lines, who says that we have a national transportation crisis caused by domestic airports' lacking enough runway capacity to handle an annual passenger load that is expected to reach a billion in 2010, from the current 680 million.

title: Two Are Promoted as Enron Seeks Executive Stability
description: With its stock still suffering after the unexpected departure of its chief executive, the Enron Corporation today promoted a top official in its core energy-trading business to be the company's No. 2 executive as it begins finding new leadership.

title: In Rape Case Gone Awry, New Suspect
description: The case of an Oklahoma prisoner recently freed after serving 15 years on a wrongful rape conviction that hinged on a police scientist's testimony took another twist today: Law enforcement officials, citing DNA evidence, announced that an imprisoned sex offender might be the real rapist.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Minsheng Posts Big Profit
description: China Minsheng Banking, the only private lender in China, said its first-half profit rose 90 percent from a year ago as demand from a swelling army of entrepreneurs helped it expand lending more than a third. Net income in the first six months of the year increased to 302.4 million yuan ($36.5 million) from 159.2 million yuan ($19.2 million) a year ago. China Minsheng Banking, based in Beijing and founded in 1996 by a group of China's wealthiest businessmen, reported the biggest rise in earnings among China's three publicly traded banks as it increased lending to private companies, spurning the state-owned businesses that dominate the client lists of its rivals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ULANOV, JOAN BEL GEDDES
description: ULANOV-Joan Bel Geddes, peacefully, in her sleep, New York, July 31, age 84. A memorial service for Joan Bel Geddes Ulanov will be held on Friday, September 7, at 2 PM, at NYU Catholic Center, Washington Square South, NYC. Reception will follow. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to UNICEF, 1-800-FOR-KIDS, or PO Box 96093, Washington, DC 20090, or The Authors Guild, 31 East 28th Street, NY 10016.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I will take them to their grandparents. It is safer there. My kids were scared. Not only them. I'm scared, too.''

title: A Beginner's Guide to Sushi, From Wrapping to Rolling
description: The wrapping, rolling, topping and slicing of sushi are all explained in ''Sushi Made Easy,'' a bright, easy little volume by Michel Gomes, Noel Cottrell and Kumfoo Wong (Sterling Publishing, $12.95). Color pictures show ingredients, equipment and the varieties of sushi, including inside-out rolls and a battleship wrap, in which rice and nori seaweed are molded into an oblong shape (right) with cucumber slivers sticking out at one end. Step-by-step diagrams abound. There are recipes, including one for pickled ginger, and the book even shows how to set a proper Japanese table. When it comes to raw fish, the book falls short, advising that ''if you're going to eat raw fish, it's best to eat it the day it was caught,'' a virtual impossibility unless you are at the shore. Moreover, the only fish the book says is not suitable for sushi is ''soft white fish,'' without being specific about the exact kind. (Never make sushi from freshwater fish.) Use the book for its techniques or for sushi made with cooked seafood or vegetables.

title: Gateway Plans Foreign Cuts And Layoffs
description: Gateway said late yesterday that it would lay off about 5,000 workers, or 25 percent of its work force, and eliminate most overseas operations in an effort to return to profitability by the last quarter of this year.

title: Roche Issues Denial That It Made Offer For Bayer Business
description: Roche Holding A.G. issued a statement today denying reports that it had bid for the pharmaceutical operations of Bayer A.G., the German drug and chemical company.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Envoy Seeks Talks
description: A special United Nations envoy, Razali Ismael, met with the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, and with top leaders of the military government as he continued efforts to broker talks between them. It was his fifth visit to the former Burma this year. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: METALS USA TO SELL SOME UNITS AND CONSOLIDATE OTHERS
description: Metals USA, a processor of metals, will sell its specialty metals and aerospace businesses, integrate eight smaller operations into larger ones and suspend its quarterly cash dividend as part of a plan to reduce debt and costs. It will also sell other unspecified facilities and assets. The plan is expected to increase profit by about $20 million a year and reduce annual interest expenses by about $4 million. The company, which is based in Houston, expects to take a charge of about $66 million in the third quarter for the plan.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Forum On Harlem
description: Harlem community leaders, business executives and real estate brokers will gather tonight to discuss the effects of rising property values on their neighborhood. Titled ''The New Harlem Renaissance: Is it Good for Everyone?'' the forum is being organized by State Senator David A. Paterson, a Harlem Democrat, and is open to the public. It will take place at 6 p.m. in the art gallery of the State Office Building at 163 West 125th Street. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Nursing Home Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL RISES. Crude oil gained ahead of a report expected to show tightening inventories in the United States. In New York, crude oil for October delivery rose 50 cents, or 1.9 percent, to $27.17 a barrel.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bank Profit Is Up
description: A leading Canadian bank, the Bank of Montreal, said its profit rose 14 percent in its most recent quarter, helped by securities trading and electronic banking. Net income in the period ended July 31, the third quarter of the bank's fiscal year, increased to 444 million Canadian dollars ($288.1 million), or 83 Canadian cents (54 cents) a share, from 401 million Canadian dollars ($260.2 million), or 69 Canadian cents (45 cents), a year earlier. Earnings at BMO Nesbitt Burns, the Bank of Montreal's investment firm, rose 21 percent, and profit at the Emfisys electronic-banking unit rose more than fourfold.

title: Agent Becomes G.M. Of the Coyotes
description: Mike Barnett went from player agent to general manager of the Phoenix Coyotes yesterday, replacing Cliff Fletcher as G.M. and joining one his former clients, Wayne Gretzky, the Coyotes' managing partner, in the Phoenix front office.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Suspect Dies In Custody
description: A retired army sergeant, suspected in the assassination last month of a judge who sentenced the fugitive son of former President Suharto to prison, died in police custody of what authorities called a heart attack. The police have accused Mr. Suharto's youngest son, Hutomo Mandala Putra, known as Tommy, of ordering the killing of the judge. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: I.B.M. Realigns Global Assignments
description: I.B.M. is realigning its roster of agencies handling the direct marketing and interactive assignments that are part of its worldwide integrated marketing communications account by naming offices of Ogilvy One Worldwide and Wunderman as its ''global partners'' for those tasks.

title: GRAVES OF MISSING HAUNT SRI LANKA
description: The bones of 15 people, most bearing marks of blunt trauma, have been unearthed from hidden graves around this desolate military checkpoint, where soldiers fighting local rebels had beaten the victims to death and buried them.

Burial was at Wellwood Cemetery in Farmingdale, Long Island in the presence of her many friends, relatives and neighbors.

description: AReality Check for College Rankings

title: Frank Emilio Flynn, 80, Versatile Force in Cuban Music
description: The blind Cuban pianist Frank Emilio Flynn, whose long career connected many tributaries of Cuban jazz, died Thursday at his home in Havana. He was 80, said Ren Lopez, his friend and record producer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUNZ, DONALD
description: KUNZ-Donald, Passed August 24, 2001. The Administration and Faculty of The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art mourn the death of Professor Donald Kunz. Serving the Cooper Union with distinction for 33 years, he enriched the lives of generations of talented students and contributed immensely to the teaching and learning of graphic design. A memorial Mass is scheduled for 10am, Thursday, August 30 at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in Manhattan. Faculty, Staff & Administration The Cooper Union

description: NEW YORK

title: CVS TO PAY $4 MILLION TO SETTLE PRESCRIPTION CHARGES
description: The CVS Corporation has agreed to pay $4 million to settle allegations it submitted false prescription claims, the government said yesterday. CVS and the Revco chain it acquired in 1997 have been accused of dispensing partial prescriptions because of insufficient stock, while billing government health insurance programs for the full quantities prescribed, the Justice Department said. The settlement covers the period between Jan. 1, 1988, and June 1, 1997. The settlement money will go to the federal government, the District of Columbia and 20 states. A portion also will go to settle an individual's complaint against Revco.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVY, ROBERT M.
description: LEVY-Robert M. Passed away on Monday, August 27, 2001 after a valiant fight against lung cancer. He will be deeply mourned by his wife Shirley, his children Andrew and Rani, their spouses Annie and Jack, grandchildren Brianna and Zoe and his brother Arthur and his companion Fred. There will be a graveside service at Hillside Cemetery, Rutherford, NJ on Wednesday, August 29th at 1:00 PM. Shiva will be at home in New York on Wednesday through Friday, and at home in Connecticut Saturday night through Monday.

description: Aetna Inc., the health insurer, has been accused in a suit by a rival, WellPoint Health Networks Inc., of violating an agreement by hiring a WellPoint executive.

description: LUPETIN-Fulvio. Two long years have gone by; our love & memories have been untouched by time. Mom & Dad, Christine & family.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Schools Make Cuts
description: Public schools across the state are being forced to cut budgets and programs, citing a lack of state financing. Because of a property tax cut approved in 1994, some districts whose increases in state aid fell below the inflation rate are cutting teaching positions, increasing class sizes and charging students to compete in sports. The 1994 plan cut school property taxes up to 82 percent, moved the burden of school financing to the state from property owners and tried to even spending among districts. Gov. John Engler, who helped design the tax cut, said the education problems were not the result of a lack of resources. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Alas! Is Nothing Sacred? Even Cubbies' Shrine?
description: For some people here, it is akin to adding a few teeth to Mona Lisa's smile. Or adjusting the Tower of Pisa to fix that lean. Or putting billboards behind the altar at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Justice Dept. Approves Appeal In Case of 5 Orange Policemen
description: Justice Department officials in Washington have given federal prosecutors here the go-ahead to appeal a judge's decision dismissing a jury's conviction of five Orange police officers in the death of a man they mistakenly believed had killed a fellow officer.

title: Its Notorious Past Unearthed, Dump Loses Landmark Status
description: The United States Department of the Interior moved on Monday to make this city's municipal landfill a national historic landmark, but the move was trumped later that day by another designation, a less illustrious one, on the federal Superfund list.

title: National Briefing | Education: Support For Gay Rights
description: American teenagers are more likely than their parents to support the legalization of gay marriage and other protections for gay men and lesbians, a national survey of 1,000 high school seniors has found. The survey, conducted this year by researchers at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., found that two-thirds of the students supported the legal recognition of gay marriage. That compares with about a third of adults in Associated Press and Gallup Organization surveys. More than two-thirds of the teenagers also said gay couples should be permitted to adopt children. Jacques Steinberg (NYT)

title: Intel Insists Faster Chips Can Aid Sales
description: With the chip industry's speed race outpacing mainstream computer uses, a top executive of the Intel Corporation said today that the computer industry must give customers more reasons to spend money on technology.

title: Accord at VW Signals a Shift For Germany
description: Striking a blow against Germany's rigid work rules, Volkswagen reached an agreement today with the country's biggest labor union that should permit VW to demand longer workweeks and higher productivity.

title: Some Cabernets Shout, Some Whisper
description: IN the 1960's, when this country's wine revolution was just getting under way, there were plenty of skeptics who said California could never produce good chardonnay. Almost overnight, it seemed, California's winemakers showed that they could make great chardonnay. Then, to nail down their achievement, they went on to make some of the biggest, most powerful chardonnays the world had ever seen.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Bullet Removed
description: A Palestinian girl brought to the United States from the West Bank to remove a bullet from her brain underwent successful surgery yesterday and is in good condition, doctors at Connecticut Children's Medical Center said. The girl, Marwa Adel al Sharif, 10, was alert and talking to her mother within two hours of the surgery, a hospital spokesman said. The girl was wounded July 17 by a ricocheting bullet in Dubra on the West Bank. Israeli doctors were unable to remove the bullet. A Catholic relief worker paid for air fare for the girl and her mother, a hospital spokesman said. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: Redefining Diversity
description: In ruling on Monday that an affirmative action policy at the University of Georgia was unconstitutional, a federal appeals court panel in Atlanta called on the university and other colleges to expand their thinking about what it means to be diverse.

title: A 6-8 Tough Guy Signs With Rangers
description: The Rangers added considerable size and toughness to their roster yesterday by signing the free-agent Steve McKenna. McKenna, a 6-foot-8 left wing, had only 1 goal and 1 assist in 54 games for Minnesota and Pittsburgh last season but incurred 119 penalty minutes

title: Cowboys and Indians Vie, Politely, for a Museum
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28  It is hard to avoid an almost electrical surge of emotion when browsing in the storerooms of the Southwest Museum here, which has one of the country's leading collections of American Indian artifacts. The floors are concrete and the shelves cold steel, but everywhere there are signs of a vivid, hand-crafted world humming with an inner life, lost but for many of these objects.

title: A Quarterback, a Legacy and a Lot of Pressure to Win
description: When the college football season began a year ago, Notre Dame was coming off a 5-7 record and Coach Bob Davie was hearing doubts about his job security. The Fighting Irish were beginning two years of probation for an embarrassing scandal involving sex and other favors for players. The female booster involved was convicted and jailed for embezzlement from a private business.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Suspect Surrenders
description: The second of three men who the police say robbed guests at gunpoint last week at the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort has surrendered, the authorities said. The suspect, Dana James, 27, of Atlantic City, turned himself in Monday to face charges of armed robbery and other offenses. Mr. James and two accomplices pulled guns during a private card game in a hotel room, tied up the five players and robbed them of $5,000, the police said. The gunmen fled, but a victim fired his weapon at them in the hotel parking area. The police arrested Carlos Cutler, 31, outside the hotel. A third man is still at large. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

description: The Taliban of Afghanistan, whose name comes from talib, ''religious student,'' seem to have declared war on religion.

title: The Clambake, Minus the Beach
description: THERE are few things less minimalist than a real clambake, which takes a whole day and includes among the items for its preparation a shovel, a stack of firewood, a bushel or two of seaweed and a few hundred pounds of good-size rocks. From a recreational and social standpoint, the clambake can be supremely entertaining, and if you want to feed 20, 30 or more people, it's not an entirely inefficient way to do so -- as long as you have plenty of help, plenty of time and a handy beach.

title: Stocks Close Down Sharply on Economic Fears
description: Stocks fell sharply today in a broad-based decline after the government said that United States economic growth for the second quarter remained weak.

title: Mussina Gives Yankees Room To Breathe
description: The chant for Mike Mussina was dormant until a tense sixth inning. Then, like the growing, growling sound of an approaching train, it rumbled throughout Yankee Stadium. As Mussina bent down to work from the stretch position, the fans chanted, ''Moose!'' As Mussina raised his glove, it advanced to ''Mooose!'' As Mussina unleashed the baseball, it evolved to ''Moooose!''

description: HARNETT-Frances. The Board of Directors of The Prescott Fund For Children & Youth mourns the loss of its dear friend and devoted secretary for over 40 years. description: Reducing its dependence on advertising, Vivendi Universal, Europe's leading media company, said today that it would sell its trade and medical publishing businesses to Cinven, a British private equity firm, for $1.8 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SORKIN, NATHAN
description: SORKIN-Nathan. Of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of Manhasset, NY, on August 27, 2001. Lieutenant, U.S. Navy, WW II. Past President, B'nai B'rith-Greater Flushing Chapter. Supporter of UJA-Federation, The Hebrew University of Jerusalem, U.S Holocaust Memorial Museum, National Yiddish Book Center. Co-Founder of Temple Judea, Manhasset, NY. Past President of the Printer's League. Trustee of the Printer's Pension Fund. Loving husband of 62 years to Rosalie Sorkin, father to Ira & Joel, father-in-law to Ellen, grandfather to Roger and Peter. Funeral on Thursday, August 30, 11 AM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery. title: Heart Attack Kills New Firefighter During a Blaze on Staten Island
description: A rookie firefighter helping to battle one of his first major blazes died yesterday afternoon, apparently of a heart attack, minutes after unraveling water hoses during a giant fire at a Staten Island auto repair shop, the authorities said.

title: Resignation at Wet Seal
description: The president and chief operating officer of Wet Seal, a specialty clothing retailer, has resigned after less than three months with the company. Christopher G. Staff and Wet Seal found they were ''not a good fit,'' Kathy Bronstein, the chief executive, said in a statement. They mutually agreed to part, and Ms. Bronstein and Walter Parks, the chief financial officer, will take over Mr. Staff's duties, the company said. Mr. Staff joined the company in June from the Authentic Fitness unit of the Warnaco Group, which makes swimwear and athletic apparel. He replaced Edmond Thomas, who resigned in October. Mr. Parks joined Wet Seal shortly after Mr. Staff to replace Ann Cadier-Kim, who decided to resign.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, ALAN S.
description: GREENSTEIN-Alan S., 47, August 27, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruby. Adored son of Dorothy. Loving brother of Marcy Schulman and Penny Berger, and also survived by cherished pet, Marilyn. For information, Moss-Feaster Funeral Home, Serenity Gardens Chapel, Largo, FL. 727-446-2375.

title: The Bully of Belarus
description: Nothing is more likely to drive a dictatorship to extremes of repression than the threat of a competitive election. That is happening now in Belarus, Europe's last redoubt of Soviet-style tyranny. With the candidate of a unified opposition given a chance of winning an honestly conducted vote next month, President Aleksandr Lukashenko seems determined to crush his critics, while lashing out at the West. It is up to the outside world, primarily the European Union, Russia and the United States, to insist on a free campaign and honest vote count.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISMAN, LEAH
description: WEISMAN - Leah. American Friends of The Hebrew University mourns the passing of Leah Weisman, mother of Rivka Arad and mother-in-law of Ambassador Moshe Arad, Vice-President for External Affairs at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Leah was a fifth generation sabra and died at the age of 91. On behalf of AFHU, we extend our deepest condolences to Rivka and Moshe and the entire family. American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs, Chairman of the Board Adam B. Kahan, Executive Vice President

title: GREEN AND HEVESI EXCHANGE ATTACKS IN MAYORAL DEBATE
description: Mark Green and Alan G. Hevesi tangled over each other's ethics and credentials at a televised mayoral debate yesterday. Mr. Green questioned Mr. Hevesi's role as city comptroller in helping out a campaign contributor four years ago, while Mr. Hevesi mocked Mr. Green, the public advocate, as being unqualified to take over as New York's next mayor.

description: When HAROLD O. LEVY, the New York City schools chancellor, announced in February that the consultants McKinsey & Company would study the Board of Education's administrative structure, he said McKinsey would ''provide its services on a pro bono basis.''

description: Economic growth in the second quarter of the year was even slower than the government had reported initially, the Commerce Department said today in a scheduled revision of its own estimates.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Waterbury: Mayor Makes Deal
description: Waterbury's jailed mayor, Philip A. Giordano, has agreed to a plan that allows him to retain his office at half pay and full benefits until Jan. 1. Andrew B. Bowman, Mr. Giordano's lawyer, signed the agreement yesterday, said Steven Markowski, a spokesman for Waterbury's acting mayor, Sam S. F. Caligiuri. The plan, approved on Monday by the Board of Aldermen, allows the mayor to keep his title while stripping him of virtually every mayoral privilege or power. Last month, Mr. Giordano, 38, was indicted on federal charges that he had lured a child for sex. He denies the charges. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDESBERG, MIRIAM
description: LANDESBERG-Miriam. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Devoted mother of Roy and Lydia Landesberg. Cherished grandmother of Stuart, Edward, Celia Jean and Paige. She was formerly a Hebrew teacher in Great Neck.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: AOL Enters Deal With H&R Block
description: AOL Time Warner said yesterday that it had selected H&R Block to be the exclusive provider of tax preparation services and tax advice within AOL's Tax Center and in Compuserve. The expanded Tax Center will include H&R Block's Online Tax Program, access to the services of a tax professional and H&R's ''Ask a Tax Advisor'' service. Previously, AOL, based in Dulles, Va., had an exclusive agreement with Intuit to provide tax preparation services. As part of the agreement, H&R Block, of Kansas City, Mo., will also market its services across AOL's brands, which now include Time, People and Fortune magazines as well as the TNT and CNN television networks. Also as part of the deal, H&R Block will also offer the AOL online service to its tax clients. AOL officials declined to provide financial terms. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: Debut for Teenager Is Closely Watched
description: Ashley Harkleroad said with an embarrassed giggle afterward that she did not really even see herself in the outfit. Perhaps it was because the meager Lycra material with an abstract pattern of blue and gray squares was so streamlined it seemed wallpapered to her body, clinging like a bathing suit.

title: Angola's Skeptics Are Buzzing as Leader Says He Won't Run
description: The announcement last week by the Angolan president, Jos Eduardo dos Santos, that he will not run in the country's next elections was greeted with surprise and skepticism. Still, in a country where one man has presided for more than two decades and where the political machine operates out of sight, hints of change stir up all sorts of talk.

title: East Takes Center Stage as Yale Focuses on China
description: When the 1,300 Yale seniors assembled in the university's ornate Woolsey Hall for their graduation this year, they did not hear a speech about the moral quandaries facing their generation or the responsibilities they shoulder as Americans. They heard a speech about China.

title: Bush Says Defense Spending to Increase Despite Economic Slowdown
description: SAN ANTONIO, Aug. 29  President Bush vowed today not to let an economic slowdown or an evaporating federal surplus deter him from an increase in the defense budget, beginning work on a missile shield or increasing spending on education.

description: For the first time since 1939, there will not be a supermarket at the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue and 55th Street. A.&P. plans to close the Food Emporium there in September. An investment group led by Earle S. Altman and Steven Hornstock is buying the property, with plans to eventually build an apartment house on the corner. In the meantime, the group is talking to retailers interested in leasing the 25,000-square-foot parcel. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: Using Math in the Real World
description: Twenty-four New York City math teachers can now deftly answer this age-old student question: ''When will I ever use this?'' On Aug. 17, the teachers graduated from Polytechnic University's six-week real-world math program. They studied how mathematics is actually used in finance, industry, management and the physical and life sciences. In addition to classes, the teachers spent Fridays at institutions like Gruntal & Company, the Federal Reserve Bank and the Keyspan Energy Corporation. Stephanie Rosenbloom

description: Football coaches leave little to chance. Schedule a team dinner and one of the assistants might diagram the flow of plates around the buffet table. description: Signaling a more pessimistic outlook for the Canadian economy, the Bank of Canada cut its leading short-term interest rate today by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 4 percent.

description: Catherine Russell's understudy does not get much work. After a year as the backup lead in ''Perfect Crime,'' the longest-running nonmusical show in New York, she has learned not to expect it.

description: It was supposed to be a 15-minute hike in the White Mountains of New Hampshire, about 10 miles from the synagogue that Abraham Hauer managed for the many Orthodox Jews who vacationed in the area.

description: WHEN Ann Amernick sends out a plate of amuse-gueules at Palena, her restaurant in Washington, diners tend to forget their manners and lunge.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Execution Of Killer
description: James Homer Elledge, 58, was executed by injection at the penitentiary in Walla Walla for killing Eloise Fitzner in 1998. Mr. Elledge was the fourth person executed by the state since it reinstated capital punishment 20 years ago. He had asked the governor not to grant him clemency. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

She was a convert to Judaism and her lifelong love of reading led her to build a library at her synagogue. She will be forever loved and greatly missed. With all our hearts - Her family.
