description: Hundreds of ethnic Albanian fighters lined up to hand in their weapons to NATO troops today at a rebel training camp in this village high in the hills above Tetovo, in western Macedonia.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Company To Pay U.S. Fine
description: Ajinomoto, a Japanese food seasoning producer, has agreed to pay the United States Justice Department fines for conspiring to manipulate the price of a food flavor enhancer called nucleotides used in soups, sauces and spices. Ajinomoto, along with two Korean food additives makers, Daesang and Cheil Jedan, agreed to pay a total of $9 million for the violation. Of the amount, Ajinomoto will pay $6 million for its role in the price fixing, which lasted from 1992 to 1996. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Diverging Views About Policing, Race Policy, Taxes and Education
description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate of the Democratic candidates for mayor, as recorded for The New York Times. The debate was organized by the New York City Campaign Finance Board for candidates who receive public money, and was sponsored by WPIX-TV (Channel 11), WNYC-AM Radio (820) and Newsday. It was moderated by Kaity Tong, co-anchor of ''WB11 News at 10.'' The candidates were questioned by Brian Lehrer, host of WNYC's ''On the Line''; Les Payne, deputy managing editor at Newsday; and Jim Watkins, co-anchor of ''WB11 News at 10.''

description: The president of SUNY New Paltz, who was sharply criticized by Gov. George E. Pataki and a university trustee after he defended his campus's right to play host to sex conferences and sexually frank plays, announced yesterday that he would leave next month. The president, Roger W. Bowen, will become president of the Milwaukee Public Museum.

title: The Bolongo Bay Beach Club
description: Through Oct. 31, the Bolongo Bay Beach Club on St. Thomas is cutting $50 to $85 a night off its all-inclusive rates. Prices start at $315 a couple (versus the regular rate of $400); beachfront rooms are $350. The rates include all meals, unlimited drinks, non-motorized watersports equipment, tennis and taxes and tips. For five-night bookings, an all-day sail to St. John aboard a 53-foot catamaran is included. Children up to age 12 can stay in the same room as their parents and eat for free (limit of two children). Information: (800) 524-4746 or www.bolongobay.com .

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: Considering Race For Governor
description: Representative J. D. Hayworth, a four-term Republican from the Sixth Congressional District, said he was considering running for governor next year. That could be bad news for Matt Salmon, the conservative former House member from the First District who is considered the Republican front-runner. Mr. Hayworth, a former television sports reporter, said he would be the sixth Republican to consider entering a primary. The others are Randall Gnant, the State Senate president; State Treasurer Carol Springer, Secretary of State Betsey Bayless and the Maricopa County sheriff, Joe Arpaio. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

description: An article yesterday about the lives of three Vermont sisters since they gave up dairy farming referred incorrectly to a school that was dedicated to the memory of their mother and misstated its location. It is named for Bishop John A. Marshall, not for their mother, Imelda Lepine. It is in Morrisville, not Stowe.

title: Officer Resigns Before Hearing In D.W.I. Case
description: Police Officer Joseph Gray, accused of running down a pregnant woman, her son and her sister in Brooklyn three weeks ago after an afternoon of drinking in a topless bar, resigned from the Police Department yesterday, just before he was to face an internal disciplinary hearing that would have required him to testify about the fatal accident.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: More Mental Help At M.I.T.
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where six students have committed suicide since 1998, said it would expand its mental health services. A task force report found that the mental health staff had been the same size since 1995, despite a 60 percent rise in student visits. About 74 percent of the students surveyed said they had an emotional problem that disrupted daily life, but only 28 percent had used M.I.T.'s mental health services. Preliminary changes will include later hours for counseling and outreach to students. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: What's Missing in Paradise?
description: WHEN we last left Brandon and Jill Lowitz three months ago, they were off to Bali. Frustrated by life in New York (and particularly peeved that they couldn't spare the time for something as simple as lunch together a few times a month), the newlywed couple quit their jobs and headed to the quietest and least expensive place they could find. Their plan -- because even a life spent defying obligation needs a plan -- was to separate themselves from work long enough to figure out who they wanted to be when they grew up.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: GeoCities Will Charge For 2 Services
description: Yahoo Inc.'s GeoCities unit, the biggest service that lets consumers set up their own Internet sites, said it would charge users for two new, expanded versions of its free basic service. Yahoo will charge $8.95 a month for GeoCities Pro and $11.95 a month for GeoCities Webmaster, with a $15 setup fee for both. GeoCities Pro and Webmaster provide personalized Web-site domain names, multiple e-mail accounts and more data storage than the basic service, said Mark Feldman, GeoCities' senior producer. Yahoo, whose network of Web sites is used by more than 200 million people a month, has been trying to develop new services it can charge users for, as it tries to offset a decline in advertising on its pages.

title: She Chases a Life of Wind and Water and Sail
description: SURE, Samantha Heyman runs a tight ship, but the Hudson River sloop Clearwater is hardly an autocracy. ''I don't wear epaulettes,'' says Ms. Heyman, who is, nevertheless, the captain. There is no saluting. Never has there been a mutiny on, or off, the bounty. And no one has ever walked the plank. ''We don't have a plank,'' she says.

description: To the Editor:

title: Stevenson Ousted Again
description: Alexandra Stevenson, a Wimbledon semifinalist in 1999, has not been able to recapture her success. For the fourth straight year, she lost in the first round of the Open, last night falling to 19th-seeded Barbara Schett, 6-1, 6-3. ''I think it's horrible that I haven't been able to win a match here,'' said Stevenson, now 20. ''I expected to be at the top but it's taking longer for that to happen.'' Liz Robbins

title: Pioline Is Struggling To Regain His Form
description: For Cdric Pioline, it has been a glorious tennis career. In 12 years and more than 650 matches as a professional, he has exceeded $6 million in prize money. He reached the finals of the United States Open in 1993 and Wimbledon in 1997, losing each time to Pete Sampras. He led France to the Davis Cup title in 1996. In May 2000, he reached his highest ranking, fifth in the world.

title: In Capitol, AT&T and Bells Fight to Control Web Access
description: The country's regional Bell telephone companies and the cable giant AT&T are engaged in a furious fight on Capitol Hill over the rules managing the rollout of high-speed Internet access into Americans' homes, in the process reopening one of the most bitter lobbying clashes of the last decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'HARNONCOURT, SARAH CARR
description: d'HARNONCOURT-Sarah Carr. Daughter of Harry Cumings Carr and Anne Connor Carr, sister of the late Malcolm Collier, and widow of Rene d'Harnoncourt, died on Tuesday, August 7, at Bryn Mawr Hospital after a brief illness. She was ninety-seven. She was born in Chicago on October 24, 1903, moved with her family to Milwaukee, Wisconsin, where she attended the German-American Academy, and moved back to Chicago where she graduated from The Faulkner School. She went to Wellesley College, from which she received her B.A. in 1925, and after a brief business school course, she worked for several years at Marshall Field and Company in Chicago as an editor of the store's magazine, Fashions of the Hour. She met her future husband, Rene d'Harnoncourt, a young Austrian then living in Mexico, when he came to Chicago on tour with an exhibition of Mexican Arts which he had organized for the American Federation of the Arts. They met in the book store at Marshall Fields, where he was signing copies of children's books he had illustrated, and it was love at first sight. They were married in 1933 in Chicago. Her husband became a U.S. citizen and they lived in Washington, D.C. while he worked for the American Indian Arts & Crafts Board of the United States Bureau of Indian Affairs. In 1943 they moved to New York when he was hired by The Museum of Modern Art, where he later served as director until his retirement in 1968. Mr. d'Harnoncourt died in an automobile accident a few months later. The couple's only child, Anne, was born in 1943 and currently serves as Director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. In 1982, Mrs, d'Harnoncourt moved to the Philadelphia area to be closer to her daughter and son-in-law, Joseph J. Rishel, and was a resident of Dunwoody Village in Newtown Square where she had many friends. She was a lifelong devotee of movies and the ballet, a staunch fan of public television and C-Span, and an avid reader, and her volunteer work included a stint of mentoring Hispanic children in the New York public school system. She is survived by her devoted & admiring daughter Anne d'Harnoncourt Rishel, two nephews in the United States, David Collier of Berkeley, California, and Bruce Collier of Worcester, Vermont, and their families, as well as seven Austrian nieces & nephews & their families. A memorial service will take place in Philadelphia in the fall.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Polling Service To Move
description: Voter News Service, an eight-year-old consortium that provides exit polling data for news organizations, will open corporate headquarters with 17,000 square feet of space next week in the small Brooklyn neighborhood called Dumbo (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass), a spokeswoman for the consortium said yesterday. Voter News, which is owned by ABC News, The Associated Press, CBS News, CNN, Fox News and NBC News, will receive city benefits for moving from Manhattan to Dumbo, including tax breaks and reductions in rent and utility costs. The building at 45 Main Street is owned by David C. Walentas, who has worked on Dumbo revitalization for more than 20 years. The building has recently undergone a $5 million capital improvement program that included new lobbies, high-speed elevators and underground parking. The Associated Press is leasing 2,150 square feet in the same building for local election coverage and will move in Sept. 1, said Isaac Esterman, a project manager for Mr. Walentas's development company. Tara Bahrampour (NYT)

title: N.F.L. Locks Out Officials as Negotiations Falter
description: The National Football League initiated its first work stoppage involving its game officials yesterday when it officially locked them out, beginning with this week's schedule of exhibition games. The decision came after two days of intense negotiations failed to produce significant progress toward a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Technology Briefing | Intellectual Property: M.I.T. Sues A Sony Division
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has sued Sony Electronics Inc. for infringing on its patents used in digital televisions, a university official said. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Boston, seeks to block Sony Electronics from infringing on its patents, and asks for damages. A spokesman for Sony Electronics, a unit of the Sony Corporation, declined to comment on the pending litigation. Sony, Sharp and Toshiba are among the companies that sell digital televisions, with prices ranging from about $800 to more than $10,000. M.I.T. said in its suit that the university was entitled to some of the money Sony has made using the patents. The university dropped similar lawsuits against Sharp and Toshiba, a spokesman said, when it signed licensing agreements with the companies. Scientists from the university, in Cambridge, Mass., contributed to meetings set up by the Federal Communications Commission in 1993, during which corporate and academic researchers worked together toward a national standard for high-definition television.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telephone Profit Up
description: A leading Australian telephone company, the Telstra Corporation, said full-year profit from operations rose 4.6 percent but sales growth was likely to slow as competition intensified. Net income increased 10 percent, to 4.06 billion Australian dollars ($2.15 billion), from 3.7 billion ($1.96 billion) a year earlier. Excluding one-time items, the company's income rose to 3.71 billion Australian dollars, from 3.54 billion Australian dollars. Sales in the year, which ended June 30, rose 12 percent, to 23.1 billion Australian dollars ($12.25 billion). But Telstra's chairman, Ziggy Switkowski, said results would be flat for the next six months as competition increased from Cable and Wireless Optus Ltd. and the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand.

Survived by his wife Ro, his sons Bob, Rich and Skip, daughters-in-law Pat and Margaret, grandchildren Becca, Mason, Adam and Eric. Former president of Hygrade Printing Corp., he served as president of IBFI/PIA, chairman of the board of the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York (now, Assn. of Graphic Communications) and leader of, or advisor to, many organizations including the YPO and the Junior Achievement Program of New York. He was an active volunteer with SCORE (Svc. Corp. of Ret'd. Execs.) until his death. A memorial service will be held 2:30 PM Friday, August 31 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

title: A Paris Exhibition for the Man of Iron
description: Perhaps Eduardo Chillida was born to be an artist, but the fortuities of youth also taught him the tools of his trade. Perception, for instance. His father would send his sons from his sitting room, move one object, then see if the boys spotted the change. And perspective. When studying architecture in the mid-1940's, Mr. Chillida was a goalkeeper for a top soccer team, a position that taught him to ''see'' the angle of an attacking player or a dangerous ball.

title: U.S. Effort to Evade China's Web Censors

title: Questions Raised About Pilot in Crash That Killed Singer
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that the pilot of a plane that crashed in the Bahamas on Saturday, killing the singer Aaliyah and eight others, was not authorized to fly the craft and that the agency was investigating why he was at the controls.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Cheer For Premier
description: More than 2,000 ethnic Chinese community leaders pledged their support to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. With his support among ethnic Malays slipping, backing from the Chinese is increasingly important to the prime minister. The delegates carried a banner reading, ''Our Beloved and Caring Leader'' and several bowed before him.

description: Herman Badillo, a Republican mayoral candidate, lashed out yesterday at his opponent, Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire entrepreneur, saying he was ill-equipped to deal with a race riot or other crisis that might confront the city in the next four years.

Gateway announced that it would lay off one-quarter of its work force, Lucent told 2,200 workers in the United States that they would lose their jobs, and at least 21 dot-coms shut their doors for good.

title: New Campaigns
description: * Mutual of Omaha Insurance Co. will start running its first advertising aimed at consumers in more than a decade on Sept. 8, with a corporate image campaign carrying the theme ''Begin today.'' The campaign, with spending estimated at $30 million, is being created by the Chicago office of the Bozell Group, which next month becomes the Chicago office of Campbell Mithun, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Other initiatives include the company's first major sports sponsorship, of U.S.A. Swimming, and a new corporate identity from Crosby & Associates, Chicago.

title: REGENT COMMUNICATIONS MAKES A DEAL WITH COMCORP
description: Regent Communications Inc., a radio broadcaster that focuses on midsize media markets, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy seven stations in Louisiana from ComCorp of Lafayette Inc. for $39.6 million in cash. Regent is buying five FM stations and two AM stations in Lafayette, which will give the company the top position in the area, the nation's 123rd-largest radio market by revenue, its chief financial officer, Tony Vasconcellos, said. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of the year and will add to earnings in the first year, Regent said. Regent has bought or agreed to buy 16 stations this year, Mr. Vasconcellos said. When pending purchases have been completed, Regent will own and run 60 radio stations in 12 markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Aug. 21 about the opening of a section of the Foothill Freeway in Los Angeles referred incorrectly to a California ballot proposition. The proposal would dedicate all state sales tax on gasoline to transportation projects. It would not stipulate that separate gas taxes be used for such projects; gas taxes are already used solely for transportation.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Ex-Trader Pleads Guilty
description: Kevin Ingram, a onetime star bond trader for Goldman Sachs, pleaded guilty on Tuesday in United States District Court in West Palm Beach, Fla., to a charge of money laundering. Mr. Ingram, of Jersey City, who was arrested in June, was accused of agreeing to launder $2.2 million for agents posing as arms dealers. Under the plea agreement, he will pay the government $185,000 and testify against his two co-defendants. Mr. Ingram's sentencing was set for Nov. 30. His lawyer, Richard G. Lubin, said that Mr. Ingram could face two to three years under the sentencing guidelines but that he was likely to get his term reduced in exchange for his cooperation.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Hostages Seized
description: Separatist rebels in Aceh Province were reported to have kidnapped six Indonesian crewmen from a Honduran-registered ship in the Malacca Strait. According to news reports, they threatened to kill their hostages and demanded $33,000 for their release. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: You're Beautifully Extruded Tonight
description: The TriBeCa Issey Miyake clothing store opens on Sept. 12. Mr. Miyake's new outpost, designed by Frank Gehry and his protg Gordon Kipping, will contain the entire Miyake brand, including the A-Poc line. The letters stand for ''a piece of cloth,'' a seamless cloth made by a computer-driven process that extrudes a shaped material. Now, Mr. Miyake has used A-Poc to make the whimsical six-foot-tall Mobile chair, above. ''I wanted to experiment and make a piece of furniture, using this new technology,'' Mr. Miyake said. ''Something that was fun as well as functional.'' Prototypes of the Mobile chair, which looks like a blow-up paper doll, will lounge around the store and offices at 119 Hudson Street (North Moore); (212) 226-0100. Actual chairs will not be sold until next year. MELISSA FELDMAN

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kazakhstan: Nuclear Appeal
description: President Nursultan Nazarbayev appealed for international assistance to help his nation overcome the disastrous legacy of Soviet-era nuclear weapons testing. The Semipalatinsk nuclear test site in the Kazakh steppe was used to conduct nearly 500 nuclear tests. Residents were not warned about the dangers, and 1.6 million people were estimated to have been affected by radiation. Mr. Nazarbayev was addressing a conference called to mark the day 10 years ago when he ordered the test site closed. Douglas Frantz (NYT)

title: Let There Be Old Lights
description: Anyone fixing up a brownstone or a prewar apartment should know about Remains, a store full of antique wall sconces. Its inventory includes 400 pairs made from 1880 to 1930. David Calligeros and Alix MacGowan, a husband and wife, opened their business in 1996 but moved into their present shop in the flower district this spring. They have restored every piece in their own workrooms. All fixtures have been wired and are ready to hang. Most of the sconces are bronze or brass, some are silver-plate or gilt. Prices range from $800 to $20,000 a pair. Also available, a line of 10 reproduction sconces inspired by designs of the early 20th century, $300 to $825 each. Remains is at 130 West 28th Street; www.remains.com.

title: No More Shrinking Violet: Latin Bass as Main Event

If you had dropped in to Tuesday night's performance at the Zinc Bar, you might conclude that he doesn't run a band for the reason that jazz bassists often do, which is to show how well they work with the legacy of Jimmy Blanton, the Ellington bassist of the early 40's. Bassists have a lot to prove to transcend a background role; some, in positions of leadership, overcompensate with a hypermelodic, almost guitarlike style.

title: Life Master, 9 This Week, Displays His Skill
description: The world's youngest bridge expert, Shivam Shah of Barnet, England, celebrated his ninth birthday on Monday. He has been fascinated by cards since age 2, when he learned the rank of the suits and could line up the cards in order. At 3 he could do simple sums, taking the three and four of spades and counting spots to solve 3 + 4 = 7. At the same age he was fascinated by cars, learning the alphabet by starting with A for Alfa Romeo and correctly spelling Lamborghini.

Amazon.com, the Internet bookstore that grew into an Internet superstore, opened its online computer storefront yesterday at www .amazon.com/computers. It offers new computers from Apple, Compaq, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M. and Toshiba, and refurbished computers from resellers like Essex Technology Group, TechSmart and Overstock.com.

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Redback Names New Chief
description: Redback Networks, which makes equipment for fiber optic networks, named Kevin DeNuccio as its president and chief executive, becoming the second company in two days to hire away a Cisco Systems executive for a top position. Mr. DeNuccio served as a senior vice president selling to telecommunications companies before taking a six-month leave of absence to spend time with his family. ''I definitely had the desire to be a C.E.O. again,'' said Mr. DeNuccio, who ran Bell Atlantic Integration Inc. before joining Cisco six years ago. Pierre Lamond, who has served as interim chief executive of Redback since March, remains chairman. Mr. DeNuccio's announced hiring came one day after Openwave Systems said it hired Kevin J. Kennedy -- a Cisco senior vice president who left the company last week as part of its restructuring -- as its chief executive. Chris Gaither (NYT)

''We wanted to be one of a few,'' said Nils Goran Lindblad, Bodum's president. ''If you go to SoHo, you are one among 10,000.'' Mr. Lindblad calls Bodum's new store, designed by Carsten Jorgensen, left, with the owner Jorgen Bodum, ''an experience about Scandinavian design,'' but it is also an experience about caffeine. Along with fresh espresso and bagged teas and coffees, the store will showcase Bodum's glass teapots, a signature coffee press and jaunty eight-cup vacuum pot ($130; shown), also designed by Mr. Jorgensen. Bodum is at 413 West 14th Street, near 10th Avenue. DEBORAH BALDWIN

title: National Briefing | Religion: Anti-Abortion Advertising Campaign
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops plan to unveil a national anti-abortion advertising campaign on Tuesday, beginning with posters and radio spots in Philadelphia and southern New Jersey. The campaign's tag line is ''Have we gone too far?'' and it seeks to produce outrage that American women may have abortions for any reason into the ninth month of pregnancy. The sponsor of the advertisements is identified only as the Second Look Project; the bishops are not mentioned, a spokesman said, because ''this is not a religious message, and it is not directed to Catholics, but to a far broader audience.''

title: Economic Scene; A tarnished new economy loses more luster with revised productivity data.
description: THE overly romantic faith in a new economy has already done plenty of damage. Just ask all those investors in Nasdaq stocks. But recent revisions to the productivity data reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics show how thin the new- economy thinking has been all along.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Long-Distance Suit Settled
description: Connecticut officials said yesterday that they had reached a settlement in which Qwest Communications agreed to cease telephone-service abuses -- including taking over the long-distance service of other companies' customers without authorization -- and pay restitution to thousands of people believed to have been financially harmed by the practice, known as slamming. While the amount of potential restitution will not be calculated until the affected customers have submitted claims, Qwest, based in Denver, has agreed to pay $1.1 million in penalties to the state, officials said. The accord ends a lawsuit that Attorney General Richard Blumenthal filed in 1999. The settlement papers say Qwest has not admitted any wrongdoing. Customers who believe they may be entitled to restitution may call 1-800-405-1506. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

title: Mets' Hitters Show What Could Have Been
description: Some nights, the Mets make you wonder why it was all so hard. When they play a game the way they did last night, defeating the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-5, it highlights how disappointing this season has been.

description: Jorge Posada's foot felt well enough for him to play yesterday, but the catcher was not at Yankee Stadium for last night's game against the Toronto Blue Jays because his 21-month-old son, Jorge Jr., was receiving medical treatment.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Poachers Shoot Rangers
description: Poachers gunned down one forest guard and injured three others who were patrolling Corbett National Park, a wildlife sanctuary 120 miles north of Delhi. Some forest rangers said it was time to provide them with guns so they can defend themselves against poachers armed with automatic weapons. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Bosnian Serb Freed, For Now
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal released the former Bosnian Serb president, Biljana Plavsic, and allowed her to wait in Serbia until her trial next year. The only woman among the court's 46 prisoners, she surrendered this year after learning that the tribunal had indicted her on charges including genocide. But Momcilo Krajisnik, another detained former Bosnian Serb politician, was told he could not leave jail to attend his father's memorial service. The tribunal was not convinced that Mr. Krajisnik, who was arrested by NATO troops, would return to The Hague. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: The riders' group sets out to give motorcycle racing a place in the mainstream with Nascar.
description: MOTORCYCLES have long had an outlaw image, associated with groups like the Hell's Angels and cinematic rebels like the leather-jacket-clad Marlon Brando in ''The Wild One'' and Peter Fonda in ''Easy Rider.''

description: It was the meanest, ugliest fire anyone in this old mining town could remember, tearing through houses, sending people fleeing and scorching the green hills that lure the tourists here and fill the air with pine scent.

title: Pakistan's Cruel Blasphemy Law
description: A Pakistani criminal court has sentenced Dr. Younus Shaikh to be hanged for stating obvious facts about the life of Muhammad before he became the founder of Islam. That verdict and the blasphemy law that underlies it are an embarrassment to Pakistan and a threat to the basic liberties of its citizens. Other countries can and do honor the beliefs of Islam without offending basic precepts of justice and intellectual honesty.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Millennium Terror Plot
description: A Manhattan grand jury has indicted a man who is in custody in London, charging that he aided what prosecutors call a plot to blow up Los Angeles International Airport just before the start of 2000. The eight-count indictment, filed on Monday in United States District Court, charges Abu Doha, also known as Dr. Haider, with providing money, safe houses and other aid to terrorists. Proceedings to extradite Mr. Doha, 37, are pending.

description: Computer Associates International soundly defeated an effort yesterday by the dissident investor Sam Wyly to replace four directors, including Charles Wang, the company's founder and chairman.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Arizona: A Question Of Residency
description: The state elections office said it would look into where Representative Bob Stump, a Republican who represents the Third District, has been voting. Mr. Stump, first elected in 1976, lists a home in Tolleson, a town west of Phoenix, as his legal voting address, but he has lived in central Phoenix since 1980. Both locations are in his district, but the precincts are different, which means his votes have affected local elections. State residency laws require that a voter cast ballots where he has ''actual physical presence.'' Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Grave Relocation Price Tag
description: The Turnpike Authority estimates that it will cost $1 million to exhume and relocate up to 900 bodies buried in an old graveyard that is blocking a proposed $225 million interchange in Secaucus. Robert Grimm, supervising engineer for planning, said state engineers planned to use ground-penetrating radar to determine the extent of the graveyard. The century-old site may contain the bodies of the poor, tubercular and insane from nearby institutions. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

It is scheduled for 9:30 a.m. at St. Charles Church, at Penn Avenue and Hyland Boulevard, in Staten Island. title: Technology Briefing | Internet: 2 Settle Fraud Charges
description: Two operators of pornographic Web sites that advertised memberships for less than $50, or free, but billed consumers for hundreds of dollars in international long-distance telephone calls, have agreed to settle charges that they violated federal law, the Federal Trade Commission said. When users tried to view pornographic images on the sites, their computers were connected to an outside server using a ''dialer'' program that disconnected them from their Internet service provider and reconnected them through long-distance telephone calls to Ghana and Madagascar. Hillary Sheinkin, of Ladson, S.C., was barred from using aliases to register other Web sites, and must pay a $10,000 fine to the government. And Charlo Barbosa, of Vancouver, British Columbia, agreed to pay more than $26,000 in consumer redress for bilking people out of hundreds of dollars in telephone charges through a similar, but separate Internet operation.

title: From Brazil, An Emerging Steel Giant; A Family Company Shops Abroad for Acquisitions

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Less Teacher Strife Reported

The union, which represents 90 percent of the state's teachers, said that out of the 950 local unions it represents, 191 will begin the school year without a contract, down from 222 last year and 369 five years ago. Thomas Hobart, the union's president, credited improved labor relations as well as cooperation between teachers and school boards. But, he warned, budget cuts might hamper future contract negotiations.

title: New Home for Donna Karan Designs, With Enchanted Garden
description: Call it a vest-pocket park. It is a serene garden behind the first store in the United States dedicated to the Donna Karan couture line, fenced in by enormous bamboo trees. It is bare except for a waterlily pond and two perfectly proportioned stone seats, above, hand-cut in Japan by the sculptor Izumi Masatoshi. Price of admission: simply passing through the renovated limestone building, built in 1852 as a private residence. Now it is home to the Donna Karan Collection for men and women and also to a preciously handpicked assortment of objects for the home. ''To me, design is all about form and sensuality, and it doesn't matter if it's a belt, a handbag or something for the house,'' said Ms. Karan, left. Prices run from $45 for a pair of chopsticks to candles that cost $45 to $500 (for one that stands on the floor); $300 to $800 for ceramic bowls with gold interiors (far left) by the English ceramist Sheila Boyce; and up to $32,500 for a 14-foot lacquered bench by the architect Zaha Hadid. Those stone chairs in the garden? Not for sale here; but the artist can be contacted through the Japonesque Gallery in San Francisco (415-391-8860). Donna Karan New York opened on Monday at 819 Madison Avenue (68th Street).

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Airgate To Buy Ipcs
description: AirGate PCS Inc., an Atlanta-based company that sells wireless telephone service under the Sprint PCS name in the southeastern United States, said yesterday that it would buy iPCS Inc., which operates largely in the Midwest, for $802.8 million in stock. The combined company will be one of Sprint PCS's largest affiliates, with over 300,000 subscribers in Georgia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Illinois, Michigan, Iowa and Nebraska. Thomas M. Dougherty, chief executive of AirGate, said the new company would have the potential to reach 12 million customers. Assuming Sprint PCS and regulatory bodies approve the deal, iPCS will be acquired for 13.5 million shares of AirGate stock. AirGate will also assume $97 million in debt from the privately held iPCS, which is based in Schaumburg, Ill. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: U.S. Jets Attack Iraqi Radar Installation
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 30  United States fighter jets attacked an Iraqi radar installation today in response to recent threats against American and British aircraft, military officials said.

title: Samsung and Toshiba Consider Link on Chips
description: Samsung Electronics said yesterday that it was weighing a proposal to take over semiconductor manufacturing from Toshiba. The proposal came after the companies agreed to work together on manufacturing and marketing washing machines in the midst of an economic downturn that is forcing electronics manufacturers to consider radical restructuring plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBB, ELIZABETH BLISS PARKINSON
description: COBB-Elizabeth Bliss Parkinson. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and Members of its International Council are deeply saddened by the death of their treasured friend and colleague, Eliza Parkinson Cobb. In her almost 70-year close association with the Museum, she gave generously of her time and resources, following in the tradition of her aunt, Lillie P. Bliss, one of the three founders of the Museum in 1929. From her first formal involvement with the Museum, at the invitation of Nelson Rockefeller, as Chairman of the Junior Advisory Committee, to her election as a Trustee in 1939, and her subsequent involvement in the founding of the Museum's International Council on which she served as President from 1957 to 1966, Eliza remained active in the Council for many years thereafter, & was deeply linked to every facet of the Museum's activities. She served as a member of virtually every Museum Trustee committee, participating in curatorial, administrative, financial, educational, and archival areas, chairing the Photography Committee from 1983 to 1987 and the Building Committee from 1968 to 1977, among others. Her deep and abiding intererest in the Museum's staff was well known, and she encouraged its growth with the same vigor and spirit she showed in support of young artists. Eliza was President of the Museum from 1965 to 1968, and remained an active Vice Chairman until 1993 when she became a Life Trustee. We extend our deepest sympathy and affection to her devoted family: her daughter Zaidee Parkinson; her son John Parkinson III and her daughter-in-law Charlotte; her step-children Alex & Sheila Ewing, Ian and Victoria Mackintosh, and John and Bayard Cobb; 5 grandchildren, John Parkinson, Allston Parkinson, Elizabeth ParkinsonWyner, Basil Dufallo and Cornelius Dufallo; and three great-grandchildren. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Brian Urquhart, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Crossing Into Cinema and Real Life
description: SNOW falls on the deserted city streets, where Max Payne stands ready, shotgun in hand. As two armed men run into the street, the scene goes into slow motion. Leaping sideways, Max pulls the trigger and one man flies backward, blood floating about him in a fine spray. The other man's bullets waft slowly past Max as he hits the ground and fires again. The second man is hit and we see his face distorted in pain before time speeds to normal and Max walks forward to strip the bodies of ammunition.

The proposal would dedicate all state sales tax on gasoline to transportation projects. It would not stipulate that separate gas taxes be used for such projects; gas taxes are already used solely for transportation.

title: Software May Replace the Eye Chart on the Wall
description: FOR decades, rudimentary vision tests have remained almost entirely unchanged. Even grandparents would recognize the ritual: Subjects are asked to stand or sit several feet away from a poster-size eye chart, cover one eye and squint at rows of capital letters. Nothing could be more low-tech.

title: Encryption Schemes Aimed at Film Piracy
description: NAPSTER'S threat to the financial health of the recording industry may have waned, but its paradigm continues to terrify Hollywood. Thanks to digital television, the motion picture industry fears that legions of international video pirates and crafty teenagers could soon be intercepting transmissions and then uploading perfect digital copies of the latest feature films to the Internet. Eventually those grainy pirated videotapes sold in New York and other cities could be replaced by pristine Internet-transmitted copies before the film has even hit the local multiplex.

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Wyoming: A Plea To End Drilling
description: The owners of 54 businesses in towns around Yellowstone National Park sent a letter to President Bush, urging him to stop oil and gas drilling in three areas near the park because it is hurting the local economy. Arguing that tourism is more important to the region than mineral extraction, the letter says in part, ''Our way of life is severely endangered by the prospect of oil and gas drilling, which will industrialize'' the area. The owners said the areas in question were the Bridger-Teton National Forest, the Upper Green River Basin and the Red Desert. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: It's Still a Plain Gray Box, but the Innards Are Changing
description: A TRAFFIC jam has formed inside your computer. While chip makers keep developing faster processors -- new models released this week feature Pentium 4 chips running at 2 gigahertz -- the main road carrying data between the processor and other components has not expanded as quickly.

description: Breaking a logjam that had all but stopped the Fish and Wildlife Service from listing new endangered species, the Bush administration promised quick action today to protect 29 vanishing plant and animal species, including some that are on the verge of extinction.

title: Doing Justice To Mazursky, Long Bypassed
description: Often, the truest indicator of great pop culture is its timeliness. Some of it is so date sensitive that when you take it in years after its creation, you're slightly embarrassed because the piece so acutely summed up its time that you see a reflection of yourself as you were when you first beheld it. This could be why, in an era when almost every director to step behind a camera in the 1970's is lionized, one of the most talented and subtle has been ignored: Paul Mazursky, whose comedies had a luscious sensuality, has yet to receive tribute.

description: Choice china does not have to be bone white. title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Railroad Acquisition
description: Hyundai Mobis, controlled by Hyundai Motor, will soon become Korea's largest manufacturer of railroad cars. Hyundai Mobis is increasing its stake in the Korea Rolling Stock Corporation to 78.6 percent of the shares after agreeing to buy Daewoo Heavy Industry's stake of 39.18 percent for $118 million. Hyundai Mobis manufactures the containers carried on railroad cars, ships and trucks.

While total employment has declined 0.2 percent since March, it has not fallen to 4.5 percent. The 4.5 percent figure is the unemployment rate, which has risen from 4.3 percent in March.

title: Families Sue Pfizer on Test Of Antibiotic
description: Thirty Nigerian families sued Pfizer in federal court yesterday, saying the company conducted an unethical clinical trial of an antibiotic on their children in 1996. It is the first suit in the United States seeking damages from an American pharmaceutical company for what the plaintiffs say was medical experimentation on foreign citizens without their consent.

title: AES, POWER PRODUCER, MAKES OFFER IN VENEZUELA
description: The AES Corporation, which produces power in 27 countries, offered yesterday to buy a controlling stake in Venezuela's largest phone company, Compaa Annima Nacional Telfonos de Venezuela, for about $1.4 billion in cash. AES offered $3.43 a share for about 43 percent of the outstanding Class D shares, the company said in a statement. It will offer $24 a share for American depository receipts, each representing seven Class D shares. The offer is 21 percent higher than yesterday's closing price. Gaining another 43 percent of the stock would give AES a 50.1 percent stake in the company. It already owned 6.9 percent through Corporacin EDC. Shares of AES fell 19 cents, to $35.59.

description: The American economy grew more slowly in the second quarter than at any time in eight years, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Still, the new numbers suggested to many economists that if consumers continued to spend at their present level, the nation could avoid a recession.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Arrests In Gunrunning
description: Five people have been arrested and charged with buying guns in Virginia and illegally reselling them in the Bronx, the authorities said. The guns, ranging from handguns to high-powered assault rifles, were sold primarily in the vicinity of the Gun Hill public housing development. The arrests follow a five-month investigation and the undercover purchase of 107 guns and about 1,100 rounds of ammunition, officials said. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Washington: Link Between Gun Use And Limits
description: States that require the licensing and registration of handguns make it harder for criminals and juveniles to obtain guns in their state, says a study being published today in the journal Injury Prevention by researchers at Bloomberg School of Public Health at Johns Hopkins University. In states with mandatory licensing and registration, 33 percent of handguns used in crimes came from dealers or gun shows in the state, the study found. By comparison, in states with either licensing or registration, but not both, 72 percent of guns used in crimes were traced to sources in the state. And in states with neither restriction, 84 percent of guns used in crimes were acquired in the state. Only seven states, including New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts, require both.

title: CHANCELLOR MAKES A $150 MILLION CUT IN SCHOOL BUDGET
description: After weeks of bickering with City Hall over the Board of Education's budget, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy said yesterday that he had ordered $150 million in immediate program cuts, including less spending for after-school classes, athletic and arts programs, lab equipment, computer software and teacher training.

The rebels have not responded, and diplomats said the government, which has lost its majority and suspended Parliament, lacks the broad political support it would need to effectively bargain with the rebels. title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Bombs Defused
description: British security forces defused two pipe bombs at a pub and a hotel in Ballycastle, just one day after a large car bomb was discovered and defused in the town. The Red Hand Defenders, a name used by Protestant paramilitary groups, claimed responsibility for the car bomb, which was left in an area crowded with tourists during a festival. The Red Hand Defenders also admitted killing a Roman Catholic man in June. Brian Lavery (NYT)

description: The European Commission said today that it has broadened its inquiry into the business practices of the Microsoft Corporation ( news/quote ), repeating its accusation that the company violated antitrust laws and seeking new information about a software product that enables audio and video content on computers.

description: About 3,000 people showed up at a job fair in Brooklyn yesterday to apply for 400 jobs as New York City school teachers, Board of Education officials said.

title: Hotel Occupancy and Rates Fell in July
description: Hotel room revenue fell 6 percent in July, the fourth consecutive decline, and room rates fell for the first time in 10 years, as cuts in business travel hurt hotels in New York, San Francisco and Boston, a travel research firm said yesterday.

title: Mara Believes Lockout Will Last Into Season
description: The Giants' Wellington Mara, arguably the most influential owner in the N.F.L., gave the first public signal yesterday that the league's lockout of its officials could be bitter and long when he accused the chief negotiator for the officials of deceiving players regarding safety issues and replacement officials. Mara said he believed the lockout would last into the regular season, which begins Sept. 9.

description: THERE is a time for exotic woods, fragile textiles and precious metals. But from the looks of the merchandise last week at the New York Gift Market in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, this does not seem to be the season. The wholesale market was full of colorful designs, many for children, in ordinary materials like plywood, nylon, textured sisal and natural cotton. As a bonus, many have a handmade look.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Flu Shots To Cost More
description: Influenza vaccines will cost almost twice as much this winter, but will arrive on time in New Jersey, unlike last year's shipments, according to state and municipal health officials. Aventis Pasteur, the French company that is the largest supplier of vaccines, has increased its per-shot price to cover what it says are additional costs from increasing its production capacity. Shots will cost $5 to $5.50 each, up from as little as $3 last year, depending on volume discounts.

title: Ugandan, Seeking Higher Office, Submits to Higher Education

title: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Mobile Phone Sales Drop
description: Sales of mobile phones fell 7 percent in the second quarter as network operators reduced subsidies and customers held off buying new phones until new versions appear, according to Dataquest, a unit of Gartner Inc. The industry sold 89.8 million units in the second quarter of 2001, down from 96.7 million phones in the first quarter, Dataquest said yesterday. In the second quarter last year, 98 million phones were sold.

description: Among the myriad open City Council seats this year, few have attracted as many candidates with the political credentials and connections as those in the six-way race in the Democratic primary in the 39th Council District.

description: While the Rolando Paulino All-Stars rode triumphantly in a parade through their home streets of the Bronx yesterday, the parents of Danny Almonte insisted that their son, the ace pitcher for the team, is 12 years old and was eligible to play during the last two Little League seasons and in this year's World Series, which ended Sunday.
