title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AT&T CORP., New York, the long-distance telephone company, said it would close a customer-service office in San Antonio to cut costs after demand for calling services declined. The company has not decided whether or not to offer the office's 590 employees other jobs at AT&T.

title: American Express Discount
description: Using an American Express card to book a Bahamas vacation from Sept. 1 to Dec. 16, can save travelers $75 on a three-night vacation and $150 for stays of four nights or longer. Trips must be purchased by Oct. 31. If the package includes tickets on US Airways, Delta, Continental (from Newark), TWA or American Eagle, there will be an extra saving of $50 a person. Information: www.bahamas.com .

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Economic Growth Declines
description: Belgium's economic growth fell 0.6 percent in the second quarter of this year compared with the previous quarter, the first such decline in two and a half years, according to figures released by the Belgian National Bank. Analysts said the slowdown in the United States, and the effect it had on Belgium's neighbor Germany, was a considerable factor in the decline. According to the report, imports declined 2 percent, but exports fell 6.5 percent. Prime Minister Guy Verhofstadt, above, said he expected the economy to grow 2 percent this year and 2.5 percent to 3 percent in 2002. Paul Meller (NYT)

title: A Dramatic Geometric Jumble For a Denver Museum's New Wing
description: Since time immemorial, most of the spectacular beauty in the Rocky Mountain region has been natural rather than man-made. That may change in 2005, when the Denver Art Museum is scheduled to open a breathtakingly modern new wing that may become this region's first signature building.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: School Food Supplier Fined
description: A food distributor in the Bronx must pay a $4.2 million fine and $4.2 million in restitution for rigging bids on contracts awarded by New York City schools and other agencies, a federal judge ruled yesterday. Judge Jed Rakoff of United States District Court imposed the sentence on the Nick Penachio Company two days after ordering its president, Nicholas A. Penachio, to serve four years in prison. Mr. Penachio, 65, must also pay a $1 million fine and contribute toward the $4.2 million restitution. Prosecutors said the scheme lasted nearly a decade and inflated prices by 10 percent on $210 million in food contracts with Mr. Penachio's and other firms.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  APPLEMAN, DEE
description: APPLEMAN-Dee. A woman of grace and beauty, whose every breath was love. Precious wife of Herb for 45 years, mother of Marc, grandmother of Michael and Drew, mother-in-law of Shari and sister-in-law of Linda and George. Inspiring school director and teacher, artist and author. Services Friday at 11:00 A.M. from Temple Israel, 14 Coleytown Rd., Westport, CT (203-227-1293). Donations can be made to A Child's Place, Westport, in memory of Dee Appleman.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sentencing Set For Hacker
description: The lawyer for the youth known as Mafiaboy told a Montreal court that his client should not be placed in detention. The boy, who turned 17 in July, pleaded guilty Jan. 19, to causing $25,000 damage during five attacks that crippled Internet sites for several hours in February 2000. He also admitted to hacking into at least 75 computer networks. The lawyer, Jan Romanowski, argued that the teenager simply conducted tests that went out of control. He recommended that the youth pay a fine, perform community service and return to school. The prosecutor, Louis Miville-Deschnes prefers that the youth spend 12 months in close custody followed by two years' probation and be prevented from profiting from the crimes. He added that detention would also deter would-be hackers. He saw no need, however, to bar the teenager from the Internet, provided he had adult supervision.

title: Archbishop Bids Brotherly Goodbye to Wife, and Returns to Fold
description: Archbishop Emmanuel Milingo finally faced his wife tonight, handed her a rosary and told her he was indeed leaving her to return to priestly life, apparently ending an embarrassing episode for the Roman Catholic Church.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Submarine Scrapes Bottom
description: The submarine Greeneville, in service for the first time since accidentally ramming and sinking a Japanese trawler last February, scraped bottom on Monday in rough seas off Saipan and sustained minor damage to its rudder, the Navy said. The nuclear-powered attack submarine returned to port in Guam for repairs. The Greeneville, under a new skipper, Cmdr. David S. Bogdan, began a six-month deployment in the Pacific on Aug. 15, its first since the accident in which the submarine crashed into the Ehime Maru near Pearl Harbor in Hawaii, killing nine Japanese.

title: National Briefing | South: North Carolina: Judge To Run For Senate
description: Ray Warren, a Superior Court judge in Charlotte who two years ago publicly announced his homosexuality and then renounced his membership in the Republican Party, has said he plans to run as a Democrat for the Senate seat being vacated by Jesse Helms. The only Democrat who has formally declared for the seat is Secretary of State Elaine Marshall. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Rates Steady
description: Thailand's central bank left its leading interest rate unchanged, even as it said economic growth might slow to a smaller-than-expected 1.5 percent this year. The bank's Monetary Policy Board left the benchmark 14-day repurchase rate at 2.5 percent, saying borrowing costs were already low enough to support an economy hurt by stalling exports and investment, said Thirachai Phuvanatnaranubala, an assistant governor of the Bank of Thailand, after a board meeting. The bank said the economy would probably grow 1.5 percent to 2 percent this year, down from last year's 4.4 percent. That would be the worst performance since 1998, when the country was in recession. Last week, the bank forecast 1.8 percent growth for 2001.

title: Speed Traps
description: As I noted in a column a few months ago, Apple Computer has long been the victim of a public perception problem: that megahertz (MHz) is the true measure of a computers speed.

title: Restaurant Accused of Exploiting Immigrants
description: Four former workers at a Chinese restaurant here and about 20 sympathizers demonstrated outside the establishment today, saying its owners and managers had failed to pay workers and forced them to return some of their tips.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Costly Epidemic
description: The foot-and-mouth epidemic is likely to cost Britain as much as 4.1 billion this year, according to a new report. Thirteen more farms were also identified as infected with the disease in the latest outbreak, bringing the total number to 1,989. The Countryside Agency reported that the epidemic was having a devastating effect on the export market and on the agriculture and tourism industries. The group's chairman, Ewen Cameron, said the government should consider vaccinating animals as a way to control any future outbreaks. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: New Jersey Confirms First Case Of a West Nile-Related Illness
description: For the first time this year, health officials have confirmed a case of illness caused by the mosquito-borne West Nile virus in a resident of New Jersey, and they outlined plans yesterday to spray pesticides in parts of Bergen County. At the same time, New York City planned more spraying in Staten Island after a third illness was confirmed in the city.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DECLINES. The euro slipped after the government said the economy unexpectedly expanded in the second quarter. In New York, the euro settled at 90.97 cents, down from 91.09 cents on Tuesday.

title: The Other Dusan Knezevic
description: I married a war criminal -- at least that's what immigration officials tried to tell me every time we landed at Kennedy Airport. The routine was always the same. We handed over our little stack of passports: American blue, with gold trim and bald eagle, for our daughter and me; a similar blue for my husband, who is Serbian, but with the double-headed eagle of Yugoslavia. The immigration agent typed in his name: D-U-S-A-N K-N-E-Z-E-V-I-C.

title: Another Source
description: To the Editor:

title: New Kmart Characters Based on Blue Lights
description: The Kmart Corporation in Troy, Mich., begins a national television campaign today featuring animated characters based on the blue lights that are part of its in-store sales known as ''blue light specials.'' Spending was estimated at $15 million to $30 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUZZI, KAREN
description: CUZZI-Karen. The Faculty and Staff of the Divison of Social Work and Behavorial Science Department of Community and Preventive Medicine of the Mt. Sinai School of Medicine are deeply saddened by the death of Karen Cuzzi, beloved wife of our colleague, Dr. Larry Cuzzi, Director of Social Work at the Elmhurst Hospital Center. Karen was known for her wonderful warmth and caring manner and her numerous volunteer activities in New York State. She is survived by her devoted daughter, Lynn Pearson, her caring son-in-law Brian Pearson, her new granddaughter, Caroline May, by her loving son David and her brother Thomas Klein. Funeral Friday, August 31, 2001 at 11am St. Kilian R.C. Church, 485 Conklin St, Farmingdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the ALS Foundation. Gary Rosenberg, Ph.D. Edith J. Baerwald, Professor Director, Division of Social Work and Behavorial Science, The Mt. Sinai School of Medicine

title: Ford Motor Will Not Pay Annual Bonus To Managers
description: The Ford Motor Company, which is struggling with falling auto sales and the Firestone tire recall, said today that it would not pay bonuses this year to 6,000 middle-level and senior managers, including its chief executive, Jacques A. Nasser.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Idaho: Spending Restrictions
description: Gov. Dirk Kempthorne ordered state agencies to restrict their budgets by 2 percent for the 2002 fiscal year and asked public schools to hold back on spending by 1.5 percent, or $13.9 million of the $933 million they received. Unexpected firefighting costs and shrinking revenues have led to projections of a $35.4 million budget deficit, the governor's financial office said. Matthew Preusch (NYT)

title: Why E-Book's Time Hasn't Come
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Rocket Launched
description: Ending a string of costly and embarrassing failures, Japan launched an advanced rocket capable of carrying commercial satellites into orbit. The launching of the H-2A rocket was seen as a do-or-die test for the country's beleaguered space agency after huge cost overruns and repeated failures in its attempt to enter the international satellite launching business. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Nod To Ethnic Minorities
description: The United Nations envoy, Razali Ismail, met leaders of ethnic minority groups and told them they would eventually be included in talks now under way between the military government and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy leader. Mr. Razali, on his fifth visit to Myanmar this year, also met for a second time with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi, and with leaders of her party, the National League for Democracy. Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: AFFILIATED MANAGERS TO GET 51% OF FRIESS ASSOCIATES
description: The Affiliated Managers Group, an asset management holding company, has agreed to buy 51 percent of Friess Associates, adviser to the Brandywine Funds, for $247 million in cash. Affiliated said yesterday that it planned to increase its stake in Friess another 19 percent in three years. The remaining 30 percent will be held by Foster Friess, the firm's founder, and by other Friess employees. Affiliated is buying Friess to expand its lineup of asset managers and bolster its mutual fund business.

title: The Wisdom of Whiskers
description: Why has everyone failed to observe that Al Gore is hardly the first national figure to ignite a public stir by growing a private beard after running for president? Abraham Lincoln did precisely the same thing, with nearly the same result. Of course, unlike Mr. Gore, Lincoln had won his election (although he received only 39 percent of the popular vote, considerably less than Mr. Gore did). But, for a time, he was just as mysterious about what inspired him to stop shaving as Mr. Gore has been. And in an age before television cameras could glimpse and report on beards in progress, Lincoln's decision took America by complete surprise.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AUSTRALIA

title: A Quarterback, a Legacy and a Lot of Pressure to Win
description: When the college football season began a year ago, Notre Dame was coming off a 5-7 record and Coach Bob Davie was hearing doubts about his job security. The Fighting Irish were beginning two years of probation for an embarrassing scandal involving sex and other favors for players. The female booster involved was convicted and jailed for embezzlement from a private business.

title: With Court Ruling, Hynes Faces Challenger
description: For the first time since he won office 12 years ago, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, will face an opponent in the Democratic primary, despite his best effort in court to knock the challenger off the ballot.

title: A Macedonian Hawk Vows To Extend Pursuit of Rebels
description: Macedonia's interior minister, Ljube Boskovski, said today that NATO's operation to collect weapons from rebels was only a ''symbolic disarmament,'' and he warned that his anti-terrorist police would seize any remaining illegal weapons as soon as NATO was finished with its 30-day mission.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Coach Moving Uptown
description: Coach, the leather accessories company, plans to open a store on Madison Avenue and 85th Street, becoming the first major international luxury retailer to venture that far uptown on the East Side. ''The demographics in that area are very, very strong,'' said Alan Victor, a retail broker with the Lansco Corporation. ''But whether people will be walking those streets specifically to shop remains to be seen.'' Annual rents on Madison in the 80's range from $150 to $200 a square foot, compared with as much as $300 a square foot between 73rd and 78th Streets, Mr. Victor said.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Telecom Concern's Debt
description: Enitel A.S.A., a Norwegian phone company, said it would seek court protection from creditors while trying to refinance its debt. The decision was made at a board meeting late Tuesday night and came as the Oslo-based company faced mounting losses that threatened its ability to repay bondholders and 19 banks led by J. P. Morgan Chase. Enitel said that without additional funds the company had only enough money to pay for operations for the next two months.

title: United States Backs Plan to Help Chinese Evade Government Censorship of Web
description: The United States government agencies that once tried to breach the Iron Curtain with radio broadcasts are taking the information war to the Internet, hoping to finance an American-based computer network designed to thwart attempts by the Chinese government to censor the World Wide Web for users in China.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: 4 Sue For Powerball Share
description: Four people who worked with one of last week's Powerball winners say they deserve a share of her windfall. The day after the winners, Pat and Erwin Wales of Buxton, accepted their oversized check for $41.5 million, the employees, who worked with Ms. Wales at Lincoln Financial Group in Portland, filed suit in a Maine court. They claim they were among 19 people who gave Ms. Wales $10 each to join an office ticket pool. Ms. Wales's lawyer says she bought the winning ticket separately from the 190 that she purchased for the pool, and has records from the New Hampshire convenience store to back her up.

title: People Power; Talk if You Must, but at Least Put Some Muscle Into Idle Chat
description: THERE are many reasons that you might not flip open a phone in the most remote patches of an increasingly cellular world. But battery failure is, for better or worse, no longer an excuse. A growing number of products, more Flintstones than Jetsons in concept, allow you to recharge a cell phone with nothing more than your own muscle power.

title: TIGHTER FINANCES WON'T CURB GOALS, PRESIDENT ASSERTS
description: President Bush vowed today not to let the economic slowdown or the evaporating federal surplus deter him from increasing the military budget, beginning work on a missile shield or increasing spending on education.

title: Demolition Raises Squall in Nantucket
description: AN 1890 sepia photograph from Nantucket shows the Monument Square Grocery in its heyday, a white Italianate building with its many square-paned windows, its wooden front doors and its neat picket fence all intact. Its proud owner is standing beside it in his Sunday suit, his hand placed jauntily on his hip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOULD, MILDRED
description: GOULD-Mildred. My beloved sister. Family was the highest priority, the very essence, of her life. Unsurpassed in giving love and devotion, as daughter and sister, wife, mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. We will miss and love you always. Take care of Mom, Dad and Sylvia. Walter

title: Vision of the Future
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: When Hot Cars Go Cold
description: THE Lexus SC 430 is the chief object of automotive desire this summer. Demand is high, supplies are short and dealers are charging thousands of dollars over the $60,000 sticker. But to Jay Shoemaker, the elegant convertible is old news.

title: Executive Changes in Media and Marketing
description: Dr. Conrad R. Newman was named director for information architecture at Fitch, Columbus, Ohio, part of the Cordiant Communications Group. He had headed the information architecture practice at the New York office of MarchFirst.

title: First Matching Funds for 9
description: The Campaign Finance Board handed out an additional $1 million in city matching funds yesterday, approving the first public financing for eight candidates for City Council and one for the Staten Island borough presidency.

title: Downside of the Stem Cell Policy
description: In the three weeks since President Bush announced his policy on federal funding for stem cell research, it has become increasingly clear that his plan is likely to deliver far less help to biomedical researchers than originally promised. The president's policy may conceivably allow this promising scientific field to advance adequately for the next year or two -- though even that is uncertain. But it will assuredly not be flexible enough to allow science to advance at a reasonable pace after that.

title: A Chance to Prevent the Partition of Macedonia
description: Lord Robertson, the unflappable secretary-general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is rarely at a loss for words. But he was struggling to find them when asked this question at a press conference hailing the Aug. 13 political agreement between ethnic Macedonians and Albanians: ''Doesn't the agreement reward violence?''

title: MILOSEVIC TO FACE CHARGES COVERING 3 WARS IN BALKANS
description: The chief prosecutor of the United Nations tribunal said today that she would expand the charges against Slobodan Milosevic to include genocide in the massacres in Bosnia and accusations of war crimes in Croatia.

title: Russians Deem Arrest Insult to Their Industry
description: The arrest and arraignment of a Russian programmer in the United States have provoked outrage in this country's computer programming industry.

title: Govan Mbeki, 91, an Enemy Of Apartheid System, Dies
description: Govan Mbeki, a South African liberation leader who sent his eldest son, Thabo, into the antiapartheid struggle and lived to see him become president of South Africa, died early this morning in the coastal city of Port Elizabeth. He was 91.

title: Nursing Homes Are Facing Loss of Their Voting Booths
description: Sophie Godfrey is angry that she has to vote on an absentee ballot during this election season. The 91-year-old, who lives at a nursing home in the Bronx, wants to vote like everyone else: she wants to pull a lever.

title: Reckonings; Greenspan Stands Alone
description: There are three great economic powers in today's world -- the United States, Europe and Japan. In principle, each of these has two potent recession-fighting tools at its disposal. One is monetary policy: the central bank can print money and drive down interest rates. The other is fiscal policy: the government can try to support a flagging economy by cutting taxes and increasing spending.

title: In Fort Greene, Prosperity Is Bittersweet; Some Blacks Reap Profits As Others Lament Change
description: On a recent sweet summer evening on a sidewalk in Brooklyn, two acquaintances, middle-class black men approaching 40, got to talking. The conversation turned, as it often does in Fort Greene, to the three R's: race, riches and real estate. They played the license-plate game.

title: CARRIER IS CUTTING 600 JOBS AT 2 SITES IN TENNESSEE
description: The Carrier unit of the United Technologies Corporation is eliminating 600 jobs at two operations in Tennessee because of declining orders. Carrier is the largest maker of air-conditioners. Fan coil and evaporator coil manufacturing at the International Comfort Products plant in Lewisburg, Tenn., and work done at a distribution center in LaVergne, Tenn., will be moved to other sites, the company said in a statement. The job cuts amount to 31 percent of the work force at the operations.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Aer Lingus Executive
description: The Irish government appointed Tom Mulcahy, left, a former chief executive of Allied Irish Banks, as the chairman of the state-owned airline, Aer Lingus. Mr. Mulcahy, 60, retired last month from his seven-year tenure at Ireland's largest bank. He replaces the longtime chairman Bernie Cahill, who died on Aug. 17 in a boating accident. Aer Lingus has not yet appointed a permanent chief executive to replace Michael Foley, who was fired in June after accusations of sexual harassment were made. The airline reported a loss of 38 million euros ($35 million) for the first half of the year, on revenue of 534 million euros ($486 million).

title: National Briefing | Rockies: Colorado: U.S. Breaks Drug Ring
description: Federal authorities have indicted 55 people, including 37 Colorado residents, on charges of distributing Ecstasy in the state. Among those in custody are three Coloradans -- John D. Sposit, 26, of Lakewood, and Megan M. Schey, 25, and Shawn Sweeney, 20, both of Fort Collins -- accused of supplying Ecstasy to Brittney Chambers, a 16-year-old Boulder girl who died in February after friends gave her the drug as a birthday present. The other 18 people charged were from California. Michael Janofsky (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TABACHNIK, RABBI JOSEPH
description: TABACHNIK-Rabbi Joseph. We mourn with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1946, his first pulpit was in New Haven. In 1963, he was called to the pulpit of West Suburban Temple Har-Zion in Chicago, which he served until he became its Rabbi Emeritus in 1989. He served the RA both as convention chairman and chairman of our Joint Placement Commission. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Miriam, sister, Yetta Segal and children Emanuel, Rena Viner and Naomi Kayne and to all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Vernon H. Kurtz, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: After Remarks On Migrants, An Apology
description: A Suffolk County legislator's comment at a public hearing this week -- that if his town were ''attacked'' by an influx of Hispanic day laborers, ''we'll be out with baseball bats'' -- has touched off a storm of condemnations in this county, where two Mexican workers were beaten with construction tools last fall.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Additional Cuts at Schwab Add to Troubles on Wall St.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOON, ROSE
description: BOON-Rose. On August 30, 2001, after a lengthy illness. Mother of Stephen. Mother-in-law of Barbara and grandmother of Christopher, Jonathan and Timothy. She was the daughter of the late Harold L. Lee of Chinatown's Harold L. Lee & Sons, Inc. Reposing Friday, August 31, 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st St. Services will be held at Pinelawn's Chapel on Saturday, September 1, Pinelawn, Long Island, NY. For information call: 212288-3500.

title: United Way to Continue Aid To Central Jersey Scouts
description: The United Way of Central Jersey has decided to continue financial support for a local Boy Scout council after the scouting group signed a letter agreeing not to discriminate against homosexuals, United Way officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COBB, ELIZABETH BLISS PARKINSON
description: COBB-Elizabeth Bliss Parkinson. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art and Members of its International Council are deeply saddened by the death of their treasured friend and colleague, Eliza Parkinson Cobb. In her almost 70-year close association with the Museum, she gave generously of her time and resources, following in the tradition of her aunt, Lillie P. Bliss, one of the three founders of the Museum in 1929. From her first formal involvement with the Museum, at the invitation of Nelson Rockefeller, as Chairman of the Junior Advisory Committee, to her election as a Trustee in 1939, and her subsequent involvement in the founding of the Museum's International Council on which she served as President from 1957 to 1966, Eliza remained active in the Council for many years thereafter, & was deeply linked to every facet of the Museum's activities. She served as a member of virtually every Museum Trustee committee, participating in curatorial, administrative, financial, educational, and archival areas, chairing the Photography Committee from 1983 to 1987 and the Building Committee from 1968 to 1977, among others. Her deep and abiding intererest in the Museum's staff was well known, and she encouraged its growth with the same vigor and spirit she showed in support of young artists. Eliza was President of the Museum from 1965 to 1968, and remained an active Vice Chairman until 1993 when she became a Life Trustee. We extend our deepest sympathy and affection to her devoted family: her daughter Zaidee Parkinson; her son John Parkinson III and her daughter-in-law Charlotte; her step-children Alex & Sheila Ewing, Ian and Victoria Mackintosh, and John and Bayard Cobb; 5 grandchildren, John Parkinson, Allston Parkinson, Elizabeth ParkinsonWyner, Basil Dufallo and Cornelius Dufallo; and three great-grandchildren. David Rockefeller, Chairman Emeritus Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY Brian Urquhart, Chairman Jo Carole Lauder, President The International Council of The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CARTER, PAULINE
description: CARTER-Pauline. The house has been sold. No more tulips or geraniums. I miss our Saturday lunch, our Sunday dinner, your audience for my piano, your smile, and your laugh. I miss you dearly, Larry.

title: Police Behind the Wheel
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOCCO, ROSEMARY
description: TOCCO-Rosemary. On August 29, 2001. Beloved mother of Alessandra Tocco and Gina and Juan Trujillo. Cherished daughter of Josephine Mirando. Loving grandmother of Robert Palermo and Matthew and Nicholas Trujillo. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St on Friday from 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Saint Jean the Baptiste Church, Lexington Ave at 76 St on Saturday, 10AM.

title: Big Decision On Future Of Polish Oil Is Looming
description: The Polish government is expected to make a preliminary decision in the next few weeks on the sale of a stake in the country's largest oil refinery, a move that could reshape the region's oil industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERBER, DAVID A.
description: FERBER-David A. Beloved brother of Phyllis Ferber, Marilyn Witkin and Roy. Adored uncle of Terri and Gary Shurgin and Helene Witkin and granduncle of Rebecca, Rachel and Jessica. We will keep you in our hearts forever. Services Friday 12 noon ''Parkside'' Chapels Queens Blvd at 66 Av, Forest Hills.

title: Dutch Company Selects Shop for United States
description: The ING Group in Amsterdam, a financial services company, said yesterday that it had named the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, as its agency of record to handle marketing and branding assignments in the United States. Billings were estimated at more than $20 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Aug. 19 about the Fresh Air Fund's Camp Tommy referred incorrectly in some copies to the timing of $2.8 million in donations to the fund by its namesake, the fashion designer Tommy Hilfiger. He donated $1 million from his foundation in 1999 and $1.8 million in July from a celebrity golf tournament that he organized. The total was not all donated in July.

title: Child Sex Case Brings Battle On Admission To Clerics
description: A volunteer Sunday-school teacher charged with sexually abusing two girls in a Massachusetts congregation asked a judge yesterday to throw out a confession that he made to several ministers, who then turned him in to the authorities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAITZ, EDWARD H.
description: BAITZ-Edward H. Born November 30, 1922 in Baltimore, MD. Raised there and in Washington, DC; passed away August 30, 2001 in Los Angeles after a lengthy illness. Beloved husband of Sybil; loving father of Jeff, Rick (Penny) and Robbie (Joe); cherished grandfather of Joshy; dear brother of Esther Zisman, Bea Zuckerman and Micky (Joe) Hamer. Mr Baitz was a retired Executive Vice President of Carnation International and an avid pianist and lover of music and theatre. Services 4PM Sunday, September 2, 2001 at Mount Sinai Memorial Parks-Hollywood Hills, CA. For information, contact Mount Sinai Mortuaries. In lieu of flowers, family prefers donations in his memory to the USC/ Norris Cancer Center, 1441 Eastlake Avenue, Los Angeles, CA 90033-0800.

title: Central Bank In Europe Cuts A Rate Slightly
description: Conceding that Europe has been hit much harder by the American slowdown than it had expected, the European Central Bank changed course today and announced a small reduction in its benchmark interest rate.

title: Sulzer Shares Rise After Settlement Is Approved
description: Shares of the medical device maker Sulzer Medica rose about 19 percent yesterday after a judge gave preliminary approval to the company's $780 million settlement offer for class-action lawsuits over defective hip implants.

title: Metro Business Briefing | Leaving Ziff Davis
description: Wenda Harris Millard, a co-founder of DoubleClick, has resigned from her position as president of Ziff Davis Media's Internet division and chief Internet officer of the parent company, officials said yesterday. She left DoubleClick, a prominent Internet advertising and research firm, to join Ziff Davis, a publisher of high-tech magazines and Web sites, in a surprise move last December. Company executives said Ms. Millard was a close ally of James Dunning, who was removed as Ziff Davis's chief executive this month. Ms. Millard, who had been executive vice president at DoubleClick, had previously been an executive at Family Circle and AdWeek magazines, and the president and group publisher at SRDS, a large media and marketing information company. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Residential Real Estate; Designs Change to Meet a Demand for Larger Apartments
description: It takes conviction to change design plans midstream, when an apartment building's frame is already up, even if the sales office is filled with prospective buyers who want something bigger than the studios or one- and two-bedroom condominiums typically available.

title: Union Chief Opposes Drunken Driving Change
description: The president of New York's largest police union said yesterday that the Giuliani administration risked violating federal law if it pushed forward with proposals to toughen and accelerate the administrative penalties for officers accused of drunken driving.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Calling For An End To Police Chases
description: After the third death in car crashes following police chases in Newark, a community leader yesterday called for an end to all police chases in the city. The Star-Ledger of Newark reported on Wednesday that chase restrictions would be tightened. But one community leader, Salaam Ismial, said that any chase was too dangerous. In the most recent death during a police pursuit, Richard Hall, 64, was killed early Saturday when his car was struck by a vehicle being chased for speeding, said Judy Gagliano, an assistant Essex County prosecutor. Her office is investigating the case. Steve Strunsky (NYT)

title: 2001 United States Open Archive
description: Here is an archive of The Times' complete coverage of the 2001 United States Open.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAKAYAMA, AKIKO (SHIRAI)
description: TAKAYAMA-Akiko (Shirai). We mourn the passing of a wonderful friend, teacher and extraordinarily gifted artist, who earned great international acclaim. Our deepest condolences to her daughters, Suzanna and Cecilia, and all who loved and admired her. Seiko, Robert, Seiji and Hana Newman

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: New Arrest In Frankel Case
description: A Roman Catholic Church official from Italy will face federal wire fraud and conspiracy charges in Connecticut. Prosecutors say he helped Martin Frankel, the Greenwich financier accused of stealing more than $200 million from insurance companies in five states. The official, Msgr. Emilio Colagiovanni, was arrested in Ohio yesterday, the United States attorney's office in Connecticut said. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

title: The Rites and Rights of Dating
description: To the Editor:

title: The 'Death Match' in Albany
description: The budget deadlock in Albany is a tiresome annual ritual during which New York's governor and Legislature refuse to speak, paralyzing the state for months on end. But this year's conflict has become a political death match, with the two sides intent on beating each other into submission. The voters are beginning to pay attention, especially those who worry about a statewide shortfall of school aid.

title: On Tourism, Mexico Now Thinks Green
description: The paving of paradise in Mexico proceeds apace -- but not as fast as before.

title: Baseball and Ex-Umpires Still Stuck Over Phillips
description: The deal was basically done two months ago. Through either the restoration of their jobs or financial packages, 22 former major league umpires would have their status resolved and their lives placed in order. But the agreement remains unsigned. Two years after they lost their jobs, the former umpires continue to wait, receiving neither severance payments nor medical benefits.

title: Yes, Yes, It's the Euro! No, No, Don't Touch!
description: With only four months left before most Europeans are forced to give up their rainbow of marks and francs and pesetas and start using euros, the European Central Bank let people actually see their new money today.

title: Sign-Ups for Foreign Service Test Nearly Double After 10-Year Ebb
description: The State Department announced today that nearly twice as many people had registered to take the Foreign Service exam this year as last year, reversing a 10-year decline, and said the percentage of applicants from minority groups had reached an all-time high.

title: Lawn Boy Battles the Odds On the Field of Dreams
description: Summer Catch

title: Slavery Reparations
description: To the Editor:

title: Army to Move Some Weapons Out of Europe
description: In the latest sign that the military is shifting its focus toward Asia, the Army said today that it planned to move combat weapons currently stored in Europe to the island of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean.

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook column in the arts pages yesterday about the film director Paul Mazursky misstated the title of one of his films. It is ''Faithful,'' not ''Faithless.''

title: Yankees Can Shine or Slide In 2 Series Against Red Sox
description: Nomar Garciaparra could be finished for the season, a season that lasted only 21 games for him. Pedro Martnez is a five-inning pitcher until proved otherwise. Joe Kerrigan has two weeks of managerial experience. David Cone, who went more than three months without winning for the Yankees last season, has been perhaps the most consistent starter for the Boston Red Sox this year. There is no need to recall the team's eight decades of ignominious history.

title: Senator Says Thurmond Isn't 'Keen'
description: Ernest F. Hollings, who despite 34 years of service remains South Carolina's junior senator, told newspaper editors on Wednesday that the state's senior senator, Strom Thurmond, was ''not mentally keen.''

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: TV Mogul Seized, Freed
description: The accused leader of a gang that last week kidnapped the daughter of Silvio Santos, owner of the country's second-largest television network, and set her free on Tuesday after the payment of a $200,000 ransom, returned to the magnate's home in So Paulo and held him hostage for more than seven hours. The incident, which ended with the suspect surrendering to police officers, came a day after police say Fernando Dutra Pinto shot and killed two detectives about to arrest him at the hotel where he and a girlfriend were hiding out. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, ISRAEL, M.D.
description: SIEGEL-Israel, M.D. Departed from this world on August 24th after a heroic battle with cancer. He practiced the science and art of medicine with dedication and humanity in the community of Bayonne, NJ and the Bayonne Hospital. He was recently awarded tributes and high honors for his 50 years in the practice of medicine by the Bayonne Hospital and the community of Bayonne. He also received awards from the State of New Jersey and Hudson County Medical Societies. Following his 40 years in private practice, he served the Bayonne Hospital as Director of Medical Education to the medical staff and nurses and as supervisor of the house physicians and clinic with wisdom, brilliance and dignity. He was also a devoted member of Ahavat Torah Synagogue in Englewood, NJ and was an ardent lover of Israel. He is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Mollie (Danishefsky), by daughter, Dr. Francine Stein, son, Dr. David Siegel, son-in-law, Dr. Aaron Stein, and daughter-in-law, Ruth Siegel, brothers, Murray and Dr. Harold, six grandchildren, Beth, Mikey, Gary, Annie, Michelle and Jackie. His love of humanity and friendship will be emulated and always remembered.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HIRSCHHORN, ROSE
description: HIRSCHHORN-Rose. On this, your birthday, I ponder the prodigious loss to me over the last five years and wonder how I am sustained. I clamber into successive reveries and recall the azure blue of your eyes, your soothing caresses, your gleaming smile and your many other graces, all contributing to the imagery of the poet who wrote: ''a thing of beauty is a joy forever.'' That is how I am sustained. Love, Herbert

title: To Spank or Not?
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Reclaim Their Town After Israelis Withdraw
description: Exhausted but exultant, Palestinians emerged today from curfews and sleepless nights to reclaim neighborhoods in this town south of Jerusalem that had been taken over for more than two days by Israeli tanks and sharpshooters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VERDON, DORIS STROUD
description: VERDON-Doris Stroud, longtime Malverne resident on August 30, 2001. Active in Nassau County Girl Scouts for over thirty years. Beloved wife of the late John A. Loving mother of Anne E., Joan, Patricia Hickey, and John M., and the late Mary. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Brian, Laura, Tom, Julia Marie, and John Aloysius. Family will receive friends Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Avenue, (corner Peninsula Blvd.), Lynbrook. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45 AM Our Lady of Lourdes R.C. Church, Malverne. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to: Girl Scouts Nassau County for Doris Verdon: Friendship Tree, c/o Antoinette Agosta, 110 Ring Road West, Garden City, NY 11530-3296.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOEHM, DOROTHY

title: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Intel Announces 5 Appointments
description: The Intel Corporation, the world's largest chip maker, announced the appointment of a new vice president and four Intel Fellows. The five men were among more than 200 engineers from the Compaq Computer Corporation who moved to Intel this summer, as part of Compaq's decision to phase out its Alpha line of high-performance microprocessors for business computers by 2004 in favor of Intel's line of Itanium chips. Daniel J. Casaletto was named a vice president in the Intel Architecture Group. Joel S. Emer, Tryggve Fossum, William J. Grundmann and P. Geoffrey Lowney were named Intel Fellows, the company's highest technical post. The five men work in the Massachusetts Microprocessor Design Center, which Intel acquired from Compaq as part of the agreement between the two companies, announced June 25. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Mideast Bid to Set Up Talks Between Arafat and Peres
description: JERUSALEM, Aug. 31  With an Israeli-Palestinian truce holding on Jerusalem's southern fringe, diplomatic efforts were made today to see if calm could be extended elsewhere to finally bring the conflict of the last year under control.

title: Artists Who Made Bronze a Household Word
description: Bronze can be trusted. A durable fusion of copper, tin and sometimes zinc, it reproduces every nuance of a sculptor's thought and touch when molded. And it has a warmth that comes from its rich colors, ranging from golden brown to gray, which can be changed naturally or artificially by the process known as patination.

title: ALBUM OF THE WEEK
description: BJORK: -- ''Vespertine'' (Elektra). Like Morrissey and a few other pop singers, Bjork has a strong sense of her own internal melodies and how to apply them to a lyric. Too strong, almost: you can sometimes look at her words, without having heard the songs they accompany, and predict how they'll be sung.

title: In 90's Economy, Middle Class Stayed Put, Analysis Suggests
description: The booming late 1990's appear to have left the middle class in the New York region and California no better off than it was a decade before, an analysis of Census Bureau data suggests. The poor got a little poorer, the rich got a lot richer and the large group in the middle emerged slightly worse off than when the decade began.

title: Who's That Fronting for the Grunts?
description: Rock 'n' roll is an art of emotional close-ups. The din of cranked guitars and the yowl of unfettered voices shove listeners toward ecstasy, a state offering little perspective. Rockers are naturals, unlike movie stars, whose allure relies on the flatness and distance of a screen. So a movie star can't be a rock star, or so the wisdom goes.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: 2 Shot In Street
description: The authorities were looking yesterday for the man who walked up to two men on Wednesday on a street corner in Kingsbridge and shot and killed them. The police said that the victims -- Darrel McQueen, 38, and Shamal Hammond, 27 -- were each shot once in the chest while they stood near the intersection of Webb Avenue and West Kingsbridge Road around 9:30 p.m. They were pronounced dead at St. Barnabas Hospital. Richard Lezin Jones (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Crime Lowest In 30 Years
description: The overall crime rate in New Jersey last year was the lowest in more than 30 years, according to official statistics released yesterday. The crime rate dropped by 4 percent in 2000, the fifth straight annual drop in crime, according to the Crime in New Jersey Uniform Crime Report. The crime rate last year was 31.6 crimes per 1,000 residents. There were 265,840 offenses recorded in 2000, compared with 277,472 in 1999. While there was one more murder statewide last year, for a total of 288, rape and other serious crimes all decreased, the report said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Riot Over City's Fate
description: Violence erupted in the northeastern city of Sabzevar after it was passed over as a possible provincial capital, leaving at least 1 person dead and 37 wounded. The fighting between protesters and security forces followed Parliament's decision to split Khorasan Province into three smaller provinces. Residents of Sabzevar, Khorasan's second most populous city, were infuriated that it was not nominated to become capital of one of the new provinces, which would have entitled it to a higher state budget. Officials promised that Parliament would reconsider before the final decision is made. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Ex-State Dept. Aide Guilty In Conflict-of-Interest Case
description: A retired State Department expert on North Korea pleaded guilty today to improperly using his influence to help secure a government contract for a wealthy New Jersey businessman who had offered him a job and lavished tens of thousands of dollars in gifts on him and his family.

title: Aspen's Winter Kickoff
description: For those who need cooling thoughts, try this: From Nov. 17 to Dec. 1, the St. Regis Aspen Hotel is offering a Winter Kickoff/World Cup package, with nightly rates in a deluxe room of $229. That includes lift tickets for two at Aspen and Snowmass and daily breakfast. A three-night minimum stay is required and taxes and tips are extra. From Nov. 22 to 26, there will be World Cup alpine races at the resort. Information:(888) 454-9005 or www.stregisaspen.com .

title: The Modern Finds Unexpected Benefits in a Space Crunch
description: Museums these days only grow larger. Downsizing flies in the face of the more-is-more cultural mood. So a museum that becomes smaller can stand out, especially one already as prominent as the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Voter Turnout Rose in 2000, But No Lasting Impact Is Seen
description: Grass-roots efforts to increase voter turnout during last year's presidential election were effective, particularly in the fiercely contested states. But such efforts will probably not affect participation in future elections, a report said today.

description: Those who wonder where Russia's affections turned after its American infatuation soured should come to this enclave of farms and Baltic beachfront, a prize patch of German heartland until the Red Army seized it in 1945, and talk to Irina Korobova. They'll get an earful.

title: Borough President Endorsements
description: New York City's borough presidents do not have many official powers, but the position gives its holder an important platform from which to lobby for schools, urban planning and city services for the home borough. Here are our choices in the Democratic primaries in the Bronx, Queens and Brooklyn, where, unlike Manhattan, term limits have required the retirement of the present occupants. Our endorsements for Staten Island races will appear later.

title: Replacements Get New Offer
description: Replacement referees have been offered a four-game guarantee by the National Football League, doubling the two games they were initially assured of being paid for, which means they could be working well into the regular season.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: MP3.Com Gets New Chairman
description: Vivendi Universal S.A. promoted Robin Richards to chairman and chief executive of its online music-sharing site, MP3.com, which Vivendi of France acquired on Tuesday. Mr. Richards, 45, had been president of MP3.com since 1999, Vivendi said. He replaces the MP3.com founder, Michael Robertson, 34, who will become an adviser to Vivendi's chairman and chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier. Vivendi's purchase of MP3.com, based in San Diego, gives the company technology to sell music on the Internet. Mr. Richards, above, was previously managing director of Tickets.com Inc. and founded Lexi International, a teleservices company.

title: White House Unveils New Web Site
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The White House unveiled a new web site today, offering a Spanish-language section, better access for disabled users and an area designed especially for children, who can learn about the First Family's pets while studying history and current events.

title: Technology Briefing | Internet: Auction Case Settled
description: The operators of Internet computer auctions that consistently delivered computers to winning bidders late, or not at all, have agreed to settle charges that their business practices violated federal law, the Federal Trade Commission said. Computers by Us Inc. and its principals -- Jeffrey M. Wesko and Wanda M. Wesko, who are married, and Richard A. Wesko, Jeffrey's brother, all of Baltimore -- sold computers through Internet auctions. Consumers were told that their computers would be delivered after they had placed the winning bid, and had paid various costs. But after people waited extended periods of time to receive their computers, they were not given the option to cancel orders, commission officials said, and requests for refunds were denied. The settlement requires the Weskos to post bonds before engaging in other Web-based marketing operations.

title: Up-and-Down Season For Pawtucket Outfielder
description: In early July, IZZY ALCANTARA was eyeing the International League triple crown. Just a few days later, he was wearing the black hat of a villain.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Norwich: Fraternity Sued
description: The parents of two Colgate students killed in a car crash last year after accepting a ride from a man who had been drinking at his fraternity and later a bar, are suing the fraternity, Delta Kappa Epsilon. The parents of the two women -- Katherine Almeter and Emily Collins, both 18 and of Norwich -- also are suing the driver, who pleaded guilty last week to vehicular manslaughter. Hope Reeves (NYT)

title: REUTERS RECEIVES CLEARANCE TO BUY ASSETS FROM BRIDGE
description: The Reuters Group received regulatory clearance yesterday to buy certain assets of Bridge Information Systems. The Justice Department closed an antitrust investigation that began in May, Reuters said in a statement. Reuters said it planned to complete the purchase in the next few weeks. A bankruptcy judge previously cleared the sale of the assets to Reuters, which is based in Britain, for more than $325 million. The assets include some of Bridge's Internet-based services and commodity pricing products. Bridge, which is closely held, sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Feb. 15, two weeks after some creditors tried to force it to sell assets to satisfy debts.

title: Despite a Rise In Incomes, Spending Slows
description: After keeping the economy growing slowly by stepping up their spending in spring and early summer, consumers tightened their belts a bit in July despite a rise in personal incomes, a government report released yesterday showed.

description: For several weeks now, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been calling the Board of Education a bloated bureaucracy that has more than enough money -- $12 billion by his calculations -- to provide the city's 1.1 million public schoolchildren with everything they need. In doing so, he has steadfastly refused to grant Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy's requests for $120 million that the schools had been counting on.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Ford Unit Profits
description: Ford-Werke, the German unit of Ford Motor, said it posted a profit in the first half after a loss in the period a year earlier, helped by the sales of its redesigned Mondeo car. The company reported a pretax profit of 57 million marks ($26.5 million) after a loss of 97 million marks ($45.1 million) a year earlier. Sales rose 27 percent, to 17.3 billion marks ($8 million), led by an 80 percent increase in sales of the Mondeo.

title: DIAL TO TAKE $9.8 MILLION CHARGE TO CONSOLIDATE PLANTS
description: The Dial Corporation, which put itself up for sale this month, will take a $9.8 million third-quarter pretax charge to consolidate two liquid-soap plants in the United States and merge some operations in Argentina. Dial, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., already plans to record a $200 million tax write-off in the third quarter for the sale of its personal-care division. Earlier this week, the company sold that unit, which includes Sarah Michaels lotions and Freeman cosmetics, to the Hathi Group for an undisclosed amount. Work at a liquid-soap plant in Compton, Calif., will be moved to a Dial plant in Hazleton, Pa., the company said. No details about the Argentina consolidation were given.

title: A Place Excused From Change
description: Between two drowsy villages in southern Vermont -- Poultney on the north and Wells on the south -- lies Lake St. Catherine, the product of tectonic upheavals and a glacier that retreated north 12,000 years ago.

title: IMMUNE RESPONSE TO DROP STUDY OF H.I.V. TREATMENT
description: The Immune Response Corporation said yesterday that it was dropping a study of the Remune H.I.V. treatment after the Agouron Pharmaceuticals unit of Pfizer pulled out of a development partnership last month. The drug was not meeting the study's main goal of reducing levels of H.I.V. in the bloodstream, the company said. Officials said that results of another study of Remune being conducted in Spain appeared promising and that Immune Response would try to continue testing the therapy, aimed at enhancing the immune system to fight H.I.V., on its own. Shares of Immune Response, based in Carlsbad, Calif., fell 9 cents, to $2.09.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Malaysia: Buyer Beware
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad put some of his personal belongings on sale on the Internet, including two desktop computers, a laptop computer, a printer and 10 autographed copies of a book he wrote about the Asian financial crisis. The auction site, Lelong.com.my, carried a cautionary note that the electronic items were ''not operational, only for display.'' A spokesman for the site said, ''The bidding has not really caught on yet.'' Seth Mydans (NYT)

title: New Studies Detail Swiss Ties With Hitler's Germany
description: GENEVA  Some of the Switzerland's largest companies, including Nestle, ignored reports of Nazi atrocities and pursued business-as-usual with neighboring Germany, according to the reports that were issued Thursday as part of a five-year examination of Switzerland's actions in World War II.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Insurer Doubles Profit
description: The world's largest reinsurer, Munich Re, said its net profit doubled in the first half of the year, to 1.3 billion euros ($1.18 billion). A gain of 550 million euros ($500 million) from the revaluation of the company's stake in Allianz and from tax reductions were the main reasons for the larger-than-expected increase. Since Munich Re's gross premium income rose 12 percent, to 17 billion euros ($15.5 billion), the company, which is the second-largest insurance company in Germany, raised its full-year forecast slightly, to 34 billion euros ($31 billion). Petra Kappl (NYT)

description: CSFB Direct, an online brokerage firm, will begin a campaign tomorrow to raise its standing among investors. Spending is estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

Vallone has won the support of the New York Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in his race for mayor, officials announced at the union's annual resort in the Catskills yesterday. In Manhattan, Mark Green said he would support ''as a last resort'' raising taxes to pay for police protection and improving schools.

title: Gabor Peterdi, 85, Artist and Printmaker
description: Gabor Peterdi, a painter and printmaker who worked in New York during the heyday of Abstract Expressionism but who chose to retain ties to nature in his work, died on Aug. 13 at a hospice in Stamford, Conn. He was 85.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Lynching Exhibit Planned
description: After prolonged debate, a deal has been struck to exhibit dozens of photographs of American lynchings next year at the Martin Luther King Jr. National Historic Site in Atlanta. The pictures, owned by two Atlantans, were a sensation when exhibited in New York, but the incendiary nature of the show made it difficult to find a home for the photographs in Atlanta. Emory University will be the host of the exhibition. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: National Briefing | South: Tennessee: Judge Admits Misconduct
description: Admitting ''improper and intemperate conduct'' toward lawyers, Judge Jon McCalla of Federal District Court in Memphis entered a last-minute guilty plea to judicial misconduct charges on Wednesday, as a hearing before fellow judges was about to begin. Among the potential witnesses waiting to testify were Gov. Don Sundquist, who had been openly critical of the judge after recent courtroom run-ins with lawyers and state officials. The judge, who apologized on Wednesday, was placed on a six-month leave of absence and will be required to undergo behavioral counseling.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Changes In Power Pricing Sought
description: A regional energy council for the Pacific Northwest has asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to reconfigure price caps it instituted in June for wholesale electricity in 11 Western states. The caps were intended to hold down the price of power in California this summer, as hot weather increased demand for power. Members of the Northwest Power Planning Council, which includes appointees by the governors of Idaho, Montana, Oregon and Washington, want the Bush administration to change the caps to encourage power generators to sell electricity to the Northwest next winter, when demand there is highest. title: The Moor Shoots Hoops
description: ''But wherefore do not you a mightier way/ Make war upon this bloody tyrant, Time?'' So Shakespeare starts his Sonnet XVI. The distributors of ''O'' sought to defeat Time by simply waiting for a media storm to dissipate. Not much of a stratagem, since ''O,'' the director Tim Blake Nelson's updating of ''Othello'' set in an American prep school, was made so long ago than Mekhi Phifer could still get away with playing a teenager -- well, almost. Filming was completed in 1999, the same year as the shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado, and the picture made Miramax, the distributing company, nervous because it feared the gun violence in ''O'' might incite copycat gunplay.

title: Where the Real Successes Are
description: GRAYING diehard cinephiles may remember Pauline Kael's 1972 review of ''The Godfather,'' extolling Francis Ford Coppola's masterpiece for bringing a ''tragic realism'' to American cinema. Reviews like Ms. Kael's, which dug their fingers deeply into the marrow of a movie to examine its sticky emotional textures, assumed that serious films had the cultural weight and density of literature.

description: An Argentine music retailer, Musimundo, which is controlled by the Exxel Group, a buyout firm, sought protection from creditors after sales dropped 50 percent and financing dried up. description: Rutgers is considering using computer software created to detect plagiarism on term papers and other work by using the Internet. Rutgers said it paid $4,000 for the software and is now testing it. It detects plagiarism by searching Web sites that offer term papers.

title: Bits and Pieces From the Intersection Where a Deaf Man Meets the Hearing
description: Joseph Grigely became deaf in 1967, when he was 10, and like many deaf people (Beethoven, famously) he began communicating with others by having them write down their sides of conversations. Mr. Grigely's interlocutors used scraps of paper, which for years he simply threw away, the paper seeming to him as ephemeral as most of the conversations, until one day during the early 1990's he noticed the scribbled scraps scattered around a table and thought that maybe they ''told a story,'' he said, ''without telling too much.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANE, ROBERT D.
description: LANE-Robert D. Peacefully, after a struggle with cancer, August 28, at 76 years. Survived by his wife Ro, his sons Bob, Rich and Skip, daughters-in-law Pat and Margaret, grandchildren Becca, Mason, Adam and Eric. Former president of Hygrade Printing Corp., he served as president of IBFI/PIA, chairman of the board of the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York (now, Assn. of Graphic Communications) and leader of, or advisor to, many organizations including the YPO and the Junior Achievement Program of New York. He was an active volunteer with SCORE (Svc. Corp. of Ret'd. Execs.) until his death. A memorial service will be held 2:30 PM Friday, August 31 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St.

description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday about a Brazilian company that is one of the world's fastest-growing steel producers misstated the action shown. The worker was using a grinder, not soldering equipment.

title: France Tlcom's News Is Good, and Early
description: France Tlcom found itself having to rush out part of its earnings report for the first half of 2001 a week ahead of schedule today, after a draft version of a computer slide presentation about the results was e-mailed to some analysts on Wednesday.

title: Doubles Defense Dashed
description: Ai Sugiyama will not have a chance to defend the United States Open doubles title after her partner this year, Kim Clijsters, withdrew yesterday because of a strained right quadriceps muscle. She sustained the injury last week at the Pilot Pen in New Haven. Although Clijsters, the fifth-seeded player, won her second-round singles match in 45 minutes against Allison Bradshaw, 6-3, 6-2, she said afterward that she was only playing at 75 percent.

title: Moon Cycles
description: Here are some interesting calendrical facts concerning the phases of the moon. All are cyclical, the most noteworthy being the Metonic cycle that was independently discovered by the Greek astronomer Meton, born about 432 B.C. This is a 19-year cycle. At its end, the phases of the moon begin again on the same dates of the year, or approximately so.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article yesterday about the lockout of National Football League officials referred incorrectly in some copies to the team for which Trace Armstrong plays. It is Oakland, not Miami.

title: Interview Turns Into Grudge Match
description: It was the unscheduled (it seems) undercard to the Nov. 17 main event, when Hasim Rahman is to defend his heavyweight title belts against the man he dethroned, Lennox Lewis.

title: Mets Inject Themselves Into Pennant Chase: Philadelphia's
description: Only one team had a reason to watch the scoreboard at Shea Stadium last night. That team was the Philadelphia Phillies, one game behind the Atlanta Braves in the National League East. The Mets have been unable to join the chase.

description: EARNINGS

title: Kindred Spirit Recreates Earhart Round-Trip
description: When Amelia Earhart took off from a polo field here 73 years ago on Friday to become the first woman to fly solo across the country and back, her first stop was Bellefonte, Pa., where she landed on a grassy airstrip and was treated to a lunch of fried eggs and ham at a nearby farmhouse.

title: Schwab to Eliminate 2,400 Jobs in New Round of Cuts
description: On Wall Street, the week before Labor Day is usually the quietest and most relaxed of the year. But the Charles Schwab Corporation sent a ripple of tension through the brokerage industry yesterday by announcing that it would cut as many as 2,400 more jobs in the next few weeks.

title: State Judge Dismisses Lawsuit Over Spending for Schundler
description: A State Superior Court judge today dismissed a lawsuit by James E. McGreevey, the Democratic nominee for governor, aimed at blocking the Republican National Committee from spending unlimited amounts of money in support of his Republican rival, Bret D. Schundler.

title: They Had Expensive Tastes
description: WHILE there appears to be no official count, it's said that the Forbidden City, the imperial palace in Beijing built by the Ming dynasty in the early 15th century, has 999 buildings and 9,999 rooms, including antechambers. (The number nine signifies longevity in Chinese tradition.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEISLER, NATHAN
description: HEISLER-Nathan on August 30, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Phoebe (nee Grund). Cherished father of Thomas and daughter-inlaw Nan. Adored grandfather of Elayne and Jessica. Dearly beloved brother of Edward and Irving (both deceased), William, Marcus, Alexander, Ruth, and many nieces, nephews and cousins. World War II Veteran, served in the Pacific Theatre. We will miss your cheerful spirit.

title: Connecticut's Speeder-Friendly Crackdown
description: Acme Rent-A-Car is an unassuming operation in a converted gas station on the outskirts of New Haven. But Acme's cars come with a special gadget. They have global positioning satellite equipment that lets the company detect how fast the car is traveling. And Acme requires its customers to pay an additional $150 if they drive 80 miles an hour or more for more than two minutes.

title: A Dollmaker and His Demons in the Big City
description: FURY

title: Rivera Shows His Fire, And Some Old Heat, Too
description: The emotion Mariano Rivera usually represses erupted on the mound at Yankee Stadium yesterday, evident to anyone with a pair of high-powered binoculars. Muttered words and a quick angry glare for the home plate umpire, Rick Reed, over a ball-strike call. An exasperated stare for Toronto's Alberto Castillo after the hitter kept stepping out of the batter's box. The disdainful glance after Castillo struck out.

title: Making a Real Peace in Macedonia
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia -- Lord Robertson, the unflappable secretary-general of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, is rarely at a loss for words. But he was struggling to find them when asked this question at a press conference hailing the Aug. 13 political agreement between ethnic Macedonians and Albanians: "Doesn't the agreement reward violence?"

description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Daewoo Talks
description: General Motors is still negotiating intensely with the creditors of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor but knows nothing about a deadline for reaching an agreement by today, a spokesman for G.M said. ''We haven't got any deadlines from anybody,'' said Rob Leggat, the Asian regional communications official at G.M. South Korea's finance minister, Jin Nyum, said earlier that the talks should wind up by the end of this month or the government would consider other options for Daewoo, where the liabilities exceed $17 billion. Disagreement has reportedly centered on Daewoo's aging plant in the Pupyong district of Inchon, which G.M. has said it does not want in the deal. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Quarter-Point Trim Is Aimed at Reviving Growth : ECB Cuts Rates Modestly
description: FRANKFURT  In a nod of recognition that Europe's economy has slowed more quickly than expected, the European Central Bank delivered a long-awaited quarter-point reduction in interest rates on Thursday, but gave no indication of whether further easings were on the horizon.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Acquittals In Strip Club Case
description: A jury acquitted the final two defendants in Atlanta's sensational Gold Club trial some four weeks after the most important defendants in the case struck plea agreements with federal prosecutors. The two defendants, Michael DiLeonardo and Reginald Burney, a retired Atlanta police officer, declined this month to plead guilty to charges of racketeering related to operations of the strip club. Mr. DiLeonardo, left, had been accused of extorting money from a New York strip club while Mr. Burney was accused of warning Gold Club managers of police inspections in exchange for free food and drink. Kevin Sack (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AVERICK, HAROLD BERNARD
description: AVERICK-Harold Bernard. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Harold Bernard Averick, who expressed his commitment to Jewish and humanitarian causes through the Averick Philanthropic Foundation. His beloved niece, Pamela, helped Harold create the Foundation, and embraced her uncle's devotion to our community through her leadership on behalf of UJA-Federation. Pamela is currently the chair of the Business and Professional Women's Division of our Women's Campaign. A true leader in his community, Harold will be sorely missed by all of those who knew him. We extend our deepest sympathies to Pamela, and to Mr. Averick's entire family. Larry Zicklin, President Morris W. Offit, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Gimelstob Says Fine For Spitting Is Low
description: Michal Tabara spewed his frustration in the direction of Justin Gimelstob Wednesday and will now pay for his spitting.

title: Regulators In Europe Add To Scrutiny Of Microsoft
description: The European Commission broadened its antitrust investigation of Microsoft today, introducing new accusations about the company's bundling of its Windows Media Player, and backing up existing concerns about the company's practices in the server operating systems market with new evidence.

title: The Rites and Rights of Dating
description: The Rites and Rights of Dating

title: Pataki Asks Legislature To Fix Budget
description: Gov. George E. Pataki called today for an emergency session of the State Legislature, demanding that lawmakers meet next Tuesday to fix what he called glaring holes in the no-frills budget that was passed earlier this month.

title: U.S. Urges High Court to Reject Microsoft Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  The government today urged the Supreme Court to reject a request by the Microsoft Corporation ( news/quote ) to consider throwing out the findings that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly in the software industry.

title: MAN WINS $55 MILLION VERDICT AGAINST KELLY-MOORE PAINT
description: Kelly-Moore Paint, the largest privately owned paint manufacturer, has been ordered to pay a Texas man and his family $55.5 million after a jury found that his cancer was caused by asbestos in company products. The man, Alfredo Hernandez Sr., 47, developed asbestos-related lung disease last year after working as a contractor in California in the 1970's using a Kelly-Moore joint compound that contained asbestos, said his lawyer, Rick Nemeroff of Dallas. Mr. Hernandez sued the company in El Paso County Court. The verdict included $15 million in punitive damages, Mr. Nemeroff said. Officials of Kelly-Moore, which is based in San Carlos, Calif., could not immediately be reached for comment.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Bloomberg Hits His Opponent On Petitions
description: During most of the Republican primary campaign for mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg has treated his opponent, Herman Badillo, as a nuisance who is best left ignored. Mr. Badillo has kept a limited public schedule, has had trouble in raising money and has rarely stolen the spotlight from his big-name rival.

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Media Bid Likely
description: The Irish media conglomerate Independent News and Media is expected to revive its attempt to buy Fairfax, Australia's main newspaper group, once changes to Australia's regulations on foreign ownership of media companies are completed. A group led by Independent failed in an earlier bid for Fairfax, which has a market capitalization of 3 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion). Any new attempt would go through Independent's 41 percent stake in APN News and Media or its Wilson & Horton subsidiary.

title: Citigroup Severs Ties to Brokers
description: Citigroup ( news/quote ) said yesterday that it had severed ties with 3,622 independent brokers who had arranged loans for Associates First Capital ( news/quote ), a consumer finance company acquired by Citigroup that has been accused of predatory lending practices. The brokers were dropped from the company's list of approved agents for a variety of reasons, said a memorandum to employees from Robert Willumstad, head of the company's consumer group. Some were not properly licensed or had not brought in enough business; others had failed to agree to a Citigroup ethics code. About 1,000 of the brokers were suspended in April, a Citigroup spokeswoman said. The cuts amount to about 64 percent of the brokers affiliated with Associates, a leading lender of mortgages to customers who do not qualify for standard loans.  (Bloomberg News)
