title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRINCE, NANCY GEORGETTE
description: PRINCE-Nancy Georgette. Age 60. Died on Tuesday, August 28, 2001 after a heroic fight with Leukemia. A longtime Manhattan and Westport CT. resident. Nancy is survived by her devoted friend and companion Pamela Perry, her loving family, sister Margot Rose and cousin Christine Jewel; and three beloved dogs, Buddy, Tyler and Hattie and many wonderful friends. A graduate of Boston University, she was an accomplished chef. Her parties always were enlivened by her irrepressible joie de vivre and panache. She was always open for a good laugh as well as a good meal. The family will receive friends Tuesday, September 4 from 5-8pm and Wednesday 6-9pm at Raymond Funeral Home, Norwalk, CT. 203847-7291. A memorial service will be held at 7:30pm on Wednesday, September 5. If anyone wishes, donations can be made in her memory to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society, Fairfield County, CT. Chapter, 25 Third Street, Stamford, CT. 06905

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHMAN, JESSE
description: ROTHMAN-Jesse. Beloved husband of Lillian. Devoted father of John and Joanne, Warren, Anne Rothman-Hicks and Kenneth. Cherished grandfather of Brendan, Zachary, Alice, Jacob, David, and Jennifer. Services Sunday, 12 noon, ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Metro Business Briefing | New On The Development Board
description: Alan B. Friedberg, a real estate investor and developer, was appointed to the board of the city's Economic Development Corporation this month by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Friedberg, who is also a commissioner of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, developed the Sutton Hotel on East 56th Street, as well as two apartment towers: the Brevard, on East 54th Street, and Nevada Tower, at 70th Street and Broadway. He is planning a seven-story apartment house for students and teachers at city and state colleges on 24th Street.

title: The Therapeutic Value of Getting Close to the Ground
description: Showtime's ''Back to the Secret Garden'' wants very badly to be magical. It settles for being sensible, restrained, uncomplicated and instructive. (Adults are always saying things like ''Trust in your own conscience'' and ''It's what's in your heart that matters.'') Considered alone, the film, which has its premiere on Sunday night at 8, is a perfectly respectable addition to Showtime's Original Pictures for All Ages series. Compared with the film versions of Frances Hodgson Burnett's 1911 novel ''The Secret Garden,'' to which it aspires to be a sequel of sorts, it misses the point.

title: The Big City; If He Is 14, Don't Blame New Yorkers
description: NEW YORK, we have a problem. We have given a hero's parade to a kid who looks more and more like the most famous fraud in the history of youth sports. The key to the city has been presented by our mayor to a Little Leaguer who may be almost old enough to use the key to a car.

title: With the Valedictorians in Life's Graduation Class
description: When I tell my musician-friends that I spent a recent summer afternoon with the violinist Fritz Kreisler, they tend to look at me a bit quizzically. It's not that they don't share my admiration for Kreisler's honeyed tone on the instrument and his refined interpretations. What seems odd to them is simply that I've been visiting a man who's been dead since 1962.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about President Bush's vow to increase military and education spending referred incorrectly in some copies to an effort to make him declare that the Social Security surplus might have to be used. A letter in which Democratic leaders asked Mr. Bush to specify how he would pay for his proposals appeared to be such an effort. A statement from a White House spokesman that Mr. Bush had scheduled a meeting with Democratic leaders was not.

title: The Importance Of the Box
description: ''People who put up money for movies now are completely star-driven,'' the director Michael Steinberg said. ''That's their insurance. Even if you have the next Julia Stiles and a great script, they balk. They say: 'What if the movie stinks? Who do I put on the video box?' ''

title: Snug in Three Walls Amid Mist and Mystery
description: One of the advantages of lean-to's is that they can accommodate large and unruly groups, which pretty much describes us. We were seven in all. Two hiked in to the campsite just to be sociable and have dinner. The ones who stayed overnight were three adults, a 16-year-old and a 10-year-old. That's not counting the two dogs, a wheezy Pomeranian and an untrained 7-month-old Labrador retriever mix.

title: 2 Groups Try to Involve Public In Internet Address Policy
description: In an effort to increase public participation in policy decisions regarding the Internet's address system, two groups issued reports this week with recommendations on how best to involve individuals in policy matters.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Contract For Firefighters
description: After working without a contract for more than two years, Boston firefighters have reached tentative agreement with the city on a four-year pact, one that may make the mayor's public life a little easier. Picketing firefighters have been turning up at most of Mayor Thomas M. Menino's public appearances. At a news conference, the mayor and union officials said they were pleased with the contract, which had been held up by disagreements over salaries, injury leave and shift swapping. No details of the agreement were made available. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Stocks Decline
description: The Dow Jones industrial average fell for a fourth day yesterday, to 9,919.58, a drop of 503.59 points, 4.8 percent, for the week. It was the first close below 10,000 since April. Business Day, Page C1.

description: FRANKFURT  The lights dimmed in Frankfurt's Opera, the curtains parted and Europeans caught their first glimpse of a potentially powerful new symbol.

description: Holdup movies have been getting big play in theaters recently, but at home you can enjoy such vintage heist films on video as ''Dog Day Afternoon'' with Al Pacino, below.

title: Rancor and Powell's Absence Cloud Racism Parley
description: The presidents flew into this port city from across the continent today, joining 6,000 delegates from around the world to deplore prejudice, ethnic hatreds and intolerance. But they were all overshadowed by the one man who was not here.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Citarella starts out with an unfair advantage. Most new restaurants compete frantically to get first call on the best ingredients. But Citarella has had its hands on prime material for years. It's simply a matter of bringing it over from the store.

title: Few Choose Legal Havens to Abandon Babies
description: Jamie Marie Smith was 19 when she gave birth on the floor of her trailer home here last December, hours after leaving her night-shift job. Her 2-year-old son was the only one with her.

title: 2-Year-Olds Use Final Weekend to Prepare Themselves for Star Turns
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 30 — The strapping Point Given looked invincible circling the Saratoga track in the Travers Stakes, as did Flute, leading every step of the way in the Alabama as she rumbled her way to the top of the 3-year-old filly division. Now, heading into the final weekend at Saratoga, the focus returns to what distinguishes the meet here: the baby races, especially the stakes sprints for 2-year-olds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALLER, TILDA
description: GALLER-Tilda. On August 28, 2001. Beloved daughter and sister. She will be missed by her dear friends. Service at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave (at 91 St), NYC Sunday, 11AM. Interment to follow immediately at Riverside Cemetery, Saddle Brook, N.J.

title: Deep in Debt, Swissair to Cut Back
description: The Swissair Group closed the book today on its ambitions to become a major airline competitor, saying it would sell big stakes in two profitable units to reduce its $9 billion debt. It will also eliminate 1,250 jobs to cut costs.

title: Two Big European Retailers Contrast in Strategy and Profit
description: One is pursuing a global brand, as recognizable to consumers in Belgium as Brazil, while the other operates a variety of stores known only to local customers. That is proving to be the difference between Carrefour and Ahold, two large European retailers that reported first-half profits today.

description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention added its voice today to the growing alarm over China's rapidly escalating H.I.V. epidemic, and the United States agency said that China had asked for its help in addressing the problem.

title: Variety's Editor to Return to Job After Suspension for Remarks
description: Peter Bart, the outspoken and irascible editor in chief of Variety, will return to his post on Sept. 10, ending a 21-day suspension that came after derogatory comments about blacks, women and gays were attributed to him in a magazine article.

title: CITIGROUP DROPS 3,622 INDEPENDENT BROKERS
description: Citigroup said yesterday that it had severed ties with 3,622 independent brokers who had arranged loans for Associates First Capital, a consumer finance company acquired by Citigroup that has been accused of predatory lending practices. The brokers were dropped from the company's list of approved agents for a variety of reasons, said a memorandum to employees from Robert Willumstad, head of the company's consumer group. Some were not properly licensed or had not brought in enough business; others had failed to agree to a Citigroup ethics code. About 1,000 of the brokers were suspended in April, a Citigroup spokeswoman said. The cuts amount to about 64 percent of the brokers affiliated with Associates, a leading lender of mortgages to customers who do not qualify for standard loans.

description: REAL men may not eat quiche, but will they eat yogurt?

title: Agassi Puts the Brakes on a Chilean's Magic Ride
description: Against all logic, Nicolas Massu was creating shots usually concocted on driveways with imaginary nets and invisible opponents, not on center court against a superstar like Andre Agassi.

title: G.E. AND QWEST FORM JOINT VENTURE FOR HOSPITAL IMAGING
description: General Electric and Qwest Communications International have formed a joint venture that will let hospitals store and retrieve digital images using a high-speed fiber optic network. The agreement, for three years, is expected to generate $250 million in revenue, the companies said. GE Medical Systems is the biggest maker of medical imaging machines. Qwest, a phone service provider, runs a 113,000-mile fiber optic network. GE Medical Systems is based in Waukesha, Wis., and has about $8 billion in annual revenue.

title: Alix Williamson, 85, Publicist For Noted Singers and Musicians
description: Alix Williamson, a classical music publicist who helped promote and shape the careers of legendary musicians from Lotte Lehmann to the Trapp Family Singers, died on Sunday at her home in New York. She was 85.

title: For the Giants' Defense, It's a Game That Counts
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel and Baltimore Ravens Coach Brian Billick have been good friends for several years. When the two coaches settled into their current jobs a few seasons ago, they looked ahead at the 2001 schedule and realized they would be playing each other in the final game of each team's preseason.

title: In a District of Quiet Streets, Louima Case Continues to Have a Particular Resonance
description: A note of concern seems to linger just below the surface with residents in the 45th Council District in Brooklyn, which includes Flatbush and East Flatbush. It was here, in an area of many quiet streets and middle-class homes, that Abner Louima was taken into custody before being tortured by the police more than four years ago, and that searing crime is on the minds of many voters as the Sept. 11 primary approaches.

title: Court Backs Florida Ban On Adoption By Gays
description: A Florida judge yesterday upheld a state law banning gays from adopting children, the first federal court ruling on the issue.

title: Factory Jobs Move Overseas As Japan's Troubles Deepen
description: A generation ago, when America's manufacturing heartland was declining into a Rust Belt, Japan's leaders vowed to avoid the same fate as their own economy matured. Now, the global technology bust has sent manufacturing here into a precipitous decline that seems to be leading the chronically sick economy into another recession.

title: A Victim of Wide Economic Fears, Dow Falls Below 10,000
description: It has been a long, cold summer on Wall Street. Stock prices, which have staggered since June, fell yesterday, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average below 10,000 for the first time since April. The Dow and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index both lost 1.70 percent, while the Nasdaq composite index dropped 2.79 percent.

title: Travel Agents Protest Cut in Their Fees by Airlines
description: Many travel agents around the country stopped doing business for two hours yesterday to protest the recent decision by airlines to cut sharply the fees they pay travel agents for selling tickets.

title: Little League To Accept Dominicans' Ruling on Age
description: Officials in the Dominican Republic may rule today on the age of Danny Almonte, the ace pitcher for the Rolando Paulino All-Stars of the Bronx, and Little League officials said yesterday that they would accept that decision, whatever it was.

title: Man Denies Digital Piracy In First Case Under '98 Act
description: Dmitri Sklyarov, the first person to be indicted under a 1998 digital copyright law, pleaded not guilty yesterday in federal court in San Jose, Calif., to four counts of trafficking in illegal technology and one count of conspiracy.

If coverage trends continue, the report said, the number of uninsured women will surpass the number of uninsured men by 2005.

title: New Coach, New Passer, Good Start For Knights
description: It was by no means pretty, but Greg Schiano got his coaching career at Rutgers off to a good start tonight with a 31-15 victory over Buffalo at U.B. Stadium.

description: The University of Miami's Joaquin Gonzalez laughs about the time that he and several teammates, including the all-American strong safety Edward Reed, sneaked into Bryant McKinnie's room at 5:30 a.m. and jumped on him as he slept.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Accused In Arson Attempt
description: A former employee at a Midtown nightclub poured gasoline on the club's entrance early yesterday morning but was chased away by club patrons, the police said. The former employee, Steve Rivera, 22, was charged with attempted arson in the incident at the Edelweiss nightclub, on 11th Avenue near 43rd Street, the police said.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Victory For Lottery Winners
description: The Maine couple who won $41.5 million in the Powerball lottery last week can cash the check, now that a legal challenge has been dropped. Four co-workers of one winner, Pat Wales, had filed a suit asserting that 19 people, including Ms. Wales, had contributed to an office pool and agreed to share any winnings. They withdrew the suit after a judge said they could not win. Ms. Wales said she bought the winning ticket separately. In Delaware, the final winners in the $294.8 million drawing stepped forward. Kathleen Kearny, a teacher from Hockessin, Del., and her brother Michael J. Kearny, a Pittsburgh-area lawyer, will share $41.5 million. Julie Flaherty (NYT)

title: Hitting the Big Show With the Other Tennis Mac
description: THIS is the tentative week, the loosey-goosey week, Patrick McEnroe's favorite time at the United States Open. It's before the grand opera of Week Two -- before the losers bite the dust, ''when it's funkier, the real tennis fans are out, when there's action, there's buzz,'' he says.

title: Technology Briefing | Earnings: Alloy Posts 2nd-Quarter Loss
description: Alloy Online Inc., a New York Internet company and retailer focused on the teenage market, announced pro forma losses of $2.3 million, or 10 cents a share, yesterday for its fiscal second quarter, ended on July 31. Including good-will amortization, stock-based compensation and other charges, the company lost $11.3 million, or 51 cents a share. Revenue for the second quarter was $28.7 million, up from $12.3 million in the second quarter of fiscal 2000. The company, which sells merchandise over the Web and through catalogs, revised its financial estimates upward for the full fiscal year, expecting revenue of $157 million to $160 million. Susan Stellin (NYT)

description: The four major Democratic candidates for mayor stood together outside City Hall yesterday and accused Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of forcing $150 million in spending cuts on the city's public schools.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: South Korea: Sex Offenders' Names Disclosed
description: The names of 169 convicted sex offenders were posted at a government building in Seoul and on a government Web site. The site, however, was shut down most of the day after thousands of people tried to access it at the same time. Human rights organizations said the posting stigmatized those who had already been punished. The government's commission on youth protection said, however, that the publicity was needed to protect teenagers and children. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: 'Controlled' Blaze That Wasn't Haunts Firefighters in California
description: With a reasonable assurance that Weaverville the only town of any real size in the only county in California without a single stoplight -- was not going to burn to the ground, people here today got back to debating one force of nature that seems to defy human manipulation -- wildfire.

title: New Delhi Journal; Modern India Gazes in Wonder at Its Gaudy Past

title: TREATIES MAY CURB FARMERS' SUBSIDIES

title: Whatever It Is, It's Awfully Hungry
description: ''Jeepers Creepers,'' a cannier-than-average teen horror movie, makes you shudder in its early scenes, then turns into a noisy carnival attraction once its designated monster finally materializes. The movie takes its title from the jaunty 1930's love song by Johnny Mercer and Harry Warren. Mercer, a genius at setting rurally flavored American slang into humorous rhymes, would probably have appreciated the movie's diabolical application of his lyric, especially the line ''Jeepers creepers, where'd you get those eyes?'' The song is heard several times in the movie (usually as a swing recording but once in rock form) and is invariably a prelude to catastrophe.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Atlantic City: Fireworks Company Penalized
description: Fire officials have fined a Long Island fireworks company $13,800 for a Fourth of July display that damaged a barge but injured no one. Bay Fireworks of Huntington Station, N.Y., was fined for improperly leaving explosives and other debris on the barge during a 30-minute display this year. Fire investigators also cited the company for failing to provide technicians with life jackets. Company officials said they did nothing wrong. During the fire and explosion that followed, a car-size chunk of steel was torn from the barge and flew over a state police boat. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: Squandering Our Technological Future
description: Two years ago I pledged to donate $150 million to create a center for biomedical engineering and science at Stanford. Now Congress and the president are thwarting part of the intended purpose of this center by supporting restrictions on stem cell research and cloning. While only a portion of Stanford's plans involve stem cells, I believe research that uses them is vital to the future of medicine. I am therefore suspending $60 million of my remaining pledge pending the outcome of ongoing political deliberations.

title: Movie Magic: Feasting and Staying Slim
description: The most eye-catching steel-handling in a film this summer takes place not in the latest Jet Li spectacular or even ''Rush Hour 2,'' in which Jackie Chan makes the blade sing. The finest work with a knife is by Hector Elizondo -- or rather his stunt double -- over the carving board in the forgettable romantic farce ''Tortilla Soup.'' Mr. Elizondo is Martin, an enormously talented chef who whips up sumptuous, camera-ready feasts for his three adult daughters. The feat here, which no one bothers to mention, is that the widowed Martin cooks enough to feed the entire audience, and yet his daughters have retained their willowy figures.

title: Greenspan Says Market Swings Pose Challenge to the Fed
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31  This may be the information age, but policymakers do not have all the information they need to make good decisions about monetary matters, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan said today.

title: World Briefing | Asia/Pacific: Papua New Guinea: Bougainville Peace Signed
description: The government signed a peace agreement with separatists in its easternmost island province, Bougainville, formally ending a decade of war that has left an estimated 20,000 people dead. The agreement, which accords broad autonomy to the mineral-rich province and holds out the possibility of future independence, needs to be approved by two thirds of the Parliament of Papua New Guinea. Seth Mydans (NYT)
